original: anuppattisaññitaṃ vimuccanaṃ, ayaṃ vikkhambhanavimutti nāma. Yaṃ catunnaṃ ariyamaggānaṃ🔽bhāvitattā taṃtaṃmaggavato ariyassa santāne yathārahaṃ “diṭṭhigatānaṃ pahānāyā”tiādinā🔽nayena vuttassa samudayapakkhiyassa kilesagaṇassa puna accantaṃ appavattibhāvena🔽samucchedappahānavasena vimuccanaṃ, ayaṃ samucchedavimutti nāma. Yaṃ pana phalakkhaṇe🔽paṭippassaddhattaṃ kilesānaṃ, ayaṃ paṭippassaddhivimutti nāma. Sabbasaṅkhatanissaṭattā🔽pana sabbasaṅkhāravimuttaṃ nibbānaṃ, ayaṃ nissaraṇavimutti nāma. Idha pana bhagavato🔽nibbānārammaṇā phalavimutti adhippetā. Tena vuttaṃ – “vimuttisukhapaṭisaṃvedīti vimuttisukhaṃ
analyzed: an uppatti saññitam vimuccanam ayam vikkhambhana vimutti nāma yam catunnam ariya maggānam  bhāvita ttā taṃ taṃ maggavataḥ ariyassa santāne yathāraham diṭṭhi gatānam pahānāya iti ādinā  nayena vuttassa samudaya pakkhiyassa kilesa gaṇassa puna accantam appavatti bhāvena  samuccheda pahāna vasena vimuccanam ayam samuccheda vimutti nāma yam pana phala kkhaṇe  kilesānam ayam paṭippassaddhivimutti nāma sabba saṅkhata nissaṭa ttā  pana sabba saṅkhāra vimuttam nibbānam ayam nissaraṇa vimutti nāma idha pana bhagavataḥ  nibbāna ārammaṇā phala vimutti adhippetā tena vuttam vimutti sukha paṭisaṃvedī iti vimutti sukham
translated: and the liberation consisting in the arising of the path is called the liberation by suppression. The liberation consisting in the destruction of the defilements that are to be abandoned by each of the four paths in the mental continuity of the noble person who has developed the four paths is called the liberation by eradication. The liberation consisting in the state of peace of the defilements at the moment of fruition is called the liberation by tranquilization. But the Nibbāna that is free from all formations because it is devoid of all formations is called the liberation by renunciation. Here, however, the Blessed One’s fruition attainment of liberation with Nibbāna as its object is intended. Therefore it is said: “experiencing the bliss of liberation” .🔽🔽

original: phalasamāpattisukhaṃ paṭisaṃvediyamāno nisinno hotīti attho”ti.
analyzed: phala samāpatti sukham paṭisaṃvediyamānaḥ nisinnaḥ hoti iti attho ti
translated: and the liberation consisting in the arising of the path is called the liberation by suppression. The liberation consisting in the abandoning of the defilements by the severance of their roots is called the liberation by eradication. The liberation consisting in the subsiding of the defilements at the moment of fruition is called the liberation by tranquilization. And the Nibbāna element, which is free from all formations, is called the liberation by renunciation. But here the Blessed One’s fruition attainment of liberation, which has Nibbāna as its object, is intended. Hence it is said: “Experiencing the bliss of liberation”: experiencing the bliss of liberation, the bliss of fruition attainment. The meaning is that he sat experiencing that.

original: Vimuttīti ca upakkilesehi paṭippassaddhivasena cittassa vimuttabhāvo, cittameva vā
analyzed: vimutti iti ca upakkilesehi paṭippassaddhi vasena cittassa vimutta bhāvaḥ cittam eva vā
translated: And “liberation” is the liberated state of the mind by the subsiding of the defilements, or the mind itself should be understood as liberated in that way.

original: tathā vimuttaṃ veditabbaṃ, tāya vimuttiyā jātaṃ sampayuttaṃ vā sukhaṃ vimuttisukhaṃ.🔽“Yāyaṃ, bhante, upekkhā sante sukhe vuttā bhagavatā”ti vacanato upekkhāpi cettha
analyzed: tathā vimuttam veditabbam tāya vimuttiyā jātam sampayuttam vā sukham vimutti sukham  yā ayam bhante upekkhā sante sukhe vuttā bhagavatā ati vacanato upekkhā api ca ittha
translated: Or the pleasure born of that liberation or associated with it is “the pleasure of liberation.”🔽And equanimity too should be understood as pleasure here, since it is said: “That equanimity, venerable sir, which the Blessed One spoke of, is pleasure” .

original: sukhamicceva veditabbā. Tathā ca vuttaṃ sammohavinodaniyaṃ “upekkhā pana santattā,
analyzed: sukham iccā iva veditabbā tathā ca vuttam sammoha vinodaniyam upekkhā pana santattā
translated: And it is said: “But equanimity is called pleasure🔽Because it is peaceful” .

original: sukhamicceva bhāsitā”ti. Bhagavā hi catutthajjhānikaṃ arahattasamāpattiṃ samāpajjati,🔽na itaraṃ. Atha vā “tesaṃ vūpasamo sukho”tiādīsu yathā saṅkhāradukkhūpasamo sukhoti
analyzed: sukham icca iva bhāsitā ati bhagavā hi catuttha jjhānikam arahatta samāpattim samāpajjati  na itaram atha vā tesam vūpasamo sukho ti ādīsu yathā saṅkhāra dukkha upasamaḥ sukho ti
translated: For the Blessed One enters upon the fruition attainment of Arahantship, which is the fourth jhāna,🔽not any other.

original: vuccati, evaṃ sakalakilesadukkhūpasamabhāvato aggaphale labbhamānā paṭippassaddhivimutti
analyzed: vuccati evam sakala kilesa dukkha upasama bhāvataḥ agga phale labbhamānā paṭippassaddhi vimutti
translated: Or just as the subsiding of the pain faculty is called “pleasure” in such passages as “The stilling of all formations, the relinquishing of all acquisitions, the destruction of craving, dispassion, cessation, Nibbāna—this is the best, namely, the stilling of all formations” ,

original: eva idha sukhanti veditabbā. Tayidaṃ vimuttisukhaṃ maggavīthiyaṃ kālantareti phalacittassa
analyzed: eva idha sukhanti veditabbā tayidam vimutti sukham magga vīthiyam kāla antareti phala cittassa
translated: so too the subsiding of the suffering of the defilements, which is found in the supreme fruit of Arahantship, should be understood as the “pleasure of liberation” here.🔽And that pleasure of liberation is “in the interval” in the course of the path consciousnesses.

original: pavattivibhāgena duvidhaṃ hoti. Ekekassa hi ariyamaggassa anantarā tassa tasseva
analyzed: pavatti vibhāgena duvidham hoti ekekassa hi ariya maggassa anantarā tassa tassa iva
translated: It is twofold as classed according to occurrence. For after each noble path,

original: vipākabhūtāni nibbānārammaṇāni tīṇi dve vā phalacittāni uppajjanti anantaravipākattā
analyzed: vipāka bhūtāni nibbāna ārammaṇāni tīṇi dve vā phala cittāni uppajjanti anantara vipāka ttā
translated: three or two resultant consciousnesses, which are its fruits and have Nibbāna as their object, arise in succession.🔽For the supramundane profitable has next-to-last resultant fruit ,

original: lokuttarakusalānaṃ. Yasmiñhi javanavāre ariyamaggo uppajjati, tattha yadā dve anulomāni,
analyzed: lokuttara kusalānam yasmin hi javana vāre ariya maggo uppajjati tattha yadā dve anulomāni
translated: and in the impulsions of the path there are two conformings,

original: tadā tatiyaṃ gotrabhu, catutthaṃ maggacittaṃ, tato paraṃ tīṇi phalacittāni honti.🔽Yadā pana tīṇi anulomāni, tadā catutthaṃ gotrabhu, pañcamaṃ maggacittaṃ, tato paraṃ
analyzed: tadā tatiyam gotrabhu catuttham magga cittam tato param tīṇi phala cittāni honti  yadā pana tīṇi anulomāni tadā catuttham gotra bhu pañcamam magga cittam tatas param
translated: one change-of-lineage, one path consciousness, and then three fruits.🔽But when there are three conformings, then there is one change-of-lineage, one path consciousness, and then two fruits.

original: dve phalacittāni honti. Evaṃ catutthaṃ pañcamaṃ appanāvasena pavattati, na tato paraṃ🔽bhavaṅgassa āsannattā. Keci pana “chaṭṭhampi cittaṃ appetī”ti vadanti, taṃ aṭṭhakathāsu
analyzed: dve phala cittāni honti evam catuttham pañcamam appanā vasena pavattati na tatas param  bhavaṅgassa āsanna ttā keci pana chaṭṭham pi cittam appeti iti vadanti tam aṭṭhakathāsu
translated: Thus the fourth and fifth occur as jhānas, but not the sixth,

original: paṭikkhittaṃ. Evaṃ maggavīthiyaṃ phalaṃ veditabbaṃ. Kālantare phalaṃ pana phalasamāpattivasena
analyzed: paṭikkhittam evam magga vīthiyam phalam veditabbam kāla antare phalam pana phala samāpatti vasena
translated: because the life-continuum is near. But some say that the sixth also occurs as jhāna. That is rejected in the commentaries. This is how the fruit should be understood in the path’s occurrence. But the fruit in the interval is

original: pavattaṃ, nirodhā vuṭṭhahantassa uppajjamānañca eteneva saṅgahitaṃ. Sā panāyaṃ phalasamāpatti
analyzed: pavattam nirodhā vuṭṭhahantassa uppajjamānam ca etena iva saṅgahitam sā pana ayam phala samāpatti
translated: and that occurring in emergence from cessation is included by this too. This attainment of fruition should be regarded as follows:

original: atthato lokuttarakusalānaṃ vipākabhūtā nibbānārammaṇā appanāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: atthatas lokuttara kusalānam vipāka bhūtā nibbāna ārammaṇā appanā ati daṭṭhabbā
translated: in meaning it is the supramundane profitable’s result, and in respect of object it has Nibbāna as object, and in respect of absorption it is absorption.

original: Ke taṃ samāpajjanti, ke na samāpajjantīti? Sabbepi puthujjanā na samāpajjanti anadhigatattā.
analyzed: ke tam samāpajjanti ke na samāpajjanti iti sabbe pi puthujjanāḥ na samāpajjanti anadhigata ttā
translated: Who attain it and who do not? None of the ordinary men attain it because they have not acquired it.

original: Tathā heṭṭhimā ariyā uparimaṃ, uparimāpi ariyā heṭṭhimaṃ na samāpajjantiyeva puggalantarabhāvūpagamanena🔽paṭippassaddhabhāvato. Attano eva phalaṃ te te ariyā samāpajjanti. Keci pana “sotāpannasakadāgāmino
analyzed: tathā heṭṭhimāḥ ariyāḥ uparimam uparimā api ariyāḥ heṭṭhimam na samāpajjantiyā iva puggala antara bhāva upagamanena  paṭippassaddha bhāvataḥ attanaḥ eva phalam te te ariyā samāpajjanti keci pana sotāpanna sakadāgāmino
translated: Nor do the lower kinds of noble persons attain the higher kinds, nor do the higher kinds attain the lower kinds, because of the cessation of the state of being a person by their attaining.🔽But the noble persons attain their own respective fruition.

original: phalasamāpattiṃ na samāpajjanti, uparimā dveyeva samāpajjanti samādhismiṃ paripūrakāribhāvato”ti
analyzed: phala samāpattim na samāpajjanti uparimāḥ samāpajjanti samādhismim
translated: Some say that stream-enterers and once-returners do not attain the attainment of fruition, and that only the two, the non-returner and the Arahant, attain it, because they perfect concentration.

original: vadanti. Taṃ akāraṇaṃ puthujjanassāpi attanā paṭiladdhalokiyasamādhisamāpajjanato.
analyzed: vadanti tam akāraṇam puthujjanassa api attanā paṭiladdha lokiya samādhi samāpajjanato
translated: But that is no reason, because even the ordinary man attains the mundane concentration that he has acquired.

original: Kiṃ vā ettha kāraṇacintāya? Vuttañhetaṃ paṭisambhidāyaṃ “katamā dasa saṅkhārupekkhā
analyzed: kim vā ettha kāraṇa cintāya vuttam ha etam paṭisambhidā ayam katamā dasa saṅkhārupekkhā
translated: Or what need is there to think of reasons here? For this is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “What is equanimity about formations?

original: vipassanāvasena uppajjanti, katame dasa gotrabhudhammā vipassanāvasena uppajjantī”ti
analyzed: vipassanā vasena uppajjanti katame dasa gotrabhu dhammā vipassanā vasena uppajjanti iti
translated: Or what need is there to think of reasons here? For this is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “What are the ten equalities of equanimity about formations that arise by way of insight? What are the ten states of change-of-lineage that arise by way of insight?”

original: imesaṃ pañhānaṃ vissajjane sotāpattiphalasamāpattatthāya sakadāgāmiphalasamāpattatthāyāti🔽tesampi ariyānaṃ phalasamāpattisamāpajjanaṃ vuttaṃ. Tasmā sabbepi ariyā yathāsakaṃ
analyzed: imesam pañhānam vissajjane sotāpatti phala samāpatta tthāya sakadāgāmi phala samāpatta tthāya ati  tesam pi ariyānam phala samāpatti samāpajjanam vuttam tasmā sabbe pi ariyāḥ yathāsakam
translated: In the answer to these questions it is said that the noble persons enter upon the attainment of the fruit of stream-entry and the attainment of the fruit of once-return,🔽and the noble persons’ entering upon the attainment of the fruits is also said in the answer to the questions beginning, “What is the attainment of the fruit of stream-entry? What is the attainment of the fruit of once-return? What is the attainment of the fruit of non-return? What is the attainment of the fruit of arahantship?”

original: phalaṃ samāpajjantīti niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ.
analyzed: phalam samāpajjanti iti niṭṭham ettha gantabbam
translated: So it must be concluded that all noble persons enter upon the attainment of their respective fruits.

original: Kasmā pana te samāpajjantīti? Diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāratthaṃ. Yathā hi rājāno rajjasukhaṃ,
analyzed: kasmai pana te samāpajjanti iti diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāra attham yathā hi rājānaḥ rajja sukham
translated: But why do they enter upon it? For the sake of a pleasant abiding here and now. For just as kings enjoy the pleasures of sovereignty,

original: devatā dibbasukhaṃ anubhavanti, evaṃ ariyā “lokuttarasukhaṃ anubhavissāmā”ti addhānaparicchedaṃ
analyzed: devatāḥ dibba sukham anubhavanti evam ariyāḥ lokuttara sukham anubhavissāma ati addhāna paricchedam
translated: and deities enjoy the pleasures of heaven, so too, the noble persons, thinking, “We shall enjoy the bliss of the supramundane,”

original: katvā icchitakkhaṇe phalasamāpattiṃ samāpajjanti.
analyzed: katvā icchita khaṇe phala samāpattim samāpajjanti
translated: make a division of the path of actual deliverance and enter upon the attainment of the fruit at the time they choose.

original: Kathañcassā samāpajjanaṃ, kathaṃ ṭhānaṃ, kathaṃ vuṭṭhānanti? Dvīhi tāva ākārehi assā
analyzed: katham ca assā samāpajjanam katham ṭhānam katham vuṭṭhānam ti dvīhi tāva ākārehi assā
translated: How is it attained? How is it persisted in? How is it emerged from? Firstly, its attainment is twofold,

original: samāpajjanaṃ hoti nibbānato aññassa ārammaṇassa amanasikārā, nibbānassa ca manasikārā. Yathāha –
analyzed: samāpajjanam hoti nibbānataḥ aññassa ārammaṇassa amanasikārāḥ nibbānassa ca manasikārāḥ yathā āha
translated: as attention is given neither to any object other than Nibbāna nor to Nibbāna itself, according to the passage:

original: “Dve kho, āvuso, paccayā animittāya cetovimuttiyā samāpattiyā, sabbanimittānañca amanasikāro, animittāya ca dhātuyā manasikāro”ti.
analyzed: dve kho āvuso paccayāḥ animittāya cetaḥ vimuttiyā samāpattiyā sabba nimittānam ca amanasikāraḥ animittāya ca dhātuyā manasikāraḥ ti
translated: “There are two conditions, friend, for the attainment of the mind-deliverance of the signless, the non-attention to any sign whatever and the attention given to the signless element” .

original: Ayaṃ panettha samāpajjanakkamo – phalasamāpattitthikena ariyasāvakena rahogatena
analyzed: ayam pana ittha samāpajjana kkamaḥ phala samāpattitthikena ariyasāvakena rahogatena
translated: But the order of the attainment is as follows. A noble disciple who is a once-returner or a non-returner, and who is seeking the attainment of fruition, goes into solitary retreat.

original: paṭisallīnena udayabbayādivasena saṅkhārā vipassitabbā. Tassevaṃ pavattānupubbavipassanasseva
analyzed: paṭisallīnena udaya bbaya ādi vasena saṅkhārāḥ vipassitabbā tassa evam pavatta anupubba vipassanassa eva
translated: He contemplates formations as impermanent, painful, and not-self by the method of rise and fall, etc.,

original: saṅkhārārammaṇagotrabhuñāṇānantaraṃ phalasamāpattivasena nirodhe cittamappeti, phalasamāpattininnabhāvena
analyzed: saṅkhāra ārammaṇa gotra bhuñāṇa anantaram phala samāpatti vasena nirodhe cittam appeti phala samāpatti ninna bhāvena
translated: and immediately next to the knowledge of the state of change-of-lineage that has Nibbāna as its object, he directs his mind to Nibbāna as the attainment of fruition.🔽And because he is devoted to the attainment of fruition,

original: ca sekkhassāpi phalameva uppajjati, na maggo. Ye pana vadanti “sotāpanno attano phalasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: ca sekkhassa api phalam eva uppajjati na maggaḥ ye pana vadanti sotāpannaḥ attanaḥ phala samāpattim
translated: only fruition arises in him, not the path. But some say that a stream-enterer can attain the fruition attainment of a non-returner.

original: samāpajjissāmīti vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā sakadāgāmī hoti, sakadāgāmī ca anāgāmī”ti.
analyzed: samāpajjissāmi iti vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā sakadāgāmī hoti sakadāgāmī ca anāgāmī iti
translated: He becomes a once-returner, and a once-returner becomes a non-returner” .

original: Te vattabbā – evaṃ sante anāgāmī arahā bhavissati, arahā ca paccekabuddho, paccekabuddho
analyzed: te vattabbā evam sante anāgāmī arahā bhavissati arahā ca paccekabuddhaḥ paccekabuddho
translated: They should be told: “If that were so, then a non-returner would become an Arahant, and an Arahant would become a Paccekabuddha, and a Paccekabuddha would become a Sambuddha.

original: ca sambuddhoti āpajjeyya, tasmā yathābhinivesaṃ yathājjhāsayaṃ vipassanā atthaṃ sādhetīti🔽sekkhassāpi phalameva uppajjati, na maggo. Phalampi tassa sace anena paṭhamajjhāniko
analyzed: ca sambuddhaḥ ti āpajjeyya tasmai yathābhinivesam yathājjhāsayam vipassanā attham sādheti iti  sekkhassa api phalam eva uppajjati na maggaḥ phalam pi tassa sace anena paṭhamajjhānikaḥ
translated: Therefore insight reaches its goal according to the way in which it is resolved and according to the way in which it is intended.

original: maggo adhigato, paṭhamajjhānikameva uppajjati. Sace dutiyādīsu aññatarajjhāniko,
analyzed: maggaḥ adhigataḥ paṭhama jhānikam eva uppajjati sace dutiya ādīsu aññatara jhāniko
translated: And the fruit only arises in the trainer, not the path. And if the path he has reached belongs to the first jhāna, the fruit arises in the first jhāna too. If it belongs to the second or any other jhāna,

original: dutiyādīsu aññatarajjhānikamevāti.🔽Kasmā panettha gotrabhuñāṇaṃ maggañāṇapurecārikaṃ viya nibbānārammaṇaṃ na hotīti?
analyzed: dutiya ādīsu aññatara jhānikam eva ti  kasmā pana ittha gotrabhu ñāṇam magga ñāṇa purecārikam viya nibbāna ārammaṇam na hoti iti
translated: the fruit arises in that jhāna.🔽But why is the knowledge of change-of-lineage not, like the path knowledge, made to have Nibbāna as its object?

original: Phalañāṇānaṃ aniyyānikabhāvato. Ariyamaggadhammāyeva hi niyyānikā. Vuttañhetaṃ “katame
analyzed: phala ñāṇānaṃ aniyyānika bhāvato ariya magga dhammāya iva hi niyyānikāḥ vuttam ha etam katame
translated: Because the fruits of knowledge are not emancipating. Only the states of the noble paths are emancipating. For this is said: “What is emancipating?

original: dhammā niyyānikā? Cattāro ariyamaggā apariyāpannā”ti. Tasmā ekanteneva niyyānikabhāvassa
analyzed: dhammā niyyānikā cattāro ariyamaggāḥ a pariyāpannā ti tasmai ekantena iva niyyānika bhāvassa
translated: and the truths are the escape? The four noble paths are not included in the round.

original: ubhato vuṭṭhānabhāvena pavattamānassa anantarapaccayabhūtena ñāṇena nimittato vuṭṭhiteneva🔽bhavitabbanti tassa nibbānārammaṇatā yuttā, na pana ariyamaggassa bhāvitattā tassa
analyzed: ubhatas vuṭṭhāna bhāvena pavattamānassa anantara paccaya bhūtena ñāṇena nimittataḥ vuṭṭhitena eva  bhavitabbanti tassa nibbāna ārammaṇa tā yuttā na pana ariya maggassa bhāvita ttā tassa
translated: Therefore it is proper that the knowledge that is the proximate cause of the escape should be the escape itself,🔽and that it should be the escape by emerging from the sign.

original: vipākabhāvena pavattamānānaṃ kilesānaṃ asamucchindanato aniyyānikattā avuṭṭhānasabhāvānaṃ
analyzed: vipāka bhāvena pavattamānānam kilesānam a samucchindanataḥ aniyyānika ttā avuṭṭhāna sabhāvānam
translated: But it is not proper that the path should be the escape, because it does not cut off the defilements that occur as its result,

original: phalañāṇānaṃ purecārikañāṇassa kadācipi nibbānārammaṇatā ubhayattha anulomañāṇānaṃ
analyzed: phala ñāṇānam purecārika ñāṇassa kadācipi nibbāna ārammaṇa tā ubhayattha anuloma ñāṇānam
translated: and because the fruition knowledges, which do not have the nature of an escape since they do not cut off the defilements,

original: atulyākārato. Ariyamaggavīthiyañhi anulomañāṇāni anibbiddhapubbānaṃ thūlathūlānaṃ
analyzed: atulya ākārataḥ ariya magga vīthiyam hi anulomañāṇāni anibbiddha pubbānam thūla thūlānam
translated: and the conformity knowledge, which has no such object as the path,🔽are not the escape.

original: lobhakkhandhādīnaṃ sātisayaṃ padālanena lokiyañāṇena ukkaṃsapāramippattāni maggañāṇānukūlāni
analyzed: lobha kkhandha ādīnam sa atisayam padālanena lokiya ñāṇena ukkaṃsa pārami pattāni magga ñāṇa anukūlāni
translated: For the conformity knowledge in the path of the noble ones is the culmination of mundane knowledge, which crushes the gross and grossest greed, etc., that have not already been subdued.

original: uppajjanti, phalasamāpattivīthiyaṃ pana tāni tāni tena tena maggena tesaṃ tesaṃ kilesānaṃ
analyzed: uppajjanti phala samāpatti vīthiyam pana tāni tāni tena tena maggena tesam tesam kilesānam
translated: but in the course of the fruition attainment, the kinds of knowledge that are the fruit of the path are called “knowledge of the fruit” .

original: samucchinnattā tattha nirussukkāni kevalaṃ ariyānaṃ phalasamāpattisukhasamaṅgibhāvassa
analyzed: samucchinna ttā tattha nirussukkāni kevalam ariyānam phala samāpatti sukha samaṅgi bhāvassa
translated: But in the course of the fruition attainment the equanimity, etc., occur in the mere form of the conditions for the noble persons’ possession of the bliss of fruition attainment, since those defilements have been cut off by that path.

original: parikammamattāni hutvā uppajjantīti na tesaṃ kutoci vuṭṭhānasambhavo, yato tesaṃ🔽pariyosāne ñāṇaṃ saṅkhāranimittaṃ vuṭṭhānato nibbānārammaṇaṃ siyā. Evañca katvā sekkhassa🔽attano phalasamāpattivaḷañjanatthāya udayabbayādivasena saṅkhāre sammasantassa vipassanāñāṇānupubbāya
analyzed: parikamma mattāni hutvā uppajjanti iti na tesam kutoci vuṭṭhāna sambhavaḥ yatas tesam  pariyosāne ñāṇam saṅkhāra nimittam vuṭṭhānataḥ nibbāna ārammaṇam siyā evam ca katvā sekkhassa  attanaḥ phala samāpatti vaḷañjana tthāya udaya bbaya ādi vasena saṅkhāre sammasantassa vipassanā ñāṇa anupubbāya
translated: So they do not arise from anywhere,🔽and at the end of them there is no arising of knowledge with the sign of formations, as there is in the case of emergence from cessation.

original: phalameva uppajjati, na maggoti ayañca attho samatthito hoti. Evaṃ tāva phalasamāpattiyā
analyzed: phalam eva uppajjati na maggo ti ayaṃ ca attho samatthito hoti evam tāva phala samāpattiyā
translated: And it is only when this is so that it is proper to say that the learning ender’s insight knowledge is followed by fruition attainment and not by the path, and that he contemplates formations only as impermanent, etc., for the purpose of refreshing the fruition attainment.

original: samāpajjanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: samāpajjanam veditabbam
translated: So it should be understood that this is how the entering for fruition attainment comes about.

original: “Tayo kho, āvuso, paccayā animittāya cetovimuttiyā ṭhitiyā, sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikāro, animittāya ca dhātuyā manasikāro, pubbe ca abhisaṅkhāro”ti –
analyzed: tayo kho āvuso paccayāḥ animittāya cetaḥ vimuttiyā ṭhitiyā sabba nimittānam amanasikāraḥ animittāya ca dhātuyā manasikāro pubbe ca abhisaṅkhāro ti
translated: “There are these three conditions, friend, for the stability of mind-deliverance unaccompanied by form: non-attention to all signs, attention to the signless element, and previous aspiration” .

original: Vacanato panassā tīhākārehi ṭhānaṃ hoti. Tattha pubbe ca abhisaṅkhāroti samāpattito
analyzed: vacanato panassā tīhā ākārehi ṭhānam hoti tattha pubbe ca abhisaṅkhāro ti samāpattito
translated: But it is steadied in three ways according to the words: “There are these three conditions, friend, for the stability of mind-deliverance unaccompanied by form: non-attention to all signs, attention to the signless element, and previous aspiration” .🔽Herein, previous aspiration is the delimitation of time before entering,

original: pubbe kālaparicchedo. “Asukasmiṃ nāma kāle vuṭṭhahissāmī”ti paricchinnattā hissā
analyzed: pubbe kāla paricchedaḥ asukasmin nāma kāle vuṭṭhahissāmi iti paricchinna ttā
translated: as follows: “I shall emerge at such a time.”

original: yāva so kālo nāgacchati, tāva vuṭṭhānaṃ na hoti.🔽“Dve kho, āvuso, paccayā animittāya cetovimuttiyā vuṭṭhānassa, sabbanimittānañca manasikāro, animittāya ca dhātuyā amanasikāro”ti –
analyzed: yāva saḥ kālaḥ na āgacchati tāva vuṭṭhānam na hoti  dve kho āvuso paccayāḥ animittāya cetas vimuttiyāḥ vuṭṭhānassa sabba nimittānam ca manasikāraḥ animittāya ca dhātuyāḥ amanasikāraḥ ti
translated: So long as that time does not come, there is no emergence.🔽“There are these two conditions, friend, for the emergence from mind-deliverance unaccompanied by form: attention to all signs and non-attention to the signless element” .🔽But it emerges in two ways according to the words: “There are these two conditions, friend, for the emergence from mind-deliverance unaccompanied by form: attention to all signs and non-attention to the signless element” .

original: Vacanato panassā dvīhākārehi vuṭṭhānaṃ hoti. Tattha sabbanimittānanti rūpanimittavedanāsaññāsaṅkhāraviññāṇanimittānaṃ.
analyzed: vacanato panassāḥ dvīhākārehi vuṭṭhānam hoti tattha sabba nimittānam ti rūpa nimitta vedanā saññā saṅkhāra viññāṇa nimittānam
translated: Herein, all signs are the sign of materiality, the sign of feeling, the sign of perception, the sign of formations, and the sign of consciousness.

original: Kāmañca na sabbānevetāni ekato manasi karoti, sabbasaṅgāhikavasena panevaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: kāmam ca na sabbān eva etāni ekatas manasi karoti sabba saṅgāhika vasena pana evam vuttam
translated: And although he does not give attention to all these together, still it is said in this way in order to include all.

original: Tasmā yaṃ bhavaṅgassa ārammaṇaṃ, tassa manasikaraṇena phalasamāpattito vuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: tasmai yam bhavaṅgassa ārammaṇam tassa manasikaraṇena phala samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhānam
translated: So the emergence from fruition attainment is by giving attention to the object of the life-continuum.🔽This is how the emergence should be understood.

original: hotīti evaṃ assā vuṭṭhānaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tayidaṃ evamidha samāpajjanavuṭṭhānaṃ arahattaphalabhūtaṃ –
analyzed: hoti iti evam assā vuṭṭhānam veditabbam tayidam evam idha samāpajjana vuṭṭhānam arahatta phala bhūtam
translated: And this emergence from fruition attainment, which is the state of Arahantship, is described in the Paṭisambhidā as follows:

original: “Paṭippassaddhadarathaṃ, amatārammaṇaṃ subhaṃ;
analyzed: amata ārammaṇam subham
translated: “The state of peace, the Deathless, the auspicious,🔽The escape from the world’s three realms,🔽The stilling of all formations, the bliss of renunciation,

original: Vantalokāmisaṃ santaṃ, sāmaññaphalamuttamaṃ”.🔽Iti vuttaṃ sātātisātaṃ vimuttisukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedesi. Tena vuttaṃ – “vimuttisukhapaṭisaṃvedīti vimuttisukhaṃ phalasamāpattisukhaṃ paṭisaṃvediyamāno nisinno hotīti attho”ti.
analyzed: vanta loka āmisam santam sāmañña phalam uttamam  iti vuttam sāta ati sātam vimutti sukham paṭisaṃvedesi tena vuttam vimutti sukha paṭisaṃvedī iti vimutti sukham phala samāpatti sukham paṭisaṃvediyamānaḥ nisinnaḥ hoti iti atthaḥ ti
translated: The supreme fruit of the life of purity” .🔽So he experienced the bliss of the liberation described in this way. Hence it was said above: “He sat rejoicing in the bliss of liberation. The meaning is that he sat experiencing the bliss of fruition attainment, the bliss of liberation” .🔽Now: the word now is a particle in the sense of a reason. Kho is a mere particle.

original: Athāti adhikāratthe nipāto. Khoti padapūraṇe. Tesu adhikāratthena athāti iminā vimuttisukhapaṭisaṃvedanato
analyzed: atha ati adhikāra atthe nipātaḥ kho ti pada pūraṇe tesu adhikāra atthena atha ati iminā vimutti sukha paṭisaṃvedanato
translated: Herein, by the word now he shows a reason other than the experiencing of the bliss of liberation.🔽But what is that reason? It is the giving attention to dependent origination.

original: aññaṃ adhikāraṃ dasseti. Ko panesoti? Paṭiccasamuppādamanasikāro. Athāti vā pacchāti
analyzed: aññam adhikāram dasseti kaḥ pana iso ti paṭiccasamuppāda manasikāraḥ atha ati vā pacchā ati
translated: Or alternatively, now may be taken as meaning later.

original: etasmiṃ atthe nipāto, tena “tassa sattāhassa accayenā”ti vakkhamānameva atthaṃ joteti.
analyzed: etasmin atthe nipātaḥ tena tassa sattāhassa accayena ati vakkhamānam eva attham jotā iti
translated: The instrumental case is used in the sense of cause, thus the phrase “by the passing of seven days” indicates the meaning that is to be stated, namely, “by the cause consisting in the passing of seven days.”

original: Tassa sattāhassāti pallaṅkasattāhassa. Accayenāti apagamena. Tamhā samādhimhāti arahattaphalasamādhito.
analyzed: tassa sattāhassa ati pallaṅka sattāhassa accayena ati apagamena tamhā samādhimhā ati arahatta phala samādhito
translated: “Of that”: of the seven days of sitting. “By the passing”: by the elapsing. “From that concentration”: from the concentration of the fruit of arahantship.

original: Idha pana ṭhatvā paṭipāṭiyā satta sattāhāni dassetabbānīti keci tāni vitthārayiṃsu.
analyzed: idha pana ṭhatvā paṭipāṭiyā satta sattāhāni dassetabbāni iti keci tāni vitthārayiṃsu
translated: Some have explained that the seven days should be shown in succession, beginning from here.

original: Mayaṃ pana tāni khandhakapāṭhena imissā udānapāḷiyā avirodhadassanamukhena parato
analyzed: mayam pana tāni khandhaka pāṭhena imissā udāna pāḷiyāḥ avirodha dassana mukhena paratas
translated: But we will explain them later on in the way that does not contradict the method of exposition of this Udāna collection, by showing how they are not in conflict with the method of exposition of the Khuddaka Nikāya.🔽“Night” is a word in the genitive case in the sense of a part related to a whole.

original: vaṇṇayissāma. Rattiyāti avayavasambandhe sāmivacanaṃ. Paṭhamanti accantasaṃyogatthe
analyzed: vaṇṇayissāma rattiyā iti avayava sambandhe sāmi vacanam a c c anta saṃyoga tthe
translated: “First” is a word in the sense of a whole related to a part.

original: upayogavacanaṃ. Bhagavā hi tassā rattiyā sakalampi paṭhamaṃ yāmaṃ teneva manasikārena yutto ahosīti.
analyzed: upayoga vacanam bhagavā hi tassā rattiyā sakalam pi paṭhamam yāmam tena iva manasikārena yuttaḥ ahosi iti
translated: For the Blessed One was occupied with that same thought throughout the whole of the first watch of the night.

original: Paṭiccasamuppādanti paccayadhammaṃ. Avijjādayo hi paccayadhammā paṭiccasamuppādo.
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppādanti paccaya dhammam avijjā ādayaḥ hi paccaya dhammā paṭiccasamuppādaḥ
translated: “Dependent origination”: the state of being a condition. For ignorance, etc., as states of being a condition are the dependent origination.

original: Kathamidaṃ jānitabbanti ce? Bhagavato vacanena. Bhagavatā hi “tasmātihānanda, eseva🔽hetu, etaṃ nidānaṃ, esa samudayo, esa paccayo jarāmaraṇassa, yadidaṃ jāti…pe… saṅkhārānaṃ,
analyzed: katham idam jānitabbanti ce bhagavataḥ vacanena bhagavatā hi tasmā ati ha ānanda  hetu etam nidānam esa samudayaḥ esa paccayaḥ jarā maraṇassa yat idam jātipe
translated: How is this to be known? By the Blessed One’s word. For the Blessed One has said: “Therefore, Ananda, this is the cause, this is the reason, this is the origin, this is the condition of ageing and death, namely birth. … of formations,

original: yadidaṃ avijjā”ti evaṃ avijjādayo hetūti vuttā. Yathā dvādasa paccayā dvādasa paṭiccasamuppādāti.
analyzed: yat idam avijjā ati evam avijjā ādayaḥ hetu iti vuttāḥ yathā dvādasa paccayāḥ dvādasa paṭiccasamuppādā ti
translated: How is this to be known? By the Blessed One’s word. For the Blessed One has said this: “Therefore, Ānanda, this is the cause, this is the reason, this is the origin, this is the condition, for ageing-and-death, namely birth … for formations, namely ignorance” . So ignorance, etc., are stated as causes in the way already stated. As the twelve conditions are the twelve dependent originations.

original: Tatrāyaṃ vacanattho – aññamaññaṃ paṭicca paṭimukhaṃ katvā kāraṇasamavāyaṃ appaṭikkhipitvā
analyzed: tatra ayam vacana atthaḥ aññam aññam paṭicca paṭimukham katvā kāraṇa samavāyam a paṭikkhipitvā
translated: Here is the word-meaning. They originate in dependence on each other, face to face, without bypassing each other, by the concurrence of causes,

original: sahite uppādetīti paṭiccasamuppādo. Atha vā paṭicca paccetabbaṃ paccayārahataṃ paccayaṃ🔽paṭigantvā na vinā tena sambandhassa uppādo paṭiccasamuppādo. Paṭiccasamuppādoti🔽cettha samuppādapadaṭṭhānavacanaviññeyyo phalassa uppādanasamatthatāyutto hetu, na
analyzed: sahite uppādeti iti paṭiccasamuppādaḥ atha vā paṭicca paccetabbam paccaya arahatam paccayam  paṭigantvā na vinā tena sambandhassa uppādaḥ paṭiccasamuppādo paṭiccasamuppādo ti  ca ittha samuppāda padaṭṭhāna vacana viññeyyaḥ phalassa uppādana samattha tā yuttaḥ hetu na
translated: so it is dependent origination. Or alternatively, it is origination in dependence on a condition that is to be sought in the past,🔽not origination that occurs without that condition, so it is dependent origination. Herein, the word “dependent origination” should be understood as a cause that is fit to be a producer of a fruit by being a state that is a footing for origination,

original: paṭiccasamuppattimattaṃ veditabbaṃ. Atha vā paccetuṃ arahanti naṃ paṇḍitāti paṭicco,
analyzed: paṭicca samuppattimattam veditabbam atha vā paccetum arahanti nam paṇḍitā ati paṭiccaḥ
translated: not merely as dependent origination. Or alternatively, it is dependent because it is fit to be sought in the past,

original: sammā sayameva vā uppādetīti samuppādo, paṭicco ca so samuppādo cāti paṭiccasamuppādoti
analyzed: sammā sayam eva vā uppādeti iti samuppādaḥ paṭiccaḥ ca so samuppādo ca ati paṭiccasamuppādo ti
translated: Or else, it arises by itself, thus it is origination . And that is a condition, thus it is a conditional origination .

original: evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo.🔽Anulomanti “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā”tiādinā nayena vutto avijjādiko paccayākāro attanā
analyzed: evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo  anulomam ti avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ti ādinā nayena vuttaḥ avijjā ādikaḥ paccaya ākāraḥ attanā
translated: This is how the meaning should be regarded here.

original: kattabbakiccakaraṇato anulomoti vuccati. Atha vā ādito paṭṭhāya antaṃ pāpetvā vuttattā
analyzed: kattabba kicca karaṇataḥ anulomaḥ ti vuccati atha vā āditaḥ paṭṭhāya antam pāpetvā vutta ttā
translated: The order of arising : the order of arising of the states beginning with ignorance stated in the way beginning, “With ignorance as condition there are formations” is called “order of arising” because it is the order in which the respective functions are performed by the conditions. Or alternatively, it is the order of arising because it is the order of arising of the process ; it is order of arising, thus it is the order of arising.

original: pavattiyā vā anulomato anulomo, taṃ anulomaṃ. Sādhukaṃ manasākāsīti sakkaccaṃ manasi🔽akāsi. Yo yo paccayadhammo yassa yassa paccayuppannadhammassa yathā yathā hetupaccayādinā
analyzed: pavattiyāḥ vā anulomataḥ anulomaḥ tam anulomam sādhukam manasā akāsi iti sakkaccam manasi  akāsi yaḥ yaḥ paccaya dhammaḥ yassa yassa paccaya uppanna dhammassa yathā yathā hetu paccaya ādinā
translated: He gave close attention with his mind : he gave attention to it with his mind, he gave attention to it with his mind properly, is the meaning.

original: paccayabhāvena paccayo hoti, taṃ sabbaṃ aviparītaṃ aparihāpetvā anavasesato paccavekkhaṇavasena
analyzed: paccaya bhāvena paccayaḥ hoti tam sabbam aviparītam a parihāpetvā anavasesataḥ paccavekkhaṇa vasena
translated: For whatever state is a condition in whatever way for whatever state, he gave attention to it with his mind by way of reviewing it without confounding it or missing it out, without leaving out any of it.

original: citte akāsīti attho. Yathā pana bhagavā paṭiccasamuppādānulomaṃ manasākāsi, taṃ saṅkhepena
analyzed: citte akāsi iti atthaḥ yathā pana bhagavā paṭiccasamuppāda anulomam manasā akāsi tam saṅkhepena
translated: But in brief, he gave attention to it with his mind in the way in which the Blessed One gave attention to the order of arising of dependent origination.

original: tāva dassetuṃ “iti imasmiṃ sati idaṃ hoti, imassuppādā idaṃ uppajjatī”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Tattha itīti evaṃ, anena pakārenāti attho. Imasmiṃ sati idaṃ hotīti imasmiṃ avijjādike🔽paccaye sati idaṃ saṅkhārādikaṃ phalaṃ hoti. Imassuppādā idaṃ uppajjatīti imassa🔽avijjādikassa paccayassa uppādā idaṃ saṅkhārādikaṃ phalaṃ uppajjatīti attho. Imasmiṃ🔽asati idaṃ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṃ nirujjhatīti avijjādīnaṃ abhāve saṅkhārādīnaṃ
analyzed: tāva dassetum iti imasmin sati idam hoti imassa uppādā idam uppajjati iti vuttam  tattha iti iti evam anena pakārena ati attho imasmin sati idam hoti iti imasmin avijjā ādike  paccaye sati idam saṅkhāra ādikam phalam hoti imassa uppādā idam uppajjati iti imassa  avijjā ādikassa paccayassa uppādā idam saṅkhāra ādikam phalam uppajjati iti atthaḥ imasmin  asati idam na hoti imassa nirodhā idam nirujjhati iti avijjā ādīnam abhāve saṅkhāra ādīnam
translated: In order to show this, it is said: “With the arising of that, this comes to be; with the cessation of that, this ceases.”

original: abhāvassa avijjādīnaṃ nirodhe saṅkhārādīnaṃ nirodhassa ca dutiyatatiyasuttavacanena🔽etasmiṃ paccayalakkhaṇe niyamo dassito hoti – imasmiṃ sati eva, nāsati. Imassuppādā
analyzed: abhāvassa avijjā ādīnam nirodhe saṅkhāra ādīnam nirodhassa ca dutiya tatiya sutta vacanena  etasmin paccaya lakkhaṇe niyamaḥ dassitaḥ hoti imasmin sati eva na asati
translated: Herein, it is said thus: “With the arising of that” means with the arising of that condition, ignorance, etc.; “this comes to be” means this fruit, formations, etc., comes to be. “With the cessation of that” means with the cessation of that condition, ignorance, etc.; “this ceases” means this fruit, formations, etc., ceases. “With the non-appearance of that” means with the non-appearance of that condition, ignorance, etc.; “this does not come to be” means this fruit, formations, etc., does not come to be. “With the cessation of that” means with the cessation of that condition, ignorance, etc.; “this ceases” means with the cessation of ignorance, etc., formations, etc., cease. Thus the statement of the second and third sentences in the above passage shows the rule in the characteristic of condition thus: “With the existence of this, that exists; not without the existence of this. With the arising of that, this arises; not without the arising of that. With the cessation of that, this ceases; not with the non-cessation of that.” Therefore, the rule included in the characteristic is shown here thus:

original: eva, nānuppādā. Anirodhā eva, na nirodhāti. Tenetaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ antogadhaniyamaṃ idha
analyzed: eva na anuppādāḥ anirodhāḥ eva na tena itam lakkhaṇam antogadha niyamam idha
translated: “With the existence of this, that exists; not without the existence of this. With the arising of that, this arises; not without the arising of that. With the cessation of that, this ceases; not with the non-cessation of that.”

original: paṭiccasamuppādassa vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Nirodhoti ca avijjādīnaṃ virāgādhigamena
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppādassa vuttanti daṭṭhabbam nirodhaḥ ti ca avijjā ādīnam virāga adhigamena
translated: should be understood as stated in the case of dependent origination.🔽And cessation is the non-occurrence of ignorance, etc., through the attainment of dispassion.

original: āyatiṃ anuppādo appavatti. Tathā hi vuttaṃ – “avijjāya tveva asesavirāganirodhā saṅkhāranirodho”tiādi.
analyzed: āyatim anuppādaḥ appavatti tathā hi vuttam avijjāya tu eva asesa virāga nirodhā saṅkhāra nirodhaḥ tiādi
translated: and it should be regarded as the dependent origination stated in the reverse order. “Cessation” is the non- arising, the non- occurrence, of ignorance, etc., through the attainment of the fading away of ignorance, etc. For this is said: “With the remainderless fading away and cessation of ignorance” , etc.🔽And “cessation as cessation” is stated as the cessation of arising.

original: Nirodhanirodhī ca uppādanirodhībhāvena vutto “imassa nirodhā idaṃ nirujjhatī”ti.
analyzed: nirodha nirodhī ca uppāda nirodhī bhāvena vuttaḥ imassa nirodhā idam nirujjhati iti
translated: “Through the cessation of this, that ceases” .

original: Tenetaṃ dasseti – anirodho uppādo nāma, so cettha atthibhāvotipi vuccatīti. “Imasmiṃ
analyzed: tena itam dasseti anirodhaḥ uppādaḥ nāma so ca ittha atthi bhāvaḥ ti pi vuccati iti imasmin
translated: So it shows that “non-cessation” is called “arising,” and that is called “existence” here.🔽For this is the characteristic of the dependent origination stated in the forward order: “When this exists, that comes to be;

original: sati idaṃ hotī”ti idameva hi lakkhaṇaṃ pariyāyantarena “imassa uppādā idaṃ uppajjatī”ti🔽vadantena parena purimaṃ visesitaṃ hoti. Tasmā na dharamānataṃyeva sandhāya “imasmiṃ
analyzed: sati idam hoti iti idam eva hi lakkhaṇam pariyāya antarena imassa uppādā idam uppajjati iti  vadantena parena purimam visesitam hoti tasmāt na sandhāya imasmin
translated: with the arising of this, that arises” .🔽The other characteristic stated in the reverse order is distinguished by the other, namely, “Through the arising of this, that arises” .

original: satī”ti vuttaṃ, atha kho maggena aniruddhabhāvañcāti viññāyati. Yasmā ca “imasmiṃ
analyzed: satī iti vuttam atha kho maggena aniruddha bhāvam ca ati viññāyati yasmā ca imasmin
translated: Therefore “when this exists” is not stated here with reference to mere presentness, but rather with reference to the non- cessation of what exists through the path.

original: asati idaṃ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṃ nirujjhatī”ti dvidhāpi uddiṭṭhassa lakkhaṇassa
analyzed: asati idam na hoti imassa nirodhā idam nirujjhati iti dvidhā api uddiṭṭhassa lakkhaṇassa
translated: And since the characteristic stated in the two ways, “When this does not exist, that does not exist; through the cessation of this, that ceases” ,

original: niddesaṃ vadantena “avijjāya tveva asesavirāganirodhā saṅkhāranirodho”tiādinā nirodho
analyzed: niddesam vadantena avijjāya tu eva asesa virāga nirodhā saṅkhāra nirodhā iti ādinā nirodhaḥ
translated: When he explains the text, he explains cessation only, saying, “With the remainderless fading away and cessation of ignorance” , etc.,

original: eva vutto, tasmā natthibhāvopi nirodho evāti natthibhāvaviruddho atthibhāvo anirodhoti
analyzed: eva vuttaḥ tasmā natthi bhāvaḥ api nirodhaḥ evā ati natthi bhāva viruddhaḥ atthi bhāvaḥ anirodho ti
translated: So the non-existent state is cessation too. Thus the existent state, which is the opposite of the non-existent state, is not cessation.

original: dassitaṃ hoti. Tena anirodhasaṅkhātena atthibhāvena uppādaṃ viseseti. Tato na idha🔽atthibhāvamattaṃ uppādoti attho adhippeto, atha kho anirodhasaṅkhāto atthibhāvo cāti🔽ayamattho vibhāvitoti. Evametaṃ lakkhaṇadvayavacanaṃ aññamaññavisesanavisesitabbabhāvena
analyzed: dassitam hoti tena anirodha saṅkhātena atthi bhāvena uppādam viseseti tatas na idha  atthi bhāva mattam uppādaḥ ti atthaḥ adhippetaḥ atha kho a nirodha saṅkhātaḥ atthi bhāvaḥ ca ati  ayam atthaḥ vibhāvito ti evam etam lakkhaṇa dvaya vacanam aññam añña visesana visesitabba bhāvena
translated: So it is shown. And by the existent state called “non-cessation” he distinguishes arising. Therefore🔽the meaning intended here is not merely the existent state, but rather the existent state called “non-cessation.”

original: sātthakanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sa atthakam ti veditabbam
translated: So this meaning is analyzed. This explanation of the two characteristics should be understood as fruitful in that it shows how each is distinguished and not distinguished.

original: Ko panāyaṃ anirodho nāma, yo “atthibhāvo, uppādo”ti ca vuccatīti? Appahīnabhāvo ca,
analyzed: kaḥ pana ayam anirodhaḥ nāma yaḥ atthi bhāvo uppādo ti ca vuccati iti appahīna bhāvo ca
translated: But what is this so-called non-cessation that is called “existent state” and “arising”? It is the state of not being abandoned,

original: anibbattitaphalārahatāpahānehi phalānuppādanārahatā ca. Ye hi pahātabbā akusalā dhammā,
analyzed: a nibbattita phala araha tā apahānehi phala an uppādana araha tā ca ye hi pahātabbāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: and the state of not being fit to give rise to the fruit by the abandoning of the fruit’s cause and by the non-production of the fruit. The unprofitable states that are to be abandoned

original: tesaṃ ariyamaggena asamugghāṭitabhāvo ca. Ye pana na pahātabbā kusalābyākatā dhammā,
analyzed: tesam ariya maggena a samugghāṭita bhāvo ca ye pana na pahātabbā kusala abyākatāḥ dhammā
translated: and the fact that they are not eradicated by the noble path.🔽But the wholesome and indeterminate dhammas that are not to be abandoned

original: yāni tesu saṃyojanāni akhīṇāsavānaṃ tesaṃ aparikkhīṇatā ca. Asamugghāṭitānusayatāya
analyzed: yāni tesu saṃyojanāni akhīṇa āsavānam tesam aparikkhīṇa tā ca a samugghāṭita anusaya tāya
translated: and the fact that the fetters in them are not exhausted in those who have not exhausted the asavas.🔽For the occurrence of the aggregates with fetters is dependent origination by way of the fact that the underlying tendencies are not eradicated.

original: hi sasaṃyojanā khandhappavatti paṭiccasamuppādo. Tathā ca vuttaṃ –
analyzed: hi sa saṃyojanā khandha ppavatti paṭiccasamuppādaḥ tathā ca vuttam
translated: And it is said thus:

original: “Yāya ca, bhikkhave, avijjāya nivutassa bālassa yāya ca taṇhāya sampayuttassa ayaṃ
analyzed: yāya ca bhikkhave avijjāya nivutassa bālassa yāya ca taṇhāya sampayuttassa ayaṃ
translated: “Bhikkhus, the fool, being enveloped by ignorance and fettered by craving,

original: kāyo samudāgato, sā ceva avijjā bālassa appahīnā, sā ca taṇhā aparikkhīṇā. Taṃ kissa🔽hetu? Na, bhikkhave, bālo acari brahmacariyaṃ sammā dukkhakkhayāya, tasmā bālo kāyassa
analyzed: kāyaḥ samudāgato sā ca iva avijjā bālassa appahīnā sā ca taṇhā aparikkhīṇā tam kissa  hetu na bhikkhave bālaḥ acari brahmacariyam sammā dukkha kkhayāya tasmā bālaḥ kāyassa
translated: has produced this body. That ignorance has not been abandoned by the fool, that craving has not been exhausted.

original: bhedā kāyūpago hoti, so kāyūpago samāno na parimuccati jātiyā jarāmaraṇenā”tiādi.
analyzed: bhedā kāya upago hoti saḥ kāya upago samānaḥ na parimuccati jātiyā jarā maraṇena atiādi
translated: What is the reason for that? Because, bhikkhus, the fool has not practised the holy life for the complete destruction of suffering. Therefore, bhikkhus, on the dissolution of the body, the fool is bound to reappear, and reappearing, he is not freed from birth, ageing, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair. ”

original: Khīṇasaṃyojanānaṃ pana avijjāya abhāvato saṅkhārānaṃ, taṇhupādānānaṃ abhāvato upādānabhavānaṃ asambhavoti vaṭṭassa upacchedo paññāyissatīti. Tenevāha –
analyzed: khīṇa saṃyojanānam pana avijjāya abhāvato saṅkhārānam taṇhā upādānānam abhāvataḥ upādāna bhavānam asambhavaḥ ti vaṭṭassa upacchedaḥ paññāyissati iti tena eva āha
translated: But when the cankers are destroyed, ignorance is absent, and so too are formations, and craving and assuming, and so too are the kinds of becoming that are due to them. So the cutting off of the round is evident. That is why it is said:

original: “Channaṃ tveva, phagguṇa, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā phassanirodho, phassanirodhā vedanānirodho”tiādi.🔽Na hi aggamaggādhigamato uddhaṃ yāva parinibbānā saḷāyatanādīnaṃ appavatti. Atha
analyzed: channam tu eva phagguṇa asesa virāga nirodhā phassa nirodho phassa nirodhā vedanā nirodho tiādi  na hi agga magga adhigamataḥ uddham yāva parinibbānā saḷāyatana ādīnam appavatti atha
translated: “With the remainderless fading away and cessation of the six bases for contact there is cessation of contact; with the cessation of contact, the cessation of feeling” ,🔽and so on. For after the attainment of the supramundane path there is no occurrence of the six bases for contact, etc., until the attainment of Nibbāna. But it is not because they are nonexistent that they are called “ceased” in the texts.

original: kho natthitā nirodhasaddavacanīyatā khīṇasaṃyojanatāti nirodho vutto. Apica cirakatampi🔽kammaṃ anibbattitaphalatāya appahīnāhāratāya ca phalārahaṃ santaṃ eva nāma hoti,
analyzed: kho natthi tā nirodha sadda vacanīya tā khīṇa saṃyojana tā ati nirodho vutto apica cirakatam pi  kammam a nibbattita phala tāya a pahīna āhāra tāya ca phala araham santam eva nāma hoti
translated: They are called “ceased” because they are destroyed, because they are abandoned.🔽Moreover, even when a deed has been done long ago, it is still called “present” as long as it has not given its fruit or has not lost its potency through the lapse of time.

original: na nibbattitaphalaṃ, nāpi pahīnāhāranti. Phaluppattipaccayānaṃ avijjāsaṅkhārādīnaṃ
analyzed: na nibbattita phalam na api pahīna āhāranti phala uppatti paccayānam avijjā saṅkhāra ādīnam
translated: It is not called “past” until it has given its fruit or lost its potency.

original: vuttanayeneva phalārahabhāvo anirodhoti veditabbo. Evaṃ aniruddhabhāveneva hi yena
analyzed: vutta nayena iva phala araha bhāvaḥ anirodho ti veditabbaḥ evam aniruddha bhāvena iva hi yena
translated: And the fact that it is still capable of giving its fruit should be understood as its not having ceased in the way already stated.🔽For it is only because it has not ceased in this way that it is called “present” and not “past.”

original: vinā phalaṃ na sambhavati, taṃ kāraṇaṃ atītantipi imasmiṃ satīti iminā vacanena vuttaṃ.🔽Tatoyeva ca avusitabrahmacariyassa appavattidhammataṃ anāpanno paccayuppādo kālabhedaṃ
analyzed: vinā phalam na sambhavati tam kāraṇam imasmin sati iti iminā vacanena vuttam  tatas yā iva ca a vusita brahmacariyassa appavatti dhamma tam an āpannaḥ paccayuppādaḥ kāla bhedam
translated: and it is not possible without the fruit. The reason for this is stated in the words “with the arising of this, that arises.”🔽And the condition is said to be “the arising” of the fruit, not “the occurrence” of the fruit, because it is not possible for the fruit to occur without the non-fulfillment of the life of purity.

original: anāmasitvā anivattanāya eva imassa uppādāti vutto. Atha vā avasesapaccayasamavāye
analyzed: an āmasitvā a nivattanāya eva imassa uppādā ti vuttaḥ atha vā avasesa paccaya samavāye
translated: Or alternatively, the condition is said to be “the arising” of the fruit because it is the state of facing the fruit’s arising, as if it were present, even though it is not present, when the other conditions are present,

original: avijjamānassapi vijjamānassa viya pageva vijjamānassa yā phaluppattiabhimukhatā,🔽sā imassa uppādāti vuttā. Tathā hi tato phalaṃ uppajjatīti tadavatthaṃ kāraṇaṃ phalassa
analyzed: a vijjamānassa api vijjamānassa viya pageva vijjamānassa yā phala uppatti abhimukha tā  sā imassa uppādā iti vuttā tathā hi tatas phalam uppajjati iti tad avattham kāraṇam phalassa
translated: and because it is the state of facing the fruit’s arising, as if it were present, even though it is present, when the other conditions are present.

original: uppādanabhāvena uṭṭhitaṃ uppatitaṃ nāma hoti, na vijjamānampi atadavatthanti tadavatthatā uppādoti veditabbo.
analyzed: uppādana bhāvena uṭṭhitam uppatitam nāma hoti na vijjamānam pi a tad avatthanti tad avattha tā uppādaḥ iti veditabbo
translated: For when the fruit arises from it, the condition is called “arisen” in the sense of having arisen to the state of producing the fruit, not in the sense of being present but not in that state. Thus “arising” should be understood as the state of being in that state.🔽Herein, by the words “with the arising of this, that arises,” the Exalted One, showing the state of condition by the mere fact of presence,

original: Tattha satīti iminā vijjamānatāmattena paccayabhāvaṃ vadanto abyāpārataṃ paṭiccasamuppādassa
analyzed: tattha sati iti iminā vijjamāna tā mattena paccaya bhāvam vadantaḥ abyāpāratam paṭiccasamuppādassa

analyzed: dasseti uppādā ti uppatti dhamma tam asabba kāla bhāvitam phala uppatti abhimukha tañca dīpentaḥ  anicca tam paṭiccasamuppādassa dasseti sati na asati uppādāḥ na pana
translated: He shows the impermanence of the dependent origination by the words “arising” and so on, which signify the state of being subject to arising, and the state of being directed towards the arising of the fruit at all times.

original: avijjamānesu javati vijjamānesu na javatīti avijjā, vijjāya paṭipakkhāti avijjā,🔽sā “dukkhe aññāṇa”ntiādinā catubbidhā veditabbā. Paṭicca na vinā phalaṃ eti uppajjati🔽ceva pavattati cāti paccayo, upakārakattho vā paccayo. Avijjā ca sā paccayo cāti🔽avijjāpaccayo, tasmā avijjāpaccayā. Saṅkharontīti saṅkhārā, lokiyakusalākusalacetanā,
analyzed: a vijjamānesu javati vijjamānesu na javati iti avijjā vijjāya paṭipakkhā ati avijjā  sā dukkhe aññāṇa nti ādinā catubbidhā veditabbā paṭicca na vinā phalam eti uppajjati  ca iva pavattati ca ati paccayaḥ upakāraka atthaḥ vā paccayaḥ avijjā ca sā paccayaḥ ca ati  tasmai avijjā paccayā saṅkharonti iti saṅkhārāḥ lokiya kusala akusala cetanā
translated: It is ignorance because it does not hurry to the known and it does not hurry to the unknown. It is ignorance because it is the opposite of knowledge.🔽It should be understood as fourfold as “ignorance of suffering,” and so on.🔽It is a condition because it is not without fruit, it is not without result, it is not without effect.🔽It is a condition because it is a condition for the arising and occurrence of the fruit, or it is a condition because it is a helper.🔽It is ignorance and it is a condition,🔽therefore it is ignorance as condition.🔽They are formed, thus they are formations. They are the volition of the mundane profitable and unprofitable.

original: sā puññāpuññāneñjābhisaṅkhāravasena tividhā veditabbā. Vijānātīti viññāṇaṃ, taṃ lokiyavipākaviññāṇavasena🔽dvattiṃsavidhaṃ. Namatīti nāmaṃ, vedanādikkhandhattayaṃ. Ruppatīti rūpaṃ, bhūtarūpaṃ🔽cakkhādiupādārūpañca. Āyatati āyatañca saṃsāradukkhaṃ nayatīti āyatanaṃ. Phusatīti🔽phasso. Vedayatīti vedanā. Idampi dvayaṃ dvāravasena chabbidhaṃ, vipākavasena gahaṇe
analyzed: sā puñña apuñña aneñja abhisaṅkhāra vasena tividhā veditabbā vijānāti iti viññāṇam tam lokiya vipāka viññāṇa vasena 🔽dvattiṃsavidham namati iti nāmam vedanā ādi khandha ttayam ruppati iti rūpam bhūta rūpam 🔽cakkha ādi upādā rūpam ca āyatati āyatam ca saṃsāra dukkham nayati iti āyatanam phusati iti 🔽phassaḥ vedayati iti vedanā idam pi dvayam dvāra vasena chabbidham vipāka vasena gahaṇe
translated: It is ignorance because it does not hurry to the known, it hurries to the unknown. It is ignorance because it is the opposite of knowledge. It should be understood as fourfold as “ignorance of suffering,” etc. 1 It is a condition because it is not without fruit, it is not without an effect, it is not without occurrence, it is not without manifestation. Or a condition is what assists. And ignorance is that, thus it is ignorance as condition. Therefore it is said: “With ignorance as condition there are formations.” 2 They form , thus they are formations . They are mundane volition, both profitable and unprofitable. They should be understood as threefold as formations of merit, of demerit, and of an imperturbable kind. It cognizes , thus it is consciousness . It is of thirty-two kinds as mundane resultant consciousness. It bends , thus it is mentality . It is the three aggregates, feeling, etc. It is matter that is malleable , thus it is materiality . It is the four great primary elements and the materiality derived by clinging from the four primaries. It leads on the longings , thus it is a base . It touches , thus it is contact . It feels , thus it is feeling . This pair is sixfold as the six doors, and in the case of apprehending by way of resultants, it is of thirty-six kinds.

original: chattiṃsavidhaṃ. Paritassatīti taṇhā, sā kāmataṇhādivasena saṅkhepato tividhā, vitthārato
analyzed: chattiṃsavidham paritassati iti taṇhā sā kāma taṇhā ādi vasena saṅkhepataḥ tividhā vitthārato
translated: and it is of thirty-six kinds. 10 “He is anxious” : this is craving. It is threefold in brief as sense-desire craving, and so on.

original: aṭṭhuttarasatavidhā ca. Upādīyatīti upādānaṃ, taṃ kāmupādānādivasena catubbidhaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhuttara satavidhā ca upādīyati iti upādānam tam kāma upādāna ādi vasena catubbidham
translated: It is of one hundred and twenty-one kinds in detail.11 “He clings” : this is clinging. It is fourfold as sense-desire clinging, and so on.

original: Bhavati bhāvayati cāti bhavo, so kammūpapattibhedato duvidho. Jananaṃ jāti. Jīraṇaṃ
analyzed: bhavati bhāvayati ca ati saḥ kammūpapatti bhedataḥ duvidhaḥ
translated: “He becomes” : this is becoming. It is twofold as kamma-process becoming and rebirth-process becoming.12 “Generation” is birth. “Decay” is aging.

original: jarā. Maranti tenāti maraṇaṃ. Socanaṃ soko. Paridevanaṃ paridevo. Dukkhayatīti dukkhaṃ,
analyzed: jarā maranti tena ati maraṇam socanam sokaḥ paridevanam paridevaḥ dukkhayati iti dukkham
translated: “Death” is death. “Sorrow” is sorrow. “Lamentation” is lamentation. “Pain” is pain.

original: uppādaṭṭhitivasena dvedhā khaṇatīti dukkhaṃ. Dumanassa bhāvo domanassaṃ. Bhuso āyāso
analyzed: uppāda ṭṭhiti vasena dvedhā khaṇati iti dukkham dumanassa bhāvaḥ domanassam āyāso
translated: “Grief” is grief. “Despair” is despair. “Agitation” is agitation. “Distress” is distress. “Sorrow and lamentation” are sorrow and lamentation. “Pain, grief, and despair” are pain, grief, and despair. “This great mass of suffering” is this great mass of suffering.

original: upāyāso. Sambhavantīti nibbattanti. Na kevalañca sokādīhiyeva, atha kho sabbapadehi
analyzed: upāyāsaḥ sambhavanti iti nibbattanti na kevalam ca soka ādīhi yeva atha kho sabba padehi
translated: “Arises” : it comes to be born. And not only by sorrow, etc., but by all the terms

original: “sambhavantī”ti padassa yojanā kātabbā. Evañhi “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā sambhavantī”ti
analyzed: sambhavanti iti padassa yojanā kātabbā evam hi avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā sambhavanti iti
translated: “arises” should be construed. For in this way the distinction between condition and conditionally-arisen is shown by the words “With ignorance as condition there are formations.”

original: paccayapaccayuppannavavatthānaṃ dassitaṃ hoti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: paccaya paccaya uppanna vavatthānam dassitam hoti esa nayo sabbattha
translated: This method applies in all cases.

original: Tattha aññāṇalakkhaṇā avijjā, sammohanarasā, chādanapaccupaṭṭhānā, āsavapadaṭṭhānā.🔽Abhisaṅkharaṇalakkhaṇā saṅkhārā, āyūhanarasā, saṃvidahanapaccupaṭṭhānā, avijjāpadaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: tattha aññāṇa lakkhaṇā avijjā sammohana rasā chādana paccupaṭṭhānā āsava padaṭṭhānā  abhisaṅkharaṇa lakkhaṇā saṅkhārāḥ āyūhana rasā saṃvidahana paccupaṭṭhānā avijjā padaṭṭhānā
translated: Herein, ignorance has the characteristic of non-penetration. Its function is to confound. It is manifested as non-discernment. Its proximate cause is the taints.🔽Mentality-materiality has the characteristic of fabrication. Its function is to accumulate. It is manifested as the state of being put together. Its proximate cause is ignorance.

original: Vijānanalakkhaṇaṃ viññāṇaṃ, pubbaṅgamarasaṃ, paṭisandhipaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, saṅkhārapadaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: vijānana lakkhaṇam viññāṇam pubbaṅgama rasam paṭisandhi paccupaṭṭhānam saṅkhāra padaṭṭhānam
translated: Consciousness has the characteristic of cognizing. Its function is to precede. It is manifested as rebirth-linking. Its proximate cause is formations.

original: vatthārammaṇapadaṭṭhānaṃ vā. Namanalakkhaṇaṃ nāmaṃ, sampayogarasaṃ, avinibbhogapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ,🔽viññāṇapadaṭṭhānaṃ. Ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ rūpaṃ, vikiraṇarasaṃ, appaheyyabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ,🔽viññāṇapadaṭṭhānaṃ. Āyatanalakkhaṇaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, dassanādirasaṃ, vatthudvārabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: vattha ārammaṇa padaṭṭhānam vā namana lakkhaṇam nāmam sampayoga rasam a vinibbhoga paccupaṭṭhānam  viññāṇa padaṭṭhānam ruppana lakkhaṇam rūpam vikiraṇa rasam appaheyya bhāva paccupaṭṭhānam  viññāṇa padaṭṭhānam āyatana lakkhaṇam saḷāyatanam dassana ādi rasam vatthu dvāra bhāva paccupaṭṭhānam
translated: Or its proximate cause is the physical basis and object. Mentality has the characteristic of bending. Its function is to associate. It is manifested as non-division.🔽Its proximate cause is consciousness. Materiality has the characteristic of being molested. Its function is to scatter. It is manifested as the state of being not to be abandoned.🔽Its proximate cause is consciousness. The sixfold base has the characteristic of being a sense-sphere. Its function is to cause seeing, etc. It is manifested as the state of being a physical basis and a door.

original: nāmarūpapadaṭṭhānaṃ. Phusanalakkhaṇo phasso, saṅghaṭṭanaraso, saṅgatipaccupaṭṭhāno,
analyzed: nāma rūpa padaṭṭhānam phusana lakkhaṇaḥ phassaḥ saṅghaṭṭana raso saṅgati paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: Its proximate cause is mentality-materiality. Contact has the characteristic of touching. Its function is to impinge. It is manifested as the state of meeting.

original: saḷāyatanapadaṭṭhāno. Anubhavanalakkhaṇā vedanā, visayarasasambhogarasā, sukhadukkhapaccupaṭṭhānā,
analyzed: anubhavana lakkhaṇā vedanā visaya rasa sambhoga rasā sukha dukkha paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: Feeling has the characteristic of being sensed. Its function is to experience the taste of an object. It is manifested as the experience of pleasure and pain.

original: phassapadaṭṭhānā. Hetubhāvalakkhaṇā taṇhā, abhinandanarasā, atittibhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā,
analyzed: phassa padaṭṭhānā hetu bhāva lakkhaṇā taṇhā abhinandana rasā atittibhāva paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: It has contact as its proximate cause. Craving has the characteristic of being a cause. Its function is to delight in. It is manifested as non-contentment.

original: vedanāpadaṭṭhānā. Gahaṇalakkhaṇaṃ upādānaṃ, amuñcanarasaṃ, taṇhādaḷhattadiṭṭhipaccupaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: vedanā padaṭṭhānāḥ gahaṇa lakkhaṇam upādānam amuñcana rasam taṇhā daḷha tta diṭṭhi paccupaṭṭhānam
translated: It has feeling as its proximate cause. Clinging has the characteristic of grasping. Its function is not to let go. It is manifested as the intensification of craving and views.

original: taṇhāpadaṭṭhānaṃ. Kammakammaphalalakkhaṇo bhavo, bhavanabhāvanaraso, kusalākusalābyākatapaccupaṭṭhāno,
analyzed: taṇhā padaṭṭhānam kamma kamma phala lakkhaṇaḥ bhavaḥ bhavana bhāvana raso kusala akusala abyākata paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: It has craving as its proximate cause. Becoming has the characteristic of being kamma and its result. Its function is to bring about rebirth. It is manifested as the wholesome, the unwholesome, and the indeterminate.

original: upādānapadaṭṭhāno. Tattha tattha bhave paṭhamābhinibbattilakkhaṇā jāti, niyyātanarasā,
analyzed: upādāna padaṭṭhāno tattha tattha bhave paṭhama abhinibbatti lakkhaṇā jāti niyyātana rasā
translated: It has clinging as its proximate cause. Birth has the characteristic of first producing the aggregates in a particular state of existence. Its function is to bring about the appearance of the aggregates.

original: atītabhavato idhuppannapaccupaṭṭhānā, dukkhavicittatāpaccupaṭṭhānā vā. Khandhaparipākalakkhaṇā
analyzed: atīta bhavataḥ idha uppanna paccupaṭṭhānā dukkha vicitta tā paccupaṭṭhānā vā khandha paripāka lakkhaṇā
translated: It is manifested as the arising of the aggregates from the past to the present state of existence, or it is manifested as the variety of suffering.🔽Aging has the characteristic of maturing the aggregates. Its function is to lead to death. It is manifested as the destruction of youthfulness.

original: jarā, maraṇūpanayanarasā, yobbanavināsapaccupaṭṭhānā. Cutilakkhaṇaṃ maraṇaṃ, visaṃyogarasaṃ,
analyzed: jarā maraṇa upanayana rasā yobbana vināsa paccupaṭṭhānā cuti lakkhaṇam maraṇam visaṃyoga rasam
translated: Death has the characteristic of falling away. Its function is to cause the dissolution of the aggregates. It is manifested as the giving up of the aggregates.

original: gativippavāsapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ. Antonijjhānalakkhaṇo soko, cetaso nijjhānaraso, anusocanapaccupaṭṭhāno.
analyzed: gati vippavāsa paccupaṭṭhānam antonijjhāna lakkhaṇo soko cetasaḥ nijjhāna raso anusocana paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: Sorrow has the characteristic of inward burning. Its function is to burn the heart. Its manifestation is that of sorrowing.

original: Lālappanalakkhaṇo paridevo, guṇadosaparikittanaraso, sambhamapaccupaṭṭhāno. Kāyapīḷanalakkhaṇaṃ🔽dukkhaṃ, duppaññānaṃ domanassakaraṇarasaṃ, kāyikābādhapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ. Cittapīḷanalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: lālappana lakkhaṇaḥ paridevaḥ guṇa dosa parikittana raso sambhama paccupaṭṭhāno kāya pīḷana lakkhaṇam  dukkham duppaññānam domanassa karaṇa rasam kāyika ābādha paccupaṭṭhānam citta pīḷana lakkhaṇam
translated: Lamentation has the characteristic of uttering cries of distress. Its function is to utter cries of blame about good and bad points. Its manifestation is the state of being in a bad plight.🔽Pain has the characteristic of afflicting the body. Its function is to cause grief to the unwise. Its manifestation is bodily affliction.

original: domanassaṃ, manovighātanarasaṃ, mānasabyādhipaccupaṭṭhānaṃ. Cittaparidahanalakkhaṇo
analyzed: domanassam manaḥ vighātana rasam mānasa byādhi paccupaṭṭhānam citta paridahana lakkhaṇo
translated: Grief has the characteristic of afflicting the mind. Its function is to torment the mind. Its manifestation is mental affliction.

original: upāyāso, nitthunanaraso, visādapaccupaṭṭhāno. Evamete avijjādayo lakkhaṇāditopi veditabbāti.
analyzed: upāyāsaḥ nitthuna na rasaḥ visāda paccupaṭṭhāno evam ete avijjā ādayaḥ lakkhaṇa āditaḥ pi veditabbā ati
translated: Vexation has the characteristic of burning the mind. Its function is to dry up. Its manifestation is despondency. This is how they should be understood as to characteristic, etc.

original: Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana sabbākārasampannaṃ vinicchayaṃ icchantena sammohavinodaniyā
analyzed: ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana sabba ākāra sampannam vinicchayam icchantena sammoha vinodaniyā
translated: This is the brief account here. But one who wants a detailed account should consult the Description of the Dependent Origination in the Paṭisambhidā,

original: vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāya gahetabbo.
analyzed: vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathāya gahetabbo
translated: and the commentary to the Vibhaṅga called the Sammohavinodani.

original: Evanti niddiṭṭhassa nidassanaṃ, tena avijjādīheva kāraṇehi, na issaranimmānādīhīti
analyzed: evam ti niddiṭṭhassa nidassanam tena avijjā ādīhi iva kāraṇehi na issara nimmāna ādīhi iti
translated: So: This is the indication of what has been analysed above. By ignorance, etc., as the causes, not by a Supreme God, etc., as causes.

original: dasseti. Etassāti yathāvuttassa. Kevalassāti asammissassa sakalassa vā. Dukkhakkhandhassāti
analyzed: dassa iti etassa ati yathā vuttassa kevalassa ati asammissassa sakalassa vā dukkha kkhandhassa ati
translated: He shows. Of this: of what has been said. Entire: unmixed, or complete. Mass of suffering:

original: dukkhasamūhassa, na sattassa, nāpi jīvassa, nāpi subhasukhādīnaṃ. Samudayo hotīti
analyzed: dukkha samūhassa na sattassa na api jīvassa na api subha sukha ādīnam samudayaḥ hoti iti
translated: of the aggregate of suffering, not of a being, nor of a life-principle, nor of the pleasant, painful, etc. Origination:

original: nibbatti sambhavati.🔽Etamatthaṃ viditvāti yvāyaṃ avijjādivasena saṅkhārādikassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo
analyzed: nibbatti sambhavati  etam attham viditvā iti yvā ayam avijjā ādi vasena saṅkhāra ādikassa dukkha kkhandhassa samudayaḥ
translated: appearance, coming-to-be.

original: hotīti vutto, sabbākārena etamatthaṃ viditvā. Tāyaṃ velāyanti tāyaṃ tassa atthassa🔽viditavelāyaṃ. Imaṃ udānaṃ udānesīti imaṃ tasmiṃ atthe vidite hetuno ca hetusamuppannadhammassa
analyzed: hoti iti vuttaḥ sabba ākārena etam attham viditvā tāyam velāyanti tāyam tassa atthassa  vidita velāyam imam udānam udānesi iti imam tasmin atthe vidite hetuno ca hetu samuppanna dhammassa
translated: Having understood the matter thus: having understood in all its modes the matter stated thus: “The origination of the aggregate of suffering beginning with formations is through ignorance” ,

original: ca pajānanāya ānubhāvadīpakaṃ “yadā have pātubhavantī”tiādikaṃ somanassasampayuttañāṇasamuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: ca pajānanāya ānubhāva dīpakam yadā have pātubhavanti iti ādikam somanassa sampayutta ñāṇa samuṭṭhānam
translated: At that time: at the time of understanding that matter thus. This exalted utterance: this utterance accompanied by joy, which is the outcome of knowledge, and which is expressive of the power of understanding the cause and the states originated by the cause, namely, the stanza beginning with the words “When there is a manifestation of” ,

original: udānaṃ udānesi, attamanavācaṃ nicchāresīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: udānam udānesi atta mana vācam nicchāresi iti vuttam hoti
translated: he uttered; what is meant is that he uttered the words of joy.

original: Tassattho – yadāti yasmiṃ kāle. Haveti byattanti imasmiṃ atthe nipāto. Keci pana
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ yadā iti yasmin kāle have iti byattanti imasmin atthe nipāto keci pana
translated: The meaning is this: at what time, indeed, is the term “have” in the sense of “are fit” . But some say that the word “have” is used in the sense of “there is” .

original: “haveti āhave yuddhe”ti atthaṃ vadanti, “yodhetha māraṃ paññāvudhenā”ti vacanato🔽kilesamārena yujjhanasamayeti tesaṃ adhippāyo. Pātubhavantīti uppajjanti. Dhammāti
analyzed: hava iti āhave yuddha iti attham vadanti yodhetha māram paññāvudhena ati vacanato  kilesa mārena yujjhana samaye iti tesam adhippāyaḥ pātubhavanti iti uppajjanti dhammā ati
translated: Their intention is that it is the same as the engagement in battle with the defilement-Mara, since it is said, “Fight with Mara with the sword of wisdom” .

original: anulomapaccayākārapaṭivedhasādhakā bodhipakkhiyadhammā. Atha vā pātubhavantīti pakāsenti,🔽abhisamayavasena byattā pākaṭā honti. Dhammāti catuariyasaccadhammā, ātāpo vuccati🔽kilesasantāpanaṭṭhena vīriyaṃ. Ātāpinoti sammappadhānavīriyavato. Jhāyatoti ārammaṇūpanijjhānena
analyzed: anuloma paccaya ākāra paṭivedha sādhakāḥ bodhi pakkhiya dhammāḥ atha vā pātubhavanti iti pakāsenti  abhisamaya vasena byattā pākaṭāḥ honti dhammā ati catu ariya sacca dhammā ātāpaḥ vuccati  kilesa santāpana ṭṭhena vīriyam ātāpino ti sammappadhāna vīriyavataḥ jhāyato ti ārammaṇa upanijjhānena
translated: “Manifest” : arise. “The Dhamma” : the ideas that are the requisites of enlightenment, which bring about the penetration of the conditions in the form of conformity. Or alternatively, “manifest” : reveal,

original: ‘dhammadāyādā me, bhikkhave, bhavatha, mā āmisadāyādā”’tiādīsu kathane. Idhāpi kathane🔽eva daṭṭhabbo, tena ayampi udāno bhāsitoti attho. Itīti evaṃ. Me sutanti padadvayassa🔽attho nidānavaṇṇanāyaṃ sabbākārato vuttoyeva. Pubbe “evaṃ me suta”nti nidānavasena🔽vuttoyeva hi attho idha nigamanavasena “iti me suta”nti puna vutto. Vuttasseva hi
analyzed: dhamma dāyādāḥ me bhikkhave bhavatha mā āmisa dāyādā ati ādīsu kathane idha api kathane 🔽eva daṭṭhabbaḥ tena ayam pi udānaḥ bhāsito ti atthaḥ iti iti evam me suta nti pada dvayassa 🔽atthaḥ nidāna vaṇṇanā ayam sabba ākārataḥ vuttaḥ yā iva pubbe evam me sutam ti nidāna vasena 🔽vuttaḥ iva hi atthaḥ idha nigamana vasena iti me sutan ti punar vuttaḥ vuttassa iva hi
translated: In the first, in the sense of “to be sown” . In the second, in the sense of “to be made equal” by means of the eight-branched plough, etc. In the third, in the sense of “to live” , as in the passage: “I live with my hair and beard grown long, clothed in a rough cloak of antelope hide, subsisting on what is given from house to house, and making my bed in the open” . In the fourth, in the sense of “to be released” , as in the passage: “The withered leaf falls from the stalk without regret” . In the fifth, in the sense of “to be uttered” , as in the passage: “The song is sung, the speech is spoken” . In the sixth, in the sense of “to be uttered” in the sense of “to be recited” , as in the passage: “The Pārāyaṇa has been uttered” . In the seventh, in the sense of “to be uttered” in the sense of “to be spoken” , as in the passage: “It has been said by the Blessed One: ‘Monks, be recipients of my Dhamma, not recipients of material gifts’ ” . Here too the word should be understood in the sense of “to be spoken” . Thus the meaning of the expression iti me sutaṃ is to be understood in this way. Thus: in this way. By me: the meaning of the two words evaṃ me has been given in full in the commentary on the nidāna.

original: ariyamaggena avijjāya anavasesanirodhā, anusayappahānavasena aggamaggena avijjāya🔽accantasamugghāṭatoti attho. Yadipi heṭṭhimamaggehi pahīyamānā avijjā accantasamugghāṭavaseneva🔽pahīyati, tathāpi na anavasesato pahīyati. Apāyagāminiyā hi avijjā paṭhamamaggena
analyzed: ariya maggena avijjāya anavasesa nirodhā anusaya ppahāna vasena agga maggena avijjāya  accanta samugghāṭato ti atthaḥ yadi api heṭṭhima maggehi pahīyamānāḥ avijjāḥ accanta samugghāṭa vasena iva  pahīyati tathā api na anavasesataḥ pahīyati apāya gāminiyā hi avijjā paṭhama maggena

For ignorance leading to the states of woe is abandoned by the first path;

original: pahīyati. Tathā sakideva imasmiṃ loke sabbattha ca anariyabhūmiyaṃ upapattipaccayabhūtā
analyzed: pahīyati tathā sakidevaḥ imasmin loke sabbattha ca anariya bhūmiyam upapatti paccaya bhūtā
translated: and so on up to ignorance leading to the plane of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. But ignorance that is the condition for rebirth in this world and in all the unwholesome planes of existence is abandoned

original: avijjā yathākkamaṃ dutiyatatiyamaggehi pahīyati, na itarāti. Arahattamaggeneva hi
analyzed: avijjā yathākkamam dutiya tatiya maggehi pahīyati na arahatta maggena iva hi
translated: Ignorance is abandoned by the second and third paths respectively, not by the other.🔽For it is only by the path of arahatship that it is abandoned without remainder.

original: sā anavasesaṃ pahīyatīti. Saṅkhāranirodhoti saṅkhārānaṃ anuppādanirodho hoti. Evaṃ
analyzed: sā anavasesam pahīyati iti saṅkhāra nirodhaḥ iti saṅkhārānam anuppāda nirodhaḥ hoti evam
translated: The cessation of formations: the non-arising of formations.

original: niruddhānaṃ pana saṅkhārānaṃ nirodhā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇādīnañca nirodhā nāmarūpādīni
analyzed: niruddhānam pana saṅkhārānam nirodhāḥ viññāṇam viññāṇa ādīnam ca nirodhāḥ nāma rūpa ādīni
translated: When formations have ceased in this way, consciousness, etc., also cease.

original: niruddhāni eva hontīti dassetuṃ “saṅkhāranirodhā viññāṇanirodho”tiādiṃ vatvā “evametassa
analyzed: niruddhāni eva honti iti dassetum saṅkhāra nirodhā viññāṇa nirodho tiādim vatvā evam etassa
translated: To show this, the text says: “With the cessation of formations, the cessation of consciousness” and so on.🔽And it concludes: “This is the cessation of this whole mass of suffering.”

original: kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotī”ti vuttaṃ. Tattha yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayameva.🔽Apicettha kiñcāpi “avijjānirodhā saṅkhāranirodho, saṅkhāranirodhā viññāṇanirodho”ti
analyzed: kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodhaḥ hoti iti vuttam tattha yat vattabbam tat heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva  apica ittha kiñca api avijjā nirodhā saṅkhāra nirodho saṅkhāra nirodhā viññāṇa nirodho ti
translated: Here what is to be said has already been said above.

original: ettāvatāpi sakalassa dukkhakkhandhassa anavasesato nirodho vutto hoti, tathāpi yathā
analyzed: ettāvatā api sakalassa dukkhakkhandhassa anavasesataḥ nirodhaḥ vuttaḥ hoti tathā api yathā
translated: Here, although the cessation of the whole mass of suffering without remainder is stated by the words: “With the cessation of ignorance, the cessation of formations; with the cessation of formations, the cessation of consciousness,”🔽nevertheless, just as in the case of the exposition in direct order,

analyzed: anulome yassa yassa paccaya dhammassa atthitāya yaḥ yaḥ paccaya uppanna dhammo na nirujjhati
translated: whereby the non-cessation of any conditioned thing is stated to be due to the existence of any conditioned thing,

original: pavattati evāti imassa atthassa dassanatthaṃ “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā…pe… samudayo🔽hotī”ti vuttaṃ. Evaṃ tappaṭipakkhato tassa tassa paccayadhammassa abhāve so so paccayuppannadhammo🔽nirujjhati nappavattatīti dassanatthaṃ idha “avijjānirodhā saṅkhāranirodho, saṅkhāranirodhā
analyzed: pavattati eva ati imassa atthassa dassana ttham avijjā paccayā saṅkhāra āpe samudayo  hoti iti vuttam evam tad paṭipakkhato tassa tassa paccaya dhammassa abhāve saḥ so paccaya uppanna dhammo  nirujjhati na ppavattati iti dassana ttham idha avijjā nirodhā saṅkhāra nirodho saṅkhāra nirodhā
translated: and when it does not occur, then it ceases. In order to show the meaning of this, it is said: “With the cessation of ignorance as condition, formations cease … and so on up to … the cessation of the mass of suffering comes about.”

original: viññāṇanirodho…pe… dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotī”ti vuttaṃ, na pana anulome viya🔽kālattayapariyāpannassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodhadassanatthaṃ. Anāgatasseva hi ariyamaggabhāvanāya
analyzed: viññāṇa nirodha upe dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hoti iti vuttam na pana anulome viya  kāla ttaya pariyāpannassa dukkha kkhandhassa nirodha dassana ttham anāgatassa iva hi ariya magga bhāvanāya
translated: In order to show that when there is the absence of each condition, the conditioned states that would have arisen through that condition do not arise, it is said here: “With the cessation of ignorance, the cessation of formations comes about; with the cessation of formations, the cessation of consciousness comes about … and so on up to … the cessation of the mass of suffering comes about.” But this is not said in order to show the cessation of the mass of suffering included in the three times, as it is in the case of the exposition in direct order.

original: asati uppajjanārahassa dukkhakkhandhassa ariyamaggabhāvanāya nirodho icchitoti ayampi viseso veditabbo.
analyzed: asati uppajjana arahassa dukkhakkhandhassa ariya magga bhāvanāya nirodhaḥ icchito ti ayam pi visesaḥ veditabbo
translated: For it is the cessation of the mass of suffering that is due to arise in the future, which is capable of arising, that is accepted as the cessation of the mass of suffering through the development of the noble path. This too is a distinction that should be understood.
