analyzed: sugata bojjhaṅgā ati  idam avoca bhagavā attamanaḥ āyasmā mahākassapaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandi vuṭṭhahi ca āyasmā mahākassapo tamhā ābādhā tathā pahīnaḥ ca āyasmataḥ mahākassapassa saḥ ābādhaḥ ahosi iti
translated: Well-Farer, the factors of Awakening.”🔽The Fortunate One said this, and after saying this, the Teacher, the Fortunate One, got up from his seat and went into his living quarters. Then after that not long after the Fortunate One had gone, the venerable Mahā Kassapa recovered from that affliction, and that venerable one’s affliction was abandoned.

original: Tena vuttaṃ – “atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo aparena samayena tamhā ābādhā vuṭṭhāsī”ti.
analyzed: tena vuttam atha kho āyasmā mahākassapaḥ aparena samayena tamhā ābādhā vuṭṭhāsi iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “Then after that not long after the Fortunate One had gone, the venerable Mahā Kassapa recovered from that affliction, and that venerable one’s affliction was abandoned.”

original: Etadahosīti pubbe gelaññadivasesu saddhivihārikehi upanītaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjitvā
analyzed: etat ahosi iti pubbe gelañña divasesu saddhivihārikehi upanītam piṇḍapātam paribhuñjitvā
translated: This was what happened: On the previous days of his illness, he had eaten the alms food brought by his pupils and had remained in the monastery.

original: vihāre eva ahosi. Athassa tamhā ābādhā vuṭṭhitassa etaṃ “yaṃnūnāhaṃ rājagahaṃ piṇḍāya
analyzed: vihāre eva ahosi athassa tamhā ābādhā vuṭṭhitassa etam yaṃnūna aham rājagaham piṇḍāya
translated: Then, after he had recovered from that affliction, the thought occurred to him, “Suppose I were to enter Rājagaha for alms?”

original: paviseyya”nti parivitakko ahosi. Pañcamattāni devatāsatānīti sakkassa devarañño paricārikā🔽pañcasatā kakuṭapādiniyo accharāyo. Ussukkaṃ āpannāni hontīti therassa piṇḍapātaṃ🔽dassāmāti pañcapiṇḍapātasatāni sajjetvā suvaṇṇabhājanehi ādāya antarāmagge ṭhatvā,
analyzed: paviseyyanti parivitakkaḥ ahosi pañcamattāni devatā satāni iti sakkassa deva rañño paricārikā  pañca satā kakuṭa pādiniyaḥ accharāyaḥ ussukkam āpannāni honti iti therassa piṇḍapātam  dassāma ati pañca piṇḍapāta satāni sajjetvā suvaṇṇa bhājanehi ādāya antara āmagge ṭhatvā
translated: Five hundred devatās: five hundred celestial nymphs, Kakudha’s feet, who were attendants of Sakka, the deva-king.🔽They were eager: they had prepared five hundred alms offerings, taking them in golden bowls, and were standing on the road, saying, “Venerable sir, accept this alms food; do us the favour.”

original: “bhante, imaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ gaṇhatha, saṅgahaṃ no karothā”ti vadamānā piṇḍapātadāne
analyzed: bhante imam piṇḍapātam gaṇhatha saṅgaham no karotha ati vadamānā piṇḍapāta dāne
translated: They were intent on giving alms food.

original: yuttappayuttāni honti. Tena vuttaṃ “āyasmato mahākassapassa piṇḍapātappaṭilābhāyā”ti.
analyzed: yutta ppayuttāni honti tena vuttam āyasmataḥ mahākassapassa piṇḍapāta paṭilābhāya ati
translated: That is why it is said: “for the obtaining of alms food by the venerable elder Mahā Kassapa.”

original: Sakko kira devarājā therassa cittappavattiṃ ñatvā tā accharāyo uyyojesi “gacchatha
analyzed: sakkaḥ kira devarājā therassa citta ppavattim ñatvā tāḥ accharāyaḥ uyyojesi gacchatha
translated: Sakka, it seems, the deva-king, having known the elder’s thought, sent those celestial nymphs, saying, “Go

original: tumhe ayyassa mahākassapattherassa piṇḍapātaṃ datvā attano patiṭṭhaṃ karothā”ti.
analyzed: tumhe ayyassa mahākassapa therassa piṇḍapātam datvā attanaḥ patiṭṭham karotha ati
translated: “You should give alms food to the venerable elder Mahā Kassapa and make your own foundation.”

original: Evaṃ hissa ahosi “imāsu sabbāsu gatāsu kadāci ekissāpi hatthato piṇḍapātaṃ thero
analyzed: evam hi ssa ahosi imāsu sabbāsu gatāsu kadāci ekissa api hatthato piṇḍapātam thero
translated: For he thought: “If all these go, perhaps the elder will accept alms food from the hand of one of them,

original: paṭiggaṇheyya, taṃ tassā bhavissati dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti. Paṭikkhipi thero,
analyzed: paṭiggaṇheyya tam tassā bhavissati dīgharattam hitāya sukhāya ti paṭikkhipi theraḥ
translated: and that will be for her welfare and happiness for a long time.” The elder refused,

original: “bhante, mayhaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ gaṇhatha, mayhaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ gaṇhathā”ti vadantiyo “gacchatha🔽tumhe katapuññā mahābhogā, ahaṃ duggatānaṃ saṅgahaṃ karissāmī”ti vatvā, “bhante,
analyzed: bhante mayham piṇḍapātam gaṇhatha mayham piṇḍapātam gaṇhatha ati vadantiyaḥ gacchatha  tumhe kata puññāḥ mahā bhogāḥ aham duggatānam saṅgaham karissāmi iti vatvā bhante
translated: “Take my alms food, venerable sirs, take my alms food,” they said. “Go away,

original: mā no nāsetha, saṅgahaṃ no karothā”ti vadantiyo punapi paṭikkhipitvā punapi apagantuṃ
analyzed: mā naḥ na āsetha saṅgaham naḥ karotha ati vadantiyaḥ punapi paṭikkhipitvā punapi apagantum
translated: you have made merit, you will be very wealthy. I shall look after the poor.” “Do not abandon us, venerable sir, look after us.”

original: anicchamānā yācantiyo “na attano pamāṇaṃ jānātha, apagacchathā”ti vatvā accharaṃ
analyzed: an icchamānāḥ yācantiyaḥ na pamāṇam jānātha apagacchatha ati vatvā accharam
translated: Though he refused again and again, they would not go away. “You do not know your own measure. Go away.”

original: pahari. Tā therassa accharāsaddaṃ sutvā santajjitā ṭhātuṃ asakkontiyo palāyitvā devalokameva
analyzed: tā therassa accharā saddam sutvā santajjitāḥ ṭhātum a sakkontiyaḥ palāyitvā deva lokam eva
translated: He snapped his fingers. They were frightened by the sound of his fingers and, unable to stand there, they fled and went to the world of the gods.

original: gatā. Tena vuttaṃ – “pañcamattāni devatāsatāni paṭikkhipitvā”ti.
analyzed: gatā tena vuttam pañcamattāni devatā satāni paṭikkhipitvā ati
translated: “Having refused five hundred devatās” : thus it was said.🔽“In the morning time” : in the morning, at one time, at one occasion.

original: Pubbaṇhasamayanti pubbaṇhe ekaṃ samayaṃ, ekasmiṃ kāle. Nivāsetvāti vihāranivāsanaparivattanavasena
analyzed: pubbaṇha samayam ti pubbaṇhe ekam samayam ekasmin kāle nivāsetvā ati vihāra nivāsana parivattana vasena
translated: “Having dressed” : having dressed firmly by putting on the inner and outer robes.

original: nivāsanaṃ daḷhaṃ nivāsetvā. Pattacīvaramādāyāti cīvaraṃ pārupitvā pattaṃ hatthena🔽gahetvā. Piṇḍāya pāvisīti piṇḍapātatthāya pāvisi. Daliddavisikhāti duggatamanussānaṃ
analyzed: nivāsanam daḷham nivāsetvā patta cīvaram ādāya ati cīvaram pārupitvā pattam hatthena  gahetvā piṇḍāya pāvisi iti piṇḍapāta atthāya pāvisi dalidda visikhā ati duggata manussānam
translated: “Having taken bowl and robe” : having put on the robe and having taken the bowl in the hand.🔽“He entered for alms” : he entered for the purpose of alms.🔽“The poor quarter” : the dwelling place of the unfortunate people.🔽“The wretched quarter” : the dwelling place of the miserable people who have fallen into poverty.

original: vasanokāso. Kapaṇavisikhāti bhogapārijuññappattiyā dīnamanussānaṃ vāso. Pesakāravisikhāti🔽tantavāyavāso. Addasā kho bhagavāti kathaṃ addasa? “Ābādhā vuṭṭhito mama putto kassapo
analyzed: vasanokāsaḥ kapaṇa visikhā ati bhoga pārijuñña ppattiyā dīna manussānam vāso pesakāra visikhā ati  tantavāya vāsaḥ addasā kho bhagavā ati katham addasa ābādhā vuṭṭhitaḥ mama putto kassapo
translated: “The weavers’ quarter” : the dwelling place of the weavers.🔽“The Blessed One saw” : how did he see? The Blessed One, sitting in the Bamboo Grove, saw with his divine eye,🔽reflecting thus: “My son Kassapa, having recovered from his illness,

original: kinnu kho karotī”ti āvajjento veḷuvane nisinno eva bhagavā dibbacakkhunā addasa.
analyzed: kin nu kho karoti iti āvajjentaḥ veḷuvane nisinnaḥ eva bhagavā dibba cakkhunā addasa
translated: what is he doing?”

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti yāyaṃ āyasmato mahākassapassa pañcahi accharāsatehi upanītaṃ
analyzed: etam attham viditvā ati yāyam āyasmataḥ mahākassapassa pañcahi accharāsatehi upanītam
translated: “Having known this meaning” : this was brought by five hundred celestial nymphs to the venerable Mahā Kassapa.

original: anekasūpaṃ anekabyañjanaṃ dibbapiṇḍapātaṃ paṭikkhipitvā kapaṇajanānuggahappaṭipatti
analyzed: aneka sūpam aneka byañjanam dibba piṇḍapātam paṭikkhipitvā kapaṇa jana anuggaha ppaṭipatti
translated: and the practice of giving alms to the poor, having refused divine food and drink with many a soup and many a sauce,

original: vuttā, etamatthaṃ jānitvā. Imaṃ udānanti imaṃ paramappicchatādassanamukhena khīṇāsavassa🔽tādībhāvānubhāvadīpakaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.🔽Tattha anaññaposinti aññaṃ posetīti aññaposī, na aññaposī anaññaposī, attanā posetabbassa🔽aññassa abhāvena adutiyo, ekakoti attho. Tena therassa subharataṃ dasseti. Thero
analyzed: vuttāḥ etam attham jānitvā imam udānanti imam parama piccha tā dassana mukhena khīṇāsavassa  tādībhāva anubhāva dīpakam udānam  tattha an añña posinti aññam poseti iti añña posī na añña posī an añña posī attanā posetabbassa  aññassa abhāvena adutiyaḥ ekako ti attho tena therassa subharatam dasseti thero
translated: having understood this matter, he uttered this exalted utterance.

original: hi kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena ca piṇḍapātena attānameva posento
analyzed: hi kāya parihārikena cīvarena kucchi parihārikena ca piṇḍapātena attānam eva posento
translated: Herein, one who supports another is an other-supporter, one who is not an other- supporter is a non-other-supporter. Because there is no other to be supported, he is not a companion, the meaning is, he is alone. With this he shows that the Elder was easy to support. For the Elder, by means of the robe that is the requisite for the body and by means of the alms food that is the requisite for the stomach, supported himself alone,

original: paramappiccho hutvā viharati, aññaṃ ñātimittādīsu kañci na poseti katthaci alaggabhāvato.
analyzed: param appicchaḥ hutvā viharati aññam ñāti mitta ādīsu kañci na poseti katthaci alagga bhāvato
translated: and he lived with supreme fewness of wishes, not supporting anyone else, not a single relative or friend or anyone else, because he was unattached anywhere.

original: Atha vā aññena aññatarena posetabbatāya abhāvato anaññaposī. Yo hi ekasmiṃyeva paccayadāyake
analyzed: atha vā aññena aññatarena posetabba tāya abhāvataḥ anaññaposī yaḥ hi ekasmiṃ yeva paccaya dāyake
translated: Or alternatively, he is a non-other-supporter because there is no need to support him by anyone else, by anyone at all. For the Elder,

original: paṭibaddhacatupaccayo so anaññaposī nāma na hoti ekāyattavuttito. Thero pana “yathāpi
analyzed: paṭibaddha catu paccayo so anaññaposī nāma na hoti eka āyatta vuttito thero pana yathā api
translated: He is not independent, but dependent on others for his four requisites. But the elder, “As a bird cannot fly with one wing,🔽

original: bhamaro puppha”nti gāthāya vuttanayena jaṅghābalaṃ nissāya piṇḍāya caranto kulesu
analyzed: bhamaro pupphanti gāthāya vutta nayena jaṅghā balam nissāya piṇḍāya carantaḥ kulesu
translated: He is not a “one-bowl man” in the sense of being dependent on others for his living. But the Elder, as described in the verse, “Like a bee that alights” , went for alms by his own effort, and he lived on miscellaneous alms.

original: niccanavo hutvā missakabhattena yāpeti. Tathā hi naṃ bhagavā candūpamappaṭipadāya🔽thomesi. Aññātanti abhiññātaṃ, yathābhuccaguṇehi patthaṭayasaṃ, teneva vā anaññaposibhāvena
analyzed: nicca navaḥ hutvā missaka bhattena yāpeti tathā hi nam bhagavā candu upama paṭipadāya  aññātam ti abhiññātam yathābhucca guṇehi tena iva vā
translated: For the Blessed One extolled him as a model for the moderate practice of the proper amount in eating.

original: appicchatāsantuṭṭhitāhi ñātaṃ. Atha vā aññātanti sabbaso pahīnataṇhatāya lābhasakkārasilokanikāmanahetu
analyzed: appiccha tā santuṭṭhi tāhi ñātam atha vā aññātam ti sabbaso pahīna taṇha tāya lābha sakkāra siloka nikāmana hetu
translated: “Well known” : well known for his virtues as they really are, or well known for his contentment and fewness of wishes by reason of his not being a “one-bowl man.” Or alternatively, “well known” means not known for making himself known for the sake of gain, honour, and renown, because his craving had been completely abandoned.

original: attānaṃ jānāpanavasena na ñātaṃ. Avītataṇho hi pāpiccho kuhakatāya sambhāvanādhippāyena
analyzed: attānam jānāpana vasena na ñātam a vīta taṇhaḥ hi pāpa icchaḥ kuhaka tāya sambhāvanā adhippāyena
translated: For a lustful man of evil desires makes himself known through his desire for gain, honour, and renown by means of hypocrisy.

original: attānaṃ jānāpeti. Dantanti chaḷaṅgupekkhāvasena indriyesu uttamadamanena dantaṃ.
analyzed: attānam jānāpeti dantam ti chaḷaṅgu pekkhā vasena indriyesu uttama damanena dantam
translated: “Self-controlled” : self-controlled by the highest control of the faculties by means of the six kinds of equanimity.

original: Sāre patiṭṭhitanti vimuttisāre avaṭṭhitaṃ, asekkhasīlakkhandhādike vā sīlādisāre
analyzed: sāre patiṭṭhitanti vimutti sāre avaṭṭhitam asekkha sīla kkhandha ādike vā sīla ādi sāre
translated: “Steadfast” : steadfast in the core of freedom, or steadfast in the core of virtue, etc., consisting of the aggregates of virtue, etc., of a non-returner.

original: patiṭṭhitaṃ. Khīṇāsavaṃ vantadosanti kāmāsavādīnaṃ catunnaṃ āsavānaṃ anavasesaṃ pahīnattā🔽khīṇāsavaṃ. Tato eva rāgādidosānaṃ sabbaso vantattā vantadosaṃ. Tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇanti
analyzed: patiṭṭhitam khīṇa āsavam kāma āsava ādīnam catunnam āsavānam anavasesam pahīna ttā  khīṇāsavam tatas eva rāga ādi dosānam sabbasas vanta ttā vanta dosam tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa nti
translated: He is established. He has destroyed cankers : he has abandoned without remainder the four cankers consisting of the canker of sense desire, etc.

original: taṃ yathāvuttaguṇaṃ paramatthabrāhmaṇaṃ ahaṃ brāhmaṇanti vadāmīti. Idhāpi heṭṭhā
analyzed: tam yathā vutta guṇam paramattha brāhmaṇam aham brāhmaṇa nti vadāmi iti idha api heṭṭhā
translated: He is one who has destroyed cankers. And because he has completely vomited out greed and hate, he is one who has vomited out greed and hate. I call him a brahmin : I call him a brahmin in the ultimate sense, endowed with the aforesaid qualities.

original: vuttanayeneva desanānānattaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vutta nayena iva desanā nānattam veditabbam
translated: Here too the variety of teaching should be understood in the way already described.

original: Chaṭṭhasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: chaṭṭha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the sixth sutta is finished.

original: 7. Ajakalāpakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ajakalāpaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The sutta on Ajakalāpaka

original: 7. Sattame pāvāyanti evaṃnāmake mallarājūnaṃ nagare. Ajakalāpake cetiyeti ajakalāpakena
analyzed: sattame evaṃnāmake mallarājūnam nagare aja kalāpake cetiyā iti aja kalāpakena
translated: In the town named Pāvā: in the town of the Malla kings named Pāvā.

original: nāma yakkhena pariggahitattā “ajakalāpaka”nti laddhanāme manussānaṃ cittīkataṭṭhāne.
analyzed: nāma yakkhena pariggahita ttā ajakalāpakanti laddha nāme manussānam cittīkata ṭṭhāne
translated: At Ajakalāpaka Shrine: a shrine that had been dedicated to the yakkha named Ajakalāpaka.

original: So kira yakkho aje kalāpe katvā bandhanena ajakoṭṭhāsena saddhiṃ baliṃ paṭicchati,
analyzed: saḥ kira yakkhaḥ aje kalāpe katvā bandhanena ajakoṭṭhāsena saddhim balim paṭicchati

original: Yasmā pana so saddo “akkula pakkula” iti iminā ākārena sattānaṃ sotapathaṃ agamāsi,🔽tasmā tassa anukaraṇavasena “akkulo pakkulo”ti, yakkhassa ca tassaṃ nigghosanicchāraṇāyaṃ
analyzed: yasmā pana saḥ saddaḥ akkula pakkula iti iminā ākārena sattānam sota patham agamāsi  tasmā tassa anukaraṇa vasena akkulo pakkuloti yakkhassa ca
translated: But because the sound reached the ears of beings in the form of the words “akkula pakkula,”🔽the commentators have taken the word “akkula pakkula” as a reduplication and have given the meaning of “akkula pakkula” as “not confused, not muddled.”

original: akkulapakkulakaraṇaṃ atthīti katvā “akkulapakkulikaṃ akāsī”ti saṅgahaṃ āropayiṃsu.🔽Keci pana “ākulabyākula iti padadvayassa pariyāyābhidhānavasena akkulo bakkuloti
analyzed: akkula pakkula karaṇam atthi iti katvā akkula pakkulikam akāsi iti saṅgaham āropayiṃsu  keci pana ākula byākulaḥ iti pada dvayassa pariyāya abhidhāna vasena akkulaḥ
translated: And they have given the meaning of “akkula pakkula” as “not confused, not muddled” because the sound of the yakkha’s cry was not confused or muddled.🔽But some say that the word “akkula pakkula” is used as a reduplication of the two words “ākula byākula” in the way in which “ekaṃ ekakaṃ” is used.

original: ayaṃ saddo vutto”ti vadanti yathā “ekaṃ ekaka”nti. Yasmā ekavāraṃ jāto paṭhamuppattivaseneva🔽nibbattattā ākuloti ādiattho ākāro, tassa ca kakārāgamaṃ katvā rassattaṃ katanti.
analyzed: ayam saddo vutto ti vadanti yathā ekam ekakam iti yasmai eka vāram jātaḥ paṭhama uppatti vasena iva  nibbatta ttā ākulaḥ ti ādi atthaḥ ākāro tassa ca kakāra āgamam katvā rassattam katanti
translated: And they say that the meaning of “akkula pakkula” is “not confused, not muddled,” taking the word “akkula pakkula” as having the form “akkula” with the addition of the letter “k” and the augment “a” to make it a stem noun.🔽But “ākula” is the form in the sense of “confused” and so on, which is derived by adding the “a” vowel to the stem “āku” with the addition of the letter “k” and the augment “a” to make it a stem noun.

original: Dve vāre pana jāto bakkulo, kulasaddo cettha jātipariyāyo kolaṃkolotiādīsu viya.
analyzed: dve vāre pana jātaḥ bakkulaḥ kula saddo ca ittha jāti pariyāyo kolaṃkola uti ādīsu viya
translated: “Byākula” is the form in the sense of “confused” and so on, which is derived by adding the “ā” vowel to the stem “āku” with the addition of the letter “k” and the augment “a” to make it a stem noun.🔽“Ākula” is the form in the sense of “confused” and so on, which is derived by adding the “a” vowel to the stem “āku” with the addition of the letter “k” and the augment “a” to make it a stem noun.🔽“Byākula” is the form in the sense of “confused” and so on, which is derived by adding the “ā” vowel to the stem “āku” with the addition of the letter “k” and the augment “a” to make it a stem noun.

original: Vuttaadhippāyānuvidhāyī ca saddappayogoti paṭhamena padena jalābujasīhabyagghādayo,🔽dutiyena aṇḍajaāsīvisakaṇhasappādayo vuccanti, tasmā sīhādiko viya āsīvisādiko viya
analyzed: vutta adhippāya anuvidhāyī ca sadda ppayogaḥ iti paṭhamena padena jalābuja sīha byaggha ādayaḥ  dutiyena aṇḍa ja āsīvisa kaṇha sappa ādayaḥ vuccanti tasmā sīha ādikaḥ viya āsīvisa ādikaḥ viya
translated: The first word refers to water-lilies, lions, tigers, etc.,

original: ca “ahaṃ te jīvitahārako”ti imaṃ atthaṃ yakkho padadvayena dassetīti aññe. Apare
analyzed: ca aham te jīvita hārako ti imam attham yakkhaḥ pada dvayena dasseti iti aññe apare
translated: and the second to eggs, snakes, black cobras, etc. So others say that the spirit shows the meaning “I am the taker of your life” by the two words as a lion, etc., does, and as a cobra, etc., does.

original: pana “akkhulo bhakkhulo”ti pāḷiṃ vatvā “akkhetuṃ khepetuṃ vināsetuṃ ulati pavattetīti
analyzed: pana akkhulaḥ bhakkhulaḥ iti pāḷim vatvā akkhetum khepetum vināsetum ulati pavatteti iti
translated: But others, quoting the text as “akkhulo bhakkhulo,” explain the meaning as follows: “He flows, he moves, to cast, to throw, to destroy,

original: akkhulo, bhakkhituṃ khādituṃ ulatīti bhakkhulo. Ko paneso? Yakkharakkhasapisācasīhabyagghādīsu
analyzed: akkhulaḥ bhakkhitum khāditum ulati iti bhakkhulaḥ kaḥ pana isaḥ yakkha rakkhasa pisāca sīha byaggha ādīsu
translated: thus he is akkhulo. He flows to eat, to devour, thus he is bhakkhulo. But who is he?

original: aññataro yo koci manussānaṃ anatthāvaho”ti tassa atthaṃ vadanti. Idhāpi pubbe vuttanayeneva
analyzed: aññataraḥ yaḥ koci manussānam anattha āvahaḥ ti tassa attham vadanti idha api pubbe vutta nayena iva
translated: He is any one of the spirits, ogres, demons, lions, tigers, etc., who brings misfortune to men.”

original: adhippāyayojanā veditabbā.
analyzed: adhippāya yojanā veditabbā
translated: Here too the application of the intended meaning should be understood as stated above.

original: Eso te, samaṇa, pisācoti “ambho, samaṇa, tava pisitāsano pisāco upaṭṭhito”ti mahantaṃ bheravarūpaṃ abhinimminitvā bhagavato purato ṭhatvā attānaṃ sandhāya yakkho vadati.
analyzed: esaḥ te samaṇa pisācaḥ iti ambho samaṇa tava pisita āsanaḥ pisācaḥ upaṭṭhitaḥ ti mahantam bherava rūpam abhinimminitvā bhagavato puratas ṭhatvā attānam sandhāya yakkhaḥ vadati
translated: “This is your ogre, ascetic,” he said, meaning that the ascetic’s ogre was attending on him.

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ tena yakkhena kāyavācāhi pavattiyamānaṃ vippakāraṃ. Tena
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam tena yakkhena kāya vācāhi pavattiyamānam vippakāram tena
translated: Having known the meaning: having known the meaning of the ogre’s behaviour by means of his body and speech,

original: ca attano anabhibhavanīyassa hetubhūtaṃ lokadhammesu nirupakkilesataṃ sabbākārato🔽viditvā. Tāyaṃ velāyanti tassaṃ vippakārakaraṇavelāyaṃ. Imaṃ udānanti taṃ vippakāraṃ
analyzed: ca attanaḥ an abhibhavanīyassa hetu bhūtam loka dhammesu nirupakkilesa tam sabba ākārato  viditvā tāyam velāyanti tassam vippakāra karaṇa velāyam imam udānanti tam vippakāram
translated: and having known in all aspects the absence of defilement in the world-spheres that was the cause of his being unassailable,

original: agaṇetvā assa agaṇanahetubhūtaṃ dhammānubhāvadīpakaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: a gaṇetvā assa a gaṇana hetu bhūtam dhamma anubhāva dīpakam imam udānam udānesi
translated: at that time, he uttered this exalted utterance.

original: Tattha yadā sakesu dhammesūti yasmiṃ kāle sakaattabhāvasaṅkhātesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhadhammesu.
analyzed: tattha yadā sakesu dhammesu iti yasmin kāle saka atta bhāva saṅkhātesu pañcasu upādāna kkhandha dhammesu
translated: Herein, when he had attained to his own true nature: at the time when he had attained to the five aggregates as objects of clinging, which are called his own true nature.

original: Pāragūti pariññābhisamayapāripūrivasena pāraṅgato, tatoyeva tesaṃ hetubhūte samudaye,
analyzed: pāragū ti tesam hetu bhūte samudaye
translated: He had gone beyond: he had gone beyond by means of full understanding, by means of penetration, and by means of fulfilment. In the origin of these, which is the cause of them,

original: tadappavattilakkhaṇe nirodhe, nirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ca pahānasacchikiriyābhāvanābhisamayapāripūrivasena
analyzed: tad appavatti lakkhaṇe nirodhe nirodha gāminiyā paṭipadāya ca pahāna sacchikiriyā bhāvanā abhisamaya pāripūri vasena
translated: In the cessation which has the characteristic of their non- occurrence, and in the way leading to cessation, he has gone to the end of abandoning, of realizing, of developing, of perfecting.

original: pāragato. Hoti brāhmaṇoti evaṃ sabbaso bāhitapāpattā brāhmaṇo nāma hoti, sabbaso🔽sakaattabhāvāvabodhanepi catusaccābhisamayo hoti. Vuttañcetaṃ – “imasmiṃyeva byāmamatte
analyzed: pāragataḥ hoti brāhmaṇaḥ ti evam sabbasas bāhita pāpattā brāhmaṇaḥ nāma hoti sabbaso  catu sacca abhisamayaḥ hoti vuttam ca itaṃ imasmin yeva byāma matte
translated: He is a brahmin: thus he is a brahmin in the sense of having expelled all evil.

original: kaḷevare sasaññimhi samanake lokañca lokasamudayañca paññapemī”tiādi. Atha vā sakesu
analyzed: kaḷevare sa saññimhi samanake lokañca loka samudayañca paññapemi itiādi atha vā sakesu
translated: In the understanding of his own self too there is the penetration of the four noble truths. For this is said: “In this fathom-long carcase with its perceptions and ideas I declare the world, the origin of the world, the cessation of the world, and the way leading to the cessation of the world” .

original: dhammesūti attano dhammesu, attano dhammā nāma atthakāmassa puggalassa sīlādidhammā.🔽Sīlasamādhipaññāvimuttiādayo hi vodānadhammā ekantahitasukhasampādanena purisassa
analyzed: dhammesu iti attanaḥ dhammesu attanaḥ dhammāḥ nāma attha kāmassa puggalassa sīla ādi dhammā  sīla samādhi paññā vimutti ādayaḥ hi vodāna dhammāḥ ekanta hita sukha sampādanena purisassa
translated: Or alternatively, in his own dhammas : in his own dhammas, in his own things. A person who is a seeker of welfare has dhammas, things, that are virtue, etc.,

original: attano dhammā nāma, na anatthāvahā saṃkilesadhammā viya asakadhammā. Pāragūti tesaṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ dhammāḥ nāma na anattha āvahā saṃkilesa dhammāḥ viya asakadhammā tesam
translated: For the dhammas, things, that are virtue, concentration, wisdom, deliverance, etc., are the person’s own dhammas, his own things, since they bring about his welfare and happiness exclusively, not things that are not his own, things that are corrupt dhammas, things that are failures.

original: sīlādīnaṃ pāripūriyā pāraṃ pariyantaṃ gato.
analyzed: pāripūriyā pāram pariyantam gataḥ
translated: He has gone to the end of them: he has gone to the end, to the furthest limit, of perfecting those dhammas, things, that are virtue, etc.

original: Tattha sīlaṃ tāva lokiyalokuttaravasena duvidhaṃ. Tesu lokiyaṃ pubbabhāgasīlaṃ. Taṃ
analyzed: tattha sīlam tāva lokiya lokuttara vasena duvidham tesu lokiyam pubbabhāga sīlam
translated: Herein, virtue is twofold as mundane and supramundane. Of these, the mundane is the virtue of the prior stage. That is

original: saṅkhepato pātimokkhasaṃvarādivasena catubbidhaṃ, vitthārato pana anekappabhedaṃ.
analyzed: saṅkhepato pātimokkha saṃvara ādi vasena catubbidham vitthārato pana aneka ppabhedam
translated: virtue in brief of four kinds as virtue consisting in limited purification, and so on. But in detail it has many divisions.

original: Lokuttaraṃ maggaphalavasena duvidhaṃ, atthato sammāvācāsammākammantasammāājīvā. Yathā
analyzed: lokuttaram magga phala vasena duvidham atthato yathā
translated: The supramundane is twofold as that of the path and that of fruition. In meaning it is right speech, right action, and right livelihood.

original: ca sīlaṃ, tathā samādhipaññā ca lokiyalokuttaravasena duvidhā. Tattha lokiyasamādhi
analyzed: ca sīlam tathā samādhi paññā ca lokiya lokuttara vasena duvidhā tattha lokiya samādhi
translated: And just as virtue is twofold, so also concentration and understanding are twofold as mundane and supramundane. Herein, mundane concentration

original: saha upacārena aṭṭha samāpattiyo, lokuttarasamādhi maggapariyāpanno. Paññāpi lokiyā🔽sutamayā, cintāmayā, bhāvanāmayā ca sāsavā, lokuttarā pana maggasampayuttā phalasampayuttā
analyzed: saha upacārena aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ lokuttara samādhi magga pariyāpanno paññā api lokiyā  suta mayā cintā mayā bhāvanā mayā ca sa āsavā lokuttarā pana magga sampayuttā phala sampayuttā
translated: is the eight attainments together with access concentration. Supramundane concentration is that included in the path. And understanding is🔽mundane when it is mundane knowledge, and supramundane when it is associated with the path and fruition. Deliverance is the fruition deliverance and extinction. So it is supramundane.

original: ca. Vimutti nāma phalavimutti nibbānañca, tasmā sā lokuttarāva. Vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ🔽lokiyameva, taṃ ekūnavīsatividhaṃ paccavekkhaṇañāṇabhāvato. Evaṃ etesaṃ sīlādidhammānaṃ
analyzed: ca vimutti nāma phala vimutti nibbānam ca tasmā sā vimutti ñāṇa dassanam 🔽lokiyam eva tam ekūnavīsatividham paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇa bhāvataḥ evam etesam sīla ādi dhammānam
translated: Knowledge and vision of deliverance is mundane. It is knowledge of reviewing of nineteen kinds. Thus these states of virtue,🔽and so on,

original: attano santāne arahattaphalādhigamena anavasesato nibbattapāripūriyā pāraṃ pariyantaṃ
analyzed: attano santāne arahatta phala adhigamena anavasesataḥ nibbatta pāripūriyā pāram pariyantam
translated: He has gone to the end of his own dhammas, to the end which is the culmination of their arising, by the attainment of Arahantship in his own mental continuity.

original: gatoti sakesu dhammesu pāragū.🔽Atha vā sotāpattiphalādhigamena sīlasmiṃ pāragū. So hi “sīlesu paripūrakārī”ti vutto,
analyzed: gato ti sakesu dhammesu pāragū  atha vā sotāpatti phala adhigamena sīlasmim pāragū so hi sīlesu paripūra kārī iti vutto
translated: So he is one who has gone to the end of his own dhammas.🔽Or alternatively, he is one who has gone to the end of virtue by the attainment of the fruit of stream-entry,

original: sotāpannaggahaṇeneva cettha sakadāgāmīpi gahito hoti. Anāgāmiphalādhigamena samādhismiṃ🔽pāragū. So hi “samādhismiṃ paripūrakārī”ti vutto. Arahattaphalādhigamena itaresu
analyzed: sotāpanna ggahaṇena iva ca ittha gahitaḥ hoti anāgāmi phala adhigamena samādhismin  pāragū saḥ hi samādhismim paripūra kārī iti vuttaḥ arahatta phala adhigamena itaresu
translated: for he is called “one who has fulfilled virtue” . And by the mention of the stream-enterer here, the once-returner is also included. He is one who has gone to the end of concentration by the attainment of the fruit of non-return,🔽for he is called “one who has fulfilled concentration” . And he is one who has gone to the end of the remaining three by the attainment of the fruit of Arahantship.

original: tīsu pāragū. Arahā hi paññāvepullappattiyā aggabhūtāya akuppāya cetovimuttiyā adhigatattā
analyzed: tīsu pāragū arahā hi paññā vepulla ppattiyāḥ agga bhūtāya akuppāya cetaḥ vimuttiyāḥ adhigata ttā
translated: For the Arahant is called “one who has gone to the end of understanding” because he has reached the unshakable deliverance of mind, which is the highest state of all, by attaining the fulfilment of understanding.

original: paccavekkhaṇañāṇassa ca pariyosānagamanato paññāvimuttivimuttiñāṇadassanesu pāragū
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇassa ca pariyosāna gamanato paññā vimutti vimutti ñāṇa dassanesu pāragū
translated: And he is called “one who has gone to the end of knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path” and “one who has gone to the end of knowledge and vision of the way” because he has reached the end of the knowledge and vision of reviewing and the end of the knowledge and vision of the way respectively.

original: nāma hoti. Evaṃ sabbathāpi catūsu ariyasaccesu catumaggavasena pariññādisoḷasavidhāya
analyzed: nāma hoti evam sabbathā api catūsu ariya saccesu catu magga vasena pariññā ādi soḷasa vidhāya
translated: So he is one who has gone to the end of all dhammas in all four noble truths by the four paths in the sixteen aspects of fully understanding and the rest.

original: kiccanipphattiyā yathāvuttesu tasmiṃ tasmiṃ kāle sakesu dhammesu pāragato.
analyzed: kicca nipphattiyā yathā vuttesu tasmim tasmim kāle sakesu dhammesu pāragataḥ
translated: He is a brahmin, in the sense of one who has gone to the end of his own Dhamma, in the various kinds of his own Dhamma mentioned above, by the fulfilment of his task.🔽He is a brahmin, in the ultimate sense, because he has expelled evil qualities.

original: Hoti brāhmaṇoti tadā so bāhitapāpadhammatāya paramatthabrāhmaṇo hoti. Atha etaṃ pisācañca,🔽pakkulañcātivattatīti tato yathāvuttapāragamanato atha pacchā, ajakalāpaka, etaṃ
analyzed: hoti brāhmaṇaḥ iti tadā saḥ bāhita pāpa dhamma tāya paramattha brāhmaṇaḥ hoti atha etam pisācam ca  pakkulam ca ativattati iti tatas yathāvutta pāra gamanataḥ atha pacchā aja kalāpake etam
translated: Then he goes beyond the ogre,🔽and the clan as well.

original: tayā dassitaṃ pisitāsanatthamāgataṃ pisācaṃ bhayajananatthaṃ samuṭṭhāpitaṃ akkulapakkulikañca
analyzed: tayā dassitam pisita āsana attham āgatam pisācam bhaya janana attham samuṭṭhāpitam akkulapakkulikam ca
translated: Then, after that, after the going to the end mentioned above, he goes beyond, he transcends, he masters, the ogre that you have shown, which has come to devour his thought of insight, and the clan as well, which you have conjured up to terrify him,

original: ativattati, atikkamati, abhibhavati, taṃ na bhāyatīti attho.
analyzed: ativattati atikkamati abhibhavati tam na bhāyati iti atthaḥ
translated: the clan of the akkhas and the clan of the pukkusa. The meaning is that he is not afraid of it.

original: Ayampi gāthā arahattameva ullapitvā kathitā. Atha ajakalāpako attanā katena tathārūpenapi
analyzed: ayam pi gāthā arahattam eva ullapitvā kathitā atha aja kalāpakaḥ attanā katena tathārūpena api
translated: This stanza too was spoken by the Elder after boasting about Arahantship.

original: paṭibhayarūpena vibhiṃsanena akampanīyassa bhagavato taṃ tādibhāvaṃ disvā “aho acchariyamanussovatāya”nti
analyzed: paṭibhaya rūpena vibhiṃsanena akampanīyassa bhagavato tam tādi bhāvam disvā aho
translated: Then the ogre, seeing that the Blessed One, who was of such a kind, who was so terrifying and awe-inspiring, was unshaken, and that he was such like this,🔽thought “How wonderful! What a man! What a great man!”

original: pasannamānaso pothujjanikāya saddhāya attani niviṭṭhabhāvaṃ vibhāvento satthu sammukhā
analyzed: pasanna mānasaḥ pothujjanikāya saddhāya attani niviṭṭha bhāvam vibhāvento satthu sammukhā
translated: and, with his mind confident, he revealed to the Master his own state of being established in the faith of the ordinary man.

original: upāsakattaṃ pavedesi.
analyzed: upāsaka ttam pavedesi
translated: and he declared himself a lay follower.

original: Sattamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sattama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the seventh sutta is finished.

original: 8. Saṅgāmajisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: saṅgāmaji sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The sutta with Saṅgāmaji

original: 8. Aṭṭhame saṅgāmajīti evaṃnāmo. Ayañhi āyasmā sāvatthiyaṃ aññatarassa mahāvibhavassa
analyzed: aṭṭhame saṅgāmajī ti evaṃnāmaḥ ayan hi āyasmā sāvatthiyam aññatarassa mahā vibhavassa
translated: In the eighth sutta the name of the brahmin is Saṅgāmaji. He was the son of a wealthy merchant in Sāvatthī.

original: seṭṭhino putto, vayappattakāle mātāpitūhi patirūpena dārena niyojetvā sāpateyyaṃ
analyzed: seṭṭhino putto vaya patta kāle mātā pitūhi pati rūpena dārena niyojetvā sāpateyyam
translated: When he reached the right age, his parents gave him a suitable wife and handed over his inheritance.

original: niyyātetvā gharabandhanena baddho hoti. So ekadivasaṃ sāvatthivāsino upāsake pubbaṇhasamayaṃ
analyzed: niyyātetvā ghara bandhanena baddhaḥ hoti saḥ eka divasam sāvatthi vāsinaḥ upāsake pubbaṇha samayam
translated: He was bound by the fetters of the household life. One day he saw the lay followers of Sāvatthī giving gifts in the morning

original: dānaṃ datvā sīlaṃ samādiyitvā sāyanhasamaye suddhavatthe suddhuttarāsaṅge gandhamālādihatthe
analyzed: dānam da tvā sīlam samādiyitvā sāyanha samaye suddhavatthe suddhuttarāsaṅge gandha mālā ādi hatthe
translated: and undertaking the precepts in the evening, wearing clean clothes and upper robes, and carrying perfumes, garlands, and so on.

original: dhammassavanatthaṃ jetavanābhimukhe gacchante disvā “kattha tumhe gacchathā”ti pucchitvā
analyzed: dhammassavana attham jetavana abhimukhe gacchante disvā kattha tumhe gacchatha ati pucchitvā
translated: They were going to Jeta’s Wood to listen to the Teaching. He asked them, “Where are you going?”🔽“To the Buddha at Jeta’s Wood to listen to the Teaching.”

original: “dhammassavanatthaṃ jetavane satthu santika”nti vutte “tena hi ahampi gamissāmī”ti
analyzed: dhammassavana attham jetavane satthu santikam ti vutte tena hi aham pi gamissāmi iti
translated: “Then I’ll come too.”

original: tehi saddhiṃ jetavanaṃ agamāsi. Tena ca samayena bhagavā kañcanaguhāyaṃ sīhanādaṃ
analyzed: tehi saddhim jetavanam tena ca samayena bhagavā sīha nādam
translated: He went to Jeta’s Wood with them. At that time the Buddha was staying in the Golden Cave,

original: nadanto kesarasīho viya saddhammamaṇḍape paññattavarabuddhāsane nisīditvā catuparisamajjhe dhammaṃ deseti.
analyzed: nadantaḥ kesarasīhaḥ viya saddhamma maṇḍape paññatta vara buddhāsane nisīditvā catu parisamajjhe dhammam deseti
translated: and he was teaching the Dhamma, like a lion in his mountain cave, in the excellent assembly hall, in the Buddha’s seat that had been prepared.

original: Atha kho te upāsakā bhagavantaṃ vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu, saṅgāmajipi kulaputto🔽tassā parisāya pariyante dhammaṃ suṇanto nisīdi. Bhagavā anupubbikathaṃ kathetvā
analyzed: atha kho te upāsakāḥ bhagavantam vanditvā ekamantam nisīdiṃsu saṅgāmajipi kula putto  tassā parisāya pariyante dhammam suṇantaḥ nisīdi bhagavā anupubbi katham kathetvā
translated: Then those lay followers worshipped the Lord and sat down to one side, and the young man Sangāmaji,

original: cattāri saccāni pakāsesi, saccapariyosāne anekesaṃ pāṇasahassānaṃ dhammābhisamayo
analyzed: cattāri saccāni pakāsesi sacca pariyosāne anekesam pāṇa sahassānam dhamma abhisamayaḥ
translated: sitting at the back of the crowd, was able to hear the sound of the Lord’s voice but could not see the Lord. The Lord, having instructed, inspired, fired and delighted the lay followers with a talk on Dhamma,🔽dismissed them, saying: “The night is far spent. Do now what you think fit.” And those lay followers,

original: ahosi. Saṅgāmajipi kulaputto sotāpattiphalaṃ patvā parisāya vuṭṭhitāya bhagavantaṃ🔽upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā pabbajjaṃ yāci “pabbājetha maṃ bhagavā”ti. “Anuññātosi pana🔽tvaṃ mātāpitūhi pabbajjāyā”ti? “Nāhaṃ, bhante, anuññāto”ti. “Na kho, saṅgāmaji, tathāgatā
analyzed: ahosi saṅgāma jipi kula putto sotāpatti phalam patvā parisāya vuṭṭhitāya bhagavantam  upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā pabbajjam yāci pabbājetha mama bhagavā ti anuññātaḥ asi pana  tvam mātā pitūhi pabbajjāya ati na aham bhante anuññātaḥ ti na kho saṅgāmaji tathāgatā
translated: having delighted and rejoiced in the Lord’s words, rose from their seats, worshipped and circumambulated the Lord, keeping him to their right, and then departed. Then the young man Sangāmaji,

original: mātāpitūhi ananuññātaṃ puttaṃ pabbājentī”ti. “Sohaṃ, bhante, tathā karissāmi, yathā
analyzed: mātā pitūhi an anuññātam puttam pabbājenti iti saḥ ham bhante tathā karissāmi yathā
translated: having risen from his seat, worshipped the Lord, and said: “Lord, I would receive the going forth in the Lord’s presence, I would receive ordination.” “But, Sangāmaji, have you been approved by your parents?” “No, Lord, I have not.” “Sangāmaji, the Tathagatas do not give the going forth to anyone who has not been approved by his parents.” “Lord, I will do whatever is necessary to obtain my parents’ approval.”

original: maṃ mātāpitaro pabbajituṃ anujānantī”ti. So bhagavantaṃ vanditvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā
analyzed: mam mātā pitaraḥ pabbajitum anujānanti iti saḥ bhagavantam vanditvā padakkhiṇam katvā
translated: and my parents have given me permission to go forth.” He paid homage to the Buddha, circumambulated him,

original: mātāpitaro upasaṅkamitvā, “ammatātā, anujānātha maṃ pabbajitu”nti āha. Tato paraṃ
analyzed: mātā pitaraḥ upasaṅkamitvā ammatātā anujānātha mama pabbajitunti āha tato param
translated: and then went to his parents. He said, “Mother, Father, please give me permission to go forth.” What follows

original: raṭṭhapālasutte āgatanayena veditabbaṃ.🔽Atha so “pabbajitvā attānaṃ dassessāmī”ti paṭiññaṃ datvā anuññāto mātāpitūhi bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: raṭṭhapāla sutte āgata nayena veditabbam  atha saḥ pabbajitvā attānam dassessāmi iti paṭiññam da tvā anuññātaḥ mātā pitūhi bhagavantam
translated: should be understood according to the account in the Ratthapala Sutta.🔽After he had given his promise, saying, “I’ll show myself to you after I’ve gone forth,” and had been given permission by his parents, he went to the Buddha,

original: upasaṅkamitvā pabbajjaṃ yāci. Alattha kho ca bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ upasampadañca,
analyzed: upasaṅkamitvā pabbajjam yāci alattha kho ca bhagavato santike pabbajjam upasampadam ca
translated: asked for the going forth, and was given the full ordination.

original: acirūpasampanno ca pana so uparimaggatthāya ghaṭento vāyamanto aññatarasmiṃ araññāvāse🔽vassaṃ vasitvā chaḷabhiñño hutvā vutthavasso bhagavantaṃ dassanāya mātāpitūnañca
analyzed: acira upasampanno ca pana so upari magga atthāya ghaṭentaḥ vā āyamantaḥ aññatarasmin araññā vāse  vassam vasitvā chaḷabhiññaḥ hutvā vuttha vassaḥ bhagavantam dassanāya mātā pitūnañca
translated: Soon after his full ordination, while striving and making effort, he reached Arahantship.

original: paṭissavamocanatthaṃ sāvatthiṃ agamāsi. Tena vuttaṃ – “tena kho pana samayena āyasmā🔽saṅgāmaji sāvatthiṃ anuppatto hotī”ti.
analyzed: paṭissava mocana attham sāvatthim agamāsi tena vuttam tena kha pana samayena āyasmā 🔽saṅgāma ji sāvatthim an uppattaḥ hoti iti
translated: After he had completed the rainy season residence, he went to Savatthi to see the Buddha and to inform his parents of his freedom.

original: So hāyasmā dhuragāme piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto jetavanaṃ
analyzed: saḥ ha ayasmai dhura gāme piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ jetavanam
translated: After he had wandered for alms in Dhura village and had returned from his almsround, after his meal he went to Jeta’s Grove,

original: pavisitvā bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ katapaṭisanthāro aññaṃ byākaritvā🔽puna bhagavantaṃ vanditvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā nikkhamitvā aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ🔽nisīdi. Athassa mātāpitaro ñātimittā cassa āgamanaṃ sutvā, “saṅgāmaji, kira idhāgato”ti
analyzed: pavisitvā bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhim kata paṭisanthāraḥ aññam byākaritvā  puna bhagavantam vanditvā padakkhiṇam katvā nikkhamitvā aññatarasmin rukkha mūle divāvihāram  nisīdi athassa mātā pitaraḥ ñāti mittā ca assa āgamanam sutvā saṅgām aji kira idha āgataḥ ti
translated: approached the Lord, exchanged courtesies with him, and after the exchange of courtesies and greetings🔽he saluted the Lord, passed by to the right, and left. He then sat down at the foot of a tree for the day’s abiding. Now his parents and his friends, hearing that he had come,

original: haṭṭhatuṭṭhā turitaturitā vihāraṃ gantvā pariyesantā naṃ tattha nisinnaṃ disvā upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: haṭṭha tuṭṭhā turita turitā vihāram gantvā pariyesantā nam tattha nisinnam disvā upasaṅkamitvā
translated: and saying: ‘Saṅgāmaji has come’, were delighted and hurried to the monastery. Searching for him, they saw him sitting there, and approaching him,

original: paṭisanthāraṃ katvā “mā aputtakaṃ sāpateyyaṃ rājāno hareyyuṃ, appiyā dāyādā vā gaṇheyyuṃ,
analyzed: paṭisanthāram katvā mā aputtakam sāpateyyam rājānaḥ hareyyum appiyāḥ dāyādāḥ vā gaṇheyyum
translated: after exchanging courtesies, said: ‘Let not the king take your property as that of a sonless man, or let not your disfavoured relatives take it.

original: nālaṃ pabbajjāya, ehi, tāta, vibbhamā”ti yāciṃsu. Taṃ sutvā thero “ime mayhaṃ kāmehi
analyzed: na alam pabbajjāya ehi tāta yāciṃsu tam sutvā theraḥ ime mayham kāmehi
translated: It is not worth the trouble of going forth. Come, dear, give up the going forth.’ Hearing this, the elder thought: ‘These people are asking me to give up the going forth for the sake of sensual pleasures.

original: anatthikabhāvaṃ na jānanti, gūthadhārī viya gūthapiṇḍe kāmesuyeva allīyanaṃ icchanti,
analyzed: anatthika bhāvam na jānanti gūtha dhārī gūtha piṇḍe allīyanam icchanti
translated: They do not know what is good for them, like a man carrying dung who is attached to a lump of dung. They want to be attached to sensual pleasures alone.

original: nayime sakkā dhammakathāya saññāpetu”nti assuṇanto viya nisīdi. Te nānappakāraṃ yācitvā🔽attano vacanaṃ aggaṇhantaṃ disvā gharaṃ pavisitvā puttena saddhiṃ tassa bhariyaṃ
analyzed: na yime sakkā dhamma kathāya saññāpetunti a suṇantaḥ viya nisīdi te nānappakāram yācitvā  attanaḥ vacanam aggaṇhantam disvā gharam pavisitvā puttena saddhim tassa bhariyam
translated: They cannot be convinced by a talk on the Dhamma.” And he sat down as if he had not heard. When they had asked him in various ways and

original: saparivāraṃ uyyojesuṃ “mayaṃ nānappakāraṃ taṃ yācantāpi tassa manaṃ alabhitvā āgatā,
analyzed: sa parivāram uyyojesum mayam nānappakāram tam yācantā api tassa manam a labhitvā āgatā
translated: seen that he would not accept their advice, they went home and sent his wife and child away with their retinue, saying, “We have come back after asking him in various ways, but we have not been able to change his mind.

original: gaccha tvaṃ, bhadde, tava bhattāraṃ puttasandassanena yācitvā saññāpehī”ti. Tāya
analyzed: gaccha tvam bhadde tava bhattāram putta sandassanena yācitvā saññāpehi iti tāya
translated: Go, dear, and ask your husband to return by showing him the child.”

original: kira āpannasattāya ayamāyasmā pabbajito. Sā “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchitvā dārakamādāya
analyzed: kira āpannasattāya ayam āyasmā pabbajitaḥ sā sādhu iti sampaṭicchitvā dārakam ādāya
translated: It seems that this venerable one had gone forth when his wife was already pregnant. She agreed, saying, “Very well,” and taking the child with her,

original: mahatā parivārena jetavanaṃ agamāsi. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “assosi kho āyasmato saṅgāmajissā”tiādi.
analyzed: mahatā parivārena jetavanam agamāsi tam sandhāya vuttam assosi kho āyasmataḥ saṅgāmajissa atiādi
translated: she went to Jeta’s Wood with a large retinue. The story is told in the Commentary on the Mahā-Lakkhaṇa Sutta .

original: Tattha purāṇadutiyikāti pubbe gihikāle pādaparicaraṇavasena dutiyikā, bhariyāti attho.
analyzed: tattha purāṇa dutiyikā ti pubbe gihi kāle pāda paricaraṇa vasena dutiyikā bhariyā ti attho
translated: Herein, former wife means a wife by virtue of the duties of mutual service performed in the past as a layman; the meaning is, a wife.

original: Ayyoti “ayyaputto”ti vattabbe pabbajitānaṃ anucchavikavohārena vadati. Kirāti anussavanatthe🔽nipāto, tassa anuppatto kirāti sambandho veditabbo. Khuddaputtañhi samaṇa, posa manti🔽āpannasattameva maṃ chaḍḍetvā pabbajito, sāhaṃ etarahi khuddaputtā, tādisaṃ maṃ chaḍḍetvāva
analyzed: ayyo ti ayya putto ti vattabbe pabbajitānam anucchavika vohārena vadati kirāti anussavana atthe  nipātaḥ tassa anuppattaḥ kira āti sambandhaḥ veditabbaḥ khudda puttam hi samaṇa posa  āpannasattam eva mam chaḍḍetvā pabbajito sā aham etarahi khudda puttā tādisam mam chaḍḍetvā ava
translated: “Sir” : he says this by the respectful form of address suitable for those gone forth. “Indeed” : the indeclinable kirā is in the sense of recalling.

original: tava samaṇadhammakaraṇaṃ ayuttaṃ, tasmā, samaṇa, puttadutiyaṃ maṃ ghāsacchādanādīhi
analyzed: tava samaṇa dhamma karaṇam ayuttam tasmā samaṇa putta dutiyam mam ghāsa chādana ādīhi
translated: The connection should be understood thus: “Indeed, he has come to me.” For the ascetic, having abandoned me who was pregnant, went forth. Now I am one who has a small child. It is not proper for you, ascetic, to practice the ascetic life, having abandoned me who am like that. Therefore, ascetic, you should support me who am with a child, with food, clothing, etc.

original: bharassūti. Āyasmā pana, saṅgāmaji, indriyāni ukkhipitvā taṃ neva oloketi, nāpi ālapati.
analyzed: bharassu iti āyasmā pana saṅgāmaji indriyāni ukkhipitvā tam na iva oloketi na api ālapati
translated: But the venerable Saṅgāmaji, having raised his senses, did not look at her or speak to her.

original: Tena vuttaṃ – “evaṃ vutte āyasmā saṅgāmaji tuṇhī ahosī”ti.
analyzed: tena vuttam evam vutte āyasmā saṅgāmaji tuṇhī ahosi iti
translated: Therefore it was said: “When this was said, the venerable Saṅgāmaji was silent.”

original: Sā tikkhattuṃ tatheva vatvā tuṇhībhūtameva taṃ disvā “purisā nāma bhariyāsu nirapekkhāpi
analyzed: sā tikkhattum tathā iva vatvā tuṇhībhūtam eva tam disvā purisāḥ nāma bhariyāsu nirapekkhā api
translated: She, having spoken thus three times, seeing him silent, thought: “Men, although they are indifferent to their wives,

original: puttesu sāpekkhā honti, puttasineho pitu aṭṭhimiñjaṃ āhacca tiṭṭhati, tasmā puttapemenāpi
analyzed: puttesu sa apekkhāḥ honti putta sinehaḥ pitu aṭṭhimiñjam āhacca tiṭṭhati tasmā putta pemena api
translated: are affectionate towards their children. The affection for a child stands firm, having reached the marrow of the bones of a father. Therefore, even out of love for a child,

original: mayhaṃ vase vatteyyā”ti maññamānā puttaṃ therassa aṅke nikkhipitvā ekamantaṃ apakkamma🔽“eso te, samaṇa, putto, posa na”nti vatvā thokaṃ agamāsi. Sā kira samaṇatejenassa
analyzed: mayham vase vatteyya ati maññamānā puttam therassa aṅke nikkhipitvā ekamantam apakkamma  eso te samaṇa putto posa nanti vatvā thokam agamāsi sā kira
translated: Thinking, “He will be under my control,” she placed her son on the Elder’s lap, and then she went away to one side.

original: sammukhe ṭhātuṃ nāsakkhi. Thero dārakampi neva oloketi nāpi ālapati. Atha sā itthī
analyzed: sammukhe ṭhātum na asakkhi theraḥ dārakam pi na iva oloketi na api ālapati atha sā itthī
translated: “This is your son, ascetic. Feed him,” she said, and then she went away a little. She was unable to stand in the presence of the ascetic, it seems, because of the majesty of his spiritual power. The Elder did not even look at the child or speak to him. Then the woman

original: avidūre ṭhatvā mukhaṃ parivattetvā olokentī therassa ākāraṃ ñatvā paṭinivattitvā🔽“puttenapi ayaṃ samaṇo anatthiko”ti dārakaṃ gahetvā pakkāmi. Tena vuttaṃ – “atha
analyzed: avidūre ṭhatvā mukham parivattetvā olokentī therassa ākāram ñatvā paṭinivattitvā  puttena api ayam samaṇaḥ anatthikaḥ ti dārakam gahetvā pakkāmi tena vuttam atha
translated: stood not far away, turned her face around, and looked back. She understood the Elder’s character. She turned around and went away,

original: kho āyasmato saṅgāmajissa purāṇadutiyikā”tiādi.
analyzed: kho āyasmataḥ saṅgāmajissa purāṇa dutiyikā ati ādi
translated: thinking, “This ascetic does not want even his own son, much less anyone else.” She took the child and went away. Therefore it was said: “Then the former wife of the venerable Saṅgāmaji” and so on.

original: Tattha puttenapīti ayaṃ samaṇo attano orasaputtenapi anatthiko, pageva aññehīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: tattha puttena api iti ayam samaṇaḥ attanaḥ orasa puttena api anatthikaḥ pagā iva aññehi iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: Herein, even with his own son means this ascetic does not want even his own son, much less anyone else. This is the meaning.

original: Dibbenāti ettha dibbasadisattā dibbaṃ. Devatānañhi sucaritakammanibbattaṃ pittasemharuhirādīhi
analyzed: dibbena ati ettha dibba sadisa ttā dibbam devatānam hi su carita kamma nibbattam pitta semha ruhira ādīhi
translated: Divine means like the divine, like that of the gods. For what is produced by the kamma of the gods’ good conduct is free from bile, phlegm, and wind.

original: apalibuddhaṃ dūrepi ārammaṇasampaṭicchanasamatthaṃ dibbaṃ pasādacakkhu hoti. Idampi
analyzed: apalibuddham dūre pi ārammaṇa sampaṭicchana samattham dibbam pasāda cakkhu hoti idam pi
translated: The divine eye is unobstructed, and it is able to receive an object even at a distance.🔽

original: catutthajjhānasamādhinibbattaṃ abhiññācakkhuṃ tādisanti dibbaṃ viyāti dibbaṃ, dibbavihārasannissayena
analyzed: catuttha jhāna samādhi nibbattam abhiññācakkhum tādisanti dibbam viyāti dibbam dibba vihāra sannissayena
translated: The divine eye is able to see and to receive an impression from an object even at a distance. This divine eye is like the eye of the fourth jhāna, which is also able to see and to receive an impression from an object even at a distance. Therefore it is called divine.🔽Or alternatively, it is divine because it is obtained by the support of divine abiding.🔽Or it is divine because it has great brightness and great range.

original: laddhattā vā dibbaṃ, mahājutikattā mahāgatikattā vā dibbaṃ, tena dibbena. Visuddhenāti
analyzed: laddhattā vā dibbam mahājutikattā mahāgatikattā vā dibbam tena dibbena visuddhena ati
translated: By the divine eye: by that divine eye.🔽Pure: very pure, by the absence of defilements such as the hindrances, etc.

original: nīvaraṇādisaṃkilesavigamena suparisuddhena. Atikkantamānusakenāti manussānaṃ visayātītena.
analyzed: nīvaraṇa ādi saṃkilesa vigamena su parisuddhena atikkanta mānusakena ati manussānam visaya atītena
translated: Surpassing that of men: transcending the range of human eyes.

original: Imaṃ evarūpaṃ vippakāranti imaṃ evaṃ vippakāraṃ yathāvuttaṃ pabbajitesu asāruppaṃ
analyzed: imam evarūpam vippakāram ti imam evam vippakāram yathā vuttam pabbajitesu a sāruppam
translated: This kind of behaviour: this kind of behaviour of the kind already described, which is unbecoming in one gone forth,

original: aṅke puttaṭṭhapanasaṅkhātaṃ virūpakiriyaṃ.🔽Etamatthanti etaṃ āyasmato saṅgāmajissa puttadārādīsu sabbattha nirapekkhabhāvasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: aṅke putta ṭṭhapana saṅkhātam virūpa kiriyam  etam attham ti etam āyasmataḥ saṅgāmajissa putta dāra ādīsu sabbattha nirapekkha bhāva saṅkhātam
translated: this kind of ugly behaviour consisting in the carrying of a child on the hip.🔽Having understood the meaning of this: having understood in all aspects the meaning of this, which consists in the complete lack of concern for son, wife, etc.,

original: atthaṃ sabbākārato viditvā. Imaṃ udānanti imaṃ tassa iṭṭhāniṭṭhādīsu tādibhāvadīpakaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: attham sabba ākārataḥ viditvā imam udānanti imam tassa iṭṭha aniṭṭha ādīsu ta ādi bhāva dīpakam udānam udānesi
translated: he uttered this exalted utterance: he uttered this utterance, which reveals his imperturbability in regard to what is desirable and undesirable.

original: Tattha āyantinti āgacchantiṃ, purāṇadutiyikanti adhippāyo. Nābhinandatīti daṭṭhuṃ
analyzed: tattha āyantim ti āgacchantim purāṇadutiyikam ti adhippāyaḥ na abhinandati iti daṭṭhum
translated: Herein, “coming” is coming to see me; the former wife is intended. “Does not delight” means does not delight, does not rejoice, in seeing her.

original: maṃ āgatāti na nandati na tussati. Pakkamantinti sā ayaṃ mayā asammoditāva gacchatīti🔽gacchantiṃ. Na socatīti na cittasantāpamāpajjati. Yena pana kāraṇena thero evaṃ nābhinandati
analyzed: mam āgatā ati na nandati na tussati sā ayam mayā a sammoditā ava gacchati iti  na socati iti na citta santāpam āpajjati yena pana kāraṇena theraḥ evam na abhinandati
translated: “Going” means “She is going away without delighting in me.”

original: na socati, taṃ dassetuṃ “saṅgā saṅgāmajiṃ mutta”nti vuttaṃ. Tattha saṅgāti rāgasaṅgo
analyzed: na socati tam dassetum saṅgā saṅgām ajim muttan ti vuttam tattha saṅgā ati rāga saṅgo
translated: “Does not grieve” means does not experience mental pain. But in order to show the reason why the Elder did not delight and did not grieve, it was said: “The victor in the fight, free from all ties” . Herein, “fight” is the five kinds of ties, namely, the ties of lust, of hate, of delusion, of conceit, and of views.

original: dosamohamānadiṭṭhisaṅgoti pañcavidhāpi saṅgā samucchedappaṭipassaddhivimuttīhi vimuttaṃ🔽saṅgāmajiṃ bhikkhuṃ. Tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇanti taṃ tādibhāvappattaṃ khīṇāsavaṃ ahaṃ
analyzed: dosa moha māna diṭṭhi saṅgaḥ ti pañcavidhā api saṅgā samuccheda paṭipassaddhi vimuttīhi vimuttam  saṅgāmajim bhikkhum tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa nti tam ta ādi bhāva ppattam khīṇa āsavam aham
translated: The bhikkhu who is liberated from the five kinds of ties by means of the severence of the defilements, by means of the tranquilization of the aggregates, and by means of the liberation from the round of rebirths,

original: sabbaso bāhitapāpattā brāhmaṇanti vadāmīti.
analyzed: sabbasas vadāmi iti
translated: I call a brahman. I say that he who has reached such a state, who is an arahat, has expelled all evil and is a brahman.

original: Aṭṭhamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽9. Jaṭilasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: aṭṭhama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  jaṭila sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the eighth sutta is finished.🔽The Thread on the Ascetic

original: 9. Navame gayāyanti ettha gayāti gāmopi titthampi vuccati. Gayāgāmassa hi avidūre
analyzed: navame gayāyanti ettha gayā ati gāmaḥ api tittham pi vuccati gayā gāmassa hi avidūre
translated: In the ninth sutta, “at Gaya” : here “Gaya” is a village and a shrine.

original: viharanto bhagavā “gayāyaṃ viharatī”ti vuccati, tathā gayātitthassa. Gayātitthanti🔽hi gayāgāmassa avidūre ekā pokkharaṇī atthi nadīpi, tadubhayaṃ “pāpapavāhanatittha”nti
analyzed: viharantaḥ bhagavā gayā ayam viharati iti vuccati tathā gayā titthassa gayā tittham ti  hi gayā gāmassa avidūre ekā pokkharaṇī atthi nadī pi tat ubhayam pāpa pavāhana tittham ti
translated: The Blessed One is said to be “at Gayā” because he was dwelling there, as also at the Gayā Head. For there is a lotus-tank and a river not far from the village of Gayā, and both are called “the ford of Gayā” .

original: lokiyamahājano samudācarati. Gayāsīseti gajasīsasadisasikharo tattha eko pabbato
analyzed: lokiya mahājanaḥ samudācarati gayā sīsa iti gaja sīsa sadisa sikharaḥ tattha ekaḥ pabbataḥ
translated: The ordinary people of the world call it “the ford for the removal of evil” . At Gayā Head: a mountain peak shaped like an elephant’s head,

original: gayāsīsanāmako, yattha hatthikumbhasadiso piṭṭhipāsāṇo bhikkhusahassassa okāso pahoti,
analyzed: gayāsīsa nāmakaḥ yattha hatthi kumbha sadiso piṭṭhi pāsāṇaḥ bhikkhu sahassassa okāso pahoti
translated: called “Gayā Head,” where there is a rock on the back of the mountain shaped like an elephant’s back, which can accommodate a thousand bhikkhus,

original: tatra bhagavā viharati. Tena vuttaṃ – “gayāyaṃ viharati gayāsīse”ti.
analyzed: tatra bhagavā viharati tena vuttam gayāyam viharati gayā sīsa iti
translated: and the Blessed One was dwelling there. Hence it is said, “at Gayā, at Gayā Head” .

original: Jaṭilāti tāpasā. Te hi jaṭādhāritāya idha “jaṭilā”ti vuttā. Antaraṭṭhake himapātasamayeti
analyzed: jaṭilā ati tāpasā te hi jaṭā dhāritāya idha jaṭilā ati vuttā antaraṭṭhake himapāta samaye iti
translated: Ascetics: seers. They are called “ascetics” here because they wore matted hair. In the interval between the rains, when it was snowing:

original: hemantassa utuno abbhantarabhūte māghamāsassa avasāne cattāro phagguṇamāsassa ādimhi
analyzed: hemantassa utuno abbhantara bhūte māgha māsassa avasāne cattāro phagguṇa māsassa ādimhi
translated: at the end of the month of Māgha, which is in the middle of the cold season, and at the beginning of the four months of the hot season,

original: cattāroti aṭṭhadivasaparimāṇe himassa patanakāle. Gayāyaṃ ummujjantīti keci tasmiṃ
analyzed: cattāro ti aṭṭha divasa parimāṇe himassa patana kāle gayā ayam ummujjanti iti keci tasmin
translated: that is, at the time of the snowfall, which lasts for four days. At Gayā it was raining: some say that it was raining at Gayā.

original: titthasammate udake paṭhamaṃ nimuggasakalasarīrā tato ummujjanti vuṭṭhahanti uppilavanti.
analyzed: tittha sammate udake paṭhamam nimugga sakala sarīrā tatas ummujjanti vuṭṭhahanti uppilavanti
translated: They first sink down in the water at the place where they have decided to do their purification, and then they come up again, and they come up again and again.

original: Nimujjantīti sasīsaṃ udake osīdanti. Ummujjanimujjampi karontīti punappunaṃ ummujjananimujjanānipi karonti.
analyzed: nimujjanti iti sa sīsam udake osīdanti ummujja nimujjam pi karonti iti punappunam ummujjana nimujjanāni api karonti
translated: They sink down means they go down in the water with their heads. They come up and sink down means they come up and go down again and again.

original: Tattha hi keci “ekummujjaneneva pāpasuddhi hotī”ti evaṃdiṭṭhikā, te ummujjanameva
analyzed: tattha hi keci eka ummujjanena iva pāpa suddhi hoti iti evaṃdiṭṭhikā te ummujjanam eva
translated: For some have the view that purification comes about just by coming up once, and they go away after coming up once.

original: katvā gacchanti. Ummujjanaṃ pana nimujjanamantarena natthīti avinābhāvato nimujjanampi
analyzed: katvā gacchanti ummujjanam pana nimujjanam antarena na atthi iti avinābhāvataḥ nimujjanam pi
translated: But because coming up is invariably associated with going down, they also go down.

original: te karontiyeva. Yepi “ekanimujjaneneva pāpasuddhi hotī”ti evaṃdiṭṭhikā, tepi ekavārameva🔽nimujjitvā vuttanayena avinābhāvato ummujjanampi katvā pakkamanti. Ye pana “tasmiṃ
analyzed: te ye pi eka nimujjanena iva pāpa suddhi hoti iti evaṃdiṭṭhikā te pi eka vāram eva  nimujjitvā vutta nayena avinābhāvataḥ ummujjanam pi katvā pakkamanti ye pana tasmin
translated: And some have the view that purification comes about just by going down once, and they go away after going down once.🔽But because going down is invariably associated with coming up, they also come up.

original: titthe nimujjaneneva pāpasuddhi hotī”ti evaṃdiṭṭhikā, te tattha nimujjitvā assāse
analyzed: titthe nimujjanena iva pāpa suddhi hoti iti evaṃdiṭṭhikā te tattha nimujjitvā
translated: And some have the view that purification comes about just by going down at that place, and they go away after going down there.

original: sannirumbhitvā maruppapātapatitā viya tattheva jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpuṇanti. Apare “punappunaṃ
analyzed: sannirumbhitvā maru papāta patitāḥ viya tattha iva jīvita kkhayam pāpuṇanti apare punappunam
translated: and they die there like those who have fallen from a precipice in the wilderness. Others, holding the view that “bathing is a means of purification,”

original: ummujjananimujjanāni katvā nhāte pāpasuddhi hotī”ti evaṃdiṭṭhikā, te kālena kālaṃ
analyzed: ummujjana nimujjanāni katvā nhāte pāpa suddhi hoti iti evaṃdiṭṭhikā te kālena kālam
translated: bathe again and again, plunging in and out.

original: ummujjananimujjanāni karonti. Te sabbepi sandhāya vuttaṃ – “ummujjantipi nimujjantipi🔽ummujjanimujjampi karontī”ti. Ettha ca kiñcāpi nimujjanapubbakaṃ ummujjanaṃ, nimujjanameva🔽pana karontā katipayā, ummujjanaṃ tadubhayañca karontā bahūti tesaṃ yebhuyyabhāvadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: ummujjana nimujjanāni karonti te sabbe pi sandhāya vuttam ummujjanti pi nimujjanti pi  ummujja nimujjam pi karonti iti ettha ca kiñcā api nimujjana pubbakam ummujjanam nimujjanam eva  pana karontā katipayāḥ ummujjanam tat ubhayam ca karontā bahū ti tesam yebhuyya bhāva dassana attham
translated: All these are referred to in the text by the words “they plunge in and out, they plunge in and out again and again.”🔽And although the plunging out is prior to the plunging in, still the text speaks of “plunging out” first in order to show that there are fewer who plunge in only, while there are more who plunge out.

original: ummujjanaṃ paṭhamaṃ vuttaṃ. Tathā sambahulā jaṭilāti jaṭilānaṃ yebhuyyatāya vuttaṃ,
analyzed: ummujjanam paṭhamam vuttam tathā sambahulāḥ jaṭilā ati jaṭilānam yebhuyyatāya vuttam
translated: Similarly, “many knotted-haired ascetics” are mentioned in order to show that there were more of them than of the others.

original: muṇḍasikhaṇḍinopi ca brāhmaṇā udakasuddhikā tasmiṃ kāle tattha tathā karonti.
analyzed: muṇḍa sikhaṇḍinaḥ api ca brāhmaṇāḥ tasmin kāle tattha tathā karonti
translated: For at that time there were also many shaven-headed ascetics and naked ascetics who performed water rites.

original: Osiñcantīti keci gayāya udakaṃ hatthena gahetvā attano sīse ca sarīre ca osiñcanti,
analyzed: osiñcanti iti keci gayāya udakam hatthena gahetvā attano sīse ca sarīre ca osiñcanti
translated: Some, taking water in their hands, sprinkle their heads and bodies with it.

original: apare ghaṭehi udakaṃ gahetvā tīre ṭhatvā tathā karonti. Aggiṃ juhantīti keci gayātīre
analyzed: apare ghaṭehi udakam gahetvā tīre ṭhatvā tathā karonti aggim juhanti iti keci gayā tīre
translated: Others, taking water in jars, do likewise while standing on the bank. They worship fire: some, having prepared an altar on the bank of the Gayā,

original: vediṃ sajjetvā dhūmadabbhipūjādike upakaraṇe upanetvā aggihutaṃ juhanti aggihutaṃ
analyzed: vedim sajjetvā dhūma dabbhi pūjā ādike upakaraṇe upanetvā aggi hutam juhanti aggi hutam
translated: bring the requisites such as the dhūmadabbī and worship fire, i.e. they offer oblations into the fire.

original: paricaranti. Iminā suddhīti iminā gayāyaṃ ummujjanādinā aggiparicaraṇena ca pāpamalato
analyzed: paricaranti iminā ummujjana ādinā aggi paricaraṇena ca
translated: By this purification: by this purification in the Gayā, by rising up from the water, etc., and by worshipping fire,

original: suddhi pāpapavāhanā saṃsārasuddhi eva vā hotīti evaṃdiṭṭhikā hutvāti attho.
analyzed: suddhi pāpa pavāhanā saṃsāra suddhi eva vā hoti iti evaṃdiṭṭhikā hutvā attho
translated: there is purification from the stain of evil, or there is purification in the round of rebirths. The meaning is that they hold this view.

original: Ummujjanādi cettha nidassanamattaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tesu hi keci udakavāsaṃ vasanti,
analyzed: ummujjana ādi ca ittha nidassana mattam vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam tesu hi keci udaka vāsam vasanti
translated: Here, rising up from the water, etc., should be regarded as mentioned only by way of illustration. For some of them live in the water,

original: keci udakassañjaliṃ denti, keci tasmiṃ udake ṭhatvā candimasūriye anuparivattanti,
analyzed: keci udakassañjalim denti keci tasmin udake ṭhatvā candima sūriye anuparivattanti
translated: some offer water in handfuls, some stand in the water and circle the moon and sun,

original: keci anekasahassavāraṃ sāvittiādike japanti, keci “inda āgacchā”tiādinā vijjājapaṃ
analyzed: aneka sahassa vāram sāvitti ādike japanti keci indo āgacchāti ādinā vijjājapam
translated: some chant the Sāvitti, etc., many thousands of times, some invoke the incantation of the vijjā by saying “Inda āgacchā” ,

original: avhāyanti, keci mahatupaṭṭhānaṃ karonti, evañca karontā keci otaranti, keci uttaranti
analyzed: avhāyanti keci mahat upaṭṭhānam karonti evañca karontā keci otaranti keci uttaranti
translated: some perform the great worship, and while doing so some go down and some come up.

original: keci uttaritvā suddhikaācamanaṃ karonti, keci antoudake ṭhitā tantī vādenti, vīṇaṃ🔽vādentīti evamādikā nānappakārakiriyā dassenti. Yasmā vā te evarūpā vikārakiriyā
analyzed: uttaritvā suddhika ācamanam karonti keci antar udake ṭhitā tantī vādenti vīṇam  vādenti iti evamādikāḥ nānā pakāra kiriyāḥ dassenti yasmai vā te evarūpā vikāra kiriyā
translated: Some, after coming out, performed pure ablutions, some, standing in the water, played the lute, the flute, the guitar, the drum, and so on.🔽Or, because they performed such various actions while doing such transformations,🔽all that is included in the phrase “while diving in and out.”

original: karontāpi tasmiṃ udake nimujjanaummujjanapubbakameva karonti, tasmā taṃ sabbaṃ nimujjanummujjanantogadhameva🔽katvā “ummujjantī”tipiādi vuttaṃ. Evaṃ tattha ākulabyākule vattamāne uparipabbate🔽ṭhito bhagavā tesaṃ taṃ kolāhalaṃ sutvā “kinnu kho eta”nti olokento taṃ kiriyavikāraṃ
analyzed: karontā api tasmim udake nimujjana ommujjana pubbakam eva karonti tasmai tam sabbam nimujjan ummujjana ntogadham eva  katvā ummujjanti iti pi ādi vuttam evam tattha ākula byākule vattamāne upari pabbate  ṭhitaḥ bhagavā tesam tam kolāhalam sutvā kinnu kho etat ti olokentaḥ tam kiriya vikāram
translated: Thus, while they were acting in this way, the Blessed One, who was standing on the mountain top,🔽heard their commotion and looked to see what it was. He saw their actions and transformations.🔽With reference to that, it was said: “The Blessed One saw the brahmin student Jotipala and those brahmins performing ablutions in the river Aciravatl. . . . This is the purification.” The meaning is the same.

original: addasa, taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “addasā kho bhagavā…pe… iminā suddhī”ti, taṃ vuttatthameva.
analyzed: addasa tam sandhāya vuttam addasā kho bhagavā āpe iminā suddhi iti tam vutta ttham eva
translated: Having understood the meaning

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ atthaṃ udakorohanādiasuddhimagge tesaṃ suddhimaggaparāmasanaṃ
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam attham udakorohana ādi a suddhi magge tesam suddhi magga parāmasanam
translated: Having understood the meaning of their taking the wrong path of purification, beginning with their entering the water,

original: saccādike ca suddhimagge attano aviparītāvabodhaṃ sabbākārato viditvā. Imaṃ udānanti
analyzed: sacca ādike ca suddhi magge attanaḥ aviparīta avabodham sabba ākārataḥ viditvā imam udānanti
translated: and having understood the unperverted knowledge of his own path to purity in the Truths, etc.,🔽he uttered this utterance,

original: imaṃ udakasuddhiyā asuddhimaggabhāvadīpakaṃ saccādidhammānañca yāthāvato suddhimaggabhāvadīpakaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: imam udaka suddhiyāḥ asuddhi magga bhāva dīpakam sacca ādi dhammānam ca yāthāvataḥ suddhi magga bhāva dīpakam udānam udānesi
translated: which illuminates the impure path of water-purity, and which illuminates the pure path of the Truths, etc., as they are.

original: Tattha na udakena sucī hotīti ettha udakenāti udakummujjanādinā. Udakummujjanādi
analyzed: tattha na udakena sucī hoti iti ettha udakena ati uda kummujjana ādinā uda kummujjana ādi
translated: Herein, as regards the words “One is not purified by water” , “by water” means by the action of splashing water, etc.

original: hi idha uttarapadalopena “udaka”nti vuttaṃ yathā rūpabhavo rūpanti. Atha vā udakenāti
analyzed: hi uttara pada lopena udakam iti vuttam yathā rūpa bhavaḥ atha vā udakena ati
translated: For the action of splashing water, etc., is here called “water” by the elision of the intermediate word, as “The essence of form” is called “form” .🔽Or alternatively, “by water” means by water which is the means to the action of splashing water, etc.

original: ummujjanādikiriyāya sādhanabhūtena udakena suci sattassa suddhi nāma na hoti, natthīti
analyzed: ummujjana ādi kiriyāya sādhana bhūtena udakena suci sattassa suddhi nāma na hoti natthi iti
translated: Purification of a being by means of water does not exist, does not occur.🔽This is the meaning.

original: attho. Atha vā sucīti tena yathāvuttena udakena suci pāpamalato suddho nāma satto
analyzed: attho atha vā suci iti tena yathāvuttena udakena suci pāpa malataḥ suddhaḥ nāma satto
translated: Or “purified” means cleansed of the stain of evil by means of the water described above.🔽A being does not exist who is purified.

original: na hoti. Kasmā? Bahvettha nhāyatī jano. Yadi hi udakorohanādinā yathāvuttena pāpasuddhi
analyzed: na hoti kasmai bahu ettha nhāyatī janaḥ yadi hi udakorohana ādinā yathāvuttena
translated: Why not? Because many people bathe here. If purification from evil were to be by the action of splashing water, etc., as described above,

original: nāma siyā, bahu ettha udake jano nhāyati, mātughātādipāpakammakārī añño ca gomahiṃsādiko
analyzed: nāma siyā bahu ettha udake janaḥ nhāyati mātughāta ādi pāpa kamma kārī añño ca go mahiṃsa ādiko
translated: There may be, but it is not so. Many people bathe in the water, such as a matricide, a parricide, a murderer of a perfected one, and one who has committed any of the other evil deeds, such as the killing of cattle, etc.,

original: antamaso macchakacchape upādāya, tassa sabbassāpi pāpasuddhi siyā, na panevaṃ hoti.
analyzed: antamasaḥ maccha kacchape upādāya tassa sabbassa api pāpa suddhi siyā na pana evam hoti
translated: and even fish and turtles. But there is no purification of any of their evil deeds.

original: Kasmā? Nhānassa pāpahetūnaṃ appaṭipakkhabhāvato. Yañhi yaṃ vināseti, so tassa paṭipakkho
analyzed: kasmā nhānassa pāpa hetūnam appaṭipakkha bhāvataḥ yam hi yam vināseti saḥ tassa paṭipakkhaḥ
translated: Why is it not so? Because bathing is not a counteragent to the causes of evil. That which destroys something is a counteragent to it,

original: yathā āloko andhakārassa, vijjā ca avijjāya, na evaṃ nhānaṃ pāpassa. Tasmā niṭṭhamettha
analyzed: yathā ālokaḥ andhakārassa vijjā ca avijjāya na evam nhānam pāpassa tasmā niṭṭham ettha
translated: like light to darkness, and knowledge to ignorance. But bathing is not a counteragent to evil in this way. Therefore it should be concluded

original: gantabbaṃ “na udakena suci hotī”ti.
analyzed: gantabbam naḥ udakena suci hoti iti
translated: that one is not purified by water.

original: Yena pana suci hoti, taṃ dassetuṃ “yamhi saccañcā”tiādimāha. Tattha yamhīti yasmiṃ
analyzed: yena pana suci hoti tam dassetum yamhi saccañca iti ādim āha tattha yamhi iti yasmin
translated: In order to show by what one is purified, he said, “In whom there is truth and Dhamma” . Herein, in whom means in which person.

original: puggale. Saccanti vacīsaccañceva viratisaccañca. Atha vā saccanti ñāṇasaccañceva
analyzed: puggale saccanti vacī saccañca iva virati saccañca atha vā saccanti ñāṇa saccañca iva
translated: Truth is truth of speech and truth of abstinence. Or alternatively, truth is the truth of knowledge and

original: paramatthasaccañca. Dhammoti ariyamaggadhammo, phaladhammo ca, so sabbopi yasmiṃ
analyzed: paramattha saccam ca dhammo ti ariya magga dhammo phala dhammo ca so sabbaḥ api yasmin
translated: the truth of the ultimate . Dhamma is the Dhamma of the noble path and the Dhamma of the fruits . All of that is in whom.

original: puggale upalabbhati, so sucī so ca brāhmaṇoti so ariyapuggalo visesato khīṇāsavo
analyzed: puggale upalabbhati saḥ sucī so ca brāhmaṇo ti saḥ ariya puggalaḥ visesataḥ khīṇa āsavaḥ
translated: He is pure and a brahmin.

original: accantasuddhiyā suci ca brāhmaṇo cāti. Kasmā panettha saccaṃ dhammato visuṃ katvā
analyzed: suci ca ca ati kasmā pana ittha saccam dhammataḥ visum katvā
translated: Why is truth here taken separately as a virtue?

original: gahitaṃ? Saccassa bahūpakārattā. Tathā hi “saccaṃ ve amatā vācā, saccaṃ have sādutaraṃ
analyzed: gahitam saccassa bahu upakāra ttā tathā hi saccam ve amatā vācā saccam have sādutaram
translated: Because it is very helpful. For in many places in the suttas the virtue of truth is revealed thus: “Truth is the immortal speech,🔽Truth is the sweetest taste,🔽In truth and meaning and in law, the good are established.

original: rasānaṃ, sacce atthe ca dhamme ca, āhu santo patiṭṭhitā, sacce ṭhitā samaṇabrāhmaṇā
analyzed: rasānam sacce atthe ca dhamme ca āhu santaḥ patiṭṭhitā sacce ṭhitā samaṇa brāhmaṇā
translated: The ascetics and brahmins stand on truth” .🔽And the opposite of truth is revealed thus: “For a man who has passed beyond

original: cā”tiādinā anekesu suttapadesu saccaguṇā pakāsitā. Saccavipariyassa ca “ekaṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: ca ati ādinā anekesu sutta padesu sacca guṇā pakāsitā sacca vipariyassa ca ekam dhammam
translated: The one law, the liar,

original: atītassa, musāvādissa jantuno, abhūtavādī nirayaṃ upetī”ti ca ādinā pakāsitāti.
analyzed: atītassa musāvādissa jantunaḥ abhūta vādī nirayam upeti iti ca ādinā pakāsitā ati
translated: Goes to hell” .

original: Navamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽10. Bāhiyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: navama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  bāhiya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the ninth sutta is ended.🔽The Sutta on Bāhiya

original: 10. Dasame bāhiyoti tassa nāmaṃ. Dārucīriyoti dārumayacīro. Suppāraketi evaṃnāmake
analyzed: dasame bāhiyoti tassa nāmam dārucīriyoti dāru maya cīro suppāraka iti evaṃnāmake
translated: In the tenth sutta, Bāhiya was his name. Dārucīriya means “having a head of wood.” Suppāraka was the name of a

original: paṭṭane vasati. Ko panāyaṃ bāhiyo, kathañca dārucīriyo ahosi, kathaṃ suppārake paṭṭane paṭivasatīti?
analyzed: paṭṭane vasati kaḥ pana ayam bāhiyaḥ katham ca dārucīriyaḥ ahosi katham suppārake paṭṭane paṭivasati iti
translated: He lives in the town of Suppāraka. But who was this Bāhiya, and how did he come to be called Dārucīriya? And how did he come to live in the town of Suppāraka?

original: Tatrāyaṃ anupubbīkathā – ito kira kappasatasahassamatthake padumuttarasammāsambuddhakāle
analyzed: tatra ayam anupubbī kathā itas kira kappa sata sahassa matthake padumuttara sammāsambuddha kāle

translated: Honoured, respected, esteemed, worshipped, revered.”🔽Herein, honoured means honoured with attendance by being waited on with reverence and deference.🔽Respected means respected with the respect due to his special qualities,

translated: He is honoured when he is honoured with the giving of a path, a seat, and so on. original: uparūpari upanīyamānānaṃ cīvarādīnaṃ catunnaṃ paccayānaṃ labhanavasena lābhī.

translated: One whom they do all this by way of worship is worshipped. One to whom they give them after paying homage with the duties of reverential salutation, rising up, raising joined palms, and worshipping is revered.

original: paramanipaccakāraṃ karonti, so apacito. Bāhiyassa pana te sabbametaṃ akaṃsu. Tena🔽vuttaṃ – “bāhiyo dārucīriyo suppārake paṭivasati sakkato”tiādi. Ettha ca cīvaraṃ
analyzed: karonti saḥ apacitaḥ bāhiyassa pana te sabbam etam akaṃsu tena  vuttam bāhiyaḥ dārucīriyaḥ suppārake paṭivasati sakkato tiādi ettha ca cīvaram
translated: He was honoured by them, and so he was honoured. But they did all this for Bāhiya.

original: so aggaṇhantopi “ehi, bhante, imaṃ vatthaṃ paṭiggaṇhāhī”ti upanāmanavasena cīvarassāpi “lābhī”tveva vutto.🔽Rahogatassāti rahasi gatassa. Paṭisallīnassāti ekībhūtassa bahūhi manussehi “arahā”ti

translated: Therefore it was said: “Bāhiya of the Bark Robe, who was staying at Suppāraka, was honoured, revered, esteemed, worshipped, and venerated” . original: vuccamānassa tassa idāni vuccamānākārena cetaso parivitakko udapādi cittassa micchāsaṅkappo
analyzed: vuccamānassa tassa idāni vuccamāna ākārena cetasaḥ parivitakkaḥ udapādi cittassa micchā saṅkappo
