How? “Whatever ascetics or brahmins in the world have reached, are reaching, or shall reach …🔽I am one of them.” The meaning is: “Whatever ascetics or brahmins in this world have reached …

original: uppajji. Kathaṃ? Ye kho keci loke arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannā, ahaṃ tesaṃ🔽aññataroti. Tassattho – ye imasmiṃ sattaloke kilesārīnaṃ hatattā pūjāsakkārādīnañca
analyzed: uppajji katham ye kho keci loke arahantaḥ vā arahatta maggam vā samāpannāḥ aham tesam 🔽aññatarā ti tassa atthaḥ ye imasmin satta loke kilesa arīnam hata ttā pūjā sakkāra ādīnam ca
translated: I am one of them.”

original: arahabhāvena arahanto, ye kilesārīnaṃ hananena arahattamaggaṃ samāpannā, tesu ahaṃ ekoti.🔽Purāṇasālohitāti purimasmiṃ bhavesālohitā bandhusadisā ekato katasamaṇadhammā devatā.
analyzed: araha bhāvena arahantaḥ ye kilesa arīnam hananena arahatta maggam samāpannā tesu aham ekaḥ ti  purāṇasālohitā ati purimasmin bandhu sadisā ekatas kata samaṇa dhammā devatā
translated: They are Arahants because of their state of being Arahants, and I am one of them because of my attainment of the Arahant path by the destruction of the defilements.🔽The deity Purāṇa Sālohitā: in a previous existence she was a deity who was related to me and who had been my companion in the practice of the spiritual life.

original: Keci pana “purāṇasālohitāti purāṇakāle bhavantare sālohitā mātubhūtā ekā devatā”ti
analyzed: pana purāṇa sālohitāḥ ati purāṇa kāle bhavantare sālohitāḥ mātu bhūtāḥ ekā devatā iti
translated: But some say that the deity Purāṇa Sālohitā was my mother in a previous existence.

original: vadanti, taṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ paṭikkhipitvā purimoyevattho gahito.
analyzed: vadanti tam aṭṭhakathāyam paṭikkhipitvā gahitaḥ
translated: This is rejected in the commentary, and the former explanation is accepted.🔽It seems that in the past, when the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa was declining, seven bhikkhus,

original: Pubbe kira kassapadasabalassa sāsane osakkamāne sāmaṇerādīnaṃ vippakāraṃ disvā satta
analyzed: pubbe kira kassapadasabalassa sāsane osakkamāne sāmaṇera ādīnam vippakāram disvā satta
translated: seeing the misconduct of the novices and others, were deeply moved.

original: bhikkhū saṃvegappattā “yāva sāsanaṃ na antaradhāyati, tāva attano patiṭṭhaṃ karissāmā”ti
analyzed: bhikkhū saṃvega pattāḥ yāva sāsanam na antaradhāyati tāva attanaḥ patiṭṭham karissāma ati
translated: They said, “As long as the dispensation does not disappear, we will maintain our position.”

original: suvaṇṇacetiyaṃ vanditvā araññaṃ paviṭṭhā ekaṃ pabbataṃ disvā “jīvite sālayā nivattantu,
analyzed: suvaṇṇa cetiyam vanditvā araññam paviṭṭhāḥ ekam pabbatam disvā jīvite sa ālayāḥ nivattantu
translated: After paying homage to the Golden Shrine, they entered the forest. Seeing a mountain, they said, “Let those who have a home to go to turn back.

original: nirālayā imaṃ pabbataṃ abhiruhantū”ti vatvā nisseṇiṃ bandhitvā sabbe taṃ pabbataṃ
analyzed: nirālayāḥ imam pabbatam abhiruhantu iti vatvā nisseṇim bandhitvā sabbe tam pabbatam

analyzed: arahattam pāpuṇi saḥ uttarakurutaḥ piṇḍapātam ānetvā te bhikkhū āvuso itas piṇḍapātam  paribhuñjatha iti āha te tumhe bhante attanaḥ ānubhāvena evam akattha mayam pi
translated: He brought alms food from Uttarakuru and said to the bhikkhus, “Friends, eat the alms food from here.”🔽They said, “Venerable sir, you did this by your own power. If we too could develop distinction

analyzed: kumārakassapaḥ ekaḥ dabbaḥ malla putto ekaḥ sabhiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ ekaḥ bāhiyaḥ dārucīriyaḥ  tattha yaḥ saḥ anāgāmī brahma loke nibbatto tam sandhāya itam vuttam purāṇasālohitā

analyzed: atha kho aññatarā devatā ati ādīsu viya idha pana brahmā devatā ati adhippeto

translated: On this occasion, he directed his mind to the question, “Where is Bāhiya?” and he saw him living at Suppāraka on the coast, making a living by trading in salt and timber.🔽“This man,” he thought, “was my companion in the past. He would not eat the alms-food brought by the arahats.

original: piṇḍapātaṃ aparibhuñjitvā idāni sambhāvanādhippāyo anarahāva arahattaṃ paṭijānitvā

translated: Now he is living a life of luxury, and he claims to be an arahat, though he is not.

original: vicarati lābhasakkārasilokaṃ nikāmayamāno, dasabalassa ca nibbattabhāvaṃ na jānāti,
analyzed: vicarati lābha sakkāra silokam nikāmayamānaḥ dasabalassa ca nibbatta bhāvam na jānāti

analyzed: suppārakapaṭṭane dārucīriyassa sammukhe pāturahosi bāhiyaḥ attanaḥ vasanaṭṭhāne uḷāram
translated: light in his own dwelling place,

analyzed: obhāsam disvā kim nu kho etanti bahi nikkhamitvā olokentaḥ ākāse ṭhitam mahābrahmānam
translated: went out and looked around. Seeing the Great Brahma standing in the sky,

analyzed: arahā paṭinissajjetam pāpakam diṭṭhi gatam mā te ahosi dīgharattam ahitāya
translated: Bāhiya, you are not a Worthy, give up this evil view, don’t let it be for your long-term harm,🔽harm, suffering.”

analyzed: dukkhāya sammāsambuddhaḥ loke uppannaḥ saḥ hi bhagavā arahā gaccha nam payirupāsassu iti

translated: So it was that the deity who was a former intimate friend of Bahiya of the Bark-cloth said this, etc.

translated: she shows that the deity was desirous of removing Bahiya’s suffering, and by the second that she was desirous of bringing him welfare.🔽‘With her own mind’ means with her own mind, with her own thought. original: nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya,

translated: ‘The thought that was in his mind’: the occurrence of that thought in his mind. ‘She knew’: she understood. ‘She approached him’: just as a strong man might extend his flexed arm or flex his extended arm,

analyzed: evam eva brahma loke antarahitaḥ bāhiyassa puratas pātubhavana vasena etat avoca ati
translated: so did she vanish from the Brahmā-world and appear in front of Bahiya. ‘She said this’:

analyzed: ye kho keci loke arahantaḥ vāti ādi pavattam icchā parivitakkam bāhiyam sahoḍham coram  gaṇhantaḥ viya na iva kho tvam arahā ati ādikam etam idāni vuccamāna vacanam
translated: “‘Whoever in the world are arahants’ and so on, is a wrong thought of covetousness that had arisen in Bāhiya.🔽The Brahmā said this statement now being spoken, ‘You are not an arahant, Bāhiya,’

original: nāpi arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannoti etena sekkhabhāvaṃ, ubhayenapissa anariyabhāvameva
analyzed: na api arahatta maggam vā samāpannoti etena sekkha bhāvam ubhayena api ssa anariya bhāvam eva
translated: ‘Nor have you entered the path to arahantship,’ by this he rejects his state of being a learner. By both he shows that he is not a noble one.

original: dīpeti. Sāpi te paṭipadā natthi, yāya tvaṃ arahā vā assa arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannoti
analyzed: dīpeti sā api te paṭipadā natthi yāya tvam arahā vā assa arahatta maggam vā samāpanno ti
translated: ‘There is no way for you to be an arahant or to enter the path to arahantship,’

analyzed: iminā pana assa kalyāṇa puthujjana bhāvam pi paṭikkhipati tattha paṭipadā ti sīla visuddhi ādayaḥ
translated: by this he rejects his state of being a good worldling. Therein, ‘way’ is the six purifications beginning with purification of virtue.

original: cha visuddhiyo. Paṭipajjati etāya ariyamaggeti paṭipadā. Assāti bhaveyyāsi.🔽Ayañcassa arahattādhimāno kiṃ nissāya uppannoti? “Appicchatāya santuṭṭhitāya sallekhatāya
analyzed: cha visuddhiyaḥ paṭipajjati etāya ariya magge ti paṭipadā assa ati bhaveyyāsi 🔽ayam ca assa arahatta adhimāno kim nissāya uppannaḥ ti appiccha tāya santuṭṭhitāya sallekha tāya
translated: ‘Path’ is that by which one enters. ‘You would be’ means you would become.

original: dīgharattaṃ katādhikārattā tadaṅgappahānavasena kilesānaṃ vihatattā arahattādhimāno
analyzed: dīgharattam kata adhikāra ttā tad aṅga ppahāna vasena kilesānam vihata ttā arahatta adhimāno
translated: Some say that it was because he had long practised the duties of a monk and had thus destroyed the defilements by abandoning their concomitants that he had the conceit of being an arahant.

original: uppanno”ti keci vadanti. Apare panāhu “bāhiyo paṭhamādijhānacatukkalābhī, tasmāssa🔽vikkhambhanappahānena kilesānaṃ asamudācārato arahattādhimāno uppajjatī”ti. Tadubhayampi
analyzed: uppannaḥ iti keci vadanti apare pana āhu tasmā assa  vikkhambhana ppahānena kilesānam asamudācārataḥ arahatta adhimānaḥ uppajjati iti tat ubhayam pi
translated: Others say that it was because he had attained the first jhāna and the four paths that he had the conceit of being an arahant.

original: tesaṃ matimattameva “sambhāvanādhippāyo lābhasakkārasilokaṃ nikāmayamāno”ti ca aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: tesam matimattam eva sambhāvanā adhippāyaḥ lābha sakkāra silokam nikāmayamāno ti ca aṭṭhakathāyam
translated: But both of these opinions are mere conjecture. For the commentary says that he had the conceit of being an arahant because he was desirous of gain, honour, and renown, and because he was intent on being regarded as such.

original: āgatattā. Tasmā vuttanayenevettha attho veditabbo.
analyzed: āgata ttā tasmā vutta nayena iva ittha atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: Therefore the meaning should be understood in the way stated.

original: Atha bāhiyo ākāse ṭhatvā kathentaṃ mahābrahmānaṃ oloketvā cintesi – “aho bhāriyaṃ🔽vata kammaṃ, yamahaṃ arahāti cintesiṃ, ayañca ‘arahattagāminī paṭipadāpi te natthī’ti
analyzed: atha bāhiyaḥ ākāse ṭhatvā kathentam mahābrahmānam oloketvā cintesi aho bhāriyam  vata kammam yam aham cintesim ayam ca arahatta gāminī paṭipadā api te natthi iti
translated: Then Bāhiya, looking at Mahā-Brahmā who was speaking thus while standing in the air, thought: “Oh, what a heavy burden I have taken up,

original: vadati, atthi nu kho loke koci arahā”ti? Atha naṃ pucchi. Tena vuttaṃ – “atha ke
analyzed: vadati atthi nu kho loke koci arahā ati atha nam pucchi tena vuttam atha ke
translated: that I should think of myself as an arahant, and this one should say to me: ‘You do not even have the way to arahantship.’ Is there anyone in the world who is an arahant?” And he asked him. Therefore it is said: “Then he asked him … ”

original: carahi devate loke arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannā”ti.
analyzed: carahi devate loke arahantaḥ vā arahatta maggam vā
translated: “Do any of the Arahants or Arahant-path-attainers live in the world now?”

analyzed: tattha atha ati puccha ārambhe nipāto ke carahi iti ke etarahi loke iti okāsa loke ayan ha ittha
translated: Herein, now is a particle indicating a question. Who? —Who are they? In the world: in the world as the location. The intention is this:

analyzed: adhippāyaḥ bhājana loka bhūte sakalasmin jambudīpa tale kasmin ṭhāne arahantaḥ vā arahatta maggam
translated: “In what place in the whole of Jambudīpa, which is the world as container,🔽do the Arahants or those who have entered upon the Arahant-path live now,

original: vā samāpannā etarahi viharanti, yattha mayaṃ te upasaṅkamitvā tesaṃ ovāde ṭhatvā
analyzed: vā samāpannāḥ etarahi viharanti yattha mayam te upasaṅkamitvā tesam ovāde ṭhatvā
translated: so that we could go there and, by keeping to their advice,

analyzed: vaṭṭa dukkhataḥ muccissāma ati uttaresu iti suppāraka paṭṭanataḥ pubbuttara disā bhāgam sandhāya vuttam
translated: be released from the suffering of the round?” The north is said in reference to the northern direction beginning with Suppāraka.

analyzed: arahanti āraka ttā araham ārakā hi so sabba kilesehi su vidūra vidūre ṭhitaḥ maggena  kilesānam vā hatattā araham bhagavatā hi kilesa arayaḥ
translated: Arahant: he is an Arahant because he is far removed , for he is far removed, quite remote, from all defilements by means of the path.🔽Or he is an Arahant because he is a killer of enemies , for the Blessed One has killed without remainder the enemies beginning with greed and hate by means of the noble path.

original: anavasesato ariyamaggena hatā samucchinnāti. Arānaṃ vā hatattā arahaṃ. Yañca avijjābhavataṇhāmayanābhi
analyzed: anavasesataḥ ariya maggena hatā samucchinnā ati vā hata ttā araham yat ca
translated: Or he is an Arahant because he is one who has killed the killers , for the Blessed One has killed the killers, namely, ignorance, craving for becoming, and the conceit “I am,” by means of the noble path.

original: puññādiabhisaṅkhārāraṃ jarāmaraṇanemi āsavasamudayamayena akkhena vijjhitvā tibhavarathe
analyzed: puñña ādi abhisaṅkhāra aram jarā maraṇa nemi āsava samudaya mayena akkhena vijjhitvā ti bhava rathe
translated: The wheel of existence is the wheel of the round of rebirths, which is set in motion by the spokes of the formations of merit, etc.,🔽and is driven by the axle of the origin of the taints, and which is yoked to the three realms of existence,

original: samāyojitaṃ anādikālappavattaṃ saṃsāracakkaṃ. Tassānena bodhimaṇḍe vīriyapādehi sīlapathaviyaṃ
analyzed: samāyojitam anādi kāla ppavattam saṃsāra cakkam tassa anena bodhimaṇḍe vīriya pādehi sīla pathaviyam
translated: and which has been revolving from beginningless time. The Blessed One, having stood firm on the ground of virtue with the feet of energy,

original: patiṭṭhāya saddhāhatthena kammakkhayakarañāṇapharasuṃ gahetvā sabbepi arā hatā vihatā
analyzed: patiṭṭhāya saddhā hatthena kamma kkhaya kara ñāṇa pharasum gahetvā sabbe pi arāḥ hatāḥ vihatā
translated: and having taken up the axe of knowledge that destroys kamma with the hand of faith, cut down all the spokes of the wheel of the round of rebirths at the root.

original: viddhaṃsitāti. Arahatīti vā arahaṃ. Bhagavā hi sadevake loke aggadakkhiṇeyyattā uḷāre
analyzed: arahati iti vai araham bhagavā hi sa devake loke uḷāre
translated: Or alternatively, he is worthy of offerings because he is worthy of the foremost offerings in the world with its deities.

original: cīvarādipaccaye pūjāvisesañca arahati. Rahābhāvato vā arahaṃ. Tathāgato hi sabbaso
analyzed: cīvara ādi paccaye pūjā visesam ca arahati raha abhāvataḥ vā araham tathāgataḥ hi sabbaso
translated: Or he is worthy because he is worthy of the requisites of a bhikkhu, such as the yellow robes, etc., and of the special offerings of gifts and reverential salutation.

original: samucchinnarāgādikilesattā pāpakilesassāpi asambhavato pāpakaraṇe rahābhāvatopi arahanti vuccati.
analyzed: samucchinna rāga ādi kilesa ttā pāpa kilesassa api asambhavataḥ pāpa karaṇe arahanti vuccati
translated: Or he is worthy because he is worthy of the name “worthy” since he has no secret evil deeds, being devoid of all evil, such as lust, etc.

original: Sammā sāmañca sabbadhammānaṃ buddhattā sammāsambuddho. Bhagavā hi abhiññeyye dhamme
analyzed: sammā sāmañca sabba dhammānam buddha ttā sammāsambuddhaḥ bhagavā hi abhiññeyye dhamme
translated: He is a Perfectly Enlightened One because he has discovered all things rightly and by himself.

original: abhiññeyyato, pariññeyye dhamme pariññeyyato, pahātabbe dhamme pahātabbato, sacchikātabbe
analyzed: abhiññeyyataḥ pariññeyye dhamme pariññeyyataḥ pahātabbe dhamme pahātabbataḥ sacchikātabbe
translated: as to be directly known, of ideas that are to be fully understood as to full understanding, of ideas that are to be abandoned as to abandoning, of ideas that are to be realized as to realization,

original: dhamme sacchikātabbato, bhāvetabbe dhamme bhāvetabbato abhisambujjhi. Vuttañhetaṃ –🔽“Abhiññeyyaṃ abhiññātaṃ, bhāvetabbañca bhāvitaṃ;
analyzed: dhamme sacchikātabbataḥ bhāvetabbe dhamme bhāvetabbataḥ abhisambujjhi vuttam ha etam  abhiññeyyam abhiññātam bhāvetabbañca bhāvitam
translated: He fully awakened to them by knowing them as they really are as to be fully known, by knowing them as they really are as to be abandoned, by knowing them as they really are as to being to be realized, and by knowing them as they really are as to being to be developed. For this is said:

original: Pahātabbaṃ pahīnaṃ me, tasmā buddhosmi brāhmaṇā”ti. ;
analyzed: pahātabbam pahīnam me tasmai buddhaḥ asmi brāhmaṇa ati
translated: “What is to be fully known has been fully known, What is to be developed has been developed, What is to be abandoned has been abandoned by me, Therefore, brahmin, I am a Buddha.”

original: Apica kusale dhamme anavajjasukhavipākato, akusale dhamme sāvajjadukkhavipākatotiādinā🔽sabbattikadukādivasena ayamattho netabbo. Iti aviparītaṃ sayambhuñāṇena sabbākārato
analyzed: apica kusale dhamme anavajja sukha vipākato akusale dhamme sāvajja dukkha vipākato tiādinā  sabba ttika duka ādi vasena ayam attho netabbaḥ iti aviparītam sayambhu ñāṇena sabba ākārataḥ
translated: Moreover, this meaning should be understood by the method of the couplets and triplets beginning with “as to profitable ideas as having blameless pleasant consequences” and “as to unprofitable ideas as having blameable painful consequences.”

original: sabbadhammānaṃ abhisambuddhattā sammāsambuddhoti ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthāro pana
analyzed: sabba dhammānam abhisambuddha ttā sammāsambuddhaḥ ti ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana
translated: Thus, because he has fully awakened to all ideas in all aspects by means of his own direct-knowledge without relying on another’s advice, he is the “ Fully Enlightened One” . This is the brief account here. The detailed account comes to some 12,000 lines in the Visuddhimagga.

original: visuddhimagge āgatanayeneva veditabbo. Arahattāyāti aggaphalappaṭilābhāya. Dhammaṃ
analyzed: visuddhi magge āgata nayena iva veditabbaḥ arahattāya ati agga phala ppaṭilābhāya dhammaṃ
translated: To arahatship: to the attainment of the supreme fruit. The True Idea:

original: desetīti ādikalyāṇādiguṇavisesayuttaṃ sīlādipaṭipadādhammaṃ samathavipassanādhammameva
analyzed: deseti iti ādi kalyāṇa ādi guṇa visesa yuttam sīla ādi paṭipadā dhammam samatha vipassanā dhammam eva
translated: He teaches: he teaches the Dhamma of virtue, etc., which is endowed with the special qualities of being good in the beginning, etc., and the Dhamma of serenity and insight.

original: vā veneyyajjhāsayānurūpaṃ upadisati katheti.
analyzed: vā veneyya jhāsayā anurūpam upadisati kathā iti
translated: He teaches: he teaches, he expounds, the Dhamma of virtue, etc., which is endowed with the special qualities of being good in the beginning, etc., or else the Dhamma of serenity and insight, according to the inclination of those who need training.

original: Saṃvejitoti “dhiratthu vata, bho, puthujjanabhāvassa, yenāhaṃ anarahāva samāno arahāti
analyzed: saṃvejitaḥ iti vata bho puthujjana bhāvassa yena aham samānaḥ
translated: He is stirred: “Shame on me that I have been a worldling, that I have claimed to be an arahant,

original: amaññiṃ, sammāsambuddhañca loke uppajjitvā dhammaṃ desentaṃ na jāniṃ, dujjānaṃ kho🔽panidaṃ jīvitaṃ, dujjānaṃ maraṇa”nti saṃvegamāpādito, devatāvacanena yathāvuttenākārena🔽saṃviggamānasoti attho. Tāvadevāti tasmiṃyeva khaṇe. Suppārakā pakkāmīti buddhoti
analyzed: amaññim sammāsambuddham ca loke uppajjitvā dhammam desentam na jānim dujjānam kho  jīvitam dujjānam saṃvegam āpāditaḥ devatā vacanena yathā vuttena ākārena  saṃvigga mānasaḥ ti attho tāvat eva ati tasmin yeva khaṇe suppārakā pakkāmi iti buddhaḥ ti
translated: that I have not known the Buddha arisen in the world, that I have not known the Dhamma taught by him, that I have not known the Sangha of his disciples well trained.”🔽He is stirred by the thought: “Life is a matter of chance, death is a matter of chance.🔽” The meaning is that he is stirred in mind in the way described by the words of the deity.

original: nāmamapi savanena uppannāya buddhārammaṇāya pītiyā saṃvegena ca codiyamānahadayo
analyzed: nāmam api savanena uppannāya buddha ārammaṇāya pītiyā saṃvegena ca codiyamāna hadayaḥ
translated: He set out for Savatthi: urged on by the joy that arose in him at the mere hearing of the word “Buddha” and by the stirring of his heart, he set out for Savatthi, aiming at Savatthi, from the district of Suppāraka.

original: suppārakapaṭṭanato sāvatthiṃ uddissa pakkanto. Sabbattha ekarattiparivāsenāti sabbasmiṃ
analyzed: suppāraka paṭṭanataḥ sāvatthim uddissa pakkantaḥ sabbattha eka ratti parivāsena ati sabbasmin
translated: He stayed one night in every place: in every place

original: magge ekarattivāseneva agamāsi. Suppārakapaṭṭanato hi sāvatthi vīsayojanasate hoti,
analyzed: magge eka ratti vāsena iva agamāsi suppāraka paṭṭanataḥ hi sāvatthi vīsa yojana sate hoti
translated: and he reached Sāvatthī in one night. For Sāvatthī is two hundred and fifty leagues from Suppāraka,

original: tañcāyaṃ ettakaṃ addhānaṃ ekarattivāsena agamāsi. Yadā suppārakato nikkhanto, tadaheva
analyzed: tat ca ayam ettakam addhānam eka ratti vāsena agamāsi yadā suppārakataḥ nikkhanto tadahā iva
translated: and he reached it in one night. When he left Suppāraka,

original: sāvatthiṃ sampattoti.🔽Kathaṃ panāyaṃ evaṃ agamāsīti? Devatānubhāvena, “buddhānubhāvenā”tipi vadanti. “Sabbattha
analyzed: sāvatthim sampattoti  katham pana ayam evam agamāsi iti devatā anubhāvena buddha anubhāvena ati pi vadanti sabbattha
translated: he reached Sāvatthī on the same day.

original: ekarattiparivāsenā”ti pana vuttattā maggassa ca vīsayojanasatikattā antarāmagge gāmanigamarājadhānīsu
analyzed: eka ratti parivāsena āti pana vutta ttā maggassa ca vīsa yojana satika ttā antarāmagge gāma nigama rājadhānīsu
translated: But how did he go? By the power of the deities, some say. “By the power of the Buddha,” others say. But since it is said that he went “by spending one night at each stage,” and since the road is two hundred and fifty leagues, it is clear that he spent the night in the villages, towns, and royal cities on the way,

original: yattha yattha rattiyaṃ vasati, tattha tattha dutiyaṃ aruṇaṃ anuṭṭhāpetvā sabbattha
analyzed: yattha yattha rattiyam vasati tattha tattha dutiyam aruṇam anuṭṭhāpetvā sabbattha
translated: and that he reached Sāvatthī in one night by rising at each place at the second flush of dawn.

original: ekarattivāseneva sāvatthiṃ upasaṅkamīti ayamattho dīpito hotīti. Nayidaṃ evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: eka ratti vāsena iva sāvatthim upasaṅkami iti ayam atthaḥ dīpitaḥ hoti iti na idam evam daṭṭhabbam
translated: This is not the way to see it.

original: Sabbasmiṃ vīsayojanasatike magge ekarattivāsenāti imassa atthassa adhippetattā. Ekarattimattaṃ
analyzed: sabbasmin vīsa yojana satike magge eka ratti vāsena ati imassa atthassa adhippeta ttā eka rattimattam
translated: For the meaning intended is that he went by spending one night on the whole road of two hundred and fifty leagues.

original: so sakalasmiṃ tasmiṃ magge vasitvā pacchimadivase pubbaṇhasamaye sāvatthiṃ anuppattoti.
analyzed: so sakalasmim tasmim magge vasitvā pacchima divase pubbaṇha samaye sāvatthim an uppatto ti
translated: and after spending the night on the way, he arrived at Sāvatthī in the morning.

original: Bhagavāpi bāhiyassa āgamanaṃ ñatvā “na tāvassa indriyāni paripākaṃ gatāni, khaṇantare
analyzed: bhagavā api bāhiyassa āgamanam ñatvā na tāva assa indriyāni paripākam gatāni khaṇa antare
translated: The Blessed One, knowing that Bāhiya was coming, thought: “His faculties are not yet ripe, but in a short time

original: pana paripākaṃ gamissantī”ti tassa indriyānaṃ paripākaṃ āgamayamāno mahābhikkhusaṅghaparivuto
analyzed: pana paripākam gamissanti iti tassa indriyānam paripākam āgamayamānaḥ mahā bhikkhu saṅgha parivutaḥ
translated: they will be ripe.” So, waiting for his faculties to ripen, he entered Sāvatthī for alms with a large number of bhikkhus.

original: tasmiṃ khaṇe sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi. So ca jetavanaṃ pavisitvā bhuttapātarāse kāyālasiyavimocanatthaṃ
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe sāvatthim piṇḍāya pāvisi saḥ ca jetavanam pavisitvā bhutta pāta rāse kāya alasiya vimocana attham
translated: Bāhiya entered Jeta’s Grove, and after his meal he walked about in the open space for the purpose of easing his digestion.

original: abbhokāse caṅkamante sambahule bhikkhū passitvā “kahaṃ nu kho etarahi bhagavā”ti
analyzed: abbhokāse caṅkamante sambahule bhikkhū passitvā kaham nu kho etarahi bhagavā ati
translated: Seeing a number of bhikkhus, he asked them, “Where is the Blessed One now?”

original: pucchi. Bhikkhū “bhagavā sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya paviṭṭho”ti vatvā pucchiṃsu “tvaṃ pana
analyzed: pucchi bhikkhū bhagavā sāvatthim piṇḍāya paviṭṭhaḥ iti vatvā pucchiṃsu tvam pana
translated: The bhikkhus replied, “The Blessed One has entered Sāvatthī for alms.” They asked him, “But where have you come from?”

original: kuto āgato”ti? “Suppārakapaṭṭanato āgatomhī”ti. “Dūrato āgatosi, nisīda, tāva pāde
analyzed: kutas āgataḥ ti suppāraka paṭṭanataḥ āgataḥ asi iti dūratas āgataḥ asi nisīda tāva pāde
translated: “I have come from Suppāraka.” “You have come a long way. Sit down and rest your feet a while.”

original: dhovitvā makkhetvā thokaṃ vissamāhi, āgatakāle satthāraṃ dakkhasī”ti. “Ahaṃ, bhante,🔽attano jīvitantarāyaṃ na jānāmi, ekarattenevamhi katthacipi ciraṃ aṭṭhatvā anisīditvā
analyzed: dhovitvā makkhetvā thokam āgata kāle satthāram dakkhasi iti aham bhante  attanaḥ jīvita antarāyam na jānāmi katthacipi ciram a ṭhatvā a nisīditvā
translated: and after washing and anointing it, rest a little, and when you have recovered you will see the Teacher.” “Venerable Sir,

original: vīsayojanasatikaṃ maggaṃ āgato, satthāraṃ passitvāva vissamissāmī”ti vatvā taramānarūpo
analyzed: vīsa yojana satikam maggam āgataḥ satthāram passitvā ava vissamissāmi iti vatvā taramāna rūpaḥ
translated: I do not know whether I will live or not, for in one night I have walked a hundred and twenty leagues without stopping anywhere for even a little rest.”

original: sāvatthiṃ pavisitvā anopamāya buddhasiriyā virocamānaṃ bhagavantaṃ passi. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: sāvatthim pavisitvā anopamāya buddha siriyā virocamānam bhagavantam passi tena vuttam
translated: So saying, he entered Sāvatthi with all speed, and saw the Exalted One shining with incomparable Buddha-glory. Hence it is said:

original: “tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū abbhokāse caṅkamanti. Atha kho bāhiyo dārucīriyo
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena sambahulāḥ bhikkhū abbhokāse caṅkamanti atha kho bāhiyaḥ dārucīriyo
translated: “Now at that time a number of monks were walking up and down in the open air. Then Bāhiya of the Bark-cloth

original: yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkamī”tiādi.
analyzed: yena te bhikkhū tena upasaṅkami itiādi
translated: approached those monks.”

original: Tattha kahanti kattha. Nūti saṃsaye, khoti padapūraṇe, kasmiṃ nu kho padeseti attho.
analyzed: tattha kahanti kattha nu iti saṃsaye kha iti pada pūraṇe kasmin nu kho padese iti attho
translated: Herein, kahā means where. Nū is an expression of doubt. Kho is a particle for filling out the verse. The meaning is, “In what place?”

original: Dassanakāmamhāti daṭṭhukāmā amha. Mayañhi taṃ bhagavantaṃ andho viya cakkhuṃ, badhiro
analyzed: dassana kāmamha ati daṭṭhu kāmāḥ amha mayam hi tam bhagavantam andhaḥ viya cakkhum badhiraḥ
translated: Dassanakāmamhā means we are desirous of seeing. For we are like the blind who desire to see, or like the deaf who desire to hear,

original: viya sotaṃ, mūgo viya kalyāṇavākkaraṇaṃ, hatthapādavikalo viya hatthapāde, daliddo
analyzed: viya sotam mūgaḥ viya kalyāṇa vāc karaṇam hattha pāda vikalaḥ viya hattha pāde daliddaḥ
translated: like a deaf man, a good speaker, like a man without hands and feet, hands and feet, like a poor man,

original: viya dhanasampadaṃ, kantāraddhānappaṭipanno viya khemantabhūmiṃ, rogābhibhūto viya
analyzed: viya dhana sampadam viya khemanta bhūmim roga abhibhūtaḥ viya
translated: wealth, like a man on a desert path, a safe place, like a man overcome by disease,

original: ārogyaṃ, mahāsamudde bhinnanāvo viya mahākullaṃ passituṃ upasaṅkamituñca icchāmāti
analyzed: ārogyam mahā samudde bhinna nāvaḥ viya mahā kullam passitum upasaṅkamitum ca icchāma ati
translated: health, like a man whose ship has been wrecked in the great ocean, a great raft, to see and to approach.

original: dasseti. Taramānarūpoti taramānākāro.
analyzed: dasseti taramāna rūpaḥ ti taramāna ākāraḥ
translated: The form of one who is crossing over: the form of one who is crossing over.

original: Pāsādikanti bāttiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇaasītianubyañjanabyāmappabhāketumālālaṅkatāya
analyzed: pāsādikanti
translated: Beautiful: adorned with the thirty-two marks of a great man, the eighty minor characteristics, the fathom-wide aura, and the halo of light,🔽beautiful in every way,

original: samantapāsādikāya attano sarīrasobhāsampattiyā rūpakāyadassanabyāvaṭassa janassa🔽sabbabhāgato pasādāvahaṃ. Pasādanīyanti dasabalacatuvesārajjachaasādhāraṇañāṇaaṭṭhārasāveṇika-
analyzed: samanta pāsādikāya attano sarīra sobhā sampattiyā rūpa kāya dassana byāvaṭassa janassa  sabba bhāgataḥ pasāda āvaham pasādanīyanti
translated: causing faith to arise in all people who are inclined to see the beauty of the physical form by the excellence of the beauty of his own body.

original: buddhadhammappabhutiaparimāṇaguṇagaṇasamannāgatāya dhammakāyasampattiyā sarikkhakajanassa
analyzed: buddha dhamma ppabhuti aparimāṇa guṇa gaṇa samannāgatāya dhammakāya sampattiyā sa rikkhaka janassa
translated: Faith-inspiring: in people who are similar to him by the excellence of the attainment of the body of the Dhamma, which is endowed with the four kinds of confidence, the ten powers, the three special knowledges, the eighteen principal qualities of the Buddha, and the immeasurable multitude of special qualities such as the analytical knowledges,

original: pasādanīyaṃ pasīditabbayuttaṃ pasādārahaṃ vā. Santindriyanti cakkhādipañcindriyalolabhāvāpagamanena
analyzed: pasādanīyam pasīditabba yuttam pasāda araham vā cakkha ādi pañca indriya lola bhāva apagamanena
translated: It is inspiring, fit to inspire confidence, worthy of confidence. He has peaceful faculties: he has peaceful five faculties, eye, etc., by abandoning their unpeaceful state.

original: vūpasantapañcindriyaṃ. Santamānasanti chaṭṭhassa manindriyassa nibbisevanabhāvūpagamanena🔽vūpasantamānasaṃ. Uttamadamathasamathamanuppattanti lokuttarapaññāvimutticetovimuttisaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: vūpasanta pañca indriyam chaṭṭhassa man indriyassa nibbisevana bhāva upagamanena  vūpasanta mānasam uttama damatha samatham anuppatta nti lokuttara paññā vimutti cetaḥ vimutti saṅkhātam
translated: He has a peaceful mind: he has a peaceful mind by abandoning the sixth, the mind faculty, by not attending to its object.

original: uttamaṃ damathaṃ samathañca anuppatvā adhigantvā ṭhitaṃ. Dantanti suparisuddhakāyasamācāratāya
analyzed: uttamam damatham samatham ca an uppatvā adhigantvā ṭhitam su parisuddha kāya samācāra tāya
translated: He has attained to the highest self-control and peace: he has attained to the highest self-control and peace called the liberation of mind by the supramundane path.

original: ceva hatthapādakukkuccābhāvato davādiabhāvato ca kāyena dantaṃ. Guttanti suparisuddhavacīsamācāratāya
analyzed: ca iva hattha pāda kukkucca abhāvataḥ dava ādi abhāvataḥ ca kāyena dantam su parisuddha vacī samācāra tāya
translated: He is restrained: he is restrained by body, by having a very pure bodily behaviour and by having no bodily anxiety or agitation, etc.

original: ceva niratthakavācābhāvato davādiabhāvato ca vācāya guttaṃ. Yatindriyanti suparisuddhamanosamācāratāya
analyzed: ca iva niratthaka vācā abhāvataḥ dava ādi abhāvataḥ ca vācāya guttam su parisuddha manaḥ samācāra tāya
translated: He is guarded: he is guarded by speech, by having a very pure verbal behaviour and by having no verbal anxiety or agitation, etc.

original: ariyiddhiyogena abyāvaṭaappaṭisaṅkhānupekkhābhāvato ca manindriyavasena yatindriyaṃ.
analyzed: ca man indriya vasena yatindriyam
translated: He is one who has attained to perfect confidence of faculties: he is one who has attained to perfect confidence of faculties by means of the mind faculty, by having a very pure mental behaviour and by having no mental anxiety or agitation, etc., and by having the equanimity of the noble ones’ power.

original: Nāganti chandādivasena agamanato, pahīnānaṃ rāgādikilesānaṃ punānāgamanato, kassacipi
analyzed: chanda ādi vasena agamanataḥ pahīnānam rāga ādi kilesānam kassaci pi
translated: “Not” means not coming by way of desire, etc., and not coming again of the defilements of lust, etc., that have been abandoned. “To anyone” means to anyone at all.

original: āgussa sabbathāpi akaraṇato, punabbhavassa ca agamanatoti imehi kāraṇehi nāgaṃ. Ettha🔽ca pāsādikanti iminā rūpakāyena bhagavato pamāṇabhūtataṃ dīpeti, pasādanīyanti iminā
analyzed: āgussa sabbathā api akaraṇataḥ punabbhavassa ca agamanataḥ ti imehi kāraṇehi na āgam ettha  ca iminā rūpakāyena bhagavataḥ dīpeti iminā
translated: “He is a nāga” because he does not go by way of desire, etc., because he does not bring back again the defilements of lust, etc., that have been abandoned, because he does not go to anyone else for the sake of anger, etc., and because he does not go to renewed existence.

original: dhammakāyena, santindriyantiādinā sesehi pamāṇabhūtataṃ dīpeti. Tena catuppamāṇike
analyzed: dhammakāyena sesehi pamāṇa bhūta tam dīpeti tena catuppamāṇike
translated: Herein, by the words “he is a delight” the Blessed One shows that he is a measure in the world by means of his form body. By the words “he is lovable” he shows that he is a measure by means of his Dhamma body. By the words “he is of peaceful faculties” and the rest he shows that he is a measure in the world by means of his mind.

original: lokasannivāse anavasesato sattānaṃ bhagavato pamāṇabhāvo pakāsitoti veditabbo.🔽Evaṃbhūtañca bhagavantaṃ antaravīthiyaṃ gacchantaṃ disvā “cirassaṃ vata me sammāsambuddho
analyzed: loka sannivāse anavasesato sattānam bhagavataḥ pamāṇa bhāvaḥ pakāsito iti veditabbo  evaṃbhūtam ca bhagavantam antara vīthiyam gacchantam disvā cirassam vata me sammāsambuddhaḥ
translated: Thus it should be understood that the Blessed One’s being a measure for all beings without exception in the fourfold world-measure is made known.

original: diṭṭho”ti haṭṭhatuṭṭho pañcavaṇṇāya pītiyā nirantaraṃ phuṭasarīro pītivipphāritavivaṭaniccalalocano
analyzed: diṭṭhaḥ ti haṭṭha tuṭṭhaḥ pañca vaṇṇāya pītiyā nirantaram phuṭa sarīro pīti vipphārita vivaṭa niccala locano
translated: And when he saw the Blessed One thus, who was going along the main street, he was thrilled and satisfied. His body was suffused with the five kinds of happiness without interval. His eyes, opened wide with the expansion of his happiness,

original: diṭṭhaṭṭhānato paṭṭhāya oṇatasarīro bhagavato sarīrappabhāvemajjhaṃ ajjhogāhetvā
analyzed: diṭṭha ṭṭhānataḥ paṭṭhāya oṇata sarīraḥ bhagavato sarīra ppabhā vemajjham ajjhogāhetvā
translated: did not wink. From the place where he saw him, he bent his body and entered into the middle of the Blessed One’s radiance.

original: tattha nimujjanto bhagavato samīpaṃ upasaṅkamitvā pañcapatiṭṭhitena vanditvā bhagavato🔽pāde sambāhanto paricumbanto “desetu me, bhante, bhagavā dhamma”nti āha. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: tattha nimujjantaḥ bhagavato samīpam upasaṅkamitvā pañca patiṭṭhitena vanditvā bhagavato  pāde sambāhantaḥ paricumbantaḥ desetu me bhante bhagavā dhamman ti āha tena vuttam
translated: There he emerged and approached the Blessed One. He worshipped him with the fivefold prostration and,

original: – “bhagavato pāde sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘desetu me, bhante, bhagavā
analyzed: bhagavataḥ pāde sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantam etat avoca desetu me bhante bhagavā
translated: while massaging the Blessed One’s feet and kissing them, he said: ‘Venerable sir, let the Blessed One teach the Dhamma.

original: dhammaṃ, desetu sugato dhammaṃ, yaṃ mamassa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”’ti.
analyzed: dhammam desetu sugataḥ dhammam yam mamassa dīgharattam hitāya sukhāya ati
translated: Let the Sublime One teach the Dhamma. That will be for our lasting welfare and happiness.’

original: Tattha sugatoti sobhanagamanattā, sundaraṃ ṭhānaṃ gatattā, sammā gatattā, sammā gadattā
analyzed: tattha sugataḥ ti sobhana gamanattā sundaram ṭhānam gatattā sammā gatattā sammā
translated: Herein, he is sublime because of his good going, because of his having gone to a good place, because of his having gone rightly, and because of his having gone together with many.

original: sugato. Gamanampi hi gatanti vuccati, tañca bhagavato sobhanaṃ parisuddhaṃ anavajjaṃ.
analyzed: sugataḥ gamanam pi hi gata nti vuccati tat ca bhagavataḥ sobhanam parisuddham anavajjam
translated: For going is called going in the sense of going rightly, and that of the Blessed One is good, purified, and blameless.

original: Kiṃ pana tanti? Ariyamaggo. Tena hesa gamanena khemaṃ disaṃ asajjamāno gato, aññepi
analyzed: kim pana ariya maggo tena ha isa gamanena khemam disam a sajjamānaḥ gataḥ aññe pi
translated: But what is it? It is the noble path. For by that going he has gone to the secure place without being obstructed, and he has also🔽made others go there. So he is sublime because of his good going. He has gone to the beautiful place, which is the deathless Nibbāna, thus he is sublime

original: gametīti sobhanagamanattā sugato. Sundarañcesa ṭhānaṃ amataṃ nibbānaṃ gatoti sundaraṃ
analyzed: gameti iti sobhana gamana ttā sugato sundaram ca isa ṭhānam amatam nibbānam gataḥ ti sundaram
translated: because of his having gone to a good place.

original: ṭhānaṃ gatattā sugato. Sammā ca gatattā sugato tena tena maggena pahīne kilese puna
analyzed: ṭhānam gata ttā sugato sammā ca gata ttā sugato tena tena maggena pahīne kilese puna
translated: He is well-gone because he has gone to the goal. And he is well-gone because he has gone rightly, for he has gone rightly in that he does not return to abandon the defilements abandoned by each path.

original: apaccāgamanato. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: a paccāgamanataḥ vuttam ha etam
translated: For this is said:

original: “Sotāpattimaggena ye kilesā pahīnā, te kilese na puneti na pacceti na paccāgacchatīti sugato. Sakadāgāmi…pe… arahattamaggena…pe… na paccāgacchatīti sugato”ti.
analyzed: sotāpatti maggena ye kilesā pahīnā te kilese na puneti na pacceti na paccāgacchati iti sugato sakadāgāmi pe arahatta maggena pe na paccāgacchati iti sugato ti
translated: “The defilements abandoned by the path of stream-entry he does not re-enter, does not return to, does not revert to, thus he is well-gone. The defilements abandoned by the path of once-return … by the path of non-return … by the path of Arahantship he does not re-enter, does not return to, does not revert to, thus he is well-gone” .

original: Atha vā sammā gatattāti tīsupi avatthāsu sammāpaṭipattiyā gatattā, suppaṭipannattāti
analyzed: atha vā sammā gata ttā ati tīsu pi avatthāsu sammā paṭipattiyā gata ttā suppaṭipanna ttā ti
translated: Or alternatively, he is well-gone because he has gone rightly in the three fruitions, the meaning is that he has gone rightly by the three kinds of right progress.

original: attho. Dīpaṅkarapādamūlato hi paṭṭhāya yāva mahābodhimaṇḍā tāva samatiṃsapāramipūritāya
analyzed: atthaḥ dīpaṅkara pāda mūlataḥ hi paṭṭhāya mahā bodhimaṇḍā tāva sama tiṃsa pārami pūritāya
translated: For he has reached the pinnacle of the right progress fulfilled by the thirty perfections from the time of the Great Being’s taking the perfections in hand under the Buddha Dīpaṅkara up till the time of his full enlightenment in the Great Monastery at Uruvelā.

original: sammāpaṭipattiyā ñātatthacariyāya lokatthacariyāya buddhatthacariyāya koṭiṃ pāpuṇitvā🔽sabbalokassa hitasukhameva paribrūhanto sassataṃ ucchedaṃ kāmasukhaṃ attakilamathanti
analyzed: sammā paṭipattiyāḥ ñāta ttha cariyāya loka ttha cariyāya buddha ttha cariyāya koṭim pāpuṇitvā 🔽sabba lokassa hita sukham eva paribrūhantaḥ sassatam ucchedam kāma sukham atta kilamathanti
translated: And he has reached the pinnacle of the right progress fulfilled by the knowledge of what is an and what is not a cause, by the knowledge of the ripening of kamma, by the knowledge of the world, by the knowledge of the disposition of beings, by the knowledge of the supreme order of the path, by the knowledge of the four discriminations, by the knowledge of the four foundations of mindfulness, by the knowledge of the four roads of devas and the four roads of humans, by the knowledge of the four truths, by the knowledge of the four foundations of mindfulness, by the knowledge of the four roads of devas and the four roads of humans, by the knowledge of the four foundations of mindfulness, by the knowledge of the four roads of devas and the four roads of humans, by the knowledge of the four foundations of mindfulness, by the knowledge of the four roads of devas and the four roads of humans, by the knowledge of the four foundations of mindfulness, by the knowledge of the four roads of devas and the four roads of humans, by the knowledge of the four foundations of mindfulness, by the knowledge of the four roads of devas and the four roads of humans, by the knowledge of the four foundations of mindfulness, by the knowledge of the four roads of devas and the four roads of humans, by the knowledge of the four foundations of

original: ime ante anupagacchantiyā anuttarāya bojjhaṅgabhāvanāsaṅkhātāya majjhimāya paṭipadāya
analyzed: ime ante an upagacchantiyā anuttarāya bojjhaṅga bhāvanā saṅkhātāya majjhimāya paṭipadāya
translated: He has gone to the end of the four noble truths, which are called the supreme development of the factors of enlightenment, the middle way.

original: ariyasaccesu tato paraṃ samadhigatadhammādhipateyyo sabbasattesu avisayāya sammāpaṭipattiyā
analyzed: ariya saccesu tatas param samadhigata dhamma ādhipateyyaḥ sabba sattesu avisayāya sammāpaṭipattiyā
translated: He has gone to the end of the practice of the right way, which is the mastery of the Dhamma that has been attained, and which is the practice of the right way for all beings without exception.🔽He has gone to the end of the right way, and so he is the Well-Gone.

original: ca gato paṭipannoti evampi sammā gatattā sugato. Sammā cesa gadati yuttaṭṭhāne yuttameva
analyzed: ca gato paṭipanno ti evam pi sammā gata ttā sugato sammā ca isa gadati yutta ṭṭhāne yuttam eva
translated: He speaks rightly, in the right place, and he speaks only what is right.

original: vācaṃ bhāsatīti sugato. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: vācam bhāsati iti sugataḥ
translated: And this is said:

original: “Kālavādī, bhūtavādī, atthavādī, dhammavādī, vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā kālena sāpadesaṃ pariyantavatiṃ atthasaṃhita”nti.
analyzed: kāla vādī bhūta vādī attha vādī dhamma vādī vinaya vādī nidhānavatim vācam bhāsitā kālena sa apadesam pariyantavatim attha saṃhitanti
translated: “He speaks at the right time, he speaks what is true, he speaks what is beneficial, he speaks about the Dhamma, he speaks about the discipline, he speaks with a mind that is full of loving-kindness, at the right time, with a purpose, in moderation, and with a mind that is full of loving-kindness.”

original: Aparampi vuttaṃ –
analyzed: aparam pi vuttam
translated: And this is also said:

original: “Yā sā vācā abhūtā atacchā anatthasaṃhitā, yā ca paresaṃ appiyā amanāpā, na taṃ tathāgato vācaṃ bhāsatī”tiādi.
analyzed: yā sā vācā abhūtā atacchā anattha saṃhitā yā ca paresam appiyā amanāpā na tam tathāgataḥ vācam bhāsati itiādi
translated: “That speech which is untrue, false, and not beneficial, and which is unloved and displeasing to others, the Realised One does not speak.”🔽And so on.

original: Evaṃ sammā gadattāpi sugato.
analyzed: evam sammā gadattā api sugataḥ
translated: He speaks rightly in this way, and so he is the Well-Gone.

original: Yaṃ mamassa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyāti yaṃ dhammassa upadisanaṃ cirakālaṃ mama
analyzed: yam mamassa dīgharattam hitāya sukhāya ati yam dhammassa upadisanam cira kālam mama
translated: For my long-lasting benefit and happiness: for the teaching of the Dhamma to me for a long time,

original: jhānavimokkhādihitāya tadadhigantabbasukhāya ca siyā. Akālo kho tāva bāhiyāti tava🔽dhammadesanāya na tāva kāloti attho. Kiṃ pana bhagavato sattahitapaṭipattiyā akālopi
analyzed: jhāna vimokkha ādi hitāya tad adhigantabba sukhāya ca siyā akālaḥ kho tāva tava  dhamma desanāya na tāva kālo ti attho kim pana bhagavato satta hita paṭipattiyā
translated: and to the happiness to be attained by the development of jhāna, etc.🔽“It is not the right time, Bāhiya,” means “the time for teaching the Dhamma to you has not yet come.”🔽But is there any time that is not the right time for the Blessed One’s practice of benefiting others?

original: nāma atthi, yato bhagavā kālavādīti? Vuccate – kāloti cettha veneyyānaṃ indriyaparipākakālo
analyzed: nāma atthi yatas bhagavā kāla vādī iti vuccate kālo ti ca ittha veneyyānam indriya paripāka kālo
translated: The answer is: here the right time is the time for the disciples’ ripening of the faculties.

original: adhippeto. Yasmā pana tadā bāhiyassa attano indriyānaṃ paripakkāparipakkabhāvo dubbiññeyyo,
analyzed: adhippetaḥ yasmā pana tadā bāhiyassa attanaḥ indriyānam paripakka aparipakka bhāvaḥ dubbiññeyyaḥ
translated: But since it was difficult for Bāhiya to know whether his own faculties were ripe or unripe,

original: tasmā bhagavā taṃ avatvā attano antaravīthiyaṃ ṭhitabhāvamassa kāraṇaṃ apadisanto
analyzed: tasmai bhagavā tam avatvā attanaḥ antara vīthiyam ṭhita bhāvam assa kāraṇam a padisantaḥ
translated: the Blessed One, without referring to him, indicated the reason for his own presence there by saying, “We have entered the village for alms.”

original: āha “antaragharaṃ paviṭṭhamhā”ti. Dujjānanti dubbiññeyyaṃ. Jīvitantarāyānanti jīvitassa
analyzed: āha antara gharam paviṭṭhamha ati dujjānanti dubbiññeyyam jīvita antarāyānanti jīvitassa
translated: “It is difficult to know”: difficult to discern.

original: antarāyakaradhammānaṃ vattanaṃ avattanaṃ vāti vattukāmo sambhamavasena “jīvitantarāyāna”nti
analyzed: antarāya kara dhammānam vattanam avattanam vāti vattu kāmo
translated: “The occurrence or non-occurrence of conditions that are a threat to life”: the occurrence or non-occurrence of things that are a threat to life.🔽The Blessed One said “the occurrence or non-occurrence of conditions that are a threat to life” in order to show that he was not in a hurry.

original: āha. Tathā hi anekapaccayappaṭibaddhavuttijīvitaṃ anekarūpā ca tadantarāyā. Vuttañhi –
analyzed: āha tathā hi aneka paccaya paṭibaddha vutti jīvitam aneka rūpā ca tad antarāyā vuttam hi
translated: He said: for life is dependent on many conditions, and there are many forms of its obstruction. For this is said:

original: “Ajjeva kiccamātappaṃ, ko jaññā maraṇaṃ suve;
analyzed: ajjā iva kiccam ātappam kaḥ jaññā maraṇam suve
translated: “Today the task must be done, for who can know about tomorrow?

original: Na hi no saṅgaraṃ tena, mahāsenena maccunā”ti. ;
analyzed: na hi naḥ saṅgaram tena mahā senena maccunā ati
translated: For there is no bargaining with Death, that mighty king.”

original: Kasmā panāyaṃ jīvitantarāyameva tāva purakkharoti? “Nimittaññutāya adiṭṭhakosallena
analyzed: kasmā pana ayam jīvita antarāyam eva tāva purakkharoti nimittaññu tāya a diṭṭha kosallena
translated: But why does he mention only the obstruction of life? “Because of his knowledge of omens and his skill in reading signs,” say some.

original: vā”ti keci. Apare “devatāya santike jīvitantarāyassa sutattā”ti vadanti. Antimabhavikattā
analyzed: vāti keci apare devatāya santike jīvitantarāyassa vadanti antimabhavikattā
translated: Others say: “Because he heard from a deity that there was an obstruction to his life.”🔽But he said as he did because he was urged on by the fulfilment of the support for his final existence.

original: pana upanissayasampattiyā codiyamāno evamāha. Na hi tesaṃ appattaarahattānaṃ jīvitakkhayo
analyzed: pana upanissaya sampattiyā codiyamānaḥ evam āha na hi tesam appatta arahattānam jīvita kkhayo
translated: For they who have not yet attained arahatship do not die before their time.

original: hoti. Kiṃ pana kāraṇā bhagavā tassa dhammaṃ desetukāmova dvikkhattuṃ paṭikkhipi?🔽Evaṃ kirassa ahosi “imassa maṃ diṭṭhakālato paṭṭhāya sakalasarīraṃ pītiyā nirantaraṃ
analyzed: hoti kim pana kāraṇā bhagavā tassa dhammaṃ desetu kāmaḥ iva dvi khattum paṭikkhipi  evam kira assa ahosi imassa mam diṭṭha kālataḥ paṭṭhāya sakala sarīram pītiyā nirantaram
translated: But why did the Exalted One refuse him twice, although he was desirous of teaching him the Dhamma?🔽For he thought: “Since the moment he saw me, his whole body has been suffused with a stream of joy. The force of his joy is so strong that he will not be able to penetrate the Dhamma even if he hears it.

original: phuṭaṃ, atibalavā pītivego, dhammaṃ sutvāpi na tāva sakkhissati paṭivijjhituṃ. Yāva
analyzed: phuṭam ati balavā pīti vegaḥ dhammam sutvā api na tāva sakkhissati paṭivijjhitum yāva
translated: Therefore I will first make him calm and then teach him the Dhamma.”

original: pana majjhattupekkhā saṇṭhāti, tāva tiṭṭhatu, vīsayojanasataṃ maggaṃ āgatattā darathopissa
analyzed: pana majjhatta upekkhā saṇṭhāti tāva tiṭṭhatu vīsa yojana satam maggam āgata ttā darathopissa
translated: but equanimity of mind towards them has settled down, let that stand aside for the moment. And because he has come a hundred and twenty leagues, his fatigue is strong,

original: kāye balavā, sopi tāva paṭippassambhatū”ti. Tasmā dvikkhattuṃ paṭikkhipi. Keci pana
analyzed: kāye balavā saḥ api tāva tasmā dvi khattum paṭikkhipi keci pana
translated: let that subside for the time being.” So he refused twice. But some say that

original: “dhammassavane ādarajananatthaṃ bhagavā evamakāsī”ti vadanti. Tatiyavāraṃ yācito
analyzed: dhammassavane ādara janana attham bhagavā evam akāsi iti vadanti tatiya vāram yācito
translated: he did this in order to inspire respect for listening to the Dhamma. When asked a third time,

original: pana majjhattupekkhaṃ darathappaṭipassaddhiṃ paccupaṭṭhitañcassa jīvitantarāyaṃ disvā
analyzed: pana majjhatta upekkham daratha ppaṭipassaddhim paccupaṭṭhitam ca assa jīvita antarāyam disvā
translated: he saw that equanimity of mind towards them had settled down, that his fatigue had subsided, and that there was a threat to his life,

original: “idāni dhammadesanāya kālo”ti cintetvā “tasmā tihā”tiādinā dhammadesanaṃ ārabhi.🔽Tattha tasmāti yasmā tvaṃ ussukkajāto hutvā ativiya maṃ yācasi, yasmā vā jīvitantarāyānaṃ
analyzed: idāni dhamma desanāya kālo ti cintetvā tasmā tihā ati ādinā dhamma desanam ārabhi  tattha tasmā iti yasmai tvam ussukka jātaḥ hutvā mam yācasi yasmai vā
translated: and he thought, “Now is the time to teach the Dhamma.” So he began his teaching with the words “Therefore, Ānanda.”🔽Herein, therefore is merely a particle.

original: dujjānataṃ vadasi, indriyāni ca te paripākaṃ gatāni, tasmā. Tihāti nipātamattaṃ.
analyzed: dujjānatam vadasi indriyāni ca te paripākam gatāni nipāta mattam
translated: He is saying, “You have made an effort and asked me very much, or you have said that the threat to life is hard to know, and your faculties have reached maturity, therefore.”

original: Teti tayā evanti idāni vattabbākāraṃ vadati.
analyzed: tā iti tayā evam ti idāni vattabba ākāram vadati
translated: You is the way he addresses him.

original: Sikkhitabbanti adhisīlasikkhādīnaṃ tissannampi sikkhānaṃ vasena sikkhanaṃ kātabbaṃ. Yathā pana sikkhitabbaṃ, taṃ dassento “diṭṭhe diṭṭhamattaṃ bhavissatī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: sikkhitabbanti adhisīla sikkhā ādīnam tissannam pi sikkhānam vasena sikkhanam kātabbam yathā pana sikkhitabbam tam dassentaḥ diṭṭhe diṭṭha mattam bhavissati itiādim āha
translated: “One should train” means one should train in the three trainings, namely, in higher virtue, etc. But how one should train is shown by the words “In the seen there will be only the seen.”

original: Tattha diṭṭhe diṭṭhamattanti rūpāyatane cakkhuviññāṇena diṭṭhamattaṃ. Yathā hi cakkhuviññāṇaṃ🔽rūpe rūpamattameva passati, na aniccādisabhāvaṃ, evameva sesaṃ. Cakkhudvārikaviññāṇena
analyzed: tattha diṭṭhe diṭṭha mattam ti rūpa āyatane cakkhu viññāṇena diṭṭha mattam yathā hi cakkhu viññāṇam  rūpe rūpa mattam eva passati na anicca ādi sabhāvam evam eva sesam cakkhu dvārika viññāṇena
translated: Herein, in the seen there will be only the seen means: in the visible form base there will be only the seen, only the cognized by eye-consciousness. For just as eye-consciousness

original: hi me diṭṭhamattameva bhavissatīti sikkhitabbanti attho. Atha vā diṭṭhe diṭṭhaṃ nāma
analyzed: hi me diṭṭha mattam eva bhavissati iti sikkhitabbanti atthaḥ atha vā diṭṭhe diṭṭham nāma
translated: sees visible form and cognizes only visible form, not its impermanence, etc., so too will the rest . The meaning is: I will train thus: “There will be only the seen in me by the consciousness belonging to the eye door.” Or alternatively, in the seen there will be only the seen means

original: cakkhuviññāṇena rūpavijānananti attho. Mattanti pamāṇaṃ. Diṭṭhā mattā etassāti diṭṭhamattaṃ,🔽cakkhuviññāṇamattameva cittaṃ bhavissatīti attho. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yathā āpāthagate
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇena rūpa vijānananti atthaḥ mattanti pamāṇam diṭṭhāḥ mattāḥ etassa ati diṭṭhamattam 🔽cakkhu viññāṇa mattam eva cittam bhavissati iti attho idam vuttam hoti yathā āpāthagate
translated: the seen is cognized by eye-consciousness. Only is a measure word. He who has only the seen is one who has only eye-consciousness. The meaning is: there will be only eye-consciousness. This is what is meant: I will train thus: “There will be only the seen in me, only the cognized by eye-consciousness, when a visible form comes into focus.” Or alternatively, in the seen there will be only the seen means

original: rūpe cakkhuviññāṇaṃ na rajjati, na dussati, na muyhati, evaṃ rāgādivirahena cakkhuviññāṇamattameva
analyzed: rūpe cakkhu viññāṇam na rajjati na dussati na muyhati evam rāga ādi virahena cakkhu viññāṇam attam eva
translated: In the case of visible forms, eye-consciousness is not greedy, nor is it hostile or confused. In this way, eye-consciousness alone is free from greed, etc.,

original: me javanaṃ bhavissati, cakkhuviññāṇappamāṇeneva javanaṃ ṭhapessāmīti.🔽Atha vā diṭṭhaṃ nāma cakkhuviññāṇena diṭṭhaṃ rūpaṃ, diṭṭhamattaṃ nāma tattheva uppannaṃ🔽sampaṭicchanasantīraṇavoṭṭhabbanasaṅkhātaṃ cittattayaṃ. Yathā taṃ na rajjati, na🔽dussati, na muyhati, evaṃ āpāthagate rūpe teneva sampaṭicchanādippamāṇena javanaṃ🔽uppādessāmi, nāhaṃ taṃ pamāṇaṃ atikkamitvā rajjanādivasena uppajjituṃ dassāmīti evamettha
analyzed: me javanam bhavissati cakkhu viññāṇa ppamāṇena iva javanam ṭhapessāmi iti  atha vā diṭṭham nāma cakkhu viññāṇena diṭṭham rūpam diṭṭhamattam nāma tattha eva uppannam  sampaṭicchana santīraṇa voṭṭhabbana saṅkhātam cittattayam yathā tam na rajjati na  dussati na muyhati evam āpātha gate rūpe tena iva sampaṭicchana ādi ppamāṇena javanam  uppādessāmi na aham tam pamāṇam atikkamitvā rajjana ādi vasena uppajjitum dassāmi iti evam ettha
translated: “When a visible form is seen, eye-consciousness does not delight in the visible form, nor does it disapprove of it, nor does it grasp it. In this way, with the absence of delight, disapproval, and grasping, there will be only the mere occurrence of eye-consciousness. I will stop the occurrence of consciousness with the mere extent of eye-consciousness.”

original: attho daṭṭhabbo. Eseva nayo sutamute. Mutanti tadārammaṇaviññāṇehi saddhiṃ gandharasaphoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo esa iva nayaḥ suta mute mutan ti tad ārammaṇa viññāṇehi saddhim gandha rasa phoṭṭhabba āyatanam
translated: Or else, “seen” is what is seen by eye-consciousness; “mere seeing” is the three thoughts called “receiving,” “investigation,” and “determining” that arise just there. As it does not delight, disapprove, or grasp, in this way, when a visible form comes into the visual range, I will cause the occurrence of consciousness to arise with the mere extent of receiving, etc. I will not allow it to arise with delight, disapproval, and grasping, exceeding that extent.” This is how the meaning should be regarded here. The same method applies to “heard” and “sensed.” “Cognized” is the base of odor, flavor, and tactile objects together with the consciousnesses that have them as their objects.

original: veditabbaṃ. Viññāte viññātamattanti ettha pana viññātaṃ nāma manodvārāvajjanena viññātārammaṇaṃ.🔽Tasmiṃ viññāte viññātamattanti āvajjanappamāṇaṃ. Yathā āvajjanaṃ na rajjati, na dussati,
analyzed: veditabbam viññāte viññāta mattam ti ettha pana viññātam nāma manaḥ dvāra āvajjanena viññāta ārammaṇam  tasmin viññāte viññāta mattanti āvajjana ppamāṇam yathā āvajjanam na rajjati na dussati
translated: When that is known as known, the extent of the adverting is known as known.🔽As the mind is not to be steadied by lust, hate, or delusion,

original: na muyhati, evaṃ rajjanādivasena ca uppajjituṃ adatvā āvajjanappamāṇeneva cittaṃ
analyzed: na muyhati evam rajjana ādi vasena ca uppajjitum a datvā āvajjana ppamāṇena iva cittam
translated: so it is not to be steadied by lust, etc., that arise by taking the extent of the adverting as an object.🔽The meaning is that he should steady the mind by means of the extent of the adverting itself.

original: ṭhapessāmīti ayamettha attho. Evañhi te, bāhiya, sikkhitabbanti evaṃ imāya paṭipadāya
analyzed: ṭhapessāmi iti ayam ettha atthaḥ evam hi te bāhiya sikkhitabban ti evam imāya paṭipadāya
translated: Thus, Bahiya, should you train yourself.

original: tayā, bāhiya, tissannaṃ sikkhānaṃ anuvattanavasena sikkhitabbaṃ.
analyzed: tayā bāhiya tissannam sikkhānam anuvattana vasena sikkhitabbam
translated: Thus, Bahiya, you should train yourself by following the three trainings.

original: Iti bhagavā bāhiyassa saṃkhittarucitāya chahi viññāṇakāyehi saddhiṃ chaḷārammaṇabhedabhinnaṃ
analyzed: iti bhagavā bāhiyassa saṃkhitta rucitāya chahi viññāṇakāyehi saddhim chaṣ ārammaṇa bheda bhinnam
translated: So the Blessed One, having shown the object of insight knowledge by dividing it into four sections beginning with “seen” with reference to the six bases of contact together with the six classes of consciousness,

original: vipassanāya visayaṃ diṭṭhādīhi catūhi koṭṭhāsehi vibhajitvā tatthassa ñātatīraṇapariññaṃ
analyzed: vipassanāya visayam diṭṭha ādīhi catūhi koṭṭhāsehi vibhajitvā tatthassa ñāta tīraṇa pariññam
translated: and having shown the three kinds of full-understanding of that object, namely, full-understanding of the known, of the investigated, and of what is thus fully understood,

original: dasseti. Kathaṃ? Ettha hi rūpāyatanaṃ passitabbaṭṭhena diṭṭhaṃ nāma, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ
analyzed: dasseti katham ettha hi rūpa āyatanam passitabba ṭṭhena diṭṭham nāma cakkhu viññāṇam
translated: the Blessed One now shows the three kinds of clear-vision, namely, clear-vision of the known, of the investigated, and of what is thus seen.

original: pana saddhiṃ taṃdvārikaviññāṇehi dassanaṭṭhena, tadubhayampi yathāpaccayaṃ pavattamānaṃ🔽dhammamattameva, na ettha koci kattā vā kāretā vā, yato taṃ hutvā abhāvaṭṭhena aniccaṃ,🔽udayabbayappaṭipīḷanaṭṭhena dukkhaṃ, avasavattanaṭṭhena anattāti kuto tattha paṇḍitassa
analyzed: pana saddhim taṃdvārika viññāṇehi dassana ṭṭhena tat ubhayam pi yathāpaccayam pavattamānam  dhamma mattam eva na ettha koci kattā vā kāretā vā yatas tam hutvā abhāva ṭṭhena aniccam  udaya bbaya paṭipīḷana ṭhena dukkham avasavattana ṭhena anattā ati kutas tattha paṇḍitassa
translated: but together with the eye-consciousness and the mind element and mind-consciousness element that occur together with it, it is the seen. Both these kinds of object occur according to conditions,🔽and they are mere ideas. There is no doer or feeler here. Since they are not, they are impermanent in the sense of non-existence after having been.🔽They are painful in the sense of oppressing through rise and fall. They are not-self in the sense of having no core of permanence, etc. How can the wise🔽

original: rajjanādīnaṃ okāsoti? Ayamettha adhippāyo sutādīsupi.🔽Idāni ñātatīraṇapariññāsu patiṭṭhitassa upari saha maggaphalena pahānapariññaṃ dassetuṃ,🔽“yato kho te, bāhiyā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha yatoti yadā, yasmā vā. Teti tava. Tatoti
analyzed: rajjana ādīnam okāsaḥ ti ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ suta ādīsu pi  idāni ñāta tīraṇa pariññāsu patiṭṭhitassa upari saha magga phalena pahāna pariññam dassetuṃ  yatas kho te bāhiyā atiādi āraddham tattha yatā uti yadā yasmai vā tati tava tatā iti
translated: but together with the eye-consciousness and the mind element and mind-consciousness element that occur together with the eye-consciousness, it is “seeing” in the sense of looking at. And all that is “merely ideas” occurring according to conditions. There is no doer or causer here. So it is “impermanent” in the sense of non-existence after having been. It is “painful” in the sense of oppression by rise and fall. It is “not-self” in the sense of having no core of selfhood. So how can there be any room for the conceivings of “I” and “mine” in it? This is the intention here. The same method applies to hearing, etc.,

original: tadā, tasmā vā. Tenāti tena diṭṭhādinā, diṭṭhādipaṭibaddhena rāgādinā vā. Idaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: tadā tasmai vā tena ati tena diṭṭha ādinā diṭṭha ādi paṭibaddhena rāga ādinā vā idam vuttam
translated: Now, in order to show the kind of full-understanding of abandoning that is combined with the path and fruition in one who is established in the full-understanding of discernment of ideas, the following sutta was begun: “When, Bahiya, in regard to these five aggregates as objects of clinging, there is no I-making, mine-making, and underlying tendency to conceit” , etc. Herein, when means at the time when or because of which. Your: of you. Then: at that time or because of that. By that: by that seeing, etc., or by the greed, etc., bound up with the seeing, etc. This is what is meant.

original: hoti – bāhiya, tava yasmiṃ kāle yena vā kāraṇena diṭṭhādīsu mayā vuttavidhiṃ paṭipajjantassa
analyzed: tava yasmin kāle yena vā kāraṇena diṭṭha ādīsu mayā vutta vidhim paṭipajjantassa
translated: Bhikkhu Bahiya, at the time when or because of which you practise in the way stated by me in regard to the seeing, etc.,

original: aviparītasabhāvāvabodhena diṭṭhādimattaṃ bhavissati, tasmiṃ kāle tena vā kāraṇena🔽diṭṭhādipaṭibaddhena rāgādinā saha na bhavissasi, ratto vā duṭṭho vā mūḷho vā na
analyzed: aviparīta sabhāva avabodhena diṭṭha ādimattam bhavissati tasmin kāle tena vā kāraṇena  diṭṭha ādi paṭibaddhena rāga ādinā saha na bhavissasi rattaḥ vā duṭṭhaḥ vā mūḷhaḥ vā na
translated: “You will not be bound by the seen, etc.,” means that at that time, for that reason,🔽you will not be bound up with lust, hatred, or delusion in regard to the seen, etc. You will not be

original: bhavissasi, pahīnarāgādikattā tena vā diṭṭhādinā saha paṭibaddho na bhavissasīti.🔽Tato tvaṃ, bāhiya, na tatthāti yadā yasmā vā tvaṃ tena rāgena vā ratto dosena vā
analyzed: bhavissasi pahīna rāga ādi kattā tena vā diṭṭha ādinā saha paṭibaddhaḥ na bhavissasi iti  tato tvam na yadā yasmai vā tvam tena rāgena vā rattaḥ dosena vā
translated: lustful, hateful, or deluded. Because you will have abandoned lust, etc., you will not be bound up with the seen, etc.

original: duṭṭho mohena vā mūḷho na bhavissasi, tadā tasmā vā tvaṃ tattha diṭṭhādike na bhavissasi,🔽tasmiṃ diṭṭhe vā sutamutaviññāte vā “etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā”ti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhīhi
analyzed: duṭṭhaḥ mohena vā mūḷhaḥ na bhavissasi tadā tasmai vā tvam tattha diṭṭha ādike na bhavissasi  tasmin diṭṭhe vā suta muta viññāte vā etam mama esaḥ aham asmi esaḥ me attā ati taṇhā māna diṭṭhīhi
translated: “Then you will not be here or there or between the two” means that when you are not lustful, hateful, or deluded, then you will not be here or there or between the two in regard to the seen, etc.

original: allīno patiṭṭhito na bhavissasi. Ettāvatā pahānapariññaṃ matthakaṃ pāpetvā khīṇāsavabhūmi dassitā.
analyzed: allīnaḥ patiṭṭhitaḥ na bhavissasi ettāvatā pahāna pariññam matthakam pāpetvā khīṇāsava bhūmi dassitā
translated: When you are not attached to or settled down in the seen, heard, sensed, or cognized through craving, conceit, or views, thinking “This is mine, this I am, this is my self,” you have reached the culmination of the full understanding of abandoning. The plane of one free of cankers is shown.

original: Tato tvaṃ, bāhiya, nevidha na huraṃ na ubhayamantarenāti yadā tvaṃ, bāhiya, tena
analyzed: tatas tvam bāhiya na huram na ubhayam antarena ati yadā tvam tena
translated: “Then you will not be this or that” means that when you are not lustful, hateful, or deluded,

original: rāgādinā tattha diṭṭhādīsu paṭibaddho na bhavissasi, tadā tvaṃ neva idhaloke na paraloke
analyzed: rāga ādinā tattha diṭṭha ādīsu paṭibaddhaḥ na bhavissasi tadā tvam na iva idha loke na para loke
translated: You will not be bound by lust, etc., to visible objects, etc., then you will not be in this world, nor in the next world,

original: na ubhayatthāpi. Esevanto dukkhassāti kilesadukkhassa ca vaṭṭadukkhassa ca ayameva🔽hi anto ayaṃ parivaṭumabhāvoti ayameva hi ettha attho. Ye pana “ubhayamantarenā”ti
analyzed: na ubhayattha api esevantaḥ dukkhassa ati kilesa dukkhassa ca vaṭṭa dukkhassa ca ayam eva  hi antaḥ ayam ayam parivaṭuma bhāvaḥ iti ayam eva hi ettha atthaḥ ye pana ubhayam antarena ati
translated: nor in between the two. This is the end of suffering. The meaning is this: this is the end, the non-existence, of the suffering of the defilements and of the suffering due to the process of existence.🔽But those who take the words “in between the two” to refer to the intermediate existence maintain that there is such a thing as an intermediate existence. That is wrong,

original: padaṃ gahetvā antarābhavaṃ nāma icchanti, tesaṃ taṃ micchā. Antarābhavassa hi bhāvo🔽abhidhamme paṭikkhittoyeva. Antarenāti vacanaṃ pana vikappantaradīpanaṃ, tasmā ayamettha🔽attho – “neva idha na huraṃ, aparo vikappo na ubhaya”nti.
analyzed: padam gahetvā antarābhavam nāma icchanti tesam tam micchā antarābhavassa hi bhāvo  abhidhamme paṭikkhittaḥ yeva antarena ati vacanam pana vikappa antara dīpanam tasmai ayam ettha  na iva idha na aparaḥ vikappaḥ na ubhayanti
translated: for the existence of an intermediate existence is rejected in the Abhidhamma.🔽The word “in between” indicates a different kind of interval, so the meaning here is this: “not in this world, nor in the next world, nor in between the two, nor in any other place.”

original: Atha vā antarenāti vacanaṃ pana vikappantarābhāvadīpanaṃ. Tassattho – “neva idha🔽na huraṃ, ubhayamantare pana na aññaṭṭhānaṃ atthī”ti. Yepi ca “antarāparinibbāyī
analyzed: atha vā antarena ati vacanam pana vikappa antara abhāva dīpanam tassa atthaḥ na iva idha 🔽na ubhayam antare pana na añña ṭṭhānam atthi iti ye pi ca antarā parinibbāyī
translated: Or else the word “in between” indicates the non-existence of any other interval. The meaning is this: “not in this world, nor in the next world, nor in between the two, nor in any other place.”🔽And those who maintain that there is an intermediate existence and who maintain that there is an attainment of final Nibbāna in the interval

original: sambhavesī”ti ca imesaṃ suttapadānaṃ atthaṃ ayoniso gahetvā “atthiyeva antarābhavo”ti
analyzed: sambhavesi iti ca imesam sutta padānam attham ayonisas gahetvā atthiyā iva antarābhavoti
translated: and “one who is seeking to be” , taking the meaning of these sutta passages wrongly, say that there is an intermediate-state existence.

original: vadanti, tepi yasmā avihādīsu tattha tattha āyuvemajjhaṃ anatikkamitvā antarā aggamaggādhigamena
analyzed: vadanti te api yasmai a vihā ādīsu tattha tattha āyu vemajjham an atikkamitvā antarā agga magga adhigamena
translated: But since they attain the noble paths and fruitions without exceeding the middle of the life span in Aviha, etc.,

original: anavasesakilesaparinibbānena parinibbāyatīti antarāparinibbāyī, na antarābhavabhūtoti
analyzed: anavasesa kilesa parinibbānena parinibbāyati iti antarāparinibbāyī na antarābhava bhūtaḥ ti
translated: and they are extinguished by the complete extinction of defilements, they are “those extinguished in the interval” , not “those in an intermediate state.”

original: purimassa suttapadassa attho. Pacchimassa ca ye bhūtā eva, na bhavissanti, te khīṇāsavā
analyzed: purimassa sutta padassa attho pacchimassa ca ye bhūtāḥ eva na bhavissanti te khīṇa āsavā
translated: This is the meaning of the first sutta passage. And the meaning of the second is this: those who are born and are not going to be born again are cankers-destroyed.

original: purimapade bhūtāti vuttā. Tabbiruddhatāya sambhavamesantīti sambhavesino, appahīnabhavasaṃyojanattā🔽sekhā puthujjanā ca. Catūsu vā yonīsu aṇḍajajalābujasattā yāva aṇḍakosaṃ vatthikosañca
analyzed: purima pade bhūtā ati vuttā tad viruddha tāya sambhavam esanti iti sambhavesinaḥ appahīna bhava saṃyojana ttā  sekhā puthujjanā ca catūsu vā yonīsu aṇḍa ja jalābu ja sattā yāva aṇḍa kosam vatthi kosam ca
translated: Those who are born are called “those who are” in the first passage. Those who are seeking to be are the opposite of them. They are seeking to be because they have not abandoned the fetter of being.🔽They are the trainees and ordinary men. Or alternatively, in the four kinds of birth, those born from an egg or from the womb or from moisture are called “those seeking to be” as long as they have not broken out of the egg shell or the caul or the womb.

original: na bhindanti, tāva sambhavesī nāma, aṇḍakosato vatthikosato ca bahi nikkhantā bhūtā
analyzed: na bhindanti tāva sambhavesī nāma aṇḍa kosataḥ vatthi kosataḥ ca bahi nikkhantā bhūtā
translated: Those who have come out are “those who are.”

original: nāma. Saṃsedajā opapātikā ca paṭhamacittakkhaṇe sambhavesī nāma, dutiyacittakkhaṇato🔽paṭṭhāya bhūtā nāma. Yena vā iriyāpathena jāyanti, yāva tato aññaṃ na pāpuṇanti,
analyzed: nāma saṃseda jā opapātikā ca paṭhama cittakkhaṇe sambhavesī nāma dutiya cittakkhaṇato  paṭṭhāya bhūtāḥ nāma yena vai iriyāpathena jāyanti yāva tatas aññam na pāpuṇanti
translated: and the egg-born and the spontaneously born are called “being generated” in the first conscious moment, and they are called “beings” from the second conscious moment onwards.🔽Or else, they are called “being generated” for as long as they are in the posture in which they are born, and they are called “beings” when they have reached another posture.

original: tāva sambhavesino, tato paraṃ bhūtāti attho. Tasmā natthīti paṭikkhipitabbā. Sati
analyzed: tāva sambhavesinaḥ tato param bhūtā ati attho tasmā na atthi iti paṭikkhipitabbā sati
translated: So there is no need to deny the existence of the intermediate state.

original: hi ujuke pāḷianugate atthe kiṃ aniddhāritasāmatthiyena antarābhavena parikappitena payojananti.🔽Ye pana “santānavasena pavattamānānaṃ dhammānaṃ avicchedena desantaresu pātubhāvo
analyzed: hi ujuke pāḷi anugate atthe kim a niddhārita sāmatthiyena antarābhavena parikappitena  ye pana santāna vasena pavattamānānam dhammānam avicchedena desantaresu pātubhāvaḥ
translated: For when the meaning is in accordance with the straight meaning of the texts, what is the use of postulating an intermediate-state existence whose capability is not admitted?

original: diṭṭho, yathā taṃ vīhiādiaviññāṇakasantāne, evaṃ saviññāṇakasantānepi avicchedena
analyzed: diṭṭhaḥ yathā tam vīhi ādi aviññāṇaka santāne evam sa viññāṇaka santāne pi avicchedena
translated: But those who argue as follows are to be refuted: “The appearance of dhammas that occur in a continuity in different places without interruption is seen in the case of the rice shoot, etc., and the consciousness continuity, and it is to be expected that the same would apply in the case of the material continuity too.

original: desantaresu pātubhāvena bhavitabbaṃ. Ayañca nayo sati antarābhave yujjati, na aññathā”ti
analyzed: desantaresu pātubhāvena bhavitabbam ayam ca nayo sati antarābhave yujjati na aññathā ti
translated: And this is reasonable only if there is an intermediate state, not if there is not.”

original: yuttiṃ vadanti. Tena hi iddhimato cetovasippattassa cittānugatikaṃ kāyaṃ adhiṭṭhahantassa
analyzed: yuttim vadanti tena hi iddhimataḥ cetaḥ vasi pattassa citta anugatikam kāyam adhiṭṭhahantassa
translated: But if they argue thus, they are to be asked: “When a possessor of supernormal power, who has attained mental mastery, resolves his body to be light, does it become so?

original: khaṇena brahmalokato idhūpasaṅkamane ito vā brahmalokagamane yutti vattabbā. Yadi
analyzed: khaṇena brahmalokataḥ idhu upasaṅkamane itas vā brahmaloka gamane yutti vattabbā yadi
translated: and in the case of the instant arrival here from the Brahmā-world or the departure thence to the Brahmā-world, it would be necessary to say that it is reasonable.

original: sabbattheva avicchinnadese dhammānaṃ pavatti icchitā, yadipi siyā iddhimantānaṃ iddhivisayo
analyzed: sabbattha iva avicchinna dese dhammānam pavatti icchitā yadi api siyā iddhimantānam iddhi visayo
translated: If the occurrence of dhammas is admitted as uninterrupted in all instances, then, even though it may be so, it is the province of the supernormal power of those who possess it,

original: acinteyyoti. Taṃ idhāpi samānaṃ “kammavipāko acinteyyo”ti vacanato. Tasmā taṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: acinteyya uti tam idha api samānam kamma vipāko vacanato tasmā tam tesam
translated: which is unthinkable. But that is the same here too, since it is said that ‘the result of kamma is unthinkable’ . So that is

original: matimattameva. Acinteyyasabhāvā hi sabhāvadhammā, te katthaci paccayavasena vicchinnadese🔽pātubhavanti, katthaci avicchinnadese. Tathā hi mukhaghosādīhi paccayehi aññasmiṃ
