original: Tassattho – yaṃ tumhe seṭṭhaṭṭhena brahmaṃ adhisīlādipaṭipattidhammaṃ sandiṭṭhaṃ🔽caratha, taṃ so tumhehi samānaṃ brahmaṃ acarīti sabrahmacārī maraṇakālassa pattiyāva
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ yam tumhe seṭṭha ṭṭhena brahmam adhi sīla ādi paṭipatti dhammam sandiṭṭham  caratha tam saḥ tumhehi samānam brahmam acari iti sabrahmacārī maraṇa kālassa
translated: that is, the one who lived the holy life that is the highest, the holy life of virtue, etc., that is visible here and now, which is the same for you as for him, has died,

original: kālakato, tasmā taṃ mañcakena nīharitvā jhāpetha, thūpañcassa karothāti.🔽Tassa kā gatīti pañcasu gatīsu tassa katamā gati upapatti bhavabhūtā, gatīti nipphatti,
analyzed: kālakato tasmai tam mañcakena nīharitvā jhāpetha thūpañcassa karotha ati  tassa kā gatī iti pañcasu gatīsu tassa katamā gati upapatti bhava bhūtā gatī iti nipphatti
translated: has passed away, at the time of his death. Therefore, having carried him out on a litter, cremate him, and build a monument for him.”🔽What is his destination? What is his future state? What is his rebirth? What is his reappearance? What is his destiny? What is his future bourn?

original: ariyo puthujjano vāti kā niṭṭhāti attho. Abhisamparāyoti pecca bhavuppatti bhavanirodho🔽vā. Kiñcāpi tassa thūpakaraṇāṇattiyāva parinibbutabhāvo atthato pakāsito hoti, ye
analyzed: ariyaḥ puthujjanaḥ vāti kā niṭṭhā ati atthaḥ abhisamparāyaḥ ti bhava uppatti bhava nirodho  vā kiñcā api tassa thūpa karaṇa āṇattiyā ava parinibbuta bhāvo atthataḥ pakāsito hoti ye
translated: What is his destination among the five destinations? What is his future state among the five future states? What is his rebirth among the five kinds of rebirth? What is his reappearance among the five kinds of reappearance? What is his destiny among the five kinds of destiny? What is his future bourn among the five kinds of future bourn?🔽What is his destination among the five destinations? What is his future state among the five future states? What is his rebirth among the five kinds of rebirth? What is his reappearance among the five kinds of reappearance? What is his destiny among the five kinds of destiny? What is his future bourn among the five kinds of future bourn?

original: pana bhikkhū tattakena na jāniṃsu, te “tassa kā gatī”ti pucchiṃsu. Pākaṭataraṃ vā
analyzed: pana bhikkhū tattakena na jāniṃsu te tassa kā gatī ti pucchiṃsu pākaṭataram vā
translated: Though the fact that he had attained final Nibbāna was made known by the mere building of the monument, still those monks who did not know it asked, “What is his destination?” or “What is his future state?” or “What is his rebirth?” or “What is his reappearance?” or “What is his destiny?” or “What is his future bourn?”

original: kārāpetukāmā tathā bhagavantaṃ pucchiṃsu.🔽Paṇḍitoti aggamaggapaññāya adhigatattā paṇḍena ito gato pavattoti paṇḍito. Paccapādīti
analyzed: kārā petu kāmā tathā bhagavantam pucchiṃsu  paṇḍito ti agga magga paññāya adhigata ttā paṇḍena itas gato pavatto ti paṇḍito paccapādi iti
translated: and so they asked the Blessed One.

original: paṭipajji. Dhammassāti lokuttaradhammassa. Anudhammanti sīlavisuddhiādipaṭipadādhammaṃ.
analyzed: dhammassa ati lokuttara dhammassa anu dhammam ti sīla visuddhi ādi paṭipadā dhammam
translated: He is wise : he has gone forth from here by means of the wisdom of the path of arahatship, thus he is wise . He has followed : he has practised . The Dhamma : the supramundane Dhamma . The discipline : the Dhamma of the practice, beginning with purification of virtue .

original: Atha vā dhammassāti nibbānadhammassa. Anudhammanti ariyamaggaphaladhammaṃ. Na ca
analyzed: atha vā dhammassa ati nibbāna dhammassa anu dhammam ti ariya magga phala dhammam na ca
translated: Or alternatively, the Dhamma is the Dhamma of Nibbāna, and the discipline is the Dhamma of the noble path and fruit.

original: maṃ dhammādhikaraṇanti dhammadesanāhetu na ca maṃ vihesesi yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipannattā.
analyzed: mam dhamma adhikaraṇan ti dhamma desanā hetu na ca mama vihesesi yathānusiṭṭham paṭipanna ttā
translated: He has not vexed me on account of the Dhamma : he has not vexed me for the sake of the teaching of the Dhamma. Because he practised in accordance with the advice.

original: Yo hi satthu santike dhammaṃ sutvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ vā gahetvā yathānusiṭṭhaṃ na paṭipajjati,🔽so satthāraṃ viheseti nāma. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “vihiṃsasaññī paguṇaṃ na bhāsiṃ,
analyzed: yaḥ hi satthu santike dhammam sutvā kammaṭṭhānam vā gahetvā yathānusiṭṭham na paṭipajjati  so satthāram viheseti nāma yam sandhāya vuttam vihiṃsa saññī paguṇam na
translated: For one who hears the Dhamma from the Teacher and takes up a meditation subject but does not practise in accordance with the advice

original: dhammaṃ paṇītaṃ manujesu brahme”ti. Atha vā na ca maṃ dhammādhikaraṇanti na ca imaṃ
analyzed: dhammam paṇītam manujesu brahmā iti atha vā na ca mama dhamma adhikaraṇanti na ca imam
translated: vexes the Teacher. With reference to this it is said: “I did not speak what was hurtful, though I knew the Dhamma, O Brahmā, the sublime Dhamma among men” . Or alternatively, he has not vexed me on account of the Dhamma : he has not vexed me for the sake of the Dhamma.

original: dhammādhikaraṇaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – vaṭṭadukkhato niyyānahetubhūtaṃ imaṃ mama sāsanadhammaṃ
analyzed: dhamma adhikaraṇam idam vuttam hoti vaṭṭa dukkhataḥ niyyāna hetu bhūtam imam mama sāsana dhammam
translated: Dhamma-issue. This is what is meant: this Dhamma of my Dispensation, which is the cause of escape from the suffering of the round,

original: suppaṭipannattā na viheseti. Duppaṭipanno hi sāsanaṃ bhindanto satthu dhammasarīre
analyzed: suppaṭipanna ttā na viheseti duppaṭipannaḥ hi sāsanam bhindantaḥ satthu dhamma sarīre
translated: he does not disturb by his right practice. For one who is wrongly practising and who is breaking up the Dispensation is said to be striking the Master’s Dhamma-body.

original: pahāraṃ deti nāma. Ayaṃ pana sammāpaṭipattiṃ matthakaṃ pāpetvā anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā
analyzed: pahāram deti nāma ayam pana sammāpaṭipattim matthakam pāpetvā anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā
translated: But this one, having brought his right practice to its culmination, attained extinction in the element of extinction without residue of clinging left.

original: parinibbāyi. Tena vuttaṃ – “parinibbuto, bhikkhave, bāhiyo dārucīriyo”ti.
analyzed: parinibbāyi tena vuttam parinibbutaḥ bhikkhave bāhiyaḥ dārucīriyaḥ ti
translated: Hence it was said: ‘Bāhiya of the Bark-cloth, bhikkhus, has attained extinction’ .

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ therassa bāhiyassa anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbutabhāvaṃ,
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam therassa bāhiyassa anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbuta bhāvam
translated: Having known the meaning of this: having known in all its modes the Elder Bāhiya’s attainment of extinction in the element of extinction without residue of clinging left,

original: tathā parinibbutānañca khīṇāsavānaṃ gatiyā pacurajanehi dubbiññeyyabhāvaṃ sabbākārato
analyzed: tathā parinibbutānam ca khīṇāsavānam gatiyā pacura janehi dubbiññeyya bhāvam sabba ākārataḥ
translated: and the difficulty of knowing the destiny of those who have attained extinction and are cankers-destroyed by ordinary men.

original: viditvā. Imaṃ udānanti imaṃ appatiṭṭhitaparinibbānānubhāvadīpakaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: viditvā imam udānan ti imam appatiṭṭhita parinibbāna anubhāva dīpakam udānam udānesi
translated: This exalted utterance: this utterance that illuminates the potency of extinction without trace left.

original: Tattha yatthāti yasmiṃ nibbāne āpo ca na gādhati, pathavī ca tejo ca vāyo ca na gādhati,
analyzed: tattha yattha ati yasmin nibbāne āpaḥ ca na gādhati pathavī ca tejaḥ ca vāyo ca na gādhati
translated: Herein, as to where: in what extinction neither water nor earth nor fire nor air has footing,

original: na patiṭṭhāti. Kasmā? Nibbānassa asaṅkhatasabhāvattā. Na hi tattha saṅkhatadhammānaṃ
analyzed: na patiṭṭhāti kasmā nibbānassa asaṅkhata sabhāva ttā na hi tattha saṅkhata dhammānam
translated: For in it there is not even the slightest trace of formed states.

original: lesopi sambhavati. Sukkāti sukkavaṇṇatāya sukkāti laddhanāmā gahanakkhattatārakā.
analyzed: lesaḥ api sambhavati sukkā ati sukka vaṇṇa tāya sukkā ati laddha nāmā gaha nakkhattatārakā
translated: “Stars” are the stars of the firmament, so called because of their bright colour.🔽“Do not shine”: do not illuminate.

original: Na jotantīti na bhāsanti. Ādicco nappakāsatīti tīsu dīpesu ekasmiṃ khaṇe ālokapharaṇasamattho
analyzed: na jotanti iti na bhāsanti ādiccaḥ na pakāsati iti tīsu dīpesu ekasmin khaṇe āloka pharaṇa samattho
translated: “The sun does not shine”: the sun, which is capable of spreading light over the three continents at one time,🔽does not shine by way of radiance.

original: ādiccopi ābhāvasena na dibbati. Na tattha candimā bhātīti satipi bhāsurabhāve kantasītalakiraṇo
analyzed: na na tattha candimā bhāti iti sati api bhāsura bhāve kanta sītala kiraṇaḥ
translated: “The moon does not light up”: although the moon has a lovely cool radiance,

original: candopi tasmiṃ nibbāne abhāvato eva attano juṇhāvibhāsanena na virocati. Yadi tattha
analyzed: candaḥ api tasmin nibbāne abhāvataḥ eva attanaḥ juṇhā vibhāsanena na virocati yadi tattha
translated: it does not shine by its own light in Nibbāna because of the absence of light there.

original: candimasūriyādayo natthi, lokantaro viya niccandhakārameva taṃ bhaveyyāti āsaṅkaṃ
analyzed: candima sūriya ādayaḥ natthi viya nicca andhakāram eva tam bhaveyyāti āsaṅkam
translated: If the sun, moon, etc., are absent there, then that place would be like the intermediate realm between worlds, and would be completely dark.

original: sandhāyāha “tamo tattha na vijjatī”ti. Sati hi rūpābhāve tamo nāma na siyā.
analyzed: sandhāya āha tamaḥ tattha na vijjati iti sati hi rūpa abhāve tamaḥ nāma na siyā
translated: With this doubt in mind, he says, “Darkness is not found there.” For if there is no visible form, darkness cannot exist.

original: Yadā ca attanā vedi, muni monena brāhmaṇoti catusaccamunanato monanti laddhanāmena
analyzed: yadā ca laddha nāmena
translated: When he himself has known, the sage, the brahmin through his sagacity.

original: maggañāṇena kāyamoneyyādīhi ca samannāgatattā “munī”ti laddhanāmo ariyasāvakabrāhmaṇo
analyzed: magga ñāṇena kāyamoneyya ādīhi ca samannāgata ttā muni iti laddha nāmaḥ ariya sāvaka brāhmaṇo
translated: The noble disciple, who has acquired the name “sage” by virtue of his possession of the body of a noble one, etc., through the knowledge of the path,

original: teneva monasaṅkhātena paṭivedhañāṇena yadā yasmiṃ kāle aggamaggakkhaṇe attanā sayameva
analyzed: tena iva mona saṅkhātena paṭivedha ñāṇena yadā yasmin kāle agga magga kkhaṇe attanā sayam eva
translated: at that time, at the moment of the path of stream-entry, has himself,

original: anussavādike pahāya attapaccakkhaṃ katvā nibbānaṃ vedi paṭivijjhi. “Avedī”tipi pāṭho,🔽aññāsīti attho. Atha rūpā arūpā ca, sukhadukkhā pamuccatīti athāti tassa nibbānassa
analyzed: anussava ādike pahāya atta paccakkham katvā nibbānam vedi paṭivijjhi avedi iti pi pāṭhaḥ  aññāsi iti atthaḥ atha rūpā arūpā ca sukha dukkhā pamuccati iti atha ati tassa nibbānassa
translated: by himself, through his own insight, penetrated nibbāna, having abandoned the views of others, such as the views of the teachers of doctrines based on oral tradition, etc. The reading “avedī” is also correct.

original: jānanato pacchā. Rūpāti rūpadhammā, tena pañcavokārabhavo ekavokārabhavo ca gahito🔽hoti. Arūpāti arūpadhammā, tena rūpenāmissīkato arūpabhavo gahito hoti. So “catuvokārabhavo”tipi🔽vuccati. Sukhadukkhāti sabbattha uppajjanakasukhadukkhatopi vaṭṭato. Atha vā rūpāti
analyzed: jānanato pacchā rūpā ati rūpa dhammā tena pañcavokāra bhavo ekavokāra bhavo ca gahito  hoti arūpā ati arūpa dhammā tena rūpena amissīkataḥ arūpa bhavaḥ gahitaḥ hoti saḥ catuvokāra bhavaḥ ti pi  vuccati sukha dukkhā ti sabbattha uppajjanaka sukha dukkhataḥ pi vaṭṭataḥ atha vā rūpā ati
translated: The meaning is: “he has known.” Then, having known, he is freed from form and the formless, from pleasure and pain: “then” means after the knowledge of the path of stream-entry. “Form” refers to the form element, and thus includes the five-constituent existence and the one-constituent existence.

original: rūpalokapaṭisandhito. Arūpāti arūpalokapaṭisandhito. Sukhadukkhāti kāmāvacarapaṭisandhito.
analyzed: rūpa loka paṭisandhito arūpā ati arūpa loka paṭisandhito sukha dukkhā ati kāmāvacara paṭisandhito
translated: “The formless” refers to the formless element, and thus includes the formless existence, which is unmixed with the form element. This is also called the “four-constituent existence.” “Pleasure and pain” refers to the pleasure and pain that arise in all three planes of existence, and also to the round of existence. Or alternatively, “form” refers to rebirth-linking in the form plane, “the formless” refers to rebirth-linking in the formless plane, and “pleasure and pain” refers to rebirth-linking in the sense-sphere plane.

original: Kāmabhavo hi byāmissasukhadukkho. Evametasmā sakalatopi vaṭṭato accantameva muccatīti
analyzed: kāma bhavaḥ hi byāmissa sukha dukkhaḥ evam etasmā sakalatas api vaṭṭataḥ accantam eva muccati iti
translated: for the sensual-desire realm is the pleasure and pain of the perversions. So he is completely freed from the entire round of rebirths.

original: gāthādvayenapi bhagavā “mayhaṃ puttassa bāhiyassa evarūpā nibbānagatī”ti dasseti.
analyzed: gāthā dvayena api bhagavā mayham puttassa bāhiyassa evarūpā nibbāna gatī iti dasseti
translated: So by these two stanzas the Blessed One shows that his son Bāhiya has such a destiny for Nibbāna.

original: Dasamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dasama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the tenth sutta is finished.

original: Niṭṭhitā ca bodhivaggavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: niṭṭhitā ca bodhi vagga vaṇṇanā
translated: And the commentary on the Bodhi Chapter is finished.

original: 2. Mucalindavaggo🔽1. Mucalindasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: mucalinda vaggo
translated: The Mucalinda Chapter🔽The First Sutta in the Mucalinda Chapter is called “The Mucalinda Sutta” .

original: 11. Mucalindavaggassa paṭhame mucalindamūleti ettha mucalindo vuccati nīparukkho.
analyzed: mucalinda vaggassa paṭhame mucalinda mūla iti ettha mucalindaḥ vuccati nīpa rukkho
translated: Herein, “at the foot of the Mucalinda tree” : the tree called Mucalinda is a kind of coral tree .

original: So “niculo”tipi vuccati, tassa samīpe. Keci pana “mucaloti tassa rukkhassa nāmaṃ,
analyzed: so niculo tipi vuccati tassa samīpe keci pana mucalo ti tassa rukkhassa nāmam
translated: It is also called “the coral tree” . Near it. But some say that “Mucala” is the name of the tree,

original: taṃ vanajeṭṭhakatāya pana mucalindoti vutta”nti vadanti. Mahā akālameghoti asampatte
analyzed: tam vana jeṭṭhaka tāya pana mucalindo ti vuttan ti vadanti mahā akāla megho ti asampatte
translated: and that it is called “Mucalinda” because it is the chief of the forest trees.🔽A great out-of-season cloud: a great cloud that arose at a time when the rains were not due.

original: vassakāle uppannamahāmegho. So hi gimhānaṃ pacchime māse sakalacakkavāḷagabbhaṃ pūrento
analyzed: vassa kāle uppanna mahā meghaḥ so hi gimhānam pacchime māse sakala cakkavāḷa gabbham pūrentaḥ
translated: For it arose filling the whole womb of the world in the last month of the hot season.🔽For seven days it rained incessantly.

original: udapādi. Sattāhavaddalikāti tasmiṃ uppanne sattāhaṃ avicchinnavuṭṭhikā ahosi. Sītavātaduddinīti
analyzed: udapādi satta aha vat dalikā ati tasmin uppanne satta aham avicchinna vuṭṭhikā ahosi sīta vāta duddinī iti
translated: Cold winds and rain:

original: sā ca sattāhavaddalikā udakaphusitasammissena sītavātena samantato paribbhamantena
analyzed: sā ca satta aha vaddalikā udaka phusita sammissena sīta vātena samantataḥ paribbhamantena
translated: And for seven days and nights a cool wind blew from the ocean, bringing rain and clearing the air.

original: dusitadivasattā duddinī nāma ahosi. Mucalindo nāma nāgarājāti tasseva mucalindarukkhassa
analyzed: dusita divasattā duddinī nāma ahosi mucalindaḥ nāma nāga rājā ati tassa iva mucalinda rukkhassa
translated: This was called the “Rain of Purification.” The king of the nāgas was called Mucalinda.

original: samīpe pokkharaṇiyā heṭṭhā nāgabhavanaṃ atthi, tattha nibbatto mahānubhāvo nāgarājā.🔽Sakabhavanāti attano nāgabhavanato. Sattakkhattuṃ bhogehi parikkhipitvāti sattavāre
analyzed: samīpe pokkharaṇiyāḥ heṭṭhā nāga bhavanam atthi tattha nibbattaḥ mahā anubhāvaḥ nāga rājā  saka bhavanā ati attanaḥ nāga bhavanato satta kkhattum bhogehi parikkhipitvā iti satta vāre
translated: His nāga-palace was situated under a lake near the Mucalinda tree.

original: attano sarīrabhogehi bhagavato kāyaṃ parivāretvā. Uparimuddhani mahantaṃ phaṇaṃ vihaccāti
analyzed: attano sarīra bhogehi bhagavato kāyam parivāretvā upari muddhani mahantam phaṇam vihaccāti
translated: He was a powerful nāga-king. “From his own abode” means from his own nāga-palace. “He coiled his coils around the Blessed One seven times” means he surrounded the Blessed One’s body with his own body seven times.🔽“And spread his large hood over the Blessed One’s head” means he spread out his own large hood over the Blessed One’s head.

original: bhagavato muddhappadesassa upari attano mahantaṃ phaṇaṃ pasāretvā. “Phaṇaṃ karitvā”tipi pāṭho, so evattho.
analyzed: bhagavataḥ muddhappadesassa upari attanaḥ mahantam phaṇam pasāretvā phaṇam karitvā iti pi pāṭhaḥ saḥ evatthaḥ
translated: The reading “having made a hood” is also correct.

original: Tassa kira nāgarājassa etadahosi “bhagavā ca mayhaṃ bhavanasamīpe rukkhamūle nisinno,
analyzed: tassa kira nāga rājassa etat ahosi bhagavā ca mayham bhavana samīpe rukkha mūle nisinno
translated: It is said that the nāga-king thought: “The Blessed One is sitting at the foot of a tree near my palace.

original: ayañca sattāhavaddalikā vattati, vāsāgāramassa laddhuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti. So sattaratanamayaṃ🔽pāsādaṃ nimminituṃ sakkontopi “evaṃ kate kāyasāro gahito na bhavissati, dasabalassa🔽kāyaveyyāvaccaṃ karissāmī”ti mahantaṃ attabhāvaṃ katvā satthāraṃ sattakkhattuṃ bhogehi🔽parikkhipitvā upari phaṇaṃ katvā dhāresi. “Parikkhepabbhantaraṃ lohapāsāde bhaṇḍāgāragabbhappamāṇaṃ
analyzed: ayam ca vattati vāsāgāram assa laddhum vaṭṭati iti so satta ratana mayam  pāsādam nimminitum sakkontaḥ api evam kate kāya sāraḥ gahitaḥ na bhavissati dasabalassa  kāyaveyyāvaccam karissāmi iti mahantam atta bhāvam katvā satthāram sattakkhattum bhogehi  parikkhipitvā upari phaṇam katvā dhāresi parikkhepa abbhantaram loha pāsāde bhaṇḍāgāra gabbha ppamāṇam
translated: “And this rain will last for seven days. It is proper for him to have a dwelling.” Although he could have created a palace of the seven precious substances, he thought, “If I do so, I will not have done my duty to the body of the Master. I will therefore do my duty to the body of the Master.” He therefore assumed a huge form, surrounded the Master seven times with his coils, and held up his hood above him. “The space within the coils was the size of the storehouse of the Iron Palace.

original: ahosī”ti khandhakaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Majjhimaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “heṭṭhālohapāsādappamāṇa”nti.🔽“Icchiticchitena iriyāpathena satthā viharissatī”ti kira nāgarājassa ajjhāsayo. Bhagavā
analyzed: ahosi iti khandhaka ṭṭhakathāyam vuttam majjhima ṭṭhakathāyam pana heṭṭhā loha pāsāda ppamāṇam ti  icchiticchitena iriyāpathena satthā viharissati iti kira nāga rājassa ajjhāsayaḥ bhagavā
translated: And this rain will last for seven days. It is proper for him to have a dwelling.” Although he was able to create a palace made of the seven precious substances, he thought, “If I do this, the essence of the body will not be taken. I will do service to the body of the One of Ten Powers.” So he made his body huge, surrounded the Teacher with his coils seven times, and held up his hood above him. In the Commentary to the Khandhaka it is said that the space enclosed by the coils was the size of the storehouse of the Copper Palace. But in the Commentary to the Majjhima Nikāya it is said that it was the size of the Copper Palace itself.

original: pana yathānisinnova sattāhaṃ vītināmesi. Tañca ṭhānaṃ supihitavātapānaṃ suphusitaaggaḷadvāraṃ
analyzed: pana yathā nisinnaḥ uva sattāham vītināmesi tat ca ṭhānam su pihita vāta pānam su phusita aggaḷa dvāram
translated: The king of nāgas thought, “The Teacher will live in whatever posture he wishes.” But the Blessed One spent the seven days sitting in the same posture. And that place was closed up with the windows tightly shut and the doors bolted.

original: kūṭāgāraṃ viya ahosi. Mā bhagavantaṃ sītantiādi tassa tathā karitvā ṭhānakāraṇaparidīpanaṃ.
analyzed: kūṭāgāram viya ahosi mā bhagavantam sīta ntiādi tassa tathā karitvā ṭhāna kāraṇa paridīpanam
translated: and it was like a peaked house. The words “Lest the cold, etc., disturb the Blessed One” show the reason why he did it.

original: So hi “mā bhagavantaṃ sītaṃ bādhayittha, mā uṇhaṃ, mā ḍaṃsādisamphasso bādhayitthā”ti
analyzed: saḥ hi mā bhagavantam sītam bādhayittha mā uṇham mā ḍaṃsa ādi samphassaḥ bādhayittha ati
translated: For he thought, “Lest the cold disturb the Blessed One, lest the heat, lest contact with flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and serpents disturb him,”

original: tathā karitvā aṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: tathā karitvā aṭṭhāsi
translated: and he stood thus.

original: Tattha kiñcāpi sattāhavaddalikāya uṇhameva natthi, sace pana antarantarā megho vigaccheyya,
analyzed: tattha kiñca api uṇham eva natthi sace pana antar antarā meghaḥ vigaccheyya
translated: Herein, although there is no heat for seven days during the rainy season, still if the cloud should depart in the interval,

original: uṇhaṃ bhaveyya, tampi mā bādhayitthāti evaṃ tassa cintetuṃ yuttaṃ. Keci panettha
analyzed: uṇham bhaveyya tam pi mā bādhayittha ati evam tassa cintetum yuttam keci pana ittha
translated: there would be heat, and he thought, “Lest that disturb him.”

original: vadanti “uṇhaggahaṇaṃ bhogaparikkhepassa vipulabhāvakaraṇe kāraṇakittanaṃ. Khuddake
analyzed: vadanti uṇha ggahaṇam bhoga parikkhepassa vipula bhāva karaṇe kāraṇa kittanam khuddake
translated: But some say that the mention of heat is a commendation of the cause for making the extent of the enjoyment extensive.

original: hi tasmiṃ bhagavantaṃ nāgassa sarīrasambhūtā usmā bādheyya, vipulabhāvakaraṇena pana
analyzed: hi tasmin bhagavantam nāgassa sarīra sambhūtā usmā bādheyya vipula bhāva karaṇena pana
translated: For if it were small, the heat generated in the Blessed One’s body would disturb him, but by making it extensive

original: tādisaṃ ‘mā uṇhaṃ bādhayitthā’ti tathā karitvā aṭṭhāsī”ti.
analyzed: tādisam mā uṇham bādhayittha iti tathā karitvā aṭṭhāsi iti
translated: he thought, “Lest the heat disturb him,” and he stood thus.

original: Viddhanti ubbiddhaṃ, meghavigamena dūrībhūtanti attho. Vigatavalāhakanti apagatameghaṃ.
analyzed: viddham nti ubbiddham megha vigamena dūrībhūtam attho vigata valāhakam ti apagata megham
translated: “The cloud departed” means that it went away; the meaning is that it was no longer near. “The sky became clear” means that the cloud had gone.

original: Devanti ākāsaṃ. Viditvāti “idāni vigatavalāhako ākāso, natthi bhagavato sītādiupaddavo”ti
analyzed: ākāsam viditvā iti idāni vigata valāhakaḥ ākāsaḥ na atthi bhagavato sītā ādi upaddavo ti
translated: “The sky” : the sky. “Having known” : having known, “Now the sky is free from clouds, there is no danger of cold, etc., for the Exalted One.”

original: ñatvā. Viniveṭhetvāti apanetvā. Sakavaṇṇanti attano nāgarūpaṃ. Paṭisaṃharitvāti antaradhāpetvā.
analyzed: ñatvā viniveṭhetvā ati apanetvā sa kavaṇṇanti attanaḥ nāga rūpam paṭisaṃharitvā iti antaradhāpetvā
translated: “Having turned back” : having removed. “His own color” : his own nāga form. “Having withdrawn” : having disappeared.

original: Māṇavakavaṇṇanti kumārakarūpaṃ.
analyzed: kumāraka rūpam
translated: “The form of a youth” : the form of a young man.

original: Etamatthanti vivekasukhappaṭisaṃvedino yattha katthaci sukhameva hotīti etamatthaṃ sabbākārena jānitvā. Imaṃ udānanti imaṃ vivekasukhānubhāvadīpakaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: etam attham ti viveka sukha paṭisaṃvedinaḥ yattha katthaci sukham eva hoti iti etam attham sabba ākārena jānitvā imam udānan ti imam viveka sukha anubhāva dīpakam udānam udānesi
translated: “This meaning” : having known this meaning in all its aspects, that wherever there is the bliss of seclusion, there is bliss. “This inspired utterance” : this inspired utterance illuminating the power of the bliss of seclusion, he uttered.

original: Tattha sukho vivekoti nibbānasaṅkhāto upadhiviveko sukho. Tuṭṭhassāti catumaggañāṇasantosena🔽tuṭṭhassa. Sutadhammassāti pakāsitadhammassa vissutadhammassa. Passatoti taṃ vivekaṃ,
analyzed: tattha sukhaḥ viveko ti nibbāna saṅkhātaḥ upadhi viveko sukhaḥ tuṭṭhassa ati catu magga ñāṇa santosena  tuṭṭhassa suta dhammassa ati pakāsita dhammassa vissuta dhammassa passato ti tam vivekam
translated: Herein, “Seclusion is bliss” : seclusion from acquisitions called Nibbāna is bliss. “For one who is content” : for one who is content with the knowledge of the four paths.

original: yaṃ vā kiñci passitabbaṃ nāma, taṃ sabbaṃ attano vīriyabalādhigatena ñāṇacakkhunā
analyzed: yam vā kiñci passitabbam nāma tam sabbam attanaḥ vīriya bala adhigatena ñāṇa cakkhunā
translated: “For one who has heard the Dhamma” : for one who has been taught the Dhamma, for one who has a well-known Dhamma. “Seeing” : seeing that seclusion, or whatever else there is to be seen, all that with the eye of knowledge attained by his own strength.

original: passantassa. Abyāpajjanti akuppanabhāvo, etena mettāpubbabhāgo dassito. Pāṇabhūtesu
analyzed: passantassa a byāpajjanti a kuppana bhāvaḥ etena mettā pubba bhāgaḥ dassito pāṇa bhūtesu
translated: and seeing. “No ill-will” is non-irritation. This shows the preliminary stage of loving-kindness. “ Restraint” is restraint towards beings.

original: saṃyamoti sattesu ca saṃyamo avihiṃsanabhāvo sukhoti attho. Etena karuṇāpubbabhāgo dassito.
analyzed: saṃyamaḥ ti sattesu ca saṃyamaḥ a vihiṃsana bhāvaḥ sukhaḥ ti atthaḥ etena karuṇā pubbabhāgaḥ dassitaḥ
translated: The meaning is: “happiness.” This shows the preliminary stage of compassion.

original: Sukhā virāgatā loketi vigatarāgatāpi loke sukhā. Kīdisī? Kāmānaṃ samatikkamoti, yā
analyzed: sukhā virāga tā loke iti vigata rāga tā api loke sukhā kīdisī kāmānam samatikkamoti yā
translated: “The happiness of fading away in the world” is the fading away of lust. What is it like? “The surmounting of sense desires” is the fading away of lust.

original: kāmānaṃ samatikkamoti vuccati, sā vigatarāgatāpi sukhāti attho, etena anāgāmimaggo
analyzed: kāmānam samatikkamaḥ ti vuccati sā vigata rāga tā api sukhā ati atthaḥ etena anāgāmi maggo
translated: The meaning is: “that which is called the surmounting of sense desires is the happiness of fading away in the world.” This shows the non-return path.

original: kathito. Asmimānassa yo vinayoti iminā pana arahattaṃ kathitaṃ. Arahattañhi asmimānassa🔽paṭippassaddhivinayoti vuccati, ito parañca sukhaṃ nāma natthi, tenāha “etaṃ ve paramaṃ
analyzed: kathitaḥ asmimānassa yaḥ vinayaḥ iti iminā pana arahattam kathitam arahattam hi asmimānassa  paṭippassaddhi vinayaḥ ti vuccati itas param ca sukham nāma natthi tena āha etam ve paramam
translated: “The taming of the conceit ‘I am’” shows the state of Arahantship. For the state of Arahantship is called the taming of the conceit “I am.”

original: sukha”nti. Evaṃ arahattena desanāya kūṭaṃ gaṇhīti.
analyzed: evam arahattena desanāya kūṭam
translated: There is no happiness beyond this, and so it is said: “This is the highest happiness.” Thus he concludes the teaching with the state of Arahantship.

original: Paṭhamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭhama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the first sutta is finished.

original: 2. Rājasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: rāja sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The King’s Sutta

original: 12. Dutiye sambahulānanti vinayapariyāyena tayo janā “sambahulā”ti vuccanti, tato
analyzed: dutiye vinaya pariyāyena tayaḥ janā sambahulā ati vuccanti tatas
translated: In the second sutta, “a number of” means three people according to the Vinaya method. “A number of” is said of three people.

original: paraṃ saṅgho. Suttantapariyāyena pana tayo tayo eva, tato uddhaṃ sambahulā. Tasmā
analyzed: param saṅghaḥ suttanta pariyāyena pana tayo eva tatas uddham sambahulā tasmai
translated: and the other is the Sangha. But according to the Suttas there are three each, and more than that is a number of bhikkhus.

original: idhāpi suttantapariyāyena sambahulāti veditabbā. Upaṭṭhānasālāyanti dhammasabhāmaṇḍape.
analyzed: idha api suttanta pariyāyena sambahulā ati veditabbā upaṭṭhānasālāyanti dhamma sabhā maṇḍape
translated: So here too it should be understood as a number of bhikkhus according to the Suttas. In the assembly hall: in the Dhamma hall.

original: Sā hi dhammaṃ desetuṃ āgatassa tathāgatassa bhikkhūnaṃ upaṭṭhānakaraṇaṭṭhānanti “upaṭṭhānasālā”ti
analyzed: sā hi dhammam desetum āgatassa tathāgatassa bhikkhūnam upaṭṭhāna karaṇa ṭṭhānan ti upaṭṭhāna sālā ati
translated: For that is called “the assembly hall” because it is the place where the bhikkhus attend upon the Tathāgata who has come to teach the Dhamma.

original: vuccati. Atha vā yattha bhikkhū vinayaṃ vinicchinanti, dhammaṃ kathenti, sākacchaṃ🔽samāpajjanti, sannipatanavasena pakatiyā upatiṭṭhanti, sā sālāpi maṇḍapopi “upaṭṭhānasālā”tveva🔽vuccati. Tatthāpi hi buddhāsanaṃ niccaṃ paññattameva hoti. Idañhi buddhānaṃ dharamānakāle
analyzed: vuccati atha vā yattha bhikkhū vinayam vinicchinanti dhammam kathenti sākaccham  samāpajjanti sannipatana vasena pakatiyā upatiṭṭhanti sā sālā api maṇḍapaḥ api upaṭṭhāna sālā tu eva  vuccati tattha api hi buddha āsanam niccam paññattam eva hoti idam hi buddhānam dharamāna kāle
translated: Or alternatively, the hall or the pavilion where the bhikkhus decide upon the Discipline, discuss the Dhamma,🔽and attend upon it by gathering together in the normal way is called “the assembly hall.” For there the Enlightened One’s seat is always set out. For this is the bhikkhus’ practice as long as the Enlightened One is living.

original: bhikkhūnaṃ cārittaṃ. Sannisinnānanti nisajjanavasena saṅgamma nisinnānaṃ. Sannipatitānanti
analyzed: bhikkhūnam cārittam sannisinnānam ti nisajjana vasena saṅgamma nisinnānam sannipatitānam
translated: Sitting together: having gathered together by sitting.

original: tato tato āgantvā sannipatanavasena sannipatitānaṃ. Atha vā buddhāsanaṃ purato katvā🔽satthu sammukhe viya ādaruppattiyā sakkaccaṃ nisīdanavasena sannisinnānaṃ, samānajjhāsayattā
analyzed: tatas tatas āgantvā sannipatana vasena atha vā buddha āsanam puratas katvā  satthu sammukhe viya ādaruppattiyā sakkaccam nisīdana vasena sannisinnānam samānajjhāsaya tā
translated: and they had assembled from here and there by coming together in a gathering. Or alternatively, they were sitting down respectfully as though in the presence of the Teacher, having made the Teacher’s seat their fore-front.

original: aññamaññasmiṃ ajjhāsayena suṭṭhu sammā ca nipatanavasena sannipatitānaṃ. Ayanti idāni
analyzed: aññam aññasmin ajjhāsayena suṭṭhu sammā ca nipatana vasena sannipatitānam ayanti idāni
translated: And they had assembled by falling well and truly upon one another in mutual confidence, because of their having the same confidence.

original: vuccamānaṃ niddisati. Antarākathāti kammaṭṭhānamanasikārauddesaparipucchādīnaṃ antarā🔽aññā ekā kathā, atha vā majjhanhike laddhassa sugatovādassa, sāyaṃ labhitabbassa🔽dhammassavanassa ca antarā pavattattā antarākathā, samaṇasamācārasseva vā antarā
analyzed: vuccamānam niddisati antarākathā ati kammaṭṭhāna manasikāra auddesa paripucchā ādīnam antarā  aññā ekā kathā atha vā majjhanhike laddhassa sugata uvādassa sāyam labhitabbassa  dhammassavanassa ca antarā pavatta tā antarākathā samaṇa samācārassa iva vā antarā
translated: ‘Then’ : this shows what is now going to be said. ‘Some conversation’: some conversation other than that concerned with the meditation subject, such as a discussion of the Master’s instructions, a discussion of the meditation subject, or a discussion of questions;🔽or alternatively, it is called ‘some conversation’ because it occurred in the interval between the Master’s instruction received in the forenoon and the hearing of the Dhamma in the evening;

original: pavattā aññā ekā kathāti antarākathā. Udapādīti uppannā.
analyzed: pavattā aññā ekā kathā ati antarākathā udapādi iti uppannā
translated: or it is called ‘some conversation’ because it was some conversation occurring in the interval of the life of a recluse. ‘Arose’ : came into existence.

original: Imesaṃ dvinnaṃ rājūnanti niddhāraṇe sāmivacanaṃ. Mahaddhanataro vātiādīsu pathaviyaṃ
analyzed: dvinnam niddhāraṇe sāmi vacanam mahat hanataraḥ vāti ādīsu pathaviyam
translated: ‘Of these two kings’ : the instrumental case is used to show the instrumentality.

original: nikhaṇitvā ṭhapitaṃ sattaratananicayasaṅkhātaṃ mahantaṃ dhanaṃ etassāti mahaddhano,
analyzed: nikhaṇitvā ṭhapitam satta ratana nicaya saṅkhātam mahantam dhanam etassa ati mahat dhanaḥ
translated: He has great wealth, a great store of the seven kinds of precious substances, buried and laid by, thus he is a great man of wealth.

original: dvīsu ayaṃ atisayena mahaddhanoti mahaddhanataro. Vāsaddo vikappattho. Sesapadesupi
analyzed: dvīsu ayam atisayena mahat dhanaḥ ti mahat dhanataraḥ vā saddaḥ vikappa atthaḥ sesa padesu pi
translated: He is a greater man of wealth than the two, thus he is a greater man of wealth. The word vasa has the sense of vikappa .

original: eseva nayo. Ayaṃ pana viseso – niccaparibbayavasena mahanto bhogo etassāti mahābhogo.🔽Devasikaṃ pavisanaāyabhūto mahanto koso etassāti mahākoso. Apare pana “devasikaṃ🔽pavisanaāyabhūtaṃ maṇisārapheggugumbādibhedabhinnaṃ pariggahavatthu dhanaṃ, tadeva
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ ayam pana visesaḥ nicca paribbaya vasena mahantaḥ bhogaḥ etassa ati mahā bhogo  devasikam pavisana āya bhūtaḥ mahanto koso etassa ati mahākosaḥ apare pana devasikam  maṇisāra pheggu gumba ādi bheda bhinnam pariggaha vatthu dhanam tat eva
translated: The same method of explanation applies in the other cases. But there is this difference: he has great property, great riches, by reason of his constant use of it, thus he is a great man of property.🔽He has a great treasure, a great store of wealth, which is his daily income, thus he is a great man of treasure. But others say that the word kosa is a word for wealth consisting of such things as jewels, pearls, precious stones, etc., which is the daily income of a king.

original: sāragabbhādīsu nihitaṃ koso”ti vadanti. Vajiro, mahānīlo, indanīlo, marakato, veḷuriyo,🔽padumarāgo, phussarāgo, kakketano, pulāko, vimalo, lohitaṅko, phaliko, pavāḷo, jotiraso,
analyzed: sāragabbha ādīsu nihitam kosaḥ iti vadanti vajiraḥ mahānīlaḥ indanīlaḥ marakataḥ veḷuriyaḥ  padumarāgaḥ phussarāgaḥ kakketanaḥ pulākaḥ vimalaḥ lohitaṅkaḥ phalikaḥ pavāḷaḥ jotirasaḥ
translated: That same wealth stored in such places as the inner palace is called a treasure.🔽The great diamond, the great sapphire, the Indra sapphire, the cat’s eye, the lapis lazuli,

original: gomuttako, gomedako, sogandhiko, muttā, saṅkho, añjanamūlo, rājapaṭṭo, amataṃsako,
analyzed: gomuttakaḥ gomedakaḥ sogandhikaḥ muttā saṅkhaḥ añjanamūlaḥ rājapaṭṭaḥ amataṃsakaḥ
translated: the ruby, the coral, the kakudha gem, the pearl, the beryl, the red pearl, the phalikā gem, the conch shell, the antimony gem, the royal turban, the ambrosial gem,

original: piyako, brāhmaṇī cāti catubbīsati maṇi nāma. Satta lohāni kahāpaṇo ca sāro nāma.🔽Sayanacchādanapāvuraṇagajadantasilādīni pheggu nāma. Candanāgarukuṅkumatagarakappūrādi
analyzed: piyakaḥ brāhmaṇī ca ati catubbīsati maṇi nāma satta lohāni kahāpaṇo ca sāraḥ nāma  sayana chādana pāvuraṇa gaja danta sila ādīni pheggu nāma candana agaru kuṅkuma tagara kappūra ādi
translated: and a wife dear to him, a brahmin woman, make twenty-four. The seven metals and the kahāpaṇa coin are called ‘wealth’.🔽Beds, bedding, clothes, elephants’ tusks, stone slabs, etc., are called ‘furniture’. Sandalwood, aloes, camphor, etc.,

original: gumbā nāma. Tattha purimena ādisaddena sālivīhiādimuggamāsādipubbaṇṇāparaṇṇabhedaṃ
analyzed: gumbā nāma tattha purimena ādi saddena sāli vīhi ādi mugga māsa ādi pubbaṇṇa aparaṇṇa bhedam
translated: are called ‘perfume’. The word ‘etc.’ in ‘grains, etc.’ includes the various kinds of grain such as rice, barley, etc., and the various kinds of pulse such as beans, peas, etc.,

original: dhaññavikatiṃ ādiṃ katvā yaṃ sattānaṃ upabhogaparibhogabhūtaṃ vatthu, taṃ sabbaṃ🔽saṅgayhati. Mahantaṃ vijitaṃ raṭṭhaṃ etassāti mahāvijito. Mahanto hatthiassādivāhano🔽etassāti mahāvāhano. Mahantaṃ senābalañceva thāmabalañca etassāti mahabbalo. Icchitanibbattisaṅkhātā
analyzed: dhañña vikatim ādim katvā yam sattānam upabhoga paribhoga bhūtam vatthu tam sabbam  mahantam vijitam raṭṭham etassa ati mahā vijitaḥ mahantaḥ hatthi assādi vāhanaḥ  etassa ati mahāvāhanaḥ mahantam senā balam ca iva thāma balam ca etassa ati mahabbalaḥ icchita nibbatti saṅkhātā
translated: and all the kinds of property that are used and enjoyed by beings.🔽‘Great realm’: it has a great realm, a great territory. ‘Great army’: it has a great army of elephants, horses, chariots, and foot-soldiers.

original: puññakammanipphannā mahatī iddhi etassāti mahiddhiko. Tejasaṅkhāto ussāhamantapabhusattisaṅkhāto
analyzed: puñña kamma nipphannā mahatī iddhi etassa ati mahiddhiko teja saṅkhātaḥ ussāha manta pabhusatti saṅkhāto
translated: ‘Great strength’: it has a great army and great physical strength. ‘Great power’: it has great power consisting of the psychic potency called ‘wishing and getting’ , which is produced by kamma consisting in good conduct of body, speech, and mind.

original: vā mahanto ānubhāvo etassāti mahānubhāvo.
analyzed: vā mahantaḥ etassa ati mahā anubhāvaḥ
translated: ‘Great majesty’: it has great majesty consisting of energy, zeal, courage, and resoluteness.

original: Ettha ca paṭhamena āyasampadā, dutiyena vittūpakaraṇasampadā, tatiyena vibhavasampadā,
analyzed: ettha ca paṭhamena āya sampadā dutiyena vittu upakaraṇa sampadā tatiyena vibhava sampadā
translated: And here, by the first verse the king’s success in the acquisition of noble qualities is shown, by the second his success in the acquisition of wealth, by the third his success in the acquisition of property,

original: catutthena janapadasampadā, pañcamena yānasampadā, chaṭṭhena parivārasampadāya saddhiṃ
analyzed: catutthena janapada sampadā pañcamena yāna sampadā chaṭṭhena parivāra sampadāya saddhim
translated: by the fourth his success in the acquisition of a country, by the fifth his success in the acquisition of a vehicle, and by the sixth his success in the acquisition of a retinue,

original: attasampadā, sattamena puññakammasampadā, aṭṭhamena pabhāvasampadā tesaṃ rājūnaṃ🔽pakāsitā hoti. Tena yā sā sāmisampatti, amaccasampatti, senāsampatti, raṭṭhasampatti,
analyzed: atta sampadā sattamena puñña kamma sampadā aṭṭhamena pabhāva sampadā tesam rājūnam  pakāsitā hoti tena yā sā sāmi sampatti amacca sampatti senā sampatti raṭṭha sampatti
translated: together with his success in the acquisition of himself. By the seventh his success in the acquisition of meritorious deeds is shown, and by the eighth his success in the acquisition of greatness.

original: vibhavasampatti, mittasampatti, duggasampattīti satta pakatisampadā rājūnaṃ icchitabbā.
analyzed: vibhava sampatti mitta sampatti dugga sampatti iti satta pakati sampadā rājūnam icchitabbā
translated: Thus the seven kinds of success that are desirable for kings, namely, success in the acquisition of wealth, success in the acquisition of ministers, success in the acquisition of an army, success in the acquisition of a country, success in the acquisition of property, success in the acquisition of friends, and success in the acquisition of a wife,

original: Tā sabbā yathārahaṃ paridīpitāti veditabbā.
analyzed: tā sabbā yathāraham paridīpitā iti veditabbā
translated: are all shown here as appropriate.

original: Dānādīhi catūhi saṅgahavatthūhi parisaṃ rañjetīti rājā. Magadhānaṃ issaroti māgadho.
analyzed: dāna ādīhi catūhi saṅgaha vatthūhi parisam rañjeti iti rājā magadhānam issaroti māgadhaḥ
translated: He is a king because he delights his retinue with the four means of gathering a retinue, namely, generosity, agreeable speech, beneficent conduct, and equality of treatment. He is a Magadhan because he is the lord of the Magadhans.

original: Mahatiyā senāya samannāgatattā seniyagottattā vā seniyo. Bimbi vuccati suvaṇṇaṃ,
analyzed: mahatiyā senāya samannāgata ttā seniya gotta ttā vā seniyaḥ bimbi vuccati suvaṇṇam
translated: He is a Seniya because he is endowed with a great army or because he belongs to the Seniya clan. Bimbi is said to be gold,

original: tasmā sārabimbivaṇṇatāya bimbisāro. Keci pana “nāmamevetaṃ tassa rañño”ti vadanti.
analyzed: tasmā sāra bimbi vaṇṇa tāya bimbisāro keci pana nāmam eva etam tassa rañño ti vadanti
translated: Therefore he was Bimbisāra because of his appearance like a gem. But some say that this was the name of the king.

original: Paccāmittaṃ parasenaṃ jinātīti pasenadi. Kosalaraṭṭhassa adhipatīti kosalo. Ayañcarahīti
analyzed: pacca amittam para senam jināti iti pasenadi kosala raṭṭhassa adhipati iti kosalaḥ ayam carahi iti
translated: He conquers the enemy, the opposing army, thus he is Pasenadi. He is the lord of the Kosala country, thus he is Kosala. This one here,

original: ettha carahīti nipātamattaṃ. Vippakatāti apariyositā. Ayaṃ tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ antarākathā aniṭṭhitāti attho.🔽Sāyanhasamayanti sāyanhe ekaṃ samayaṃ. Paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitoti tato tato rūpādiārammaṇato
analyzed: ettha carahi iti nipāta mattam vippakatā ati a pariyositā ayam tesam bhikkhūnam antarākathā aniṭṭhitā ti attho  sāyanha samayanti sāyanhe ekam samayam paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitā ti tatas tatas rūpa ādi ārammaṇato
translated: Here, “here” is merely a particle. “Not yet finished” means not yet completed. This is the meaning: the conversation among those monks was not finished.

original: cittassa paṭisaṃharaṇato paṭisallānasaṅkhātāya phalasamāpattito yathākālaparicchedaṃ🔽vuṭṭhito. Bhagavā hi pubbaṇhasamayaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto sāvatthiṃ pavisitvā bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: cittassa paṭisaṃharaṇataḥ paṭisallāna saṅkhātāya phala samāpattitaḥ yathākāla paricchedam  vuṭṭhitaḥ bhagavā hi pubbaṇhasamayam bhikkhu saṅgha parivutaḥ sāvatthim pavisitvā bhikkhūnam
translated: In the evening time: at one time in the evening. Having risen from seclusion: having risen from the attainment of fruition called seclusion, which is the state of the mind’s withdrawal from such sense objects as visible forms, etc.,🔽having risen from it at the time determined by him. For the Blessed One, surrounded by the community of monks, enters Sāvatthī in the morning time, makes alms easy to obtain for the monks, and after the meal, having returned from his alms round,

original: sulabhapiṇḍapātaṃ katvā katabhattakicco bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ sāvatthito nikkhamitvā
analyzed: sulabha piṇḍapātam katvā kata bhatta kiccaḥ bhikkhūhi saddhim sāvatthitaḥ nikkhamitvā
translated: leaves Sāvatthī together with the monks.

original: vihāraṃ pavisitvā gandhakuṭippamukhe ṭhatvā vattaṃ dassetvā ṭhitānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ yathāsamuṭṭhitaṃ
analyzed: vihāram pavisitvā gandha kuṭippa mukhe ṭhatvā vattam dassetvā ṭhitānam bhikkhūnam yathā samuṭṭhitam
translated: having entered the dwelling, and standing in the perfume chamber, having shown the conduct, and standing, to the monks who were standing, according to what had arisen,

original: sugatovādaṃ datvā tesu araññarukkhamūlādidivāṭṭhānaṃ uddissa gatesu gandhakuṭiṃ pavisitvā
analyzed: sugata uvādam da tvā tesu arañña rukkha mūla ādi divāṭṭhānam uddissa gatesu gandhakuṭim pavisitvā
translated: and after entering the monastery, and standing in the door of the Fragrant Cell, and showing the duties to the monks who were standing there, and giving them the Sugata’s advice, and after they had gone to their respective places, such as the forest, the foot of the tree, and the open air, he entered the Fragrant Cell,

original: phalasamāpattisukhena divasabhāgaṃ vītināmetvā yathākālaparicchede samāpattito vuṭṭhāya,
analyzed: phala samāpatti sukhena divasa bhāgam yathā kāla paricchede samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāya
translated: and after spending the day in the happiness of the fruition attainment, he arose from his attainment at the time of the evening watch,

original: “mayhaṃ upagamanaṃ āgamayamānā catasso parisā sakalavihāraṃ paripūrentiyo nisinnā,
analyzed: mayham upagamanam āgamayamānā catasso parisā sakala vihāram nisinnā
translated: and after thinking: “The four assemblies, who are waiting for me to come, are sitting filling the whole monastery,

original: idāni me dhammadesanatthaṃ dhammasabhāmaṇḍalaṃ upagantuṃ kālo”ti āsanato vuṭṭhāya,🔽kesarasīho viya kañcanaguhāya surabhigandhakuṭito nikkhamitvā yūthaṃ upasaṅkamanto
analyzed: idāni me dhamma desana attham dhamma sabhā maṇḍalam upagantum kālo ti āsanataḥ vuṭṭhāya  kesarasīhaḥ viya kañcana guhāya surabhi gandha kuṭitaḥ nikkhamitvā yūtham upasaṅkamanto
translated: now it is time for me to go to the Dhamma pavilion to teach the Dhamma,” and after rising from his seat,🔽like a lion of the snow-capped mountains who has come out from his fragrant fragrant cave, and is approaching his herd,🔽like a mighty elephant in rut who is approaching his herd, with a beautiful and graceful gait, without moving his body,

original: mattavaravāraṇo viya akāyacāpallena cāruvikkantagamano asītianubyañjanappaṭimaṇḍitabāttiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇasamujjalāya
analyzed: matta vara vāraṇaḥ viya a kāya cāpallena cāru vikkanta gamanaḥ asīti anubyañjana paṭimaṇḍita bāttiṃsa mahā purisa lakkhaṇa samujjalāya
translated: with his body shining with the thirty-two marks of a great man, and adorned with the eighty minor characteristics,

original: byāmappabhāya parikkhepavilāsasampannāya pabhassaraketumālālaṅkatāya nīlapītalohitodātamañjiṭṭhapabhassarānaṃ
analyzed: byāma ppabhāya parikkhepa vilāsa sampannāya pabhassara ketu mālā alaṅkatāya
translated: and which, with its six-coloured Buddha-rays, blue, yellow, red, white, crimson, and opalescent,

original: vasena chabbaṇṇabuddharaṃsiyo vissajjentiyā acinteyyānubhāvāya anupamāya buddhalīlāya
analyzed: vasena chabbaṇṇa buddha raṃsiyaḥ vissajjentiyā acinteyya anubhāvāya anupamāya buddha līlāya
translated: issuing forth, possesses the inconceivable majesty of the incomparable Buddha-sport,

original: samannāgatāya rūpakāyasampattiyā sakalavihāraṃ ekālokaṃ kurumāno upaṭṭhānasālaṃ upasaṅkami.
analyzed: samannāgatāya rūpa kāya sampattiyā sakala vihāram eka ālokam kurumānaḥ upaṭṭhāna sālam upasaṅkami
translated: and which, by the possession of the perfection of the material body, makes the whole monastery one light, approached the attendance hall.

original: Tena vuttaṃ – “atha kho bhagavā…pe… tenupasaṅkamī”ti.
analyzed: tena vuttam atha kho bhagavā āpe tena upasaṅkami iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “Then the Blessed One…etc… approached.”

original: Evaṃ upasaṅkamitvā vattaṃ dassetvā nisinne te bhikkhū tuṇhībhūte disvā “mayi akathente
analyzed: evam upasaṅkamitvā vattam dassetvā nisinne te bhikkhū tuṇhībhūte disvā mayi a kathente
translated: Having approached in this way, and having shown the proper behaviour, and having sat down, and having seen those monks silent, (he thought): “If I do not speak,

original: ime bhikkhū buddhagāravena kappampi na kathessantī”ti kathāsamuṭṭhāpanatthaṃ “kāya
analyzed: ime bhikkhū buddha gāravena kappam pi na kathessanti iti kathā samuṭṭhāpana attham kāya
translated: these monks, out of respect for the Buddha, will not speak even for a aeon.” Therefore, in order to begin the discussion, he said: “What, monks,

original: nuttha, bhikkhave”tiādimāha. Tattha kāya nutthāti katamāya nu bhavatha. “Kāya notthā”tipi
analyzed: nuttha bhikkhave tiādim āha tattha kāya nuttha ati katamāya nu bhavatha kāya nottha atipi
translated: what is the discussion that you were engaged in just now as you sat here all gathered together? And what was the subject of your conversation?” Herein, what is the discussion? What is the matter? The reading is kāya nutthā, but the meaning is the same as kāya nutthā.

original: pāḷi, so evattho, “kāya nvetthā”tipi paṭhanti, tassa katamāya nu etthāti attho. Tatrāyaṃ
analyzed: saḥ evatthaḥ kāya nu ettha atipi paṭhanti tassa katamāya nu ettha ati atthaḥ tatra ayam
translated: They also read kāya nvetthā, the meaning of which is what is the matter here? Herein, this is the explanation:

original: saṅkhepattho – bhikkhave, katamāya nāma kathāya idha sannisinnā bhavatha, katamā
analyzed: saṅkhepa atthaḥ bhikkhave katamāya nāma kathāya idha sannisinnāḥ bhavatha katamā
translated: The meaning of the words is this: “Monks, what is the talk about that you are sitting here engaged in?

original: ca tumhākaṃ kathā mamāgamanapaccayā aniṭṭhitā, taṃ niṭṭhāpessāmīti evaṃ sabbaññupavāraṇāya pavāresi.
analyzed: ca tumhākam kathā mama āgamana paccayā aniṭṭhitā tam niṭṭhāpessāmi iti evam sabbaññu pavāraṇāya pavāresi
translated: What is the talk that you have left unfinished that I have come upon? I will finish it off for you.” Thus he invited them to continue the talk by inviting them to be all-knowing.🔽“But this is not the time for that”: the reading is “na kho etaṃ,” or “na kho taṃ.”

original: Na khvetanti na kho etaṃ, ayameva vā pāṭho. “Na khota”ntipi paṭhanti, na kho etaṃ
analyzed: na khu etanti na kho etam ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ paṭhanti na kho etam
translated: The analysis of the words is this: “na kho eta” .🔽“Sons of good family”: sons of good family by birth and by conduct.

original: icceva padavibhāgo. Kulaputtānanti jātiācārakulaputtānaṃ. Saddhāti saddhāya, kammaphalasaddhāya
analyzed: iccā iva pada vibhāgaḥ kula puttānam ti jāti ācāra kula puttānam saddhā ati saddhāya kamma phala saddhāya
translated: “Faith”: faith in kamma and its fruits,🔽and faith in the Three Jewels.🔽“From home”: from the house; the meaning is, from the state of a householder.

original: ratanattayasaddhāya ca. Agārasmāti gharato, gahaṭṭhabhāvāti attho. Anagāriyanti pabbajjaṃ.
analyzed: ca agārasma ati gharataḥ gahaṭṭha bhāvā ati attho anagāriyanti pabbajjam
translated: “To homelessness”: to the going forth;🔽“gone forth”: gone forth to it.🔽“Go”: the taking up of an action.

original: Pabbajitānanti upagatānaṃ. Yanti kiriyāparāmasanaṃ. Tatthāyaṃ padayojanā – “bhikkhave,
analyzed: pabbajitānam ti upagatānam yanti kiriyā parāmasanam tattha ayam pada yojanā bhikkhave
translated: Here is the word-by-word meaning: “Monks,

original: tumhe neva rājābhinītā na corābhinītā na iṇaṭṭā na jīvitapakatā pabbajitā, atha kho
analyzed: tumhe na iva rāja abhinītāḥ na cora abhinītāḥ na iṇaṭṭāḥ na jīvita pakatāḥ pabbajitāḥ atha kho
translated: you have not gone forth because you have been sent by the king, or because you have been sent by thieves, or because you are in debt, or because you are avoiding punishment, or because you are afraid of want,

original: saddhāya agārato nikkhamitvā mama sāsane pabbajitā, tumhe etarahi evarūpiṃ rājappaṭisaṃyuttaṃ🔽tiracchānakathaṃ katheyyātha, yaṃ evarūpāya kathāya kathanaṃ, etaṃ tumhākaṃ na kho
analyzed: saddhāya agārataḥ nikkhamitvā mama sāsane pabbajitā tumhe etarahi evarūpim rāja paṭisaṃyuttam  tiracchāna katham katheyyātha yam evarūpāya kathāya kathanam etam tumhākam na kho
translated: “You have gone forth in my Dispensation from the home into homelessness out of faith, and now you are talking this kind of talk connected with kings,

original: patirūpaṃ na yuttamevā”ti.🔽Evaṃ sannipatitānaṃ pabbajitānaṃ appatirūpaṃ paṭikkhipitvā idāni nesaṃ patirūpaṃ🔽paṭipattiṃ anujānanto “sannipatitānaṃ vo, bhikkhave, dvayaṃ karaṇīyaṃ dhammī vā kathā🔽ariyo vā tuṇhībhāvo”ti āha. Tattha voti tumhākaṃ. Karaṇīyanti hi padaṃ apekkhitvā🔽kattari sāmivacanametaṃ, tasmā tumhehīti attho. Dvayaṃ karaṇīyanti dve kātabbā. Dhammī
analyzed: pati rūpam na yuttam eva ati  evam sannipatitānam pabbajitānam appatirūpam paṭikkhipitvā idāni na esam patirūpam  paṭipattim anujānanto sannipatitānam vaḥ bhikkhave dvayam karaṇīyam dhammī vā kathā  ariyaḥ vā tuṇhībhāvaḥ ti āha tattha vo ti tumhākam karaṇīyanti hi padam apekkhitvā  kattari sāmi vacanam etam tasmā atthaḥ dvayam karaṇīyanti dve kātabbā dhammī
translated: which is unbecoming, unfitting, and unworthy of a recluse.”🔽After thus forbidding the kind of talk that is unbecoming for those who have gone forth and assembled together, the Exalted One now permits the kind of talk that is proper for them, saying: “Bhikkhus, when you have assembled together, two things should be done: a talk on the Dhamma or noble silence.”

original: kathāti catusaccadhammato anapetā kathā, pavattinivattiparidīpinī dhammadesanāti
analyzed: kathā ati catu sacca dhammataḥ an apetā kathā pavatti nivatti paridīpinī dhamma desanā ati
translated: Here the word “vo” is used in the sense of “tumhākaṃ,” “your.” The word “karaṇīyaṃ” is a gerundive formed with the passive termination of the “ya” class. It is used here in the sense of “kattari,” “that which should be done.” Thus the expression means: “What should be done by you.” “Dvayaṃ karaṇīyaṃ” means: “Two things should be done.” “A talk on the Dhamma” is a talk that does not deviate from the four noble truths, a talk that reveals the way to the cessation of suffering.

original: attho. Dasakathāvatthusaṅkhātāpi hi dhammakathā tadekadesā evāti. Ariyoti ekantahitāvahattā
analyzed: atthaḥ dasa kathā vatthu saṅkhātā api hi dhamma kathā tad eka desā evā ati ariyaḥ ti ekanta hita āvahattā
translated: For the Dhamma talk consisting of the ten instances of talk is a part of that.🔽“Noble silence”: noble because it is the sole means of attaining the highest good,🔽or because it is purified and sublime.

original: ariyo, visuddho uttamoti vā ariyo. Tuṇhībhāvoti samathavipassanābhāvanābhūtaṃ akathanaṃ.
analyzed: ariyaḥ visuddhaḥ uttamaḥ ti vā ariyaḥ tuṇhībhāvaḥ ti samatha vipassanā bhāvanā bhūtam a kathanam
translated: “Silence”: non-utterance, which is the development of serenity and insight.

original: Keci pana “vacīsaṅkhārapaṭipakkhabhāvato dutiyajjhānaṃ ariyo tuṇhībhāvo”ti vadanti.
analyzed: keci pana vacī saṅkhāra paṭipakkha bhāvataḥ dutiya jhānam ariyaḥ tuṇhībhāvaḥ ti vadanti
translated: But some say that the second jhāna is noble silence because it is the opposite of verbal formations.🔽Others say that the fourth jhāna is noble silence.

original: Apare “catutthajjhānaṃ ariyo tuṇhībhāvo”ti vadanti. Ayaṃ panettha attho – “bhikkhave,
analyzed: apare catuttha jhānam ariyaḥ tuṇhībhāvaḥ ti vadanti ayam pana ittha atthaḥ bhikkhave
translated: But the meaning here is this: “Monks,

original: cittavivekassa paribrūhanatthaṃ vivekaṭṭhakāyā suññāgāre viharantā sace kadāci sannipatatha,🔽evaṃ sannipatitehi tumhehi ‘assutaṃ sāveti sutaṃ vā pariyodapetī’ti vuttanayena aññamaññassūpakārāya
analyzed: citta vivekassa paribrūhana attham viveka ṭṭhakāyā suññāgāre viharantā sace kadāci sannipatatha  evam sannipatitehi tumhehi assutam sāveti sutam vā pariyodapeti iti vutta nayena aññamaññassa upakārāya
translated: in order to increase the seclusion of mind, when you live in secluded resting places in the forest and occasionally assemble together,

original: khandhādīnaṃ aniccatādipaṭisaṃyuttā dhammakathā vā pavattetabbā, aññamaññaṃ abyābādhanatthaṃ
analyzed: khandha ādīnam anicca tā ādi paṭisaṃyuttā dhamma kathā vā pavattetabbā aññam aññam a byābādhana tham
translated: then, when you have assembled, you should either hold a Dhamma talk connected with the impermanence, etc., of the aggregates, etc., in order to help one another,

original: jhānasamāpattiyā vā viharitabba”nti.
analyzed: jhāna samāpattiyā vā viharitabbanti
translated: or else you should live in the attainment of jhāna, in order not to be a burden to one another.”

original: Tattha purimena karaṇīyavacanena anotiṇṇānaṃ sāsane otaraṇūpāyaṃ dasseti, pacchimena
analyzed: tattha purimena karaṇīya vacanena anotiṇṇānam sāsane otaraṇa upāyam dasseti pacchimena
translated: Herein, by the first statement of what is to be done he shows the means for those who have not yet entered the Dispensation to enter it,🔽and by the second the means for those who have entered it to escape from the round of rebirths.

original: otiṇṇānaṃ saṃsārato nissaraṇūpāyaṃ. Purimena vā āgamaveyyattiye niyojeti, pacchimena
analyzed: otiṇṇānam saṃsārataḥ nissaraṇa upāyam purimena vā āgama veyyattiye niyojeti pacchimena
translated: Or alternatively, by the first he urges them to the fulfilment of the learning that comes from what is heard,🔽and by the second to the fulfilment of the learning that comes from what is reflected upon.

original: adhigamaveyyattiye. Atha vā purimena sammādiṭṭhiyā paṭhamaṃ uppattihetuṃ dīpeti,
analyzed: adhigama veyyattiye atha vā purimena sammādiṭṭhiyā paṭhamam uppatti hetum dīpeti
translated: Or again, by the first he shows the cause for the first arising of right view,

original: dutiyena dutiyaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: dutiyena dutiyam vuttam ha etam
translated: and by the second the second. For this is said:

original: “Dveme, bhikkhave, hetū dve paccayā sammādiṭṭhiyā uppādāya parato ca ghoso, paccattañca yoniso manasikāro”ti.
analyzed: dve me bhikkhave hetū dve paccayā sammādiṭṭhiyāḥ uppādāya paratas ca ghoso paccattam ca yonisas manasikāro ti
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these two causes, two conditions, for the arising of right view. The teaching of another and wise attention” .

original: Purimena vā lokiyasammādiṭṭhiyā mūlakāraṇaṃ vibhāveti, pacchimena lokuttarasammādiṭṭhiyā mūlakāraṇanti evamādinā ettha yojanā veditabbā.
analyzed: purimena vā lokiya sammādiṭṭhiyāḥ mūla kāraṇam vibhāveti pacchimena lokuttara sammādiṭṭhiyāḥ mūla kāraṇam ti evamādinā ettha yojanā veditabbā
translated: Or alternatively, by the first he analyses the root cause of mundane right view, and by the second the root cause of supramundane right view. The construction should be understood in this way.🔽Having understood the meaning of this, those bhikkhus,

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti tehi bhikkhūhi kittitakāmasampattito jhānādisampatti santatarā
analyzed: etam attham viditvā ti tehi bhikkhūhi kittita kāma sampattitaḥ jhāna ādi sampatti santatarā
translated: who were more intent on the attainment of jhāna, etc., than on the attainment of fame,

original: ceva paṇītatarā cāti etamatthaṃ sabbākārato viditvā. Imaṃ udānanti imaṃ ariyavihārasukhānubhāvadīpakaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: ca iva paṇītatarā ca ati etam attham sabba ākārataḥ viditvā imam udānan ti imam ariya vihāra sukha anubhāva dīpakam udānam udānesi
translated: and more excellent than that, and he uttered this Solemn Utterance:

original: Tattha yañca kāmasukhaṃ loketi lokasaddo “khandhaloko āyatanaloko dhātuloko”tiādīsu saṅkhāresu āgato.
analyzed: tattha yat ca kāma sukham loka iti loka saddaḥ khandha lokaḥ āyatana lokaḥ dhātu lokaḥ iti ādīsu saṅkhāresu āgataḥ
translated: Herein, the word world is found in the Categories in such passages as “The world of kamma-formations, the world of kamma-results, the world of the kamma-formed, the world of the kamma-unformed” .🔽“As far as moon and sun do circulate

original: “Yāvatā candimasūriyā pariharanti,🔽Disā bhanti virocanā;
analyzed: yāvatā candima sūriyā pariharanti  disā bhanti virocanā
translated: Shining,

original: Tāva sahassadhā loko,
analyzed: tāva sahassadhā lokaḥ
translated: So far extends this world a thousand times,

original: Ettha te vattatī vaso”ti. –
analyzed: ettha te vattatī vasoti
translated: Where your power holds sway” .

original: Ādīsu okāse āgato. “Addasā kho bhagavā buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokento”tiādīsu sattesu.
analyzed: ādīsu okāse āgataḥ addasā kho bhagavā buddha cakkhunā lokam volokento ti ādīsu sattesu
translated: It is found in the sense of place in such passages as “The Blessed One saw with his Buddha-eye that the world had fallen into trouble” .🔽Here, however, it should be understood in the sense of the world of beings and the world of location,

original: Idha pana sattaloke okāsaloke ca veditabbo. Tasmā avīcito paṭṭhāya upari brahmalokato
analyzed: idha pana satta loke okāsa loke ca veditabbo tasmai avīcitaḥ paṭṭhāya upari brahmalokato

translated: “Who but a Tathāgata could know the interval between the two?” “People, having gathered, talk; but you,

original: “antarā ca sāvatthiṃ antarā ca jetavana”nti. Īdisesu ṭhānesu akkharacintakā “antarā🔽gāmañca nadiñca gacchatī”ti ekameva antarāsaddaṃ payujjanti, so dutiyapadenapi yojetabbo
analyzed: antarā ca sāvatthim antarā ca jetavanan ti īdisesu ṭhānesu akkhara cintakāḥ antarā 🔽gāmam ca nadin ca gacchati iti ekam eva antarāsaddam payujjanti saḥ dutiya padena api yojetabbaḥ
translated: what is the interval?” and so on. In the passage “I saw a certain woman, venerable sir, washing a pot in the light of a flash of lightning” it is a moment. In the passage “In whom there are no internal fevers” it is mind. In the passage “You have taken up residence in the interval” it is middle. In the passage “This, bhikkhus, is the way to the great hell, coming between the two great hells” it is a gap. Here too it should be understood in the same way. Therefore the meaning here should be understood thus: “between Sāvatthī and Jeta’s Wood.” For the word “interval” is used here in the sense of “connection.” “Between Sāvatthī and Jeta’s Wood” is the way it is used. In such places as this, those who think in terms of syllables use the word “interval” only once, as in the passage “He goes between the village and the river.” It should be compounded with the second word as well.

analyzed: sarīra daṇḍena vā satam vā sahassam vā ṭhāpana vasena dhana daṇḍena vā ati imesu daṇḍesu  yena kenacid daṇḍena vihiṃsati viheṭheti dukkham pāpeti attanaḥ sukham esāno pecca

analyzed: evam sabbe api iti cintetvā sampatta virati ādīsu ṭhitaḥ vutta nayena kenacid daṇḍena sabbāni api

analyzed: bhūtāni na hiṃsati na bādhati saḥ puggalaḥ para loke manussa bhūtaḥ manussa sukham deva bhūtaḥ

analyzed: dibba sukham ubhayam atikkamantaḥ nibbāna sukham labhati iti ettha ca tādisassa puggalassa

analyzed: tam sukham paccuppannam viya hoti iti dassana attham labhata iti vuttam
translated: And because such happiness is not to be expected, it is said that he “obtains” it as if it were present.

original: 4. Sakkārasuttavaṇṇanā🔽14. Catutthe tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sakkato hotīti kappānaṃ satasahassādhikesu🔽catūsu asaṅkhyeyyesu paripūritassa puññasambhāravisesassa phalabhūtena “ito paraṃ
analyzed: sakkāra sutta vaṇṇanā  catutthe tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sakkataḥ hoti iti kappānam sata sahassa adhikesu  catūsu asaṅkhyeyyesu paripūritassa puñña sambhāra visesassa phala bhūtena itas param

analyzed: mayham okāsaḥ natthi iti ussaha jātena viya upari upari vaḍḍhamānena sakkāra ādinā bhagavā
translated: In the fourth sutta, “at that time the Blessed One was honoured” means that the Blessed One was honoured with the highest honours, as if he were the one who had no more opportunity to be reborn, because of the fruit of the special accumulation of merit that he had fulfilled in the four incalculable ages plus a hundred thousand aeons.

original: sakkato hoti. Sabbadisāsu hi yamakamahāmegho vuṭṭhahitvā mahoghaṃ viya sabbapāramiyo
analyzed: sakkataḥ hoti sabba disāsu hi yamaka mahā meghaḥ vuṭṭhahitvā mahā ogham viya sabba pāramiyaḥ

original: “ekasmiṃ attabhāve vipākaṃ dassāmā”ti sampiṇḍitā viya bhagavato lābhasakkāramahoghaṃ
analyzed: ekasmin atta bhāve vipākam dassāma ati sampiṇḍitāḥ viya bhagavataḥ lābha sakkāra mahogham

original: nibbattayiṃsu. Tato annapānavatthayānamālāgandhavilepanādihatthā khattiyabrāhmaṇādayo
analyzed: nibbattayiṃsu tatas anna pāna vattha yāna mālā gandha vilepana ādi hatthā khattiya brāhmaṇa ādayaḥ

analyzed: āgantvā kaham buddhaḥ kaham bhagavā kaham devadevaḥ kaham narāsabhaḥ kaham purisa sīhaḥ iti

analyzed: bhagavantam pariyesanti sakaṭa satehi paccaye āharitvā okāsam a labhamānā samantā

analyzed: gāvuta ppamāṇe pi sakaṭa dhurena sakaṭa dhuram āhacca tiṭṭhanti ca iva anubandhanti ca

original: andhakavindabrāhmaṇādayo viya. Sabbaṃ taṃ khandhake tesu tesu ca suttesu āgatanayena
analyzed: andhaka vinda brāhmaṇa ādayaḥ viya sabbam tam khandhake tesu tesu ca suttesu āgata nayena

analyzed: veditabbam yathā ca bhagavataḥ evam bhikkhu saṅghassa ati vuttam ha etam

analyzed: yāvatā kho cunda etarahi saṅghāḥ vā gaṇāḥ vā loke uppannāḥ na aham cunda aññam eka saṅgham pi samanupassāmi evam lābha gga yasagga ppattam yathariva ayam cunda bhikkhu saṅghaḥ ti  svā ayam bhagavataḥ ca bhikkhu saṅghassa ca uppannaḥ lābha sakkāraḥ ekatas hutvā dvinnam
translated: “Cunda, I do not see any other community or group in the world so worthy of offerings as the Community of monks.”🔽The offerings and respect that came to the Exalted One and the Community of monks were immeasurable, like the waters of the two great rivers.

original: mahānadīnaṃ udakogho viya appameyyo ahosi. Tena vuttaṃ – “tena kho pana samayena
analyzed: mahā nadīnam udaka oghaḥ viya appameyyaḥ ahosi tena vuttam tena kho pana samayena
translated: Therefore it is said: “At that time the Exalted One was honored,

analyzed: pana visesataḥ vipanna sobhā sūri yuggamane khajjopanakā viya nippabhā nittejā hata lābha sakkārā

analyzed: tattha bhikkhū akkosantā paribhāsantā vicariṃsu tena vuttam añña titthiyā pana  paribbājakāḥ a sakkatāḥ honti pe parikkhārānaṃ atha kho te añña titthiyāḥ paribbājakā

original: catukoṭikaṃ suññataṃ vibhāvesi.

translated: Thus the Blessed One analyzed the emptiness of the four-cornered formula, namely, “I am not anywhere anyone’s anything, nor is there anywhere anything that is mine.”
