translated: and when there is that, they contact their respective objects and occur there.

original: hi vedanā santasabhāvatāya sukhe eva saṅgahaṃ gacchatīti duvidhasamphassavasenevāyaṃ atthavaṇṇanā katā.
analyzed: hi vedanā santasa bhāvatāya sukhe eva saṅgaham gacchati iti duvidha samphassa vasena iva ayam attha vaṇṇanā katā
translated: For the neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling is included in the pleasant because of its peaceful nature. So the commentary on the meaning is given in terms of the two kinds of contact.

original: Yathā pana te phassā na phusanti, taṃ dassetuṃ “nirupadhiṃ kena phuseyyuṃ phassā”ti
analyzed: yathā pana te phassāḥ na phusanti tam dassetum nirupadhim kena phuseyyum phassa ati
translated: But in order to show how those contacts do not contact, it is said, “Without a substrate, by what means would contacts contact?”

original: vuttaṃ. Sabbaso hi khandhūpadhiyā asati kena kāraṇena te phassā phuseyyuṃ, na taṃ🔽kāraṇaṃ atthi. Yadi hi tumhe akkosādivasena uppajjanasukhadukkhaṃ na icchatha, sabbaso
analyzed: vuttam sabbaso hi khandha upadhiyā asati kena kāraṇena te phassā phuseyyum na tam  kāraṇam atthi yadi hi tumhe akkosa ādi vasena uppajjana sukha dukkham na icchatha sabbaso
translated: For if the substrate of the aggregates is completely absent, by what means would those contacts contact? That means is not.

original: nirupadhibhāveyeva yogaṃ kareyyāthāti anupādisesanibbānadhātuyā gāthaṃ niṭṭhapesi.
analyzed: nirupadhi bhāveya iva yogam kareyyātha ati anupādisesa nibbānadhātuyā gātham niṭṭhapesi
translated: If you do not want the pleasure and pain that arise through abuse, etc., you should strive for the state of being completely without a substrate. Thus he concluded the stanza with the element of Nibbāna without residue left.

original: Evaṃ iminā udānena vaṭṭavivaṭṭaṃ kathitaṃ.🔽Catutthasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽5. Upāsakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: evam iminā udānena vaṭṭa vivaṭṭam kathitam 🔽catuttha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽upāsaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: So in this way the round of rebirths and the escape from it are stated in the introduction.

original: 15. Pañcame icchānaṅgalakoti icchānaṅgalanāmako kosalesu eko brāhmaṇagāmo, taṃnivāsitāya
analyzed: pañcame icchānaṅgalakaḥ iti icchānaṅgala nāmakaḥ kosalesu ekaḥ brāhmaṇa gāmaḥ
translated: The fifth: at Icchānaṅgala. Icchānaṅgala is the name of a brahmin village in the Kosala country.🔽He was either a resident there or he was born there, thus he was of Icchānaṅgala.

original: tattha vā jāto bhavoti vā icchānaṅgalako. Upāsakoti tīhi saraṇagamanehi bhagavato
analyzed: tattha vā jātaḥ bhavoti vā tīhi saraṇa gamanehi bhagavato
translated: A lay follower: by going for refuge three times he had announced his lay follower status in the Blessed One’s presence.

original: santike upāsakabhāvassa paveditattā upāsako pañcasikkhāpadiko buddhamāmako, dhammamāmako,
analyzed: santike upāsaka bhāvassa paveditattā upāsako pañca sikkhāpadikaḥ buddha māmakaḥ dhamma māmakaḥ
translated: He was a lay follower with the five training precepts, a devotee of the Enlightened One, a devotee of the True Idea, a devotee of the Community.

original: saṅghamāmako. Kenacideva karaṇīyenāti uddhārasodhāpanādinā kenacideva kattabbena.
analyzed: saṅgha māmakaḥ kenacid eva karaṇīyena ati uddhāra sodhāpana ādinā kenacid eva kattabbena
translated: With some business: with some matter to be done, such as the fetching of water, the fetching of wood, and so on.

original: Tīretvāti niṭṭhāpetvā. Ayaṃ kira upāsako pubbe abhiṇhaṃ bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: tīretvā ti niṭṭhāpetvā ayam kira upāsakaḥ pubbe abhiṇham bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā
translated: Having crossed: having finished. It seems that this lay follower had often gone to see the Blessed One before,

original: payirupāsati, so katipayaṃ kālaṃ bahukaraṇīyatāya satthu dassanaṃ nābhisambhosi.
analyzed: payiḥ upāsati saḥ katipayam kālam bahu karaṇīya tāya satthu dassanam na abhisambhosi
translated: but for some time he had not been able to see the Master because he had much to do.

original: Tenāha bhagavā – “cirassaṃ kho tvaṃ, upāsaka, imaṃ pariyāyamakāsi, yadidaṃ idhāgamanāyā”ti.
analyzed: tena āha bhagavā cirassam kho tvam upāsaka imam pariyāyam akāsi yat idam idha āgamanāya ati
translated: So the Blessed One said, “It is long, lay follower, since you found an opportunity to come here” .🔽Herein, long is late.

original: Tattha cirassanti cirena. Pariyāyanti vāraṃ. Yadidanti nipāto, yo ayanti attho. Idaṃ
analyzed: tattha cirassanti cirena pariyāyanti vāram yat idam ti nipātaḥ yaḥ ayanti atthaḥ idam
translated: Opportunity is occasion. Since you found an opportunity is the meaning.

original: vuttaṃ hoti – idha mama santike āgamanāya yo ayaṃ ajja kato vāro, taṃ imaṃ cirena
analyzed: vuttam hoti idha mama santike āgamanāya yaḥ ayam ajja kataḥ vāro tam imam cirena
translated: He means: “The turn that was made today for coming into my presence, that I have made long

original: papañcaṃ katvā akāsīti. Cirapaṭikāhanti cirapaṭiko ahaṃ, cirakālato paṭṭhāya ahaṃ
analyzed: katvā akāsi iti cira paṭikā hanti cira paṭikaḥ aham cira kālataḥ paṭṭhāya aham
translated: by making a delay.” Cirapaṭikāhaṃ: I am a long-time-comer, I have been wanting to come

original: upasaṅkamitukāmoti sambandho. Kehici kehicīti ekaccehi ekaccehi. Atha vā kehici kehicīti🔽yehi vā tehi vā. Tattha gāravaṃ dasseti. Satthari abhippasannassa hi satthudassanadhammassavanesu
analyzed: upasaṅkamitu kāmaḥ iti sambandhaḥ kehici kehici iti ekaccehi ekaccehi atha vā kehici kehici iti  yehi vā tehi vā tattha gāravam dasseti satthari abhippasannassa hi satthu dassana dhamma ssavanesu
translated: for a long time. Kehici kehicīti ekaccehi ekaccehi. Or else kehici kehicīti🔽by some or other. There he shows respect. For one who has full confidence in the Teacher has no respect for anything else

original: viya na aññattha ādaro hoti. Kiccakaraṇīyehīti ettha avassaṃ kātabbaṃ kiccaṃ, itaraṃ🔽karaṇīyaṃ. Paṭhamaṃ vā kātabbaṃ kiccaṃ, pacchā kātabbaṃ karaṇīyaṃ. Khuddakaṃ vā kiccaṃ,
analyzed: viya na aññattha ādaraḥ hoti kicca karaṇīyehi iti ettha avassam kātabbam kiccam itaram  karaṇīyam paṭhamam vā kātabbam kiccam pacchā kātabbam karaṇīyam khuddakam vā kiccam
translated: as he has for seeing the Teacher and hearing the Dhamma. Kiccakaraṇīyehīti : here kicca is what must be done by all means, and karaṇīya is what can be done if it is possible;

original: mahantaṃ karaṇīyaṃ. Byāvaṭoti ussukko. Evāhanti evaṃ iminā pakārena ahaṃ nāsakkhiṃ
analyzed: mahantam karaṇīyam byāvaṭoti ussukkaḥ eva aham ti evam iminā pakārena aham na asakkhim
translated: or else kicca is what must be done first, and karaṇīya is what can be done afterwards; or else kicca is a small matter, and karaṇīya is a big matter. Byāvaṭo: eager. Evāhaṃ: in this way, in this manner, I was unable to come;

original: upasaṅkamituṃ, na agāravādināti adhippāyo.
analyzed: upasaṅkamitum na agāra vādinā ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: I am not disrespectful, is the meaning.

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti dullabhe buddhuppāde manussattalābhe ca sattānaṃ sakiñcanabhāvena
analyzed: etam attham viditvā ati dullabhe buddhuppāde manussatta lābhe ca sattānam sakiñcana bhāvena
translated: Having understood the meaning of this,

original: kiccapasutatāya kusalantarāyo hoti, na akiñcanassāti etamatthaṃ sabbākārato viditvā.
analyzed: kicca pasuta tāya kusala antarāyaḥ hoti na akiñcanassa ati etam attham sabba ākārataḥ viditvā
translated: Having understood in all aspects the meaning of this, namely, that for beings who have not got rid of their belongings there is an obstacle to the profitable because of their being occupied with the business of their belongings, which is difficult to overcome, since the arising of Buddhas and the gaining of the human state are difficult to come by,

original: Imaṃ udānanti tadatthaparidīpanameva imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.🔽Tattha sukhaṃ vata tassa na hoti kiñcīti yassa puggalassa kiñci rūpādīsu ekavatthumpi
analyzed: imam udānan ti tad attha paridīpanam eva imam udānam udānesi  tattha sukham vata tassa na hoti kiñci iti yassa puggalassa kiñci rūpa ādīsu eka vatthum pi
translated: he uttered this exalted utterance.

original: “mameta”nti taṇhāya pariggahitabhāvena na hoti natthi na vijjati, sukhaṃ vata tassa
analyzed: mama etat ti taṇhāya pariggahita bhāvena na hoti natthi na vijjati sukham vata tassa
translated: Herein, he has no belongings at all, bliss indeed: for the person who has no belongings at all, who has not got anything at all, such as material form, etc., as ‘mine’ by appropriation through craving,

original: puggalassa, aho sukhamevāti attho. “Na hosī”tipi pāṭho, tassa atītakālavasena attho
analyzed: puggalassa aho sukham eva iti atthaḥ na hosi iti pi pāṭho tassa atīta kāla vasena attho
translated: he has no belongings, bliss indeed. The meaning is that he has bliss indeed. The reading ‘na hosī’ is also allowable, and its meaning should be understood as the past tense of the verb ‘hoti’.

original: veditabbo. Keci pana na hoti kiñcīti padassa “rāgādikiñcanaṃ yassa na hotī”ti atthaṃ🔽vaṇṇenti, taṃ na sundaraṃ pariggahadhammavasena desanāya āgatattā. Rāgādikiñcananti
analyzed: veditabbo keci pana na hoti kiñci iti padassa rāga ādi kiñcanam yassa na hoti iti attham 🔽vaṇṇenti tam na sundaram pariggaha dhamma vasena desanāya āgata ttā rāga ādi kiñcana nti
translated: But some explain the words ‘na hoti kiñci’ as meaning ‘he has no belongings such as greed, etc.’,🔽which is not good because the teaching is given in terms of the state of appropriation.

original: pariggahetabbassāpi saṅgahe sati yuttameva vuttaṃ siyā atha vā yassa puggalassa kiñci
analyzed: pariggahetabbassa api saṅgahe sati yuttam eva vuttam siyā atha vā yassa puggalassa kiñci
translated: Or else, in the case of a person in whom there is no attachment to anything,

original: appampi kiñcanaṃ palibodhajātaṃ rāgādikiñcanābhāvato eva na hoti, taṃ tassa akiñcanattaṃ
analyzed: appam pi kiñcanam palibodha jātam rāga ādi kiñcana abhāvataḥ eva na hoti tam tassa akiñcanattam
translated: not even the slightest, because of the absence of attachment to sense desires, etc., his being without attachment🔽is a “breeze” because it is a condition for happiness. The meaning is: “Oh, what a happiness!”

original: sukhassa paccayabhāvato sukhaṃ vataṃ, aho sukhanti attho. Kassa pana na hoti kiñcananti
analyzed: sukhassa paccaya bhāvato sukham vatam aho sukhanti attho kassa pana na hoti kiñcananti
translated: But whose is this being without attachment?

original: ce, āha “saṅkhātadhammassa bahussutassā”ti. Yo catūhipi maggasaṅkhāhi soḷasakiccanipphattiyā
analyzed: ce āha saṅkhāta dhammassa bahu ssutassa ati yaḥ catūhi pi magga saṅkhāhi soḷasa kicca nipphattiyā
translated: The Master said, “The one who has understood the Dhamma and is learned.” The one who has understood the Dhamma is the one who has done what was to be done by means of the four paths and the sixteenfold performance of the task.

original: saṅkhātadhammo katakicco, tato eva paṭivedhabāhusaccena bahussuto, tassa.
analyzed: saṅkhāta dhammaḥ kata kiccaḥ tatas eva paṭivedha bāhusaccena bahu ssutaḥ tassa
translated: And because of the abundance of his penetration, he is learned.

original: Iti bhagavā akiñcanabhāve ānisaṃsaṃ dassetvā sakiñcanabhāve ādīnavaṃ dassetuṃ “sakiñcanaṃ🔽passā”tiādimāha. Tassattho – rāgādikiñcanānaṃ āmisakiñcanānañca atthitāya sakiñcanaṃ,
analyzed: iti bhagavā akiñcana bhāve ānisaṃsam dassetvā sakiñcana bhāve ādīnavam dassetum sakiñcanam  passa iti ādim āha tassa atthaḥ rāga ādi kiñcanānam āmisa kiñcanānam ca atthitāya sa kiñcanam
translated: Having thus shown the benefit in being without attachment, the Master said, “The one who has attachment,” etc., in order to show the danger in having attachment.🔽The meaning is: because of the existence of attachment to sense desires, etc., and attachment to material things, he has attachment.

original: sakiñcanattā eva aladdhānañca laddhānañca kāmānaṃ pariyesanārakkhaṇahetu kiccakaraṇīyavasena
analyzed: eva a laddhānam ca laddhānam ca kāmānam pariyesanā rakkhaṇa hetu kicca karaṇīya vasena
translated: Because of having attachment, he is occupied with the pursuit and protection of sense desires, both those he has not yet obtained and those he has obtained, and with the performance of his duties.

original: “ahaṃ mamā”ti gahaṇavasena ca vihaññamānaṃ vighātaṃ āpajjamānaṃ passāti dhammasaṃvegappatto
analyzed: aham mama ati gahaṇa vasena ca vihaññamānam vighātam āpajjamānam passāti dhamma saṃvega patto
translated: He sees that it is harassed, that it is afflicted, by the assumption “This is mine, this is I, this is my self.”

original: satthā attano cittaṃ vadati. Jano janasmiṃ paṭibandharūpoti sayaṃ añño jano samāno
analyzed: satthā attano cittam vadati janaḥ janasmim paṭibandha rūpaḥ ti sayam aññaḥ jano samāno
translated: The Teacher speaks of his own mind. “People are bound to people by the nature of their relationship”:

original: aññasmiṃ jane “ahaṃ imassa, mama aya”nti taṇhāvasena paṭibandhasabhāvo hutvā vihaññati
analyzed: aññasmin jane aham imassa mama ayanti taṇhā vasena paṭibandha sabhāvaḥ hutvā vihaññati
translated: one person, being another person, is bound to another person by the nature of his relationship through craving, thinking “I am his, he is mine.” He is harassed, he is afflicted.

original: vighātaṃ āpajjati. “Paṭibaddhacitto”tipi pāṭho. Ayañca attho –
analyzed: vighātam āpajjati paṭibaddha citta itipi pāṭhaḥ ayam ca atthaḥ
translated: The reading is also “paṭibaddhacitto.” The meaning is this:

original: “Puttā matthi dhanammatthi, iti bālo vihaññati;
analyzed: puttāḥ matthi dhanammatthi iti bālaḥ vihaññati
translated: “The fool is harassed by the thought, ‘I have sons, I have wealth.’

original: Attā hi attano natthi, kuto puttā kuto dhana”nti. –
analyzed: attā hi attanaḥ natthi kutas puttā kutas dhananti
translated: For there is no self that is one’s own; how can there be sons or wealth?”

original: Ādīhi suttapadehi dīpetabboti.
analyzed: ādīhi sutta padehi dīpetabbaḥ ti
translated: This is the meaning that should be illustrated by the sutta passages beginning with the words “The fool is harassed.”

original: Pañcamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pañcama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the fifth sutta is ended.

original: 6. Gabbhinīsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: gabbhinī sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the sixth sutta

original: 16. Chaṭṭhe aññatarassa paribbājakassāti ekassa kuṭumbikassa paribbājakassa. Daharāti
analyzed: chaṭṭhe aññatarassa paribbājakassa ati ekassa kuṭumbikassa paribbājakassa dahara ati
translated: In the sixth sutta, a certain wanderer: a certain householder wanderer. Young:

original: taruṇī. Māṇavikāti brāhmaṇadhītāya vohāro. Pajāpatīti bhariyā. Gabbhinīti āpannasattā.
analyzed: taruṇī māṇavikā ati brāhmaṇa dhītāya vohāro pajāpatī iti bhariyā gabbhinī iti āpannasattā
translated: tender. Maiden: a term for the daughter of a brahmin. Wife: a term for a woman who is one’s own. Pregnant: one who has conceived.

original: Upavijaññāti ajja suveti paccupaṭṭhitavijāyanakālā hotīti sambandho. So kira brāhmaṇajātiko
analyzed: upavijaññā ati ajja suva iti paccupaṭṭhita vijāyana kālā hoti iti sambandho saḥ kira brāhmaṇa jātiko
translated: ‘To be delivered’: the time for delivery has arrived today. The connection is this. He was of brahmin caste, it seems.

original: sabhariyo vādapatthassame ṭhito, tena naṃ sapajāpatikaṃ paribbājakavohārena samudācaranti.
analyzed: sa bhariyaḥ vāda patthassame ṭhitaḥ tena nam sa pajāpatikam paribbājaka vohārena samudācaranti
translated: He was standing in the place for the sick, so they addressed him and his wife by the terms ‘wanderer’ and ‘female wanderer’.

original: Bhariyā panassa brāhmaṇajātikattā brāhmaṇāti ālapati. Telanti tilatelaṃ. Telasīsena
analyzed: bhariyā panassa brāhmaṇa jāti kattā brāhmaṇa ati ālapati telanti tila telam tela sīsena
translated: But because his wife was of brahmin caste, he addressed her as ‘brahmin’. ‘Oil’: sesamum oil.

original: cettha yaṃ yaṃ vijātāya pasavadukkhappaṭikāratthaṃ icchitabbaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ sappiloṇādiṃ
analyzed: ca ittha yam yam vijātāya pasava dukkha ppaṭikāra attham icchitabbam tam sabbam sappi loṇa ādim
translated: Herein, whatever is required for the purpose of alleviating the pain of delivery, all that, such as ghee,

original: āharāti āṇāpeti. Yaṃ me vijātāya bhavissatīti yaṃ telādi mayhaṃ vijātāya bahinikkhantagabbhāya
analyzed: āharāti āṇāpa iti yam me vijātāya bhavissati iti yam mayham vijātāya bahi nikkhanta gabbhāya
translated: he orders to be brought. ‘What will be useful for me when I am delivered’: what will be useful for me when I have delivered and the child has come out,

original: upakārāya bhavissati. “Paribbājikāyā”tipi pāṭho. Kutoti kasmā ṭhānā, yato ñātikulā
analyzed: upakārāya bhavissati paribbājikāya atipi pāṭhaḥ kutas iti kasmā ṭhānā yatas ñāti kulā
translated: ‘The female wanderer’ is also a reading. ‘From where’: from what place, from my relatives’ place or from my friends’ place,

original: vā mittakulā vā telādiṃ āhareyyaṃ, taṃ ṭhānaṃ me natthīti adhippāyo. Telaṃ āharāmīti
analyzed: vā mitta kulā vā tela ādim āhareyyam tam ṭhānam me natthi iti adhippāyo telam āharāmi iti
translated: where I could get oil, etc., there is no such place for me. This is the meaning. ‘I will bring the oil’

original: vattamānasamīpatāya vattamānaṃ katvā vuttaṃ, telaṃ āharissāmīti attho. Samaṇassa
analyzed: vattamāna samīpa tāya vattamānam katvā vuttam telam āharissāmi iti attho samaṇassa
translated: is said by making the present tense out of the future tense because of proximity to the present. The meaning is: I will bring the oil. ‘The recluse’s’

original: vā brāhmaṇassa vā sappissa vā telassa vāti ca samuccayattho vā-saddo “aggito vā udakato🔽vā mithubhedā vā”tiādīsu viya. Sappissa vā telassa vāti paccatte sāmivacanaṃ, sappi🔽ca telañca yāvadatthaṃ pātuṃ pivituṃ dīyatīti attho. Apare pana “sappissa vā telassa
analyzed: vā brāhmaṇassa vā sappissa vā telassa vā ati ca samuccaya tthaḥ vā saddaḥ aggitaḥ vā udakataḥ  vā mithu bhedāḥ vāti ādīsu viya sappissa vā telassa vā ati paccatte sāmi vacanam sappi  ca telam ca yāvadattham pātum pivitum dīyati iti atthaḥ apare pana sappissa vā telassa
translated: or ghee or oil, or: the word ‘or’ has the sense of ‘and’ here, as in such passages as ‘from fire or from water’ or ‘from the breaking of a limb’ or ‘from the breaking of a chariot-wheel’ . The words ‘ghee or oil’ are a genitive substantive in apposition,

original: vāti avayavasambandhe sāmivacanaṃ. Sappitelasamudāyassa hi avayavo idha yāvadatthasaddena
analyzed: vāti avayava sambandhe sāmi vacanam sappi tela samudāyassa hi avayavaḥ yāvadattha saddena
translated: meaning that as much ghee or oil as is required is given to drink. But others say that the words ‘ghee or oil’ are a genitive substantive in the sense of ‘part of’ . For what is meant is that what is called ‘as much as is required’ here is a part of the combination of ghee and oil.

original: vuccatī”ti vadanti. No nīharitunti bhājanena vā hatthena vā bahi netuṃ no dīyati,🔽ucchadditvānāti vamitvā, yaṃnūna dadeyyanti sambandho. Evaṃ kirassa ahosi “ahaṃ rañño🔽koṭṭhāgāraṃ gantvā telaṃ kaṇṭhamattaṃ pivitvā tāvadeva gharaṃ āgantvā ekasmiṃ bhājane
analyzed: vuccati iti vadanti naḥ nīharitum ti bhājanena vā hatthena vā bahi netum no dīyati  vamitvā yat nūna dadeyyanti sambandhaḥ evam kirassa ahosi aham rañño  koṭṭhāgāram gantvā telam kaṇṭha mattam pivitvā tāvat eva gharam āgantvā ekasmin bhājane
translated: Not to take out: it is not given to take out with a vessel or with the hand.

original: yathāpītaṃ vamitvā uddhanaṃ āropetvā pacissāmi, yaṃ pittasemhādimissitaṃ, taṃ agginā
analyzed: yathā apītam vamitvā uddhanam āropetvā pacissāmi yam pitta semha ādi missitam tam agginā
translated: Having vomited: the construction is ‘having vomited, thinking “What if I were to give it?” ’ . This is how it occurred to him: ‘I will go to the king’s storehouse, drink oil to the point of suffocation, and then come home. I will vomit it into a vessel, put it on the fire, and cook it. Then what is mixed with bile and phlegm will be burned up by the fire and what is pure will be left.

translated: because of the non-existence of the something consisting in lust, etc., and of the something consisting in possessions. But whose something is there not? He said:🔽The learned people,

original: 18. Aṭṭhame kuṇḍikāyanti evaṃnāmake koliyānaṃ nagare. Kuṇḍadhānavaneti tassa nagarassa avidūre kuṇḍadhānasaṅkhāte vane.
analyzed: aṭṭhame kuṇḍikāyanti evaṃnāmake koliyānam nagare kuṇḍadhāna vane iti tassa nagarassa avidūre kuṇḍadhāna saṅkhāte vane

analyzed: pubbe kira kuṇḍaḥ nāma ekaḥ yakkhaḥ tasmin vana saṇḍe vāsam kappesi kuṇḍadhāna missakena

analyzed: ca bali kammena tussati iti tassa tathā tattha balim upaharanti tena itam vana saṇḍam  kuṇḍadhāna vanam tu eva paññāyittha tassa avidūre ekā gāma patikā ahosi sā api tassa
translated: They brought him that offering there, and so that wood became known as

analyzed: yakkhassa āṇā pavatti ṭṭhāne niviṭṭha ttā tena iva paripālita ttā kuṇḍikā ati voharīyittha
translated: the Kuṇḍadhāna Wood. Not far from it there was a village headman’s residence. Because it was situated in the place where the yakkha’s orders were carried out and because it was protected by him, it was called Kuṇḍikā.

original: Aparabhāge tattha koliyarājāno nagaraṃ kāresuṃ, tampi purimavohārena kuṇḍikātveva
analyzed: aparabhāge tattha koliya rājānaḥ nagaram kāresum purima vohārena
translated: Later, the Koliyan kings built a town there. Because of the previous name it was called Kuṇḍikā.

analyzed: vuccati tasmin ca vana saṇḍe koliya rājānaḥ bhagavataḥ bhikkhu saṅghassa ca vasana tthāya
translated: And in that wood the Koliyan kings had a dwelling built for the Blessed One and the community of bhikkhus.

original: vihāraṃ patiṭṭhāpesuṃ, tampi kuṇḍadhānavanantveva paññāyittha. Atha bhagavā janapadacārikaṃ🔽caranto anukkamena taṃ vihāraṃ patvā tattha vihāsi. Tena vuttaṃ – “ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā
analyzed: vihāram patiṭṭhāpesum tam pi kuṇḍadhāna vanam tu eva paññāyittha atha bhagavā janapada cārikam  carantaḥ anukkamena tam vihāram patvā tattha vihāsi tena vuttam ekam samayam bhagavā
translated: and they built a dwelling-place there, which became known as the Kuṇḍadhāna Wood. Then the Blessed One,🔽wandering on tour among the provinces,

original: kuṇḍikāyaṃ viharati kuṇḍadhānavane”ti.🔽Suppavāsāti tassā upāsikāya nāmaṃ. Koliyadhītāti koliyarājaputtī. Sā hi bhagavato
analyzed: kuṇḍikā ayam viharati kuṇḍadhāna vana iti  suppavāsā ti tassāḥ upāsikāya nāmam koliyadhītā ati koliya rāja puttī sā hi bhagavataḥ
translated: after some time reached that dwelling-place and stayed there. Therefore it is said: “At one time the Blessed One was staying at Kuṇḍikā in the Kuṇḍadhāna Wood.”

original: aggupaṭṭhāyikā paṇītadāyikānaṃ sāvikānaṃ etadagge ṭhapitā sotāpannā ariyasāvikā.
analyzed: aggupaṭṭhāyikā paṇīta dāyikānam sāvikānam etad agge ṭhapitā sotāpannā ariya sāvikā
translated: Suppavāsā: this was the lay-follower’s name. Koliyadhītā: daughter of the Koliya king. For she was the Blessed One’s chief female supporter, and she was placed at the head of those who gave choice things. She was a stream-enterer, a noble disciple.

original: Yañhi kiñci bhagavato yuttarūpaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ bhesajjaṃ vā na tattha aññāhi

original: upaneti. Devasikañca aṭṭhasataṃ saṅghabhattapāṭipuggalikabhattāni deti. Yo koci bhikkhu

translated: Therefore it is said: “She carried him in her womb for seven years, and for seven days she was a woman in travail.”

analyzed: tattha satta vassāni iti satta saṃvaccharāni accanta saṃyoge ca idam upayoga vacanam  gabbham dhāreti iti gabbham vahati gabbhinī hoti iti attho satta aham mūḷha gabbhā ati satta
translated: Herein, for seven years means for seven years, a period of time reckoned as the maximum for carrying a child in the womb.🔽She carried him in her womb means she carried him in her womb, she was pregnant.

translated: For seven days she was a woman in travail means for seven days she was a woman with a difficult delivery. For when the child is fully developed and is about to be born, the winds that bring forth the child stir,🔽and the child turns to face the door of birth. Then the mother suffers great pain, and she cries out: “He is tearing my liver! He is tearing my heart! He is tearing my kidneys! He is tearing my lungs! He is pulling out my entrails! He is cutting my belly-lining! He is cutting my bowels! He is cutting my rectum!”

original: sañcāletvā parivattito uddhaṃpādo adhosiro hutvā yonimukhābhimukho hoti, evaṃ so
analyzed: sañcāletvā parivattitaḥ uddhaṃpādaḥ adhosiraḥ hutvā yonimukha abhimukhaḥ hoti evam saḥ

analyzed: pacchinditvā bārāṇasi nagaram parivāretu tatas dāru udaka bhatta parikkhayena kilantā  nagare manussāḥ vinā uva yuddhena rājānam gahetvā dassanti iti paṇṇam pesesi saḥ mātu

analyzed: sāsanam sutvā cattāri mahā dvārāni rakkhantaḥ satta vassāni nagaram uparundhi nagare

analyzed: rajjam aggahesi saḥ tadā satta vassāni nagara rundhana kamma nissandena etarahi satta  vassāni mātukucchi saṅkhātāya lohitakumbhiyāḥ vasi avasesataḥ pana satta aham naga rūpa rundhanena
translated: and took over the kingdom. For seven years he lived in a blood-filled womb,🔽because of the result of his laying siege to the city for seven years. For the remaining seven days he was in a state of confusion,

translated: But the great gift he gave at the feet of the Padumuttara Buddha, saying, “May I be foremost among those who receive gifts,”🔽and the gift of a thousand kahāpaṇa coins’ worth of treacle and curd he gave at the time of the Buddha Vipassī together with the nāgas,

original: sahassagghanikaṃ guḷadadhiṃ datvā patthanaṃ akāsi, tassānubhāvena lābhīnaṃ aggo jāto.
analyzed: sahassa gghanikam guḷa dadhim da tvā patthanam akāsi tassa anubhāvena lābhīnam aggaḥ jātaḥ

translated: And because she had sent him, saying, “Take the city by force, dear,” Suppavāsā had to carry the child in her womb for seven years

original: īdisaṃ dukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvediṃsu.

analyzed: mūḷhagabbha tāya uppanna dukkham sahati sā hi bhagavataḥ sambuddha bhāvam ariya saṅghassa

translated: She endures the pain that has arisen through stupidity. For she endures it by not giving attention to the pain that has arisen in herself, remembering the Enlightened One’s state of being a Perfect One, the Noble Sangha’s

original: amanasikaraṇeneva abhibhavitvā khamati. Tena vuttaṃ “tīhi vitakkehi adhivāsetī”ti.🔽Sammāsambuddho vatātiādi tesaṃ vitakkānaṃ pavattiākāradassanaṃ. Tassattho – yo bhagyavantatādīhi
analyzed: a manasikaraṇena iva abhibhavitvā khamati tena vuttam tīhi vitakkehi adhivāseti iti  sammāsambuddhaḥ vata atiādi tesam vitakkānam pavatti ākāra dassanam tassa atthaḥ yaḥ
translated: state of being one of good practice, and the state of being the escape from suffering that is Nibbāna. That is why it is said that she endures it with three thoughts.🔽The words “The Perfect One, they say, is fully enlightened” and so on show the mode of occurrence of these thoughts. Their meaning is this. The Blessed One, the Lord of the World, is fortunate, and so on.

original: kāraṇehi bhagavā lokanātho sammā aviparītaṃ sāmaṃ sayameva sabbadhamme aho vata buddho,🔽so bhagavā evarūpassa etarahi mayā anubhaviyamānassa aññassa ca evaṃjātikassa sakalassa
analyzed: kāraṇehi bhagavā lokanātho sammā aviparītam sāmam sayam eva sabba dhamme aho vata buddho  so bhagavā evarūpassa etarahi mayā anubhaviyamānassa aññassa ca evaṃjātikassa sakalassa
translated: He is fully enlightened, fully awakened, with respect to all things, rightly and by himself. He is the Blessed One.🔽He teaches the Dhamma for the purpose of abandoning all this suffering of the round, which is now being experienced by me and is of this kind, and for the purpose of the utter ending of all suffering of the round that is of this kind. He teaches the undeluded Dhamma,

original: vaṭṭadukkhassa pahānāya accantaṃ anuppādanirodhāya dhammaṃ katheti, aviparītadhammaṃ
analyzed: vaṭṭa dukkhassa pahānāya accantam anuppāda nirodhāya dhammam katheti aviparīta dhammaṃ
translated: the Dhamma that is not upside down.

original: katheti. Aviparītadhammadesanatāya hi satthu sammāsambodhisiddhi. Tassa yathāvuttaguṇassa
analyzed: kathā iti aviparīta dhamma desana tāya hi satthu sammāsambodhi siddhi tassa yathā vutta guṇassa
translated: for the Master’s success in the supreme enlightenment is due to his teaching the True Idea without distortion.🔽The Community of disciples of that Blessed One, who has the aforesaid qualities,

original: bhagavato dhammassavanante jātattā sīladiṭṭhisāmaññena saṃhatattā ca sāvakasaṅghoti
analyzed: bhagavataḥ dhammassavana ante jāta ttā sīla diṭṭhi sāmaññena saṃhata ttā ca sāvaka saṅghaḥ ti
translated: is called the Community of Disciples because it is united by virtue and view,🔽and because it has arisen in the presence of the True Idea.🔽How well gone is the Noble Community of disciples of the Blessed One,🔽which has entered upon the good way, the right way, the way of purity, the way of wisdom, the way of the holy life,

original: laddhanāmo aṭṭhaariyapuggalasamūho suppaṭipanno vata aho vata sammā paṭipanno, yo🔽ariyasaṅgho evarūpassa īdisassa vaṭṭadukkhassa pahānāya anuppādanirodhāya anivattipaṭipadaṃ
analyzed: laddha nāmaḥ aṭṭha ariya puggala samūho suppaṭipannaḥ vata aho vata sammā paṭipannaḥ yaḥ  ariya saṅghaḥ evarūpassa īdisassa vaṭṭa dukkhassa pahānāya an uppāda nirodhāya a nivatti paṭipadam
translated: that is to say, the four pairs of persons, the eight individual persons:🔽how well-set is the Community of disciples of the Blessed One, which has entered upon the good way, the right way, the way of purity, the way of wisdom, the way of the holy life,🔽that is to say, the four pairs of persons, the eight individual persons.

original: paṭipanno. Susukhaṃ vata aho vata suṭṭhu sukhaṃ sabbasaṅkhatanissaṭaṃ nibbānaṃ, yasmiṃ🔽nibbāne īdisaṃ vaṭṭadukkhaṃ na upalabbhatīti. Ettha ca paṭipajjamānāpi paṭipannā
analyzed: paṭipanno su sukham vata aho vata suṭṭhu sukham sabba saṅkhata nissaṭam nibbānam yasmin  nibbāne īdisam vaṭṭa dukkham na upalabbhati iti ettha ca paṭipajjamānā api paṭipannā
translated: How happy is the extinction that is not liable to the occurrence of such a round of suffering as this!🔽And here, although it is the practice that is being spoken of, it is nevertheless said to be ‘gone’ because the practice is not turned back.

original: icceva vuttā paṭipattiyā anivattibhāvato. Atha vā uppannasaddo viya paṭipannasaddo
analyzed: iccā iva vuttā paṭipattiyāḥ anivatti bhāvataḥ atha vā uppanna saddaḥ viya paṭipanna saddaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, the word ‘gone’ can be understood in the sense of occurring, like the word ‘arisen’ .

original: vattamānatthopi veditabbo. Tenevāha “sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno”ti.
analyzed: vattamāna tthaḥ api veditabbaḥ tena iva āha sotāpatti phala sacchikiriyāya paṭipannaḥ iti
translated: That is why it is said ‘he is practising for the realization of the fruit of stream-entry’ .

original: Sāmikanti attano patiṃ koliyarājaputtaṃ. Āmantesīti abhāsi. Mama vacanena bhagavato🔽pāde sirasā vandāhīti mayhaṃ vacanena cakkalakkhaṇappaṭimaṇḍitāni vikasitapadumasassirīkāni
analyzed: sāmikam ti attanaḥ patim koliya rāja puttam āmantesi iti abhāsi mama vacanena bhagavataḥ  pāde sirasā vandāhi iti mayham vacanena cakka lakkhaṇa ppaṭimaṇḍitāni vikasita paduma sassirīkāni
translated: Bhagavato: of the Blessed One.🔽Pāde sirasā vandāhi: worship with your head the feet of the Blessed One, which are adorned with the wheel-mark and are lovely like a fully-opened lotus.🔽The meaning is: do homage with your head.

original: bhagavato caraṇāni tava sirasā vandāhi, uttamaṅgena abhivādanaṃ karohīti attho. Appābādhantiādīsu
analyzed: bhagavataḥ caraṇāni tava sirasā vandāhi uttamaṅgena abhivādanam karohi iti attho appābādhanti ādīsu
translated: In the passage beginning with “without affliction”

original: ābādhoti visabhāgavedanā vuccati, yā ekadese uppajjitvāpi sakalasarīraṃ ayapaṭṭena
analyzed: ābādhaḥ ti visabhāga vedanā vuccati yā eka dese uppajjitvā api sakala sarīram
translated: affliction is said to be an unpleasant feeling that arises in one place and yet seems to seize the whole body as if it were bound with an iron band.🔽A disease that makes life difficult is a calamity.

original: ābandhitvā viya gaṇhati. Ātaṅkoti kicchajīvitakaro rogo. Atha vā yāpetabbarogo ātaṅko,
analyzed: ābandhitvā gaṇhati ātaṅkoti kiccha jīvita karaḥ rogaḥ atha vā yāpetabba rogo ātaṅko
translated: Or a disease that is to be cured is a calamity,🔽the other is an affliction. A slight disease is a calamity, a severe one an affliction.

original: itaro ābādho. Khuddako vā rogo ātaṅko, balavā ābādho. Keci pana “ajjhattasamuṭṭhāno
analyzed: itaraḥ ābādhaḥ khuddakaḥ vā rogaḥ ātaṅkaḥ balavā ābādhaḥ keci pana ajjhatta samuṭṭhāno
translated: But some say that an affliction is an internal disease,🔽a calamity an external one.

original: ābādho, bahiddhāsamuṭṭhāno ātaṅko”ti vadanti. Tadubhayassāpi abhāvaṃ pucchāti vadati.
analyzed: ābādhaḥ bahiddhā samuṭṭhānaḥ ātaṅko iti vadanti tad ubhayassa api abhāvam vadati
translated: She says that she asks about the absence of both of these.

original: Gilānasseva ca uṭṭhānaṃ nāma garukaṃ hoti, kāye balaṃ na hoti, tasmā niggelaññatāya
analyzed: gilānassa iva ca uṭṭhānam nāma garukam hoti kāye balam na hoti tasmā niggelañña tāya
translated: And it is a serious matter for one who is sick to get up, the body has no strength, therefore

original: lahuparivattisaṅkhātaṃ kāyassa lahuṭṭhānaṃ sarīrabalañca pucchāti vadati. Phāsuvihāranti
analyzed: lahu parivatti saṅkhātam kāyassa lahu ṭṭhānam sarīra balañca pucchāti vadati phāsu vihāranti
translated: He asks about the lightness of the body, that is, the quickness of rising up, and the strength of the body. He asks about the easeful living,

original: ṭhānanisinnagamanasayanasaṅkhātesu catūsu iriyāpathesu sukhavihārañca pucchāti vadati.
analyzed: ṭhāna nisinna gamana sayana saṅkhātesu catūsu iriyāpathesu sukha vihārañca vadati
translated: that is, the pleasant living in the four postures of the body, standing, sitting, walking, and lying down.

original: Athassa pucchitabbākāraṃ dassentī “suppavāsā, bhante”tiādimāha. Evañca vadehīti idāni
analyzed: atha assa pucchitabba ākāram dassentī suppavāsā bhante tiādim āha evam ca vadehi iti idāni
translated: Then, showing the way in which she should be asked, she says, “Venerable sir, Suppavāsā.” Thus speak,

original: vattabbākāraṃ nidasseti.
analyzed: vattabba ākāram nidasseti
translated: showing the way in which she should speak.

original: Paramanti vacanasampaṭicchanaṃ. Tena sādhu, bhadde, yathā vuttaṃ, tathā paṭipajjāmīti
analyzed: paraman ti vacana sampaṭicchanam tena sādhu bhadde yathā vuttam tathā paṭipajjāmi iti
translated: “To her” is the acceptance of the message. By that she shows: “Good, Bhaddā, I will act as you have said.”

original: dasseti. Koliyaputtoti suppavāsāya sāmiko koliyarājaputto. Sukhinī hotūti sadevake
analyzed: dasseti koliya putto ti suppavāsāya sāmiko koliya rāja putto sukhinī hotu iti sa devake
translated: The Koliyan son is Suppavāsā’s husband, the Koliyan prince. “May she be happy” means

original: loke aggadakkhiṇeyyo satthā suppavāsāya pesitavandanaṃ sampaṭicchitvā tadanantaraṃ
analyzed: loke agga dakkhiṇeyyaḥ satthā suppavāsāya pesita vandanam sampaṭicchitvā tad anantaram
translated: in the world with its gods. The Teacher, who is worthy of the highest offerings in the world with its gods, having accepted the salutation sent by Suppavāsā,

original: attano mettāvihārasaṃsūcakaṃ buddhāciṇṇaṃ sukhūpasaṃhāraṃ tassā sāmaññato pakāsetvā
analyzed: attanaḥ mettā vihāra saṃsūcakam buddha āciṇṇam sukhu upasaṃhāram tassā sāmaññato pakāsetvā
translated: after that, showing the common practice of the Buddhas, which is the indication of his dwelling in loving-kindness, he manifested the bringing of happiness to her.

original: puna tassā puttassa ca gabbhavipattimūlakadukkhuppattipaṭikkhepamukhena sukhūpasaṃhāraṃ
analyzed: puna tassā puttassa ca gabbha vipatti mūlaka dukkha uppatti paṭikkhepa mukhena sukhu upasaṃhāram
translated: and again, the bringing of happiness to the son and to her, by way of the prevention of the suffering that would have arisen from the loss of the child in the womb,

original: nidassento “sukhinī…pe… arogā, arogaṃ puttaṃ vijāyatū”ti āha.
analyzed: nidassentaḥ sukhinī pe arogā arogam puttam vijāyatu iti āha
translated: and then, showing her the means of obtaining happiness by preventing the suffering that would have arisen from the loss of her child, he said, “May she be happy … May she give birth to a healthy child.”

original: Saha vacanāti bhagavato vacanena saheva. Yasmiṃ kāle bhagavā tathā avoca, tasmiṃyeva
analyzed: saha bhagavataḥ vacanena saha iva yasmin kāle bhagavā tathā avoca tasmin yā iva
translated: “Together with his words”: together with the Blessed One’s words. At the very moment when the Blessed One spoke thus,

original: kāle tampi kammaṃ parikkhayaṃ agamāsi. Tassa parikkhīṇabhāvaṃ oloketvā satthā tathā🔽abhāsi. Apare pana vadanti – sace tathā satthā nācikkhissā, tato parampi kiñci kālaṃ
analyzed: kāle tam pi kammam parikkhayam agamāsi tassa parikkhīṇa bhāvam oloketvā satthā tathā  abhāsi apare pana vadanti sace tathā satthā na ācikkhissā tato param pi kiñci kālam
translated: that deed of hers was exhausted. Seeing that it was exhausted, the Teacher spoke thus.

original: tassā taṃ dukkhaṃ anubandhissā. Yasmā pana bhagavatā “sukhinī arogā arogañca puttaṃ
analyzed: tassā tam dukkham yasmā pana bhagavatā sukhinī arogā arogam ca puttam
translated: But others say: “If the Teacher had not predicted thus, her suffering would have continued for some time more. But because the Blessed One said, ‘May she be happy … May she give birth to a healthy child,’

original: vijāyatū”ti vuttaṃ, tasmā tassa vacanasamakālameva so gabbho byākulabhāvaṃ vijahitvā
analyzed: vijāyatu iti vuttam tasmā tassa vacana sama kālam eva saḥ gabbhaḥ byākula bhāvam vijahitvā
translated: therefore at the very moment of his words, that embryo, abandoning its abnormal state,

original: sukheneva bahi nikkhami, evaṃ tesaṃ mātāputtānaṃ sotthi ahosi. Acinteyyo hi buddhānaṃ
analyzed: sukhena iva bahi nikkhami evam tesam mātā puttānam sotthi ahosi acinteyyaḥ hi buddhānam
translated: came out easily, and thus the mother and child were saved. For the Buddhas’

original: buddhānubhāvo. Yathā hi paṭācārāya piyavippayogasambhūtena sokena ummādaṃ patvā –
analyzed: buddha anubhāvaḥ yathā hi paṭa ācārāya piya vippayoga sambhūtena sokena ummādam patvā
translated: It is the Buddha’s power. For just as when Patācārā, having gone mad through grief arising from separation from her dear ones,

original: “Ubho puttā kālakatā, panthe mayhaṃ patī mato;
analyzed: ubho puttā kālakatā panthe mayham patī mato
translated: “Both my children are dead, and on the road my husband died;

original: Mātā pitā ca bhātā ca, ekacitakamhi jhāyare”ti. –
analyzed: mātā pitā ca bhātā ca
translated: Mother, father, and brother, they are burning on one pyre”

original: Vatvā jātarūpeneva carantiyā “satiṃ paṭilabhāhi bhaginī”ti bhagavato vacanasamanantarameva🔽ummādo vūpasami, tathā suppiyāpi upāsikā attanāva attano ūruyaṃ katena mahāvaṇena
analyzed: vatvā jātarūpena iva carantiyā satim paṭilabhāhi bhagini iti bhagavataḥ vacana samanantaram eva  tathā suppiyā api upāsikā katena mahā vaṇena
translated: and having spoken thus, she was wandering about as if she were made of gold, the Blessed One, saying “Sister, regain your mindfulness,”🔽immediately after his words her madness was allayed. So too, the laywoman Suppiyā, unable to heal a great wound that she had made in her own thigh,

original: vuṭṭhātuṃ asakkontī sayanapiṭṭhe nipannā “āgantvā maṃ vandatū”ti vacanasamanantarameva
analyzed: vuṭṭhātum a sakkontī sayana piṭṭhe nipannā āgantvā mama vandatu iti vacana samanantaram eva
translated: lying on her bed, immediately after the words “Come and pay homage to me,”

original: vaṇe pākatike jāte sayameva gantvā bhagavantaṃ vandīti evamādīni vatthūni idha udāharitabbānīti.
analyzed: vaṇe pākatike jāte sayam eva gantvā bhagavantam vandi iti evamādīni vatthūni idha udāharitabbāni iti
translated: the wound having become normal, went herself and paid homage to the Blessed One. Such are the instances that should be cited here.

original: Evaṃ, bhanteti, bhante, yathā bhagavā saputtāya mātuyā arogabhāvaṃ āsīsanto āha –
analyzed: evam bhanta iti bhante yathā bhagavā sa puttāya mātuyāḥ aroga bhāvam āha
translated: “Yes, Lord,” the Blessed One, wishing to ensure the health of his mother together with her children, said:

original: “sukhinī arogā arogaṃ puttaṃ vijāyatū”ti, taṃ evameva. Na hi kadāci buddhānaṃ bhagavantānaṃ
analyzed: sukhinī arogā arogam puttam vijāyatu iti tam evam eva na hi kadācid buddhānam bhagavantānam
translated: “May she be happy and give birth to a healthy son,” so it was with her. For the word of the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones,

original: vacanassa aññathābhāvoti adhippāyo. Keci pana “evamatthū”ti vadanti, apare “hotū”ti🔽padassa atthaṃ ānetvā vaṇṇayanti. Abhinanditvāti karavīkarutamañjunā brahmassarena
analyzed: vacanassa aññathābhāvo ti adhippāyo keci pana evamatthu iti vadanti apare hotu uti  padassa attham ānetvā vaṇṇayanti abhinanditvā ati karavīka ruta mañjunā brahmassarena
translated: never fails. This is the intention. But some say “evamatthū” (thus it is) and others,🔽interpreting the meaning of the word hotu (may it be so), explain it.🔽Having rejoiced: having rejoiced with a face turned towards the word spoken by the Blessed One with a sweet voice like the sound of a karavīka bird,

original: bhagavatā vuccamāne tasmiṃ vacane pītisomanassapaṭilābhato abhimukhabhāvena nanditvā.
analyzed: bhagavatā vuccamāne tasmin vacane pīti somanassa paṭilābhataḥ abhimukha bhāvena nanditvā
translated: having obtained joy and happiness.

original: Anumoditvāti tato pacchāpi sammodanaṃ uppādetvā, cittena vā abhinanditvā vācāya anumoditvā,
analyzed: anumoditvā ti tatas pacchā api sammodanam uppādetvā cittena vā abhinanditvā vācāya anumoditvā
translated: Having approved: having given rise to approval afterwards, having rejoiced with the mind, having approved with speech,

original: vacanasampattiyā vā abhinanditvā atthasampattiyā anumoditvā. Sakaṃ gharaṃ paccāyāsīti
analyzed: vacana sampattiyā vā abhinanditvā attha sampattiyā anumoditvā sakam gharam paccāyāsi iti
translated: having rejoiced with the excellence of the words, having approved with the excellence of the meaning. She returned to her own house:🔽she went back to her own house. But those who read “yena sakaṃ ghara” (by which her own house), for them, although the words ya, ta, and sa

original: attano gharaṃ paṭigacchi. Ye pana “yena sakaṃ ghara”nti paṭhanti, tesaṃ yadipi ya-ta-saddānaṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ gharam paṭigacchi ye pana yena sakam gharanti paṭhanti tesam yadi pi yata saddānam
translated: are synonyms,

original: sambandhabhāvato “tenā”ti padaṃ vuttameva hoti, tathāpi “paṭiyāyitvā”ti pāṭhaseso yojetabbo hoti.🔽Vijātanti pajātaṃ, pasutanti attho. Acchariyanti andhassa pabbatārohanaṃ viya niccaṃ🔽na hotīti acchariyaṃ, ayaṃ tāva saddanayo. Aṭṭhakathāsu pana “accharāyoggaṃ acchariya”nti🔽vuttaṃ, accharaṃ paharituṃ yuttanti attho. Vatāti sambhāvane, aho acchariyanti attho.
analyzed: sambandha bhāvataḥ tena iti padam vuttam eva hoti tathā api paṭiyāyi tvā iti pāṭha sesaḥ yojetabbaḥ hoti  vijātanti pajātam pasutanti attho acchariyanti andhassa pabbata ārohanam viya niccam  na hoti iti acchariyam ayam tāva sadda nayaḥ aṭṭhakathāsu pana accharāyoggam acchariyanti  vuttam accharam paharitum yuttanti atthaḥ vata ati sambhāvane aho acchariyam ti atthaḥ
translated: “By him” is said because of the connection. Still, the reading “having prepared” should be construed.

original: Bhoti dhammālapanaṃ. Abhūtapubbaṃ bhūtanti abbhutaṃ.🔽Tathāgatassāti aṭṭhahi kāraṇehi bhagavā tathāgato – tathā āgatoti tathāgato, tathā🔽gatoti tathāgato, tathalakkhaṇaṃ āgatoti tathāgato, tathadhamme yāthāvato abhisambuddhoti
analyzed: bhoti dhamma ālapanam abhūta pubbam bhūtanti abbhutam  tathāgatassa ati aṭṭhahi kāraṇehi bhagavā tathāgato tathā āgataḥ iti tathāgataḥ tathā  gataḥ ti tathāgataḥ tatha lakkhaṇam āgataḥ iti tathāgataḥ tatha dhamme yāthāvataḥ abhisambuddhaḥ ti
translated: “Wonderful” is what is born, what has come into being, what has been produced. It is not always so, like a blind man’s climbing a mountain. This is the word-meaning. But in the commentaries it is said: “Wonderful is what is fit for a shout of ‘Bravo!’” The meaning is: it is fit for a shout of “Bravo!” to be given. “Marvelous” is in the sense of respect. The meaning is: “Oh, how wonderful!”🔽“Never before” is what has not been before. “Happened” is what has come to be.

original: tathāgato, tathadassitāya tathāgato, tathavāditāya tathāgato, tathākāritāya tathāgato,
analyzed: tathāgato tatha dassitāya tathāgato tatha vāditāya tathāgato tathā kāritāya tathāgato
translated: “Tathāgata”: the Blessed One is a Tathāgata for eight reasons: he has gone thus ; he has come thus ; he has arrived at the state of suchness ; he has realized suchness in accordance with actuality; he has seen suchness; he has proclaimed suchness; he has shown suchness; he has revealed suchness.

original: abhibhavanaṭṭhena tathāgato.🔽Kathaṃ bhagavā tathā āgatoti tathāgato? Yathā sabbalokahitāya ussukkamāpannā purimakā
analyzed: abhibhavana ṭṭhena tathāgataḥ  katham bhagavā tathā āgataḥ ti tathāgataḥ yathā sabbaloka hitāya ussukkam āpannā purimakā
translated: He is the Tathāgata in the sense of overcoming.🔽How is he the Tathāgata in the sense of thus come? He has come thus, as the former Perfect Buddhas came,🔽striving for the welfare of the whole world. What is meant? He has come by the same eight-fold path by which those Blessed Ones came.

original: sammāsambuddhā āgatāti. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti? Yena abhinīhārena te bhagavanto āgatā, tena🔽aṭṭhaguṇasamannāgatena ayampi bhagavā āgato. Yathā ca te bhagavanto dānapāramiṃ pūretvā
analyzed: sammāsambuddhāḥ āgatā ti kim vuttam hoti yena abhinīhārena te bhagavantaḥ āgatā tena  aṭṭhaguṇa samannāgatena ayam pi bhagavā āgataḥ yathā ca te bhagavantaḥ dāna pāramim pūretvā
translated: And as those Blessed Ones came after fulfilling the ten perfections,

original: sīlanekkhammapaññāvīriyakhantisaccaadhiṭṭhānamettāupekkhāpāramīti imā dasa pāramiyo,
analyzed: sīla nekkhamma paññā vīriya khanti sacca adhiṭṭhāna mettā upekkhā pāramī ti imāḥ dasa pāramiyaḥ
translated: namely, the perfection of giving, of virtue, of renunciation, of wisdom, of energy, of patience, of truth, of determination, of loving kindness, and of equanimity,🔽and after fulfilling the ten proximate perfections, the ten ultimate perfections, and the ten perfections of purity, making thirty in all;

original: dasa upapāramiyo, dasa paramatthapāramiyoti samatiṃsa pāramiyo pūretvā pañca mahāpariccāge
analyzed: dasa upapāramiyaḥ dasa paramattha pāramiyaḥ ti pāramiyaḥ pūretvā pañca mahā pariccāge
translated: and after giving the four great gifts, namely, the gift of the country, the gift of the kingdom, the gift of the limbs, and the gift of the wife;🔽and after fulfilling the duties of a Buddha-candidate, such as the practice of austerities, the practice of the perfections, the practice of the special qualities of a Buddha, the practice of the truths, the practice of the bases of success, and so on;

original: pariccajitvā pubbayogapubbacariyadhammakkhānañātatthacariyādayo pūretvā buddhicariyāya
analyzed: pariccajitvā pubba yoga pubba cariya dhamma kkhāna ñāta ttha cariya ādayaḥ pūretvā buddhi cariyāya
translated: and after reaching the culmination of the practice of a Buddha;

original: koṭiṃ patvā āgatā, tathā ayampi bhagavā āgato. Yathā ca te bhagavanto cattāro satipaṭṭhāne…pe…
analyzed: koṭim patvā āgatā tathā ayam pi bhagavā āgataḥ yathā ca te bhagavanto cattāro
translated: so too has this Blessed One come. And as those Blessed Ones came after fulfilling the four foundations of mindfulness, the four right efforts, the four bases of success, the five spiritual faculties, the five spiritual powers, the seven factors of enlightenment, and the Noble Eightfold Path,

original: ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvetvā brūhetvā āgatā, tathā ayampi bhagavā āgato. Evaṃ
analyzed: ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāvetvā brūhetvā āgatā tathā ayam pi bhagavā āgataḥ evam
translated: and they came after developing and perfecting the Noble Eightfold Path, so too has this Blessed One come. Thus

original: tathā āgatoti tathāgato.🔽Kathaṃ tathā gatoti tathāgato? Yathā sampatijātā te bhagavanto samehi pādehi pathaviyaṃ
analyzed: tathā āgataḥ iti tathāgataḥ  katham tathā gataḥ iti tathāgataḥ yathā sampati jātā te bhagavantaḥ samehi pādehi pathaviyam
translated: he is the Tathāgata because he has come in the way he came.

original: patiṭṭhāya uttarābhimukhā sattapadavītihārena gatā, setacchatte dhāriyamāne sabbāva
analyzed: patiṭṭhāya uttara abhimukhā satta padavī tihārena gatā seta chatte dhāriyamāne
translated: How is he the Tathāgata because he has gone in the way he came? The Blessed Ones of the past, as soon as they were born, stood facing north, took seven steps, had a golden-hued body surveyed all the quarters with the elephant-like tread,

original: disā anuvilokesuṃ, āsabhiñca vācaṃ bhāsiṃsu loke attano jeṭṭhaseṭṭhabhāvaṃ pakāsentā,🔽tañca nesaṃ gamanaṃ tathaṃ ahosi avitathaṃ anekesaṃ visesādhigamānaṃ pubbanimittabhāvena,🔽tathā ayampi bhagavā gato, tañcassa gamanaṃ kathaṃ ahosi avitathaṃ tesaññeva visesādhigamānaṃ
analyzed: disāḥ āsabhiṃ ca vācam bhāsiṃsu loke attanaḥ jeṭṭha seṭṭha bhāvam pakāsentā  tat ca nesam gamanam tatham ahosi avitatham anekesam visesa adhigamānam pubba nimitta bhāvena  tathā ayam pi bhagavā gato tat ca ssa gamanam katham ahosi avitatham tesam eva visesa adhigamānam
translated: had a white parasol held over them, and uttered the words, “I am the chief in the world, I am the eldest in the world, I am the first in the world. This is my last birth. Now there is no renewal of being for me.”🔽And that going of theirs was in accordance with the way it should be, in accordance with the ancient tradition, as a sign of their future attainment of the various kinds of distinction.

original: pubbanimittabhāvena. Evaṃ tathā gatoti tathāgato.
analyzed: pubba nimitta bhāvena evam tathā gataḥ ti tathāgataḥ
translated: So too has this Blessed One gone, and that going of his was in accordance with the way it should be, in accordance with the ancient tradition, as a sign of his future attainment of the various kinds of distinction. Thus he is the Tathāgata because he has gone in the way he came.

original: Yathā vā te bhagavanto nekkhammena kāmacchandaṃ pahāya gatā, abyāpādena byāpādaṃ,
analyzed: yathā vā te bhagavantaḥ nekkhammena kāmacchandam pahāya gatāḥ a byāpādena byāpādam
translated: Or alternatively, the Blessed Ones of the past, by renouncing sense desires, went beyond sense desires; by renouncing malevolence, beyond malevolence; by renouncing stiffness and torpor, beyond stiffness and torpor; by renouncing worry and flurry, beyond worry and flurry; by renouncing doubt, beyond doubt;

original: ālokasaññāya thinamiddhaṃ, avikkhepena uddhaccakukkuccaṃ, dhammavavatthānena vicikicchaṃ
analyzed: āloka saññāya thinam iddham avikkhepena uddhacca kukkuccam dhamma vavatthānena vicikiccham
translated: He has gone by abandoning stiffness and torpor through perception of light, by abandoning agitation and worry through non-distraction, by abandoning uncertainty through defining of ideas,

original: pahāya gatā, ñāṇena avijjaṃ padāletvā, pāmojjena aratiṃ vinodetvā, aṭṭhasamāpattīhi
analyzed: pahāya gatāḥ ñāṇena avijjam padāletvā pāmojjena aratim vinodetvā aṭṭha samāpattīhi
translated: by breaking up ignorance through knowledge, by dispelling discontent through gladness, by abandoning each opposing state through the eight attainments,

original: aṭṭhārasahi mahāvipassanāhi catūhi ca ariyamaggehi taṃ taṃ paṭipakkhaṃ pahāya gatā,
analyzed: aṭṭhārasahi mahāvipassanāhi catūhi ca ariya maggehi tam tam paṭipakkham pahāya gatā
translated: through the eighteen principal kinds of insight and through the four paths.

original: evaṃ ayampi bhagavā gato. Evampi tathā gatoti tathāgato.
analyzed: evam ayam pi bhagavā gataḥ evam pi tathā gataḥ iti tathāgataḥ
translated: So this Blessed One has gone too. Thus he is the One Gone Thus.

original: Kathaṃ tathalakkhaṇaṃ āgatoti tathāgato? Pathavīdhātuyā kakkhaḷalakkhaṇaṃ, āpodhātuyā
analyzed: katham tathalakkhaṇam āgataḥ ti tathāgataḥ pathavī dhātuyā kakkhaḷa lakkhaṇam āpas dhātuyā
translated: How is it that he has come to the here and now of the specific characteristics? The specific characteristic of the earth element is its being a foundation;

original: paggharaṇalakkhaṇaṃ, tejodhātuyā uṇhattalakkhaṇaṃ, vāyodhātuyā vitthambhanalakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: paggharaṇa lakkhaṇam tejaḥ dhātuyāḥ uṇhatta lakkhaṇam vāyo dhātuyāḥ vitthambhana lakkhaṇam
translated: the specific characteristic of the water element is its being a cohesion; the specific characteristic of the fire element is its being a maturing; the specific characteristic of the air element is its being a distension;

original: ākāsadhātuyā asamphuṭṭhalakkhaṇaṃ, rūpassa ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ, vedanāya vedayitalakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: ākāsa dhātuyāḥ asamphuṭṭha lakkhaṇam rūpassa ruppana lakkhaṇam vedanāya vedayita lakkhaṇam
translated: the specific characteristic of the space element is its being an enclosure; the specific characteristic of material form is its being molested; the specific characteristic of feeling is its being felt;

original: saññāya sañjānanalakkhaṇaṃ, saṅkhārānaṃ abhisaṅkharaṇalakkhaṇaṃ, viññāṇassa vijānanalakkhaṇanti
analyzed: saññāya sañjānana lakkhaṇam saṅkhārānaṃ abhisaṅkharaṇa lakkhaṇam viññāṇassa vijānana lakkhaṇanti
translated: the specific characteristic of perception is its perceiving; the specific characteristic of formations is their forming; the specific characteristic of consciousness is its cognizing.

original: evaṃ pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ, dvādasannaṃ āyatanānaṃ, aṭṭhārasannaṃ dhātūnaṃ, bāvīsatiyā
analyzed: evam pañcannam khandhānam dvādasannam āyatanānam aṭṭhārasannam dhātūnam bāvīsatiyā
translated: Thus, in regard to the five aggregates, the twelve sense-spheres, the eighteen elements, the twenty-two faculties,

original: indriyānaṃ, catunnaṃ saccānaṃ, dvādasapadikassa paccayākārassa, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ,
analyzed: indriyānam catunnam saccānam dvādasa padikassa paccaya ākārassa catunnam sati paṭṭhānānam
translated: the four noble truths, the twelve modes of conditionality, the four foundations of mindfulness,

original: catunnaṃ sammappadhānānaṃ, catunnaṃ iddhipādānaṃ, pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ, pañcannaṃ
analyzed: catunnam sammappadhānānam catunnam iddhipādānam pañcannam indriyānam pañcannam
translated: the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties,

original: balānaṃ, sattannaṃ bojjhaṅgānaṃ, ariyassa aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa, sattannaṃ visuddhīnaṃ,
analyzed: balānam sattannam bojjhaṅgānam ariyassa aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa sattannam visuddhīnam
translated: the five powers, the seven factors of enlightenment, the noble eightfold path, the seven purities,

original: amatogadhassa nibbānassāti evaṃ tassa tassa dhammassa yaṃ sabhāvasarasalakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: amatogadhassa nibbānassa ati evam tassa tassa dhammassa yam sabhāva sarasa lakkhaṇam
translated: and the deathless Nibbāna, whatever is the individual essence, the true nature, the characteristic of each of these dhammas,

original: taṃ tathaṃ avitathaṃ anaññathaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ ñāṇagatiyā āgato avirajjhitvā patto adhigatoti
analyzed: tam tatham avitatham anaññatham lakkhaṇam ñāṇa gatiyā āgataḥ a virajjhitvā pattaḥ adhigataḥ ti
translated: he has come to that by way of knowledge, has attained it, has reached it, has penetrated it without clinging.

original: tathāgato. Evaṃ tathalakkhaṇaṃ āgatoti tathāgato.
analyzed: tathāgataḥ evam tatha lakkhaṇam āgataḥ ti tathāgataḥ
translated: Thus he is the Tathāgata because he has come to the true characteristics.

original: Kathaṃ tathadhamme yāthāvato abhisambuddhoti tathāgato? Tathadhammā nāma cattāri
analyzed: katham tathadhamme yāthāvataḥ abhisambuddhaḥ ti tathāgato tathadhammā nāma cattāri
translated: How is he the Tathāgata because he has fully awakened to things as they really are? Things as they really are are the four noble truths.

original: ariyasaccāni. Yathāha – “cattārimāni, bhikkhave, tathāni avitathāni anaññathāni.
analyzed: ariya saccāni yathā āha cattāri imāni bhikkhave tathāni avitathāni anaññathāni
translated: The four noble Truths. As it is said: “Bhikkhus, there are these four things that are real, not unreal, not otherwise,

original: Katamāni cattāri? Idaṃ dukkhanti, bhikkhave, tathametaṃ avitathametaṃ anaññathameta”nti
analyzed: katamāni cattāri idam dukkhanti bhikkhave tatham etam avitatham etam anaññatham etam ti
translated: What are the four? ‘This is suffering’ , bhikkhus, is real, not unreal, not otherwise;

original: vitthāro. Tāni ca bhagavā abhisambuddho, tasmā tathānaṃ abhisambuddhattā tathāgato.
analyzed: vitthāraḥ tāni ca bhagavā abhisambuddhaḥ tasmā tathānam abhisambuddha ttā tathāgataḥ
translated: the rest in detail. And the Blessed One has discovered these, thus he is the One who has Discovered what is Real .

original: Apica jarāmaraṇassa jātipaccayasambhūtasamudāgataṭṭho tatho avitatho anaññatho…pe…
analyzed: apica jarā maraṇassa jāti paccaya sambhūta samudāgata ṭṭho tathaḥ avitathaḥ anaññathā upe
translated: Furthermore, the meaning of the arising and occurrence of ageing-and-death, which has birth as its condition, is real, not unreal, not otherwise; … down to …

original: saṅkhārānaṃ avijjāpaccayasambhūtasamudāgataṭṭho tatho avitatho anaññatho, tathā avijjāya
analyzed: saṅkhārānaṃ avijjā paccaya sambhūta samudāgata ṭṭho tathaḥ avitathaḥ anaññathaḥ tathā avijjāya
translated: the meaning of the arising and occurrence of formations, which has ignorance as their condition, is real, not unreal, not otherwise. The meaning of ignorance

original: saṅkhārānaṃ paccayaṭṭho…pe... jātiyā jarāmaraṇassa paccayaṭṭho tatho avitatho anaññatho,🔽taṃ sabbaṃ bhagavā abhisambuddho, tasmāpi tathānaṃ abhisambuddhattā tathāgato. Abhisambuddhattho
analyzed: saṅkhārānam paccaya ṭṭho upe jātiyā jarā maraṇassa paccaya ṭṭho tathaḥ avitathaḥ anaññathaḥ  tam sabbam bhagavā abhisambuddhaḥ tasmā api tathānam abhisambuddha ttā tathāgataḥ abhisambuddha tthaḥ
translated: as condition for formations … down to … the meaning of birth as condition for ageing-and-death is real, not unreal, not otherwise.🔽The Blessed One has discovered all that, thus he is the One who has Discovered what is Real . For the word ‘gone’ has here the meaning of ‘discovered’ .

original: hi ettha gatasaddoti. Evaṃ tathadhamme yāthāvato abhisambuddhoti tathāgato.
analyzed: hi ettha gata saddo ti evam tatha dhamme yāthāvataḥ abhisambuddhaḥ ti tathāgataḥ
translated: So he is the One who has Gone in this way because he has discovered the real state of things as it is.

original: Kathaṃ tathadassitāya tathāgato? Yaṃ sadevake…pe… sadevamanussāya pajāya aparimāṇāsu
analyzed: katham tatha dassitāya tathāgataḥ yam sa deva kepe sa deva manussāya pajāya aparimāṇāsu
translated: How is he the Enlightened One because he has seen? He has seen the world with its devas, its Māras, and its Brahmās, this generation with its ascetics and brahmans, with its devas and humans, as it really is.

original: lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānaṃ sattānaṃ cakkhudvāre āpāthamāgacchantaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ nāma
analyzed: lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānam sattānam cakkhu dvāre āpātham āgacchantam rūpa ārammaṇam nāma
translated: How is he the Enlightened One because of seeing thus? There is the visible-data object that exists in the countless world-spheres of the countless world-systems, which is included in the visible-data base among the six external bases, and which comes into the eye’s focus of the countless beings in the countless world-spheres.🔽The Blessed One knows and sees that visible-data object in all its aspects.

original: atthi, taṃ bhagavā sabbākārato jānāti passati. Evaṃ jānatā passatā ca tena taṃ iṭṭhāniṭṭhādivasena
analyzed: atthi tam bhagavā sabba ākārataḥ jānāti passati evam jānatā passatā ca tena tam iṭṭha aniṭṭha ādi vasena
translated: And because he knows and sees it thus, it is “so” for him in the sense of what is desirable and undesirable, etc.,

original: vā diṭṭhasutamutaviññātesu labbhamānakapadavasena vā “katamaṃ taṃ rūpaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ,🔽yaṃ rūpaṃ catunnaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ upādāya vaṇṇanibhā sanidassanaṃ sappaṭighaṃ nīlaṃ
analyzed: vā diṭṭha suta muta viññātesu labbhamānaka pada vasena vā katamam tam rūpam rūpa āyatanam  yam rūpam catunnam mahābhūtānam upādāya vaṇṇa nibhā sa nidassanam sa paṭigham nīlam
translated: or in the sense of the terms that can be found among what is seen, heard, sensed, and cognized,

original: pītaka”ntiādinā nayena anekehi nāmehi terasahi vārehi dvipaññāsāya nayehi vibhajjamānaṃ
analyzed: pītakanti ādinā nayena anekehi nāmehi terasahi vārehi dvipaññāsāya nayehi vibhajjamānam
translated: and it is “so” for him in the sense of the various terms by which it is analyzed into thirteen sections and fifty-two modes, as follows:🔽“What, bhikkhus, is that visible-data base? It is this: the visible data called blue, which is derived from the four great primaries, is demonstrable, susceptible of resistance, and has blue colour, blue hue, blue lustre.🔽It is the same with the sound called ‘ear,’ the odour called ‘nose,’ the flavour called ‘tongue,’ the tangible called ‘body,’ and the mind-object called ‘mind.’🔽This is the visible-data base” .

original: tathameva hoti, vitathaṃ natthi. Esa nayo sotadvārādīsu āpāthamāgacchantesu saddādīsu.🔽Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: tatham eva hoti vitatham natthi esa nayo sota dvāra ādīsu āpātham āgacchantesu sadda ādīsu 🔽vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: The same method of explanation applies to the sound, etc., that come into focus in the ear, etc.

original: “Yaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevakassa lokassa…pe… sadevamanussāya diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ
analyzed: yam bhikkhave sa devakassa lokassape sa deva manussāya diṭṭham sutam mutam viññātam
translated: “Whatever is seen, heard, sensed, cognized,🔽reached, sought after, examined by the mind—

original: pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tamahaṃ jānāmi, tamahaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, taṃ
analyzed: pattam pariyesitam anuvicaritam manasā tam aham jānāmi tam aham abbhaññāsim tam
translated: that I know, that I have directly experienced,

original: tathāgatassa viditaṃ, taṃ tathāgato na upaṭṭhāsī”ti.
analyzed: tathāgatassa viditam tam tathāgataḥ na upaṭṭhāsi iti
translated: that I make known to you, that I reveal to you, that I make plain to you.”

original: Evaṃ tathadassitāya tathāgato. Tattha tathadassīatthe tathāgatoti padasambhavo veditabbo.
analyzed: evam tathā dassitāya tathāgato tattha tathadassīatthe tathāgato ti pada sambhavaḥ veditabbo
translated: Thus he is the Tathāgata because he has seen reality in such a way. The derivation of the word should be understood in this way: he is the Tathāgata because he is the seer of suchness, the seer of reality.

original: Kathaṃ tathavāditāya tathāgato? Yaṃ rattiṃ bhagavā anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho,
analyzed: katham tathavāditāya tathāgataḥ yam rattim bhagavā anuttaram sammāsambodhim abhisambuddhaḥ
translated: How is he the Tathāgata because he has spoken in such a way? On the night when the Exalted One attained supreme enlightenment,

original: yañca rattiṃ anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyi, etthantare pañcacattālīsavassaparimāṇakālaṃ
analyzed: yat ca rattim an upādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyi etthantare pañcacattālīsa vassa parimāṇa kālam
translated: and on the night when he attained final Nibbāna in the element of Nibbāna that has no remainder of clinging, during the forty-five years intervening,

original: yaṃ bhagavatā bhāsitaṃ lapitaṃ suttageyyādi, sabbaṃ taṃ parisuddhaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ rāgamadādinimmathanaṃ
analyzed: yam bhagavatā bhāsitam lapitam sutta geyya ādi sabbam tam parisuddham paripuṇṇam rāga mada ādi nimmathanam
translated: whatever the Exalted One spoke, said, or uttered—the suttas, songs, and so forth—all that was pure, complete, and unadulterated with passion, delusion, or the like.

original: ekasadisaṃ tathaṃ avitathaṃ. Tenāha –
analyzed: eka sadisam tatham avitatham tena āha
translated: It was all just so, not otherwise. Therefore it is said:

original: “Yañca, cunda, rattiṃ tathāgato anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambujjhati, yañca rattiṃ
analyzed: yañca cunda rattim tathāgataḥ anuttaram sammāsambodhim abhisambujjhati yañca rattim
translated: “Cunda, on the night when the Tathagata awakens to the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment and on the night when,

original: anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati, yaṃ etasmiṃ antare bhāsati lapati niddisati,
analyzed: an upādisesāya nibbāna dhātuyā parinibbāyati yam etasmin antare bhāsati lapati niddisati
translated: without grasping, he is totally unbound in the extinguishment element, whatever he speaks, says, or makes a statement with,

original: sabbaṃ taṃ tatheva hoti, no aññathā, tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccatī”ti.
analyzed: sabbam tam tathā iva hoti no aññathā tasmā tathāgataḥ iti vuccati iti
translated: all that is just so and not otherwise. Therefore he is called the Tathagata.”

original: Gadaattho ettha gatasaddo. Evaṃ tathavāditāya tathāgato.
analyzed: gada atthaḥ ettha gata saddo evam tathavāditāya tathāgataḥ
translated: The word gata here has the meaning of “gone.” Thus he is the Tathagata because of his true speech.

original: Apica āgadanaṃ āgado, vacananti attho. Tatho avitatho aviparīto āgado assāti dakārassa takāraṃ katvā tathāgatoti evamettha padasiddhi veditabbā.
analyzed: apica āgadanam āgadaḥ vacananti attho tatho avitatho aviparītaḥ āgadaḥ assa ati dakārassa takāram katvā tathāgataḥ iti evam ettha pada siddhi veditabbā
translated: Moreover, agata means “what has been said,” “utterance,” is the meaning. He has that, not otherwise, not wrongly, not in a distorted way. Thus the derivation of the word should be understood as tathā + agata = tathāgata.

original: Kathaṃ tathākāritāya tathāgato? Bhagavato hi vācāya kāyo anulometi, kāyassapi vācā,
analyzed: katham tathā kāritāya tathāgataḥ bhagavataḥ hi vācāya kāyaḥ kāyaḥ anulomā iti kāyaḥ api vācā
translated: How is he the Tathagata because of his true action? The Blessed One’s body conforms to his speech and his speech to his body.

original: tasmā yathāvādī tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī ca hoti. Evaṃbhūtassa cassa yathāvācā,
analyzed: tasmai yathāvādī tathākārī yathākārī tathāvādī ca hoti evaṃbhūtassa ca ssa yathāvācā
translated: Therefore he is one who acts as he speaks and speaks as he acts. And he is one who acts and speaks in accordance with the Dhamma.

original: kāyopi tathā gato pavattoti attho. Yathā ca kāyo, vācāpi tathā gatā pavattāti tathāgato. Tenāha –
analyzed: kāyaḥ api tathā gato pavattoti atthaḥ yathā ca kāyaḥ vācā api tathā gatā pavattā ati tathāgato tena āha
translated: and the body has gone thus, has occurred, is the meaning. And just as the body, so too has speech gone, has occurred, is the meaning. Thus he is the One Gone. Hence it is said:

original: “Yathāvādī, bhikkhave, tathāgato tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī. Iti yathāvādī tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī. Tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccatī”ti.
analyzed: yathāvādī bhikkhave tathāgataḥ tathākārī yathākārī tathāvādī iti yathāvādī tathākārī yathākārī tathāvādī tasmai tathāgataḥ iti vuccati iti
translated: “Bhikkhus, the Tathagata speaks only what is so ; he speaks only what is factual, for the sake of principle, for the sake of the Dhamma, for the sake of the discipline. Therefore he is called the Tathagata” .

original: Evaṃ tathākāritāya tathāgato.
analyzed: evam tathā kāritāya tathāgataḥ
translated: So he is the One Gone in the sense of having gone thus.

original: Kathaṃ abhibhavanaṭṭhena tathāgato? Yasmā upari bhavaggaṃ heṭṭhā avīciṃ pariyantaṃ🔽karitvā tiriyaṃ aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu sabbasatte abhibhavati sīlenapi samādhināpi🔽paññāyapi vimuttiyāpi vimuttiñāṇadassanenapi, na tassa tulā vā pamāṇaṃ vā atthi,
analyzed: katham abhibhavana ṭṭhena tathāgataḥ yasmai upari bhavaggam heṭṭhā avīcim pariyantam  karitvā tiriyam aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu sabba satte abhibhavati sīlena api samādhinā api  paññāya api vimuttiyā api vimutti ñāṇa dassanena api na tassa tulā vā pamāṇam vā atthi
translated: How is he the One Gone in the sense of having overcome ? Because he has overcome the world with its gods,

original: atha kho atulo appameyyo anuttaro devadevo sakkānaṃ atisakko, brahmānaṃ atibrahmā
analyzed: atha kho atulaḥ appameyyaḥ anuttaraḥ devadevaḥ sakkānam atisakkaḥ brahmānam atibrahmā
translated: with Mara, with Brahma, with the created beings, and with the brahmas, and he has overcome it by himself without a second,

original: sabbasattuttamo, tasmā tathāgato. Tenāha –
analyzed: sabba sattuttamaḥ tasmai tathāgataḥ tena āha
translated: therefore he is the One Gone in the sense of having overcome. Hence it is said:🔽“Bhikkhus, the Tathagata has gone beyond all and has no counterpart at all. Because he has known and seen this world—with its gods, with Mara, with Brahma, with created beings, and with the brahmas—🔽and this generation with its ascetics and brahmans, with its gods and men, as it is in reality, therefore he is the One Gone in the sense of having known and seen. Hence it is said:🔽“Bhikkhus, the Tathagata has known this world—with its gods, with Mara, with Brahma, with created beings, and with the brahmas—🔽and this generation with its ascetics and brahmans, with its gods and men, as it is in reality. Therefore he is called the Tathagata” .🔽So he is the One Gone in the sense of having known and seen.

original: “Sadevake, bhikkhave, loke…pe… sadevamanussāya tathāgato abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavatti, tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccatī”ti.
analyzed: sa devake bhikkhave lokepe sa deva manussāya tathāgataḥ an abhibhūtaḥ tasmā tathāgataḥ iti vuccati iti
translated: “Bhikkhus, in the world with its deities, Mara, and Brahma, among the race of recluses and brahmins, gods and men, the Tathagata is the victor, the unvanquished, the universal seer, the wielder of power. Therefore he is called the Tathagata.”

original: Tatrāyaṃ padasiddhi – agado viya agado, desanāvilāso ceva puññussayo ca. Tena so🔽mahānubhāvo bhisakko viya dibbāgadena sappe sabbaparappavādino sadevakañca lokaṃ
analyzed: tatra ayam agadaḥ viya agadaḥ desanā vilāso ca iva puññussayo ca tena so  mahā anubhāvaḥ bhisakkaḥ viya dibbāgadena sappe sabba para ppavādinaḥ sa devakam ca lokam
translated: Here is the word-commentary: “Agada” is like a medicine; “desanāvilāso” is the manifestation of the teaching; “puññussayo” is the basis of merit. By that

original: etassāti dakārassa takāraṃ katvā tathāgatoti veditabbo. Evaṃ abhibhavanaṭṭhena tathāgato.🔽Apica tathāya gatoti tathāgato, tathaṃ gatoti tathāgato. Tattha sakalalokaṃ tīraṇapariññāya
analyzed: etassa ati dakārassa takāram katvā tathāgataḥ iti veditabbaḥ evam abhibhavana ṭṭhena tathāgataḥ  apica tathāya gataḥ iti tathāgataḥ tatham gataḥ iti tathāgataḥ sakala lokam tīraṇa pariññāya
