original: Cārikaṃ caramānoti addhānagamanaṃ gacchanto. Cārikā ca nāmesā bhagavato duvidhā turitacārikā🔽aturitacārikāti. Tattha dūrepi bodhaneyyapuggalaṃ disvā tassa bodhanatthaṃ sahasā🔽gamanaṃ turitacārikā nāma, sā mahākassapapaccuggamanādīsu daṭṭhabbā. Yā pana gāmanigamarājadhānīpaṭipāṭiyā🔽devasikaṃ yojanaddhayojanavasena piṇḍapātacariyādīhi lokaṃ anuggaṇhanto gacchati,
analyzed: cārikam caramānāḥ ti addhānagamanam gacchantaḥ cārikā ca nāma īsā bhagavataḥ duvidhā turita cārikā  aturita cārikā ti tattha dūre pi bodhaneyya puggalam disvā tassa bodhana attham sahasā  gamanam turitacārikā nāma sā mahākassapa paccuggamana ādīsu daṭṭhabbā yā pana gāma nigama rājadhānī paṭipāṭiyā  devasikam yojana addha yojana vasena piṇḍapāta cariyā ādīhi lokam anuggaṇhantaḥ gacchati
translated: He was going on walking tour: he was going on a journey. And a walking tour is of two kinds for the Blessed One, namely,🔽a swift walking tour and a slow walking tour.🔽Herein, the swift walking tour is the Blessed One’s going all at once to a place where there are people to be tamed, in order to tame them, as on the occasions of the Great Kas-sapa’s going forth, etc.;

original: ayaṃ aturitacārikā nāma, ayameva idhādhippetā. Tadavasarīti tena avasari, taṃ vā🔽avasari, tattha avasari, pāvisīti attho.🔽Tatrāti tassaṃ. Sudanti nipātamattaṃ. Vesāliyanti tikkhattuṃ visālībhūtattā “vesālī”ti
analyzed: ayam aturitacārikā nāma ayam eva idha adhippetā tadavasarī iti tena tam vā  avasari tattha avasari pāvisi iti attho  tatra ati nipāta mattam vesāliyanti tikkhattum visālībhūta ttā vesālī iti
translated: but the slow walking tour is the Blessed One’s going by stages, day after day, a half-yojana or a yojana, in order to help the world, by means of the Going for alms, etc., in villages, towns, cities, and royal cities,🔽and that is what is intended here. He was going on a slow walking tour.🔽He was going to Vesālī: he was going to the city of the Licchavi princes, which was called Vesālī because it was extended three times ,

original: laddhanāme licchavirājūnaṃ nagare. Mahāvaneti mahāvanaṃ nāma sayaṃjātaṃ aropimaṃ
analyzed: laddhanāme nagare mahāvana iti mahāvanam nāma sayaṃjātam
translated: in the Great Wood: the Great Wood is a natural forest, not planted by man.

original: saparicchedaṃ mahantaṃ vanaṃ. Kapilavatthusāmantā pana mahāvanaṃ himavantena saha
analyzed: sa paricchedam mahantam vanam pana mahā vanam himavantena saha
translated: a great wood with a boundary. But the Great Wood near Kapilavatthu is not like that. It is connected with the Himalayas

original: ekābaddhaṃ aparicchedaṃ hutvā mahāsamuddaṃ āhacca ṭhitaṃ. Idaṃ tādisaṃ na hoti, saparicchedaṃ
analyzed: eka ābaddham a paricchedam hutvā mahā samuddaṃ āhacca ṭhitam idam tādisam na hoti sa paricchedam
translated: and it extends without a break to the ocean. It is not bounded.

original: mahantaṃ vananti mahāvanaṃ. Kūṭāgārasālāyanti tasmiṃ mahāvane bhagavantaṃ uddissa
analyzed: mahantam vananti mahā vanam kūṭāgāra sālāyanti tasmin mahā vane bhagavantam uddissa
translated: It is a great wood. It is a great wood. The pavilion with a peaked roof: in that Great Wood, in the monastery built for the Blessed One,

original: kate ārāme kūṭāgāraṃ anto katvā haṃsavaṭṭakacchannena katā sabbākārasampannā buddhassa
analyzed: kate ārāme kūṭāgāram antar katvā haṃsa vaṭṭaka channena katā sabba ākāra sampannā buddhassa
translated: the pavilion with a peaked roof built inside, covered with a thatch of lotus leaves, endowed with all the essentials,🔽the Perfumed Chamber of the Blessed One, is called the pavilion with a peaked roof. In that pavilion with a peaked roof.

original: bhagavato gandhakuṭi kūṭāgārasālā nāma, tassaṃ kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ. Vaggumudātīriyānanti🔽vaggumudātīravāsīnaṃ. Cetasā ceto paricca manasi karitvāti attano cittena tesaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: bhagavataḥ gandhakuṭi kūṭāgārasālā nāma tassam kūṭāgārasālāyam  vaggumudā tīra vāsīnam cetasā ceto paricca manasi karitvā ati attano cittena tesam cittam
translated: The dwellers on the banks of the Vaggumudā: the dwellers on the banks of the Vaggumudā River.

original: paricchijja manasi karitvā, cetopariyañāṇena vā sabbaññutaññāṇena vā tehi adhigatavisesaṃ jānitvāti attho.
analyzed: paricchijja manasi karitvā cetaḥ pariya ñāṇena vā sabbaññu ta ññāṇena vā tehi adhigata visesam jānitvā iti attho
translated: Having encompassed his mind with my mind: having encompassed their minds with my mind, having known the distinction they had attained by means of the knowledge of encompassing the minds of others or by means of the knowledge of omniscience.

original: Ālokajātā viyāti sañjātālokā viya. Itaraṃ tasseva vevacanaṃ, candasahassasūriyasahassehi
analyzed: āloka jātāḥ viyā ati sañjāta ālokāḥ viya itaram tassa iva vevacanam canda sahassa sūriya sahassehi
translated: “As if it were flooded with light”: as if it were flooded with light. The other phrase is a synonym for that. The meaning is: as if it were illuminated by a thousand moons and a thousand suns.

original: obhāsitā viyāti attho. Yasmā te yasojappamukhā pañcasatā bhikkhū sabbaso avijjandhakāravidhamanena🔽ālokabhūtā obhāsabhūtā hutvā viharanti, tasmā bhagavā tehi ṭhitadisāya “ālokajātā
analyzed: obhāsitāḥ viya ati atthaḥ yasmai te yasoja ppamukhā pañcasatā bhikkhū sabbasas  āloka bhūtāḥ obhāsa bhūtāḥ hutvā viharanti tasmai bhagavā ṭhita disāya āloka jātā
translated: Because those five hundred monks headed by Yasoja, by dispelling the entire darkness of ignorance,

original: viya me, ānanda, esā disā”tiādinā vaṇṇabhaṇanāpadesena te bhikkhū pasaṃsati. Tena
analyzed: viya me ānanda esā disā ti ādinā vaṇṇa bhaṇanā apadesena te bhikkhū pasaṃsati tena
translated: abide as if they were light, as if they were illumination. Therefore the Blessed One praises those monks by the expression of commendation, “To me, Ananda, this direction is as if it were flooded with light,” etc.

original: vuttaṃ – “yassaṃ disāyaṃ vaggumudātīriyā bhikkhū viharantī”ti. Appaṭikūlāti na paṭikūlā,
analyzed: vuttam disā ayam vaggumudātīriyāḥ bhikkhū viharanti iti appaṭikūlā ati na paṭikūlā
translated: Therefore it is said: “In whatever direction the monks who have crossed over to the far shore of the Vaggamudā River abide.”

original: manāpā manoharāti attho. Yasmiñhi padese sīlādiguṇasampannā mahesino viharanti, taṃ
analyzed: manāpā manoharā ti atthaḥ yasmin hi padese sīla ādi guṇa sampannāḥ mahesinaḥ viharanti tam
translated: “Not unappealing”: not unappealing, delightful, charming—this is the meaning. For whatever region the great seers who are endowed with virtue, etc., abide in,

original: kiñcāpi ukkūlavikūlavisamaduggākāraṃ, atha kho manuññaṃ ramaṇīyameva. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: kiñca api ukkūla vikūla visama dugga ākāram atha kho manuññam ramaṇīyam eva vuttam ha etam
translated: even if it has the appearance of being uneven, with hills and valleys, still it is delightful, charming. For this is said:🔽“Whether in village or in forest,

original: “Gāme vā yadi vāraññe, ninne vā yadi vā thale;
analyzed: gāme vā yadi vā araññe ninne vā yadi vā thale
translated: Whether in a low-lying or a high-lying place,

original: Yattha arahanto viharanti, taṃ bhūmirāmaṇeyyaka”nti. ;🔽Pahiṇeyyāsīti peseyyāsi. Satthā āyasmantānaṃ dassanakāmoti tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ santike
analyzed: yattha arahantaḥ viharanti tam  pahiṇeyyāsi iti peseyyāsi satthā āyasmantānam dassana kāmo ti tesam bhikkhūnam santike
translated: “Wherein the Worthy Ones dwell, that is the delightful place.”

original: paheṇākāradassanaṃ. Iti bhagavā yadatthaṃ te bhikkhū paṇāmesi, tamatthaṃ matthakappattaṃ🔽disvā āraddhacitto tesaṃ dassanakāmataṃ therassa ārocesi. Evaṃ kirassa ahosi “ahaṃ🔽ime uccāsaddamahāsaddakaraṇe paṇāmessāmi, atha te bhadro assājānīyo viya kasābhighātena,🔽tena coditā saṃvegappattā mamārādhanatthaṃ araññaṃ pavisitvā ghaṭentā vāyamantā khippameva
analyzed: paheṇa ākāra dassanam iti bhagavā yad attham te bhikkhū paṇāmesi tam attham matthaka ppattam  disvā āraddha citto tesam dassana kāma tam therassa ārocesi evam kirassa ahosi aham  ime uccāsadda mahāsadda karaṇe paṇāmessāmi atha te bhadraḥ kasā abhighātena  tena coditā saṃvega ppattā mama ārādhana attham araññam pavisitvā ghaṭentā vā āyamantā khippam eva
translated: “Send them”: you should send them. The Teacher wishes to see the venerable ones: he wishes to see them by sending them. Thus the Blessed One, seeing that the purpose for which he had sent those monks had been accomplished,

original: arahattaṃ sacchikarissantī”ti. Idāni te aggaphalappatte disvā tāya arahattappattiyā
analyzed: arahattam sacchikarissanti iti idāni te agga phala ppatte disvā tāya arahatta ppattiyā
translated: having become glad at heart, informed the Elder of his desire to see them. It occurred to him thus: “I will send these monks who make a great noise and a great commotion. Then, being urged by that, they will become anxious, and for the purpose of propitiating me they will enter the forest and striving and endeavouring will soon realize arahatship.” Having seen them now attain the highest fruit,

original: ārādhitacitto tesaṃ dassanakāmo hutvā evaṃ dhammabhaṇḍāgārikaṃ āṇāpesi.
analyzed: ārādhita cittaḥ tesam dassana kāmaḥ hutvā evam dhammabhaṇḍāgārikam āṇāpesi
translated: being pleased with their attainment of arahatship, he became desirous of seeing them and thus ordered the superintendent of the Dhamma.

original: So bhikkhūti ānandattherena tathā āṇatto chaḷabhiñño eko bhikkhu. Pamukheti sammukhe.
analyzed: so bhikkhū ti ānanda ttherena tathā āṇatto chaḍḍabhiñño ekaḥ bhikkhu pamukhe ti sammukhe
translated: “A bhikkhu” is a bhikkhu who has the six kinds of direct knowledge, as ordered by the Elder Ananda in that way. “In the presence of” means in front of.

original: Āneñjasamādhināti catutthajjhānapādakena aggaphalasamādhinā, “arūpajjhānapādakenā”tipi
analyzed: āneñja samādhinā ati catuttha jhāna pādakena agga phala samādhinā arūpa jjhāna pādakena ati pi
translated: “With the attainment of the imperturbable” means with the attainment of the foremost fruit, the fourth jhana, which is called “the imperturbable” .

original: vadanti. “Āneñjena samādhinā”tipi pāṭho. Kasmā pana bhagavā tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ āgamanaṃ
analyzed: vadanti āneñjena samādhinā atipi pāṭhaḥ kasmā pana bhagavā tesam bhikkhūnam āgamanaṃ
translated: “With the attainment of the imperturbable” is also a reading. But why did the Blessed One attain the attainment of serenity, knowing that those bhikkhus were coming,

original: jānanto paṭisanthāraṃ akatvā samāpattiṃyeva samāpajji? Tesaṃ attanā samāpannasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: jānantaḥ paṭisanthāram a katvā samāpattiṃ yā iva samāpajji tesam attanā samāpanna samāpattim
translated: without giving them a welcome? It was in order that they might know for themselves the attainment of serenity he had attained,

original: jānitvā samāpajjanatthaṃ, tesaṃ pubbe paṇāmitānaṃ idāni attanā samānasambhogadassanatthaṃ,🔽ānubhāvadīpanatthaṃ, vinā vacībhedena aññabyākaraṇadīpanatthañca. Apare panāhu “pubbe
analyzed: jānitvā samāpajjana attham tesam pubbe paṇāmitānam idāni attanā samāna sambhoga dassana ttham  ānubhāva dīpana ttham vinā vacībhedena añña byākaraṇa dīpana ttham ca apare pana āhu pubbe
translated: in order that they might see that he was now sharing the same attainment as they had previously been sent to attain,🔽in order to show his own power, and in order to show that he could give a reply without uttering speech.

original: paṇāmitānaṃ idāni attano santikaṃ āgatānaṃ anuttarasukhuppādanena anaññasādhāraṇapaṭisanthārakaraṇattha”nti.
analyzed: paṇāmitānam idāni attano santikam āgatānam anuttara sukha uppādanena anañña sādhāraṇa paṭisanthāra karaṇa ttham ti
translated: But others say that it was in order to give them a welcome that was not shared by others by causing the arising of the supreme happiness in those who had come into his presence after being sent away previously.

original: Tepi āyasmanto bhagavato ajjhāsayaṃ ñatvā taṃyeva samāpattiṃ samāpajjiṃsu. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: te api āyasmantaḥ bhagavataḥ ajjhāsayam ñatvā taṃ yeva samāpattim samāpajjiṃsu tena vuttam
translated: The venerable ones, too, knowing the Exalted One’s intention, attained that same attainment. Hence it was said:🔽“In what kind of abiding is the Exalted One now abiding?”

original: – “katamena nu kho bhagavā vihārena etarahi viharatī”tiādi.🔽Ettha ca rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānaṃ kosajjādīnaṃ pāripantikadhammānaṃ suvidūrabhāvato
analyzed: katamena nu khalu bhagavā vihārena etarahi viharati itiādi  ettha ca rūpāvacara catuttha jhānam kosajja ādīnam pāripantika dhammānam su vidūra bhāvato
translated: Herein, the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere is called “unshakable” because it is far removed from the states of agitation, etc.,

original: iddhiyā mūlabhūtehi anoṇamanādīhi soḷasahi vodānadhammehi samannāgamanato āneñjappattaṃ
analyzed: iddhiyā mūla bhūtehi anoṇamana ādīhi soḷasahi vodāna dhammehi samannāgamanataḥ āneñja ppattam
translated: and because it is endowed with the sixteen kinds of stainlessness that are the roots of success in higher iddhi.

original: sayaṃ aniñjanaṭṭhena āneñjanti vuccati. Vuttañhetaṃ –🔽“Anoṇataṃ cittaṃ kosajje na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ. Anuṇṇataṃ cittaṃ uddhacce na iñjatīti🔽āneñjaṃ. Anabhirataṃ cittaṃ rāge na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ. Anapanataṃ cittaṃ byāpāde na
analyzed: sayam an iñjana ṭṭhena āneñjanti vuccati vuttam ha etam  an oṇatam cittam kosajje naḥ iñjati iti āneñjam an uṇṇatam cittam uddhacce naḥ iñjati iti  āneñjam an abhiratam cittam rāge na iñjati iti āneñjam an apanatam cittam byāpāde na
translated: For this is said:

original: iñjatīti āneñjaṃ. Anissitaṃ cittaṃ diṭṭhiyā na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ. Appaṭibaddhaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: iñjati iti āneñjam anissitam cittam diṭṭhiyā na iñjati iti āneñjam appaṭibaddham cittam
translated: “The mind that is not bent is unshakable in idleness. The mind that is not stretched is unshakable in agitation. The mind that is not greedy is unshakable in greed. The mind that is not contracted is unshakable in ill will. The mind that is not clinging is unshakable in views. The mind that is not fettered is unshakable in doubt. The mind that is not subject to cankers is unshakable in the cankers. The mind that is well developed is unshakable in what is not well developed. The mind that is straight is unshakable in crookedness. The mind that is purified is unshakable in impurity. The mind that is bright is unshakable in darkness. The mind that is concentrated is unshakable in distraction. The mind that is liberated is unshakable in bondage. The mind that is free from hate is unshakable in hate. The mind that is free from greed is unshakable in greed. The mind that is free from delusion is unshakable in delusion. The mind that is free from defilements is unshakable in defilements. The mind that is not subject to rebirth is unshakable in what is subject to rebirth. The mind that is not subject to old age is unshakable in what is subject to old age. The mind that is not subject to sickness is unshakable in what is subject to sickness. The mind that is not subject to death is unshakable in what is subject to death. The mind that is not subject to sorrow is unshakable in what is subject to sorrow. The mind that is not subject to lamentation is unshakable in what is subject to lamentation. The mind that is not subject to defilement is unshakable in what is subject to defilement. The mind that is not subject to worldly conditions is unshakable in what is subject to worldly conditions. The mind that is not subject to the hindrances is unshakable in the hindrances. The mind that is not subject to the defilements of the fine-material and immaterial spheres

original: chandarāge na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ. Vippamuttaṃ cittaṃ kāmarāge na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ.🔽Visaṃyuttaṃ cittaṃ kilese na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ. Vimariyādikataṃ cittaṃ kilesamariyādāya
analyzed: chanda rāge naḥ iñjati iti āneñjam vippamuttam cittam kāma rāge naḥ iñjati iti āneñjam  visaṃyuttam cittam kilese na iñjati iti āneñjam vimariyādikatam cittam kilesa mariyādāya
translated: It is unmoved by sensual lust, thus it is imperturbable.🔽It is unmoved by defilements, thus it is imperturbable.🔽It is unmoved by the limit of defilements, thus it is imperturbable.🔽It is unmoved by the various defilements, thus it is imperturbable.

original: na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ. Ekattagataṃ cittaṃ nānattakilese na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ. Saddhāya🔽pariggahitaṃ cittaṃ assaddhiye na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ. Vīriyena pariggahitaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: na iñjati iti āneñjam ekatta gatam cittam nānatta kilese na iñjati iti āneñjam saddhāya  pariggahitam cittam naḥ iñjati iti āneñjam vīriyena pariggahitam cittam
translated: It is unmoved by faithlessness, thus it is imperturbable.🔽It is unmoved by idleness, thus it is imperturbable.🔽It is unmoved by negligence, thus it is imperturbable.

original: kosajje na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ. Satiyā pariggahitaṃ cittaṃ pamāde na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ.🔽Samādhinā pariggahitaṃ cittaṃ uddhacce na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ. Paññāya pariggahitaṃ
analyzed: kosajje naḥ iñjati iti āneñjam satiyā pariggahitam cittam pamāde naḥ iñjati iti āneñjam  samādhinā pariggahitam cittam uddhacce na iñjati iti āneñjam paññāya pariggahitam
translated: It is unmoved by agitation, thus it is imperturbable.🔽It is unmoved by ignorance, thus it is imperturbable.

original: cittaṃ avijjāya na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ. Obhāsagataṃ cittaṃ avijjandhakāre na iñjatīti āneñja”nti.
analyzed: cittam avijjāya naḥ iñjati iti āneñjam obhāsa gatam cittam avid andhakāre naḥ iñjati iti āneñjanti
translated: It is unmoved by the darkness of ignorance, thus it is imperturbable” .

original: Rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānameva ca rūpavirāgabhāvanāvasena pavattitaṃ, ārammaṇavibhāgena
analyzed: rūpāvacara catuttha jjhānam eva ca rūpa virāga bhāvanā vasena ārammaṇa vibhāgena
translated: And the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere itself, when it occurs by means of the development of dispassion for materiality, is called “the imperturbable” in the Paṭisambhidā:🔽“The imperturbable is the fourth jhāna. It is unmoved by the agitation due to lust, by the agitation due to hate, by the agitation due to delusion, by the agitation due to change-of-lineage” .

original: catubbidhaṃ arūpāvacarajjhānanti etesaṃ pañcannaṃ jhānānaṃ āneñjavohāro. Tesaṃ yaṃ
analyzed: catubbidham arūpāvacara jhānanti etesam pañcannam jhānānam āneñja vohāro tesam yaṃ
translated: The four immaterial jhānas are called the “state of imperturbability” among these five jhānas.

original: kiñci pādakaṃ katvā samāpannā arahattaphalasamāpatti āneñjasamādhīti porāṇā.
analyzed: pādakam katvā samāpannā arahatta phala samāpatti āneñja samādhī iti porāṇā
translated: The attainment of Arahantship, which is entered upon making any one of them the basis, is called the “concentration of imperturbability” by the Ancients.

original: Abhikkantāyāti atītāya. Nikkhanteti niggate, apagateti attho. Tuṇhī ahosīti bhagavā
analyzed: abhikkantāya ati atītāya nikkhanteti niggate apagateti attho tuṇhī ahosi iti bhagavā
translated: “Passed away”: into the past. “Disappeared”: vanished, is the meaning. “Was silent”: the Exalted One was silent by way of the noble silence.

original: ariyena tuṇhībhāvena tuṇhī ahosi. Uddhaste aruṇeti uggate aruṇe, aruṇo nāma puratthimadisāya🔽sūriyodayato puretarameva uṭṭhitobhāso. Nandimukhiyāti rattiyā aruṇassa uggatattā
analyzed: ariyena tuṇhībhāvena tuṇhī ahosi uddhaste aruṇā iti uggate aruṇe aruṇaḥ nāma puratthima disāya  sūriya udayataḥ puretaram eva uṭṭhita ubhāsaḥ rattiyā aruṇassa uggata ttā
translated: “When the dawn had risen”: when the dawn had appeared. The dawn is the light that arises in the eastern direction before sunrise.

original: eva aruṇappabhāya sūriyālokūpajīvino satte nandāpanamukhiyā viya rattiyā jātāya,
analyzed: eva aruṇa ppabhāya sūriya āloka upajīvino satte nandāpana mukhiyā viya rattiyā jātāya
translated: “When the night had become radiant”: because of the rising of the dawn, the night became radiant, as if the night had arisen,

original: vibhāyamānāyāti attho.
analyzed: vibhāyamānāya ati atthaḥ
translated: as if the night had become radiant. The meaning is that it became illuminated.

original: Tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvāti yathāparicchedaṃ tato āneñjasamādhito arahattaphalasamāpattito
analyzed: tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā ati yathāparicchedam tatas āneñja samādhitaḥ arahatta phala samāpattitaḥ
translated: “Having emerged from that concentration”: having arisen from that concentration of imperturbability, the attainment of Arahantship, within the limited extent of time.

original: uṭṭhāya. Sace kho tvaṃ, ānanda, jāneyyāsīti bhagavā “ime ca bhikkhū ettakaṃ kālaṃ
analyzed: uṭṭhāya sace kho tvam ānanda jāneyyāsi iti bhagavā ime ca bhikkhū ettakam kālam
translated: “If you, Ānanda, had known”: the Exalted One says to Ānanda: “If you had known, Ānanda, that the Exalted One would have answered thus,

original: iminā nāma samāpattisukhena vītināmentī”ti, ānanda, yadi tvaṃ jāneyyāsi. Ettakampi🔽te nappaṭibhāseyyāti lokiyapaṭisammodanaṃ sandhāya yadidaṃ te “abhikkantā, bhante,
analyzed: iminā nāma samāpatti sukhena ānanda yadi tvam jāneyyāsi ettakam pi  te na paṭibhāseyya ati lokiya paṭisammodanam sandhāya yat idam te abhikkantāḥ bhante
translated: “You could have known that they were spending the night in such and such a attainment of concentration.”🔽If you had known, you would not have spoken thus.

original: rattī”tiādinā tikkhattuṃ paṭibhānaṃ upaṭṭhitaṃ, tayidaṃ ettakampi te na upaṭṭhaheyya.
analyzed: ratti iti ādinā tikkhattum paṭibhānam upaṭṭhitam tayidam ettakam pi te na upaṭṭhaheyya
translated: With reference to the worldly form of greeting, the Venerable Ananda’s three statements beginning with “The night has passed, venerable sir” were ready to be spoken. But they did not occur to him.

original: Yasmā ca kho tvaṃ, ānanda, sekkho asekkhaṃ samāpattivihāraṃ na jānāsi, tasmā maṃ🔽imesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ lokiyapaṭisammodanaṃ kāretuṃ ussukkaṃ āpajji. Ahaṃ pana imehi bhikkhūhi🔽saddhiṃ lokuttarapaṭisammodaneneva tiyāmarattiṃ vītināmesinti dassento bhagavā āha
analyzed: yasmai ca kho tvam ānanda sekkhaḥ asekkham samāpatti vihāram na jānāsi tasmai mama  imesam bhikkhūnam lokiya paṭisammodanam kāretum ussukkam āpajji aham pana imehi bhikkhūhi  saddhim lokuttara paṭisammodanena iva tiyāma rattim vītināmesin ti dassentaḥ bhagavā āha
translated: But since you, Ananda, as a disciple in higher training, do not know the attainment of concentration of one beyond training,🔽I was anxious to have these bhikkhus greet me in the worldly way. But I spent the three watches of the night with these bhikkhus in a discussion pertaining to the higher than the worldly.

original: – “ahañca, ānanda, imāni ca pañca bhikkhusatāni sabbeva āneñjasamādhinā nisīdimhā”ti.
analyzed: aham ca ānanda imāni ca pañca bhikkhu satāni sabbā iva āneñja samādhinā nisīdimha ati
translated: The Exalted One said this to show that he spent the three watches of the night with the bhikkhus in a discussion pertaining to the supramundane.

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ attanā samaṃ āneñjasamādhisamāpajjanasamatthatāsaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: etam attham viditvā ti etam tesam bhikkhūnam attanā samam āneñja samādhi samāpajjana samattha tā saṅkhātam
translated: Having known this matter,

original: vasībhāvatthaṃ sabbākārato viditvā. Imaṃ udānanti imaṃ tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ anavasesarāgādippahānasaṃsiddhitādisabhāvadīpanaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: vasībhāva attham sabba ākārataḥ viditvā imam udānan ti imam tesam bhikkhūnam anavasesa rāga ādi pahāna saṃsiddhi tā ādi sabhāva dīpanam udānam udānesi
translated: and he uttered this inspired utterance after he had known them in all aspects for the purpose of mastery.

original: Tattha yassa jito kāmakaṇḍakoti kusalapakkhavijjhanaṭṭhena kaṇḍakabhūto kilesakāmo🔽yena ariyapuggalena anavasesaṃ jito pahīno, etenassa anunayābhāvaṃ dasseti. “Gāmakaṇṭako”tipi
analyzed: tattha yassa jitaḥ kāma kaṇḍakaḥ ti kusala pakkha vijjhana ṭṭhena kaṇḍaka bhūtaḥ kilesa kāmo  yena ariya puggalena anavasesam jitaḥ pahīnaḥ etena assa anunaya abhāvam dasseti
translated: Herein, he whose thorn of sense desire is conquered is one in whom sense-desire as a thorn, which is a corruption of the profitable side,

original: pāṭho. Tassattho – gāme kaṇṭako kaṇṭakaṭṭhāniyo sakalo vatthukāmo yassa jitoti. Jayo
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ tassa atthaḥ gāme kaṇṭakaḥ kaṇṭaka ṭṭhāniyaḥ sakalaḥ vatthu kāmaḥ yassa jitaḥ iti jayaḥ
translated: is conquered, that is to say, abandoned without remainder, by which noble person. This shows that he has no affection. There is also the reading ‘gāmakaṇṭako’ . Its meaning is: ‘he whose sense desire for all objects is conquered, which is a thorn in the village, a thorn-place in the village’.

original: cassa tappaṭibaddhachandarāgappahāneneva veditabbo, tena tesaṃ anāgāmimaggo vutto
analyzed: cassa tad paṭibaddha chanda rāga ppahānena iva veditabbaḥ tena tesam anāgāmi maggaḥ vuttaḥ
translated: His victory should be understood as due only to the abandoning of the will and lust bound up with that . Consequently, their non-return path is what is referred to here.

original: hoti. Akkoso ca jitoti sambandho. Vadho ca bandhanañcāti etthāpi eseva nayo. Tesu
analyzed: hoti akkoso ca jito ti sambandhaḥ vadho ca bandhanam ca ati ettha api esa iva nayo tesu
translated: The construction is ‘contempt is conquered’ . The same method applies in the case of ‘threat’ and ‘imprisonment’.

original: akkosajayena vacīduccaritābhāvo, itarena kāyaduccaritābhāvo dassito. Tena taṃnimittakassa
analyzed: akkosa jayena vacī duccarita abhāvaḥ itarena kāya duccarita abhāvaḥ dassito tena taṃ nimittakassa
translated: Herein, the conquest of contempt shows absence of verbal misconduct, and the other shows absence of bodily misconduct. Consequently,

original: byāpādassa anavasesappahānena tatiyamaggo vutto hoti. Atha vā akkosādijayavacanena
analyzed: byāpādassa anavasesa pahānena tatiya maggaḥ vuttaḥ hoti atha vā akkosa ādi jaya vacanena
translated: The third path is stated by the complete abandoning of ill will.

original: tatiyamaggo vutto hoti, akkosādīnaṃ accantakhamanaṃ tattha pakāsitaṃ hoti, ubhayathāpi
analyzed: tatiya maggo vuttaḥ hoti akkosa ādīnam accanta khamanam tattha pakāsitam hoti ubhayathā api
translated: Or else, the third path is stated by the words “he conquers scolding, etc.”; the complete endurance of scolding, etc., is shown there. In both cases🔽he shows the absence of contradiction between the two.

original: nesaṃ virodhābhāvaṃ dasseti. Pabbato viya so ṭhito anejoti ejā vuccati calanakilesaparipantho,
analyzed: na īsam virodha abhāvam dasseti pabbataḥ viya saḥ ṭhitaḥ anejaḥ iti ejā vuccati calana kilesa paripantho
translated: He stands firm like a rock, unshaken: “Shaking” is a term for the defilements that cause wavering.

original: ejāhetūnaṃ avasesakilesānaṃ abhāvena anejo, anejattāyeva sabbakilesehi paravādavātehi🔽ca akampanīyattā ṭhito ekagghanapabbatasadiso. Sukhadukkhesu na vedhati sa bhikkhūti
analyzed: ejā hetūnam avasesa kilesānam abhāvena anejaḥ anejattāya iva sabba kilesehi paravāda vātehi  ca a kampanīya ttā ṭhitaḥ ekagghana pabbata sadisaḥ sukha dukkhesu na vedhati sa bhikkhu iti
translated: Since he has no remaining defilements, the causes of shaking, he is unshaken. And because he is unshaken, he is unshaken by all the defilements and by the winds of opposing doctrines.🔽He stands firm like a solid rock.🔽The monk is not perturbed by pleasure and pain:

original: so bhinnakileso bhikkhu sukhadukkhanimittaṃ na kampatīti heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva attho🔽veditabbo. Iti bhagavā tesaṃ pañcasatānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ arahattādhigamena tādibhāvappattiṃ
analyzed: so bhinna kilesaḥ bhikkhu sukha dukkha nimittam na kampati iti heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva atthaḥ  veditabbaḥ iti bhagavā tesam pañca satānam bhikkhūnam arahatta adhigamena tādi bhāva ppattim
translated: The meaning should be understood in the way stated above, that the monk who has destroyed the defilements does not waver at the sign of pleasure and pain.

original: ekajjhaṃ katvā ekapuggalādhiṭṭhānaṃ udānaṃ udānesīti.
analyzed: ekajjham katvā eka puggala adhiṭṭhānam udānam udānesi iti
translated: Thus the Blessed One uttered this exalted utterance, making it the basis of a single person, namely, the attainment of such a state by the five hundred monks through the realization of arahatship.

original: Tatiyasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tatiya sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the third sutta is finished.

original: 4. Sāriputtasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sāriputta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 4. The explanation of the fourth sutta

original: 24. Catutthe parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvāti ārammaṇābhimukhaṃ satiṃ ṭhapayitvā mukhasamīpe katvā. Tathā hi vibhaṅge vuttaṃ –
analyzed: catutthe parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā ati ārammaṇa abhimukham satim ṭhapayitvā mukha samīpe katvā tathā hi vibhaṅge vuttam
translated: In the fourth sutta the words “having established mindfulness in front of him” mean having placed mindfulness facing the object, having made it present in the vicinity of the face. For this is said in the Vibhaṅga:

original: “Ayaṃ sati upaṭṭhitā hoti supaṭṭhitā nāsikagge vā mukhanimitte vā, tena vuccati parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā”ti.
analyzed: ayam sati upaṭṭhitā hoti su paṭṭhitā nāsikagge vā mukha nimitte vā tena vuccati parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā ati
translated: “This mindfulness is present, well-established, in the nose or in the sign of the nose. Hence it is said, ‘having established mindfulness in front of him’” .

original: Atha vā “parīti pariggahaṭṭho, mukhanti niyyānaṭṭho, satīti upaṭṭhānaṭṭho, tena vuccati
analyzed: atha vā pari iti pariggaha aṭṭho mukhanti niyyāna ṭṭho satī iti upaṭṭhāna ṭṭho tena vuccati
translated: Or alternatively, “pari” has the meaning of “encompassing,” “mukha” has the meaning of “outlet,” and “sati” has the meaning of “establishment.” Hence it is said:🔽“Having encompassed the outlet by mindfulness.”

original: ‘parimukhaṃ sati”’nti. Evaṃ paṭisambhidāyaṃ vuttanayenapettha attho veditabbo. Tatrāyaṃ
analyzed: parimukham satin ti evam paṭisambhidā ayam vutta nayena pa ittha atthaḥ veditabbo tatra ayam
translated: The meaning should be understood here in the way stated in the Paṭisambhidā. The meaning there is as follows:

original: saṅkhepattho – pariggahitaniyyānasatiṃ katvāti. Niyyānanti ca satiyā ogāhitabbaṃ🔽ārammaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ettha ca purimo pacchimo ca attho sabbasaṅgāhakavasena, itaro
analyzed: saṅkhepa atthaḥ pariggahita niyyāna satim katvā iti niyyānam ca satiyā ogāhitabbam  ārammaṇam daṭṭhabbam ettha ca purimo pacchimo ca attho sabba saṅgāhaka vasena itaro
translated: “Having encompassed the outlet by mindfulness” means having made the outlet of mindfulness encompassed by mindfulness. And the object that is to be entered upon by mindfulness should be regarded as the outlet . Herein,

original: samāpattiyā pubbabhāgasamannāhāravasena daṭṭhabbo. Satīti vā satisīsena jhānaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: samāpattiyā pubba bhāga samannāhāra vasena daṭṭhabbo satī iti vā sati sīsena jhānam vuttam
translated: the first and last meanings should be regarded as inclusive, and the middle meaning as suggestive of the preliminary stage of concentration. Or else, the jhāna is called “mindfulness” in the sense of a kind of mindfulness.

original: “ye kāyagatāsatiṃ paribhuñjantī”tiādīsu viya. Katamaṃ pana taṃ jhānanti? Rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānaṃ
analyzed: ye kāya gata asatim paribhuñjanti iti ādīsu katamam pana tam rūpāvacara catuttha jhānam
translated: “Those who enjoy the mindfulness occupied with the body” and so on.

original: pādakaṃ katvā samāpannaṃ arahattaphalajjhānaṃ. Kathaṃ panetaṃ jānitabbanti? Āneñjasamādhiyogena
analyzed: pādakam katvā samāpannam arahatta phala jjhānam katham pana itam jānitabbanti āneñja samādhi yogena
translated: But what is that jhāna? The jhāna of the fruit of arahantship entered upon making the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere the basis.🔽But how is this to be known? By the fact that the Blessed One said, “He is not agitated” and so on.

original: therassa savisesaṃ niccalabhāvaṃ kenaci akampanīyatañca pabbatopamāya pakāsento bhagavā
analyzed: therassa sa visesam niccala bhāvam kenaci akampanīya tam ca pabbata upamāya pakāsentaḥ bhagavā
translated: And the Blessed One, in revealing the Elder’s state of extreme stability and unshakability by anyone, as though by a mountain,🔽uttered this exclamation. And the meaning of the verse is understood thus.

original: imaṃ udānaṃ abhāsīti gāthāya eva ayamattho viññāyati. Na cāyaṃ nisajjā therassa saccappaṭivedhāya,🔽atha kho diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārāya. Pubbeyeva hi sūkarakhataleṇe attano bhāgineyyassa
analyzed: imam udānam abhāsi iti gāthāya eva ayam atthaḥ viññāyati na ca ayam nisajjā therassa sacca paṭivedhāya  atha kho diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihārāya pubbeyā iva hi sūkara khata leṇe attanaḥ bhāgineyyassa
translated: And this sitting of the Elder was not for the purpose of penetrating the truths,🔽but rather for the purpose of abiding in bliss here and now. For the Elder had already reached the peak of the task of penetrating the truths when the Blessed One was teaching the Dhamma for the purpose of his enlightenment in the Sūkarakhataka Cave,

original: dīghanakhaparibbājakassa bhagavati dhammaṃ desente ayaṃ mahāthero saccappaṭivedhakiccaṃ matthakaṃ pāpesīti.
analyzed: dīghanakha paribbājakassa bhagavati dhammam desente ayam mahā thero saccappaṭivedha kiccam matthakam pāpesi iti
translated: and the wanderer Dīghanakha, who was his sister’s son, was present.

original: Etamatthanti etaṃ therassa āneñjasamādhiyogena tādibhāvappattiyā ca kenaci akampanīyatāsaṅkhātaṃ atthaṃ sabbākārato viditvā tadatthavibhāvanaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: etam attham ti etam therassa āneñja samādhi yogena ta ādi bhāva ppattiyā ca kenaci akampanīya tā saṅkhātam attham sabba ākārataḥ viditvā tad attha vibhāvanam imam udānam udānesi
translated: “This meaning”: having known by his own mind the meaning of the Elder’s being unperturbed by anyone, which is called “unshakability,” in all its aspects, he uttered this utterance in order to reveal that meaning.

original: Tattha yathāpi pabbato seloti yathā silāmayo ekagghanasilāpabbato, na paṃsupabbato
analyzed: tattha yathā api pabbataḥ selo ti yathā silā mayaḥ ekagghana silā pabbataḥ na paṃsu pabbataḥ
translated: Herein, just as a mountain of rock is a mountain consisting of solid rock, not a mountain of sand,

original: na missakapabbatoti attho. Acalo suppatiṭṭhitoti suppatiṭṭhitamūlo pakativātehi acalo
analyzed: na missaka pabbataḥ ti attho acalaḥ suppatiṭṭhitaḥ ti suppatiṭṭhita mūlaḥ pakati vātehi acalaḥ
translated: not a mountain of mixed material, is what is meant. It is unshaken, well-established: its roots are well established, so it is unshaken by winds that blow against it,

original: akampanīyo hoti. Evaṃ mohakkhayā bhikkhu, pabbatova na vedhatīti mohassa anavasesappahānā
analyzed: a kampanīyaḥ hoti evam moha kkhayā bhikkhu pabbataḥ iva na vedhati iti mohassa anavasesa ppahānā
translated: it is unshakable. So too, the bhikkhu, by destruction of delusion: by the complete abandonment of delusion,

original: mohamūlakattā ca sabbākusalānaṃ pahīnasabbākusalo bhikkhu, yathā so pabbato pakativātehi,
analyzed: moha mūlaka ttā ca sabba akusalānam pahīna sabba akusalaḥ bhikkhu yathā saḥ pabbataḥ pakati vātehi
translated: since all unprofitable things have delusion as their root, the bhikkhu, who has abandoned all unprofitable things, is like the mountain,

original: evaṃ lokadhammehi na vedhati na kampati. Mohakkhayoti vā yasmā nibbānaṃ arahattañca
analyzed: evam loka dhammehi na vedhati na kampati moha kkhayo ti vā yasmā nibbānam arahattam ca
translated: and so he is not shaken by worldlings’ ideas. Or alternatively, since extinction and Arahantship are called “destruction of delusion,”

original: vuccati, tasmā mohakkhayassa hetu nibbānassa arahattassa vā adhigatattā catūsu ariyasaccesu
analyzed: vuccati tasmā moha kkhayassa hetu nibbānassa arahattassa vā adhigata ttā catūsu ariya saccesu
translated: therefore, since he has attained extinction or Arahantship as the cause of the destruction of delusion, in the four noble Truths

original: suppatiṭṭhito asamāpannakālepi yathāvuttapabbato viya na kenaci vedhati, pageva samāpannakāleti adhippāyo.
analyzed: su patiṭṭhitaḥ a samāpanna kāle api yathā vutta pabbataḥ viya na kenacid vedhati pagā iva samāpanna kāle iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is well established, not shaken by anything, even before he attains jhāna, as the mountain stated was not shaken by anything, much less when he has attained it.

original: Catutthasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: catuttha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the fourth sutta is ended.

original: 5. Mahāmoggallānasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Great Moggallāna Sutta

original: 25. Pañcame kāyagatāya satiyāti kāyānupassanāvasena kāye gatāya kāyārammaṇāya satiyā,
analyzed: pañcame kāya gatāya satiyā ati kāya anupassanā vasena kāye gatāya kāya ārammaṇāya satiyā
translated: In the fifth sutta the words “Mindfulness occupied with the body” mean mindfulness that has gone into the body, that has made the body its object,

original: itthambhūtalakkhaṇe idaṃ karaṇavacanaṃ. Ajjhattanti idha ajjhattaṃ nāma niyakajjhattaṃ,
analyzed: ittham bhūta lakkhaṇe idam karaṇa vacanam ajjhattanti idha ajjhattam nāma niyaka jjhattam
translated: in the sense of the characteristic of being such and such. “Internally”: here “internally” is one’s own internal .

original: tasmā attani attasantāneti attho. Atha vā yasmā kammaṭṭhānabhūto kesādiko dvattiṃsakoṭṭhāsasamudāyo
analyzed: tasmai attani atta santāne iti atthaḥ atha vā yasmai kammaṭṭhāna bhūto kesa ādikaḥ dvattiṃsa koṭṭhāsa samudāyo
translated: So the meaning is: in oneself, in one’s own continuity. Or alternatively, since the thirty-two parts of the body beginning with head hairs, which are the meditation subject,

original: idha kāyoti adhippeto, tasmā ajjhattanti padassa gocarajjhattanti attho veditabbo.
analyzed: idha kāyaḥ ti adhippeto tasmai ajjhattanti padassa gocara jjhattanti attho veditabbo
translated: are what is called “the body” here, the meaning of the word “internally” should be understood as “in one’s own domain.”

original: Sūpaṭṭhitāyāti niyakajjhattabhūte gocarajjhattabhūte vā kāye suṭṭhu upaṭṭhitāya.
analyzed: su upaṭṭhitāya ati niyaka ajjhatta bhūte gocara jjhatta bhūte vā kāye suṭṭhu upaṭṭhitāya
translated: “Well established”: well established in the body that is one’s own internal domain, or well established in the body that is one’s own domain in the sense of being one’s own.

original: Kā panāyaṃ sati, yā “ajjhattaṃ sūpaṭṭhitā”ti vuttā? Yvāyaṃ bhagavatā “atthi imasmiṃ
analyzed: kā pana ayam satī yā ajjhattam su upaṭṭhitā iti vuttā yvā ayam bhagavatā atthi imasmin
translated: But what is this mindfulness that is said to be “well established internally”? It is this: the Blessed One has said that there is mindfulness in breathing in and out,

original: kāye kesā lomā”tiādinā ajjhattakesādiko dvattiṃsākāro kāyo vutto, tattha yā paṭikūlamanasikāraṃ
analyzed: kāye kesāḥ ajjhatta kesa ādiko dvattiṃsa ākāro kāyaḥ vutto tattha yā paṭikūla manasikāraṃ
translated: The thirty-two parts of the body beginning with head hairs and body hairs are called the body in the passage: “In the body, head hairs and body hairs” .🔽🔽The attention given to repulsiveness in the various parts of the body

original: pavattentassa upacārappanāvasena kāye upaṭṭhitā sati, sā “kāyagatā satī”ti vuccati.🔽Yathā cāyaṃ, evaṃ ānāpānacatuiriyāpathasatisampajaññānaṃ vasena uddhumātakavinīlakādivasena🔽ca manasikāraṃ pavattentassa yathārahaṃ upacārappanāvasena kāye upaṭṭhitā sati “kāyagatā🔽satī”ti vuccati. Idha pana ajjhattaṃ kāyagatā sati pathavīādikā catasso dhātuyo sasambhārasaṅkhepādīsu🔽catūsu yena kenaci ekenākārena vavatthapetvā tesaṃ aniccādilakkhaṇasallakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: pavattentassa upacāra ppanā vasena kāye upaṭṭhitā sati sā kāya gatā satī iti vuccati  yathā ca ayam evam āna apāna catu iriyāpatha sati sampajaññānam vasena uddhumātaka vinīlaka ādi vasena  ca manasikāram pavattentassa yathāraham upacāra ppanā vasena kāye upaṭṭhitā sati kāya gatā  satī iti vuccati idha pana ajjhattam kāya gatā sati pathavī ādikā catasso dhātuyo sa sambhāra saṅkhepa ādīsu  catūsu yena kenaci ekena ākārena vavatthapetvā tesam anicca ādi lakkhaṇa sat lakkhaṇa vasena
translated: The thirty-two parts of the body beginning with head hairs and body hairs are called the “body” in the passage: “In the body, head hairs, body hairs” . Herein, mindfulness established in the body by the development of the kinds of attention already mentioned in the passage beginning, “When he brings to mind as repulsive” , is called “mindfulness occupied with the body” .

original: upaṭṭhitā vipassanāsampayuttā sati “kāyagatā satī”ti adhippetā. Thero pana tathā
analyzed: upaṭṭhitā vipassanā sampayuttā sati kāya gatā sati iti adhippetā theraḥ pana tathā
translated: And just as this is so, so also is mindfulness established in the body by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the in-breaths and out-breaths as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the postures as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the thirty-two-fold aspect of foulness beginning with the bloated as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the thirty-two parts of the body as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the four elements as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the four immaterial states as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the six sense bases as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the six groups of craving as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the twelve bases as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of kinds of mindfulness that have the twenty-two faculties as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the four noble truths as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the dependent origination in its two aspects of three and seven factors as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the thirty-two aspects of the object as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the thirty-two aspects of the object as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the four paths and the four fruits as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the four immaterial states as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the six sense bases as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the six groups of craving as their object, and by the development of the four kinds of mindfulness that have the twelve bases

original: vipassitvā attano phalasamāpattimeva samāpajjitvā nisīdi. Idhāpi gāthāya evaṃ imassa
analyzed: vipassitvā attanaḥ phala samāpattim eva samāpajjitvā nisīdi idha api gāthāya evam imassa
translated: and having seen it, he sat down having attained the fruit attainment himself. Here too, in the verse, it is said:

original: atthassa viññātabbatā “na cāyaṃ nisajjā”tiādinā vuttanayānusārena yojetabbā.🔽Etamatthanti etaṃ therassa catudhātuvavatthānamukhena kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānena
analyzed: atthassa viññātabba tā na ca ayam nisajja āti ādinā vutta naya anusārena yojetabbā  etam attham ti etam therassa catu dhātu vavatthāna mukhena kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhānena
translated: and having done so, he sat down and entered upon the fruition attainment. Here too the way in which the meaning should be construed by the method stated thus “This sitting down is not …” should be understood.

original: vipassanaṃ ogāhetvā phalasamāpattisamāpajjanasaṅkhātaṃ atthaṃ viditvā. Imaṃ udānanti
analyzed: vipassanam ogāhetvā phala samāpatti samāpajjana saṅkhātam attham viditvā imam udānanti
translated: Having understood the meaning: having understood the meaning consisting in the elder’s entry upon fruition attainment by insight after he had plunged into the development of the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of the body by way of the defining of the four elements.

original: imaṃ satipaṭṭhānabhāvanāya nibbānādhigamadīpakaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.🔽Tattha sati kāyagatā upaṭṭhitāti pubbe vuttalakkhaṇā sati saddhāpubbaṅgamānaṃ samādhivīriyapaññānaṃ
analyzed: imam sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanāya nibbāna adhigama dīpakam udānaṃ udānesi  tattha sati kāya gatā upaṭṭhitā ati pubbe vutta lakkhaṇā sati saddhā pubbaṅgamānam samādhi vīriya paññānam
translated: This utterance: this utterance that illuminates the attainment of Nibbāna by the development of the foundations of mindfulness.

original: yathāsakaṃ kiccanipphādanena sahāyabhāvaṃ āpannattā pahīnappaṭipakkhā tato eva tikkhavisadabhūtā
analyzed: yathāsakam kicca nipphādanena sahāya bhāvam āpanna ttā pahīna ppaṭipakkhā tatas eva tikkha visada bhūtā
translated: Herein, mindfulness is present in the body: mindfulness that has the characteristics stated above, which is accompanied by faith, concentration, energy, and understanding, which has become a condition for their performing their several functions, which has eliminated its opposite, and which for that reason is keen and clear,

original: ca yathāvuttakāyasaṃvaraṇavasena ekatthasamosaraṇavasena ca aviparītasabhāvaṃ sallakkhentī
analyzed: ca yathā vutta kāya saṃvaraṇa vasena ekattha samosaraṇa vasena ca aviparīta sabhāvam sallakkhentī
translated: which discerns the undeluded true nature of things by means of the bodily restraint stated above and by means of the convergence of the several factors of the foundations of mindfulness,

original: upagantvā ṭhitā hoti, etena kāyasaṅkhātānaṃ catunnaṃ dhātūnaṃ tannissitānañca upādārūpānaṃ
analyzed: upagantvā ṭhitā hoti etena kāya saṅkhātānam catunnam dhātūnam tad nissitānam ca upādā rūpānam
translated: by means of defining the four primary elements and the derivative materiality dependent on them,

original: sallakkhaṇavasena, paccaye vavatthapetvā tato paraṃ tesaṃ aniccādilakkhaṇasallakkhaṇavasena🔽ca pavattaṃ ñāṇaparamparāgataṃ satiṃ dasseti, satisīsena vā taṃsampayuttaṃ pariññāttayapariyāpannañāṇaparamparameva
analyzed: sat lakkhaṇa vasena paccaye vavatthapetvā tatas param tesam anicca ādi lakkhaṇa sat lakkhaṇa vasena  ca pavattam ñāṇa paramparā gatam satim dasseti sati sīsena vā tad sampayuttam pariññā taya pariyāpanna ñāṇa paramparam eva
translated: and then by means of defining their characteristics of impermanence, etc.,

original: dasseti. Chasu phassāyatanesu saṃvutoti yathāvuttāya kāye upaṭṭhitāya satiyā samannāgato
analyzed: dasseti chasu phassa āyatanesu saṃvutaḥ ti yathā vuttāya kāye upaṭṭhitāya satiyā samannāgato
translated: he shows the mindfulness that has come down in the succession of the knowledge that occurs in this way. Or alternatively, he shows the succession of knowledge that is included in the three kinds of full-understanding and is associated with that mindfulness, which is headed by mindfulness established in the way aforesaid in the body.🔽“Restrained in the six bases of contact”: he is possessed of the mindfulness established in the body in the way aforesaid.

original: cakkhādīsu phassassa kāraṇabhūtesu chasu dvāresu kāyānupassanāya abhāvitāya uppajjanārahānaṃ🔽abhijjhādīnaṃ tassā bhāvitattā ñāṇappavattiṃ paṭivedhento te pidahanto “tattha saṃvuto”ti
analyzed: cakkha ādīsu phassassa kāraṇa bhūtesu chasu dvāresu kāya anupassanāya abhāvitāya uppajjana arahānam  abhijjhā ādīnam tassā bhāvita ttā ñāṇa ppavattim paṭivedhentaḥ te pidahantaḥ tattha saṃvuto ti
translated: In the six doors, which are the eye, etc., and are the bases for contact, he restrains the arising of covetousness, etc.,🔽which are due to the non-development of contemplation of the body, by developing that contemplation. He is said to be “restrained there”

original: vuccati, etena ñāṇasaṃvaraṃ dasseti.
analyzed: vuccati etena ñāṇa saṃvaram dasseti
translated: by virtue of the penetration of the occurrence of knowledge. He shows the restraint by knowledge in this way.

original: Satataṃ bhikkhu samāhitoti so bhikkhu evaṃ upaṭṭhitassati sabbattha ca saṃvuto puthuttārammaṇe🔽cittaṃ avissajjetvā aniccādivasena sammasanto vipassanaṃ ussukkāpetvā ñāṇe tikkhe🔽sūre vahante vipassanāsamādhinā tāva satataṃ nirantaraṃ samāhito anulomañāṇānantaraṃ
analyzed: satatam bhikkhu samāhitaḥ ti saḥ bhikkhu evam upaṭṭhita ssati sabbattha ca saṃvutaḥ puthutta ārammaṇe  cittam a vissajjetvā anicca ādi vasena sammasantaḥ vipassanam ussukkāpetvā ñāṇe tikkhe  sūre vahante vipassanā samādhinā tāva satatam nirantaram samāhitaḥ anuloma ñāṇa anantaram
translated: The bhikkhu ever concentrated: this bhikkhu, thus mindful and guarded everywhere, does not let his cognizance go straying outside,🔽but he comprehends with insight by means of impermanence, etc., and he brings insight to its culmination.🔽When the knowledge is sharp and keen, he is ever concentrated, without break, by means of the concentration of insight, from the time of the conformity knowledge onwards,

original: gotrabhuñāṇodayato paṭṭhāya. Jaññā nibbānamattanoti aññesaṃ puthujjanānaṃ supinantepi
analyzed: gotra bhuñāṇa udayataḥ paṭṭhāya jaññā nibbānam attanoti aññesam puthujjanānam
translated: because it is the province of no one else, of no ordinary man, even in a dream.

original: agocarabhāvato, ariyānaṃ pana tassa tasseva āveṇikattā attasadisattā ca “attā”ti🔽laddhavohārassa maggaphalañāṇassa sātisayavisayabhāvato ekantasukhāvahaṃ nibbānaṃ
analyzed: agocara bhāvato ariyānam pana tassa tassa iva āveṇika ttā atta sadisa ttā ca attā ati  laddha vohārassa magga phala ñāṇassa sa atisaya visaya bhāvataḥ ekanta sukha āvaham nibbānam
translated: But because it is unique to the Noble Ones and is like their self, it is called their ‘self’🔽and it is the extinction element that is called ‘his own’ because it is the province of the knowledge of the path and fruition, which is given the name ‘self’ in the sense just stated. He should know that extinction,

original: asaṅkhatadhātu “attano”ti vuttaṃ, taṃ nibbānaṃ jaññā jāneyya, maggaphalañāṇehi paṭivijjheyya,
analyzed: asaṅkhata dhātu attanoti vuttam tam nibbānam jaññā jāneyya magga phala ñāṇehi paṭivijjheyya
translated: which is the sole cause of bliss, should penetrate it with the knowledge of the path and fruition.

original: sacchikareyyāti attho. Etena ariyānaṃ nibbāne adhimuttataṃ dasseti. Ariyā hi adhicittappavattikālepi🔽ekanteneva nibbāne ninnapoṇapabbhārabhāvena viharanti. Ettha ca yassa sati kāyagatā🔽upaṭṭhitā, so bhikkhu chasu phassāyatanesu saṃvuto, tato eva satataṃ samāhito attapaccakkhakaraṇena
analyzed: sacchikareyya iti atthaḥ etena ariyānam nibbāne adhimutta tam dasseti ariyāḥ hi adhi citta ppavatti kāle pi  ekantena iva nibbāne ninna poṇa pabbhāra bhāvena viharanti ettha ca yassa sati kāya gatā  upaṭṭhitā so bhikkhu chasu phassa āyatanesu saṃvutaḥ tatas eva satatam samāhitaḥ atta paccakkha karaṇena
translated: the meaning is, he would realize Nibbāna. This shows the Noble Ones’ inclination towards Nibbāna. For the Noble Ones,🔽even when they are engaged in the development of consciousness,🔽they dwell with a tendency to go down, to enter into, and to incline towards Nibbāna. And here the meaning of the stanzas should be understood as follows: “The bhikkhu in whom mindfulness

original: nibbānaṃ attano jāneyyāti evaṃ gāthāpadānaṃ sambandho veditabbo. Evaṃ kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānamukhena
analyzed: nibbānam attanaḥ jāneyya ti evam gāthā padānam sambandhaḥ veditabbaḥ evam kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhāna mukhena
translated: established in the body is present is restrained in the six bases of contact. Because of that he is always concentrated. By making Nibbāna his own direct experience he would know Nibbāna for himself.” Thus the Blessed One, the King of the Dhamma, shows by way of the development of mindfulness occupied with the body

original: yāva arahattā ekassa bhikkhuno niyyānamaggaṃ dasseti dhammarājā.
analyzed: yāva arahattā ekassa bhikkhuno niyyāna maggam dasseti dhamma rājā
translated: the path of deliverance for a bhikkhu up to arahantship.

original: Aparo nayo – sati kāyagatā upaṭṭhitāti etena kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ sati kāya gatā upaṭṭhitā ti etena kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam dasseti
translated: Another method: by the words “mindfulness established in the body” he shows the development of mindfulness occupied with the body.

original: Chasu phassāyatanesu saṃvutoti phasso āyatanaṃ kāraṇaṃ etesanti phassāyatanāni, tesu
analyzed: chasu phassa āyatanesu saṃvutaḥ ti phassaḥ āyatanam kāraṇam phassa āyatanāni tesu
translated: “Restrained in the six bases of contact” : the six bases of contact are the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. The contact that is the cause of these is the cause of the six bases of contact. Therefore contact is called the six bases of contact.

original: phassāyatanesu. Phassahetukesu phassapaccayā nibbattesu chasu cakkhusamphassajādivedayitesu
analyzed: phassa āyatanesu phassa hetukesu phassa paccayā nibbattesu chasu cakkhu samphassa ja ādi vedayitesu
translated: In the six bases for contact. In the six kinds of feeling born of contact with the eye, etc., which are produced with contact as condition in the six bases for contact that are the cause of contact.

original: taṇhādīnaṃ appavattiyā saṃvuto, etena vedanānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ dasseti. Satataṃ
analyzed: taṇhā ādīnam appavattiyā saṃvutaḥ etena vedanā anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam dasseti satatam
translated: “Controlled” : he shows the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of feeling by the non-occurrence of craving, etc., in the six kinds of feeling.

original: bhikkhu samāhitoti satataṃ niccakālaṃ nirantaraṃ vikkhepābhāvato samāhito bhikkhu.
analyzed: bhikkhu samāhitaḥ ti satatam nicca kālam nirantaram vikkhepa abhāvataḥ samāhitaḥ bhikkhu
translated: “The monk who ever is concentrated” : the monk who is concentrated, who is always, constantly, uninterruptedly, and without distraction ever concentrated.

original: So cāyaṃ avikkhepo sabbaso satipaṭṭhānabhāvanāya matthakappattāya hoti. Sammasanto
analyzed: so ca ayam avikkhepaḥ sabbaso sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanāya matthaka ppattāya hoti sammasanto
translated: And this non-distraction comes about when the development of the foundations of mindfulness has reached its culmination. For one who comprehends,

original: hi atītādibhedabhinnesu pañcupādānakkhandhesu anavasesatova pariggahetvā sammasatīti.🔽Etena sesasatipaṭṭhāne dasseti. Jaññā nibbānamattanoti evaṃ catusatipaṭṭhānabhāvanaṃ
analyzed: hi atīta ādi bheda bhinnesu pañca upādānakkhandhesu anavasesataḥ va pariggahetvā sammasati iti  etena sesa sati paṭṭhāne dasseti jaññā nibbānam attanoti evam catu sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanam
translated: having discerned the five aggregates subject to clinging classed as past, etc., comprehends them without exception.🔽By this he shows the remaining foundations of mindfulness.

original: matthakaṃ pāpetvā ṭhito bhinnakileso bhikkhu attano kilesanibbānaṃ paccavekkhaṇañāṇena
analyzed: matthakam pāpetvā ṭhitaḥ bhinna kilesaḥ bhikkhu attanaḥ kilesa nibbānam paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇena
translated: “He should know his own deliverance” : having thus brought the development of the four foundations of mindfulness to its culmination, the monk whose defilements are exhausted should know by means of the knowledge of reviewing his own deliverance from defilements.

original: sayameva jāneyyāti attho.
analyzed: sayam eva jāneyya ati attho
translated: This is the meaning.

original: Atha vā sati kāyagatā upaṭṭhitāti attano paresañca kāyassa yathāsabhāvapariññādīpanena🔽therassa sativepullappatti dīpitā. Chasu phassāyatanesu saṃvutoti cakkhādīsu chasu
analyzed: atha vā sati kāya gatā upaṭṭhitā ati attanaḥ paresam ca kāyassa yathā sabhāva pariññā dīpanena  therassa sati vepulla ppatti dīpitā chasu phassa āyatanesu saṃvuto ti cakkha ādīsu chasu
translated: Or else, “Mindful, his body well-composed” shows the elder’s fulfilment of mindfulness by showing the full understanding of his own and others’ bodies according to their individual natures.

original: dvāresu accantasaṃvaradīpanena satatavihārivasena therassa sampajaññappakāsinī paññāvepullappatti
analyzed: dvāresu accanta saṃvara dīpanena satata vihāri vasena therassa sampajañña ppakāsinī paññā vepulla ppatti
translated: “Controlled in the six bases of contact” shows the elder’s fulfilment of understanding by showing his constant abiding in the form of clear comprehension, by showing the utmost restraint in the six doors of the eye, etc.

original: dīpitā. Satataṃ bhikkhu samāhitoti samāpattibahulatādassanena navānupubbavihārasamāpattiyo🔽dassitā. Evaṃbhūto pana bhikkhu jaññā nibbānamattanoti katakiccattā uttari karaṇīyābhāvato
analyzed: dīpitā satatam bhikkhu samāhitaḥ ti samāpatti bahula tā dassanena navā anupubba vihāra samāpattiyaḥ  dassitā evaṃbhūtaḥ pana bhikkhu jaññā nibbānam attanoti kata kiccattā uttari karaṇīya abhāvato
translated: “The monk who is ever concentrated” shows the nine successive abidings and the nine successive liberations by showing his abundance of attainment.

original: kevalaṃ attano anupādisesanibbānameva jāneyya cinteyya, aññampi tassa cintetabbaṃ natthīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: kevalam attanaḥ anupādisesa nibbānam eva jāneyya cinteyya aññam pi tassa cintetabbam natthi iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: But the monk who is such should know his own Nibbāna. The intention is that because he has done what was to be done and there is nothing more for him to do, he should know only his own Nibbāna without trace left, should think about that, and there is nothing else for him to think about.

original: Pañcamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽6. Pilindavacchasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pañcama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  pilindavaccha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the fifth sutta is finished.🔽The sutta on Pilindavaccha

original: 26. Chaṭṭhe pilindavacchoti pilindātissa nāmaṃ, vacchoti gottavasena theraṃ sañjānanti.
analyzed: chaṭṭhe pilindavaccho ti pilindātissa nāmam vaccho ti gotta vasena theram sañjānanti
translated: In the sixth sutta, Pilindavaccha: his name was Pilinda, and he is known as the elder Vaccha by his clan.

original: Vasalavādena samudācaratīti “ehi, vasala, apehi, vasalā”tiādinā bhikkhū vasalavādena
analyzed: vasala vādena samudācarati iti ehi vasala apehi vasala ati ādinā bhikkhū vasala vādena
translated: He reviles with the word “vile” : he addresses the bhikkhus with the word “vile” in such terms as “Come, vile one! Go away, vile one!”

original: voharati ālapati. Sambahulā bhikkhūti bahū bhikkhū. Te theraṃ tathā samudācarantaṃ🔽disvā “arahāva samāno appahīnavāsanattā evaṃ bhaṇatī”ti ajānantā “dosantaro maññe
analyzed: voharati ālapati sambahulāḥ bhikkhū iti bahū bhikkhū te theram tathā samudācarantam  disvā arahāva samānaḥ appahīna vāsanattā evam bhaṇati iti a jānantā dosantaraḥ maññe
translated: Many bhikkhus : a number of bhikkhus. When they saw the elder reviling him in this way,

original: ayaṃ thero evaṃ samudācaratī”ti cintetvā ullapanādhippāyā taṃ tato vuṭṭhāpetuṃ bhagavato
analyzed: ayam theraḥ evam samudācarati iti cintetvā ullapana adhippāyā tam tatas vuṭṭhāpetum bhagavato
translated: not knowing that he was speaking thus because his underlying tendency to conceit had not been eradicated although he was an Arahant, they thought, “The elder must be harboring hatred against him to revile him in this way.”

original: ārocesuṃ. Tena vuttaṃ – “āyasmā, bhante, pilindavaccho bhikkhū vasalavādena samudācaratī”ti.🔽Keci panāhu – “imaṃ theraṃ bhikkhū ‘arahā’ti sañjānanti, ayañca bhikkhū pharusavacanena
analyzed: ārocesuṃ tena vuttam āyasmā bhante pilindavacchaḥ bhikkhū vasala vādena samudācarati iti  keci pana āhu imam theram bhikkhū arahā ati sañjānanti ayam ca bhikkhū pharusa vacanena
translated: With the intention of provoking him, they reported the matter to the Blessed One. Hence it was said, “Venerable sir, the venerable Pilindavaccha reviles bhikkhus with the word ‘vile’” .🔽But some say that the bhikkhus regarded this elder as an Arahant, and he reviles them with harsh words in this way.

original: evaṃ samudācarati, ‘abhūto eva nu kho imasmiṃ uttarimanussadhammo’ti vāsanāvasena
analyzed: evam samudācarati abhūtaḥ eva nu kho imasmin uttari manussa dhammaḥ ti vāsanā vasena
translated: Not knowing that this is his way of teaching them by arousing disgust in them for the underlying tendency to conceit that still persists in them although they are Arahants,

original: tassa tathā samudācāraṃ ajānantā ariyabhāvañcassa asaddahantā ujjhānasaññino bhagavato
analyzed: tassa tathā samudācāram a jānantāḥ ariya bhāvañcassa a saddahantāḥ ujjhāna saññinaḥ bhagavataḥ
translated: and not believing that he is a noble disciple, they regard him as contemptible and report the matter to the Blessed One,🔽thinking: “Is this a superhuman state?

original: tamatthaṃ ārocesu”nti. Bhagavā therassa dosantarābhāvaṃ pakāsetukāmo ekena bhikkhunā
analyzed: tam attham ārocesuḥ ti bhagavā therassa dosa antara abhāvam pakāsetu kāmo ekena bhikkhunā
translated: and told him the reason for their coming. The Exalted One, wishing to show that the Elder had no malice in his heart,

original: taṃ pakkosāpetvā sammukhā tassa “pubbāciṇṇavasenāyaṃ tathā samudācarati, na pharusavacanādhippāyo”ti
analyzed: tam pakkosāpetvā sammukhā tassa pubbāciṇṇa vasena ayam tathā samudācarati na pharusa vacana adhippāyaḥ ti
translated: had a certain monk summon the Elder. In the Elder’s presence the Exalted One said: “He acts thus because of his past habits. He does not intend to speak harshly.”

original: āha. Tena vuttaṃ – “atha kho bhagavā aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantesī”tiādi.
analyzed: āha tena vuttam atha kho bhagavā aññataram bhikkhum āmantesi itiādi
translated: Therefore it is said: “Then the Exalted One addressed a certain monk” and so forth.

original: Tattha pubbenivāsaṃ manasi karitvāti satthā “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, vaccha, bhikkhū vasalavādena
analyzed: tattha pubbenivāsam manasi karitvā ati satthā saccam kira tvam vaccha bhikkhū vasala vādena
translated: Therein, recollecting his previous lives means that the Teacher asked the Elder: “Is it true, Vaccha, that you address the monks with the word ‘low-caste’?”

original: samudācarasī”ti theraṃ pucchitvā tena “evaṃ, bhante”ti vutte “ayaṃ vaccho kilesavāsanāya
analyzed: samudācarasi iti theram pucchitvā tena evam bhante iti vutte ayam vaccho kilesa vāsanāya
translated: When the Elder replied: “Yes, Exalted One,” the Teacher thought: “This Vaccha does not give up the word ‘low-caste’ because of the influence of his defilements.

original: vasalavādaṃ na pariccajati, kiṃ nu kho atītesupi attabhāvesu brāhmaṇajātiko ahosī”ti
analyzed: vasala vādam na pariccajati kim nu kho atītesu pi atta bhāvesu brāhmaṇa jātikaḥ ahosi iti
translated: Was he of the brahmin caste in his previous existences?”

original: āvajjento pubbenivāsañāṇena sabbaññutaññāṇena vā tassa pubbenivāsaṃ atītāsu jātīsu
analyzed: āvajjento pubbenivāsa ñāṇena sabbaññuta ññāṇena vā tassa pubbenivāsam atītāsu jātīsu
translated: Recollecting his previous lives by means of the knowledge of recollecting previous births or by means of omniscience, the Teacher saw that in his previous existences the Elder had been born in the brahmin caste.

original: nivutthakkhandhasantānaṃ manasi karitvā hatthatale ṭhapitaṃ āmalakaṃ viya paccakkhakaraṇavasena
analyzed: nivuttha kkhandha santānam manasi karitvā hattha tale ṭhapitam āmalakam viya paccakkhakaraṇa vasena
translated: Having given attention to the life-continuum that is covered over, as though he were placing a myrobalan fruit on the palm of his hand,

original: attano manasi katvā. Bhikkhū āmantesīti te bhikkhū saññāpetuṃ ālapi, abhāsi. Tena
analyzed: attanaḥ manasi katvā bhikkhū āmantesi iti te bhikkhū saññāpetum ālapi abhāsi tena
translated: and having given attention to it himself, he addressed the bhikkhus, that is, he spoke to them in order to make them understand.

original: vuttaṃ “mā kho tumhe, bhikkhave”tiādi.
analyzed: vuttam mā kho tumhe bhikkhave itiādi
translated: Therefore it was said: ‘Bhikkhus, do not be angry with the bhikkhu Vaccha … ’

original: Tattha māti paṭisedhe nipāto, tassa “ujjhāyitthā”ti iminā sambandho. Mā ujjhāyitthāti
analyzed: tattha mā iti paṭisedhe nipātaḥ tassa ujjhāyittha ati iminā sambandhaḥ mā ujjhāyittha ati
translated: Herein, do not be angry is a negative particle; its meaning is ‘do not be angry.’🔽Do not be angry with the bhikkhu Vaccha: do not be angry with the bhikkhu Vaccha.

original: mā heṭṭhā katvā cintayittha, olokayitthāti attho. Vacchassa bhikkhunoti ca ujjhāyanassa🔽usūyanatthattā sampadānavacanaṃ. Idānissa anujjhāyitabbe kāraṇaṃ dassento “na, bhikkhave,
analyzed: mā heṭṭhā katvā cintayittha olokayittha ati atthaḥ vacchassa bhikkhuno ti ca ujjhāyanassa  usūyana attha ttā sampadāna vacanam idāni issa anujjhāyitabbe kāraṇam dassento na bhikkhave
translated: Do not think ill of him, do not look down upon him, is the meaning.🔽The bhikkhu Vaccha is angry: the bhikkhu Vaccha is angry, is envious, is jealous.

original: vaccho dosantaro bhikkhū vasalavādena samudācaratī”ti āha. Tassattho – bhikkhave,
analyzed: vacchaḥ dosantaraḥ bhikkhū vasala vādena samudācarati iti āha tassa atthaḥ bhikkhave
translated: The word ‘is’ is used in the sense of ‘he is doing.’ Now, showing the reason why he should not be angry, he said: ‘Bhikkhus, the bhikkhu Vaccha does not address the bhikkhus with the word “vassal” out of hatred.’

original: ayaṃ vaccho dosantaro dosacitto dosena byāpādena dūsitacitto hutvā bhikkhū vasalavādena
analyzed: ayam vacchaḥ dosantaraḥ dosa cittaḥ dosena byāpādena dūsita cittaḥ hutvā bhikkhū vasala vādena
translated: The meaning is this: Bhikkhus, this bhikkhu Vaccha does not address the bhikkhus with the word ‘vassal’ out of hatred, out of hate, out of hatefulness, out of ill will, with a mind corrupted by hate.

original: na samudācarati, maggeneva cassa byāpādo samugghātito. Evaṃ adosantarattepi tassa
analyzed: na samudācarati maggena iva cassa byāpādaḥ samugghātito evam tassa
translated: He does not do so, and the ill will is uprooted by the path.

original: tathā samudācārassa purimajātisiddhaṃ kāraṇaṃ dassento “vacchassa, bhikkhave”tiādimāha.
analyzed: tathā samudācārassa purima jāti siddham kāraṇam dassentaḥ vacchassa bhikkhave tiādim āha
translated: The Exalted One shows the reason for the occurrence of the ill will in the past life of the monk Vaccha, saying, “Monks, for five hundred lives in succession, the brahmin student Vaccha has been reborn in a brahmin family.”

original: Tattha abbokiṇṇānīti khattiyādijātiantarehi avomissāni anantaritāni. Pañca jātisatāni
analyzed: tattha abbokiṇṇāni iti khattiya ādi jāti antarehi avomissāni anantaritāni pañca jāti satāni
translated: Here, “uninterrupted” means not mixed with other families such as the khattiya family.🔽For five hundred lives in succession he has been reborn in a brahmin family.

original: brāhmaṇakule paccājātānīti sabbāni tāni vacchassa pañca jātisatāni paṭipāṭiyā brāhmaṇakule
analyzed: brāhmaṇa kule paccājātāni iti sabbāni tāni vacchassa pañca jāti satāni paṭipāṭiyā brāhmaṇa kule
translated: The meaning is: for all those five hundred lives in succession, the brahmin student Vaccha has been reborn in a brahmin family.🔽The statement “The brahmin student Vaccha has been reborn in a brahmin family for five hundred lives in succession” shows the long-standing nature of the ill will.

original: eva jātāni, ahesunti attho. So tassa vasalavādo dīgharattaṃ samudāciṇṇoti yo etarahi🔽khīṇāsavenapi satā pavattiyati, so tassa vacchassa bhikkhuno vasalavādo dīgharattaṃ
analyzed: eva jātāni ahesun ti attho saḥ tassa dīgharattam yaḥ etarahi  khīṇāsavena api satā so tassa vacchassa bhikkhuno dīgharattam
translated: The ill will that occurs even in the present time towards one who has destroyed the taints has been practiced for a long time.

original: ito jātito paṭṭhāya uddhaṃ ārohanavasena pañcajātisatamattaṃ kālaṃ brāhmaṇajātikattā
analyzed: itas jātitaḥ paṭṭhāya uddham ārohana vasena pañca jāti sata mattam kālam brāhmaṇa jāti kattā
translated: For five hundred lives in succession, the brahmin student Vaccha has been reborn in a brahmin family.

original: samudāciṇṇo samudācarito ahosi. Brāhmaṇā hi jātisiddhena mānena thaddhā aññaṃ vasalavādena
analyzed: samudāciṇṇaḥ samudācaritaḥ ahosi brāhmaṇāḥ hi jāti siddhena mānena thaddhāḥ aññam vasala vādena
translated: The brahmins are hard-hearted due to the conceit of birth and call others “low-born.”

original: samudācaranti. “Ajjhāciṇṇo”tipi paṭhanti, so eva attho. Tenāti tena dīgharattaṃ tathā🔽samudāciṇṇabhāvena, etenassa tathā samudācārassa kāraṇaṃ vāsanāti dasseti. Kā panāyaṃ🔽vāsanā nāma? Yaṃ kilesarahitassāpi santāne appahīnakilesānaṃ samācārasadisasamācārahetubhūtaṃ,
analyzed: samudācaranti paṭhanti saḥ eva atthaḥ tena ati tena dīgharattam tathā  samudāciṇṇa bhāvena etena assa tathā samudācārassa kāraṇam vāsanā ati dasseti kā pana ayam  vāsanā nāma yam kilesa rahitassa api santāne appahīna kilesānam samācāra sadisa samācāra hetu bhūtam
translated: “It is a habit” is also read, and the meaning is the same. “By that”: by that habit long cultivated in the past, he shows that this is the cause of his conduct in that way. But what is this “habit”?🔽It is that which, in the mental continuity of one who is devoid of defilements, is the cause of conduct similar to the conduct of those who have not abandoned the defilements.

original: anādikālabhāvitehi kilesehi āhitaṃ sāmatthiyamattaṃ, tathārūpā adhimuttīti vadanti.🔽Taṃ panetaṃ abhinīhārasampattiyā ñeyyāvaraṇappahānavasena yattha kilesā pahīnā, tattha🔽bhagavato santāne natthi. Yattha pana tathā kilesā na pahīnā, tattha sāvakānaṃ paccekabuddhānañca
analyzed: anādi kāla bhāvitehi kilesehi āhitam sāmatthiya mattam tathārūpā adhimutti iti vadanti  tam pana itam abhinīhāra sampattiyā ñeyya āvaraṇa pahāna vasena yattha kilesā pahīnā tattha  bhagavato santāne natthi yattha pana tathā kilesāḥ na pahīnāḥ tattha sāvakānam paccekabuddhānam ca
translated: They are in the habit of doing so. “They are accustomed to” is also read; the meaning is the same. “By that”: by that habit of doing so for a long time; he shows that this is the cause of his so behaving. But what is this “habit” ? They say that it is a mere potency infused by defilements existing from time without beginning, which is the cause of the kind of conduct similar to the conduct of those who have not abandoned the defilements, even in the mental continuity of one free from defilements.

original: santāne atthi, tato tathāgatova anāvaraṇañāṇadassano.
analyzed: santāne atthi tatas tathāgataḥ uva anāvaraṇa ñāṇa dassano
translated: But this is to be understood as the removal of the cognitive hindrance by the perfection of aspiration. Where defilements have been abandoned, it does not exist in the Exalted One’s mental continuity. But where the defilements have not been abandoned in that way, it exists in the mental continuity of disciples and paccekabuddhas. Therefore the Tathāgata alone has unobstructed knowledge and insight.

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ āyasmato pilindavacchassa satipi vasalasamudācāre dosantarābhāvasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam āyasmataḥ pilindavacchassa sati pi vasala samudācāre dosa antara abhāva saṅkhātam
translated: Having known this meaning: having known this fact about the venerable Pilindavaccha, that although he is in the habit of using abusive language, he is free from the hindrance of hate,

original: atthaṃ viditvā. Imaṃ udānanti tassa aggaphalādhigamavibhāvanaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: attham viditvā imam udānan ti tassa agga phala adhigama vibhāvanam imam udānam udānesi
translated: He had understood the meaning. He uttered this exalted utterance: he uttered this exalted utterance which reveals the attainment of the foremost fruit.🔽Herein, in which there is no deceit and no pretense: in which there are no ariyan persons,

original: Tattha yamhi na māyā vasati na mānoti yasmiṃ ariyapuggale santadosappaṭicchādanalakkhaṇā
analyzed: tattha yamhi na māyā vasati na yasmin ariya puggale santa dosa paṭicchādana lakkhaṇā
translated: deceit, which is characterized by concealing one’s faults,

original: māyā, “seyyohamasmī”tiādinā sampaggahavasena pavatto uṇṇatilakkhaṇo māno ca na vasati,
analyzed: māyā seyyā uham asmi iti ādinā sampaggaha vasena pavattaḥ uṇṇati lakkhaṇaḥ māno ca na vasati
translated: and conceit, which is characterized by haughtiness, occurring as the over-estimation of oneself in such a way as “I am better” and so on,

original: maggena samugghātitattā na pavattati na uppajjati. Yo vītalobho amamo nirāsoti yo
analyzed: maggena samugghātita ttā na pavattati na uppajjati yaḥ vīta lobhaḥ amamaḥ yaḥ
translated: do not exist, do not occur, do not arise, because they have been eradicated by the path. He who is free from greed, without possessions, without hopes:

original: ca rāgādipariyāyavasena pavattassa ārammaṇaggahaṇalakkhaṇassa lobhassa sabbathā vigatattā🔽vītalobho, tato eva rūpādīsu katthaci mamāyanābhāvato amamo apariggaho, anāgatānampi
analyzed: ca rāga ādi pariyāya vasena pavattassa ārammaṇa ggahaṇa lakkhaṇassa lobhassa sabbathā vigata ttā  vīta lobhaḥ tatas eva rūpa ādīsu katthaci amamaḥ apariggahaḥ anāgatānam pi
translated: he who is free from greed because of the complete absence of greed, which is characterized by the grasping of objects and occurs by way of the synonyms beginning with lust,🔽without possessions, without ownership, because of the absence of any ownership anywhere in such things as visible forms, and without hopes, without expectations, because of the non-acceptance of future

original: bhavādīnaṃ anāsīsanato nirāso. Panuṇṇakodhoti kujjhanalakkhaṇassa kodhassa anāgāmimaggena
analyzed: bhava ādīnam an āsīsanataḥ nirāsaḥ panuṇṇa kodho ti kujjhana lakkhaṇassa kodhassa anāgāmi maggena
translated: existence, etc. He who has shaken off anger: he who has shaken off anger, which is characterized by the state of being angry, by the path of non-returner,

original: sabbaso pahīnattā panuṇṇakodho samucchinnāghāto. Abhinibbutattoti yo evaṃ māyāmānalobhakodhānaṃ🔽samugghātena tadekaṭṭhatāya sabbassa saṃkilesapakkhassa suppahīnattā sabbaso kilesaparinibbānena🔽abhinibbutacitto sītibhūto. So brāhmaṇo so samaṇo sa bhikkhūti so evarūpo khīṇāsavo
analyzed: sabbasas pahīna ttā panuṇṇa kodhaḥ samucchinna āghātaḥ abhinibbuta ttā ti yaḥ evam māyā māna lobha kodhānam  samugghātena tad ekaṭṭha tāya sabbassa saṃkilesa pakkhassa su pahīna ttā sabbaso kilesa parinibbānena  abhinibbuta citto sīti bhūto saḥ brāhmaṇaḥ saḥ samaṇaḥ sa bhikkhu iti saḥ evarūpo khīṇa āsavaḥ
translated: and because he has completely abandoned them, he has put away anger and has cut it off at the root. He is completely quenched: by the complete extinction of defilements his mind is completely quenched, cooled, and refreshed. He is a brahmin, he is an ascetic, he is a monk: such an one who has destroyed the cankers is a brahmin,🔽🔽

original: sabbaso bāhitapāpattā brāhmaṇo, so eva samitapāpattā samacariyāya ca samaṇo, so eva🔽ca sabbaso bhinnakilesattā bhikkhu nāma. Evaṃbhūto ca, bhikkhave, vaccho so kathaṃ🔽dosantaro kiñci kāyakammādiṃ pavatteyya, kevalaṃ pana vāsanāya appahīnattā vasalavādena samudācaratīti.🔽Chaṭṭhasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽7. Sakkudānasuttavaṇṇanā🔽27. Sattame sattāhaṃ ekapallaṅkena nisinno hoti aññataraṃ samādhiṃ samāpajjitvāti
analyzed: sabbasas brāhita pāpattā brāhmaṇo saḥ eva samita pāpattā sama cariyāya ca samaṇo saḥ eva 🔽ca sabbasas bhinna kilesa ttā bhikkhu nāma evaṃbhūtaḥ ca bhikkhave vacchaḥ so katham 🔽kevalam pana vāsanāya appahīna ttā vasala vādena samudācarati iti 🔽chaṭṭha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽sakkudāna sutta vaṇṇanā 🔽sattame sattāham eka pallaṅkena nisinnaḥ hoti aññataram samādhim samāpajjitvā ati
