translated: increased his insight, he became fully enlightened by attaining the noble path, himself free from the defilements that had been pierced by the supramundane path.

original: hutvā paccavekkhaṇānantaraṃ anavasesānaṃ kilesānaṃ pahīnattā attano vaṭṭadukkhassa
analyzed: hutvā paccavekkhaṇa anantaram anavasesānam kilesānam pahīna ttā attanaḥ vaṭṭa dukkhassa
translated: and after reviewing them, he uttered the Solemn Utterance beginning, “Having known as it really is,” which shows the exhaustion of his own round of suffering and the exhaustion of all the defilements without exception.

original: parikkhīṇabhāvadīpakaṃ sabbabuddhānaṃ avijahitaṃ “anekajātisaṃsāra”nti udānaṃ udānetvā🔽teneva pallaṅkena sattāhaṃ vimuttisukhapaṭisaṃvedī nisinno sattamāya rattiyā tīsu
analyzed: parikkhīṇa bhāva dīpakam sabba buddhānam a vijahitam aneka jāti saṃsāranti udānaṃ udānetvā  tena iva pallaṅkena sattāham vimutti sukha paṭisaṃvedī nisinno sattamāya rattiyā tīsu
translated: This Solemn Utterance is never abandoned by all the Buddhas.🔽Then, after sitting for seven days enjoying the bliss of deliverance, on the seventh night, in the three watches of the night, he uttered the three Solemn Utterances in the way already described.

original: yāmesu vuttanayena tīṇi udānāni udānetvā tatiyaudānānantaraṃ buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ🔽volokento “sakalamidaṃ sattānaṃ vaṭṭadukkhaṃ kilesamūlakaṃ, kilesā nāmete pavattidukkhā
analyzed: yāmesu vutta nayena tīṇi udānāni udānetvā tatiya odāna anantaram buddha cakkhunā lokaṃ  volokento sakalam idam sattānam vaṭṭa dukkham kilesa mūlakam kilesāḥ nāma ete pavatti dukkhā
translated: After the third Solemn Utterance, he surveyed the world with his Buddha-eye.

original: āyatimpi dukkhahetubhūtā, tehi ime sattā santappanti pariḍayhanti cā”ti passi. Tena
analyzed: āyatim pi dukkha hetu bhūtā tehi ime sattā santappanti pariḍayhanti ca ati passi tena
translated: He saw that the whole round of suffering of beings has the defilements as its root, that the defilements are the cause of the suffering of renewed existence, and that beings are tormented and consumed by the defilements.

original: vuttaṃ “addasā kho bhagavā…pe… mohajehipī”ti.
analyzed: vuttam addasā kho bhagavā āpe iti
translated: Therefore it was said: “The Exalted One saw that the world was on fire with the flames of the defilements” .

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ lokassa yathāvuttasantāpapariḷāhehi abhibhuyyamānataṃ sabbākārato
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam lokassa yathā vutta santāpa pariḷāhehi sabba ākārato
translated: Having known this matter: having known the world’s being overwhelmed by the burning and fever of the defilements in all its aspects,

original: viditvā. Imaṃ udānanti imaṃ sabbasantāpapariḷāhato parinibbānavibhāvanaṃ mahāudānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: viditvā imam udānan ti imam sabba santāpa pariḷāhataḥ parinibbāna vibhāvanam mahāudānam udānesi
translated: Having known. This exalted utterance: he uttered this great exalted utterance, which is the disclosure of the complete extinction of all burning and fever.

original: Tattha ayaṃ loko santāpajātoti ayaṃ sabbopi loko jarārogamaraṇehi ceva nānāvidhabyasanehi
analyzed: tattha ayam loko santāpa jāto ti ayam sabbaḥ api lokaḥ jarā roga maraṇehi ca iva nānāvidha byasanehi
translated: Herein, this world is born of burning: this whole world is born of burning by ageing, disease, and death, and by the various kinds of misfortune,

original: ca kilesapariyuṭṭhānehi ca jātasantāpo, uppannakāyikacetasikadukkhābhibhavoti attho.
analyzed: ca kilesa pariyuṭṭhānehi ca jāta santāpaḥ uppanna kāyika cetasika dukkha abhibhavaḥ ti attho
translated: and it is overcome by the bodily and mental suffering that arises from these. The meaning is that it is overcome by the manifestation of that.

original: Phassaparetoti tato eva anekehi dukkhasamphassehi parihato upadduto. Atha vā phassaparetoti
analyzed: phassa pareto ti tatas eva anekehi dukkha samphassehi parihataḥ upaddutaḥ atha vā phassa pareto ti
translated: It is afflicted by contact: it is afflicted by the many kinds of painful contacts that arise from these. Or alternatively, it is afflicted by contact

original: sukhādisaṅkhātānaṃ tissannaṃ dukkhatānaṃ paccayabhūtehi chahi phassehi abhibhūto,
analyzed: sukha ādi saṅkhātānam tissannam dukkha tānam paccaya bhūtehi chahi phassehi abhibhūtaḥ
translated: because it is overcome by the six kinds of contact, which are the conditions for the three kinds of pain called pleasure, etc.,

original: tato tato dvārato tasmiṃ tasmiṃ ārammaṇe pavattivasena upassaṭṭho. Rogaṃ vadati attatoti
analyzed: tatas tatas dvārato tasmin tasmin ārammaṇe pavatti vasena upassaṭṭhaḥ rogam vadati attato ti
translated: and because it is oppressed by the occurrence of this or that kind of contact in this or that object. It declares disease as self:

original: phassapaccayā uppajjamānaṃ vedanāsaṅkhātaṃ rogaṃ dukkhaṃ, khandhapañcakameva vā yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: phassa paccayā uppajjamānam vedanā saṅkhātam rogam dukkham khandha pañcakam eva vā yathābhūtam
translated: the disease called feeling, which arises with contact as its condition, or the five aggregates as they really are,

original: ajānanto “aha”nti saññāya diṭṭhigāhavasena “ahaṃ sukhito dukkhito”ti attato vadati.
analyzed: a jānantaḥ aham ti saññāya diṭṭhi gāha vasena aham sukhitaḥ dukkhitaḥ ti attataḥ vadati
translated: Not knowing, he speaks of himself as “I” through the assumption of a view, saying “I am happy” or “I am miserable.”

original: “Attano”tipi paṭhanti. Tassattho – yvāyaṃ loko kenaci dukkhadhammena phuṭṭho abhāvitattatāya
analyzed: attano ti pi paṭhanti tassa atthaḥ yvā ayam loko kenacid dukkha dhammena phuṭṭhaḥ a bhāvita tta tāya
translated: “Of himself” is also read. The meaning of that is this: When this world, because of its undeveloped nature,🔽is touched by some painful thing and is unable to endure it,

original: adhivāsetuṃ asakkonto “aho dukkhaṃ, īdisaṃ dukkhaṃ mayhaṃ attanopi mā hotū”tiādinā
analyzed: adhivāsetum a sakkontaḥ aho dukkham īdisam dukkham mayham attanaḥ api mā hotu uti ādinā
translated: it laments, saying, “Oh, what pain! May such pain not befall me!”

original: vippalapanto kevalaṃ attano rogaṃ vadati, tassa pana pahānāya na paṭipajjatīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: vippalapantaḥ kevalam attanaḥ rogam vadati tassa pana pahānāya na paṭipajjati iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The intention is that it speaks only of its own pain and does not strive to abandon it.

original: Atha vā taṃ yathāvuttaṃ dukkhaṃ yathābhūtaṃ ajānanto taṇhāgāhavasena “mama”nti saññāya
analyzed: atha vā tam yathāvuttam dukkham yathābhūtam a jānantaḥ taṇhā gāha vasena mamanti saññāya
translated: Or else, not knowing that pain as it really is, it speaks of it as “mine” through the assumption of craving,

original: attato vadati, “mama ida”nti vācaṃ nicchāreti.🔽Yena yena hi maññatīti evamimaṃ rogabhūtaṃ khandhapañcakaṃ attato attano vā vadanto
analyzed: vadati vācam  yena yena hi maññati iti evam imam roga bhūtam khandha pañcakam attataḥ attanaḥ vā vadantaḥ
translated: and it utters the words “This is mine.”🔽For when the world speaks of this fivefold mass, which is a mass of diseases, as “I” or “mine,”

original: loko yena yena rūpavedanādinā kāraṇabhūtena, yena vā sassatādinā pakārena diṭṭhimānataṇhāmaññanāhi
analyzed: lokaḥ yena yena rūpa vedanā ādinā kāraṇa bhūtena yena vā sassata ādinā pakārena diṭṭhi māna taṇhā maññanāhi
translated: through whatever cause, such as material form or feeling, or through whatever mode, such as eternal,

original: maññati. Tato taṃ hoti aññathāti tato attanā parikappitākārato taṃ maññanāya vatthubhūtaṃ🔽khandhapañcakaṃ aññathā anattānattaniyameva hoti. Vase vattetuṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya ahaṅkāramamaṅkārattaṃ🔽na nipphādetīti attho. Atha vā tatoti tasmā maññanāmattabhāvato taṃ khandhapañcakaṃ
analyzed: maññati tatas tam hoti aññathā ati tatas attanā parikappita ākārato tam maññanāya vatthu bhūtam  khandha pañcakam aññathā anatta anatta niyamā iva hoti vase vattetum a sakkuṇeyya tāya ahaṅkāra mamaṅkā rattam  na nipphādeti iti attho atha vā tatas ti tasmā maññanā matta bhāvato tam khandha pañcakam
translated: He imagines it to be otherwise. Then it is otherwise than that: then that pentad of aggregates, which is the basis of the imagining, is otherwise than that imagined mode, that is, it is not self, not not-self,

original: niccādivasena maññitaṃ aññathā aniccādisabhāvameva hoti. Na hi maññanā bhāvaññathattaṃ
analyzed: nicca ādi vasena maññitam aññathā anicca ādi sabhāvam eva hoti na hi maññanā bhāva aññathattam
translated: because it cannot be made to behave as he would have it behave. The meaning is that it does not produce the state of “I” and “mine.” Or alternatively, then it is otherwise than that: that pentad of aggregates imagined as permanent, etc., is otherwise than that, that is, it is impermanent, etc. For imagining cannot make it have the state of being existent or the state of being a different nature.🔽The being who is otherwise than that: the world of beings, which is attached to the non-existent, to the increase of the impossible, to welfare and pleasure, is otherwise than that, that is, it is not welfare and pleasure, it is harm and pain, it is only frustration,

original: vā lakkhaṇaññathattaṃ vā kātuṃ sakkoti.
analyzed: vā lakkhaṇa aññathattam vā kātum sakkoti
translated: even though it is imagined by the imagining in whatever way it likes.

original: Aññathābhāvī bhavasattoti asambhave vaḍḍhiyaṃ hitasukhe satto laggo sattaloko maññanāya🔽yathāruci cintiyamānopi viparītappaṭipattiyā tato aññathābhāvī ahitadukkhabhāvī vighātaṃyeva🔽pāpuṇāti. Bhavamevābhinandatīti evaṃ santepi taṃ maññanāparikappitaṃ avijjamānaṃ
analyzed: aññathābhāvī asambhave vaḍḍhiyam hita sukhe satto laggo satta lokaḥ maññanāya 🔽yathāruci cintiyamānaḥ api viparīta ppaṭipattiyā tatas aññathābhāvī ahita dukkha bhāvī vighātaṃ yeva 🔽pāpuṇāti bhavam eva abhinandati iti evam sante pi tam maññanā parikappitam a vijjamānam
translated: He delights in being itself: although it is like this, still the being who is otherwise than that, who is otherwise than the imagined state that does not exist,

original: bhavaṃ vaḍḍhiṃ abhinandati eva abhikaṅkhati eva. Atha vā aññathābhāvīti “nicco me🔽attā”tiādinā maññanāya parikappitākārato sayaṃ aññathābhāvī samāno anicco adhuvoti🔽attho. Bhavasattoti kāmādibhavesu bhavataṇhāya satto laggo gadhito. Bhavamevābhinandatīti
analyzed: bhavam vaḍḍhim abhinandati eva abhikaṅkhati eva atha vā aññathābhāvī iti niccaḥ me  attā ati ādinā maññanāya parikappita ākārataḥ sayam aññathābhāvī samānaḥ aniccaḥ a dhuvaḥ ti  atthaḥ bhava satto ti kāma ādi bhavesu bhava taṇhāya sattaḥ laggaḥ gadhitaḥ bhavam eva abhinandati iti
translated: He delights in and longs for growth of becoming. Or else, he is subject to change: he himself is subject to change from the mode of being conceived by the conceivings “permanent is my self,” etc. The meaning is: he is impermanent, unstable.

original: aniccādisabhāvaṃ bhavameva niccādivasena parāmasitvā, tattha vā adhimuttisaññaṃ taṇhādiṭṭhābhinandanāhi🔽abhinandati, na tattha nibbindati. Yadabhinandati taṃ bhayanti yaṃ vaḍḍhisaṅkhātaṃ🔽bhavaṃ kāmādibhavaṃ vā abhinandati, taṃ aniccādivipariṇāmasabhāvattā anekabyasanānubandhattā
analyzed: anicca ādi sabhāvam bhavam eva nicca ādi vasena parāmasitvā tattha vā adhimutti saññam taṇhā diṭṭha abhinandanāhi  abhinandati na tattha nibbindati yat abhinandati tam bhayanti yam vaḍḍhi saṅkhātam  bhavam kāma ādi bhavam vā abhinandati tam anicca ādi vipariṇāma sabhāva tā aneka byasana anubandha tā
translated: A being in becoming: he is a being, stuck, attached, to the kinds of becoming beginning with the sensual plane of becoming through craving for becoming. He delights in becoming: he delights in becoming, which is of the nature of impermanence, etc., by misapprehending it as permanent, etc., or else he delights in the perception of resolve therein through the delight of craving and views.🔽He does not become dispassionate towards it. What he delights in is fearful: what he delights in, namely, becoming called “growth,” or the kinds of becoming beginning with the sensual plane of becoming, is fearful in the sense of being extremely terrifying because of being the cause of becoming, which is of the nature of manifold misfortune and change, beginning with impermanence.

original: ca bhavahetubhāvato ativiya bhayānakaṭṭhena bhayaṃ. Yassa bhāyatīti yato jarāmaraṇādito
analyzed: ca bhava hetu bhāvataḥ bhayānaka ṭṭhena bhayam yassa bhāyati iti yatas jarā maraṇa āditas
translated: What he fears: from aging, death, etc.

original: bhāyati, taṃ jarāmaraṇādi dukkhādhiṭṭhānabhāvato dukkhadukkhabhāvato ca dukkhaṃ.🔽Atha vā yassa bhāyatīti bhavābhinandanena yassa vibhavassa bhāyati, so ucchedasaṅkhāto
analyzed: bhāyati tam jarā maraṇa ādi dukkha adhiṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ dukkha dukkha bhāvataḥ ca dukkham  atha vā yassa bhāyati iti bhava abhinandanena yassa vibhavassa bhāyati saḥ uccheda saṅkhāto
translated: and that is suffering because it is the basis for the suffering of suffering, etc.,

original: vibhavo, tato bhāyanañca dukkhavatthubhāvato jātiādidukkhassa anativattanato ca dukkhaṃ🔽dukkhasabhāvamevāti attho. Atha vā yassa bhāyati taṃ dukkhanti yassa aniccādikassa
analyzed: vibhavaḥ tatas bhāyanam ca dukkha vatthu bhāvataḥ jāti ādi dukkhassa an ativattanato ca dukkham  dukkha sabhāvam eva ati atthaḥ atha vā yassa bhāyati tam dukkhanti yassa anicca ādikassa
translated: Or else, “that which one fears” is the non-existence called “passing away” that one fears through delight in existence. That is suffering because it is the basis for suffering and because one does not escape the suffering of birth, etc.🔽The meaning is that it has the nature of suffering. Or else, “that which one fears is suffering” means that one who does not know the escape from impermanence, etc.,

original: bhāyati taṃ nissaraṇaṃ ajānanto, taṃ bhayaṃ tassa dukkhaṃ hoti, dukkhaṃ āvahatīti attho.🔽Ettakena vaṭṭaṃ dassetvā idāni vivaṭṭaṃ dassetuṃ, “bhavavippahānāya kho panidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ
analyzed: bhāyati tam nissaraṇam a jānantaḥ tam bhayam tassa dukkham hoti dukkham āvahati iti attho  ettakena vaṭṭam dassetvā idāni vivaṭṭam dassetum bhava vippahānāya kho panidam brahmacariyam
translated: which one fears, has suffering from that fear. The meaning is that he brings suffering upon himself.🔽Having shown the round of existence by this much, he now said, “This holy life, bhikkhus, is lived for the abandoning of lust,”

original: vussatī”ti āha. Tattha bhavavippahānāyāti kāmādibhavassa pajahanatthāya. Khoti avadhāraṇe,
analyzed: vussati iti āha tattha bhava vippahānāya ati kāma ādi bhavassa pajahana tthāya kho ti avadhāraṇe
translated: in order to show the breaking of the round. Herein, for the abandoning of lust means for the purpose of abandoning lust for sensual desires, etc. Kho is a particle meaning “in truth.”

original: panāti padapūraṇe nipāto. Idanti āsannapaccakkhavacanaṃ. Brahmacariyanti maggabrahmacariyaṃ.
analyzed: pana ati pada pūraṇe nipātaḥ idam ti āsanna paccakkha vacanam brahmacariyan ti magga brahmacariyam
translated: Panā ti is a particle for filling out the line. Idan ti is a word for something near at hand and evident. Brahmacariyan ti is the path of the holy life.

original: Vussatīti pūressati. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – ekanteneva kāmādibhavassa samudayappahānena
analyzed: vussati iti idam vuttam hoti ekantena iva kāma ādi bhavassa samudaya ppahānena
translated: Vussatī ti will fulfil. This is what is said: by the complete abandoning of sense desires, etc.,🔽and for the sake of the complete abandoning of all becoming,

original: anavasesapajahanatthāya idaṃ mayā satasahassakappādhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni atidukkarāni
analyzed: anavasesa pajahana tthāya idam mayā sata sahassa kappa adhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni ati dukkarāni
translated: after having practised for four incalculable aeons and 100,000 aeons the perfections which are very difficult to practise,🔽and after having attained the holy life of the eight-factored path which is included in the three aggregates of morality, etc.,

original: ācaritvā pāramiyo pūretvā bodhimaṇḍe tiṇṇaṃ mārānaṃ matthakaṃ madditvā adhigataṃ
analyzed: ācaritvā pāramiyaḥ pūretvā bodhimaṇḍe tiṇṇam mārānam matthakam madditvā adhigatam
translated: and after having crushed the heads of the three enemies on the terrace of enlightenment,

original: sīlādikkhandhattayasaṅgahaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikamaggabrahmacariyaṃ cariyati bhāviyatīti.🔽Evaṃ ariyamaggassa ekaṃseneva niyyānikabhāvaṃ dassetvā idāni aññamaggassa tadabhāvaṃ
analyzed: sīla ādi kkhandha ttaya saṅgaham aṭṭhaṅgika magga brahmacariyam cariyati bhāviyati iti  evam ariya maggassa ekaṃsena iva niyyānika bhāvam dassetvā idāni añña maggassa tad abhāvam
translated: I will practise this holy life of the eight-factored path, I will develop it.🔽Having thus shown by the complete abandoning of sense desires, etc.,

original: dassento “ye hi kecī”tiādimāha. Tattha yeti aniyamaniddeso. Hīti nipātamattaṃ. Kecīti
analyzed: dassentaḥ ye hi keci iti ādim āha tattha ye iti aniyama niddesaḥ hi iti nipāta mattam keci iti
translated: the complete deliverance of the noble path, now in order to show the absence of that in another path he says: “Ye hi keci,” etc. Herein, ye hi keci is an indefinite expression. Hi is merely a particle. Keci is

original: ekacce. Padadvayenāpi tathāvādino diṭṭhigatike aniyamato pariyādiyati. Samaṇāti pabbajjūpagamanamattena
analyzed: ekacce pada dvayena api tathāvādinaḥ diṭṭhigatike aniyamataḥ samaṇa ti pabbajjūpagamana mattena
translated: and some. By the two phrases he includes those who hold such views indiscriminately. Ascetics: they are ascetics in the mere sense of having gone forth,

original: samaṇā, na samitapāpā. Brāhmaṇāti jātimattena brāhmaṇā, na bāhitapāpā. Vāsaddo vikappattho.
analyzed: samaṇāḥ na samita pāpāḥ brāhmaṇāḥ ati jātimattena brāhmaṇāḥ na vā saddaḥ vikappa atthaḥ
translated: not in the sense of having quelled evil. Brahmins: they are brahmins in the mere sense of being of twice-born caste, not in the sense of having expelled evil. The word “dwell” has the sense of a choice.

original: Bhavena bhavassa vippamokkhamāhaṃsūti ekacce kāmabhavena rūpabhavena vā sabbabhavato
analyzed: bhavena bhavassa vippamokkham āhaṃsu iti ekacce kāma bhavena rūpa bhavena vā sabba bhavataḥ
translated: They say that by existence there is deliverance from existence: some teach that deliverance from all existence is to be attained by means of the existence of the fine-material sphere or the immaterial sphere.

original: vimuttiṃ saṃsārasuddhiṃ kathayiṃsu.
analyzed: vimuttim saṃsāra suddhim kathayiṃsu
translated: They teach that purification is to be attained in the round of rebirths.

original: Ke panevaṃ vadantīti? Diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādino tesu hi keci “uḷārehi pañcahi kāmaguṇehi🔽samappito attā diṭṭheva dhamme paramaṃ nibbutiṃ patto hotī”ti vadanti. Keci “rūpāvacarajjhānesu🔽paṭhamajjhānasamaṅgī…pe… keci “dutiyatatiyacatutthajjhānasamaṅgī attā diṭṭheva dhamme
analyzed: ke pana evam vadanti iti diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādino tesu hi keci uḷārehi pañcahi kāmaguṇehi  samappitaḥ attā diṭṭhe iva dhamme paramam nibbutim patto hoti iti vadanti keci rūpāvacara jhānesu  paṭhama jhāna samaṅgīpe keci dutiya tatiya catuttha jhāna samaṅgī attā diṭṭhe iva dhamme
translated: But who are they that say this? Those who teach the annihilation of the self in this very life. For some of them say that “The self, endowed with the five objects of sense pleasure,🔽attains supreme bliss in this very life.” Some say that “The self, endowed with the first jhāna, …

original: paramaṃ nibbutiṃ patto hotī”ti vadanti. Yathāha –
analyzed: paramam nibbutim pattaḥ hoti iti vadanti yathā āha
translated: Some say that “The self, endowed with the second, third, and fourth jhānas, attains supreme bliss in this very life.” As it is said:

original: “Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃvādī hoti evaṃdiṭṭhi ‘yato kho bho ayaṃ attā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito”’ti vitthāro.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā evaṃvādī hoti evaṃdiṭṭhi yatas kho bho ayam attā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitaḥ ti vitthāraḥ
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, some recluse or brahmin is a rationalist, a reasoner. He proclaims his view and declares his belief thus: ‘When a man enjoys the pleasures of the five cords of sense desire, it is then that he is happy here and now. ’ …

original: Te pana yasmā yāvadatthaṃ pītattā suhitāya jalūkāya viya ruhirapipāsā kāmādisukhehi
analyzed: te pana yasmai yāvadattham suhitāya jalūkāya ruhira pipāsā kāma ādi sukhehi
translated: But because they have drunk their fill, they are like leeches that are satiated with blood and have no desire for the pleasures of sense desire, etc.

original: samappitassa tassa attano kāmesanādayo na bhavissanti, tadabhāve ca bhavassa abhāvoyeva,
analyzed: samappitassa tassa kāma īsana ādayaḥ na bhavissanti tad abhāve ca bhavassa
translated: And because of that absence, there is no more renewed existence.

original: yasmiṃ yasmiñca bhave ṭhitassa ayaṃ nayo labbhati, tena tena bhavena sabbabhavato
analyzed: yasmin yasmin ca bhave ṭhitassa ayam nayaḥ labbhati tena tena bhavena sabba bhavataḥ
translated: And they say that this method of theirs is applicable to whatever kind of existence there is, and so they say that there is deliverance from all kinds of existence by means of existence.

original: vimutti hotīti vadanti, tasmā “bhavena bhavassa vippamokkhamāhaṃsū”ti vuttā. Yesañca🔽“ettakaṃ nāma kālaṃ saṃsaritvā bālā ca paṇḍitā ca pariyosānabhave ṭhatvā saṃsārato
analyzed: vimutti hoti iti vadanti tasmai bhavena bhavassa vippamokkham āhaṃsu iti vuttāḥ yesam ca  ettakam nāma kālam saṃsaritvā bālā ca paṇḍitā ca pariyosāna bhave ṭhatvā saṃsārato
translated: That is why it is said that they “proclaim deliverance from becoming by means of becoming. ”

original: vimuccantī”ti laddhi, tepi bhavena bhavassa vippamokkhaṃ vadanti nāma. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: vimuccanti iti te pi bhavena bhavassa vippamokkham vadanti nāma vuttam ha etam
translated: And those who hold the doctrine that “after roaming and wandering through so many thousands of eons one is delivered from suffering at the end, when one has reached the sum of life and growth” also proclaim deliverance from becoming by means of becoming. For this is said:

original: “Cullāsīti mahākappino satasahassāni yāni bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karissantī”ti.
analyzed: mahākappino sata sahassāni yāni bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantam karissanti iti
translated: “Eighty-four thousand great eons will the fools and the wise, after transmigrating and travelling through samsara, make an end of suffering.”

original: Atha vā bhavenāti bhavadiṭṭhiyā. Bhavati sassataṃ tiṭṭhatīti pavattanato sassatadiṭṭhi
analyzed: atha vā bhavena ati bhava diṭṭhiyā bhavati sassatam tiṭṭhati iti pavattanato sassata diṭṭhi
translated: Or else, “it will be” is the view of becoming. “It will be, it is eternal, it endures” is the view of eternalism because of occurrence.🔽The view of becoming is called the view of eternalism. Here, by the omission of the second part of the compound,

original: bhavadiṭṭhīti vuccati, bhavadiṭṭhi evettha uttarapadalopena bhavataṇhātiādīsu viya🔽bhavoti vutto. Bhavadiṭṭhivasena ca ekacce bhavavisesaṃyeva kilesānaṃ vūpasantavuttiyā
analyzed: bhavat iṭṭhi iti vuccati bhavat iṭṭhi eva itthā uttara pada lopena bhava taṇhā ati ādīsu  bhavaḥ ti vuttaḥ bhava diṭṭhi vasena ca ekacce bhava visesam yā iva kilesānam vūpasanta vuttiyā
translated: “becoming” is stated as in such passages as “craving for becoming” .🔽And because of the view of becoming, some imagine that a particular becoming, which is the state of the defilements’ temporary cessation

original: āyuno ca dīghāvāsatāya niccādisabhāvaṃ bhavavimokkhaṃ maññanti, seyyathāpi bako brahmā
analyzed: āyuno ca dīgha āvāsa tāya nicca ādi sabhāvam bhava vimokkham maññanti sā iyyathā api bakaḥ brahmā
translated: and the long duration of life, has the nature of permanence, etc., and is the liberation from becoming, just as did Baka Brahma.

original: “idaṃ niccaṃ, idaṃ dhuvaṃ, idaṃ sassataṃ, idaṃ avipariṇāmadhamma”nti avoca. Tesamevaṃ
analyzed: idam niccam idam dhuvam idam sassatam idam a vipariṇāma dhammanti avoca tesam evam
translated: “This is permanent, this is stable, this is eternal, this is not subject to change.”

original: viparītagāhīnaṃ anissaraṇe nissaraṇadiṭṭhīnaṃ kuto bhavavimokkho. Tenāha bhagavā
analyzed: viparīta gāhīnam anissaraṇe nissaraṇa diṭṭhīnam kutas bhava vimokkho tena āha bhagavā
translated: For those who grasp in this way, who have the view of liberation in what is not liberation, how can there be liberation from becoming? Therefore the Exalted One said:

original: – “sabbe te ‘avippamuttā bhavasmā’ti vadāmī”ti.
analyzed: sabbe te a vippamuttāḥ bhavasma ati vadāmi iti
translated: “I declare that all of them are not liberated from the world of becoming.”

original: Vibhavenāti ucchedena. Bhavassa nissaraṇamāhaṃsūti sabbabhavato niggamanaṃ nikkhantiṃ
analyzed: vibhavena ati ucchedena bhavassa nissaraṇam āhaṃsu iti sabba bhavataḥ niggamanam nikkhantim
translated: ‘In annihilation’: by annihilation. ‘Escape from existence’: the escape, the going out, from all kinds of existence,

original: saṃsārasuddhiṃ vadiṃsu. Te hi “bhavena bhavassa vippamokkho”ti vadantānaṃ vādaṃ ananujānantā🔽bhavūpacchedena nissaraṇaṃ paṭijāniṃsu. Vibhavenāti vā ucchedadiṭṭhiyā. Vibhavati🔽vinassati ucchijjati attā ca loko cāti pavattanato ucchedadiṭṭhi vuttanayena “vibhavo”ti
analyzed: saṃsāra suddhim vadiṃsu te hi bhavena bhavassa vippamokkho ti vadantānam vādam an anujānantā  bhava upacchedena nissaraṇam paṭijāniṃsu vibhavena ati vā uccheda diṭṭhiyā vibhavati  vinassati ucchijjati attā ca loko ca ati pavattanato uccheda diṭṭhi vutta nayena vibhavo ti
translated: they declared to be purification of the round of rebirths. For they did not agree with those who said that ‘escape is by means of existence’ .🔽They declared that escape is by the cutting off of existence.🔽‘In annihilation’: by the annihilation view. ‘Annihilation’ is said

original: vuccati. Ucchedadiṭṭhivasena hi sattā adhimuccitvā tattha tattha uppannā ucchijjanti,
analyzed: vuccati uccheda diṭṭhi vasena hi sattāḥ adhimuccitvā tattha tattha uppannāḥ ucchijjanti
translated: because of the occurrence of the annihilation view. For beings, having conceived the annihilation view, are annihilated, destroyed, cut off, in the various kinds of generation where they are reborn.

original: sā eva saṃsārasuddhīti ucchedavādino. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: sā eva saṃsāra suddhī iti uccheda vādinaḥ
translated: That is the purification of the round of rebirths, say those who hold the annihilationist view. For this is said:

original: “Yato kho bho ayaṃ attā rūpī cātumahābhūtiko…pe… nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā kho bho ayaṃ attā sammā samucchinno hotī”ti.
analyzed: yatas kho bho ayam attā rūpī cātumahābhūti kope na ivasaññānāsaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati ettāvatā kho bho ayam attā sammā samucchinnaḥ hoti iti
translated: ‘When this self, possessing form, made up of the four great primaries … enters and abides in the base of neither perception nor non-perception, it is then that this self is quite perfect and quite secure’ .

original: Tathā –
analyzed: tathā
translated: And:

original: “Natthi, mahārāja, dinnaṃ, natthi yiṭṭhaṃ natthi hutaṃ…pe… bāle ca paṇḍite ca kāyassa bhedā ucchijjanti vinassanti na honti paraṃ maraṇā”ti ca.
analyzed: natthi mahā rāja dinnam natthi yiṭṭham natthi hutaṃpe bāle ca paṇḍite ca kāyassa bhedāḥ ucchijjanti vinassanti na honti param ca
translated: “There is no gift, great king, no sacrifice, no burnt offering, no merit, no evil in action. … Fools and wise men alike, at the breaking-up of the body, are annihilated and perish, and do not exist after death.”

analyzed: vadāmi iti na hi ariya magga bhāvanāya anavasesa kilesam a samugghātetvā  kadāci pi bhavataḥ nissaraṇa vimutti sambhavati tathā hi tesam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam yathā bhūta avabodha abhāvataḥ

original: paṭipadaṃ samāruḷhā, tesaṃyeva bhavavippamokkho nissaraṇañcāti dassento satthā “upadhiṃ🔽hī”tiādimāha. Tattha upadhinti khandhādiupadhiṃ. Hīti nipātamattaṃ. Paṭiccāti nissāya,
analyzed: paṭipadam samāruḷhā tesam yeva bhava vippamokkhaḥ nissaraṇam ca ati dassento satthā upadhim  hi itiādim āha tattha upadhinti khandha ādi upadhim hi iti nipāta mattam paṭicca ati nissāya
translated: But those who, by discerning the four truths, have mounted the middle way which is free from the two extremes of eternalism and annihilationism, in regard to the origination, etc., of the five aggregates, for them alone is there deliverance from existence, escape from suffering.🔽Showing this, the Exalted One says, “With clinging as condition,

original: paccayaṃ katvā. Dukkhanti jātiādi dukkhaṃ. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti? Yatthime diṭṭhigatikā
analyzed: paccayam katvā dukkhanti jāti ādi dukkham kim vuttam hoti yattha ime diṭṭhi gatikā
translated: khandha-upadhi, etc. Hī means merely a particle. Paṭicca means depending on, taking as a condition. Dukkha means the suffering of birth, etc. What is meant? Where these theorists,

analyzed: vimokkha saññinaḥ tattha khandha kilesa abhisaṅkhāra upadhayaḥ adhigatā kutas tattha dukkha nissaraṇam
translated: who are under the sway of views, have attained a state of deliverance, there the aggregates, defilements, and volitional formations are clinging. How can there be escape from suffering there?

original: Yatra hi kilesā, tatrābhisaṅkhārasambhavato bhavapabandhassa avicchedoyevāti vaṭṭadukkhassa
analyzed: yatra hi kilesā tatra abhisaṅkhāra sambhavataḥ bhava pabandhassa vaṭṭa dukkhassa
translated: For where there are defilements, there volitional formations arise, and the continuity of the round of existence is unbroken. Thus there is no cessation of the suffering of the round.

original: anivatti. Tena vuttaṃ – “upadhiñhi paṭicca dukkhamidaṃ sambhotī”ti.
analyzed: anivatti tena vuttam upadhim hi paṭicca dukkham idam sambhoti iti
translated: Therefore it is said, “With clinging as condition, this suffering originates.”

original: Idāni yaṃ paramatthato dukkhassa nissaraṇaṃ, taṃ dassetuṃ, “sabbupādānakkhayā natthi
analyzed: idāni yam paramatthataḥ dukkhassa nissaraṇam tam dassetum sabba upādāna kkhayā na atthi
translated: Now, in order to show the escape from suffering in the ultimate sense, the Exalted One says, “With the remainderless fading away and cessation of clinging,” etc.

original: dukkhassa sambhavo”ti vuttaṃ. Tattha sabbupādānakkhayāti kāmupādānaṃ diṭṭhupādānaṃ
analyzed: dukkhassa sambhavaḥ ti vuttam tattha sabba upādāna kkhayā ti kāma upādānam diṭṭha upādānam
translated: Herein, all is exhausted means all is exhausted of the four kinds of clinging, namely, sense-desire clinging, wrong- view clinging,

original: sīlabbatupādānaṃ attavādupādānanti sabbesaṃ imesaṃ catunnampi upādānānaṃ ariyamaggādhigamena🔽anavasesappahānato. Tattha diṭṭhupādānaṃ sīlabbatupādānaṃ attavādupādānanti imāni
analyzed: sīla bbata upādānam attavād upādānam ti sabbesam imesam catunnam api upādānānam ariya magga adhigamena  anavasesa ppahānato tattha diṭṭha upādānam sīla bbata upādānam atta vāda upādānam imāni
translated: rules-and-vows clinging, and self-doctrine clinging, by the obtaining of the noble paths.🔽Herein, the three kinds of clinging, namely, wrong-view clinging, rules-and-vows clinging, and self-doctrine clinging,

original: tīṇi upādānāni sotāpattimaggena khīyanti, anuppattidhammataṃ āpajjanti. Kāmupādānaṃ🔽apāyagamanīyaṃ paṭhamena, kāmarāgabhūtaṃ bahalaṃ dutiyena, sukhumaṃ tatiyena, rūparāgārūparāgappahānaṃ
analyzed: tīṇi upādānāni sotāpatti maggena khīyanti anuppatti dhamma tam āpajjanti kāma upādānam  apāya gamanīyam paṭhamena kāma rāga bhūtam bahalam dutiyena sukhumam tatiyena rūpa rāga arūpa rāga pahānam
translated: are exhausted by the path of stream-entry and come to have no scope for action. Sense-desire clinging

original: catutthenāti catūhipi maggehi khīyati, anuppattidhammataṃ āpajjatīti veditabbaṃ.🔽Natthi dukkhassa sambhavoti evaṃ sabbaso upādānakkhayā tadekaṭṭhatāya sabbassapi
analyzed: catutthena ati catūhi pi maggehi khīyati anuppatti dhamma tam āpajjati iti veditabbam  natthi dukkhassa sambhavaḥ ti evam sabbasas upādāna kkhayā tad ekaṭṭhatāya sabbassa api
translated: is exhausted by the four paths. That is to say, it should be understood that the kind of sense desire that leads to the unhappy destination is exhausted by the first path; the gross kind of sense desire rooted in lust is exhausted by the second; the subtle kind is exhausted by the third; and the exhaustion of sense desire in the form of lust for the fine material and immaterial is by the fourth path.🔽There is no origin of suffering means that with the exhaustion of all clinging in this way, since there is no arising of any of the multitude of defilements that have that as their individual essence,

original: kilesagaṇassa anuppādanato appamattakassapi vaṭṭadukkhassa sambhavo pātubhāvo natthi.
analyzed: kilesa gaṇassa anuppādanataḥ appamattakassa api vaṭṭa dukkhassa sambhavaḥ pātubhāvaḥ natthi
translated: there is no origin, no manifestation, of even the slightest suffering due to the round of rebirths.

original: Evaṃ bhagavā hetunā saddhiṃ pavattiṃ nivattiñca dassetvā “imaṃ nayaṃ ajānanto ayaṃ🔽sattaloko vaṭṭatopi sīsaṃ na ukkhipatī”ti dassento “lokamimaṃ passā”tiādimāha. Tattha🔽lokamimaṃ passāti attano buddhacakkhunā paccakkhato visayabhāvassa upagatattā “lokamimaṃ
analyzed: evam bhagavā hetunā saddhim pavattim nivattiñca dassetvā imam nayam a jānantaḥ ayam  satta lokaḥ vaṭṭataḥ api sīsam na ukkhipati iti dassentaḥ lokam imam passa iti ādim āha tattha  lokam imam passāti attanaḥ buddha cakkhunā paccakkhataḥ visaya bhāvassa upagata ttā lokam imam
translated: Having thus shown the process of becoming together with its cause and the cessation of that process, the Exalted One now says, “Loke imaṃ passatha,” etc., in order to show that one who does not know this method “will not lift his head even from the world of beings, which revolves in the process of becoming.”

original: passā”ti bhagavādassanakiriyāya niyojento attānamevālapati. Puthūti bahū, visuṃ visuṃ
analyzed: passāti bhagavā dassana kiriyāya niyojentaḥ attānam eva ālapati puthu iti bahū visum visum
translated: Herein, “Loke imaṃ passatha” is the Exalted One’s own address to himself, urging himself to the act of seeing, “See this world.”🔽Puthū: many, various.

original: vā. Avijjāya paretāti “dukkhe aññāṇa”ntiādinā nayena vuttāya catusaccapaṭicchādikāya🔽avijjāya abhibhūtā. Bhūtāti kammakilesehi jātā nibbattā. Bhūtaratāti bhūtesu mātāpituputtadārādisaññāya
analyzed: vā avijjāya paretā ti dukkhe aññāṇa nti ādinā nayena vuttāya catu sacca paṭicchādikāya  avijjāya abhibhūtā bhūtā ati kamma kilesehi jātā nibbattā bhūta ratā ati bhūtesu mātā pitu putta dāra ādi saññāya
translated: Avijjāya paretā: overcome by ignorance, which is described in the way beginning, “The not-knowing of suffering” .🔽Bhūtā: born, produced, by kamma and defilements.

original: aññasattesu taṇhāya ratā, bhūte vā khandhapañcake aniccāsubhadukkhānattasabhāve taṃsabhāvānavabodhato
analyzed: añña sattesu taṇhāya ratāḥ bhūte vā khandha pañcake anicca asubha dukkha anatta sabhāve taṃ sabhāva anavabodhato
translated: Bhūtaratā: attached to beings, i.e., to other living beings, through craving, which is the notion of mother, father, son, wife, etc., in regard to them; or else, attached to the five aggregates, which are called “beings” , through the non-understanding of their impermanence, etc.

original: itthipurisādiparikappavasena niccādivasena attattaniyagāhavasena ca abhiratā. Bhavā
analyzed: itthi purisa ādi parikappa vasena nicca ādi vasena atta tta niya gāha vasena ca abhiratā bhavā
translated: They are attached to the world in the sense of being attached to the world of beings by way of the various kinds of beings such as women and men, etc., and by way of the eternal, etc., views, and by way of the grasping of self and what belongs to self.

original: aparimuttāti yathāvuttena taṇhādiṭṭhigāhena bhavato saṃsārato na parimuttā.🔽Ettha ca “lokamima”nti paṭhamaṃ tāva sakalampi sattanikāyaṃ sāmaññato ekattaṃ upanento
analyzed: a parimuttā ati yathā vuttena taṇhā diṭṭhi gāhena bhavataḥ saṃsārataḥ na parimuttā  ettha ca lokam imanti paṭhamam tāva sakalam pi satta nikāyam sāmaññato ekattam upanento
translated: Not freed from existence: not freed from existence, from the round of rebirths, by way of the grasping of craving and views as described above.🔽Herein, “this world” : first of all, the Teacher, by means of the singular number in “this world,” shows that he is taking the entire world of beings as one unit in general.🔽Then, by means of the plural number in “these beings,” he shows that he is taking the world of beings as a plurality of individuals, classified according to the various kinds of beings, etc., and the various kinds of world-systems, etc.

original: ekavacanena anodhiso gahaṇaṃ dīpetvā “svāyaṃ loko bhavayonigatiṭhitisattāvāsādivasena

analyzed: therassa vacanam sutvā upadhārentaḥ na tāva assa ñāṇam paripākam gata nti ñatvā paṭikkhipanto  evam āha ekakamhi tāva iti idam pana assa evam ayam gantvā api kamme a nipphajjamāne nirāsaṅkaḥ
translated: Having heard the elder’s words, the Teacher thought: “His knowledge has not yet matured.” Realizing this, he refused,

original: hutvā pemavasena puna āgacchissatī”ti cittamaddavajananatthaṃ āha. Yāva aññopi koci
analyzed: hutvā pema vasena puna āgacchissati iti citta maddava janana ttham āha yāva aññaḥ api koci
translated: saying: “Wait a little.” “Alone” means “alone with me.” But this was said in order to soften his mind, thinking: “If he goes and the work is not completed, he will return out of affection without any misgivings,

original: bhikkhu āgacchatīti añño koci bhikkhu mama santikaṃ yāva āgacchati, tāva āgamehīti
analyzed: bhikkhu āgacchati iti añño koci bhikkhu mama santikam yāva āgacchati tāva āgamehi iti
translated: thinking: ‘I have not seen the Teacher.’“ “Until another bhikkhu comes” means “until another bhikkhu comes to me.”

original: attho. “Koci bhikkhu dissatī”tipi pāṭho. “Āgacchatū”tipi paṭhanti, tathā “dissatū”ti.🔽Natthi kiñci uttari karaṇīyanti catūsu saccesu catūhi maggehi pariññādīnaṃ soḷasannaṃ
analyzed: attho koci bhikkhu dissati itipi pāṭhaḥ āgacchatu itipi paṭhanti tathā dissatu iti  natthi kiñci uttari karaṇīyanti catūsu saccesu catūhi maggehi pariññā ādīnam
translated: “Anyone” : the reading is also “Any bhikkhu?” “Let him come” : they also read “Let him be seen.”

original: kiccānaṃ katattā, abhisambodhiyā vā adhigatattā tato aññaṃ uttari karaṇīyaṃ nāma
analyzed: kiccānam kata ttā abhisambodhiyā vā adhigata ttā tatas aññam uttari karaṇīyam nāma
translated: There is nothing further to be done : because the sixteen duties beginning with full understanding have been done by the four paths in regard to the four truths, or because the supreme enlightenment has been reached, there is nothing further to be done called “higher” than that.

original: natthi. Natthi katassa vā paticayoti katassa vā puna paticayopi natthi. Na hi bhāvitamaggo🔽puna bhāvīyati, pahīnakilesānaṃ vā puna pahānena kiccaṃ atthi. Atthi katassa paticayoti🔽mayhaṃ santāne nipphāditassa sīlādidhammassa ariyamaggassa anadhigatattā tadatthaṃ
analyzed: natthi natthi katassa vā paticayo ti katassa vā puna paticayaḥ pi natthi na hi bhāvita maggo  puna bhāvīyati pahīna kilesānam vā puna pahānena kiccam atthi atthi katassa paticayaḥ ti  mayham santāne nipphāditassa sīla ādi dhammassa ariya maggassa anadhigata ttā tad attham
translated: There is no storing up of what has been done : there is no storing up again of what has been done. For a path that has been developed

original: puna vaḍḍhanasaṅkhāto paticayo atthi, icchitabboti attho. Padhānanti kho meghiya
analyzed: puna vaḍḍhana saṅkhātaḥ paticayaḥ atthi icchitabbaḥ iti attho padhānam ti kho meghiya
translated: has nothing more to do, nor is there anything more to abandon for those defilements that have been abandoned. There is storing up of what has been done : there is storing up, called “increasing,” of what has been produced in my continuity, namely, the states beginning with virtue, since the noble path has not been reached. The meaning is, it is to be desired.

original: vadamānaṃ kinti vadeyyāmāti “samaṇadhammaṃ karomī”ti taṃ vadamānaṃ mayaṃ aññaṃ kiṃ nāma vadeyyāma?
analyzed: vadamānam kinti vadeyyāma ati samaṇa dhammam karomi iti tam vadamānam mayam aññam kim nāma vadeyyāma
translated: As to “I am speaking of one who is devoted to the higher thought”: what else should I say of one who says “I am doing the recluse’s duty”?

original: Divāvihāraṃ nisīdīti divāvihāratthāya nisīdi. Nisinno ca yasmiṃ maṅgalasilāpaṭṭe🔽pubbe anupaṭipāṭiyā pañca jātisatāni rājā hutvā uyyānakīḷaṃ kīḷanto vividhanāṭakaparivāro🔽nisinnapubbo, tasmiṃyeva ṭhāne nisīdi. Athassa nisinnakālato paṭṭhāya samaṇabhāvo
analyzed: divāvihāram nisīdi iti divāvihāra tthāya nisīdi nisinnaḥ ca yasmin maṅgala silā paṭṭe  pubbe anupaṭipāṭiyā pañca jāti satāni rājā hutvā uyyāna kīḷam kīḍantaḥ vividha nāṭaka parivāraḥ  nisinna pubbaḥ tasmiṃ yeva ṭhāne nisīdi athassa nisinna kālataḥ paṭṭhāya samaṇa bhāvo
translated: He sat down for his day’s abiding. And as he sat down, he sat down on the very spot where, in the past, in the order of succession, he had sat down five hundred times as king and had played in the pleasure garden, surrounded by a retinue of various kinds of players.

original: vigato viya ahosi, rājavesaṃ gahetvā nāṭakaparivāraparivuto setacchattassa heṭṭhā🔽mahārahe pallaṅke nisinno viya jāto. Athassa taṃ sampattiṃ assādayato kāmavitakko
analyzed: vigataḥ viya ahosi rāja vesam gahetvā nāṭaka parivāra parivutaḥ seta chattassa heṭṭhā  mahā rahe pallaṅke nisinnaḥ viya jātaḥ athassa tam sampattim assādayataḥ kāma vitakkaḥ
translated: Then, from the moment he sat down, his state of being a recluse disappeared, and he became as though he had taken on the guise of a king, and he was as though he were seated under a white sunshade on a costly couch surrounded by a retinue of players.

original: udapādi. So tasmiṃyeva khaṇe sahoḍḍhaṃ gahite dve core ānetvā purato ṭhapite viya
analyzed: udapādi saḥ tasmin yā iva khaṇe sahoḍḍham gahite dve core ānetvā puratas ṭhapite
translated: Then, as he was enjoying that state, a thought of sensual pleasure arose in him. At that very moment he saw as though two thieves had been brought before him and were standing there,

original: addasa. Tesu ekassa vadhaṃ āṇāpanavasena byāpādavitakko uppajji, ekassa bandhanaṃ
analyzed: addasa tesu ekassa vadham āṇāpana vasena byāpāda vitakkaḥ uppajji ekassa bandhanaṃ
translated: and in him a thought of ill will arose in the form of an order to execute one of them, and a thought of cruelty arose in the form of an order to bind the other.

original: āṇāpanavasena vihiṃsāvitakko, evaṃ so latājālena rukkho viya madhumakkhikāhi madhughātako
analyzed: āṇāpana vasena vihiṃsā vitakkaḥ evam saḥ latā jālena rukkhaḥ viya madhu makkhikāhi madhu ghātako
translated: Thus he was like a tree with a net of creepers, like a honey tree with bees.

original: viya ca akusalavitakkehi parikkhitto samparikiṇṇo ahosi. Taṃ sandhāya “atha kho āyasmato🔽meghiyassā”tiādi vuttaṃ.🔽Acchariyaṃ vata bhoti garahaṇacchariyaṃ nāma kiretaṃ yathā āyasmā ānando bhagavato🔽valiyagattaṃ disvā avoca “acchariyaṃ, bhante, abbhutaṃ, bhante”ti. Apare pana “tasmiṃ
analyzed: viya ca akusala vitakkehi parikkhittaḥ samparikiṇṇaḥ ahosi tam sandhāya atha kho āyasmataḥ  meghiyassa atiādi vuttam  acchariyam vata bhoti nāma kiretam yathā āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavataḥ  valiya gattam disvā avoca acchariyam bhante abbhutam bhante iti apare pana tasmin
translated: and he was surrounded and hemmed in by unwholesome thoughts. In reference to this it is said: “Then the venerable Meghiya” .

original: samaye pupphaphalapallavādīsu lobhavasena kāmavitakko, kharassarānaṃ pakkhiādīnaṃ🔽saddassavanena byāpādavitakko, leḍḍuādīhi tesaṃ paṭibāhanādhippāyena vihiṃsāvitakko,🔽‘idhevāhaṃ vaseyya’nti tattha sāpekkhatāvasena kāmavitakko, vanacarake tattha tattha
analyzed: samaye puppha phala pallava ādīsu lobha vasena kāma vitakkaḥ pakkhi ādīnam  byāpāda vitakkaḥ leḍḍu ādīhi tesam paṭibāhana adhippāyena vihiṃsā vitakkaḥ  idha iva aham vaseyyanti tattha sa apekkha tā vasena kāma vitakkaḥ vana carake tattha tattha
translated: “How wonderful, venerable sir! How marvellous, venerable sir!” This is called the wonder of acceptance. But others say that at that time there was sensual-desire thought because of greed for flowers, fruits, and foliage, there was ill will because of hearing the cries of birds and beasts, there was cruelty because of the intention to ward them off with clods and so on,

original: disvā tesu cittadubbhanena byāpādavitakko, tesaṃ viheṭhanādhippāyena vihiṃsāvitakko
analyzed: disvā tesu citta dubbhanena byāpāda vitakko tesam viheṭhana adhippāyena vihiṃsā vitakko
translated: there was sensual-desire thought because of the wish to live there with attachment to the place, there was ill will because of the arousal of aversion on seeing forest-dwellers here and there, there was cruelty because of the intention to harm them,

original: tassa uppajjī”tipi vadanti. Yathā vā tathā vā tassa micchāvitakkuppattiyeva acchariyakāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: tassa vadanti yathā vā tathā vā tassa micchā vitakka uppattiyā iva acchariya kāraṇam
translated: and it arose in him.” Or they say: “It arose in him.” In any case, the arising of that wrong thought is the wonderful thing.

original: Anvāsattāti anulaggā vokiṇṇā. Attani garumhi ca ekattepi bahuvacanaṃ dissati. “Anusanto”tipi pāṭho.
analyzed: anvāsattā ati anulaggā vokiṇṇā attani garumhi ca ekatte pi bahuvacanam dissati anusantaḥ iti pi pāṭhaḥ
translated: Anvāsattā = anulaggā, vokiṇṇā. The plural is seen in attani garuṃ and ekattepi. The reading is also anusanto.

original: Yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamīti evaṃ micchāvitakkehi samparikiṇṇo kammaṭṭhānasappāyaṃ
analyzed: yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamīti evam micchā vitakkehi samparikiṇṇaḥ kammaṭṭhāna sappāyam
translated: Yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami = having gone to the Blessed One in this way, having been surrounded by wrong thoughts,🔽unable to do the meditation subject,

original: kātuṃ asakkonto “idaṃ vata disvā dīghadassī bhagavā paṭisedhesī”ti sallakkhetvā “imaṃ
analyzed: kātum a sakkontaḥ idam vata disvā dīghadassī bhagavā paṭisedhesi iti sallakkhetvā imaṃ
translated: thinking: “The far-seeing Blessed One will have prohibited this,”

original: kāraṇaṃ dasabalassa ārocessāmī”ti nisinnāsanato vuṭṭhāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami.
analyzed: kāraṇam dasabalassa ārocessāmi iti nisinna āsanataḥ vuṭṭhāya yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami
translated: having got up from the seat on which he was sitting, thinking: “I will tell the one of ten powers this reason,” he went to the Blessed One.

original: Upasaṅkamitvā ca “idha mayhaṃ, bhante”tiādinā attano pavattiṃ ārocesi.
analyzed: upasaṅkamitvā ca idha mayham bhante iti ādinā attanaḥ pavattim ārocesi
translated: And having approached, he told his own story with “Here, venerable Sir,” and so on.

original: Tattha yebhuyyenāti bahulaṃ abhikkhaṇaṃ. Pāpakāti lāmakā. Akusalāti akosallasambhūtā.
analyzed: tattha yebhuyyena ati bahulam abhikkhaṇam pāpakā ati lāmakā akusalā ati akosalla sambhūtā
translated: Tattha yebhuyyenā = bahulaṃ abhikkhaṇaṃ. Pāpakā = lāmakā. Akusalā = akosallasambhūtā.

original: Duggatisampāpanaṭṭhena vā pāpakā, kusalapaṭipakkhatāya akusalā. Vitakketi ūhati ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: duggati sampāpana ṭṭhena vā pāpakā kusala paṭipakkha tāya akusalā vitakketi ūhati ārammaṇam
translated: Or, they are pāpakā in the sense of leading to bad destinations, and akusalā in the sense of being the opposite of kusala. Vitakketi = ūhati ārammaṇaṃ

original: cittaṃ abhiniropetīti vitakko, kāmasahagato vitakko kāmavitakko, kilesakāmasampayutto🔽vatthukāmārammaṇo vitakkoti attho. Byāpādasahagato vitakko byāpādavitakko. Vihiṃsāsahagato
analyzed: cittam abhiniropeti iti vitakko kāma sahagataḥ vitakkaḥ kāma vitakko kilesa kāma sampayutto  vatthu kāma ārammaṇaḥ vitakko ti atthaḥ byāpāda sahagataḥ vitakkaḥ byāpāda vitakkaḥ vihiṃsā sahagataḥ
translated: Thinking is applied thought. Applied thought associated with sensual desire is applied thought of sensual desire. It is applied thought that has as its object a sensual-desire object. It is applied thought associated with the defilement of sensual desire.

original: vitakko vihiṃsāvitakko. Tesu kāmānaṃ abhinandanavasena pavatto nekkhammapaṭipakkho
analyzed: vitakkaḥ vihiṃsā vitakko tesu kāmānam abhinandana vasena pavattaḥ nekkhamma paṭipakkho
translated: Applied thought associated with ill will is applied thought of ill will. Applied thought associated with cruelty is applied thought of cruelty.

original: kāmavitakko, “ime sattā haññantu vā vinassantu vā mā vā ahesu”nti sattesu sampadussanavasena🔽pavatto mettāpaṭipakkho byāpādavitakko, pāṇileḍḍudaṇḍādīhi sattānaṃ viheṭhetukāmatāvasena
analyzed: kāma vitakkaḥ ime sattāḥ haññantu vā vinassantu vā mā vā ahesunti sattesu sampadussana vasena  pavattaḥ mettā paṭipakkhaḥ byāpāda vitakkaḥ pāṇi leḍḍudaṇḍa ādīhi sattānam viheṭhetu kāma tā vasena
translated: Herein, applied thought of sensual desire is opposed to renunciation and occurs as delight in sensual desires.🔽Applied thought of ill will is opposed to loving-kindness and occurs as a wish for the annihilation of beings.

original: pavatto karuṇāpaṭipakkho vihiṃsāvitakko.🔽Kasmā panassa bhagavā tattha gamanaṃ anujāni? “Ananuññātopi cāyaṃ maṃ ohāya gacchissateva,
analyzed: pavattaḥ karuṇā paṭipakkhaḥ vihiṃsā vitakko  kasmā pana assa bhagavā tattha gamanam anujāni an anuññātaḥ api ca ayam mama ohāya gacchissatā iva
translated: Applied thought of cruelty is opposed to compassion and occurs as a wish to hurt beings with sticks, stones, and so on.🔽Why did the Blessed One allow him to go? “He will go away leaving me, even though I do not allow it.

original: ‘paricārakāmatāya maññe bhagavā gantuṃ na detī’ti cassa siyā aññathattaṃ. Tadassa
analyzed: paricāra kāmatāya maññe bhagavā gantum na deti iti ca siyā aññathattam tat assa
translated: He will think, ‘The Blessed One does not allow him to go, as if he were fond of his attendant,’ and he will be upset.

original: dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvatteyyā”ti anujāni.
analyzed: dīgharattam ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvatteyya iti anujāni
translated: would lead to his harm and suffering for a long time.”

original: Evaṃ tasmiṃ attano pavattiṃ ārocetvā nisinne athassa bhagavā sappāyaṃ dhammaṃ desento🔽“aparipakkāya, meghiya, cetovimuttiyā”tiādimāha. Tattha aparipakkāyāti paripākaṃ🔽appattāya. Cetovimuttiyāti kilesehi cetaso vimuttiyā. Pubbabhāge hi tadaṅgavasena
analyzed: evam tasmin attanaḥ pavattim ārocetvā nisinne athassa bhagavā sappāyam dhammam desento  aparipakkāya meghiya cetaḥ vimuttiyā iti ādim āha tattha aparipakkāya iti paripākam  appattāya cetaḥ vimuttiyā ti kilesehi cetasaḥ vimuttiyā pubba bhāge hi tad aṅga vasena
translated: After he had thus told his own experience, he sat down. Then the Blessed One, teaching him the Dhamma suitable to it,🔽said: “Meghiya, if the deliverance of mind is not matured,

original: ceva vikkhambhanavasena ca kilesehi cetaso vimutti hoti, aparabhāge samucchedavasena
analyzed: ca iva vikkhambhana vasena ca kilesehi cetasaḥ vimutti hoti apara bhāge samuccheda vasena
translated: ‘Not matured’: not reached maturity. ‘Deliverance of mind’: the mind’s deliverance from defilements. For in the earlier stage the mind is delivered from defilements by way of the factors of the path and by way of suppression,

original: ceva paṭipassaddhivasena ca. Sāyaṃ vimutti heṭṭhā vitthārato kathitāva, tasmā tattha
analyzed: ca iva paṭipassaddhi vasena ca sāyam vimutti heṭṭhā vitthārato kathitā ava tasmā tattha
translated: and in the later stage by way of eradication and by way of appeasement. This deliverance has already been explained in detail below ,

original: vuttanayena veditabbā. Tattha vimuttiparipācanīyehi dhammehi āsaye paripācite pabodhite
analyzed: vutta nayena veditabbā tattha vimutti paripācanīyehi dhammehi āsaye paripācite pabodhite
translated: and so it should be understood in the way stated there. Therein, when the states that mature the deliverance of mind have matured and developed the mind,

original: vipassanāya maggagabbhaṃ gaṇhantiyā paripākaṃ gacchantiyā cetovimutti paripakkā nāma
analyzed: vipassanāya magga gabbham gaṇhantiyā paripākam gacchantiyā cetaḥ vimutti paripakkā nāma
translated: and when the deliverance of mind is taking the embryo of the path, is maturing,

original: hoti, tadabhāve aparipakkā.
analyzed: tad abhāve aparipakkā
translated: then it is called ‘matured’; if it is not so, it is ‘not matured.’

original: Katame pana vimuttiparipācanīyā dhammā? Saddhindriyādīnaṃ visuddhikaraṇavasena pannarasa dhammā veditabbā. Vuttañhetaṃ –🔽“Assaddhe puggale parivajjayato, saddhe puggale sevato bhajato payirupāsato, pasādanīye suttante paccavekkhato – imehi tīhākārehi saddhindriyaṃ visujjhati.🔽“Kusīte puggale parivajjayato, āraddhavīriye puggale sevato bhajato payirupāsato, sammappadhāne paccavekkhato – imehi tīhākārehi vīriyindriyaṃ visujjhati.
analyzed: katame pana vimutti paripācanīyāḥ dhammāḥ saddhi indriya ādīnam visuddhi karaṇa vasena pannarasa dhammāḥ veditabbāḥ vuttam ha etam  assaddhe puggale parivajjayataḥ saddhe puggale sevataḥ bhajataḥ payirupāsataḥ pasādanīye suttante paccavekkhataḥ imehi tīhākārehi saddhi indriyam visujjhati  kusīte puggale parivajjayataḥ āraddha vīriye puggale sevataḥ bhajataḥ payirupāsataḥ sammappadhāne paccavekkhataḥ imehi tīhākārehi vīriya indriyam visujjhati
translated: What are the things that ripen in deliverance? They should be understood as the fifteen things that purify the faculties of faith, etc., for it is said:🔽“When one avoids an unbelieving person and associates with, serves, and reverences a believing person, and when one reviews the discourses that inspire confidence, then through these three things the faith faculty is purified.🔽“When one avoids a person who is lazy and delights in laziness and associates with, serves, and reverences a person who is energetic and delights in energy, and when one reviews the right endeavours, then through these three things the energy faculty is purified.

original: “Muṭṭhassatī puggale parivajjayato, upaṭṭhitassatī puggale sevato bhajato payirupāsato, satipaṭṭhāne paccavekkhato – imehi tīhākārehi satindriyaṃ visujjhati.
analyzed: muṭṭhassatī puggale parivajjayataḥ upaṭṭhitassatī puggale sevataḥ bhajataḥ payirupāsataḥ sati paṭṭhāne paccavekkhataḥ imehi tīha ākārehi sati indriyam visujjhati
translated: “When one avoids an unmindful person and delights in negligence and associates with, serves, and reverences a mindful person and delights in recollection, and when one reviews the establishments of mindfulness, then through these three things the mindfulness faculty is purified.

original: “Asamāhite puggale parivajjayato, samāhite puggale sevato bhajato payirupāsato, jhānavimokkhe paccavekkhato – imehi tīhākārehi samādhindriyaṃ visujjhati.
analyzed: asamāhite puggale parivajjayataḥ samāhite puggale sevataḥ bhajataḥ payirupāsataḥ jhāna vimokkhe paccavekkhataḥ imehi tīhākārehi samādhi indriyam visujjhati
translated: “When he avoids the person without concentration, and associates with, cultivates, and frequents the person with concentration, and reviews the jhana factors and the deliverances, in these three ways the concentration faculty is purified.

original: “Duppaññe puggale parivajjayato, paññavante puggale sevato bhajato payirupāsato, gambhīrañāṇacariyaṃ paccavekkhato – imehi tīhākārehi paññindriyaṃ visujjhati.
analyzed: duppaññe puggale parivajjayataḥ paññavante puggale sevataḥ bhajataḥ payirupāsataḥ gambhīra ñāṇa cariyam paccavekkhataḥ imehi tīhākārehi paññindriyam visujjhati
translated: “When he avoids the person without understanding, and associates with, cultivates, and frequents the person with understanding, and reviews the practice of profound knowledge, in these three ways the understanding faculty is purified.

original: “Iti ime pañca puggale parivajjayato, pañca puggale sevato bhajato payirupāsato, pañca suttante paccavekkhato – imehi pannarasahi ākārehi, imāni pañcindriyāni visujjhantī”ti.🔽Aparepi pannarasa dhammā vimuttiparipācanīyā – saddhāpañcamāni indriyāni, aniccasaññā
analyzed: iti ime pañca puggale parivajjayataḥ pañca puggale sevataḥ bhajataḥ payirupāsataḥ pañca suttante paccavekkhataḥ imehi pannarasahi ākārehi imāni pañca indriyāni visujjhanti iti  apare pi pannarasa dhammāḥ vimutti paripācanīyā saddhā pañcamāni indriyāni anicca saññā
translated: “So when he avoids these five kinds of persons and associates with, cultivates, and frequents these five kinds of persons, and reviews these five discourses, in these fifteen ways these five faculties are purified.”🔽Fifteen ideas leading to deliverance: the five faculties beginning with faith, the five perceptions belonging to the cardinal stages of insight,

original: dukkhasaññā anattasaññā pahānasaññā virāgasaññāti imā pañca nibbedhabhāgiyā saññā,
analyzed: dukkha saññā anatta saññā pahāna saññā virāga saññā ati imā pañca nibbedha bhāgiyā saññā
translated: and the five perceptions belonging to the proximate stages of insight.

original: kalyāṇamittatā sīlasaṃvaro abhisallekhatā vīriyārambho nibbedhikapaññāti. Tesu vineyyadamanakusalo
analyzed: kalyāṇa mitta tā sīla saṃvaraḥ abhisallekha tā vīriya ārambhaḥ nibbedhika paññā ati tesu vineyya damana kusalaḥ
translated: Good friendship, virtue, restraint, being easy to correct, energy, and insight.🔽The Teacher, who is skilled in taming those who can be tamed,

original: satthā vineyyassa meghiyattherassa ajjhāsayavasena idha kalyāṇamittatādayo vimuttiparipācanīye
analyzed: satthā vineyyassa meghiya therassa ajjhāsaya vasena idha kalyāṇa mitta tā ādayaḥ vimutti paripācanīye
translated: taught the five qualities that ripen into deliverance to the Elder Meghiya, who was a disciple with potential,🔽saying: “Five qualities lead to the maturing of liberation.”

original: dhamme dassento “pañca dhammā paripākāya saṃvattantī”ti vatvā te vitthārento “idha,
analyzed: dhamme dassento pañca dhammā paripākāya saṃvattanti iti vatvā te vitthārentaḥ idha
translated: Then, in order to explain them in detail, he said:

original: meghiya, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto hotī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: meghiya bhikkhu kalyāṇa mittaḥ hoti itiādim āha
translated: “Here, Meghiya, a bhikkhu has good friends, good companions, good comrades.”

original: Tattha kalyāṇamittoti kalyāṇo bhaddo sundaro mitto etassāti kalyāṇamitto. Yassa sīlādiguṇasampanno
analyzed: tattha kalyāṇa mittoti kalyāṇaḥ bhaddo sundaraḥ mittaḥ etassa ati kalyāṇa mittaḥ yassa sīla ādi guṇa sampanno
translated: Herein, good friends are those who are good, excellent, fine,

original: “aghassa ghātā, hitassa vidhātā”ti evaṃ sabbākārena upakāro mitto hoti, so puggalo
analyzed: aghassa ghātā hitassa vidhātā ati evam sabba ākārena upakāraḥ mittaḥ hoti saḥ puggalo
translated: and helpful in every way, as in the passage: “A friend is a helper in sorrow, a helper in joy, a helper in adversity, a helper in prosperity.”🔽Such a person is a good friend.

original: kalyāṇamittova. Yathāvuttehi kalyāṇapuggaleheva sabbiriyāpathesu saha ayati pavattati,
analyzed: kalyāṇa mittaḥ uva yathā vuttehi kalyāṇa puggalehi iva sa biriyāpathesu saha ayati pavattati
translated: He is a good companion because he is with good people in all postures,🔽not without them.

original: na vinā tehīti kalyāṇasahāyo.Kalyāṇapuggalesu eva cittena ceva kāyena ca ninnapoṇapabbhārabhāvena
analyzed: na vinā tehi iti kalyāṇa sahāya ukalyāṇa puggalesu eva cittena ca iva kāyena ca ninna poṇa pabbhāra bhāvena
translated: He is a good comrade because he is inclined, bent, and directed towards good people both in mind and in bodily action.

original: pavattatīti kalyāṇasampavaṅko. Padattayena kalyāṇamittasaṃsagge ādaraṃ uppādeti.
analyzed: pavattati iti kalyāṇa sampavaṅkaḥ kalyāṇa mitta saṃsagge ādaram uppādeti
translated: he is called “one who has gone over to the bright side.”🔽The three terms arouse respect for the company of good friends.

original: Tatridaṃ kalyāṇamittalakkhaṇaṃ – idha kalyāṇamitto saddhāsampanno hoti sīlasampanno
analyzed: tatra idam kalyāṇa mitta lakkhaṇam idha kalyāṇa mittaḥ saddhā sampannaḥ hoti sīla sampannaḥ
translated: Herein, the characteristic of a good friend is this. A good friend is endowed with faith, virtue, learning, generosity,

original: sutasampanno cāgasampanno vīriyasampanno satisampanno samādhisampanno paññāsampanno.🔽Tattha saddhāsampattiyā saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ kammaphalañca, tena sammāsambodhihetubhūtaṃ
analyzed: suta sampanno cāga sampanno vīriya sampanno sati sampanno samādhi sampanno paññā sampanno  tattha saddhā sampattiyā saddahati tathāgatassa bodhim kamma phalam ca tena sammāsambodhi hetu bhūtam
translated: and wisdom.🔽Herein, through his endowment with faith he has confidence in the enlightenment of the Tathāgata and in the fruit of action, and so he does not abandon his devotion to beings, which is the cause of the Tathāgata’s enlightenment.

original: sattesu hitesitaṃ na pariccajati. Sīlasampattiyā sabrahmacārīnaṃ piyo hoti manāpo🔽garu bhāvanīyo codako pāpagarahī vattā vacanakkhamo, sutasampattiyā saccapaṭiccasamuppādādipaṭisaṃyuttānaṃ
analyzed: sattesu hita isitam na pariccajati sīla sampattiyā sabrahmacārīnam piyaḥ hoti manāpaḥ  garu bhāvanīyaḥ codakaḥ pāpa garahī vattā vacana kkhamaḥ suta sampattiyā sacca paṭiccasamuppāda ādi paṭisaṃyuttānam
translated: Through his endowment with virtue he is dear and agreeable to his companions in the life of purity,🔽and he is respected, revered, and honored by them. He reproves and censures those who need reproving and censuring, and he is capable of being admonished by them.🔽Through his endowment with learning he is a speaker of what is well-defined, systematic, and pertinent to the goal of holy living, and he is a repeater of the discourses consisting of such sayings as are deep and pertain to emptiness.

original: gambhīrānaṃ kathānaṃ kattā hoti, cāgasampattiyā appiccho hoti santuṭṭho pavivitto
analyzed: gambhīrānam kathānam kattā hoti cāga sampattiyāḥ appicchaḥ hoti santuṭṭhaḥ pavivitto
translated: Through his endowment with generosity he is few in his wishes and contented, and he is secluded, aloof from society.

original: asaṃsaṭṭho, vīriyasampattiyā āraddhavīriyo hoti sattānaṃ hitappaṭipattiyā, satisampattiyā
analyzed: a saṃsaṭṭhaḥ vīriya sampattiyā āraddha vīriyaḥ hoti sattānam hita paṭipattiyā sati sampattiyā
translated: He is not mixed up in his dealings with others. He is energetic in the practice of helping beings. He is mindful in the practice of the foundations of mindfulness.

original: upaṭṭhitassati hoti, samādhisampattiyā avikkhitto hoti samāhitacitto, paññāsampattiyā
analyzed: upaṭṭhita sati hoti samādhi sampattiyā avikkhittaḥ hoti samāhita citto paññā sampattiyā
translated: He is concentrated in the practice of the jhānas. He is wise in the practice of insight.

original: aviparītaṃ jānāti. So satiyā kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ gatiyo samanvesamāno paññāya sattānaṃ🔽hitāhitaṃ yathābhūtaṃ jānitvā, samādhinā tattha ekaggacitto hutvā, vīriyena satte
analyzed: a viparītam jānāti so satiyā kusalānam dhammānam gatiyaḥ samanvesamāno paññāya sattānam  hita ahitam yathābhūtam jānitvā samādhinā tattha ekagga cittaḥ hutvā vīriyena satte
translated: He investigates the courses of the profitable with mindfulness. He knows the profitable and unprofitable of beings

original: ahitā nisedhetvā hite niyojeti. Tenāha –
analyzed: ahitāḥ tena āha
translated: with understanding. He is one-pointed in mind in that practice with concentration. He removes the unprofitable and establishes beings in the profitable with energy. Therefore it was said:🔽“Dear, respected, and esteemed,

original: “Piyo garu bhāvanīyo, vattā ca vacanakkhamo;
analyzed: piyaḥ garu bhāvanīyaḥ vattā ca vacana kkhamaḥ
translated: A speaker, and one who listens,

original: Gambhīrañca kathaṃ kattā, no caṭṭhāne niyojaye”ti. ;
analyzed: gambhīram ca katham kattā no caṭṭhāne niyojayeti
translated: A talker on the deep, and not one who misleads.”🔽This is the first thing that leads to welfare,

original: Ayaṃ paṭhamo dhammo paripākāya saṃvattatīti, ayaṃ kalyāṇamittatāsaṅkhāto brahmacariyavāsassa🔽ādibhāvato, sabbesañca kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ bahukāratāya padhānabhāvato ca imesu pañcasu
analyzed: ayam paṭhamaḥ dhammaḥ paripākāya saṃvattati iti ayam kalyāṇa mitta tā saṅkhātaḥ brahmacariya vāsassa 🔽ādi bhāvato sabbesam ca kusalānam dhammānam bahukāratāya padhāna bhāvato ca imesu pañcasu
translated: This is the first of the five things called “living the holy life.”

original: dhammesu ādito vuttattā paṭhamo anavajjadhammo avisuddhānaṃ saddhādīnaṃ visuddhikaraṇavasena🔽cetovimuttiyā paripākāya saṃvattati. Ettha ca kalyāṇamittassa bahukāratā padhānatā
analyzed: dhammesu āditas vutta ttā paṭhamaḥ anavajja dhammaḥ avisuddhānam saddhā ādīnam visuddhi karaṇa vasena  cetaḥ vimuttiyāḥ paripākāya saṃvattati ettha ca kalyāṇa mittassa bahu kāra tā padhāna tā
translated: The first blameless state is mentioned first among the states beginning with faith, and it is the cause of the purification of those states that are not yet purified.🔽It is the condition for the maturing of the deliverance of mind.

original: ca “upaḍḍhamidaṃ, bhante, brahmacariyassa yadidaṃ kalyāṇamittatā”ti vadantaṃ dhammabhaṇḍāgārikaṃ,
analyzed: ca upaḍḍham idam bhante brahmacariyassa yat idam kalyāṇa mitta tā ati vadantam dhammabhaṇḍāgārikam
translated: And here the great and important part played by a good friend is to be understood as stated in the sutta: “Venerable sir, a good friend is the half of the holy life,”

original: “mā hevaṃ, ānandā”ti dvikkhattuṃ paṭisedhetvā, “sakalameva hidaṃ, ānanda, brahmacariyaṃ,
analyzed: mā ha ivam ānanda ati dvi khattum paṭisedhetvā sakalam eva hi idam ānanda brahmacariyam
translated: and the Blessed One, who is the treasure-house of the Dhamma, twice replied to Ananda, “Do not say that, Ananda,” and then said: “The whole of the holy life, Ananda, is the good friend.

original: yadidaṃ kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā”tiādisuttapadehi veditabbā.
analyzed: yat idam kalyāṇa mitta tā kalyāṇa sahāya tā ati ādi sutta padehi veditabbā
translated: The whole of the holy life, Ananda, is the good friend.”🔽Again, a further state: another state of dhammas. Virtue: in what sense is it virtue ?

original: Puna caparanti puna ca aparaṃ dhammajātaṃ. Sīlavāti ettha kenaṭṭhena sīlaṃ? Sīlanaṭṭhena
analyzed: puna ca paranti puna ca aparam dhamma jātam sīlavā ti ettha kenaṭṭhena sīlam sīlanaṭṭhena
translated: It is virtue in the sense of composing .

original: sīlaṃ. Kimidaṃ sīlanaṃ nāma? Samādhānaṃ, kāyakammādīnaṃ susīlyavasena avippakiṇṇatāti
analyzed: sīlam kim idam sīlanam nāma samādhānam kāya kamma ādīnam susīlya vasena a vippakiṇṇa tā ti
translated: What is this composing ? It is the non-diffusion of bodily action, etc., through the virtue of good conduct.

original: attho. Atha vā upadhāraṇaṃ, jhānādikusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ patiṭṭhānavasena ādhārabhāvoti
analyzed: atthaḥ atha vā upadhāraṇam jhāna ādi kusalānam dhammānam patiṭṭhāna vasena ādhāra bhāvaḥ ti
translated: Or alternatively, it is the support in the sense of being the foundation for the profitable dhammas such as jhana, etc.

original: attho. Tasmā sīleti sīlatīti vā sīlaṃ. Ayaṃ tāva saddalakkhaṇanayena sīlattho. Apare
analyzed: tasmā sīleti sīlati iti vā sīlam ayam tāva sadda lakkhaṇa nayena sīlatthaḥ apare
translated: Therefore it is virtue . This, firstly, is the word meaning of virtue in the sense of state.

original: pana “siraṭṭho sītalaṭṭho sīlaṭṭho saṃvaraṭṭho”ti niruttinayena atthaṃ vaṇṇenti.
analyzed: pana siraṭṭhaḥ sītalaṭṭhaḥ sīlaṭṭhaḥ saṃvaraṭṭhaḥ iti nirutti nayena attham vaṇṇenti
translated: But others explain the meaning of the word sīla in the sense of state as “coolness” , “wholesomeness” , “morality” , and “restraint” .

original: Tayidaṃ pāripūrito atisayato vā sīlaṃ assa atthīti sīlavā, sīlasampannoti attho.
analyzed: tayā idam pāripūritaḥ atisayataḥ vā sīlam assa atthi iti sīlavā sīla sampannaḥ ti attho
translated: And he who has virtue in the sense of state in abundance is called “virtuous” , which means “endowed with virtue” .

original: Yathā ca sīlavā hoti sīlasampanno, taṃ dassetuṃ “pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto”tiādimāha.
analyzed: yathā ca sīlavā hoti sīla sampanno tam dassetum pātimokkha saṃvara saṃvutaḥ iti ādim āha
translated: In order to show how he is virtuous, endowed with virtue, he said “Restrained by the restraint of the Pāṭimokkha” .

original: Tattha pātimokkhanti sikkhāpadasīlaṃ. Tañhi yo naṃ pāti rakkhati, taṃ mokkheti moceti🔽āpāyikādīhi dukkhehīti pātimokkhaṃ. Saṃvaraṇaṃ saṃvaro, kāyavācāhi avītikkamo. Pātimokkhameva
analyzed: tattha pātimokkham ti sikkhāpada sīlam tat hi yaḥ nam pāti rakkhati tam mokkheti moca iti  āpāyika ādīhi dukkhehi iti pātimokkham saṃvaraṇam saṃvaro kāya vācāhi avītikkamaḥ pātimokkham eva
translated: Herein, Pāṭimokkha means training precepts virtue. For that is the Pāṭimokkha in the sense of “protection” since it protects, guards,🔽those who practice it from the suffering of the states of loss, etc., and in the sense of “deliverance” since it delivers, liberates,

original: saṃvaro pātimokkhasaṃvaro, tena saṃvuto pihitakāyavācoti pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto,
analyzed: saṃvaro pātimokkha saṃvaro tena saṃvutaḥ pihita kāya vācā ti pātimokkha saṃvara saṃvutaḥ
translated: them from the suffering of the states of loss, etc. Restraint is restraint of the body and speech, non- transgression. The Pāṭimokkha itself is restraint, thus it is the Pāṭimokkha restraint. He is restrained by that, his body and speech are restrained, thus he is restrained by the Pāṭimokkha restraint.

original: idamassa tasmiṃ sīle patiṭṭhitabhāvaparidīpanaṃ. Viharatīti tadanurūpavihārasamaṅgibhāvaparidīpanaṃ.
analyzed: idam assa tasmim sīle patiṭṭhita bhāva paridīpanam viharati iti tad anurūpa vihāra samaṅgi bhāva paridīpanam
translated: This shows his being established in that virtue. He lives, he dwells, he continues, he maintains himself, he gets along, he carries on, is the meaning of the word viharati .

original: Ācāragocarasampannoti heṭṭhā pātimokkhasaṃvarassa, upari visesānaṃ yogassa ca upakārakadhammaparidīpanaṃ.🔽Aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvīti pātimokkhasīlato acavanadhammatāparidīpanaṃ. Samādāyāti
analyzed: ācāra gocara sampanno ti heṭṭhā pātimokkha saṃvarassa upari visesānam yogassa ca upakāraka dhamma paridīpanam  aṇu mattesu vajjesu bhaya dassāvī iti pātimokkha sīlataḥ a cavana dhamma tā paridīpanam samādāya ati
translated: “Endowed with virtue and resort” : this shows the quality that helps the lower restraint of the Patimokkha and the higher yogas.🔽“Seeing fear in the slightest fault” : this shows the quality of not transgressing the virtue of the Patimokkha.🔽“Having undertaken” : this shows the taking up of the training rules without exception.

original: sikkhāpadānaṃ anavasesato ādānaparidīpanaṃ. Sikkhatīti sikkhāya samaṅgibhāvaparidīpanaṃ.
analyzed: sikkhāpadānam anavasesataḥ ādāna paridīpanam sikkhati iti sikkhāya samaṅgi bhāva paridīpanam
translated: “He trains” : this shows the state of being endowed with the training.

original: Sikkhāpadesūti sikkhitabbadhammaparidīpanaṃ.
analyzed: sikkhāpadesu uti sikkhitabba dhamma paridīpanam
translated: “In the training rules” : this shows the quality that should be trained in.

original: Aparo nayo – kilesānaṃ balavabhāvato, pāpakiriyāya sukarabhāvato, puññakiriyāya ca
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ kilesānam balava bhāvataḥ pāpa kiriyāya sukara bhāvataḥ puñña kiriyāya ca
translated: Another method: because defilements are strong, because it is easy to do evil, and because it is difficult to do good,🔽the worldling is prone to fall into the lower realms many times.

original: dukkarabhāvato bahukkhattuṃ apāyesu patanasīloti pātī, puthujjano. Aniccatāya vā
analyzed: dukkara bhāvataḥ bahu kkhattum apāyesu patana sīlaḥ iti pātī puthujjanaḥ aniccatāya vā
translated: Or, because of impermanence,

original: bhavādīsu kammavegakkhitto ghaṭīyantaṃ viya anavaṭṭhānena paribbhamanato gamanasīloti
analyzed: bhava ādīsu kamma vega kkhittaḥ ghaṭīyantam viya anavaṭṭhānena paribbhamanataḥ gamana sīlaḥ ti
translated: he is tossed about by the force of kamma in the realms of existence like a potter’s wheel, and thus he is prone to wander about without rest.

original: pātī, maraṇavasena vā tamhi tamhi sattanikāye attabhāvassa patanasīloti vā pātī,
analyzed: pātī maraṇa vasena vā tamhi tamhi satta nikāye atta bhāvassa patana sīlaḥ ti vā pātī
translated: Or, because of death, he is prone to fall into different kinds of existence.

original: sattasantāno cittameva vā. Taṃ pātinaṃ saṃsāradukkhato mokkhetīti pātimokkhaṃ. Cittassa
analyzed: satta santānaḥ cittam eva vā tam pātinam saṃsāra dukkhataḥ mokkheti iti pātimokkham cittassa
translated: Or else it is the mental continuum itself. It is the “Pāṭimokkha” because it “sets free” that mental continuum from the suffering of the round of rebirths.

original: hi vimokkhena satto “vimutto”ti vuccati. Vuttañhi “cittavodānā sattā visujjhantī”ti,
analyzed: hi vimokkhena sattaḥ vimuttaḥ iti vuccati vuttam hi citta vodānāḥ sattāḥ visujjhanti iti
translated: For it is said that a being is “liberated” through the liberation of his mind. For this is said: “Beings are purified by the purification of mind” .

original: “anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimutta”nti ca.🔽Atha vā avijjādihetunā saṃsāre patati gacchati pavattatīti pāti, “avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ
analyzed: an upādāya āsavehi cittam vimuttanti ca  atha vā avijjā ādi hetunā saṃsāre patati gacchati pavattati iti pāti
translated: And: “His mind is liberated from the taints through not clinging” .

original: sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarata”nti hi vuttaṃ. Tassa pātino sattassa
analyzed: sattānam taṇhā saṃyojanānam sandhāvatam saṃsaratanti hi vuttam tassa pātinaḥ sattassa
translated: Or alternatively, it is “Pāṭimokkha” because it “sets free” from the round of rebirths, since it “sets down” , “makes it go,” “makes it travel,” in the round of rebirths by means of the cause, namely, ignorance, etc. For this is said: “Beings, hindered by ignorance, fettered by craving, wander here and there, going to rebirth in the various ways” .

original: taṇhādisaṃkilesattayato mokkho etenāti pātimokkho, “kaṇṭhekālo”tiādīnaṃ viya samāsasiddhi veditabbā.🔽Atha vā pāteti vinipāteti dukkhehīti pāti, cittaṃ. Vuttañhi “cittena niyyatī loko,
analyzed: taṇhā ādi saṃkilesa ttayataḥ mokkhaḥ etena ati pātimokkhaḥ kaṇṭhekālaḥ ti ādīnam viya samāsa siddhi veditabbā  atha vā pāteti vinipāteti dukkhehi iti pāti cittam vuttam hi cittena loko
translated: It is the “Pāṭimokkha” because it is the “setting free” of that being who is “set down” by means of the three defilements, namely, craving, etc. The compound should be treated as “neck-time,” etc.🔽Or alternatively, it is the “Pāṭimokkha” because it is the “setting free” of that mind which is “set down” , “made to fall,” “made to descend,” into suffering. For this is said: “The world is led by mind and drawn by mind” .

original: cittena parikassatī”ti. Tassa pātino mokkho etenāti pātimokkho. Patati vā etena apāyadukkhe
analyzed: cittena parikassati iti tassa pātinaḥ mokkhaḥ etena ati pātimokkhaḥ patati vā etena apāya dukkhe
translated: Or it is the “Pāṭimokkha” because it “sets down” that mind in the suffering of the states of loss.

original: saṃsāradukkhe cāti pāti, taṇhādisaṃkilesā. Vuttañhi – “taṇhā janeti purisaṃ, taṇhādutiyo
analyzed: saṃsāra dukkhe ca ati pāti taṇhā ādi saṃkilesā vuttam hi taṇhā janeti purisam taṇhā dutiyaḥ
translated: for it is said, “Craving generates the person, the person is accompanied by craving” , and so on.

original: puriso”ti cādi. Tato pātito mokkhoti pātimokkho.
analyzed: puriso ti ca ādi tatas pātitaḥ mokkho ti pātimokkho
translated: So it is “protection from falling” .

original: Atha vā patati etthāti pāti, cha ajjhattikabāhirāni āyatanāni. Vuttañhi – “chasu
analyzed: atha vā patati ettha ati pāti cha ajjhattika bāhirāni āyatanāni vuttam hi chasu
translated: Or alternatively, it falls here, thus it is a fall ; the six internal and external bases are so called, for it is said, “The world has arisen because of the six ,

original: loko samuppanno, chasu kubbati santhava”nti. Tato cha ajjhattikabāhirāyatanasaṅkhātapātito
analyzed: loko samuppannaḥ chasu kubbati santhavanti tatas cha ajjhattika bāhira āyatana saṅkhāta pātitaḥ
translated: the world makes contact because of the six” . So it is “protection from the fall” called the six internal and external bases.

original: mokkhoti pātimokkho. Atha vā pāto vinipāto assa atthīti pātī, saṃsāro. Tato mokkhoti pātimokkho.
analyzed: mokkho ti pātimokkho atha vā pātaḥ vinipātaḥ assa atthi iti pātī saṃsāro tatas mokkho ti pātimokkho
translated: Or alternatively, it has a fall, a downfall, thus it is a fall ; the round of rebirths is so called. So it is “protection from the fall” called the round of rebirths.

original: Atha vā sabbalokādhipatibhāvato dhammissaro bhagavā patīti vuccati, muccati etenāti🔽mokkho. Patino mokkho tena paññattattāti patimokkho, patimokkho eva pātimokkho. Sabbaguṇānaṃ
analyzed: atha vā sabba loka adhipati bhāvataḥ dhammissaraḥ bhagavā pati iti vuccati muccati etena ati  mokkhaḥ patinaḥ mokkho tena paññatta ttā ati patimokkhaḥ patimokkhaḥ eva pātimokkhaḥ sabba guṇānam
translated: Or alternatively, the Blessed One, as the Lord of Dhamma, is called “the fall” because he is the supreme controller of all the world; and it is “protection from the fall” because one is thereby released.🔽So it is “protection from the fall” in the sense of what is laid down by the fall.

original: vā tammūlabhāvato uttamaṭṭhena pati ca, so yathāvuttaṭṭhena mokkho cāti patimokkho,
analyzed: vā tad mūla bhāvataḥ uttama ṭṭhena pati ca saḥ yathāvutta ṭṭhena mokkho ca ati patimokkho
translated: Or alternatively, it is the fall in the sense of the supreme, because it is the root of all special qualities; and it is protection in the sense already stated. So it is “protection from the fall” .

original: patimokkho eva pātimokkho. Tathā hi vuttaṃ “pātimokkhantiādimetaṃ mukhameta”nti vitthāro.
analyzed: patimokkhaḥ eva pātimokkho tathā hi vuttam pātimokkha nti ādim etam mukham etan ti vitthāraḥ
translated: Pāṭimokkha is the same as pātimokkha. For this is said: “Pāṭimokkha is the beginning, the face, the front, the forerunner, the chief, the summit, the culmi-nation, the end, the conclusion, the consummation” .

original: Atha vā paiti pakāre, atīti accantatthe nipāto, tasmā pakārehi accantaṃ mokkhetīti🔽pātimokkhaṃ. Idañhi sīlaṃ sayaṃ tadaṅgavasena, samādhisahitaṃ paññāsahitañca vikkhambhanavasena🔽samucchedavasena ca accantaṃ mokkheti mocetīti pātimokkhaṃ. Pati mokkhoti vā patimokkho,🔽tamhā tamhā vītikkamadosato paccekaṃ mokkhoti attho. Patimokkho eva pātimokkho. Mokkhoti🔽vā nibbānaṃ, tassa mokkhassa paṭibimbabhūtoti patimokkho. Sīlasaṃvaro hi sūriyassa
analyzed: atha vā paiti pakāre ati iti accanta atthe nipāto tasmā pakārehi accantam mokkheti iti  pātimokkham idam hi sīlam sayam tad aṅga vasena samādhi sahitam paññā sahitam ca vikkhambhana vasena  samuccheda vasena ca mokkheti moceti iti pātimokkham vā patimokkhaḥ  tamhā tamhā vītikkama dosato paccekam mokkho ti attho patimokkhaḥ eva pātimokkhaḥ mokkho ti  vā nibbānam tassa mokkhassa paṭibimba bhūto ti patimokkhaḥ sīla saṃvaraḥ hi sūriyassa
