translated: Or alternatively, pā is a prefix meaning “in all ways,” and timokkha means “deliverance.” So pātimokkha means “deliverance in all ways.” For this virtue delivers in all ways by means of its own special qualities, and it delivers by means of the special qualities of concentration and understanding,🔽by suppression and by eradication, thus it is “deliverance in all ways” . Or alternatively, pātimokkha is the same as pāti-mokkha.

original: aruṇuggamanaṃ viya nibbānassa udayabhūto tappaṭibhāgo ca yathārahaṃ saṃkilesanibbāpanato.
analyzed: aruṇuggamanam viya nibbānassa udaya bhūtaḥ tad paṭibhāgaḥ ca yathāraham saṃkilesa nibbāpanato
translated: Pāti-mokkha means “deliverance from each transgression” . Pāti-mokkha is the same as pātimokkha. Or alternatively, mokkha is Nibbāna. Pātimokkha is so called because it is a reflection of that Nibbāna. For virtue as restraint is the rising of Nibbāna, a reflection of it, and a proper means for the extinguishing of defilements, like the rising of the sun and the rising of the dawn.

original: Patimokkho eva pātimokkho. Pativattati mokkheti dukkhanti vā patimokkhaṃ, patimokkhameva
analyzed: patimokkhaḥ eva pātimokkhaḥ pativattati mokkheti dukkhanti vā patimokkham patimokkham eva
translated: Pāṭimokkha is the same as pāṭimokkha. It is the pāṭimokkha because it is the going forth by the removal of faults, or because it is the going forth by the removal of suffering. Pāṭimokkha is the same as pāṭimokkha restraint.

original: pātimokkhanti evaṃ tāvettha pātimokkhasaddassa attho veditabbo.🔽Saṃvarati pidahati etenāti saṃvaro, pātimokkhameva saṃvaro pātimokkhasaṃvaro. Atthato
analyzed: pātimokkham ti evam tāva ittha pātimokkha saddassa atthaḥ veditabbo  saṃvarati pidahati etena ati saṃvaraḥ pātimokkham eva saṃvaraḥ pātimokkha saṃvaraḥ atthato
translated: This, in the first place, is how the word pāṭimokkha should be understood here.🔽It restrains, it constrains, thus it is restraint ; pāṭimokkha is the same as pāṭimokkha restraint. But in the sense of the avoidance of what should not be done, and in the sense of volition,

original: pana tato tato vītikkamitabbato viratiyo cetanā ca. Tena pātimokkhasaṃvarena upeto
analyzed: pana tatas tatas vītikkamitabbataḥ viratiyaḥ cetanā ca tena pātimokkha saṃvarena upetaḥ
translated: it is the avoidance of what should not be done and the volition in the act of avoiding it. He is endowed with, possessed of, provided with, that restraint of the Pāṭimokkha,

original: samannāgato pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvutoti vutto. Vuttañhetaṃ vibhaṅge –
analyzed: samannāgataḥ pātimokkha saṃvara saṃvuto ti vuttaḥ vuttam ha etam vibhaṅge
translated: thus he is said to be “possessed of the Pāṭimokkha restraint.” For this is said in the Vibhaṅga:

original: “Iminā pātimokkhasaṃvarena upeto hoti samupeto upāgato samupāgato upapanno samupapanno samannāgato, tena vuccati pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto”ti.
analyzed: iminā pātimokkha saṃvarena upetaḥ hoti samupetaḥ upāgato samupāgato upapanno samupapanno samannāgato tena vuccati pātimokkha saṃvara saṃvutaḥ ti
translated: “He is endowed with, possessed of, approached, possessed, of attained, provided with this restraint of the Pāṭimokkha. Hence ‘possessed of the Pāṭimokkha restraint’ is said” .

original: Viharatīti iriyāpathavihārena viharati irīyati vattati.
analyzed: viharati iti iriyāpatha vihārena viharati irīyati vattati
translated: He lives: he lives by means of the living of life by deportment, he conducts himself, he behaves.

original: Ācāragocarasampannoti veḷudānādimicchājīvassa kāyapāgabbhiyādīnañca akaraṇena sabbaso
analyzed: ācāra gocara sampannaḥ ti veḷu dāna ādim icchājīvassa a karaṇena sabbaso
translated: Possessed of good conduct and resort: by not doing wrong for gain like the Velaṭṭha householder, etc., and by not doing the kinds of bodily misconduct beginning with illicit sexual practice,

original: anācāraṃ vajjetvā “kāyiko avītikkamo vācasiko avītikkamo kāyikavācasiko avītikkamo”ti
analyzed: anācāram vajjetvā kāyikaḥ a vītikkamaḥ vācasikaḥ a vītikkamaḥ kāyika vācasikaḥ a vītikkamaḥ iti
translated: Having avoided misconduct, he is endowed with bodily conduct and verbal conduct that are pure.

original: evaṃ vuttabhikkhusāruppaācārasampattiyā, vesiyādiagocaraṃ vajjetvā piṇḍapātādiatthaṃ🔽upasaṅkamituṃ yuttaṭṭhānasaṅkhātena gocarena ca sampannattā ācāragocarasampanno.🔽Apica yo bhikkhu satthari sagāravo sappatisso sabrahmacārīsu sagāravo sappatisso
analyzed: evam vutta bhikkhu sāruppa ācāra sampattiyā vesiyā ādi agocaram vajjetvā piṇḍapāta ādi attham  upasaṅkamitum yutta ṭṭhāna saṅkhātena gocarena ca ācāra gocara sampannaḥ  apica yaḥ bhikkhu satthari sa gāravaḥ sa patissaḥ sabrahmacārīsu sa gāravaḥ sa patissaḥ
translated: Having avoided the wrong resort of courtesans, etc., he is endowed with the right resort in that he resorts to the right places, such as an alms-resort village for the sake of alms.

original: hirottappasampanno sunivattho supāruto pāsādikena abhikkantena paṭikkantena ālokitena🔽vilokitena samiñjitena pasāritena iriyāpathasampanno indriyesu guttadvāro bhojane
analyzed: hirottappa sampanno sunivatthaḥ supāruto pāsādikena abhikkantena paṭikkantena ālokitena  vilokitena samiñjitena pasāritena iriyāpatha sampannaḥ indriyesu gutta dvāraḥ bhojane
translated: Moreover, a bhikkhu who has respect and reverence for the Teacher, who has respect and reverence for the Dhamma, who has respect and reverence for the Saṅgha, who has respect and reverence for the training, who has respect and reverence for concentration, who has respect and reverence for heedfulness, who has respect and reverence for hospitality, who has respect and reverence for the elder bhikkhus, the middle-ranking bhikkhus, and the junior bhikkhus,

original: mattaññū jāgariyamanuyutto satisampajaññena samannāgato appiccho santuṭṭho pavivitto🔽asaṃsaṭṭho ābhisamācārikesu sakkaccakārī garucittīkārabahulo viharati, ayaṃ vuccati ācārasampanno.
analyzed: mattaññū jāgariya manuyutto sati sampajaññena samannāgataḥ appicchaḥ santuṭṭho pavivitto 🔽asaṃsaṭṭhaḥ ābhisamācārikesu sakkacca kārī garu cittīkāra bahulaḥ viharati ayam vuccati ācāra sampannaḥ
translated: who is possessed of shame and fear of wrongdoing, who is well-covered, well-clothed, who inspires confidence when going out and coming back, when looking ahead and looking aside, when drawing in and extending the limbs, who is perfect in proper conduct and resort, who guards the doors of the sense faculties, who is moderate in eating, who is devoted to wakefulness, who possesses mindfulness and full awareness, who is content,🔽who is secluded, aloof, and unentangled, who is strenuous, resolute, and dauntless, who is possessed of mindfulness and full awareness, who is calm and tranquil, who is composed and unified, who is heedful, who is possessed of energy, who delights in the practice of the special qualities, who is a good speaker, who is possessed of good speech, who is a good reciter, who is possessed of good recitation, who is a good repeater, who is possessed of good repetition, who is a good questioner, who is possessed of good questioning, who is a good instructor, who is possessed of good instruction, who is a good adviser, who is possessed of good advice, who is a good reprover, who is possessed of good reproof, who is a good punisher, who is possessed of good punishment, who is a good knower, who is possessed of good knowledge, who is a good observer, who is possessed of good observation, who is a good expounder, who is possessed of good explanation, who is a good bestower, who is possessed of good bestowal, who is a good controller, who is possessed of good control, who is a good leader, who is possessed of good leadership, who is a good inspirer of confidence, who is

original: Gocaro pana upanissayagocaro ārakkhagocaro upanibandhagocaroti tividho. Tattha yo
analyzed: gocaraḥ pana upanissaya gocaraḥ ārakkha gocaraḥ upanibandha gocaraḥ ti tividhaḥ tattha yaḥ
translated: The resort is threefold as the resort for support, the resort for protection, and the resort for dependence.

original: dasakathāvatthuguṇasamannāgato vuttalakkhaṇo kalyāṇamitto, yaṃ nissāya asutaṃ suṇāti,
analyzed: dasa kathā vatthu guṇa samannāgataḥ vutta lakkhaṇaḥ kalyāṇa mittaḥ yam nissāya asutam suṇāti
translated: Herein, the good friend who possesses the qualities of the tenfold basis for confidence and has the characteristics already stated is called the resort for support, since it is by relying on him that one hears what has not been heard,

original: sutaṃ pariyodāpeti, kaṅkhaṃ vitarati, diṭṭhiṃ ujuṃ karoti, cittaṃ pasādeti, yañca
analyzed: sutam pariyodāpeti kaṅkham vitarati diṭṭhim ujum karoti cittam pasādeti yat ca
translated: gets doubts resolved about what one has heard, straightens out one’s views, purifies his motives,

original: anusikkhanto saddhāya vaḍḍhati, sīlena, sutena, cāgena, paññāya vaḍḍhati, ayaṃ vuccati upanissayagocaro.
analyzed: anusikkhanto saddhāya vaḍḍhati sīlena sutena cāgena paññāya vaḍḍhati ayam vuccati upanissaya gocaro
translated: and, by training in the training precepts, increases in faith, virtue, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

original: Yo bhikkhu antaragharaṃ paviṭṭho vīthiṃ paṭipanno okkhittacakkhu yugamattadassāvī🔽cakkhundriyasaṃvutova gacchati, na hatthiṃ olokento, na assaṃ, na rathaṃ, na pattiṃ,
analyzed: yaḥ bhikkhu antara gharam paviṭṭhaḥ vīthim paṭipannaḥ okkhitta cakkhu yuga matta dassāvī  cakkhu indriya saṃvutaḥ iva gacchati na hatthim olokentaḥ na assam na ratham na pattim
translated: The bhikkhu who, when entering a village or town, goes along keeping his eyes directed to a plough yoke’s length in front,

original: na itthiṃ, na purisaṃ olokento, na uddhaṃ olokento, na adho olokento, na disāvidisaṃ
analyzed: na itthim na purisam olokentaḥ na uddham olokentaḥ na adhas olokentaḥ na disāvidisam
translated: looking neither to the right nor to the left, not looking at elephants, horses, chariots, pedestrians, women, men, boys, or girls,

original: pekkhamāno gacchati, ayaṃ ārakkhagocaro.
analyzed: pekkhamānaḥ gacchati ayam ārakkha gocaraḥ
translated: not looking up or down or in the intermediate directions, but keeping his eyes directed to a plough yoke’s length in front, is called one who resorts to protection.

original: Upanibandhagocaro pana cattāro satipaṭṭhānā, yattha bhikkhu attano cittaṃ upanibandhati, vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: upanibandha gocaraḥ pana cattāro sati paṭṭhānā yattha bhikkhu attanaḥ cittam upanibandhati vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: The “sphere of resort” in the sense of “binding to” is the four foundations of mindfulness, where the bhikkhu binds his mind. For this is said by the Blessed One:

original: “Ko ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno gocaro sako pettiko visayo, yadidaṃ cattāro satipaṭṭhānā”ti.
analyzed: kaḥ ca bhikkhave bhikkhunaḥ gocaraḥ sakaḥ pettikaḥ visayaḥ yat idam cattāraḥ sati paṭṭhānā ati
translated: “Bhikkhus, what is the bhikkhu’s resort, his own native place? It is these four foundations of mindfulness” .

original: Tattha upanissayagocarassa pubbe vuttattā itaresaṃ vasenettha gocaro veditabbo. Iti yathāvuttāya ācārasampattiyā, imāya ca gocarasampattiyā samannāgatattā ācāragocarasampanno.
analyzed: tattha upanissaya gocarassa pubbe vutta ttā itaresam vasena ittha gocaraḥ veditabbaḥ iti yathā vuttāya ācāra sampattiyā imāya ca gocara sampattiyā samannāgata ttā ācāra gocara sampannaḥ
translated: Herein, since the “sphere of resort” in the sense of “predominance” has already been mentioned, the “sphere of resort” in the other senses should be understood here as follows. So he is “accomplished in resort” because he possesses the accomplishment of resort in the way stated and the accomplishment of resort in the sense of “binding to.”

original: Aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvīti appamattakattā aṇuppamāṇesu assatiyā asañcicca🔽āpannasekhiyaakusalacittuppādādibhedesu vajjesu bhayadassanasīlo. Yo hi bhikkhu paramāṇumattaṃ
analyzed: aṇumattesu vajjesu bhaya dassāvīti appamatta kattā aṇuppamāṇesu assatiyā  āpanna sekhiya akusala cittuppāda ādi bhedesu vajjesu bhaya dassana sīlaḥ yaḥ hi bhikkhu paramāṇumattam
translated: “Seeing fear in the slightest fault”: in the case of faults that are slight because of being of little demerit, or that are slight because of being unintentional,

original: vajjaṃ aṭṭhasaṭṭhiyojanapamāṇādhikayojanasatasahassubbedhasinerupabbatarājasadisaṃ
analyzed: vajjam aṭṭha saṭṭhi yojana pamāṇa adhika yojana sata sahassu bbedha sineru pabbata rāja sadisam
translated: or that are slight because of being curable, or that are slight because of being expiable by confession, or that are slight because of being expiable by making amends, or that are slight because of being expiable by conscious recollection, or that are slight because of being expiable by recovery from wrong view, or that are slight because of being expiable by relinquishment, or that are slight because of being expiable by confession and relinquishment, or that are slight because of being expiable by the probation for a determined offence, or that are slight because of being expiable by the probation for an undetermined offence, or that are slight because of being expiable by the manatta discipline, or that are slight because of being expiable by the rehabilitation discipline, or that are slight because of being expiable by the higher penalty discipline, or that are slight because of being expiable by the further penalty discipline, or that are slight because of being expiable by the covering over as if with grass discipline, or that are slight because of being expiable by the covering over as if with grass discipline in the case of a past offender, or that are slight because of being expiable by the covering over as if with grass discipline in the case of a present offender, or that are slight because of being expiable by the covering over as if with grass discipline in the case of a future offender, or that are slight because of being expiable by the covering over as if with grass discipline in the case of a past and future offender, or that are slight because of being expiable by the covering over as if with grass discipline in the case of a

original: katvā passati, yopi sabbalahukaṃ dubbhāsitamattaṃ pārājikasadisaṃ katvā passati,🔽ayampi aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī nāma. Samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesūti yaṃkiñci
analyzed: katvā passati yaḥ api sabba lahukam dubbhāsita mattam pārājika sadisam katvā passati  ayam pi aṇu mattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī nāma samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu uti yaṃkiñci
translated: and he sees even a mere slip of speech as if it were a grave offence entailing expulsion.🔽He is called one who sees fear in the slightest fault.

original: sikkhāpadesu sikkhitabbaṃ, taṃ sabbena sabbaṃ sabbathā sabbaṃ anavasesaṃ sammā ādiyitvā
analyzed: sikkhāpadesu sikkhitabbam tam sabbena sabbam sabbathā sabbam anavasesam sammā ādiyitvā
translated: He trains in the training rules he has undertaken: whatever should be trained in, he trains in all of it, in every way, without exception.

original: sikkhati, pavattati paripūretīti attho.
analyzed: sikkhati pavattati paripūreti iti attho
translated: The meaning is that he practices, he carries out, he fulfills.

original: Abhisallekhikāti ativiya kilesānaṃ sallekhanī, tesaṃ tanubhāvāya pahānāya yuttarūpā.
analyzed: abhisallekhikā ati kilesānam sallekhanī tesam tanu bhāvāya pahānāya yutta rūpā
translated: It is conducive to letting go: it is conducive to the letting go of defilements by reducing them, by abandoning them.

original: Cetovivaraṇasappāyāti cetaso paṭicchādakānaṃ nīvaraṇānaṃ dūrībhāvakaraṇena cetovivaraṇasaṅkhātānaṃ🔽samathavipassanānaṃ sappāyā, samathavipassanācittasseva vā vivaraṇāya pākaṭīkaraṇāya
analyzed: cetaso paṭicchādakānam nīvaraṇānam dūrībhāva karaṇena cetaḥ vivaraṇa saṅkhātānam  samatha vipassanānam sappāyā samatha vipassanā cittassa iva vā vivaraṇāya pākaṭīkaraṇāya
translated: It is conducive to the opening up of the mind: by removing the hindrances, which conceal the mind, it is conducive to the opening up of the mind called serenity and insight.🔽Or it is conducive to the opening up of the mind of one whose mind is concentrated, to its becoming evident, to its being manifested.

original: vā sappāyā upakārikāti cetovivaraṇasappāyā.
analyzed: vā sappāyā upakārikā ati cetaḥ vivaraṇa sappāyā
translated: It is conducive to the opening up of the mind in this way.

original: Idāni yena nibbidādiāvahanena ayaṃ kathā abhisallekhikā cetovivaraṇasappāyā ca nāma
analyzed: idāni yena nibbida ādi āvahanena ayam kathā abhisallekhikā cetaḥ vivaraṇa sappāyā ca nāma
translated: Now, as to the question why this talk is called “conducive to letting go” and “conducive to the opening up of the mind,”

original: hoti, taṃ dassetuṃ “ekantanibbidāyā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha ekantanibbidāyāti ekaṃseneva
analyzed: hoti tam dassetum ekanta nibbidāya atiādi vuttam tattha ekanta nibbidāya ati ekaṃsena eva
translated: The words “for the sake of complete dispassion” are said to show that. Herein, for the sake of complete dispassion means for the sake of dispassion towards the suffering of the round of rebirths by means of the complete

original: vaṭṭadukkhato nibbindanatthāya. Virāgāya nirodhāyāti tasseva virajjanatthāya ca nirujjhanatthāya
analyzed: vaṭṭa dukkhataḥ nibbindana tthāya virāgāya nirodhāya ati tassa iva virajjana tthāya ca nirujjhana tthāya
translated: cessation of the round of rebirths. For the sake of dispassion and for the sake of cessation means for the sake of the fading away of that and for the sake of its cessation.

original: ca. Upasamāyāti sabbakilesūpasamāya. Abhiññāyāti sabbassāpi abhiññeyyassa abhijānanāya.
analyzed: ca upasamāya ati sabba kilesu upasamāya abhiññāya ati sabbassa api abhiññeyyassa abhijānanāya
translated: For the sake of peace means for the sake of the peace of all defilements. For the sake of direct knowledge means for the sake of the direct knowledge of all that is to be directly known.

original: Sambodhāyāti catumaggasambodhāya. Nibbānāyāti anupādisesanibbānāya. Etesu hi ādito🔽tīhi padehi vipassanā vuttā, dvīhi maggo, dvīhi nibbānaṃ vuttaṃ. Samathavipassanā
analyzed: sambodhāya ati catu magga sambodhāya nibbānāya ati anupādisesa nibbānāya etesu hi āditas  tīhi padehi vipassanā vuttā dvīhi maggaḥ dvīhi nibbānam vuttam samatha vipassanā
translated: For the sake of enlightenment means for the sake of the enlightenment of the four paths. For the sake of Nibbāna means for the sake of Nibbāna without residue of clinging. For the first three terms here

original: ādiṃ katvā nibbānapariyosāno ayaṃ sabbo uttarimanussadhammo dasakathāvatthulābhino sijjhatīti dasseti.
analyzed: ādim katvā nibbāna pariyosānaḥ ayam sabbaḥ uttari manussa dhammo dasa kathā vatthu lābhinaḥ sijjhati iti dasseti
translated: insight is intended, for the next two the path, and for the last two Nibbāna. He shows that this whole supramundane state, which begins with serenity and insight and ends with Nibbāna, is accomplished by one who has attained the ten powers of the kinds of knowledge described in the ten chapters.

original: Idāni taṃ kathaṃ vibhajitvā dassento “appicchakathā”tiādimāha. Tattha appicchoti
analyzed: idāni tam katham vibhajitvā dassentaḥ appiccha kathā ati ādim āha tattha appiccho ti
translated: Now, in order to show that tenfold discussion by analyzing it, he said “The discussion of fewness of wishes,” and so on. Herein, fewness of wishes is

original: na iccho, tassa kathā appicchakathā, appicchabhāvappaṭisaṃyuttā kathā vā appicchakathā.
analyzed: na iccho tassa kathā appiccha kathā appiccha bhāva paṭisaṃyuttā kathā vā appiccha kathā
translated: The talk of one who is not greedy is talk about fewness of wishes, or it is talk connected with the state of fewness of wishes.

original: Ettha ca atriccho pāpiccho mahiccho appicchoti icchāvasena cattāro puggalā. Tesu
analyzed: ettha ca atricchaḥ pāpicchaḥ mahicchaḥ appicchaḥ iti icchā vasena cattāro puggalā tesu
translated: And here there are four kinds of persons according to their wishes, that is to say, the greedy, the hateful, the deluded, and the ungreedy.

original: attanā yathāladdhena lābhena atitto uparūpari lābhaṃ icchanto atriccho nāma. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –
analyzed: attanā yathā laddhena lābhena atittaḥ upari upari lābham icchantaḥ atricchaḥ nāma yam sandhāya vuttam
translated: The greedy person is one who is not satisfied with the gain he has already got and is greedy for more. It is of him that it is said:🔽“From four to eight, from eight to sixteen,

original: “Catubbhi aṭṭhajjhagamā, aṭṭhabhi cāpi soḷasa;🔽Soḷasabhi ca dvattiṃsa, atricchaṃ cakkamāsado;
analyzed: catubbhi ca api soḷasa  ca dvattiṃsa
translated: From sixteen to thirty-two,🔽The wheel of greed turns round,

original: Icchāhatassa posassa, cakkaṃ bhamati matthake”ti. ;
analyzed: icchā hatassa posassa cakkam bhamati matthaka iti
translated: And on the greedy man it turns.”🔽“The greedy man, the greedy man,

original: “Atricchā atilobhena, atilobhamadena cā”ti ca. ;
analyzed: ati lobhena ati lobha madena ca ati ca
translated: The greedy man is overcome by greed” .

original: Lābhasakkārasilokanikāmayatāya asantaguṇasambhāvanādhippāyo pāpiccho. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –
analyzed: lābha sakkāra siloka nikāmaya tāya asanta guṇa sambhāvanā adhippāyaḥ pāpa icchaḥ yam sandhāya vuttam
translated: The hateful person is one who, because of craving for gain, honour, and renown, is bent on making others appear as if they had non-existent good qualities. It is of him that it is said:

original: “Tattha katamā kuhanā? Lābhasakkārasilokasannissitassa pāpicchassa icchāpakatassa paccayappaṭisevanasaṅkhātena vā sāmantajappitena vā iriyāpathassa vā aṭhapanā”tiādi.
analyzed: tattha katamā kuhanā lābha sakkāra siloka sannissitassa pāpicchassa icchā pakatassa paccaya paṭisevana saṅkhātena vā sāmanta jappitena vā iriyāpathassa vā aṭhapana atiādi
translated: “Herein, what is dissimulation? It is the concealing of one’s real character by one who is a prey to evil wishes and is intent on gain, honour and renown, by means of indirect talk or by keeping one’s real intentions secret” .

original: Santaguṇasambhāvanādhippāyo paṭiggahaṇe amattaññū mahiccho. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –
analyzed: santa guṇa sambhāvanā adhippāyaḥ paṭiggahaṇe amattaññū mahicchaḥ yam sandhāya vuttam
translated: He is not moderate in accepting requisites and is greedy for gain, honour and renown because he is bent on being considered to have the qualities of holiness. It is said of him:

original: “Idhekacco saddho samāno ‘saddhoti maṃ jano jānātū’ti icchati, sīlavā samāno ‘sīlavāti maṃ jano jānātū’ti icchatī”tiādi.
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ saddhaḥ samānaḥ saddhaḥ iti mama janaḥ jānātu iti icchati sīlavā samānaḥ sīlavā ati mama janaḥ jānātu iti icchati itiādi
translated: “Here someone, though having faith, wishes: ‘Let people know me as having faith.’ Though having virtue, he wishes: ‘Let people know me as having virtue’” .

original: Duttappiyatāya hissa vijātamātāpi cittaṃ gahetuṃ na sakkoti. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: duttappiya tāya hi ssa vijāta mātā api cittam gahetum na sakkoti tena itam vuccati
translated: For his mind cannot be caught hold of even by his own mother, so great is his greed for gain, honour and renown. Hence it is said:🔽“A fire-brand, and the ocean,

original: “Aggikkhandho samuddo ca, mahiccho cāpi puggalo;
analyzed: aggi kkhandho samuddaḥ ca mahicchaḥ ca api puggalo
translated: And a man of great desire,🔽And a cart, and requisites given,

original: Sakaṭehi paccaye dentu, tayopete atappiyā”ti.
analyzed: sakaṭehi paccaye dentu tayā upete a tappiyā ati
translated: These three are not to one’s liking” .

original: Ete pana atricchatādayo dose ārakā parivajjetvā santaguṇanigūhanādhippāyo paṭiggahaṇe
analyzed: ete pana atricchatā ādayaḥ dose ārakā parivajjetvā santa guṇa nigūhana adhippāyo paṭiggahaṇe
translated: But avoiding these faults of greed, etc., he should be bent on concealing his own qualities and on not concealing the good qualities of others.

original: ca mattaññū appiccho. So attani vijjamānampi guṇaṃ paṭicchādetukāmatāya saddho samāno🔽“saddhoti maṃ jano jānātū”ti na icchati, sīlavā, bahussuto, pavivitto, āraddhavīriyo,
analyzed: ca mattaññū appicchaḥ saḥ attani vijjamānam pi guṇam paṭicchādetu kāma tāya saddhaḥ samānaḥ  saddhaḥ iti mam janaḥ jānātu uti naḥ icchati sīlavā bahu sutaḥ pavivittaḥ āraddha vīriyaḥ
translated: and he is content and modest. Though he has the virtue, etc., he does not want people to know about it, thinking, “Let people know me as having faith” or “Let them know me as virtuous, learned, secluded, energetic,

original: upaṭṭhitassati, samāhito, paññavā samāno “paññavāti maṃ jano jānātū”ti na icchati.
analyzed: upaṭṭhitaḥ sati samāhitaḥ paññavā samānaḥ paññavā ati mamam janaḥ jānātu uti naḥ icchati
translated: mindful, concentrated, and wise.”

original: Svāyaṃ paccayappiccho dhutaṅgappiccho pariyattiappiccho adhigamappicchoti catubbidho.
analyzed: svāyam paccaya picchaḥ dhutaṅga picchaḥ pariyatti appicchaḥ adhigama picchaḥ iti catubbidhaḥ
translated: He is of four kinds as one who is modest in requisites, modest in duties, modest in gains, and modest in reputation.

original: Tattha catūsu paccayesu appiccho paccayadāyakaṃ deyyadhammaṃ attano thāmañca oloketvā🔽sacepi hi deyyadhammo bahu hoti, dāyako appaṃ dātukāmo, dāyakassa vasena appameva🔽gaṇhāti. Deyyadhammo ce appo, dāyako bahuṃ dātukāmo, deyyadhammassa vasena appameva
analyzed: tattha catūsu paccayesu appicchaḥ paccaya dāyakam deyya dhammam attano thāmañce oloketvā  sace pi hi deyya dhammaḥ bahu hoti dāyakaḥ appam dātu kāmaḥ dāyakassa vasena appam eva  gaṇhāti deyya dhammaḥ ce appaḥ dāyakaḥ bahum dātu kāmaḥ deyya dhammassa vasena appam eva
translated: Herein, one who is modest in the four requisites considers the donor, the gift, and himself,🔽and if the gift is much and the donor wants to give much, he takes only a moderate amount, considering the donor.🔽If the gift is little and the donor wants to give little, he takes only a little, considering the gift.

original: gaṇhāti. Deyyadhammopi ce bahu, dāyakopi bahuṃ dātukāmo, attano thāmaṃ ñatvā pamāṇayuttameva
analyzed: gaṇhāti deyya dhammaḥ api ce bahu dāyakaḥ api bahum dātu kāmaḥ attanaḥ thāmam ñatvā pamāṇa yuttam eva
translated: And if the gift is much and the donor wants to give much, he takes only a moderate amount, considering himself.

original: gaṇhāti. Evarūpo hi bhikkhu anuppannaṃ lābhaṃ uppādeti, uppannaṃ lābhaṃ thāvaraṃ🔽karoti, dāyakānaṃ cittaṃ ārādheti. Dhutaṅgasamādānassa pana attani atthibhāvaṃ na🔽jānāpetukāmo dhutaṅgappiccho. Yo attano bahussutabhāvaṃ jānāpetuṃ na icchati, ayaṃ🔽pariyattiappiccho. Yo pana sotāpannādīsu aññataro hutvā sabrahmacārīnampi attano
analyzed: gaṇhāti evarūpaḥ hi bhikkhu anuppannam lābham uppādeti uppannam lābham thāvaram  karoti dāyakānam cittam ārādheti dhutaṅga samādānassa pana attani atthi bhāvam na  jānāpetu kāmaḥ yaḥ attanaḥ bahu ssuta bhāvam jānāpetum naḥ icchati ayam  pariyatti appicchaḥ yaḥ pana sotāpanna ādīsu aññataraḥ hutvā sabrahmacārīnam pi attano
translated: For such a bhikkhu generates gain that has not arisen and consolidates gain that has arisen; he delights the minds of the givers. But one who does not wish to make known that he has taken up the ascetic practices is called “ascetic-practice-averter.” One who does not wish to make known that he is learned is called “learning-averter.” But one who, being a stream-enterer or one of the other kinds of noble persons, does not wish to make known to his companions in the life of purity that he is such is called “noble-person-averter.”🔽

original: sotāpannādibhāvaṃ jānāpetuṃ na icchati, ayaṃ adhigamappiccho. Evametesaṃ appicchānaṃ
analyzed: sa utāpanna ādi bhāvam jāna apetum na icchati ayam adhigama picchaḥ evam etesam appicchānam
translated: For such a bhikkhu generates unarisen gain and honor and makes arisen gain and honor endure. He delights the minds of donors. But one who does not wish to make known that he has undertaken the ascetic practices is called “ascetic-practice-averter.” One who does not wish to make known that he is learned is called “learning-averter.” But one who, being a stream-enterer, etc., does not wish to make known to his companions in the life of purity that he is a stream-enterer, etc., is called “realization-averter.” Thus these three kinds of averters of publicity are called “averters of publicity” because they do not wish to make known to others the fact that they have gained the special qualities of fewness of wishes, etc.

original: yā appicchatā, tassā saddhiṃ sandassanādividhinā anekākāravokāraānisaṃsavibhāvanavasena,
analyzed: yā appicchatā tassā saddhim sandassana ādi vidhinā aneka ākāra vokāra ānisaṃsa vibhāvana vasena
translated: The talk that occurs in order to show the many kinds of benefits of that kind of publicity, together with the method of showing it,

original: tappaṭipakkhassa atricchādibhedassa icchācārassa ādīnavavibhāvanavasena ca pavattā
analyzed: tad paṭipakkhassa atricchā ādi bhedassa icchā ācārassa ādīnava vibhāvana vasena ca pavattā
translated: and in order to show the danger in the conduct of those who are averse to publicity, such as the wish for much, etc., which is the opposite of the publicity of fewness of wishes, etc.,

original: kathā appicchakathā.
analyzed: kathā appiccha kathā
translated: is called “talk on publicity.”

original: Santuṭṭhikathāti ettha santuṭṭhīti sakena attanā laddhena tuṭṭhi santuṭṭhi. Atha
analyzed: santuṭṭhi kathā ati ettha santuṭṭhī iti sakena attanā laddhena tuṭṭhi santuṭṭhi atha
translated: As to “talk on contentment,” contentment is being content with what one gets oneself.

original: vā visamaṃ paccayicchaṃ pahāya samaṃ tuṭṭhi, santuṭṭhi. Santena vā vijjamānena tuṭṭhi
analyzed: vā visamam paccayiccham pahāya samam tuṭṭhi santuṭṭhi santena vā vijjamānena tuṭṭhi
translated: Or else, having abandoned the wish for unequal, that is, excessive, requisites, he is content with what is equal, that is, suitable.🔽Contentment is satisfaction with what is obtained.

original: santuṭṭhi. Vuttañcetaṃ –
analyzed: santuṭṭhi vuttam ca itam
translated: For this is said:🔽“Not sorrowing for what is past,

original: “Atītaṃ nānusocanto, nappajappamanāgataṃ;
analyzed: atītam na anusocantaḥ na appajappam anāgatam
translated: Nor longing for the future,🔽He lives content whatever be

original: Paccuppannena yāpento, santuṭṭhoti pavuccatī”ti.
analyzed: paccuppannena yāpento santuṭṭhaḥ ti pavuccati iti
translated: The lot assigned by chance” .

original: Sammā vā ñāyena bhagavatā anuññātavidhinā paccayehi tuṭṭhi santuṭṭhi. Atthato itarītarapaccayasantoso,
analyzed: sammā vā ñāyena bhagavatā anuññāta vidhinā paccayehi tuṭṭhi santuṭṭhi atthataḥ itarītara paccaya santoso
translated: Or else, contentment is satisfaction with requisites obtained in accordance with the rules, that is, in accordance with the method approved by the Blessed One.

original: so dvādasavidho hoti. Kathaṃ? Cīvare yathālābhasantoso, yathābalasantoso, yathāsāruppasantosoti
analyzed: saḥ dvādasavidhaḥ katham cīvare yathā lābha santosaḥ yathā bala santosaḥ yathā sāruppa santosaḥ iti
translated: This is twelvefold according to the following analysis. There is contentment with what is obtained, with what is easy to obtain, and with what is obtained without trouble, in the case of robes, and so on.

original: tividho, evaṃ piṇḍapātādīsu.
analyzed: tividhaḥ evam piṇḍapāta ādīsu
translated: So there are three kinds in the case of each of the requisites, making twelve kinds in all.

original: Tatrāyaṃ pabhedavaṇṇanā – idha bhikkhu cīvaraṃ labhati sundaraṃ vā asundaraṃ vā,
analyzed: tatra ayam pabheda vaṇṇanā idha bhikkhu cīvaram labhati sundaram vā asundaram vā
translated: Herein, the bhikkhu gets a robe, whether it is a fine one or not,

original: so teneva yāpeti, aññaṃ na pattheti, labhantopi na gaṇhāti, ayamassa cīvare yathālābhasantoso.
analyzed: so tena iva yāpeti aññam na pattheti labhantaḥ api na gaṇhāti ayam assa cīvare yathā lābha santoso
translated: and he uses that and does not look for another, and if he gets another he does not take it. This is his contentment with what is obtained.

original: Atha pana pakatidubbalo vā hoti ābādhajarābhibhūto vā, garuṃ cīvaraṃ pārupanto kilamati,
analyzed: atha pana pakati dubbalaḥ vā hoti ābādha jarā abhibhūtaḥ vā garum cīvaram kilamati
translated: But if he is naturally weak or if he is overcome by illness or old age and finds it difficult to wear a heavy robe,

original: so sabhāgena bhikkhunā saddhiṃ taṃ parivattetvā lahukena yāpentopi santuṭṭhova hoti,
analyzed: so sabhāgena bhikkhunā saddhim tam parivattetvā lahukena yāpentaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ va hoti
translated: He is content with whatever is shared out to him, even if it is coarse, and he gets by with ease.

original: ayamassa cīvare yathābalasantoso. Aparo paṭṭacīvarādīnaṃ aññataraṃ mahagghacīvaraṃ
analyzed: ayam assa cīvare yathābala santoso aparo paṭṭa cīvara ādīnam aññataram mahaggha cīvaram
translated: This is his contentment with regard to robes in so far as they are a requisite. Another bhikkhu gets a valuable robe, such as a piece of cloth worth a hundred pieces,

original: labhitvā “idaṃ therānaṃ cirapabbajitānaṃ, idaṃ bahussutānaṃ anurūpaṃ, idaṃ gilānānaṃ
analyzed: labhitvā idam therānam cira pabbajitānam idam bahu sutānam anurūpam idam gilānānam
translated: and he thinks, “This is suitable for elder bhikkhus who have been long gone forth, for those of great wisdom, for the sick and the infirm,

original: dubbalānaṃ, idaṃ appalābhīnaṃ vā hotū”ti tesaṃ datvā attanā saṅkārakūṭādito nantakāni
analyzed: dubbalānam idam appalābhīnam vā hotu iti tesam da tvā attanā saṅkārakūṭa āditaḥ nantakāni
translated: but not for me,” and he gives it to them. He himself picks up rags from a rubbish heap, etc.,

original: uccinitvā saṅghāṭiṃ katvā tesaṃ vā purāṇacīvarāni gahetvā dhārentopi santuṭṭhova
analyzed: uccinitvā saṅghāṭim katvā tesam vā purāṇa cīvarāni gahetvā dhārentaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva
translated: and makes himself a triple robe. He is content with whatever old cast-off things he gets.

original: hoti, ayamassa cīvare yathāsāruppasantoso.
analyzed: hoti ayam assa cīvare yathā sāruppa santosaḥ
translated: This is his contentment with regard to robes in so far as they are a requisite.

original: Idha pana bhikkhu piṇḍapātaṃ labhati lūkhaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā, so teneva yāpeti, aññaṃ
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhu piṇḍapātam labhati lūkham vā paṇītam vā so tena iva yāpeti aññam
translated: Herein, when a bhikkhu gets alms food, whether it is coarse or superior, he makes do with that and does not seek for any other,

original: na pattheti, labhantopi na gaṇhāti, ayamassa piṇḍapāte yathālābhasantoso. Atha pana
analyzed: na pattheti labhantaḥ api na gaṇhāti ayam assa piṇḍapāte yathā lābha santosaḥ atha pana
translated: and if he gets any other he does not take it. This is his contentment with regard to alms food in so far as it is easy to get.

original: ābādhiko hoti, lūkhaṃ pakativiruddhaṃ vā byādhiviruddhaṃ vā piṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjitvā
analyzed: ābādhikaḥ hoti lūkham pakati viruddham vā byādhi viruddham vā piṇḍapātam bhuñjitvā
translated: He is sick. He eats almsfood that is rough or unsuitable for a sick man.

original: gāḷhaṃ rogātaṅkaṃ pāpuṇāti, so sabhāgassa bhikkhuno datvā tassa hatthato sappāyabhojanaṃ
analyzed: gāḷham roga ātaṅkam pāpuṇāti saḥ sabhāgassa bhikkhuno da tvā tassa hatthato sappāya bhojanam
translated: He gets a severe illness. He gives it to a fellow monk and eats suitable food from his hand.

original: bhuñjitvā samaṇadhammaṃ karontopi santuṭṭhova hoti, ayamassa piṇḍapāte yathābalasantoso.
analyzed: bhuñjitvā samaṇa dhammam karontaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa piṇḍapāte yathābala santoso
translated: He is content to do the ascetic’s duties after eating. This is his contentment with almsfood according to one’s strength.

original: Aparo bhikkhu paṇītaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ labhati, so “ayaṃ piṇḍapāto cirapabbajitādīnaṃ anurūpo”ti🔽cīvaraṃ viya tesaṃ datvā, tesaṃ vā santakaṃ gahetvā, attanā piṇḍāya caritvā, missakāhāraṃ
analyzed: aparaḥ bhikkhu paṇītam piṇḍapātam labhati saḥ ayam piṇḍapātaḥ cira pabbajita ādīnam anurūpaḥ ti  cīvaram viya tesam da tvā tesam vā santakam gahetvā attanā piṇḍāya caritvā missaka āhāram
translated: Another monk gets fine almsfood. He thinks, “This almsfood is suitable for those who have gone forth for a long time.”🔽He gives it to them, as if it were robe-cloth, or he takes it himself and gives them his own food. He then goes for alms himself and eats a miscellaneous diet.

original: vā paribhuñjantopi santuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa piṇḍapāte yathāsāruppasantoso.
analyzed: vā paribhuñjantaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ eva hoti ayam assa piṇḍapāte yathā sāruppa santoso
translated: He is content. This is his contentment with almsfood according to one’s opportunity.

original: Idha pana bhikkhuno senāsanaṃ pāpuṇāti manāpaṃ vā amanāpaṃ vā antamaso tiṇakuṭikāpi
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhuno senāsanam pāpuṇāti manāpam vā amanāpam vā antamasaḥ tiṇa kuṭikā pi
translated: Here a monk gets a dwelling place, whether desirable or undesirable, even a hut of grass.

original: tiṇasanthārakampi, so teneva santussati, puna aññaṃ sundarataraṃ vā pāpuṇāti, taṃ
analyzed: tiṇa santhārakam pi so tena iva santussati puna aññam sundarataram vā pāpuṇāti tam
translated: He is content with that. He gets another one, more desirable, or he gets a hut of grass.

original: na gaṇhāti, ayamassa senāsane yathālābhasantoso. Atha pana ābādhiko hoti dubbalo
analyzed: na gaṇhāti ayam assa senāsane yathā lābha santosaḥ atha pana ābādhikaḥ hoti dubbalaḥ
translated: If he does not, then he is satisfied with whatever dwelling he gets. But if he is sick and weak

original: vā, so byādhiviruddhaṃ vā pakativiruddhaṃ vā senāsanaṃ labhati, yatthassa vasato
analyzed: vā saḥ byādhi viruddham vā pakati viruddham vā senāsanam labhati yatthassa vasato
translated: and gets a dwelling that is unsuitable for him because of illness or unsuited to his temperament,

original: aphāsu hoti, so taṃ sabhāgassa bhikkhuno datvā tassa santake sappāyasenāsane vasitvā
analyzed: aphāsu hoti saḥ tam sabhāgassa bhikkhuno da tvā tassa santake sa pāyasena āsane vasitvā
translated: then he can give it to a fellow-bhikkhu who is in communion and live in a dwelling that suits him.

original: samaṇadhammaṃ karontopi santuṭṭhova hoti, ayamassa senāsane yathābalasantoso. Aparo🔽sundaraṃ senāsanaṃ pattampi na sampaṭicchati “paṇītasenāsanaṃ pamādaṭṭhāna”nti, mahāpuññatāya
analyzed: samaṇa dhammam karontaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa senāsane yathābala santosaḥ aparo  sundaram senāsanam pattam pi na sampaṭicchati paṇīta senāsanam pamāda ṭṭhānam ti mahā puñña tāya
translated: And if he does the ascetic’s duties while living there, he is still satisfied. This is his satisfaction with whatever dwelling he gets according to his strength. Another🔽does not consent to accept even a fine dwelling lest he should become negligent. Or else, because of his great merit, he gets fine dwellings like caves, huts, and stilt houses.

original: vā leṇamaṇḍapakūṭāgārādīni paṇītasenāsanāni labhati, so tāni cīvarādīni viya cirapabbajitādīnaṃ
analyzed: vā leṇa maṇḍapa kūṭāgāra ādīni paṇīta senāsanāni labhati saḥ tāni cīvara ādīni viya cira pabbajita ādīnam
translated: He gives these to bhikkhus who have gone forth a long time and who have not had such things before,

original: datvā yattha katthaci vasantopi santuṭṭhova hoti, ayamassa senāsane yathāsāruppasantoso.
analyzed: da tvā yattha katthaci vasantaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa senāsane yathā sāruppa santoso
translated: as he did the robes, etc., and he is satisfied to live anywhere at all. This is his satisfaction with whatever dwelling he gets according to his rank.

original: Idha pana bhikkhu bhesajjaṃ labhati lūkhaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā, so teneva tussati, aññaṃ
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhu bhesajjam labhati lūkham vā paṇītam vā so tena iva tussati aññam
translated: Herein, when a bhikkhu gets a medicine, whether coarse or refined, he is satisfied with that.

original: na pattheti, labhantopi na gaṇhāti, ayamassa gilānapaccaye yathālābhasantoso. Atha
analyzed: na pattheti labhantaḥ api na gaṇhāti ayam assa gilāna paccaye yathā lābha santosaḥ atha
translated: If he does not ask for it, and if he does not accept it even when obtained, this is his contentment with whatever is obtained in regard to requisites for the sick.

original: pana telena atthiko phāṇitaṃ labhati, so taṃ sabhāgassa bhikkhuno datvā, tassa hatthato
analyzed: pana telena atthikaḥ phāṇitam labhati saḥ tam sabhāgassa bhikkhuno da tvā tassa hatthato
translated: But if he needs oil and obtains molasses, he gives the molasses to a fellow-bhikkhu who needs molasses and gets oil from him in return.

original: telaṃ gahetvā, bhesajjaṃ katvā samaṇadhammaṃ karontopi santuṭṭhova hoti, ayamassa
analyzed: telam gahetvā bhesajjam katvā samaṇa dhammam karontaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa
translated: He makes up the requisite for the sick with the oil and is content with it. This is his contentment with whatever is obtained in regard to requisites for the sick.

original: gilānapaccaye yathābalasantoso. Aparo mahāpuñño bahuṃ telamadhuphāṇitādipaṇītabhesajjaṃ
analyzed: gilāna paccaye yathābala santosaḥ aparaḥ mahā puññaḥ bahum tela madhu phāṇita ādi paṇīta bhesajjam
translated: Another, who has great merit, obtains much valuable medicine such as oil, honey, molasses, etc.,

original: labhati, so taṃ cīvarādīni viya cirapabbajitādīnaṃ datvā tesaṃ ābhatena yena kenaci🔽bhesajjaṃ karontopi santuṭṭhova hoti. Yo pana ekasmiṃ bhājane muttaharītakaṃ, ekasmiṃ
analyzed: labhati saḥ tam cīvara ādīni viya cira pabbajita ādīnam da tvā tesam ābhatena yena kenacid  bhesajjam karontaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti yaḥ pana ekasmim bhājane mutta harītakam ekasmin
translated: and he makes up the requisite for the sick with whatever he gets in exchange for that, like robe-material, etc., and is content with it.

original: catumadhuraṃ ṭhapetvā “gaṇhatha, bhante, yadicchasī”ti vuccamāno sacassa tesu aññatarenapi
analyzed: catu madhuram ṭhapetvā gaṇhatha bhante yat icchasi iti vuccamāno saca ssa tesu aññatarena api
translated: But if he is told, “Take whichever you like, venerable sir, from this urine and emblic myrobalan in one vessel and the four-constituent medicine in another,”

original: rogo vūpasammati, “muttaharītakaṃ nāma buddhādīhi vaṇṇitaṃ, pūtimuttabhesajjaṃ nissāya
analyzed: rogaḥ muttaharītakam nāma buddha ādīhi vaṇṇitam pūti mutta bhesajjam nissāya
translated: and if his sickness is cured by any one of these, he thinks, “Urine is praised by the Enlightened One and the monks who are his disciples.

original: pabbajjā, tattha te yāvajīvaṃ ussāho karaṇīyo”ti vacanamanussaranto catumadhuraṃ
analyzed: pabbajjāḥ tattha te yāvajīvam ussāhaḥ karaṇīyaḥ iti vacanam anussarantaḥ catu madhuram
translated: “Go forth, monk, and strive for the highest good, and strive for the highest wisdom.”🔽🔽Remembering these words,

original: paṭikkhipitvā muttaharītakena bhesajjaṃ karonto paramasantuṭṭhova hoti, ayamassa🔽gilānapaccaye yathāsāruppasantoso.
analyzed: paṭikkhipitvā mutta harītakena bhesajjam karonto parama santuṭṭhaḥ eva hoti ayam assa  gilāna paccaye yathā sāruppa santoso
translated: and you should have zeal for that all your life.” Remembering this advice, he rejects the four delicacies and makes his medicine with urine and bile. He is satisfied with that. This is his satisfaction with the requisites as they are found in regard to sickness.

original: So evaṃpabhedo sabbopi santoso santuṭṭhīti pavuccati. Tena vuttaṃ “atthato itarītarapaccayasantoso”ti.🔽Itarītarasantuṭṭhiyā saddhiṃ sandassanādividhinā ānisaṃsavibhāvanavasena, tappaṭipakkhassa
analyzed: saḥ evaṃpabhedaḥ sabbaḥ api santosaḥ santuṭṭhī iti pavuccati tena vuttam atthataḥ itarītara paccaya santoso ti  itarītara santuṭṭhiyā saddhim sandassana ādi vidhinā ānisaṃsa vibhāvana vasena tad paṭipakkhassa
translated: All this is called “contentment” . That is why it was said above “In the matter of requisites, contentment with what is got without further seeking” .

original: atricchatādibhedassa icchāpakatattassa ādīnavavibhāvanavasena ca pavattā kathā santuṭṭhikathā.
analyzed: ādīnava vibhāvana vasena ca pavattā kathā santuṭṭhi kathā
translated: The talk that occurs in order to show the benefits of contentment with what is got without further seeking, together with the demonstration of it, etc., and in order to show the drawbacks of discontent, which is called “wanting more,” etc., is called “talk on contentment.”

original: Ito parāsupi kathāsu eseva nayo, visesamattameva vakkhāma.
analyzed: itas parāsu pi kathāsu esā iva nayaḥ visesa mattam eva vakkhāma
translated: In the rest of the talks the method is the same. Only the differences will be mentioned.

original: Pavivekakathāti ettha kāyaviveko cittaviveko upadhivivekoti tayo vivekā. Tesu eko
analyzed: ettha kāya viveko citta viveko upadhi viveko ti tayaḥ vivekā tesu ekaḥ
translated: Herein, seclusion is threefold as bodily seclusion, mental seclusion, and seclusion from perversions.

original: gacchati, eko tiṭṭhati, eko nisīdati, eko seyyaṃ kappeti, eko gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pavisati,
analyzed: gacchati ekaḥ tiṭṭhati ekaḥ nisīdati ekaḥ seyyam kappeti ekaḥ gāmam piṇḍāya pavisati
translated: One goes, one stands, one sits, one lies down, one enters the village for alms,

original: eko paṭikkamati, eko abhikkamati, eko caṅkamaṃ adhiṭṭhāti, eko carati, eko viharatīti
analyzed: ekaḥ paṭikkamati ekaḥ abhikkamati ekaḥ caṅkamam adhiṭṭhāti ekaḥ carati ekaḥ viharati iti
translated: one returns, one attends to the needs of the body, one walks for exercise, one lives in the community, one lives by oneself.

original: evaṃ sabbiriyāpathesu sabbakiccesu gaṇasaṅgaṇikaṃ pahāya vivittavāso kāyaviveko nāma.
analyzed: evam sat biriyāpathesu sabba kiccesu gaṇa saṅgaṇikam pahāya vivitta vāsaḥ kāya vivekaḥ nāma
translated: Thus, having abandoned the company of the community in all postures and in all activities, the dwelling in solitude is called bodily seclusion.

original: Aṭṭha samāpattiyo pana cittaviveko nāma. Nibbānaṃ upadhiviveko nāma. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ pana citta vivekaḥ nāma nibbānam upadhi vivekaḥ nāma vuttam ha etam
translated: The eight attainments are called mental seclusion. Nibbāna is called seclusion from acquisitions. For this is said:

original: “Kāyaviveko ca vivekaṭṭhakāyānaṃ nekkhammābhiratānaṃ, cittaviveko ca parisuddhacittānaṃ paramavodānappattānaṃ, upadhiviveko ca nirupadhīnaṃ puggalānaṃ visaṅkhāragatāna”nti.
analyzed: kāya viveko ca viveka ṭṭhakāyānam nekkhamma abhiratānam citta viveko ca parisuddha cittānam parama vodāna pattānam upadhi viveko ca nirupadhīnam puggalānam visaṅkhāra gatānam ti
translated: “Bodily seclusion is for those whose bodies are secluded, who delight in renunciation. Mental seclusion is for those whose minds are purified, who have attained the highest cleansing. Seclusion from acquisitions is for those persons who are without acquisitions, who have reached non-formation” .

original: Vivekoyeva paviveko, pavivekappaṭisaṃyuttā kathā pavivekakathā.
analyzed: viveko yā iva paviveko paviveka paṭisaṃyuttā kathā paviveka kathā
translated: Seclusion itself is solitude. Talk connected with solitude is talk on solitude.

original: Asaṃsaggakathāti ettha savanasaṃsaggo dassanasaṃsaggo samullapanasaṃsaggo sambhogasaṃsaggo
analyzed: a saṃsagga kathā ati ettha savana saṃsaggo dassana saṃsaggo samullapana saṃsaggo sambhoga saṃsaggo
translated: Talk on non-association: here, hearing is association, seeing is association, conversing is association,

original: kāyasaṃsaggoti pañca saṃsaggā. Tesu idhekacco bhikkhu suṇāti “asukasmiṃ gāme vā nigame
analyzed: kāya saṃsaggo ti pañca saṃsaggā tesu idha ekaccaḥ bhikkhu suṇāti asukasmim gāme vā nigame
translated: “Bodily contact” means the five kinds of contact. Herein, a bhikkhu hears this: “In such a village or town🔽

original: vā itthī abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā”ti, so
analyzed: vā itthī abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇa pokkharatāya samannāgatā ati so
translated: “Bodily contact” is the five kinds of contact. Herein, a bhikkhu hears that in a certain village or town there is a woman who is young, youthful, and fond of adornment, and that she is beautiful, clever, and rich.

original: taṃ sutvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na sakkoti brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ, sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya
analyzed: tam sutvā saṃsīdati visīdati na sakkoti brahmacariyam sandhāretum sikkham paccakkhāya
translated: On hearing this, he becomes lustful and cannot maintain the spiritual life.

original: hīnāyāvattati, evaṃ visabhāgārammaṇasavanena uppannakilesasanthavo savanasaṃsaggo
analyzed: hīnāya avattati evam visa bhāga ārammaṇa savanena uppanna kilesa santhavaḥ savana saṃsaggo
translated: He gives up the training and reverts to the secular life. This is called “contact by ear.”

original: nāma. Na heva kho bhikkhu suṇāti, apica kho sāmaṃ passati itthiṃ abhirūpaṃ dassanīyaṃ🔽pāsādikaṃ paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgataṃ, so taṃ disvā saṃsīdati visīdati,
analyzed: nāma na ha iva kho bhikkhu suṇāti apica kho sāmam passati itthim abhirūpam dassanīyam  pāsādikam paramāya vaṇṇa pokkharatāya samannāgatam saḥ tam disvā saṃsīdati visīdati
translated: Or he does not hear it, but he sees such a woman with his own eyes.🔽On seeing her, he becomes lustful and cannot maintain the spiritual life.

original: na sakkoti brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ, sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati, evaṃ visabhāgārammaṇadassanena🔽uppannakilesasanthavo dassanasaṃsaggo nāma. Disvā pana aññamaññaṃ ālāpasallāpavasena
analyzed: na sakkoti brahmacariyam sandhāretum sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati evam visa bhāga ārammaṇa dassanena 🔽uppanna kilesa santhavaḥ dassanasaṃsaggo nāma disvā pana aññamaññam ālāpa sallāpa vasena
translated: He gives up the training and reverts to the secular life. This is called “contact by eye.”🔽Or he does not hear it or see her, but he sees a man and a woman talking together intimately and affectionately.

original: uppanno kilesasanthavo samullapanasaṃsaggo nāma. Sahajagghanādīnipi eteneva saṅgaṇhāti.🔽Attano pana santakaṃ yaṃkiñci mātugāmassa datvā vā adatvā vā tena dinnassa vanabhaṅgiyādino
analyzed: uppannaḥ kilesa santhavaḥ samullapana saṃsaggo nāma sahajagghana ādīni pi etena iva saṅgaṇhāti  attano pana santakam yaṃkiñci mātugāmassa da tvā vā a da tvā vā tena dinnassa vanabhaṅgiya ādino
translated: The defilement that arises through the contact of meeting is called “the contact of meeting with one who is excited.” The contact of meeting with one who is not excited is also included here.

original: paribhogavasena uppannakilesasanthavo sambhogasaṃsaggo nāma. Mātugāmassa hatthaggāhādivasena
analyzed: paribhoga vasena uppanna kilesa santhavaḥ sambhogasaṃsaggo nāma mātu gāmassa hatthaggāha ādi vasena
translated: The defilement that arises through the use of an article given by a woman, whether or not one has received it in exchange for something, is called “the contact of using.” The defilement that arises through the contact of the hand, etc., with a woman is called “the contact of body.”

original: uppannakilesasanthavo kāyasaṃsaggo nāma. Yopi cesa –
analyzed: uppanna kilesa santhavaḥ kāyasaṃsaggaḥ nāma yaḥ pi ca īsa
translated: The contact of body is also described in the following way:

original: “Gihīhi saṃsaṭṭho viharati ananulomikena saṃsaggena sahasokī sahanandī sukhitesu sukhito, dukkhitesu dukkhito, uppannesu kiccakaraṇīyesu attanā uyyogaṃ āpajjatī”ti –
analyzed: gihīhi saṃsaṭṭhaḥ viharati ananulomikena saṃsaggena saha sokī saha nandī sukhitesu sukhitaḥ dukkhitesu dukkhitaḥ uppannesu kicca karaṇīyesu attanā uyyogam āpajjati iti
translated: “He lives in association with householders, in unbecoming association, sharing their joys and sorrows, following their hap­piness and unhappiness, inclining to their pleasure, seeking their favor.”

original: Evaṃ vutto ananulomiko gihisaṃsaggo, yo ca sabrahmacārīhipi kilesuppattihetubhūto
analyzed: evam vuttaḥ ananulomikaḥ gihi saṃsaggaḥ yaḥ ca sabrahmacārīhi pi kilesuppatti hetu bhūto
translated: The unbecoming association with householders mentioned here and the association with fellow celibates that is a cause for the arising of defilements—

original: saṃsaggo, taṃ sabbaṃ pahāya yvāyaṃ saṃsāre thirataraṃ saṃvegaṃ, saṅkhāresu tibbaṃ
analyzed: saṃsaggaḥ tam sabbam pahāya yvā ayam saṃsāre thirataram saṃvegam saṅkhāresu tibbam
translated: all this should be abandoned. The monk should develop a sense of urgency about the round of rebirths that is more intense than that of the worldling, and he should develop a sense of disenchantment with formations that is more intense than that of the disciples.

original: bhayasaññaṃ, sarīre paṭikūlasaññaṃ, sabbākusalesu jigucchāpubbaṅgamaṃ hirottappaṃ,
analyzed: bhaya saññam sarīre paṭikūla saññam sabba akusalesu jigucchā pubbaṅgamam hiraḥ uttappam
translated: The perception of fear, the perception of the unattractiveness of the body, and the sense of moral shame and moral dread, which are preceded by the perception of loathsomeness in all compounded things,

original: sabbakiriyāsu satisampajaññanti sabbaṃ paccupaṭṭhapetvā kamaladale jalabindu viya
analyzed: sabba kiriyāsu sati sampajaññanti sabbam paccupaṭṭhapetvā kamala dale jala bindu viya
translated: and mindfulness and full awareness in all activities. Having established all these, he is unattached everywhere, like a water drop on a lotus leaf.🔽This is non-attachment, the opposite of all attachment.

original: sabbattha alaggabhāvo, ayaṃ sabbasaṃsaggappaṭipakkhatāya asaṃsaggo. Tappaṭisaṃyuttā🔽kathā asaṃsaggakathā.
analyzed: sabbattha alagga bhāvaḥ ayam sabba saṃsagga paṭipakkha tāya a saṃsaggaḥ tad paṭisaṃyuttā  kathā a saṃsagga kathā
translated: Talk concerned with non-attachment is talk on non-attachment.🔽“Talk that is a stimulus to arouse energy”: energy is the state of a hero or it is action.

original: Vīriyārambhakathāti ettha vīrassa bhāvo, kammanti vā vīriyaṃ, vidhinā īrayitabbaṃ
analyzed: vīriya ārambha kathā ati ettha vīrassa bhāvaḥ kammanti vā vīriyam vidhinā īrayitabbam
translated: Or energy is that which should be spread out and extended by means of a method.

original: pavattetabbanti vā vīriyaṃ, vīriyañca taṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya kusalānaṃ
analyzed: pavattetabbanti vā vīriyam vīriyam ca tam akusalānam dhammānam pahānāya kusalānam
translated: And that energy is a stimulus to arouse for the abandoning of unwholesome states and for the acquisition of wholesome states.

original: dhammānaṃ upasampadāya ārambhanaṃ vīriyārambho. Svāyaṃ kāyiko cetasiko cāti duvidho,
analyzed: dhammānam upasampadāya ārambhanam vīriya ārambho svāyam kāyiko cetasiko ca ati duvidho
translated: This is twofold as bodily and mental.

original: ārambhadhātu, nikkamadhātu, parakkamadhātu cāti tividho; sammappadhānavasena catubbidho.
analyzed: ārambha dhātu nikkamadhātu parakkamadhātu ca ati tividhaḥ sammappadhāna vasena catubbidhaḥ
translated: It is threefold as the element of instigation, the element of exertion, and the element of striving. It is fourfold as right endeavour.

original: So sabbopi yo bhikkhu gamane uppannaṃ kilesaṃ ṭhānaṃ pāpuṇituṃ na deti; ṭhāne uppannaṃ
analyzed: so sabbaḥ api yaḥ bhikkhu gamane uppannam kilesam ṭhānam pāpuṇitum na deti ṭhāne uppannam
translated: All this energy, when a bhikkhu does not allow the defilements that arise in walking to persist, or those that arise in standing …

original: nisajjaṃ, nisajjāya uppannaṃ sayanaṃ pāpuṇituṃ na deti, tattha tattheva ajapadena
analyzed: nisajjam nisajjāya uppannam sayanam pāpuṇitum na deti tattha tattha iva aja padena
translated: and lying down, he does not allow the arising of sleep to reach him. He subdues it there and then, as it were, by stamping on it with the foot,

original: daṇḍena kaṇhasappaṃ uppīḷetvā gaṇhanto viya, tikhiṇena asinā amittaṃ gīvāya paharanto
analyzed: daṇḍena kaṇha sappam uppīḍetvā gaṇhantaḥ viya tikhiṇena asinā amittam gīvāya paharantaḥ
translated: as though he were catching a black snake by the neck with a strong stick, or as though he were striking an enemy on the neck with a sharp sword.

original: viya ca sīsaṃ ukkhipituṃ adatvā vīriyabalena niggaṇhāti, tassevaṃ āraddhavīriyassa
analyzed: viya ca sīsam ukkhipitum a datvā vīriya balena niggaṇhāti tassa ivam āraddha vīriyassa
translated: He does not allow his head to be raised by the energy that has thus been aroused.

original: vasena veditabbo. Tappaṭisaṃyuttā kathā vīriyārambhakathā.
analyzed: vasena veditabbo tad paṭisaṃyuttā kathā vīriya ārambha kathā
translated: This is how it should be understood. Talk concerned with arousal of energy is talk concerned with the abandoning of the hindrance of sloth and torpor.

original: Sīlakathādīsu duvidhaṃ sīlaṃ lokiyaṃ lokuttarañca. Tattha lokiyaṃ pātimokkhasaṃvarādi
analyzed: sīla kathā ādīsu duvidham sīlam lokiyam lokuttaram ca tattha lokiyam pātimokkha saṃvara ādi
translated: There are two kinds of virtue, namely, mundane and supramundane. Herein, mundane virtue is virtue consisting in the restraint of the Pāṭimokkha, etc.,

original: catupārisuddhisīlaṃ, lokuttaraṃ maggasīlaṃ phalasīlañca. Tathā vipassanāya pādakabhūtā
analyzed: catu pārisuddhi sīlam lokuttaram magga sīlam phala sīlam ca tathā vipassanāya pādaka bhūtā
translated: and virtue consisting in the four kinds of purification of the grounds of action. Supramundane virtue is virtue belonging to the path and virtue belonging to fruition.

original: saha upacārena aṭṭha samāpattiyo lokiyo samādhi, maggasampayutto panettha lokuttaro
analyzed: saha upacārena aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ lokiyaḥ samādhi magga sampayutto pana ittha lokuttaro
translated: Likewise, the eight meditative attainments together with access concentration are mundane concentration. But the concentration associated with the path is called supramundane concentration here.

original: samādhi nāma. Tathā paññāpi lokiyā sutamayā cintāmayā jhānasampayuttā vipassanāñāṇañca.
analyzed: nāma tathā paññā api lokiyā suta mayā cintā mayā jhāna sampayuttā vipassanā ñāṇañca
translated: Likewise, mundane understanding is that consisting in what is learnt by heart and in cogitation, and that associated with the jhānas, and also insight knowledge.

original: Visesato panettha vipassanāpaññā gahetabbā, lokuttarā maggapaññā phalapaññā ca. Vimuttīpi
analyzed: visesato pana ittha vipassanā paññā gahetabbā lokuttarā magga paññā phala paññā ca
translated: And of these, it is insight knowledge that should be taken as the most important, and also the supramundane path knowledge and fruition knowledge. And of the kinds of deliverance,

original: ariyaphalavimutti nibbānañca. Apare pana tadaṅgavikkhambhanasamucchedavimuttīnampi
analyzed: ariya phala vimutti nibbānam ca apare pana tad aṅga vikkhambhana samuccheda vimuttīnam pi
translated: it is noble-fruit deliverance and Nibbāna. Others explain the meaning here in accordance with the deliverance by suppression of conditions and the deliverance by cutting off.

original: vasenettha atthaṃ vaṇṇenti. Vimuttiñāṇadassanampi ekūnavīsatividhaṃ paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ.
analyzed: vasena ittha attham vaṇṇenti vimutti ñāṇa dassanam pi ekūnavīsatividham paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam
translated: And of the kinds of knowledge of the way to realization, it is the nineteen kinds of knowledge consisting in reviewing that should be taken.

original: Iti imesaṃ sīlādīnaṃ saddhiṃ sandassanādividhinā anekākāravokāraānisaṃsavibhāvanavasena
analyzed: iti imesam sīla ādīnam saddhim sandassana ādi vidhinā aneka ākāra vokāra ānisaṃsa vibhāvana vasena
translated: So this is a talk that occurs in order to reveal the many modes, aspects, benefits, and advantages of virtue, etc.,

original: ceva tappaṭipakkhānaṃ dussīlyādīnaṃ ādīnavavibhāvanavasena ca pavattā kathā, tappaṭisaṃyuttā
analyzed: ca iva tad paṭipakkhānam dussīlya ādīnam ādīnava vibhāvana vasena ca pavattā kathā tad paṭisaṃyuttā
translated: together with the method of demonstrating them, and in order to reveal the drawbacks of their opposites, that is, of unvirtuous conduct, etc.🔽Or it is a talk concerned with that,

original: kathā vā sīlādikathā nāma.
analyzed: kathā vā sīla ādi kathā nāma
translated: This is called “talk on virtue, etc.”🔽And here, since it is said, “He is himself contented with any kind of robe and he speaks in praise of being contented with any kind of robe” ,

original: Ettha ca “attanā ca appiccho hoti, appicchakathañca paresaṃ kattā”ti “santuṭṭho hoti🔽itarītarena cīvarena, itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī”ti ca ādivacanato sayañca
analyzed: ettha ca attanā ca appicchaḥ hoti appiccha katham ca paresam kattā ati santuṭṭhaḥ hoti 🔽itarītarena cīvarena itarītara cīvara santuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇa vādī iti ca ādi vacanataḥ sayam ca
translated: he is himself

original: appicchatādiguṇasamannāgatena paresampi tadatthāya hitajjhāsayena pavattetabbā tathārūpī🔽kathā, yā idha abhisallekhikādibhāvena visesetvā vuttā appicchakathādīti veditabbā.
analyzed: appiccha tā ādi guṇa samannāgatena paresam pi tad atthāya pavattetabbā tathārūpī  kathā yā idha abhisallekhika ādi bhāvena visesetvā vuttā appiccha kathā ādi iti veditabbā
translated: It should be undertaken by one who possesses the qualities of fewness of wishes, etc., and by one who has the aspiration for others’ welfare.🔽Such talk is called “talk on fewness of wishes, etc.” here in the sense of being pre-eminent, and so on.🔽For it is the talk of the doer himself that is intended as the means of accomplishing the purpose.

original: Kārakasseva hi kathā visesato adhippetatthasādhinī. Tathā hi vakkhati “kalyāṇamittassetaṃ,
analyzed: kārakassa iva hi kathā visesataḥ adhippeta attha sādhinī tathā hi vakkhati kalyāṇamittassa etam
translated: That is why it is said: “Meghiya, this bhikkhu should be expected to be a friend of good,

original: meghiya, bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṃ…pe. … akasiralābhī”ti.
analyzed: meghiya bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṃpe a kasira lābhī iti
translated: a companion of good, a supporter of good, one who courses in conformity with the Dhamma, and not to be difficult to support” .🔽Such talk as this: such talk as was described above.

original: Evarūpāyāti īdisāya, yathāvuttāya. Nikāmalābhīti yathicchitalābhī yathārucilābhī,🔽sabbakālaṃ imā kathā sotuṃ vicāretuñca yathāsukhaṃ labhanto. Akicchalābhīti niddukkhalābhī.
analyzed: evarūpāya ati īdisāya yathāvuttāya nikāma lābhī iti yathā icchita lābhī yathā ruci lābhī  sabbakālam imāḥ kathāḥ sotum vicāretum ca yathāsukham labhantaḥ a kiccha lābhī iti niddukkha lābhī
translated: One who gains at will: one who gains as he wishes, as he desires.

original: Akasiralābhīti vipulalābhī.🔽Āraddhavīriyoti paggahitavīriyo. Akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāyāti akosallasambhūtaṭṭhena
analyzed: akasira lābhī iti vipula lābhī  āraddha vīriyaḥ ti paggahita vīriyaḥ akusalānam dhammānam pahānāya ati akosalla sambhūta ṭṭhena
translated: One who gains without trouble: one who gains without difficulty.🔽One who gains easily: one who gains abundantly.🔽One who is strenuous: one who is energetic.🔽For the abandoning of unwholesome states: for the abandoning of unwholesome states that have arisen.

original: akusalānaṃ pāpadhammānaṃ pajahanatthāya. Kusalānaṃ dhammānanti kucchitānaṃ salanādiatthena
analyzed: akusalānam pāpa dhammānam pajahana tthāya kusalānam dhammānam nti kucchitānam salana ādi atthena
translated: For the arising of wholesome states: for the arousing of wholesome states that have not yet arisen.

original: anavajjaṭṭhena ca kusalānaṃ sahavipassanānaṃ maggaphaladhammānaṃ. Upasampadāyāti
analyzed: anavajja ṭṭhena ca kusalānam saha vipassanānam magga phala dhammānam upasampadāya ati
translated: To the full understanding:

original: sampādanāya, attano santāne uppādanāya. Thāmavāti ussoḷhisaṅkhātena vīriyathāmena
analyzed: sampādanāya attano santāne uppādanāya thāma vāti ussoḷhi saṅkhātena vīriya thāmena
translated: to the fulfilment, to the arising in his own continuity. Endowed with energy: endowed with the energy called “strength” .

original: samannāgato. Daḷhaparakkamoti thiraparakkamo asithilavīriyo. Anikkhittadhuroti anorohitadhuro anosakkitavīriyo.
analyzed: samannāgataḥ daḷha parakkamo ti thira parakkamaḥ a sithila vīriyaḥ a nikkhitta dhuraḥ iti anorohita dhuraḥ anosakkita vīriyaḥ
translated: Steadfast: firm. Not shirking the responsibility: not shirking the responsibility, not shirking the energy.🔽Wise: possessing the insight-understanding.

original: Paññavāti vipassanāpaññāya paññavā. Udayatthagāminiyāti pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ udayañca
analyzed: paññavā ti vipassanā paññāya paññavā udaya ttha gāminiyā ti pañcannam khandhānam udayam ca
translated: To the penetration of arising and falling: to the penetration of the arising and falling of the five aggregates.🔽Noble: standing far away from defilements by way of suppression, standing far away,

original: vayañca paṭivijjhantiyā. Ariyāyāti vikkhambhanavasena kilesehi ārakā dūre ṭhitāya🔽niddosāya. Nibbedhikāyāti nibbedhabhāgiyāya. Sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyāti vaṭṭadukkhassa
analyzed: vayam ca paṭivijjhantiyā ariyāya ati vikkhambhana vasena kilesehi ārakāḥ dūre ṭhitāya  niddosāya nibbedhikāya ati nibbedha bhāgiyāya sammā dukkha kkhaya gāminiyā ati vaṭṭa dukkhassa
translated: free from danger.🔽To the penetration of what is the meaning: to the penetration of what is the meaning of the noble path.

original: khepanato “dukkhakkhayo”ti laddhanāmaṃ ariyamaggaṃ sammā hetunā ñāyena gacchantiyā.
analyzed: khepanataḥ dukkha kkhayaḥ ti laddha nāmam ariya maggam sammā hetunā ñāyena gacchantiyā
translated: To the full understanding of suffering: to the noble path, which is called “the full understanding of suffering” because it throws off the suffering of the round of rebirths, by the right cause, by the right way.

original: Imesu ca pana pañcasu dhammesu sīlaṃ vīriyaṃ paññā ca yogino ajjhattikaṃ aṅgaṃ, itaradvayaṃ
analyzed: imesu ca pana pañcasu dhammesu sīlam vīriyam paññā ca yoginaḥ ajjhattikam aṅgam itara dvayam
translated: And of these five ideas, virtue, energy, and understanding are the meditator’s internal factors,🔽while the other two are his external factors.

original: bāhiraṃ aṅgaṃ. Tathāpi kalyāṇamittasannissayeneva sesaṃ catubbidhaṃ ijjhati, kalyāṇamittassevettha
analyzed: bāhiram aṅgam tathā api kalyāṇa mitta sannissayena iva sesam catubbidham ijjhati
translated: Nevertheless, the remaining four are successful only with the support of a good friend.

original: bahūpakārataṃ dassento satthā “kalyāṇamittassetaṃ, meghiya, bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkha”ntiādinā
analyzed: bahu upakāra tam dassento satthā kalyāṇa mittassa itam meghiya bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhanti ādinā
translated: And the Master, in showing how helpful a good friend is here, extends the teaching with the words, “This, Meghiya, is to be expected of a bhikkhu who has a good friend,”🔽and so on. Herein, “This is to be expected” : this is to be desired, this is to be regarded as not uncertain.

original: desanaṃ vaḍḍheti. Tattha pāṭikaṅkhanti ekaṃsena icchitabbaṃ, avassaṃbhāvīti attho.
analyzed: desanam vaḍḍheti tattha pāṭikaṅkhanti ekaṃsena icchitabbam avassaṃbhāvi iti attho
translated: “Y”: this is a verbal root meaning “to depend” .🔽What is meant is this: “He will be virtuous” : here, since a bhikkhu who has a good friend is virtuous,

original: Yanti kiriyāparāmasanaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – “sīlavā bhavissatī”ti ettha yadetaṃ kalyāṇamittassa
analyzed: idam vuttam hoti sīlavā bhavissati iti ettha yat etam kalyāṇa mittassa
translated: his virtue is perfected.

original: bhikkhuno sīlavantatāya bhavanaṃ sīlasampannattaṃ, tassa bhikkhuno sīlasampannattā
analyzed: bhikkhuno sīlavanta tāya bhavanam sīla sampannattam tassa bhikkhuno sīla sampannattā
translated: Because of the bhikkhu’s perfected virtue,

original: etaṃ tassa pāṭikaṅkhaṃ, avassaṃbhāvī ekaṃseneva tassa tattha niyojanatoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: etam tassa pāṭikaṅkham avassaṃbhāvī ekaṃsena iva tassa tattha niyojanato ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: this is to be expected of him, it is not uncertain. It is to be regarded as certain, since he is necessarily established in that.

original: Pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharissatītiādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: pātimokkha saṃvara saṃvutaḥ viharissati iti ādīsu pi esa eva nayaḥ
translated: The same method applies in the passages beginning, “He will live restrained with the Pātimokkha restraint” .

original: Evaṃ bhagavā sadevake loke uttamakalyāṇamittasaṅkhātassa attano vacanaṃ anādiyitvā
analyzed: evam bhagavā sa devake loke uttama kalyāṇa mitta saṅkhātassa attanaḥ vacanam an ādiyitvā
translated: Thus the Blessed One, disregarding the word of the Exalted One, who is the best of all good friends in the world of men and gods,

original: taṃ vanasaṇḍaṃ pavisitvā tādisaṃ vippakāraṃ pattassa āyasmato meghiyassa kalyāṇamittatādinā🔽sakalaṃ sāsanasampattiṃ dassetvā, idānissa tattha ādarajātassa pubbe yehi kāmavitakkādīhi
analyzed: tam vana saṇḍam pavisitvā tādisam vippakāram pattassa āyasmataḥ meghiyassa kalyāṇa mitta tā ādinā  sakalam sāsana sampattim dassetvā idāni issa tattha ādara jātassa pubbe yehi kāma vitakka ādīhi
translated: entered the forest grove and showed the entire excellence of the dispensation by the good friendship of the venerable Meghiya, who had fallen into such a state of dejection.🔽Now, in order to show the method of development of concentration, since the meditation subject did not become clear to him because he was troubled by sensual thoughts, etc.,

original: upaddutattā kammaṭṭhānaṃ na sampajji, tassa tesaṃ ujuvipaccanīkabhūtattā ca bhāvanānayaṃ
analyzed: upadduta ttā kammaṭṭhānam na sampajji tassa tesam uju vipaccanīka bhūta ttā ca bhāvanā nayam
translated: and since these are the direct opposites of the four establishments of mindfulness,

original: pakāsetvā, tato paraṃ arahattassa kammaṭṭhānaṃ ācikkhanto, “tena ca pana, meghiya,
analyzed: pakāsetvā tatas param arahattassa kammaṭṭhānam ācikkhanto tena ca pana meghiya
translated: the Blessed One, after showing the method of development, then explained the meditation subject for the attainment of arahatship. “And, Meghiya,

original: bhikkhunā imesu pañcasu dhammesu patiṭṭhāya cattāro dhammā uttari bhāvetabbā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: bhikkhunā imesu pañcasu dhammesu patiṭṭhāya cattāro dhammā uttari bhāvetabbā ti ādim āha
translated: the bhikkhu should, after establishing himself in these five things, further develop the four things that make for self-confidence.”

original: Tattha tenāti evaṃ kalyāṇamittasannissayena yathāvuttasīlādiguṇasamannāgatena. Tenevāha
analyzed: tattha tena ati evam kalyāṇa mitta sannissayena yathā vutta sīla ādi guṇa samannāgatena tena iva āha
translated: Herein, the word “then” means: by depending on a good friend in this way, by possessing the virtue, etc., as described, he should, after establishing himself in these five things, further develop the four things that make for self-confidence.

original: “imesu pañcasu dhammesu patiṭṭhāyā”ti. Uttarīti āraddhataruṇavipassanassa rāgādiparissayā
analyzed: imesu pañcasu dhammesu patiṭṭhāya ati uttarī iti āraddha taruṇa vipassanassa rāga ādi parissayā
translated: “More” : if, after beginning insight, the defilements of lust, etc.,

original: ce uppajjeyyuṃ, tesaṃ visodhanatthaṃ tato uddhaṃ cattāro dhammā bhāvetabbā uppādetabbā vaḍḍhetabbā ca.
analyzed: ce uppajjeyyum tesam visodhana attham tatas uddham cattāro dhammā bhāvetabbā uppādetabbā vaḍḍhetabbā ca
translated: were to arise, then, in order to purify himself of them, he should develop and increase the four ideas that follow.

original: Asubhāti ekādasasu asubhakammaṭṭhānesu yathārahaṃ yattha katthaci asubhabhāvanā.
analyzed: asubhā ti ekādasasu asubha kammaṭṭhānesu yathāraham yattha katthaci asubha bhāvanā
translated: “The foul” : the meditation subject of the foul in one of the eleven aspects, according to which is suitable,

original: Rāgassa pahānāyāti kāmarāgassa pajahanatthāya. Ayamattho sālilāyakopamāya vibhāvetabbo🔽– eko hi puriso asitaṃ gahetvā koṭito paṭṭhāya sālikhette sāliyo lāyati, athassa🔽vatiṃ bhinditvā gāvo pavisiṃsu. So asitaṃ ṭhapetvā, yaṭṭhiṃ ādāya, teneva maggena
analyzed: rāgassa pahānāya ati kāma rāgassa pajahana tthāya ayam atthaḥ sālilāyaka upamāya vibhāvetabbaḥ  ekaḥ hi purisaḥ asitam gahetvā koṭitaḥ paṭṭhāya sāli khette sāliyaḥ lāyati  vatim bhinditvā gāvaḥ pavisiṃsu saḥ asitam ṭhapetvā yaṭṭhim ādāya tena iva maggena
translated: “For the abandoning of lust” : for the abandoning of sense desire. This meaning should be illustrated by the story of the man who was

original: gāvo nīharitvā, vatiṃ pākatikaṃ katvā, puna asitaṃ gahetvā sāliyo lāyi. Tattha sālikhettaṃ
analyzed: gāvaḥ nīharitvā vatim pākatikam katvā punar asitam gahetvā sāliyaḥ lāyi tattha
translated: told the story of the rice-field. A man was told the story of a rice-field. He took a plough and went to the rice-field. He broke down the bank and let the water out. He put aside the plough, took a stick, and drove out the cattle that were in the rice-field. He repaired the bank and let the water in again. He took the plough and ploughed the rice-field.🔽The rice-field is like the world.

original: viya buddhasāsanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, sālilāyako viya yogāvacaro, asitaṃ viya paññā, lāyanakālo🔽viya vipassanāya kammakaraṇakālo, yaṭṭhi viya asubhakammaṭṭhānaṃ, vati viya saṃvaro,🔽vatiṃ bhinditvā gāvīnaṃ pavisanaṃ viya sahasā appaṭisaṅkhāya pamādaṃ āgamma rāgassa
analyzed: viya buddha sāsanam daṭṭhabbam sālilāyakaḥ viya yogāvacaraḥ asitam viya paññā lāyana kālo  viya vipassanāya kamma karaṇa kālo viya asubha kammaṭṭhānam vati viya saṃvaro  vatim bhinditvā gāvīnam pavisanam viya sahasā a paṭisaṅkhāya pamādam āgamma rāgassa
translated: the time for doing insight meditation as the time for reaping, the meditation subject as the rice, restraint as the binding-rope,🔽the arising of lust through negligence and lack of reflection as the cows’ breaking in and eating,🔽the meditator’s going out after putting down the meditation subject and taking up the binding-rope as the man’s going out after putting down the sickle and taking up the stick,

original: uppajjanaṃ, asitaṃ ṭhapetvā, yaṭṭhiṃ ādāya, paviṭṭhamaggeneva gāvo nīharitvā, vatiṃ
analyzed: uppajjanam asitam ṭhapetvā yaṭṭhim ādāya paviṭṭha maggena iva gāvaḥ nīharitvā vatim
translated: the meditator’s banishing lust by means of the meditation subject as the cows’ being driven out by the man with the stick,🔽the meditator’s resuming the meditation subject as the man’s resuming the sickle,

original: paṭipākatikaṃ katvā, puna ṭhitaṭṭhānato paṭṭhāya sālilāyanaṃ viya asubhakammaṭṭhānena🔽rāgaṃ vikkhambhetvā, puna vipassanāya kammakaraṇakāloti idamettha upamāsaṃsandanaṃ.🔽Evaṃbhūtaṃ bhāvanāvidhiṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “asubhā bhāvetabbā rāgassa pahānāyā”ti.
analyzed: paṭipākatikam katvā puna ṭhita ṭṭhānataḥ paṭṭhāya sālilāyanam viya asubha kammaṭṭhānena  rāgam vikkhambhetvā puna vipassanāya kamma karaṇa kālaḥ ti idam ettha upamā saṃsandanam  evaṃbhūtam bhāvanā vidhim sandhāya vuttam asubhāḥ bhāvetabbāḥ rāgassa pahānāya ati
translated: the meditator’s resuming insight meditation as the cows’ resuming their original place after the rice has been reaped,🔽the meditator’s banishing lust by means of insight meditation as the cows’ not breaking in and eating again after the man has repaired the fence and resumed his place. This is the application of the similes.

original: Mettāti mettākammaṭṭhānaṃ. Byāpādassa pahānāyāti vuttanayeneva uppannakopassa pajahanatthāya.
analyzed: mettā ti mettā kammaṭṭhānam byāpādassa pahānāya ati vutta nayena iva uppanna kopassa pajahana tthāya
translated: It is with reference to the method of development of this meditation subject that it is said in the Vibhaṅga: “‘The contemplation of the unattractive’: the unattractive comes into the mind’s range, and it is known thus, ‘The unattractive has appeared to the mind.’ The contemplation of the repulsive, the contemplation of danger, the contemplation of disenchantment, the contemplation of fading away, the contemplation of cessation, the contemplation of relinquishment—these things are the same as, not other than, the contemplation of the unattractive. That is why it was said: ‘The contemplation of the unattractive’ … Translation: sāsanaṃ viya, yogāvacaro viya, paññā viya, vipassanāya kammakaraṇakālo viya, asubhakammaṭṭhānaṃ viya, saṃvaro viya, vatiṃ bhinditvā gāviyo viya, sahasā appaṭisaṅkhāya pamādaṃ āgamma rāgassa uppatti, asitaṃ ṭhapetvā, yaṭṭhiṃ ādāya paviṭṭhamaggena gāvo viya asubhakammaṭṭhānena rāgaṃ vikkhambhetvā, puna vipassanāya kammakaraṇakāloti idamettha upamāsaṃsandana

original: Ānāpānassatīti soḷasavatthukā ānāpānassati. Vitakkupacchedāyāti vuttanayeneva uppannānaṃ🔽vitakkānaṃ upacchedanatthāya. Asmimānasamugghātāyāti asmīti uppajjanakassa navavidhassa🔽mānassa samucchedanatthāya. Aniccasaññinoti hutvā abhāvato udayabbayavantato pabhaṅguto🔽tāvakālikato niccappaṭipakkhato ca “sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā”ti pavattaaniccānupassanāvasena
analyzed: āna apāna satī iti soḷasa vatthukā āna apāna sati vitakka upacchedāya ati vutta nayena iva uppannānam  vitakkānam upacchedana tthāya asmimāna samugghātāya ati asmi iti uppajjanakassa navavidhassa  mānassa samucchedana tthāya anicca saññinaḥ ti hutvā abhāvataḥ udaya bbayavantataḥ pabhaṅgutaḥ  tāvakālikataḥ nicca ppaṭipakkhataḥ ca sabbe saṅkhārāḥ aniccā ati pavatta anicca anupassanā vasena
translated: Mindfulness of breathing is the mindfulness whose subject is the sixteen bases. For the purpose of cutting off applied thoughts: for the purpose of cutting off applied thoughts that have arisen in the way already described. For the purpose of uprooting the conceit “I am”: for the purpose of completely eradicating the ninefold conceit that arises with “I am.” One who possesses the perception of impermanence: one who possesses the contemplation of impermanence arisen in the mode of non-existence, of having rise and fall, of being subject to change, of being momentary, and of being the opposite of permanence, by means of the perception “All formations are impermanent.”🔽

original: aniccasaññino. Anattasaññā saṇṭhātīti asārakato avasavattanato parato rittato tucchato🔽suññato ca “sabbe dhammā anattā”ti evaṃ pavattā anattānupassanāsaṅkhātā anattasaññā🔽citte saṇṭhahati, atidaḷhaṃ patiṭṭhāti. Aniccalakkhaṇe hi diṭṭhe anattalakkhaṇaṃ🔽diṭṭhameva hoti. Tīsu hi lakkhaṇesu ekasmiṃ diṭṭhe itaradvayaṃ diṭṭhameva hoti. Tena
analyzed: anicca saññinaḥ anatta saññā saṇṭhāti iti asārakataḥ paratas rittataḥ tucchataḥ 🔽suññatas ca sabbe dhammā anattā ati evam pavattā anatta anupassanā saṅkhātā anatta saññā 🔽citte saṇṭhahati ati daḷham patiṭṭhāti anicca lakkhaṇe hi diṭṭhe anatta lakkhaṇam 🔽diṭṭham eva hoti tīsu hi lakkhaṇesu ekasmin diṭṭhe itara dvayam diṭṭham eva hoti tena
