translated: “Mindfulness of breathing”: the mindfulness of breathing with its sixteen bases. “For the cutting off of applied thoughts”: for the purpose of cutting off the applied thoughts that have arisen in the way stated. “For the uprooting of the conceit ‘I am’: for the purpose of eradicating the ninefold conceit that arises with the thought “I am.” “One who has the perception of inconstancy”: one who has the perception of inconstancy arisen through the contemplation of inconstancy, which occurs as the perception “All formations are impermanent” because of the fact of their non-existence after coming to be, their possession of rise and fall, their liability to destruction, their being momentary, and their being the opposite of permanent. “The perception of non-self becomes settled in him”: the perception of non-self, which is called the contemplation of non-self, becomes settled in his mind, becomes firmly established, because of the fact of their being without an inner controller, their being alien, their being void, their being empty, and their being insubstantial. “For when the characteristic of inconstancy is seen,” etc.: when the characteristic of inconstancy is seen, the characteristic of non-self is also seen. For when one of the three characteristics is seen, the other two are also seen.

original: vuttaṃ – “aniccasaññino hi, meghiya, anattasaññā saṇṭhātī”ti. Anattalakkhaṇe diṭṭhe
analyzed: vuttam anicca saññinaḥ hi meghiya anatta saññā saṇṭhāti iti anatta lakkhaṇe diṭṭhe
translated: It is said: “For one who has the perception of impermanence, bhikkhu, the perception of non-self becomes stabilized” .

original: asmīti uppajjanakamāno suppajahova hotīti āha – “anattasaññī asmimānasamugghātaṃ🔽pāpuṇātī”ti diṭṭheva dhamme nibbānanti diṭṭheyeva dhamme imasmiṃyeva attabhāve apaccayaparinibbānaṃ
analyzed: asmi iti uppajjana kamānaḥ hoti iti āha anatta saññī  pāpuṇāti iti diṭṭhe iva dhamme nibbānanti diṭṭhe iya iva dhamme imasmin yeva atta bhāve a paccaya parinibbānam
translated: When the characteristic of non-self is seen, the conceit “I am” is uprooted. Therefore it is said: “One who has the perception of non-self attains the destruction of the conceit ‘I am’ ” .

original: pāpuṇāti. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthārato pana asubhādibhāvanānayo visuddhimagge vuttanayena gahetabbo.
analyzed: pāpuṇāti ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārataḥ pana asubha ādi bhāvanā nayaḥ visuddhi magge vutta nayena gahetabbaḥ
translated: Nibbana in this very life: he attains the extinction of the cankers in this very life, in this very existence. This is the brief treatment. But the method of developing the meditation subject beginning with the contemplation of foulness should be understood in the way given in the Description of the Earth Kasiṇa .

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ āyasmato meghiyassa micchāvitakkacorehi kusalabhaṇḍupacchedasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam ā yasmataḥ meghiyassa micchā vitakka corehi kusala bhaṇḍa upaccheda saṅkhātam
translated: Having understood the meaning: having known the meaning of this verse, which is called “the cutting off of the profitable by the thief of wrong thought” .

original: atthaṃ jānitvā. Imaṃ udānanti imaṃ kāmavitakkādīnaṃ avinodane vinodane ca ādīnavānisaṃsadīpakaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: attham jānitvā imam udānanti imam kāma vitakka ādīnam avinodane vinodane ca ādīnava a nisaṃsa dīpakam udānam udānesi
translated: This inspired utterance: this utterance, which illuminates the danger and the benefit in not removing and in removing the thought of sense desire, etc., he uttered.

original: Tattha khuddāti hīnā lāmakā. Vitakkāti kāmavitakkādayo tayo pāpavitakkā. Te hi sabbavitakkehi
analyzed: tattha khuddā ati hīnā lāmakā vitakkā ati kāma vitakka ādayo tayo pāpa vitakkā te hi sabba vitakkehi
translated: Herein, low means inferior, vile. Thoughts : the three kinds of evil thoughts, that is, thoughts of sense desire, and so on. For these are the lowest of all thoughts.

original: patikiṭṭhatāya idha khuddāti vuttā “na ca khuddamācare”tiādīsu viya. Sukhumāti ñātivitakkādayo
analyzed: patikiṭṭha tāya idha khuddā ati vuttā na ca sukhumā iti ñāti vitakka ādayaḥ
translated: and because of their being small they are called here “small” in the way that “one should not do what is small” is said in the Paṭisambhidā . Subtle is the thinking of kinsmen, etc.,

original: adhippetā. Ñātivitakko janapadavitakko amarāvitakko parānuddayatāya paṭisaṃyutto
analyzed: adhippetā ñāti vitakkaḥ janapada vitakkaḥ amarā vitakko para an uddaya tāya paṭisaṃyutto
translated: They are called “small” here because of their being discarded, as in the passage beginning, “One should not do what is small” . “Subtle” : relatives’ thoughts, etc., are intended. Relatives’ thoughts, thoughts about the country, thoughts about the immortals, thoughts connected with compassion for others,

original: vitakko lābhasakkārasilokapaṭisaṃyutto vitakko anavaññattipaṭisaṃyutto vitakkoti🔽ete hi vitakkā kāmavitakkādayo viya dāruṇā na hontīti anoḷārikasabhāvatāya sukhumāti
analyzed: vitakkaḥ lābha sakkāra siloka paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vitakkaḥ anavaññatti paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vitakko ti  ete hi kāma vitakka ādayaḥ dāruṇāḥ na honti iti
translated: thoughts connected with gain, honour, and fame, thoughts connected with non-disparagement—

original: vuttā. Anugatāti cittena anuvattitā. Vitakke hi uppajjamāne cittaṃ tadanugatameva
analyzed: vuttā anugatā iti cittena anuvatti tā vitakke hi uppajjamāne cittam tad anugatam eva
translated: these thoughts are not as terrible as the thoughts of sensual desire, etc., and so they are called “subtle” because of their being of a less gross nature. “Attendant” : they follow the mind. For when thoughts arise, the mind is only attendant on them,

original: hoti tassa ārammaṇābhiniropanato. “Anuggatā”tipi pāḷi, anuuṭṭhitāti attho. Manaso
analyzed: hoti tassa ārammaṇa abhiniropanataḥ anuggatā atipi anuuṭṭhitā ati atthaḥ manasaḥ
translated: because it is applied to their object. The reading “anuggatā” is also allowable; the meaning is “following after.”

original: uppilāvāti cetaso uppilāvitattakarā.
analyzed: uppilā vāti cetasaḥ
translated: “Disturbance of mind” : they cause disturbance of the mind.

original: Ete avidvā manaso vitakketi ete kāmavitakkādike manovitakke assādādīnavanissaraṇato
analyzed: ete a vidvā manasaḥ vitakka iti ete kāma vitakka ādike manaḥ vitakke assāda ādīnava nissaraṇato
translated: “These thoughts of his, not knowing, think in the mind” : these thoughts of sensual desire, etc., are thoughts in the mind. Because of the escape from the gratification, etc., in sensual desire, etc.,

original: ñātatīraṇapahānapariññāhi yathābhūtaṃ ajānanto. Hurā huraṃ dhāvati bhantacittoti🔽appahīnamicchāvitakkattā anavaṭṭhitacitto “kadāci rūpe, kadāci sadde”tiādinā tasmiṃ
analyzed: yathābhūtam a jānantaḥ hurā huram dhāvati bhanta cittā iti  appahīna micchā vitakka ttā anavaṭṭhita cittaḥ kadāci rūpe kadāci sadda iti ādinā tasmin
translated: He who does not know as they really are through direct knowledge of them as familiar, as able to be departed from, and as able to be abandoned.🔽He runs here and there, his mind uncontrolled:

original: tasmiṃ ārammaṇe assādādivasena aparāparaṃ dhāvati paribbhamati. Atha vā hurā huraṃ
analyzed: tasmin ārammaṇe assāda ādi vasena apara aparam dhāvati paribbhamati atha vā hurā huram
translated: because he has not abandoned the thought of sensual desire, his mind is not steadied. He runs here and there, he wanders about, in regard to this and that object, such as visible forms, sounds, etc., by way of relishing their enjoyment, etc.🔽Or alternatively, he runs here and there, his mind uncontrolled: his mind is uncontrolled because he does not directly know the thoughts as they really are.

original: dhāvati bhantacittoti apariññātavitakkattā tannimittānaṃ avijjātaṇhānaṃ vasena paribbhamanamānaso
analyzed: dhāvati bhanta cittaḥ ti a pariññāta vitakka ttā tad nimittānam avijjā taṇhānam vasena paribbhamana mānasaḥ
translated: He wanders about by way of the ignorance and craving for the signs of those thoughts.

original: idhalokato paralokaṃ ādānanikkhepehi aparāparaṃ dhāvati saṃsaratīti attho.🔽Ete ca vidvā manaso vitakketi ete yathāvuttappabhede kāmavitakkādike manovitakke
analyzed: idhalokataḥ paralokam ādāna nikkhepehi apara aparam dhāvati saṃsarati iti attho  ete ca vidvā manasaḥ vitakka iti ete yathāvuttappa bhede kāma vitakka ādike manaḥ vitakke
translated: The meaning is: he runs, he transmigrates, from this world to the other world and back again by way of the taking up and laying down of the five aggregates.🔽The wise one, however, knowing these thoughts as they really are,🔽knowing them as they really are through direct knowledge of them as familiar, as able to be departed from, and as able to be abandoned.

original: assādādito yathābhūtaṃ jānanto. Ātāpiyoti vīriyavā. Saṃvaratīti pidahati. Satimāti
analyzed: yathābhūtam jānantaḥ vīriyavā saṃvarati iti pidahati
translated: He is ardent: he is energetic. He restrains: he suppresses. Mindful:

original: satisampanno. Anuggateti dullabhavasena anuppanne. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – ete vuttappakāre
analyzed: sati sampannaḥ anuggata iti dullabha vasena anuppanne idam vuttam hoti ete vutta ppakāre
translated: endowed with mindfulness. Before they arise: before they arise in the future by way of difficulty of attainment. This is the meaning:

original: kāmavitakkādike manovitakke cittassa uppilāvitahetutāya manaso uppilāve vidvā vipassanāpaññāsahitāya🔽maggapaññāya sammadeva jānanto, tassa sahāyabhūtānaṃ sammāvāyāmasatīnaṃ atthitāya
analyzed: kāma vitakka ādike manaḥ vitakke cittassa uppilāvita hetutāya manasaḥ uppilāve vidvā vipassanā paññā sahitāya  magga paññāya sammat eva jānanto tassa sahāya bhūtānam sammā vāyāma satīnam atthitāya
translated: Because the thought-arisings of sensual-desire thoughts, etc., are a cause for the mind’s being excited, they are called “exciters of the mind.”🔽The wise man, who is endowed with the understanding of insight,🔽knows them rightly by means of the path-understanding. Because of the presence of right effort and right mindfulness, which are his companions,

original: ātāpiyo satimā te ariyamaggabhāvanāya āyatiṃ uppattirahe anuggate anuppanne eva maggakkhaṇe🔽saṃvarati, ñāṇasaṃvaravasena pidahati, āgamanapathaṃ pacchindati, evaṃbhūto ca catusaccappabodhena
analyzed: te ariya magga bhāvanāya āyatim uppatti rahe anuggate an uppanne eva magga kkhaṇe  saṃvarati ñāṇa saṃvara vasena pidahati āgamana patham pacchindati evaṃbhūtaḥ ca catu sacca ppabodhena
translated: he is ardent and mindful. At the time of the path, he restrains,🔽he suppresses by means of the restraint of knowledge, he cuts off the way of coming of these thoughts that have not yet arisen and that will not arise again in the future by the development of the noble path.🔽The noble disciple who is thus,

original: buddho ariyasāvako arahattādhigamena asesaṃ, anavasesaṃ ete kāmavitakkādike pajahāsi
analyzed: buddhaḥ ariya sāvakaḥ arahatta adhigamena asesam anavasesam ete kāma vitakka ādike pajahāsi
translated: having awakened to the Four Truths, abandons, completely, without remainder, these sensual-desire thoughts, etc.

original: samucchindīti. Etthāpi “anugate”tipi paṭhanti. Tassattho heṭṭhā vuttoyeva.
analyzed: samucchindi iti ettha api anugatā iti pi paṭhanti tassa atthaḥ heṭṭhā vuttaḥ yeva
translated: Here, too, some read “anugate” . The meaning of this has already been explained above.

original: Paṭhamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽2. Uddhatasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭhama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  uddhata sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the first sutta is finished.🔽The sutta on the restless

original: 32. Dutiye kusinārāyanti kusinārāyaṃ nāma mallarājūnaṃ nagare. Upavattane mallānaṃ
analyzed: dutiye kusinārāyanti kusinārāyam nāma mallarājūnam nagare upavattane mallānam
translated: In the second sutta, “at Kusinārā” means in the city of the Mallan kings named Kusinārā. In the Upavattana, the Mallans’

original: sālavaneti yathā hi anurādhapurassa thūpārāmo, evaṃ kusinārāya uyyānaṃ dakkhiṇapacchimadisāya
analyzed: sāla vana iti yathā hi anurādhapurassa thūpa ārāmaḥ evam kusinārāya uyyānam dakkhiṇa pacchima disāya
translated: In the Sāla Grove: just as the Thūpārāma is to Anurādhapura, so the park is to Kusinārā. It is to the south-west of the city.

original: hoti. Yathā thūpārāmato dakkhiṇadvārena nagarapavisanamaggo pācīnamukho gantvā uttarena🔽nivattati, evaṃ uyyānato sālapanti pācīnamukhā gantvā uttarena nivattā, tasmā “upavattana”nti🔽vuccati. Tasmiṃ upavattane mallarājūnaṃ sālavane. Araññakuṭikāyanti sālapantiyā avidūre
analyzed: hoti yathā thūpa ārāmataḥ dakkhiṇa dvārena nagara pavisana maggo pācīna mukhaḥ gantvā uttarena  nivattati evam uyyānataḥ sā ālapanti pācīna mukhā gantvā uttarena nivattā tasmai  vuccati tasmim upavattane malla rājūnam sāla vane arañña kuṭikāyanti sālapantiyāḥ avidūre
translated: Just as the road to the city from the Thūpārāma by the southern gate goes east and turns north,

original: rukkhagacchasañchannaṭṭhāne katā kuṭikā, taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “araññakuṭikāyaṃ viharatī”ti.
analyzed: rukkha gaccha sañchanna ṭṭhāne katā kuṭikā tam sandhāya vuttam arañña kuṭikāyam viharati iti
translated: so the road from the park to the Sāla-tree Wood goes east and turns north, and for that reason it is called the “Upavattana.” In that Upavattana, in the Sāla Grove of the Mallans. In a hut in the forest: a hut built in a place covered by trees not far from the Sāla-tree Wood. It is with reference to that that it is said, “He was living in a hut in the forest.”

original: Te pana bhikkhū paṭisaṅkhānavirahitā ossaṭṭhavīriyā pamattavihārino, tena vuttaṃ “uddhatā”tiādi.
analyzed: te pana bhikkhū paṭisaṅkhāna virahitāḥ ossaṭṭha vīriyāḥ pamatta vihārino tena vuttam uddhata atiādi
translated: But those bhikkhus were without reflection, their energy was slackened, and they lived negligently. Hence it is said, “They were excited” and so on.

original: Tattha uddhaccabahulattā avūpasantacittatāya uddhatā. Tucchabhāvena māno naḷo viyāti
analyzed: tattha uddhacca bahula ttā a vūpasanta citta tāyai uddhatā tuccha bhāvena mānaḥ naḷaḥ viyāti
translated: Herein, they were excited because they had much excitement and their minds were not calm. They were puffed up because they were full of conceit. They were overweening because they were full of overweening conceit. They were domineering because they were full of domineering conceit. They were stubborn because they were full of stubborn conceit. They were arrogant because they were full of arrogant conceit. They were puffed up with conceit like reeds because they were full of conceit like reeds.

original: naḷo, mānasaṅkhāto uggato naḷo etesanti unnaḷā, uggatatucchamānāti attho. Pattacīvaramaṇḍanādicāpallena🔽samannāgatattā bahukatāya vā capalā. Pharusavācatāya mukhena kharāti mukharā. Tiracchānakathābahulatāya
analyzed: naḷaḥ māna saṅkhātaḥ uggataḥ naḷaḥ etesanti unnaḷāḥ uggata tuccha mānā ati patta cīvara maṇḍana ādi cāpallena  bahuka tāya vā capalā pharusa vācatāya mukhena kharā ati mukharā tiracchāna kathā bahu latāya
translated: Capalā: they are restless because of their restlessness in the matter of adorning their bowls and robes, etc.,🔽or because of their great activity. Mukharā: they are noisy because of their harsh speech. Tiracchānakathābahulā:🔽they are confused because of their great talk about animals. Vikiṇṇavācā: their speech is scattered, confused,

original: vikiṇṇā byākulā vācā etesanti vikiṇṇavācā. Muṭṭhā naṭṭhā sati etesanti muṭṭhassatino,
analyzed: vikiṇṇāḥ byākulāḥ vācāḥ etesanti vikiṇṇa vācāḥ muṭṭhā naṭṭhā sati etesanti muṭṭha ssatinaḥ
translated: because of this. Muṭṭhassatino: they are forgetful, their mindfulness is lost,

original: sativirahitā pamādavihārinoti attho. Sabbena sabbaṃ sampajaññābhāvato asampajānā.
analyzed: sati virahitā pamāda vihārino ti attho sabbena sabbam sampajaññā bhāvataḥ asampajānā
translated: the meaning is, they are living in negligence, devoid of mindfulness. Asampajānā: they are not fully aware because of the absence of full awareness in every way.

original: Gaddūhanamattampi kālaṃ cittasamādhānassa abhāvato na samāhitāti asamāhitā. Lolasabhāvattā🔽bhantamigasappaṭibhāgatāya vibbhantacittā. Manacchaṭṭhānaṃ indriyānaṃ asaṃvaraṇato
analyzed: kālam citta samādhānassa abhāvataḥ na samāhitā ati asamāhitā  bhanta miga sappaṭibhāga tāya vibbhanta cittāḥ manaccha ṭṭhānam indriyānam a saṃvaraṇato
translated: Asamāhitā: they are not concentrated because of the absence of mental concentration for even the time it takes to chew and swallow two or three mouthfuls.🔽Vibbhantacittā: their minds are scattered because of their restless nature,

original: asaññatindriyatāya pākatindriyā.
analyzed: a saññatindriya tāya pākatindriyā
translated: because of their being like a darting deer. Pākatindriyā: their faculties are dissipated because of their lack of restraint over the faculties,🔽which have the mind as their sixth.

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ uddhaccādivasena pamādavihāraṃ jānitvā.
analyzed: etam attham viditvā ti etam tesam bhikkhūnam uddhacca ādi vasena pamāda vihāram jānitvā
translated: Having known the meaning of this: having known the living in negligence of those monks by way of restlessness, etc.

original: Imaṃ udānanti imaṃ pamādavihāre appamādavihāre ca yathākkamaṃ ādīnavānisaṃsavibhāvanaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: imam udānan ti imam pamāda vihāre appamāda vihāre ca yathākkamam ādīnava anisaṃsa vibhāvanam udānam udānesi
translated: This utterance: he uttered this utterance which reveals the danger and the benefit respectively in the dwelling in negligence and in the dwelling in diligence.🔽Therein, unguarded: not guarded by the guard of mindfulness.

original: Tattha arakkhitenāti satiārakkhābhāvena aguttena. Kāyenāti chaviññāṇakāyena cakkhuviññāṇena
analyzed: tattha arakkhitena ati sati ārakkha abhāvena aguttena kāyena ati cha viññāṇa kāyena cakkhu viññāṇena
translated: By body: by the body of the six consciousnesses. For by means of eye-consciousness,

original: hi rūpaṃ disvā tattha nimittānubyañjanaggahaṇavasena abhijjhādipavattito viññāṇadvārassa
analyzed: hi rūpam disvā tattha nimitta anubyañjana ggahaṇa vasena abhijjhā ādi pavattitaḥ viññāṇa dvārassa
translated: having seen a visible form, through the apprehension of its sign and details, covetousness, etc., occur.🔽Because the door of consciousness is unguarded by mindfulness,

original: satiyā arakkhitabhāvato. Sotaviññāṇādīsupi eseva nayo. Evaṃ chaviññāṇakāyassa arakkhitabhāvaṃ
analyzed: satiyāḥ arakkhita bhāvato sota viññāṇa ādīsu pi esa iva nayo evam cha viññāṇa kāyassa arakkhita bhāvam
translated: the same method applies to ear-consciousness, etc. Thus, referring to the unguardedness of the body of the six consciousnesses,

original: sandhāyāha “arakkhitena kāyenā”ti. Keci pana “kāyenā”ti atthaṃ vadanti, tesampi vuttanayeneva
analyzed: sandhāya āha arakkhitena kāyena ati keci pana kāyena ati attham vadanti tesam pi vutta nayena iva
translated: it is said: “by unguarded body.” But some say that the meaning of “body” is “person.” For them also,🔽the explanation should be applied in the same way.

original: atthayojanāya sati yujjeyya. Apare pana “arakkhitena cittenā”ti paṭhanti, tesampi
analyzed: attha yojanāya sati yujjeyya apare pana arakkhitena cittena ati paṭhanti tesam pi
translated: Others read: “by unguarded mind.” For them also,🔽the meaning is the same as the above. Smitten by wrong view: defiled by the adherence to the wrong view of eternalism, etc.

original: vuttanayo eva attho. Micchādiṭṭhihatenāti sassatādimicchābhinivesadūsitena. Thinamiddhābhibhūtenāti
analyzed: vutta nayaḥ eva atthaḥ micchādiṭṭhi hatena ati sassata ādi micchā abhinivesa dūsitena thina middha abhibhūtena ati
translated: Overcome by sloth and torpor:

original: cittassa akalyatālakkhaṇena thinena kāyassa akalyatālakkhaṇena middhena ca ajjhotthaṭena,
analyzed: cittassa akalya tā lakkhaṇena thinena kāyassa akalya tā lakkhaṇena middhena ca ajjhotthaṭena
translated: By sluggishness, which has the characteristic of unfitness of consciousness, and by drowsiness, which has the characteristic of unfitness of body,

original: tena kāyena cittenāti vā sambandho. Vasaṃ mārassa gacchatīti kilesamārādikassa sabbassapi
analyzed: tena kāyena cittena ati vā sambandhaḥ vasam mārassa gacchati iti kilesa māra ādikassa sabbassa api
translated: and by the body and mind that are oppressed by them. “Comes under the sway of Mara” means that he comes under the sway of all the Maras, such as the Mara of defilements, etc.,

original: mārassa vasaṃ yathākāmakaraṇīyataṃ upagacchati, tesaṃ visayaṃ nātikkamatīti attho.
analyzed: mārassa vasam yathākāma karaṇīya tam upagacchati tesam visayam na atikkamati iti attho
translated: and is made to do the bidding of all of them; he does not transcend their domain.

original: Imāya hi gāthāya bhagavā ye satiārakkhābhāvena sabbaso arakkhitacittā, yonisomanasikārassa🔽hetubhūtāya paññāya abhāvato ayoniso ummujjanena niccantiādinā vipariyesagāhino,
analyzed: imāya hi gāthāya bhagavā ye sati ārakkha abhāvena sabbasas arakkhita cittāḥ yoniso manasikārassa  hetu bhūtāya paññāya abhāvataḥ ayonisaḥ ummujjanena niccanti ādinā vipariyesa gāhino
translated: For by this stanza the Blessed One shows the round of rebirths to those bhikkhus who, by not guarding their mind with mindfulness,

original: tato eva kusalakiriyāya vīriyārambhābhāvato kosajjābhibhūtā saṃsāravaṭṭato sīsaṃ🔽na ukkhipissantīti tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ pamādavihāragarahāmukhena vaṭṭaṃ dassetvā idāni
analyzed: tatas eva kusala kiriyāya vīriya ārambha abhāvataḥ kosajja abhibhūtā saṃsāra vaṭṭataḥ sīsam  na ukkhipissanti iti tesam bhikkhūnam pamāda vihāra garahā mukhena vaṭṭam dassetvā idāni
translated: by wrong reflection, etc., come to be overcome by sloth and torpor, and who, by not undertaking the wholesome, by not making effort, will not lift up their heads from the round of rebirths.

original: vivaṭṭaṃ dassetuṃ, “tasmā rakkhitacittassā”ti dutiyagāthamāha.
analyzed: vivaṭṭam dassetum tasmā rakkhita cittassa iti dutiya gātham āha
translated: Having shown the round of rebirths by way of their dwelling in negligence, the Blessed One now shows the cessation of the round by the second stanza, “Therefore, with guarded mind,” etc.

original: Tattha tasmā rakkhitacittassāti yasmā arakkhitacitto mārassa yathākāmakaraṇīyo hutvā
analyzed: tattha tasmai rakkhita cittassa ati yasmai arakkhita cittaḥ mārassa yathākāma karaṇīyaḥ hutvā
translated: Herein, since he is one whose mind is guarded, he is not one whose mind is unguarded and who is at Mara’s disposal as described in the passage beginning,

original: saṃsāreyeva hoti, tasmā satisaṃvarena manacchaṭṭhānaṃ indriyānaṃ rakkhaṇena pidahanena
analyzed: hoti tasmai sati saṃvarena indriyānaṃ rakkhaṇena pidahanena
translated: Herein, therefore, he should guard his mind: since one whose mind is unguarded is at the disposal of Mara in the way already stated and is in the round of rebirths. So he should guard it by means of the restraint of mindfulness, by keeping the six sense doors well guarded.

original: rakkhitacitto assa. Citte hi rakkhite cakkhādiindriyāni rakkhitāneva hontīti. Sammāsaṅkappagocaroti🔽yasmā micchāsaṅkappagocaro tathā tathā ayoniso vitakketvā nānāvidhāni micchādassanāni🔽gaṇhanto micchādiṭṭhihatena cittena mārassa yathākāmakaraṇīyo hoti, tasmā yonisomanasikārena🔽kammaṃ karonto nekkhammasaṅkappādisammāsaṅkappagocaro assa, jhānādisampayuttaṃ sammāsaṅkappameva
analyzed: rakkhita cittaḥ assa citte hi rakkhite cakkha ādi indriyāni rakkhitāni eva honti iti sammāsaṅkappa gocaraḥ ti  yasmai micchā saṅkappa gocaraḥ tathā tathā ayonisas vitakketvā nānāvidhāni micchā dassanāni  gaṇhantaḥ micchādiṭṭhi hatena cittena mārassa yathākāma karaṇīyaḥ hoti tasmai yoniso manasikārena  kammam karontaḥ nekkhamma saṅkappa ādi sammāsaṅkappa gocaraḥ assa jhāna ādi sampayuttam sammāsaṅkappam eva
translated: For when the mind is guarded the eye and the rest are also guarded.🔽He should have right view as his domain: since one whose domain is wrong view, by misconstruing things through wrong reflection, takes up various wrong beliefs, and then, with a mind struck down by wrong view, he is at the disposal of Mara in the way already stated. So he should have right reflection by means of right direction of attention. He should make right view, which is associated with the jhānas, etc.,

original: attano cittassa pavattiṭṭhānaṃ kareyya. Sammādiṭṭhipurekkhāroti sammāsaṅkappagocaratāya
analyzed: attano cittassa pavatti ṭṭhānam kareyya sammādiṭṭhi purekkhāro ti sammāsaṅkappa gocara tāya
translated: the domain of his mind, the province of his mind.🔽He should have right view as his forerunner: since one whose domain is wrong view is in the round of rebirths, therefore he should have right view as his forerunner.

original: vidhūtamicchādassano puretaraṃyeva kammassakatālakkhaṇaṃ, tato yathābhūtañāṇalakkhaṇañca
analyzed: vidhūtam icchā dassano puretaram yeva kammassaka tā lakkhaṇam tatas yathābhūta ñāṇa lakkhaṇam ca
translated: The view of self and the desire for self are shaken off. The characteristic of the ownership of kamma comes first, then the characteristic of the knowledge of things as they really are.

original: sammādiṭṭhiṃ purato katvā pubbe vuttanayeneva sīlasamādhīsu yutto payutto vipassanaṃ🔽ārabhitvā saṅkhāre sammasanto ñatvāna udayabbayaṃ pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu samapaññāsāya
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhim puratas katvā pubbe vutta nayena iva sīla samādhīsu yuttaḥ payuttaḥ vipassanam  ārabhitvā saṅkhāre sammasantaḥ ñatvānaḥ udaya bbayam pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu samapaññāsāya
translated: Having placed right view in the forefront, he is intent on and devoted to virtue and concentration in the way already described.🔽He begins insight, and having discerned the five aggregates as impermanent, painful, and not-self, he comprehends the five aggregates subject to clinging by means of the sixteen modes of materiality and mentality.

original: ākārehi uppādanirodhaṃ vavatthapetvā udayabbayañāṇamadhigantvā tato paraṃ bhaṅgānupassanādivasena
analyzed: ākārehi uppāda nirodham vavatthapetvā udaya bbaya ñāṇam adhigantvā tato param bhaṅga anupassanā ādi vasena
translated: Having thus defined the arising and falling away of materiality and mentality by means of the sixteen modes, he attains the knowledge of arising and passing away. Then, by means of the contemplation of dissolution, etc.,

original: vipassanaṃ ussukkāpetvā anukkamena ariyamaggaṃ gaṇhanto aggamaggena, thinamiddhābhibhū
analyzed: vipassanam ussukkāpetvā anukkamena ariya maggam gaṇhantaḥ agga maggena thinamiddha abhibhū
translated: he develops insight, and eventually he reaches the noble paths.

original: bhikkhu sabbā duggatiyo jaheti, evaṃ so heṭṭhimamaggavajjhānaṃ kilesānaṃ paṭhamameva
analyzed: bhikkhu sabbāḥ duggatiyaḥ jaheti evam so heṭṭhima magga vajjhānam kilesānam paṭhamam eva
translated: The bhikkhu who has overcome sloth and torpor abandons all the states of woe. Thus, since the defilements abandoned by the first path are the first to be abandoned,

original: pahīnattā diṭṭhivippayuttalobhasahagatacittuppādesu uppajjanakathinamiddhānaṃ adhigatena
analyzed: pahīna ttā diṭṭhi vippayutta lobha sahagata cittuppādesu adhigatena
translated: he abandons the sloth and torpor that arise in the consciousness accompanied by attachment dissociated from wrong view.

original: arahattamaggena samucchindanato tadekaṭṭhānaṃ mānādīnampi pahīnattā sabbaso bhinnakileso
analyzed: arahatta maggena samucchindanato tat ekaṭṭhānam māna ādīnam pi pahīna ttā sabbasas bhinna kilesaḥ
translated: Because he has cut them off by means of the path of arahatship, and because conceit, etc., which have the same basis as the defilements have also been abandoned, the bhikkhu is completely free from defilements.

original: khīṇāsavo bhikkhu tividhadukkhatāyogena duggatisaṅkhātā sabbāpi gatiyo ucchinnabhavamūlattā
analyzed: khīṇāsavaḥ tividha dukkha tā yogena duggati saṅkhātā sabbā api gatiyaḥ ucchinna bhava mūla ttā
translated: The bhikkhu of destroyed taints abandons all destinations, which are called “misery” because of their association with the three kinds of suffering.

original: jahe, pajaheyya. Tāsaṃ parabhāge nibbāne patiṭṭheyyāti attho.
analyzed: jahe pajaheyya tāsam parabhāge nibbāne patiṭṭheyya attho
translated: He abandons them, he rejects them, because the root of existence has been cut off. The meaning is that he is established in Nibbāna, which is beyond those destinations.

original: Dutiyasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dutiya sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the second sutta is finished.

original: 3. Gopālakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: gopālaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The GopakāsĪla Sutta

original: 33. Tatiye kosalesūti kosalā nāma jānapadino rājakumārā, tesaṃ nivāso ekopi janapado
analyzed: tatiye kosalesu iti kosalāḥ nāma jānapadinaḥ rāja kumārā tesam nivāsaḥ ekaḥ api janapadaḥ
translated: In the third sutta, in the Kosalan country means in the Kosalan country, which is the name of a country inhabited by princes called the Kosalans.

original: “kosalā”tveva vuccati, tesu kosalesu janapade. Cārikaṃ caratīti aturitacārikāvasena
analyzed: kosalā tu eva vuccati tesu kosalesu janapade cārikam carati iti aturita cārikā vasena
translated: It is called “Kosala” because of the presence of Kosalans. He was “wandering on a walking tour” means he was walking on a walking tour for the benefit of the people.🔽With a great

original: janapadacārikaṃ carati. Mahatāti guṇamahattenapi mahatā, aparicchinnasaṅkhyattā saṅkhyāmahattenapi🔽mahatā. Bhikkhusaṅghenāti diṭṭhisīlasāmaññasaṃhatena samaṇagaṇena. Saddhinti ekato.
analyzed: janapada cārikam carati mahatā ati guṇa mahat tena api mahatā aparicchinna saṅkhyat tā saṅkhyā mahat tena api 🔽mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena ati diṭṭhi sīla sāmañña saṃhatena samaṇa gaṇena saddhin ti ekatas
translated: means with a great community of bhikkhus, great in terms of the greatness of its qualities and great in terms of the greatness of its number, which is not limited.🔽Together with means together with.

original: Maggā okkammāti maggato apakkamitvā. Aññataraṃ rukkhamūlanti ghanapattasākhāviṭapasampannassa
analyzed: maggā okkamma ati maggataḥ a pakkamitvā aññataram rukkha mūlanti ghana patta sākhā viṭapa sampannassa
translated: “He left the road” — he left the road and went to a certain tree.

original: sandacchāyassa mahato rukkhassa samīpasaṅkhātaṃ mūlaṃ.
analyzed: sandacchāyassa mahato rukkhassa samīpa saṅkhātam mūlam
translated: “A certain tree” — the foot of a tree which was not far from a thick-leaved tree which had a dense shade.

original: Aññataro gopālakoti eko gogaṇarakkhako, nāmena pana nando nāma. So kira aḍḍho mahaddhano
analyzed: aññataraḥ eko go gaṇa rakkhakaḥ nāmena pana nandaḥ nāma so kira aḍḍhaḥ mahat dhano
translated: “A certain cowherd” — a certain cowherd who was looking after a herd of cows, by name Nanda. It is said that he was rich, had great wealth,🔽and was a great landowner. Just as the ascetic Keṇiya was, in the matter of going forth,

original: mahābhogo, yathā keṇiyo jaṭilo pabbajjāvasena, evaṃ anāthapiṇḍikassa goyūthaṃ rakkhanto
analyzed: mahā bhogaḥ yathā keṇiyaḥ jaṭilaḥ pabbajjā avasena evam anāthapiṇḍikassa go yūtham rakkhantaḥ
translated: so he was looking after Anāthapiṇḍika’s herd of cows,

original: gopālakattena rājapīḷaṃ apaharanto attano kuṭumbaṃ rakkhati. So kālena kālaṃ pañca
analyzed: gopālaka ttena rāja pīḷam apaharantaḥ attanaḥ kuṭumbam rakkhati saḥ kālena kālam pañca
translated: and by the means of a cowherd was removing the king’s oppression, and was looking after his own family. He, from time to time,

original: gorase gahetvā, mahāseṭṭhissa santikaṃ āgantvā niyyātetvā satthu santikaṃ gantvā,
analyzed: gorase gahetvā mahāseṭṭhissa santikam āgantvā niyyātetvā satthu santikam gantvā
translated: having taken five cow products, having gone into the presence of the great merchant, having handed them over, having gone into the presence of the Teacher,

analyzed: satthāram passati dhammam suṇāti attanaḥ vasana ṭṭhānam āgamana tthāya satthāram yācati

analyzed: satthā tassa iva ñāṇa paripākam āgamayamānaḥ a gantvā aparabhāge mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena

analyzed: parivutaḥ janapada cārikam carantaḥ idānissa ñāṇam paripakkan ti ñatvā tassa vasana ṭṭhānassa
translated: surrounded by a great multitude, and seeing that his knowledge was ripe, he went to the place where he was living,

original: avidūre maggā okkamma aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle nisīdi tassa āgamanaṃ āgamayamāno.
analyzed: avidūre maggā okkamma aññatarasmim rukkha mūle nisīdi tassa āgamanam āgamayamāno
translated: and when he knew that his knowledge was ripe, he left the road and sat down at the root of a certain tree not far from Nandaka’s dwelling, waiting for him to come.

original: Nandopi kho “satthā kira janapadacārikaṃ caranto ito āgacchatī”ti sutvā, haṭṭhatuṭṭho
analyzed: nandaḥ api kho satthā kira janapada cārikam carantaḥ itas āgacchati iti sutvā haṭṭha tuṭṭhaḥ
translated: Nandaka, too, hearing that the Teacher was coming that way,

analyzed: vegena gantvā satthāram upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā kata paṭisanthāraḥ ekamantam nisīdi

analyzed: sattāham pāyāsa dānam adāsi sattame divase bhagavā anumodanam katvā tena

analyzed: vuttam ekamantam nisinnam kho tam gopālakam bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassesipe

analyzed: visesa bhāva dassanena cittassa pamodāpana vasena suṭṭhu pahaṃsesi api ca ittha sāvajja anavajja dhammesu
translated: and he inspired them with confidence in the right way, in the way beginning “These ideas, when they are rightly taken up, come to maturity in direct knowledge” ,🔽and he inspired them with confidence in the right way,

original: dukkhādīsu ca sammohavinodanena sandassanaṃ, sammāpaṭipattiyaṃ pamādāpanodanena samādapanaṃ,
analyzed: dukkha ādīsu ca sammoha vinodanena sandassanam sammāpaṭipattiyam pamāda apanodanena samādapanam
translated: And he instructed him by dispelling his delusion about suffering, etc.,🔽he roused him by dispelling his sloth-and-torpor about the right way,

analyzed: cittassa alasiyā āpatti vinodanena samuttejanam sammāpaṭipatti siddhiyā sampahaṃsanam

analyzed: veditabbam evam saḥ bhagavato sāmukkaṃsikāya dhamma desanāya sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi  adhivāsesi iti tena diṭṭha saccena adhivāsetu me bhante bhagavā atiādinā nimantitaḥ

analyzed: sahatthena iva parivisantaḥ santappesi iti paṭiyattam bhojanam bhojesi sampavāresi iti
translated: he served it himself, showing respect. He satisfied him: he fed him the prepared food. He asked him:

original: “alaṃ ala”nti vācāya paṭikkhipāpesi. Bhuttāvinti katabhattakiccaṃ. Onītapattapāṇinti
analyzed: alam alam ti vācāya paṭikkhipa āpesi bhuttāvinti kata bhatta kiccam onīta patta pāṇinti
translated: “Enough, enough,” and he refused the invitation. Had finished his meal: had done what was to be done in connection with the meal. When he had eaten and had withdrawn his hand from the bowl:

original: pattato apanītapāṇiṃ, “dhotapattapāṇi”ntipi pāṭho, dhotapattahatthanti attho. Nīcanti
analyzed: pattataḥ apanīta pāṇim dhota patta pāṇim tipi pāṭhaḥ dhota patta hattham ti atthaḥ nīcam ti
translated: when he had withdrawn his hand from the bowl, “had washed his hand and withdrawn his bowl” is another reading, the meaning being “had washed his hand and his bowl.” A suitable seat:

original: anuccaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā āsaneyeva nisīdanaṃ ariyadesavāsīnaṃ cārittaṃ, so pana satthu
analyzed: anuccam āsanam gahetvā āsaneya iva nisīdanam ariya desa vāsīnam cārittam saḥ pana satthu
translated: a seat that was not too high and not too low, a seat that was in accordance with the practice of Noble Ones. But he sat down on a seat that was prepared by the Teacher,

original: santike upacāravasena paññattassa dāruphalakāsanassa samīpe nisīdi. Dhammiyā kathāyātiādi🔽sattame divase kataṃ anumodanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. So kira sattāhaṃ bhagavantaṃ bhikkhusaṅghañca
analyzed: santike upacāra vasena paññattassa dāru phalaka āsanassa samīpe nisīdi dhammiyā kathāya atiādi  sattame divase katam anumodanam sandhāya vuttam saḥ kira sattāham bhagavantam bhikkhu saṅghañca
translated: near a seat of wood and planks that had been prepared for the Teacher. A talk on the Dhamma:

original: tattha vasāpetvā mahādānaṃ pavattesi. Sattame pana divase appodakapāyāsadānaṃ adāsi.
analyzed: tattha vasāpetvā mahādānam pavattesi sattame pana divase appa udaka pāyāsa dānam adāsi
translated: this refers to the expression of appreciation made on the seventh day. For it seems that for seven days the householder had the Blessed One and the community of bhikkhus dwell there and had a great distribution of gifts made. But on the seventh day he gave a gift of rice gruel with a little curry.

original: Satthā tassa tasmiṃ attabhāve uparimaggatthāya ñāṇaparipākābhāvato anumodanameva katvā pakkāmi.
analyzed: satthā tassa tasmin atta bhāve upari magga atthāya ñāṇa paripāka abhāvataḥ anumodanam eva katvā pakkāmi
translated: The Teacher expressed his appreciation and then departed, because the householder’s present personality was not ripe for the higher paths.

original: Sīmantarikāyāti sīmantare, tassa gāmassa antaraṃ. Gāmavāsino kira ekaṃ taḷākaṃ nissāya🔽tena saddhiṃ kalahaṃ akaṃsu. So te abhibhavitvā taṃ taḷākaṃ gaṇhi. Tena baddhāghāto
analyzed: sīmantarikāya ati sīmantare tassa gāmassa antaram gāma vāsinaḥ kira ekam taḷākam nissāya  tena saddhim kalaham saḥ te abhibhavitvā tam taḷākam tena baddha āghātaḥ
translated: “In the border area” means in the border region, in the middle of that village. It seems that the inhabitants of the village had a quarrel with him over a pond.🔽He defeated them and took possession of the pond. Because of that, a man who had a grudge against him

original: eko puriso taṃ satthu pattaṃ gahetvā dūraṃ anugantvā “nivattāhi upāsakā”ti vutte
analyzed: ekaḥ purisaḥ tam satthu pattam gahetvā dūram anugantvā nivattāhi upāsaka iti vutte
translated: took the Teacher’s bowl and followed him for a long time. When the Teacher said, “Go back, lay follower,”

original: bhagavantaṃ vanditvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā bhikkhusaṅghassa ca añjaliṃ katvā yāva dassanūpacārasamatikkamā🔽dasanakhasamodhānasamujjalaṃ añjaliṃ sirasi paggayha paṭinivattitvā dvinnaṃ gāmānaṃ
analyzed: bhagavantam vanditvā padakkhiṇam katvā bhikkhu saṅghassa ca añjalim katvā yāva dassana upacāra samatikkamā  dasa nakha samodhāna samujjalam añjalim sirasi paggayha paṭinivattitvā dvinnam gāmānam
translated: he paid homage to the Blessed One, circumambulated him keeping him to his right, and then, after paying homage to the Sangha of bhikkhus, he turned back only after he had gone beyond the range of sight.🔽In the middle of the two villages, in the forest region, he struck the Teacher with a spear as he was going alone.

original: antare araññappadese ekakaṃ gacchantaṃ sarena vijjhitvā māresi. Tena vuttaṃ acirapakkantassa…pe…
analyzed: antare arañña ppadese ekakam gacchantam sarena vijjhitvā māresi tena vuttam acira pakkanta ssape
translated: Thus it is said: “Not long after he had gone …🔽he struck him with a spear.”

original: voropesī”ti. Kenacideva karaṇīyena ohīyitvā pacchā gacchantā bhikkhū taṃ tathā mataṃ
analyzed: voropesi iti kenacid eva karaṇīyena ohīyitvā pacchā gacchantā bhikkhū tam tathā matam
translated: The bhikkhus who had left him behind and were going back later saw him lying there dead.

original: disvā bhagavato tamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ, taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū”tiādi.
analyzed: disvā bhagavato tam attham ārocesuṃ tam sandhāya vuttam atha kho sambahulā bhikkhu iti ādi
translated: and after seeing it they reported the matter to the Blessed One. “Then a number of bhikkhus” is said in reference to that.🔽Having understood the meaning of this,

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti yasmā diṭṭhisampannaṃ ariyasāvakaṃ nandaṃ mārentena purisena
analyzed: etam attham viditvā ati yasmā diṭṭhi sampannam ariya sāvakam nandam mārentena purisena
translated: because the man who was killing the noble disciple Nanda, who was possessed of right view,

original: ānantariyakammaṃ bahulaṃ apuññaṃ pasutaṃ, tasmā yaṃ corehi ca verīhi ca kattabbaṃ,
analyzed: ānantariya kammam bahulam apuññam pasutam tasmai yam corehi ca verīhi ca kattabbam
translated: had done much demerit by doing an immediate-resultant action,

original: tatopi ghorataraṃ imesaṃ sattānaṃ micchāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ karotīti imamatthaṃ jānitvā
analyzed: tatas api ghorataram imesam sattānam micchā paṇihitam cittam karoti iti imam attham jānitvā
translated: therefore, “this mind of these beings, which is wrongly directed, makes them do a deed that is more terrible than what is done by thieves and enemies.” Having known the meaning of this,

original: tadatthadīpanaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: tad attha dīpanam imam udānam udānesi
translated: he uttered this utterance explaining that meaning.

original: Tattha diso disanti dūsako dūsanīyaṃ coro coraṃ, disvāti vacanaseso. Yaṃ taṃ kayirāti
analyzed: tattha disaḥ disanti dūsakaḥ dūsanīyam coraḥ coram disvā ati vacana sesaḥ yam tam kayirā ati
translated: Herein, in every direction means in every direction, a thief in every direction, a thief seeing a thief. The remainder of the words is this: “What he might do”

original: yaṃ tassa anayabyasanaṃ kareyya, dutiyapadepi eseva nayo. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – eko
analyzed: yam tassa anaya byasanam kareyya dutiya pade pi esa iva nayaḥ idam vuttam hoti ekaḥ
translated: means what he might do to bring about his ruin and disaster. The same method of explanation applies to the second line. This is the meaning:

original: ekassa mittadubbhī coro puttadārakhettavatthugomahiṃsādīsu aparajjhanto yassa aparajjhati,
analyzed: ekassa mitta dubbhī coro putta dāra khetta vatthu go mahiṃsa ādīsu aparajjhantaḥ yassa aparajjhati
translated: one who is a thief and a betrayer of friends, who is a wrong-doer in regard to the children, wives, fields, lands, cattle, buffaloes, etc., of another,

original: tampi tatheva attani aparajjhantaṃ coraṃ disvā, verī vā pana kenacideva kāraṇena
analyzed: tam pi tathā iva aparajjhantam coram disvā verī vā pana kenacid eva kāraṇena
translated: and he sees that the thief does not offend him in return, or he sees an enemy who has been bound by some means or other,

original: baddhaveraṃ veriṃ disvā attano kakkhaḷatāya dāruṇatāya yaṃ tassa anayabyasanaṃ kareyya,
analyzed: baddha veram verim disvā kakkhaḷa tāya dāruṇa tāya yam tassa anaya byasanam kareyya
translated: and because of his own harshness and cruelty he does what will bring that man misfortune and loss,

original: puttadāraṃ vā pīḷeyya, khettādīni vā nāseyya, jīvitā vā voropeyya, dasasu akusalakammapathesu
analyzed: putta dāram vā pīḷeyya khetta ādīni vā nāseyya jīvitā vā voropeyya dasasu akusala kamma pathesu
translated: or he torments his wife and children or destroys his fields, etc., or he deprives him of life,

original: micchāṭhapitattā micchāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ pāpiyo naṃ tato kare, naṃ purisaṃ pāpataraṃ
analyzed: micchā ṭhapita tā micchā paṇihitam cittam pāpiyaḥ nam tatas kare nam purisam pāpataram
translated: then because of his wrong view his mind, which is wrongly directed, makes him worse, makes him more wicked.

original: tato kareyya. Vuttappakāro hi diso vā verī vā disassa vā verino vā imasmiṃyeva attabhāve🔽dukkhaṃ vā uppādeyya, jīvitakkhayaṃ vā kareyya. Idaṃ pana akusalakammapathesu micchāṭhapitaṃ🔽cittaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme anayabyasanaṃ pāpeti, attabhāvasatasahassesupi catūsu apāyesu
analyzed: tatas kareyya vutta ppakāraḥ hi disaḥ vā verī vā disassa vā verinaḥ vā imasmiṃ eva atta bhāve  dukkham vā uppādeyya jīvita kkhayam vā kareyya idam pana akusala kamma pathesu micchā ṭhapitam  cittam diṭṭhā iva dhamme anaya byasanam pāpa iti attabhāva sata sahassesu pi catūsu apāyesu
translated: For such a quarter or such an enemy might cause him pain or even death in this very life,🔽but this mind, which is wrongly directed in the unprofitable courses of action,

original: khipitvā sīsamassa ukkhipituṃ na detīti.
analyzed: khipitvā sīsam assa ukkhipitum na deti iti
translated: leads him to misfortune and loss in this very life. It does not let him raise his head even in a hundred thousand existences in the four states of misery.

original: Tatiyasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tatiya sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the third sutta is finished.

original: 4. Yakkhapahārasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: yakkha pahāra sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 4. The sutta on the yakkha’s blow

original: 34. Catutthe kapotakandarāyanti evaṃnāmake vihāre. Tasmiṃ kira pabbatakandare pubbe
analyzed: catutthe kapotakandarāyanti evaṃnāmake vihāre tasmin kira pabbata kandare pubbe
translated: In the fourth, in the Pigeon Cave: in a monastery of that name. It seems that in the past many pigeons lived in that mountain cave,

original: bahū kapotā vasiṃsu, tena sā pabbatakandarā “kapotakandarā”ti vuccati. Aparabhāge🔽tattha katavihāropi “kapotakandarā”tveva paññāyittha. Tena vuttaṃ – “kapotakandarāyanti🔽evaṃnāmake vihāre”ti. Juṇhāya rattiyāti sukkapakkharattiyaṃ. Navoropitehi kesehīti
analyzed: bahū kapotāḥ vasiṃsu tena sā pabbatakandarā kapotakandarā ti vuccati aparabhāge  tattha kata vihāraḥ api kapotakandarā tu eva paññāyittha tena vuttam kapotakandarāyanti  evaṃnāmake vihāre ti juṇhāya rattiyā ati sukkapakkha rattiyam na voropitehi kesehi iti
translated: and so that mountain cave was called “the Pigeon Cave.” Later on,

original: aciraohāritehi kesehi, itthambhūtalakkhaṇe cetaṃ karaṇavacanaṃ. Abbhokāseti yattha🔽uparicchadanaṃ parikkhepo vā natthi, tādise ākāsaṅgaṇe.
analyzed: acira ohāritehi kesehi ittham bhūta lakkhaṇe ca itam karaṇa vacanam  uparicchadanam parikkhepaḥ vā na atthi tādise ākāsaṅgaṇe
translated: the monastery built there became known as “the Pigeon Cave” too. Hence it was said: “in the monastery of that name, the Pigeon Cave” . On a moonlit night: on a night of the bright fortnight. With newly cut hair: with hair recently shaved off; the gerund here is in the sense of the gerundive. In the open air: in a courtyard where there is no roof or enclosure.

original: Tattha āyasmā sāriputto suvaṇṇavaṇṇo, āyasmā mahāmoggallāno nīluppalavaṇṇo. Ubhopi
analyzed: tattha āyasmā sāriputto suvaṇṇa vaṇṇo āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ nīluppala vaṇṇo ubho pi
translated: There the venerable Sariputta was golden-coloured, and the venerable Maha Moggallana was the colour of a blue lotus. But both of these great elders were born as brahmans of the Udicca clan,

original: pana te mahātherā udiccabrāhmaṇajaccā kappānaṃ satasahassādhikaṃ ekaṃ asaṅkhyeyyaṃ
analyzed: pana te mahā therāḥ kappānam sata sahassa adhikam ekam asaṅkhyeyyam
translated: and they had already completed one incalculable age and a hundred thousand eons.

original: abhinīhārasampannā chaḷabhiññāpaṭisambhidāppattā mahākhīṇāsavā samāpattilābhino sattasaṭṭhiyā
analyzed: abhinīhāra sampannā chaṭṭha abhiññā paṭisambhidā appattā mahā khīṇa āsavā samāpatti lābhinaḥ satta saṭṭhiyā
translated: endowed with the aspiration (to Buddhahood), having attained the six deep knowledges and the discriminations, great (Arahants) with cankers destroyed, who had attained (the highest state),

original: sāvakapāramiñāṇānaṃ matthakappattā etaṃ kapotakandaravihāraṃ upasobhayantā ekaṃ kanakaguhaṃ
analyzed: sāvaka pāramiñāṇānam matthaka pattāḥ etam kapotakandara vihāram upasobhayantāḥ ekam kanakaguham
translated: who had reached the peak of the seventy-six knowledges of disciples, who were beautifying the Dove Cave Monastery, entered one golden cave

original: paviṭṭhā dve sīhā viya, ekaṃ vijambhanabhūmiṃ otiṇṇā dve byagghā viya, ekaṃ supupphitasālavanaṃ
analyzed: paviṭṭhāḥ dve sīhāḥ viya ekam vijambhana bhūmim otiṇṇāḥ dve byagghāḥ viya ekam su pupphita sāla vanam
translated: like two lions, entered one yawning place like two tigers, entered one well-flowered Sāla-wood

original: paviṭṭhā dve chaddantanāgarājāno viya, ekaṃ simbalivanaṃ paviṭṭhā dve supaṇṇarājāno
analyzed: paviṭṭhāḥ dve chaddanta nāga rājānaḥ viya ekam simbalivanam paviṭṭhāḥ dve supaṇṇa rājāno
translated: like two Chaddanta elephant kings, entered one Simbali-wood like two Supaṇṇa kings,

original: viya, ekaṃ naravāhanayānaṃ abhiruḷhā dve vessavaṇā viya, ekaṃ paṇḍukambalasilāsanaṃ
analyzed: viyas ekam naravāhana yānam abhiruḷhāḥ dve vessavaṇāḥ viyas ekam paṇḍu kambala silā āsanam
translated: mounted one chariot drawn by men like two Vessāvanas, sat down on one white blanket seat

original: abhinisinnā dve sakkā viya, ekavimānabbhantaragatā dve mahābrahmāno viya, ekasmiṃ
analyzed: abhinisinnāḥ dve sakkā viyaḥ eka vimāna abbhantara gatāḥ dve mahābrahmānaḥ viyaḥ ekasmin
translated: like two Sakkas, were like two Great Brahmās who had entered one divine palace, were like two moon discs

original: gaganaṭṭhāne ṭhitāni dve candamaṇḍalāni viya, dve sūriyamaṇḍalāni viya ca virociṃsu.
analyzed: gagana ṭṭhāne ṭhitāni dve canda maṇḍalāni dve sūriya maṇḍalāni ca virociṃsu
translated: in one place in the sky, like two sun discs, they shone.

original: Tesu āyasmā mahāmoggallāno tuṇhī nisīdi, āyasmā pana sāriputto samāpajji. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: tesu āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ tuṇhī nisīdi āyasmā pana sāriputto samāpajji tena vuttam
translated: The venerable Maha Moggallana sat in silence, but the venerable Sariputta attained concentration. Hence it was said:

original: – “aññataraṃ samādhiṃ samāpajjitvā”ti.🔽Tattha aññataraṃ samādhinti upekkhābrahmavihārasamāpattiṃ. Keci “saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpatti”nti🔽vadanti, apare panāhu “āruppapādakaṃ phalasamāpatti”nti. Imā eva hi tisso kāyarakkhaṇasamatthā🔽samāpattiyo. Tattha nirodhasamāpattiyā samādhipariyāyasambhavo heṭṭhā vuttova, pacchimaṃyeva
analyzed: aññataram samādhim samāpajjitvā ati  tattha aññataram samādhim ti upekkhā brahmavihāra samāpattim keci saññā vedayita nirodha samāpattim ti  vadanti apare pana āhu āruppa pādakam phala samāpattim ti imāḥ eva hi tisso kāya rakkhaṇa samatthā  tattha nirodha samāpattiyā samādhi pariyāya sambhavaḥ heṭṭhā vuttaḥ uva
translated: “Having attained a certain concentration” .

original: pana ācariyā vaṇṇenti. Uttarāya disāya dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ gacchantīti uttarāya disāya
analyzed: pana ācariyāḥ vaṇṇenti uttarāya disāya dakkhiṇam disam gacchanti iti uttarāya disāya
translated: Herein, a certain concentration is the attainment of the measureless deliverance of equanimity. Some say it is the attainment of cessation of perception and feeling. Others say it is the attainment of fruition in the immaterial sphere. For these three attainments are capable of protecting the body. Herein, the occurrence of concentration in the attainment of cessation has already been told in the way beginning, “The attainment of cessation is included in the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception” . But the teachers praise only the last of these three.

original: yakkhasamāgamaṃ gantvā attano bhavanaṃ gantuṃ dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ gacchanti. Paṭibhāti
analyzed: yakkha samāgamam gantvā attanaḥ bhavanam gantum dakkhiṇam disam gacchanti paṭibhāti
translated: Going from the northern direction to the southern direction: going from the northern direction to the southern direction in order to go to the yakkhas’ assembly and return to his own abode.

original: manti upaṭṭhāti mama. Manti hi paṭisaddayogena sāmiatthe upayogavacanaṃ, imassa sīse
analyzed: upaṭṭhāti mama hi paṭisadda yogena sāmi atthe upayoga vacanam imassa sīse
translated: It occurs to me: it appears to me. For the word manti is a word denoting use in the sense of master with the prefix paṭi .

original: pahāraṃ dātuṃ cittaṃ me uppajjatīti attho. So kira purimajātiyaṃ there baddhāghāto,
analyzed: pahāram dātum cittam me uppajjati iti so kira purima jātiyam there baddha āghāto
translated: The meaning is: “I have a mind to give him a blow.” It seems that in a previous existence he had a grudge against the Elder.

original: tenassa theraṃ disvā paduṭṭhacittassa evaṃ ahosi. Itaro pana sappaññajātiko, tasmā
analyzed: tenassa theram disvā paduṭṭha cittassa evam ahosi itaro pana sappañña jātiko tasmā
translated: Therefore, when he saw the Elder, he thought thus because his mind was corrupted. But the other was of wise nature. Therefore,

original: taṃ paṭisedhento “alaṃ sammā”tiādimāha. Tattha mā āsādesīti mā ghaṭṭesi, mā pahāraṃ
analyzed: tam paṭisedhentaḥ alam sammā ti ādim āha tattha mā āsādesi iti mā ghaṭṭesi mā pahāram
translated: in order to restrain him, he said: “Enough, friend.” Herein, mā āsādesīti means: do not strike, do not give a blow.

original: dehīti vuttaṃ hoti. Uḷāroti uḷārehi uttamehi sīlādiguṇehi samannāgato.
analyzed: dehi iti vuttam hoti uḷāraḥ ti uḷārehi uttamehi sīla ādi guṇehi samannāgataḥ
translated: Uḷāroti means: endowed with excellent, supreme, moral virtues, etc.

original: Anādiyitvāti ādaraṃ akatvā, tassa vacanaṃ aggahetvā. Yasmā pana tassa vacanaṃ aggaṇhanto🔽taṃ anādiyanto nāma hoti, tasmā vuttaṃ – “taṃ yakkhaṃ anādiyitvā”ti. Sīse pahāraṃ🔽adāsīti sabbathāmena ussāhaṃ janetvā ākāse ṭhitova sīse khaṭakaṃ adāsi, muddhani
analyzed: an ādiyitvā ati ādaram a katvā tassa vacanam aggahetvā yasmā pana tassa vacanam aggaṇhanto  tam an ādiyantaḥ nāma hoti tasmā vuttam tam yakkham an ādiyitvā iti sīse pahāram  adāsi iti sabbathā āmena ussāham janetvā ākāse ṭhitaḥ uva sīse khaṭakam adāsi muddhani
translated: Anādiyitvā means: without paying respect, without accepting his words. But because he did not accept his words,

original: muṭṭhighātaṃ akāsīti attho. Tāva mahāti thāmamahattena tattakaṃ mahanto pahāro ahosi.
analyzed: muṭṭhi ghātam akāsi iti thāma mahattena tattakam mahantaḥ pahāraḥ ahosi
translated: he was called one who did not pay respect to him. Therefore it was said: “without paying respect to that spirit.” Sīse pahāraṃ adāsīti means: having generated great effort, he stood in the air and gave a blow on his head. He gave a blow on his head with his fist. This is the meaning. Tāva mahāti means: that blow was great because of its great weight.

original: Tena pahārenāti tena pahārena karaṇabhūtena. Sattaratananti pamāṇamajjhimassa purisassa
analyzed: tena pahārena ati tena pahārena karaṇa bhūtena satta ratanam ti pamāṇam ajjhimassa purisassa
translated: By that blow: by that blow which is the instrument. Seven-league: seven times a league.

original: ratanena sattaratanaṃ. Nāganti hatthināgaṃ. Osādeyyāti pathaviyaṃ osīdāpeyya nimujjāpeyya.
analyzed: ratanena satta ratanam nāgam ti hatthi nāgam osādeyya ati pathaviyam osīdāpeyya nimujjāpeyya
translated: An elephant: a tusker. Would crush: would crush down, would make it sink into the earth.

original: “Osāreyyā”tipi pāṭho, cuṇṇavicuṇṇaṃ kareyyāti attho. Aḍḍhaṭṭhamaratananti aḍḍhena
analyzed: osāreyya atipi pāṭhaḥ cuṇṇa vicuṇṇam kareyya iti attho aḍḍha ṭṭhama ratanam ti aḍḍhena
translated: The reading “osāreyyā” is also found, the meaning of which is “would reduce to powder.”

original: aṭṭhannaṃ pūraṇāni aḍḍhaṭṭhamāni, aḍḍhaṭṭhamāni ratanāni pamāṇaṃ etassāti aḍḍhaṭṭhamaratano,
analyzed: aṭṭhannam pūraṇāni aḍḍhaṭṭhamāni aḍḍhaṭṭhamāni ratanāni pamāṇam etassa ati aḍḍhaṭṭhamaratanaḥ
translated: Half-league: half of eight is four, half of four is two, half of two is one, half of one is half.🔽That which has half as its measure is called “half-league.”

original: taṃ aḍḍhaṭṭhamaratanaṃ. Mahantaṃ pabbatakūṭanti kelāsakūṭappamāṇaṃ vipulaṃ girikūṭaṃ.
analyzed: tam aḍḍhaṭṭham aratanam mahantam pabbata kūṭanti kelāsa kūṭa ppamāṇam vipulam giri kūṭam
translated: A great mountain peak: a mountain peak as large as the Kelasa peak.🔽Would split: would split it up into pieces.

original: Padāleyyāti sakalikākārena bhindeyya. Api osādeyya, api padāleyyāti sambandho.
analyzed: padāleyyā ati sa kalikā ākārena bhindeyya api osādeyya api padāleyyā ati sambandhaḥ
translated: Even so, he would crush it down, even so, he would split it up.

original: Tāvadeva cassa sarīre mahāpariḷāho uppajji, so vedanāturo ākāse ṭhātuṃ asakkonto
analyzed: tāvat eva ca ssa sarīre mahā pariḷāhaḥ uppajji saḥ vedanā āturaḥ ākāse ṭhātum a sakkonto
translated: Immediately a great fever arose in his body. Unable to remain in the air because of the pain,

original: bhūmiyaṃ pati, taṅkhaṇaññeva aṭṭhasaṭṭhisahassādhikayojanasatasahassubbedhaṃ sinerumpi
analyzed: bhūmiyam pati aṭṭha saṭṭhi sahassa adhika yojana sata sahassa ubbedham sinerum pi
translated: he fell to the ground. At that moment, the Sineru mountain, which is 168,000 leagues high,

original: pabbatarājānaṃ sandhārentī catunahutādhikadviyojanasatasahassabahalā mahāpathavī🔽taṃ pāpasattaṃ dhāretuṃ asakkontī viya vivaramadāsi. Avīcito jālā uṭṭhahitvā kandantaṃyeva
analyzed: pabbata rājānam sandhārentī catu nahuta adhika dvi yojana sata sahassa bahalā mahā pathavī  tam pāpa sattam dhāretum a sakkontī viya vivaram adāsi avīcitaḥ jālā uṭṭhahitvā kandantam yā iva
translated: The great earth, which supports the king of mountains and is two hundred and forty leagues thick,🔽as if unable to support that wicked being, opened up and gave him entry. The Avīci hell flared up and seized him as he was crying and wailing. He fell down crying and wailing. Hence it was said:

original: taṃ gaṇhiṃsu, so kandanto vippalapanto pati. Tena vuttaṃ – “atha ca pana so yakkho
analyzed: tam gaṇhiṃsu saḥ kandantaḥ vippalapantaḥ pati tena vuttam atha ca pana so yakkho
translated: ‘Then that spirit,

original: ‘ḍayhāmi ḍayhāmī’ti vatvā tattheva mahānirayaṃ apatāsīti. Tattha apatāsīti apati.
analyzed: ḍayhāmi ḍayhāmi iti vatvā tattha iva mahānirayam apatāsi iti tattha apatāsi iti apati
translated: crying out “I am burning, I am burning!” fell right there into the Great Hell.’ There (tattha) means in that place (tattheva). Apatāsīti means he fell down (apatāsi).

original: Kiṃ pana so yakkhattabhāveneva nirayaṃ upagacchīti? Na upagacchi, yañhettha diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ
analyzed: kim pana saḥ yakkhatta bhāvena iva nirayam upagacchi iti na upagacchi yat ha ittha diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyam
translated: But did he go to hell just as a spirit? He did not go just as a spirit. The wicked deed that he did in this very life

original: pāpakammaṃ ahosi, tassa balena yakkhattabhāve mahantaṃ dukkhaṃ anubhavi. Yaṃ pana
analyzed: pāpa kammam ahosi tassa balena yakkhatta bhāve mahantam dukkham anubhavi yam pana
translated: by the power of that, he experienced great suffering in the state of a spirit. But

original: upapajjavedanīyaṃ ānantariyakammaṃ, tena cutianantaraṃ niraye uppajjīti. Therassa
analyzed: upapajja vedanīyam ānantariya kammaṃ tena cuti anantaram niraye uppajji iti therassa
translated: by the deed that was to be experienced in the next life, immediately after his death he was reborn in hell. But the Elder’s

original: pana samāpattibalena upatthambhitasarīrassa na koci vikāro ahosi. Samāpattito avuṭṭhitakāle
analyzed: pana samāpatti balena upatthambhita sarīrassa na koci vikāraḥ ahosi samāpattitaḥ a vuṭṭhita kāle
translated: body, which was supported by the power of his attainment, did not change in any way. At the time when he had not yet emerged from his attainment,

original: hi taṃ yakkho pahari, tathā paharantaṃ dibbacakkhunā disvā āyasmā mahāmoggallāno🔽dhammasenāpatiṃ upasaṅkami, upasaṅkamanasamakālameva ca dhammasenāpati samāpattito
analyzed: hi tam yakkhaḥ tathā paharantam dibba cakkhunā disvā āyasmā mahāmoggallāno  dhamma senāpatim upasaṅkami upasaṅkamana sama kālam eva ca dhamma senāpati samāpattitaḥ
translated: The Yakkha struck him, and the venerable Maha Moggallana, seeing him strike him,🔽went to the General of the Dhamma. And as soon as he had gone to him, the General of the Dhamma,🔽

original: uṭṭhāsi. Atha naṃ mahāmoggallāno sarīravuttiṃ pucchi, sopissa byākāsi, tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: uṭṭhāsi atha nam mahāmoggallānaḥ sarīra vuttim pucchi saḥ upissa tena vuttam
translated: The Elder Moggallāna saw him with the divine eye and went to the General of the Dhamma. As soon as he arrived, the General of the Dhamma rose from his attainment. Then the Elder Moggallāna asked him about his bodily condition, and he replied:

original: – “addasā kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno…pe… api ca me sīsaṃ thokaṃ dukkha”nti.
analyzed: addasā kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāna upe api ca me sīsam thokam dukkhanti
translated: “Venerable sir, I am not ill, but my head aches a little.”

original: Tattha thokaṃ dukkhanti thokaṃ appamattakaṃ madhurakajātaṃ viya me sīsaṃ dukkhitaṃ,
analyzed: tattha thokam dukkhanti thokam appamattakam madhuraka jātam viya me sīsam dukkhitam
translated: Herein, a little means a small amount, like a little honey. My head aches a little means my head is painful,🔽and it is the head that is the basis for the pain that is called “headache.”

original: dukkhappattanti attho. Dukkhādhiṭṭhānañhi sīsaṃ dukkhanti vuttaṃ. “Sīse thokaṃ dukkha”ntipi
analyzed: dukkha ppattanti atthaḥ dukkha adhiṭṭhānam hi sīsam dukkhanti vuttam sīse thokam dukkhanti pi
translated: “There is a little pain in the head” is also a reading.

original: pāṭho. Kathaṃ pana samāpattibalena sarīre upatthambhite therassa sīse thokampi dukkhaṃ
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ katham pana samāpatti balena sarīre upatthambhite therassa sīse thokam pi dukkham
translated: But how was it that the Elder’s head ached a little when his body was stiffened by the power of attainment?

original: ahosīti? Acireneva vuṭṭhitattā. Antosamāpattiyaṃ apaññāyamānadukkhañhi kāyanissitattā
analyzed: ahosi iti acirena iva vuṭṭhita ttā antosamāpattiyam a paññāyamāna dukkham hi kāya nissita ttā
translated: Because he had only recently emerged from it. For pain that is not manifest in attainment is called “headache” because it is dependent on the head.

original: niddaṃ upagatassa makasādijanitaṃ viya paṭibuddhassa thokaṃ paññāyittha.
analyzed: niddam upagatassa makasa ādi janitam viya paṭibuddhassa thokam paññāyittha
translated: and it was as if he had been asleep and had been awakened by a blow from a cudgel.

original: “Mahābalena yakkhena tathā sabbussāhena pahaṭe sarīrepi vikāro nāma natthī”ti acchariyabbhutacittajātena🔽āyasmatā mahāmoggallānena “acchariyaṃ, āvuso sāriputtā”tiādinā dhammasenāpatino mahānubhāvatāya
analyzed: mahābalena yakkhena tathā sabbussāhena pahaṭe sarīre pi vikāraḥ nāma na atthi iti acchariya bbhuta citta jātena  āyasmatā mahāmoggallānena acchariyam āvuso sāriputta ati ādinā dhamma senāpatinaḥ mahā anubhāva tāya
translated: “When the body is struck by the powerful and mighty spirit, there is no change in it at all.”🔽Then, with his mind filled with wonder and amazement,🔽the venerable Maha Moggallana said to the general of the Dhamma, the venerable Sariputta, “It is wonderful, friend Sariputta, it is marvellous!🔽” to show the great power of the general of the Dhamma.

original: vibhāvitāya sopissa ‘acchariyaṃ, āvuso moggallānā”tiādinā iddhānubhāvamahantatāpakāsanāpadesena
analyzed: vibhāvitāya acchariyam āvuso moggallāna ati ādinā iddha anubhāva mahanta tā pakāsana apadesena
translated: The venerable Sariputta said to him, “It is wonderful, friend Moggallana, it is marvellous!

original: attano issāmacchariyāhaṅkārādimalānaṃ suppahīnataṃ dīpeti. Paṃsupisācakampi na passāmāti
analyzed: attanaḥ na passāma ati
translated: ” to show the greatness of his own psychic power.🔽We do not see even a ghost in the dust.

original: saṅkārakūṭādīsu vicaraṇakakhuddakapetampi na passāma. Iti adhigamappicchānaṃ aggabhūto
analyzed: saṅkāra kūṭa ādīsu na passāma iti adhigama ppicchānam agga bhūtaḥ
translated: We do not see even a small animal wandering about in charnel grounds, etc.🔽Thus the elder, who was foremost among those who desired attainment,

original: mahāthero tasmiṃ kāle anāvajjanena tesaṃ adassanaṃ sandhāya vadati. Tenevāha “etarahī”ti.
analyzed: mahā theraḥ tasmin kāle anāvajjanena tesam adassanam sandhāya vadati tena iva āha etarahi iti
translated: said this, referring to their not seeing by way of non-remorse, at that time. Therefore he said, “now.”

original: Bhagavā pana veḷuvane ṭhito ubhinnaṃ aggasāvakānaṃ imaṃ kathāsallāpaṃ dibbasotena assosi. Tena vuttaṃ – “assosi kho bhagavā”tiādi, taṃ vuttatthameva.
analyzed: bhagavā pana veḷuvane ṭhitaḥ ubhinnam aggasāvakānam imam kathā sallāpam dibba sotena assosi tena vuttam assosi kho bhagavā itiādi tam vutta ttham eva
translated: But the Blessed One, who was staying in the Veḷuvana, heard the conversation between the two chief disciples with his divine ear. That is why it is said, “The Blessed One heard” , etc. The meaning is as already stated.

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ āyasmato sāriputtassa samāpattibalūpagataṃ iddhānubhāvamahantataṃ viditvā. Imaṃ udānanti tasseva tādibhāvappattidīpakaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam āyasmataḥ sāriputtassa samāpatti bala upagatam iddha anubhāva mahantatam viditvā imam udānan ti tassa iva tādi bhāva ppatti dīpakam imam udānam udānesi
translated: Having known the meaning of this: having known the greatness of the psychic power of the venerable Sāriputta, which is based on the strength of his attainment. This exalted utterance: this exalted utterance that illuminates his state of being such.

original: Tattha yassa selūpamaṃ cittaṃ, ṭhitaṃ nānupakampatīti yassa khīṇāsavassa cittaṃ ekagghanasilāmayapabbatūpamaṃ
analyzed: tattha yassa sela upamam cittam ṭhitam na anupakampati iti yassa khīṇāsavassa cittam ekagghana silā maya pabbata upamam
translated: Herein, his mind is like a rock, steady, unshaken: the mind of one who is a cankerless saint is like a rock consisting of a single mass of stone.

original: sabbesaṃ iñjanānaṃ abhāvato vasībhāvappattiyāva ṭhitaṃ sabbehipi lokadhammehi nānupakampati
analyzed: sabbesam iñjanānam abhāvataḥ vasībhāva ppattiyā ava ṭhitam sabbehi pi loka dhammehi
translated: It is steady, that is, it has reached mastery by the absence of all vacillation. It is not shaken by any of the mundane states.

original: na pavedhati. Idānissa akampanākāraṃ saddhiṃ kāraṇena dassetuṃ “viratta”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: na pavedhati idānissa akampanā ākāram saddhim kāraṇena dassetum viratta ntiādi vuttam
translated: It does not waver. Now, in order to show the unshaken state of his mind together with its cause, it is said, “Detacht from sense desires” , etc.

original: Tattha virattaṃ rajanīyesūti virāgasaṅkhātena ariyamaggena rajanīyesu rāguppattihetubhūtesu
analyzed: tattha virattam rajanīyesu iti virāga saṅkhātena ariya maggena rajanīyesu rāga uppatti hetu bhūtesu
translated: Herein, detached from sense desires: detached by means of the noble path called “detachment.” From sense desires: from the sense desires that are the cause for the arising of lust.

original: sabbesu tebhūmakadhammesu virattaṃ, tattha sabbaso samucchinnarāganti attho. Kopaneyyeti
analyzed: sabbesu tebhūmaka dhammesu virattam tattha sabbaso samucchinna rāganti attho kopaneyyā iti
translated: It is dispassion for all states in the three planes. The meaning is that it is the complete severing of the craving that occurs there. ‘In what is provocative of anger’:

original: paṭighaṭṭhānīye sabbasmimpi āghātavatthusmiṃ na kuppati na dussati na vikāraṃ āpajjati.
analyzed: paṭigha ṭṭhānīye sabbasmim pi āghāta vatthusmim na kuppati na dussati na vikāram āpajjati
translated: “Dispassionate” means: dispassionate towards all the mental states of the three planes. The meaning is: completely cut off in regard to them. “Not angered” means: he is not angered, does not become displeased, does not react, in regard to any object of anger, to any grounds for irritation.

original: Yassevaṃ bhāvitaṃ cittanti yassa yathāvuttassa ariyapuggalassa cittaṃ evaṃ vuttanayena🔽tādibhāvāvahanabhāvena bhāvitaṃ. Kuto taṃ dukkhamessatīti taṃ uttamapuggalaṃ kuto
analyzed: yassa evam bhāvitam cittam ti yassa yathāvuttassa ariya puggalassa cittam evam vutta nayena  ta ādi bhāva āvahana bhāvena bhāvitam kutas tam dukkham essati iti tam uttama puggalam kutas
translated: “Whose mind is thus developed” means: whose mind is developed in the way described above,

original: sattato saṅkhārato vā dukkhaṃ upagamissati, na tādisassa dukkhaṃ atthīti attho.
analyzed: sattataḥ saṅkhārataḥ vā dukkham upagamissati na tādisassa dukkham atthi iti attho
translated: by arousing such a state. “From where will suffering come to him?” From where will suffering come to that noble person, from beings or from formations? It will not come from anywhere. The meaning is: such a person has no suffering.

original: Catutthasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: catuttha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the fourth sutta is finished.

original: 5. Nāgasuttavaṇṇanā🔽35. Pañcame kosambiyanti kusumbena nāma isinā vasitaṭṭhāne māpitattā “kosambī”ti
analyzed: nāga sutta vaṇṇanā  pañcame kosambiyanti kusumbena nāma isinā vasita ṭṭhāne māpita ttā kosambī iti
translated: The Discourse on the Elephant🔽In the fifth discourse, “at Kosambī” means: in the town named “Kosambī,” which was built in the place where the sage named Kusa lived.

original: evaṃladdhanāmake nagare. Ghositārāmeti ghositaseṭṭhinā kārite ārāme. Bhagavā ākiṇṇo
analyzed: evaṃladdha nāmake nagare ghositārāmā iti ghositaseṭṭhinā kārite ārāme bhagavā ākiṇṇaḥ
translated: “In the Ghosita monastery” means: in the monastery built by the merchant Ghosita. The Blessed One was🔽staying there, surrounded by a large community of monks.

original: viharatīti bhagavā sambādhappatto viharati. Kiṃ pana bhagavato sambādho atthi, saṃsaggo🔽vāti? Natthi. Na hi koci bhagavantaṃ anicchāya upasaṅkamituṃ sakkoti. Durāsadā hi
analyzed: viharati iti bhagavā sambādha pattaḥ viharati kim pana bhagavato sambādhaḥ atthi saṃsaggo  vāti natthi na hi koci bhagavantam anicchāya upasaṅkamitum sakkoti durāsadā hi
translated: “Dwells” means that the Blessed One dwells in a crowded place. But does the Blessed One have a crowded place, a place of contact? No, he does not. For no one is able to approach the Blessed One against his will. For the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, are difficult to approach.

original: buddhā bhagavanto sabbattha ca anupalittattā. Hitesitāya pana sattesu anukampaṃ upādāya🔽“mutto mocessāmī”ti paṭiññānurūpaṃ caturoghanittharaṇatthaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ parisānaṃ attano
analyzed: buddhāḥ bhagavanto sabbattha ca an upalitta ttā hita isitāya pana sattesu anukampam upādāya  muttaḥ mocessāmi iti paṭiññā anurūpam catur ogha nittharaṇa attham aṭṭhannam parisānam attano
translated: But out of compassion for beings, who are desirous of welfare,

original: santikaṃ kālena kālaṃ upasaṅkamanaṃ adhivāseti, sayañca mahākaruṇāsamussāhito kālaññū
analyzed: santikam kālena kālam upasaṅkamanam adhivāseti sayam ca mahā karuṇā samussāhitaḥ kālaññū
translated: he assents to their coming to him from time to time in order to cross over the four floods, in accordance with his vow: “I am freed, I shall free others.” And he himself, urged on by his great compassion,

original: hutvā tattha upasaṅkamati, idaṃ sabbabuddhānaṃ āciṇṇaṃ, ayamidha ākiṇṇavihāroti adhippeto.
analyzed: hutvā tattha upasaṅkamati idam sabba buddhānam āciṇṇam ayam idha ākiṇṇa vihāro ti adhippeto
translated: goes to them at the proper time, knowing the right occasion. This is the practice of all Buddhas. This is what is meant by “dwelling in a crowded place” here.

original: Idha pana kosambikānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ kalahajātānaṃ satthā dīghītissa kosalarañño vatthuṃ
analyzed: idha pana kosambikānam bhikkhūnam kalaha jātānam satthā dīghītissa kosala rañño vatthum
translated: But here, when the monks of Kosambī were quarreling, the Teacher related the story of King Dīghīti🔽and gave them the advice beginning thus: “Hatred is never appeased by hatred;

original: āharitvā, “na hi verena verāni, sammantīdha kudācana”ntiādinā ovādaṃ adāsi, taṃ divasaṃ
analyzed: āharitvā na hi verena verāni ovādam adāsi tam divasam
translated: hatred is appeased by its opposite” .

original: tesaṃ kalahaṃ karontānaṃyeva ratti vibhātā. Dutiyadivasepi bhagavā tameva vatthuṃ🔽kathesi, taṃ divasampi tesaṃ kalahaṃ karontānaṃyeva ratti vibhātā. Tatiyadivasepi🔽bhagavā tameva vatthuṃ kathesi, athaññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ evamāha – “appossukko,🔽bhante bhagavā, diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāramanuyutto viharatu, mayametena bhaṇḍanena
analyzed: tesam kalaham karontā naṃyā iva ratti vibhātā dutiya divase pi bhagavā tam eva vatthum  kathesi tam divasam pi tesam kalaham karontānaṃyā iva ratti vibhātā tatiya divase pi  bhagavā tam eva vatthum kathesi atha aññataraḥ bhikkhu bhagavantam evam āha appa ussukkaḥ  bhante bhagavā diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāram anuyuttaḥ viharatu mayam etena bhaṇḍanena
translated: and while they were quarrelling the night passed. On the second day the Lord spoke on the same subject,🔽and while they were quarrelling the night passed. On the third day🔽the Lord spoke on the same subject, and then a certain monk said to the Lord: ‘Lord, let the Blessed Lord, living­ly happy,🔽apply himself to that for which the time is come. We will settle this legal question.’

original: kalahena viggahena vivādena paññāyissāmā”ti. Satthā “pariyādinnacittā kho ime moghapurisā🔽na dānime sakkā saññāpetuṃ, natthi cettha saññāpetabbā, yaṃnūnāhaṃ ekacārikavāsaṃ🔽vaseyyaṃ, evaṃ ime bhikkhū kalahato oramissantī”ti cintesi. Evaṃ tehi kalahakārakehi🔽bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ ekavihāre vāsaṃ vinetabbābhāvato upāsakādīhi upasaṅkamanañca ākiṇṇavihāraṃ
analyzed: kalahena viggahena vivādena paññāyissāma ati satthā pariyādinna cittāḥ kho ime moghapurisā 🔽na dāni ime sakkā saññāpetum natthi ca ittha saññāpetabbā yat nūna aham ekacārika vāsam 🔽vaseyyam evam ime bhikkhū kalahataḥ oramissanti iti cintesi evam tehi kalaha kārakehi 🔽bhikkhūhi saddhim eka vihāre vāsam vinetabba abhāvataḥ upāsaka ādīhi upasaṅkamanam ca ākiṇṇa vihāram
translated: And while they were quarreling the night passed away. On the following day also the Teacher related the same story. And while they were quarreling the night passed away a second time. On the following day also the Teacher related the same story. Then a certain monk said to the Teacher, “Reverend Sir, let the Blessed One live at ease, intent upon that happiness which is the highest of all. We will settle this quarrel and this dispute.” The Teacher reflected, “These foolish men are obsessed with the quarrel. They are not capable of being instructed. There is no use in instructing them. Suppose I were to go away and live the life of a wanderer? In that case these monks will cease quarreling.” And the Teacher thought to himself, “It is not proper that I should live in the same monastery with these monks who are engaged in quarreling.” Therefore he went away and lived the life of a wanderer. original: satthu ārocesuṃ. Satthā tassa pattatthavikaṃ nānujāni, heṭṭhāmañce pattaṃ nikkujjitvā🔽ṭhapeti, so ṭhapentopi ghaṃsentova paṇāmetvā ṭhapeti, gaṇhantopi ghaṃsentova ākaḍḍhitvā
analyzed: satthu ārocesuṃ satthā tassa pattatthavikam na anujāni heṭṭhā mañce pattam nikkujjitvā  ṭhapeti saḥ ṭhapentaḥ api ghaṃsentaḥ iva paṇāmetvā ṭhapeti gaṇhantaḥ api ghaṃsentaḥ iva ākaḍḍhitvā
translated: and the Teacher did not allow him a bowl-stand. He put the bowl upside down on the lower bed,

original: gaṇhāti. Taṃ gacchante gacchante kāle ghaṃsanena parikkhīṇaṃ, nāḷikodanamattasseva
analyzed: gaṇhāti tam gacchante gacchante kāle ghaṃsanena parikkhīṇam nāḷikā udana mattassa iva
