original: gaṇhanakaṃ jātaṃ. Tato satthu ārocesuṃ, athassa satthā pattatthavikaṃ anujāni. Thero
analyzed: gaṇhanakam jātam tatas satthu ārocesuṃ athassa satthā pattatthavikam anujāni thero
translated: and it was born. Then they told the Teacher. The Teacher allowed him a bag for the bowl. The Elder🔽after a time, developing the faculties, was established in the supreme fruit of liberation. Thus he

original: aparena samayena indriyabhāvanaṃ bhāvento aggaphale arahatte patiṭṭhāsi. Iti so pubbe
analyzed: aparena samayena indriya bhāvanam bhāventaḥ agga phale arahatte patiṭṭhāsi iti so pubbe
translated: formerly

original: savisesaṃ piṇḍatthāya ulatīti piṇḍolo, gottena pana bhāradvājoti ubhayaṃ ekato katvā
analyzed: sa visesam piṇḍa tthāya ulati iti piṇḍolaḥ gottena pana bhāradvājaḥ iti ubhayam ekatas katvā
translated: because he was superior in going for alms, and because of his clan, which was Bhāradvāja, he was called

original: “piṇḍolabhāradvājo”ti vuccati.🔽Āraññakoti gāmantasenāsanapaṭikkhipanena araññe nivāso assāti āraññako, āraññakadhutaṅgaṃ
analyzed: vuccati  āraññako ti gāmanta senāsana paṭikkhipanena araññe nivāsaḥ assa ati āraññakaḥ āraññaka dhutaṅgam
translated: “Piṇḍolabhāradvāja.”

original: samādāya vattantassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Tathā bhikkhāsaṅkhātānaṃ āmisapiṇḍānaṃ pāto piṇḍapāto,🔽parehi dinnānaṃ piṇḍānaṃ patte nipatananti attho. Piṇḍapātaṃ uñchati taṃ taṃ kulaṃ
analyzed: samādāya vattantassa etam nāmam tathā bhikkhā saṅkhātānam āmisa piṇḍānam pātaḥ piṇḍapātaḥ  parehi dinnānam piṇḍānam patte piṇḍapātam uñchati tam tam kulam
translated: A forest-dweller: by rejecting a dwelling in a village, he lives in the forest, thus he is a forest-dweller, and this is the name for one who takes up the ascetic practice of living in the forest. So too, the alms-food is the morsels of material things called alms,

original: upasaṅkamanto gavesatīti piṇḍapātiko, piṇḍāya vā patituṃ carituṃ vatametassāti piṇḍapātī,
analyzed: upasaṅkamantaḥ gavesati iti piṇḍapātikaḥ piṇḍāya vā patitum caritum vatam etassa ati piṇḍapātī
translated: the meaning is that they fall into the bowl given by others. He seeks, goes to, and searches for, that alms-food, thus he is an alms-food eater, or it is because he goes about to eat, to wander about for alms, thus he is an alms-food eater,

original: piṇḍapātīyeva piṇḍapātiko. Saṅkārakūṭādīsu paṃsūnaṃ upari ṭhitattā abbhuggataṭṭhena
analyzed: piṇḍapātīya iva piṇḍapātikaḥ saṅkāra kūṭa ādīsu paṃsūnam upari ṭhita ttā abbhuggata ṭṭhena
translated: The refuse-rag-wearer’s habit is called “refuse rag” because it is made of rags picked up from the rubbish heap, etc., and because it is worn by one who is a refuse-rag-wearer.

original: paṃsukūlaṃ viyāti paṃsukūlaṃ, paṃsu viya vā kucchitabhāvaṃ ulati gacchatīti paṃsukūlaṃ,🔽paṃsukūlassa dhāraṇaṃ paṃsukūlaṃ, taṃ sīlaṃ etassāti paṃsukūliko. Saṅghāṭiuttarāsaṅgaantaravāsakasaṅkhātāni
analyzed: paṃsu kūlam viyāti paṃsu kūlam paṃsu viya vā kucchita bhāvam ulati gacchati iti paṃsu kūlam  paṃsu kūlassa dhāraṇam paṃsu kūlam tat sīlam etassa ati paṃsukūlikaḥ saṅghāṭi uttarāsaṅga antaravāsaka saṅkhātāni
translated: Or alternatively, it is a “refuse rag” because it is worn by one who is a “rag-roller” ,

original: tīṇi cīvarāni ticīvaraṃ, ticīvarassa dhāraṇaṃ ticīvaraṃ, taṃ sīlaṃ etassāti tecīvariko.
analyzed: tīṇi cīvarāni ti cīvaram ti cīvarassa dhāraṇam ti cīvaram tat sīlam etassa ati tecīvarikaḥ
translated: The “three-robe-wearer” is one who has the habit of wearing three robes.

original: Appicchotiādīnaṃ padānaṃ attho heṭṭhā vuttoyeva.
analyzed: appiccha iti ādīnam padānam attho heṭṭhā vuttaḥ yeva
translated: The meaning of the terms “little-desire” , etc., has been given already .

original: Dhutavādoti dhuto vuccati dhutakileso puggalo, kilesadhunanakadhammo vā. Tattha atthi🔽dhuto, na dhutavādo, atthi na dhuto, dhutavādo, atthi neva dhuto, na dhutavādo, atthi
analyzed: dhuta vādaḥ ti dhutaḥ vuccati dhuta kilesaḥ puggalaḥ kilesa dhunanaka dhammaḥ vā tattha atthi  dhutaḥ na dhuta vādaḥ atthi na dhutaḥ dhuta vādaḥ atthi na iva dhutaḥ na dhuta vādaḥ atthi
translated: The “one who professes the practice of the ascetic ,” etc.: the ascetic is one who has shaken off defilements or one who has the virtue of shaking off defilements.

original: dhuto ceva, dhutavādo cāti idaṃ catukkaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tesu yo sayaṃ dhutadhamme samādāya
analyzed: dhutaḥ ca iva dhuta vādaḥ ca ati idam catukkam veditabbam tesu yaḥ sayam dhuta dhamme samādāya
translated: Herein, there are four permutations in the case of one who is an ascetic but does not profess the practice of the ascetic, one who does not profess the practice of the ascetic but is an ascetic, one who is an ascetic and also professes the practice of the ascetic, and one who is neither an ascetic nor does he profess the practice of the ascetic.🔽Herein, one who has undertaken the ascetic practices and

original: vattati, na paraṃ tadatthāya samādapeti, ayaṃ paṭhamo. Yo pana sayaṃ na dhutadhamme🔽samādāya vattati, paraṃ samādapeti, ayaṃ dutiyo. Yo ubhayarahito, ayaṃ tatiyo. Yo🔽pana ubhayasampanno, ayaṃ catuttho. Evarūpo ca āyasmā piṇḍolabhāradvājoti. Tena vuttaṃ🔽“dhutavādo”ti. Ekadesasarūpekasesavasena hi ayaṃ niddeso yathā taṃ “nāmarūpa”nti.
analyzed: vattati na param tad atthāya samādapeti ayam paṭhamaḥ yaḥ pana sayam na dhuta dhamme  samādāya vattati param samādapeti ayam dutiyaḥ yaḥ ubhaya rahitaḥ ayam tatiyaḥ yaḥ  pana ubhaya sampannaḥ ayam catuttho evarūpo ca āyasmā piṇḍolabhāradvājo ti tena vuttam  eka desa sarūpa ikasesa vasena hi ayam niddesaḥ yathā tam
translated: He does not practice the ascetic practices himself but he encourages others to do so. This is the second. He who is devoid of both is the third. He who possesses both is the fourth. The venerable Piṇḍolabhāradvāja was such a one. Therefore it was said above: “The ascetic Gotama is a proponent of the ascetic practices.” This description is given in terms of a portion and a part, just as “name-and-form” is described as “form and feeling, etc.”🔽

analyzed: adhicittam anuyuttaḥ ti ettha aṭṭha samāpatti sampayogataḥ arahatta phala samāpatti sampayogataḥ 🔽vā cittassa adhicitta bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ idha pana arahatta phala cittanti vadanti 🔽taṃ taṃ samāpattīsu samādhi eva adhicittam idha pana arahatta phala samādhi veditabbo 🔽keci pana adhicittam anuyuttena bhikkhave bhikkhunā kālena kālam tīṇi nimittāni

original: manasi kātabbānīti etasmiṃ adhicittasutte viya samathavipassanācittaṃ adhicittanti
analyzed: manasi kātabbāni iti etasmim adhicitta sutte viya samatha vipassanā cittam adhicittan ti
translated: “They should be given attention” : in this discourse on the higher mind, the mind of serenity and insight is called “higher mind” .

original: idhādhippeta”nti vadanti, taṃ na sundaraṃ. Purimoyevattho gahetabbo.
analyzed: idha adhippetanti vadanti tam na sundaram gahetabbo
translated: “Here the meaning intended is this.” This is not good. The former meaning should be accepted.

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ āyasmato piṇḍolabhāradvājassa adhiṭṭhānaparikkhārasampadāsampannaṃ
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam āyasmataḥ piṇḍolabhāradvājassa adhiṭṭhāna parikkhāra sampadā sampannam
translated: Having known the meaning of this : having known in all its modes the meaning of the higher mind, which is the possession of the requisites of concentration and the determination of the venerable Piṇḍolabhāradvāja,

original: adhicittānuyogasaṅkhātaṃ atthaṃ sabbākārato viditvā. Evaṃ “adhicittānuyogo mama sāsanānuṭṭhāna”nti🔽dīpento imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: adhicittānuyoga saṅkhātam attham sabba ākārataḥ viditvā evam adhicittānuyogaḥ mama sāsana anuṭṭhānan ti  dīpentaḥ imam udānam udānesi
translated: he uttered this exalted utterance, showing that the practice of the higher mind is the performance of the training in my dispensation.

original: Tattha anūpavādoti vācāya kassacipi anupavadanaṃ. Anūpaghātoti kāyena kassaci upaghātākaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: tattha anūpavādaḥ ti vācāya kassaci pi an upavadanam anūpaghātaḥ ti kāyena kassaci upaghāta akaraṇam
translated: Herein, non-reproach is not reproaching anyone verbally. Non-harming is not harming anyone physically.

original: Pātimokkheti ettha pātimokkhapadassa attho heṭṭhā nānappakārehi vutto, tasmiṃ pātimokkhe.
analyzed: pātimokkha iti ettha pātimokkha padassa atthaḥ heṭṭhā nānā ppakārehi vuttaḥ tasmin pātimokkhe
translated: In the Pāṭimokkha : the word Pāṭimokkha has been explained in various ways above. In that Pāṭimokkha,

original: Sattannaṃ āpattikkhandhānaṃ avītikkamalakkhaṇo saṃvaro. Mattaññutāti paṭiggahaṇaparibhogavasena
analyzed: sattannam āpatti kkhandhānam a vītikkama lakkhaṇaḥ saṃvaraḥ mattaññu tā ati paṭiggahaṇa paribhoga vasena
translated: restraint is the characteristic of non-transgression of the seven classes of rules. Knowing the limit in food : knowing moderation in eating.

original: pamāṇaññutā. Pantañca sayanāsananti vivittaṃ saṅghaṭṭanavirahitaṃ senāsanaṃ. Adhicitte
analyzed: pamāṇaññu tā sayanāsananti vivittam saṅghaṭṭana virahitam senāsanam adhicitte
translated: moderation. And secluded lodging means a lodging that is secluded, free from noise. And he should be intent on developing, etc.

original: ca āyogoti aṭṭhannaṃ samāpattīnaṃ adhigamāya bhāvanānuyogo.🔽Aparo nayo – anūpavādoti kassacipi uparujjhanavacanassa avadanaṃ. Tena sabbampi vācasikaṃ
analyzed: ca āyogaḥ ti aṭṭhannam samāpattīnam adhigamāya bhāvanā anuyogaḥ  aparaḥ nayaḥ anūpavādaḥ ti kassaci pi uparujjhana vacanassa avadanam tena sabbam pi vācasikam
translated: and moderation in food. “A secluded lodging” : a lodging in a secluded place, free from noise. “Effort” : the effort of development for the attainment of the eight attainments.

original: sīlaṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Anūpaghātoti kāyena kassaci upaghātassa paraviheṭhanassa akaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: sīlam saṅgaṇhāti anūpaghāto ti kāyena kassaci upaghātassa para viheṭhanassa a karaṇam
translated: Another method: “Blameless” : not blaming anyone for harming him. Thus it includes all verbal virtue. “Harmless” : not harming anyone by body or by speech.

original: Tena sabbampi kāyikaṃ sīlaṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Yādisaṃ panidaṃ ubhayaṃ buddhānaṃ sāsanantogadhaṃ🔽hoti, taṃ dassetuṃ – “pātimokkhe ca saṃvaro”ti vuttaṃ. Casaddo nipātamattaṃ. Pātimokkhe
analyzed: tena sabbam pi kāyikam sīlam saṅgaṇhāti yādisam panidam ubhayam buddhānam sāsana ntogadham  hoti tam dassetum pātimokkhe ca vuttam ca saddaḥ nipāta mattam pātimokkhe
translated: Thus it includes all bodily virtue. But since this twofold virtue is the essence of the Buddha’s Dispensation,

original: ca saṃvaroti pātimokkhasaṃvarabhūto anūpavādo anūpaghāto cāti attho.
analyzed: ca saṃvaro ti pātimokkha saṃvara bhūtaḥ an upavādaḥ an upaghāto ca ati attho
translated: the following is said in order to show what it is: “Restraint according to the code” . The word “ca” is merely cumulative. The meaning is: “Restraint according to the code” is the blamelessness and harmlessness that constitute the virtue of restraint according to the code.🔽Or else, “pātimokkha” is a locative of the adhikaraṇa class. “Restraint according to the code” is the restraint based on the code.

original: Atha vā pātimokkheti adhikaraṇe bhummaṃ. Pātimokkhe nissayabhūte saṃvaro. Ko pana
analyzed: atha vā pātimokkha iti adhikaraṇe bhummam pātimokkhe nissaya bhūte saṃvaraḥ kaḥ pana
translated: What is that?

original: soti? Anūpavādo anūpaghāto. Upasampadavelāyañhi avisesena pātimokkhasīlaṃ samādinnaṃ🔽nāma hoti, tasmiṃ pātimokkhe ṭhitassa tato paraṃ upavādūpaghātānaṃ akaraṇavasena
analyzed: saḥ ti anūpavādaḥ anūpaghātaḥ upasampada velāyan hi avisesena pātimokkha sīlam samādinnam  nāma hoti tasmin pātimokkhe ṭhitassa tatas param upavāda upaghātānam a karaṇa vasena
translated: What is that? It is non-reproach and non-affliction. For at the time of the admission to the Order the virtue of the Pāṭimokkha is undertaken without distinction;

original: saṃvaro, so anūpavādo anūpaghāto cāti vutto.
analyzed: saṃvaro so an upavādaḥ an upaghāto ca ati vutto
translated: and when one is established in that Pāṭimokkha, non-reproach and non-affliction are called “restraint” in the sense of not doing the reproach and affliction.

original: Atha vā pātimokkheti nipphādetabbe bhummaṃ yathā “cetaso avūpasamo ayonisomanasikārapadaṭṭhāna”nti.
analyzed: atha vā pātimokkha iti nipphādetabbe bhummam yathā cetasaḥ a vūpasamaḥ a yoniso manasikāra padaṭṭhānam ti
translated: Or alternatively, the Pāṭimokkha is the ground for the production of the non-reproach and non-affliction, just as “lack of mental tranquillity and unwise attention” is the ground for lack of faith .🔽The non-reproach and non-affliction that are to be produced by means of the Pāṭimokkha are the restraint consisting in the Pāṭimokkha.

original: Tena pātimokkhena sādhetabbo anūpavādo anūpaghāto, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṅgahito anūpavādo🔽anūpaghātoicceva attho. Saṃvaroti iminā pana satisaṃvaro, ñāṇasaṃvaro, khantisaṃvaro,
analyzed: tena pātimokkhena sādhetabbaḥ an upavādaḥ an upaghātaḥ pātimokkha saṃvara saṅgahitaḥ an upavādaḥ  attho saṃvaro ti iminā pana sati saṃvaraḥ ñāṇa saṃvaro khanti saṃvaro
translated: The meaning is: non-reproach and non-affliction that are included in the restraint consisting in the Pāṭimokkha.🔽But by the word “restraint” here the four kinds of restraint are included, that is to say, restraint by mindfulness, restraint by knowledge, restraint by energy, and restraint by patience.

original: vīriyasaṃvaroti imesaṃ catunnaṃ saṃvarānaṃ gahaṇaṃ, pātimokkhasādhanaṃ idaṃ saṃvaracatukkaṃ.
analyzed: vīriya saṃvaro ti imesam catunnam saṃvarānam gahaṇam pātimokkha sādhanam idam saṃvara catukkam
translated: This is the fourfold restraint that is the means to the Pāṭimokkha.

original: Mattaññutā ca bhattasminti pariyesanapaṭiggahaṇaparibhogavissajjanānaṃ vasena bhojane
analyzed: mattaññu tā ca bhattasmin ti pariyesana paṭiggahaṇa paribhoga vissajjanānam vasena bhojane
translated: “Moderation in food”: in regard to eating, there is seeking, accepting, using, and expelling.

original: pamāṇaññutā. Pantañca sayanāsananti bhāvanānukūlaṃ araññarukkhamūlādivivittasenāsanaṃ.🔽Adhicitte ca āyogoti sabbacittānaṃ adhikattā uttamattā adhicittasaṅkhāte arahattaphalacitte
analyzed: pamāṇaññu tā sayanāsananti bhāvanā anukūlam arañña rukkha mūla ādi vivitta senāsanaṃ  adhicitte ca sabba cittānam adhika ttā uttama ttā adhicitta saṅkhāte arahatta phala citte
translated: A secluded abode: a secluded dwelling place such as a forest or the foot of a tree, which is conducive to development.

original: sādhetabbe tassa nipphādanatthaṃ samathavipassanābhāvanāvasena āyogo. Etaṃ buddhāna🔽sāsananti etaṃ parassa anūpavadanaṃ, anūpaghātanaṃ, pātimokkhasaṃvaro, pariyesanapaṭiggahaṇādīsu
analyzed: sādhetabbe tassa nipphādana ttham samatha vipassanā bhāvanā vasena āyogaḥ etam buddhāna  sāsanam ti etam parassa anūpavadanam anūpaghātanam pātimokkha saṃvaro pariyesana paṭiggahaṇa ādīsu
translated: And exertion in higher cognizance: the exertion in the development of serenity and insight for the purpose of producing the higher cognizance called the Arahant path, which is higher than all other kinds of cognizance.

original: mattaññutā, vivittavāso, yathāvuttaadhicittānuyogo ca buddhānaṃ sāsanaṃ ovādo anusiṭṭhīti
analyzed: mattaññu tā vivitta vāsaḥ yathāvutta adhicitta anuyogaḥ ca buddhānam sāsanam ovādaḥ anusiṭṭhī iti
translated: This is the Dispensation of the Enlightened Ones: this not finding fault with others, not harming others, restraint by the Pātimokkha, moderation in food, secluded abode, and exertion in higher cognizance, is the Dispensation, the advice, the instruction of the Enlightened Ones.

original: attho. Evaṃ imāya gāthāya tisso sikkhā kathitāti veditabbā.
analyzed: atthaḥ evam imāya gāthāya tisso sikkhā kathitā iti veditabbā
translated: This is the meaning. So it should be understood that three kinds of training are stated in this verse.

original: Chaṭṭhasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: chaṭṭha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the sixth sutta is ended.

original: 7. Sāriputtasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sāriputta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Venerable Sariputta

original: 37. Sattame apubbaṃ natthi. Gāthāya adhicetasoti adhicittavato, sabbacittānaṃ adhikena

translated: it is said: “Then a number of people … low-class people … went away.” Therein, bhikkhus,🔽this sound will not last long. The Teacher said this, consoling the monks, after knowing with his knowledge of omniscience

translated: as one who is full of physical strength, but rather I made the virtue consisting of the fourfold restraint beginning with the Pātimokkha

original: akhaṇḍaṃ achiddaṃ asabalaṃ akammāsaṃ bhujissaṃ viññuppasatthaṃ aparāmaṭṭhaṃ katvā
analyzed: akhaṇḍam a chiddam a sabalam a kammāsam bhujissam viññuppasattham a parāmaṭṭham katvā
translated: unbroken, unblemished, unblotched, unmixed, looked on with equanimity by wise men, and not despised.

original: paripūrento ariyamaggaṃyeva pāpesi”nti vadati. Etena heṭṭhimaphaladvayasampattimattano
analyzed: paripūrentaḥ vadati etena
translated: By fulfilling it I brought about the Noble Path.” By this he shows his own possession of the two lower fruitions.🔽For stream-enterers and once-returners are fulfillers of virtue.

original: dīpeti. Sotāpannasakadāgāmino hi sīlesu paripūrakārino. Susamāhito camhi ekaggacittoti
analyzed: dīpeti sotāpanna sakadāgāminaḥ hi sīlesu paripūra kārinaḥ su samāhitaḥ ekagga citto ti
translated: I am well concentrated, my mind is unified:

original: upacārappanābhedena samādhinā sabbathāpi samāhito ca amhi avikkhittacitto. Iminā
analyzed: upacāra ppanā bhedena samādhinā sabbathā api samāhito ca amhi a vikkhitta cittaḥ iminā
translated: I am concentrated in every way by concentration consisting of access and absorption, and I am one whose mind is not scattered. By this

original: samādhismiṃ paripūrakāritāvacanena tatiyaphalasampattimattano dīpeti. Anāgāmino hi
analyzed: paripūra kāri tā vacanena anāgāminaḥ hi
translated: statement of his fulfillment of concentration he shows his own possession of the third fruition. For non-returners are

original: samādhismiṃ paripūrakārino. Arahā camhi khīṇāsavoti kāmāsavādīnaṃ sabbaso khīṇattā
analyzed: samādhismim paripūra kārinaḥ arahā khīṇa āsavaḥ ti kāma āsava ādīnam sabbaso khīṇa ttā
translated: I am an Arahant because I have destroyed the cankers of sense desire, etc., completely.

original: khīṇāsavo, tato eva parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sadevake loke aggadakkhiṇeyyatāya arahā
analyzed: khīṇa āsavaḥ tatas eva parikkhīṇa bhava saṃyojanaḥ sa devake loke agga dakkhiṇeyya tāya arahā
translated: And because I have destroyed the fetters of existence, I am worthy of the highest offerings in the world with its gods.🔽I am an Arahant. By this he shows that he has done what had to be done.🔽I am one of great power and great might.

original: camhi. Etena attano katakaraṇīyataṃ dasseti. Mahiddhiko camhi mahānubhāvoti adhiṭṭhānavikubbanādiiddhīsu
analyzed: camhi etena attano kata karaṇīya tam dasseti mahiddhiko camhi mahā anubhāvo ti adhiṭṭhāna vikubbana ādi iddhīsu
translated: I am one of great power because I am endowed with great mastery in the supernormal powers of resolve, transformation, etc.

original: mahatā vasībhāvena samannāgatattā mahiddhiko uḷārassa puññānubhāvassa guṇānubhāvassa
analyzed: mahatā vasībhāvena samannāgata ttā mahiddhikaḥ uḷārassa puñña anubhāvassa guṇa anubhāvassa
translated: I am one of great might because I have the excellence of great merit and the excellence of great special qualities.

original: ca sampattiyā mahānubhāvo ca asmi. Etena lokiyābhiññānavānupubbavihārasamāpattiyogamattano🔽dīpeti. Abhiññāsu vasībhāvena hi ariyā yathicchitanipphādanena mahiddhikā, pubbūpanissayasampattiyā
analyzed: ca sampattiyāḥ mahā anubhāvaḥ ca asmi etena lokiya abhiññānavā anupubba vihāra samāpatti yoga mattano  dīpeti abhiññāsu vasībhāvena hi ariyāḥ yathā icchita nipphādanena mahiddhikāḥ pubba upanissaya sampattiyā
translated: By this he shows his own possession of the mundane direct knowledges, the attainment of the liberations, and the concentration of the signless.🔽For the noble ones are of great power in that they can produce at will by means of mastery in the direct knowledges.

original: nānāvihārasamāpattīhi ca visodhitasantānattā mahānubhāvā ca hontīti.
analyzed: nānā vihāra samāpattīhi ca visodhita santānattāḥ mahā anubhāvāḥ ca honti iti
translated: And they are of great might in that their continuity is purified by the attainment of the various liberations and concentrations, which are the excellence of previous requisites.

original: Bhaddakaṃ me jīvitanti evaṃvidhasīlādiguṇasamannāgatassa me yāvāyaṃ kāyo dharati,
analyzed: bhaddakam me jīvitanti evaṃvidha sīla ādi guṇa samannāgatassa me yāva ayam kāyaḥ dharati
translated: My life has been fruitful.

original: tāva sattānaṃ hitasukhameva vaḍḍhati, puññakkhettabhāvato jīvitampi me bhaddakaṃ🔽sundaraṃ. Bhaddakaṃ maraṇanti sace panidaṃ khandhapañcakaṃ ajja vā imasmiṃyeva vā
analyzed: tāva sattānam hita sukham eva vaḍḍhati puñña kkhetta bhāvataḥ jīvitam pi me bhaddakam  sundaram bhaddakam sace vā
translated: excellent, because of being a field of merit.

original: khaṇe anupādāno viya jātavedo nibbāyati, taṃ appaṭisandhikaṃ parinibbānasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: khaṇe anupādānaḥ viya jātavedaḥ nibbāyati tam appaṭisandhikam parinibbāna saṅkhātam
translated: “Good is death”: if this five-aggregate-constituent body were to be extinguished today or in this very moment, like a fire without fuel, then that death, which is called “final Nibbāna without clinging,”

original: maraṇampi me bhaddakanti ubhayattha tādibhāvaṃ dīpeti. Evaṃ mahāthero appahīnasomanassuppilāvitavāsanussannattā
analyzed: maraṇam pi me bhaddakam ti ubhayattha ta ādi bhāvam dīpeti evam mahā theraḥ appahīna somanassa uppi lāvita vāsa nussanna ttā
translated: is good for me. In both cases he shows that he is such a one. Thus the Elder, because of the non-abandonment of the habit energy of joy and delight,

original: uḷārasomanassito dhammabahumānena dhammapītipaṭisaṃvedanena parivitakkesi.
analyzed: uḷāra somanassitaḥ dhamma bahu mānena dhamma pīti paṭisaṃvedanena parivitakkesi
translated: thought with great joy, with the experience of the rapture of the Dhamma through his great respect for the Dhamma.

original: Taṃ satthā gandhakuṭiyaṃ nisinnova sabbaññutaññāṇena jānitvā jīvite maraṇe ca tassa tādibhāvavibhāvanaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi. Tena vuttaṃ – “atha kho bhagavā…pe… udānesī”ti.
analyzed: tam satthā gandhakuṭiyam nisinnaḥ iva sabbaññuta ññāṇena jānitvā jīvite maraṇe ca tassa tādi bhāva vibhāvanam imam udānam udānesi tena vuttam atha kho bhagavā āpe udānesi iti
translated: The Teacher, sitting in the Fragrant Cell, knew this by means of his omniscience, and he uttered this solemn utterance, explaining that he was such a one in regard to life and death. Therefore it was said: “Then the Blessed One … uttered this solemn utterance.”

original: Tattha yaṃ jīvitaṃ na tapatīti yaṃ khīṇāsavapuggalaṃ jīvitaṃ āyatiṃ khandhappavattiyā
analyzed: tattha yam jīvitam na tapati iti yam khīṇāsava puggalam jīvitam āyatim khandha ppavattiyā
translated: Herein, as to the words “What life does not torment,” the life of a person whose cankers are destroyed does not torment him in regard to the future arising of the aggregates.

original: sabbena sabbaṃ abhāvato na tapati na bādhati, vattamānameva vā jīvitaṃ sabbaso saṅkhatadhammattā
analyzed: sabbena sabbam abhāvataḥ na tapati na bādhati vattamānam eva vā jīvitam sabbaso saṅkhata dhamma ttā
translated: It does not burn him because of the absence of all of everything. Or else, life itself does not burn him because it is entirely a formed thing.

original: satipaññāvepullappattiyā sabbattha satisampajaññasamāyogato na bādhati. Yo hi andhaputhujjano🔽pāpajanasevī ayonisomanasikārabahulo akatakusalo akatapuñño, so “akataṃ vata me kalyāṇa”ntiādinā🔽vippaṭisārena tapatīti tassa jīvitaṃ taṃ tapati nāma. Itare pana akatapāpā katapuññā🔽kalyāṇaputhujjanena saddhiṃ satta sekhā tapanīyadhammaparivajjanena atapanīyadhammasamannāgamena🔽ca pacchānutāpena na tapantīti na tesaṃ jīvitaṃ tapati. Khīṇāsave pana vattabbameva
analyzed: sati paññā vepulla ppattiyā sabbattha sati sampajañña samāyogataḥ na bādhati yaḥ hi andha puthujjanaḥ  pāpa jana sevī a yoniso manasikāra bahulaḥ akata kusalaḥ akata puññaḥ saḥ akatam vata me kalyāṇanti ādinā  vippaṭisārena tapati iti tassa jīvitam tam tapati nāma itare pana akata pāpā kata puññā  kalyāṇa puthujjanena saddhim satta sekhā tapanīya dhamma parivajjanena a tapanīya dhamma samannāgamena  ca pacchā anutāpena na tapanti iti na tesam jīvitam tapati khīṇāsave pana vattabbam eva
translated: It does not burn him because of the combination of mindfulness and full awareness everywhere due to the attainment of the abundance of mindfulness and full awareness. For the blind worldling

original: sokassa samugghātitattā. Sa ve diṭṭhapado dhīro, sokamajjhe na socatīti so anabhijjhādīnaṃ
analyzed: sokassa samugghātita ttā sa ve diṭṭha padaḥ dhīro soka majjhe na socati iti saḥ anabhijjha ādīnam
translated: He who has seen the state of peace, the wise one, does not sorrow in the midst of sorrow.

original: catunnaṃ dhammapadānaṃ nibbānasseva vā diṭṭhattā diṭṭhapado, dhitisampannattā dhīro🔽khīṇāsavo socanadhammattā “sokā”ti laddhanāmānaṃ avītarāgānaṃ sattānaṃ, sokahetūnaṃ
analyzed: catunnam dhamma padānam nibbānassa iva vā diṭṭha ttā diṭṭha padaḥ dhiti sampanna ttā dhīro  khīṇa āsavaḥ socana dhamma ttā sokāti laddha nāmānam a vīta rāgānam sattānam soka hetūnam
translated: He has seen the state of peace, nibbana, through the four states of the path beginning with non-greed, or he has seen nibbana itself. He is wise because he is endowed with steadfastness.

original: vā lokadhammānaṃ majjhe ṭhatvāpi na socati.
analyzed: vā loka dhammānam majjhe ṭhatvā api na socati
translated: He is a bhikkhu whose cankers are destroyed, who does not sorrow, although he stands in the midst of the sorrows of beings who are not yet free from lust and who are called “sorrowful” or in the midst of the worldly states that are the causes of sorrow.

original: Idānissa sabbaso sokahetūnaṃ abhāvaṃ dīpetuṃ “ucchinnabhavataṇhassā”tiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: idāni sabbaso soka hetūnam abhāvam dīpetum ucchinna bhava taṇhassa ati ādim āha tattha
translated: Now, in order to show that he has completely no causes for sorrow, the Master says, “Whose craving for becoming has been cut off,” and so forth.

original: yassa aggamaggena sabbaso ucchinnā bhavataṇhā, so ucchinnabhavataṇho. Tassa avasesakilesānaṃ
analyzed: yassa aggamaggena sabbasas ucchinnā bhava taṇhā so ucchinna bhava taṇho tassa avasesa kilesānaṃ
translated: He whose craving for becoming has been cut off completely by the path of arahatship is one whose craving for becoming has been cut off.🔽For the bhikkhu whose cankers are destroyed, whose mind is peaceful through the complete cessation of the remaining defilements,

original: anavasesavūpasamena santacittassa khīṇāsavabhikkhuno. Vikkhīṇo jātisaṃsāroti jātiādiko –
analyzed: anavasesa vūpasamena santa cittassa khīṇāsava bhikkhuno vikkhīṇaḥ jāti saṃsāraḥ ti jāti ādikaḥ
translated: the round of rebirths has been broken.

original: “Khandhānañca paṭipāṭi, dhātuāyatanāna ca;
analyzed: khandhānam ca paṭipāṭi dhātu āyatanāna ca
translated: The round of rebirths is the succession of aggregates, elements, and sense bases,

original: Abbocchinnaṃ vattamānā, ‘saṃsāro’ti pavuccatī”ti. –
analyzed: abbocchinnam vattamānā saṃsāro iti pavuccati iti
translated: which is said to be “the round of rebirths” as it revolves without interruption.

original: Vuttalakkhaṇo saṃsāro visesato khīṇo. Tasmā natthi tassa punabbhavoti yasmā tassa
analyzed: vutta lakkhaṇo saṃsāraḥ visesataḥ khīṇo tasmā natthi tassa punabbhavaḥ ti yasmā tassa
translated: The round of rebirths with its specific characteristics is exhausted, especially for him. Therefore, there is no more renewed existence for him.

original: evarūpassa ariyapuggalassa āyatiṃ punabbhavo natthi, tasmā tassa jātisaṃsāro khīṇo.
analyzed: evarūpassa ariya puggalassa āyatim punabbhavaḥ natthi tasmā tassa jāti saṃsāro khīṇo
translated: Since there is no more renewed existence for such a noble person in the future, therefore his round of rebirths through birth is exhausted.

original: Kasmā panassa punabbhavo natthi? Yasmā ucchinnabhavataṇho santacitto ca hoti, tasmāti
analyzed: kasmā pana assa punabbhavaḥ natthi yasmā ucchinna bhava taṇho santa citto ca hoti tasmā iti
translated: But why is there no more renewed existence for him? Because he has cut off craving for existence and his mind is peaceful.

original: āvattetvā vattabbaṃ. Atha vā vikkhīṇo jātisaṃsāro, tato eva natthi tassa punabbhavoti attho yojetabbo.
analyzed: āvattetvā vattabbam atha vā vikkhīṇaḥ jāti saṃsāro tatas eva na atthi tassa punabbhavaḥ ti atthaḥ yojetabbo
translated: Therefore, the meaning should be construed as follows: “The round of rebirths is exhausted for him, and therefore there is no more renewed existence for him.”

original: Navamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: navama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the ninth sutta is finished.

original: 10. Sāriputtaupasamasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The sutta on Sariputta’s peace

original: 40. Dasame attano upasamanti sāvakapāramīmatthakappattiyā hetubhūtaṃ aggamaggena attano anavasesakilesavūpasamaṃ.
analyzed: dasame attanaḥ upasamanti sāvaka pāramī matthaka ppattiyāḥ hetu bhūtam aggamaggena attanaḥ anavasesa kilesa vūpasamam
translated: In the tenth sutta, “his own peace” is the complete pacification of his own defilements by the supreme path, which is the cause for his attainment of the perfection of discipleship.

original: Āyasmā hi sāriputto anupasantakilesānaṃ sattānaṃ rāgādikilesajanitasantāpadarathapariḷāhadukkhañceva
analyzed: āyasmā hi sāriputtaḥ an upasanta kilesānam sattānam rāga ādi kilesa janita santāpa daratha pariḷāha dukkham ca eva
translated: For the venerable Sariputta’s defilements were pacified by the supreme path, and he was freed from the suffering of the mental disturbances, such as passion, etc., which arise from undisciplined defilements,🔽and from the suffering of the bodily disturbances, such as the four hundred and four diseases, which arise from undisciplined defilements.

original: kilesābhisaṅkhāranimittaṃ jātijarābyādhimaraṇasokaparidevādidukkhañca paccakkhato
analyzed: kilesa abhisaṅkhāra nimittam jāti jarā byādhi maraṇa soka parideva ādi dukkham ca paccakkhataḥ
translated: and the suffering of birth, aging, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, etc., which is the result of the defilements and of the kamma that is determined by the defilements,

original: disvā atītānāgatepi nesaṃ vaṭṭamūlakadukkhaṃ parituletvā karuṇāyamāno attanāpi puthujjanakāle🔽anubhūtaṃ kilesanimittaṃ vā anappakaṃ dukkhaṃ anussaritvā “īdisassa nāma mahādukkhassa
analyzed: disvā atīta anāgate api vaṭṭamūlaka dukkham parituletvā karuṇāyamānaḥ puthujjana kāle  anubhūtam kilesa nimittam vā anappakam dukkham anussaritvā īdisassa nāma mahā dukkhassa
translated: and having reflected on the suffering of the round of existence in the past and the future, he pities all beings.

original: hetubhūtā kilesā idāni me suppahīnā”ti attano kilesavūpasamaṃ abhiṇhaṃ paccavekkhati.🔽Paccavekkhanto ca “ime ettakā kilesā sotāpattimaggena upasamitā, ettakā sakadāgāmimaggena,
analyzed: hetu bhūtāḥ kilesāḥ idāni me su pahīnāḥ ati attanaḥ kilesa vūpasamam abhiṇham paccavekkhati  paccavekkhanto ca ime ettakā kilesā sotāpatti maggena upasamitāḥ ettakā sakadāgāmi maggena
translated: And recollecting the great suffering that he himself experienced in the past as a worldling, due to the defilements, he often reflects on the stilling of the defilements in himself thus: “The defilements that were the cause of such great suffering have now been well eradicated by me.”

original: ettakā anāgāmimaggena, ettakā arahattamaggena upasamitā”ti taṃtaṃmaggañāṇehi odhiso
analyzed: ettakāḥ anāgāmi maggena ettakāḥ arahatta maggena upasamitā ati tad tad magga ñāṇehi odhiso
translated: And reflecting thus, he considers the stilling of the defilements by means of the different paths thus: “So many defilements have been stilled by the path of stream-entry, so many by the path of once-return, so many by the path of non-return, and so many by the path of arahatship.”

original: kilesānaṃ upasamitabhāvaṃ paccavekkhati, tena vuttaṃ – “attano upasamaṃ paccavekkhamāno”ti.
analyzed: kilesānam upasamita bhāvam paccavekkhati tena vuttam attanaḥ upasamam paccavekkhamānaḥ ti
translated: Thus he reflects on the stilling of the defilements by means of the different kinds of knowledge of the paths. Hence it is said: “reflecting on his own stilling.”

original: Apare “thero arahattaphalasamāpattiṃ samāpajjitvā taṃ paccavekkhitvā ‘imassa vatāyaṃ🔽santapaṇītabhāvo accantasantāya asaṅkhatāya dhātuyā ārammaṇato, sayañca sammadeva🔽kilesavūpasamato’ti evaṃ abhiṇhaṃ upasamaṃ paccavekkhatī”ti vadanti. Aññe pana “anavasesakilesānaṃ
analyzed: apare theraḥ arahatta phala samāpattim samāpajjitvā tam paccavekkhitvā imassa vata ayam  santa paṇīta bhāvaḥ accanta santāya asaṅkhatāya dhātuyāḥ ārammaṇato sayam ca sammat eva  kilesa vūpasamato ti evam abhiṇham upasamam paccavekkhati iti vadanti aññe pana anavasesa kilesānam
translated: Others say that the elder, having attained the fruition of arahantship, reviews it and so repeatedly reviews peace, thinking, “This state of peace and this state of utter peace are the object of the element of peace, of the deathless, and they are well penetrated by me in conformity with reality.”🔽But others say that the elder reviews the state of peace, thinking, “The complete tranquilization of all suffering is the state of peace, and that is well penetrated by me in conformity with reality.”

original: upasamapariyosāne jātaṃ aggaphalamevettha upasamo nāma, taṃ paccavekkhamāno nisinno”ti.🔽Etamatthaṃ viditvāti yadidaṃ āyasmato sāriputtassa mahāpaññatādihetubhūtaṃ sāvakesu
analyzed: upasama pariyosāne jātam agga phalam eva ittha upasamaḥ nāma tam paccavekkhamānaḥ nisinnaḥ ti  etam attham viditvā iti yat idam āyasmataḥ sāriputtassa mahā paññatā ādi hetu bhūtam sāvakesu
translated: Others say that the elder, having entered upon the fruition attainment of Arahantship, reviews it and thinks, “This peacefulness and sublime state of mind is due to the object, namely, the supramundane Nibbāna element, which is utterly peaceful and sublime, and it is due to the complete tranquilization of the defilements.” Others say that he is seated reviewing the foremost fruit, namely, the peace that comes about with the cessation of defilements without remainder.

original: anaññasādhāraṇaṃ kilesappahānaṃ aggaphalaṃ vā upasamapariyāyena vuttaṃ, tassa paccavekkhaṇasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: anañña sādhāraṇam kilesa ppahānam agga phalam vā upasama pariyāyena vuttam tassa paccavekkhaṇa saṅkhātam
translated: Having understood the meaning: having understood in all its modes the meaning of the peace that is expressed by the term “peace” as the abandoning of defilements not shared by any disciples, or as the foremost fruit, which is the elder’s cause for his great understanding, etc.

original: atthaṃ sabbākārato viditvā tadanubhāvadīpakaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: attham sabba ākārataḥ viditvā tad anubhāva dīpakam imam udānam udānesi
translated: He uttered this utterance, which reveals the power of that peace.

original: Tattha upasantasantacittassāti upasantameva hutvā santaṃ cittaṃ etassāti upasantasantacitto.
analyzed: tattha upasanta santa cittassa ati upasantam eva hutvā santam cittam etassa ati upasanta santa cittaḥ
translated: Herein, his mind was peaceful and still: his mind was peaceful and also still, tranquil, in the sense of being stilled, in him, thus he had a peaceful and still mind.

original: Samāpattiyā vikkhambhanena hi upasantakilesattā upasantacittaṃ na sabbathā “upasantasanta”nti🔽vuccati tassa upasamassa anaccantikabhāvato, na tathā aggamaggena. Tena pana accantameva
analyzed: samāpattiyāḥ vikkhambhanena hi upasanta kilesa ttā upasanta cittam na sabbathā upasanta santanti  vuccati tassa upasamassa an accantika bhāvataḥ na tathā aggamaggena tena pana accantam eva
translated: For the mind of one who has entered upon jhāna is called “peaceful” because of the temporary suppression of defilements by jhāna. But it is not called “very peaceful” because that peace is not definitive,🔽not being the ultimate path. But the Arahant’s mind is called “very peaceful” because of the definitive peace of the ultimate path,

original: kilesānaṃ samucchinnattā arahato cittaṃ puna kilesānaṃ anupasametabbatāya samathavipassanāheṭṭhimamaggehi🔽upasantakilesaṃ hutvā accantasantabhāvatova “upasantasanta”nti vuccati. Tena vuttaṃ🔽– “upasantameva hutvā santaṃ cittaṃ etassāti upasantasantacitto”ti. Upasantanti vā
analyzed: kilesānam samucchinna ttā arahataḥ cittam puna kilesānam an upasametabba tāya samatha vipassanā heṭṭhima maggehi  upasanta kilesam hutvā accanta santa bhāvataḥ va upasantasantanti vuccati tena vuttam  upasantam eva hutvā santam cittam etassa ati upasanta santa citto ti upasantanti vā
translated: which is the path of the full understanding of the defilements. For the defilements do not occur again in the Arahant’s mind.🔽Therefore it was said above: “Because his mind is very peaceful because of the definitive peace of the defilements.”

original: upasamo vuccati, tasmā “upasantasantacittassā”ti accantūpasamena santacittassāti attho.
analyzed: upasamaḥ vuccati tasmai upasanta santa cittassa ati accantu upasamena santa cittassa ati attho
translated: Or alternatively, the word upasanto can be taken as a noun, in which case the meaning is: “because of the definitive peace of his mind.”

original: Atha vā satipi sabbesaṃ khīṇāsavānaṃ anavasesakilesavūpasame sāvakapāramīñāṇassa
analyzed: atha vā sati pi sabbesam khīṇāsavānam anavasesa kilesa vūpasame sāvaka pāramī ñāṇassa
translated: Or, although all those whose cankers are destroyed have completely suppressed all the defilements, still the knowledge of the perfection of disciples

original: pana matthakappattihetubhūto sāvakesu anaññasādhāraṇo saviseso dhammasenāpatino kilesavūpasamoti
analyzed: pana matthaka ppatti hetu bhūto sāvakesu anañña sādhāraṇaḥ sa visesaḥ dhammasenāpatino kilesa vūpasamaḥ ti
translated: But the stilling of defilements in the Master, which is unique to him and not shared by disciples, and which is the cause for his attaining the peak, is a special quality.

original: dassetuṃ satthā upasantasaddena visesetvā āha “upasantasantacittassā”ti.
analyzed: dassetum satthā upasanta saddena visesetvā āha upasanta santa cittassa iti
translated: In order to show this, the Master, after distinguishing it by the word “stilling,” said, “Whose mind is stilled and well stilled.”

original: Tatrāyamattho – bhusaṃ daḷhaṃ vā santaṃ upasantaṃ, tena upasantena upasantameva hutvā
analyzed: tatra ayam atthaḥ bhusam daḷham vā santam upasantam tena upasantena upasantam eva hutvā
translated: Herein, the meaning is this: “Still” is the same as “very” or “firmly” “stilled.” “Well stilled” is stilled by that stilledness, stilled in the very act of being stilled.

original: santaṃ upasantasantaṃ, tādisaṃ cittaṃ etassāti sabbaṃ purimasadisameva. Tathā hesa
analyzed: santam upasanta santam tādisam cittam etassa ati sabbam purima sadisam eva tathā ha āsa
translated: One whose mind is such as this is called “whose mind is stilled and well stilled.” All the rest is as already stated.

original: bhagavatā – “sāriputto, bhikkhave, mahāpañño puthupañño hāsapañño javanapañño tikkhapañño
analyzed: bhagavatā sāriputtaḥ bhikkhave mahā paññaḥ puthu paññaḥ hāsa paññaḥ javana paññaḥ tikkha paññaḥ
translated: For this venerable Sāriputta was praised and extolled by the Blessed One in many ways, as follows: “Sāriputta is wise, bhikkhus, of great wisdom, of wide wisdom, of joyous wisdom, of quick-working wisdom, of keen wisdom,

original: nibbedhikapañño”tiādinā anekapariyāyena vaṇṇito thomito. Netticchinnassāti netti
analyzed: nibbedhika paññā ti ādinā aneka pariyāyena vaṇṇito thomitaḥ netti chinnassa ati
translated: of penetrative wisdom” , and so on.

original: vuccati bhavataṇhā saṃsārassa nayanato, sā netti chinnā etassāti netticchinno. Tassa
analyzed: vuccati bhava taṇhā saṃsārassa nayanato sā chinnā etassa ati tassa
translated: “Whose net is cut” : craving is called a “net” because it leads beings on . One whose net is cut is “net-cutter.”🔽“Whose net is cut” : whose craving is abandoned, is the meaning.

original: netticchinnassa, pahīnataṇhassāti attho. Mutto so mārabandhanāti so evaṃvidho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano
analyzed: netti chinnassa pahīna taṇhassa ati atthaḥ muttaḥ saḥ māra bandhanā ati saḥ evaṃvidho parikkhīṇa bhava saṃyojano
translated: “Freed from the bonds of Māra” : this venerable one, who is thus completely freed from the bonds of becoming,

original: sabbasmā mārabandhanato mutto, na tassa mārabandhanamocanāya karaṇīyaṃ atthi, tasmā
analyzed: sabbasmā māra bandhanataḥ muttaḥ na tassa māra bandhana mocanāya karaṇīyam atthi tasmā
translated: He is freed from all the bonds of Mara. There is nothing more for him to do to be freed from the bonds of Mara. Therefore

original: dhammasenāpati attano upasamaṃ paccavekkhatīti. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: dhamma senāpati attanaḥ upasamam paccavekkhati iti sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: the General of the Dhamma reflects on his own peace. The rest is as before.

original: Dasamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dasama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the tenth sutta is finished.

original: Niṭṭhitā ca meghiyavaggavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: niṭṭhitā ca meghiya vagga vaṇṇanā
translated: And the commentary on the Meghiya Vagga is finished.

analyzed: soṇa vaggaḥ
translated: The Sonaka Vagga

original: 1. Piyatarasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: piyatara sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The More Lovely Sutta

original: 41. Mahāvaggassa paṭhame mallikāya deviyā saddhinti mallikāya nāma attano mahesiyā
analyzed: mahā vaggassa paṭhame mallikāya deviyā saddhinti mallikāya nāma attanaḥ mahesiyā
translated: With Mallika, the Queen: with his chief consort named Mallika.

original: saha. Uparipāsādavaragatoti pāsādavarassa upari gato. Kocañño attanā piyataroti koci
analyzed: saha upari pāsāda vara gato ti pāsāda varassa upari gato attanā piyataro ti koci
translated: Gone up to the excellent terrace: gone up to the top of the excellent terrace.🔽And who is dearer to you than yourself? Who is dearer to you than you are to yourself?

original: añño attanā piyāyitabbataro. Atthi nu kho teti “kiṃ te atthī”ti deviṃ pucchati.
analyzed: aññaḥ attanā piyāyitabbataraḥ atthi nu kho te iti kim te atthi iti devim pucchati
translated: Have you any? The queen asks, “What do you have?”

analyzed: kasmā pucchati ayam hi sāvatthiyam duggata mālākārassa dhītā eka divasam āpaṇataḥ
translated: Why does he ask? For she is the daughter of a poor garland maker in Savatthi. One day, taking a sweet cake from the market,

analyzed: gahetvā mālā ārāmam gantvā khādissāmi iti gacchantī paṭipathe bhikkhu saṅgha parivutam
translated: she went to the Mallika’s Park, thinking, “I’ll eat it.” On her way, she met the Community of Bhikkhus,

original: bhagavantaṃ bhikkhācāraṃ pavisantaṃ disvā pasannacittā taṃ bhagavato adāsi. Satthā
analyzed: bhagavantam bhikkhācāram pavisantam disvā pasanna cittā tam bhagavataḥ adāsi satthā
translated: and when she saw the Blessed One enter for alms, she gave it to him with a pure heart. The Teacher

original: tathārūpe ṭhāne nisīdanākāraṃ dassesi. Ānandatthero cīvaraṃ paññāpetvā adāsi. Bhagavā
analyzed: tathārūpe ṭhāne nisīdana ākāram dassesi ānanda theraḥ cīvaram paññāpetvā adāsi bhagavā
translated: showed her a place to sit down. The Elder Ānanda spread out his robe and gave it to her. The Blessed One

original: tattha nisīditvā taṃ pūvaṃ paribhuñjitvā mukhaṃ vikkhāletvā sitaṃ pātvākāsi. Thero
analyzed: tattha nisīditvā tam pūvam paribhuñjitvā mukham vikkhāletvā sitam pātvā akāsi theraḥ
translated: sat down there, ate the cake, washed his mouth, and drank water. The Elder Ānanda

original: “ko imissā, bhante, dānassa vipāko bhavissatī”ti pucchi. “Ajjesā, ānanda, tathāgatassa
analyzed: kaḥ imissā bhante dānassa vipākaḥ bhavissati iti pucchi ajja esā ānanda tathāgatassa
translated: asked, “What will be the result of this gift, Reverend Sir?” “Today, Ānanda, she gave the Tathāgata

analyzed: paṭhamam bhojanam adāsi ajjā iva kosala raññaḥ agga mahesī bhavissati piyā manāpā ti
translated: his first meal. Today she will become the most beloved and dear queen of the King of Kosala.”

original: Taṃ divasameva ca rājā kāsigāme bhāgineyyena saddhiṃ yujjhitvā parājito palāyitvā
analyzed: tam divasam eva ca rājā kāsigāme bhāgineyyena saddhim yujjhitvā parājitaḥ palāyitvā
translated: On that very day, the king, having fought with his sister’s son in the city of Kāsi, was defeated and fled.

original: āgato nagaraṃ pavisanto “balakāyassa āgamanaṃ āgamessāmī”ti taṃ mālārāmaṃ pāvisi.
analyzed: āgataḥ nagaram pavisantaḥ balakāyassa āgamanam āgamessāmi iti tam mālā ārāmam pāvisi
translated: When he entered the city, he thought, “I will send for the army,” and he entered the Mallika’s Grove.

original: Sā rājānaṃ āgataṃ passitvā tassa vattamakāsi. Rājā tassā vatte pasīditvā pitaraṃ
analyzed: sā rājānam āgatam passitvā tassa vattam akāsi rājā tassāḥ vatte pasīditvā pitaram
translated: When she saw the king, she did what was proper for him. The king was pleased with her service, and he said to his sister,🔽“Sister, I will give you a village.”

original: pakkosāpetvā mahantaṃ issariyaṃ datvā taṃ antepuraṃ paṭiharāpetvā aggamahesiṭṭhāne🔽ṭhapesi. Athekadivasaṃ rājā cintesi – “mayā imissā mahantaṃ issariyaṃ dinnaṃ, yaṃnūnāhaṃ
analyzed: pakkosāpetvā mahantam issariyam da tvā tam antepuram paṭiharāpetvā aggamahesiṭṭhāne  ṭhapesi atha eka divasam rājā cintesi mayā imissā mahantam issariyam dinnam yat nūna aham
translated: He summoned her, gave her great honour, took her to his harem, and made her his chief consort.

original: imaṃ puccheyyaṃ ‘ko te piyo’ti? Sā ‘tvaṃ me, mahārāja, piyo’ti vatvā, puna maṃ pucchissati,
analyzed: imam puccheyyam kaḥ te piyaḥ iti sā tvam me mahā rāja piyaḥ iti vatvā puna mama pucchissati
translated: One day the king thought, “I have given her great honour. Suppose I were to ask her, ‘Who is dear to you?’ She will say, ‘You are dear to me, great king.’ Then I will ask her,

original: athassāhaṃ ‘mayhampi tvaṃyeva piyā’ti vakkhāmī”ti. Iti so aññamaññaṃ vissāsajananatthaṃ🔽sammodanīyaṃ karonto pucchi.
analyzed: athassa aham mayham pi tvaṃyā iva piyā ati vakkhāmi iti so aññam aññam vissāsa janana ttham  sammodanīyam karontaḥ pucchi
translated: ‘You are dear to me too.’“ Thus he asked her in order to create mutual confidence.

original: Devī pana paṇḍitā buddhupaṭṭhāyikā saṅghupaṭṭhāyikā “nāyaṃ pañho rañño mukhaṃ ulloketvā
analyzed: devī pana paṇḍitā buddha upaṭṭhāyikā saṅgha upaṭṭhāyikā na ayam pañhaḥ raññaḥ mukham ulloketvā
translated: But the queen was wise, a supporter of the Buddha and the Sangha. She thought, “This question should not be answered by looking the king in the face.”

original: kathetabbo”ti cintetvā yathābhūtameva vadantī “natthi kho me, mahārāja, kocañño attanā
analyzed: kathetabbā iti cintetvā yathābhūtam eva vadantī natthi kho me mahā rāja kocaññaḥ attanā
translated: So she spoke the truth as she saw it: “Great king, there is no one dearer to me than myself.”

original: piyataro”ti āha. Vatvāpi attanā byākatamatthaṃ upāyena rañño paccakkhaṃ kātukāmā
analyzed: piyatarā iti āha vatvā api attanā byākatam attham upāyena rañño paccakkham kātu kāmā
translated: But after speaking thus, she wanted to make the meaning of her statement clear to the king by a stratagem.

original: “tuyhaṃ pana, mahārāja, atthañño koci attanā piyataro”ti tatheva rājānaṃ pucchi yathā
analyzed: tuyham pana mahā rāja atthañño koci attanā piyataraḥ ti tathā iva rājānam pucchi yathā
translated: “But, sire, is there anyone else dearer to you than yourself?” And he asked the king in the same way as

original: raññā sayaṃ puṭṭhā. Rājāpi tāya sarasalakkhaṇena kathitattā nivattituṃ asakkonto
analyzed: raññā sayam puṭṭhā rājā api tāya sarasa lakkhaṇena kathita ttā nivattitum a sakkontaḥ
translated: the king had asked himself. And the king, unable to turn back because of the charm of her speech,

original: sayampi sarasalakkhaṇeneva kathento tatheva byākāsi yathā deviyā byākataṃ.
analyzed: sayam pi sa rasa lakkhaṇena iva kathento tathā iva yathā deviyā byākatam
translated: answered in the same way as the queen had done, explaining himself by the charm of his own speech.

original: Byākaritvā ca mandadhātukatāya evaṃ cintesi – “ahaṃ rājā pathavissaro mahantaṃ pathavimaṇḍalaṃ
analyzed: byākaritvā ca manda dhātuka tāya evam cintesi aham rājā pathavissaraḥ mahantam pathavi maṇḍalam
translated: And when he had answered, he thought: “I am a king, lord of the earth, who has conquered and rules over a great realm.

original: abhivijiya ajjhāvasāmi, mayhaṃ tāva yuttaṃ ‘attanā piyataraṃ aññaṃ na passāmī’ti,
analyzed: abhivijiya ajjhāvasāmi mayham tāva yuttam attanā piyataram aññam na passāmi iti
translated: It is right for me to say: ‘I see no one dearer to me than myself.’

original: ayaṃ pana vasalī hīnajaccā samānā mayā ucce ṭhāne ṭhapitā sāmibhūtaṃ maṃ na tathā
analyzed: ayam pana vasalī samānā mayā ucce ṭhāne sāmibhūtam na tathā
translated: But this slave-born woman, though of low birth, has been raised to a high position by me. She does not love me as her master,

original: piyāyati, ‘attāva piyataro’ti mama sammukhā vadati, yāva kakkhaḷā vatāya”nti anattamano
analyzed: piyāyati attā ava piyataraḥ ti mama sammukhā vadati yāva kakkhaḷāḥ vatāyanti an atta mano
translated: but in my very presence she says: ‘Myself am dearer to me.’ How hard-hearted she is!”

original: hutvā “nanu te tīṇi ratanāni piyatarānī”ti codesi. Devī ‘ratanattayaṃpāhaṃ deva attano
analyzed: hutvā nanu te tīṇi ratanāni piyatarāni iti codesi devī deva
translated: And being displeased, he asked: “Are not your three jewels dearer to you?” The queen said: “Your three jewels, sire,

original: saggasukhaṃ mokkhasukhañca patthayantī sampiyāyāmi, tasmā attāva me piyataro”ti āha.
analyzed: sagga sukham mokkha sukham ca patthayantī sampiyāyāmi tasmai attā ava me piyataraḥ iti āha
translated: I love myself more than anyone else because I desire the happiness of heaven and the happiness of deliverance.”

original: Sabbo cāyaṃ loko attadatthameva paraṃ piyāyati, puttaṃ patthentopi “ayaṃ maṃ jiṇṇakāle
analyzed: sabbaḥ ca ayam lokaḥ atta dattham eva param piyāyati puttam patthentaḥ api ayam mam jiṇṇa kāle
translated: The whole world loves another for one’s own sake. Even when one desires a son, one desires him thinking, “He will support me when I am old.”

original: posessatī”ti pattheti, dhītaraṃ “mama kulaṃ vaḍḍhissatī”ti, bhariyaṃ “mayhaṃ pāde🔽paricarissatī”ti, aññepi ñātimittabandhave taṃtaṃkiccavasena, iti attadatthameva
analyzed: posessati iti pattheti dhītaram mama kulam vaḍḍhissati iti bhariyam mayham pāde  paricarissati iti aññe pi ñāti mitta bandhave taṃ taṃ kicca vasena iti
translated: One desires a daughter thinking, “My family will be prosperous.” One desires a wife thinking, “She will serve my feet.”🔽One desires other relatives, friends, and kinsmen for the sake of one’s own needs. Thus the world loves another for one’s own sake.

original: sampassanto loko paraṃ piyāyatīti. Ayañhi deviyā adhippāyo.
analyzed: sampassantaḥ loko param piyāyati iti ayam hi deviyā adhippāyaḥ
translated: This is the queen’s intention.

original: Atha rājā cintesi – “ayaṃ mallikā kusalā paṇḍitā nipuṇā ‘attāva me piyataro’ti vadati,
analyzed: atha rājā cintesi ayam mallikā kusalā paṇḍitā nipuṇā me vadati
translated: Then the king thought, “This Mallikā is skilled, wise, and clever. She says, ‘I love myself more than anyone else.’

original: mayhampi attāva piyataro hutvā upaṭṭhāti, handāhaṃ imamatthaṃ satthu ārocessāmi,
analyzed: mayham pi attā ava piyataraḥ hutvā upaṭṭhāti handa aham imam attham satthu ārocessāmi
translated: She serves me, loving me more than herself. Let me tell this matter to the Teacher.

original: yathā ca me satthā byākarissati, tathā naṃ dhāressāmī”ti. Evaṃ pana cintetvā satthu
analyzed: yathā ca me satthā byākarissati tathā nam dhāressāmi iti evam pana cintetvā satthu
translated: I will remember it as the Teacher explains it to me.” Having thought thus, he told the matter to the Teacher.

original: santikaṃ upasaṅkamitvā tamatthaṃ ārocesi. Tena vuttaṃ – “atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo…pe… piyataro”ti.
analyzed: santikam upasaṅkamitvā tam attham ārocesi tena vuttam atha kho rājā pasenadi kosala lope piyataro ti
translated: and he told him the reason for his coming. Hence it was said: “Then King Pasenadi Kosala approached the Blessed One … dearer than self.”

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ “loke sabbasattānaṃ attāva attano piyataro”ti raññā vuttamatthaṃ sabbaso jānitvā tadatthaparidīpanaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam loke sabba sattānam attā ava attanaḥ piyataraḥ iti raññā vuttam attham sabbasas jānitvā tad attha paridīpanam imam udānam udānesi
translated: Having known the meaning of this: having known completely the meaning stated by the king thus, “In the world, in all the living beings, self is dearer than anyone else,” he uttered this utterance explaining that meaning.

original: Tattha sabbā disā anuparigamma cetasāti sabbā anavasesā dasapi disā pariyesanavasena🔽cittena anugantvā. Nevajjhagā piyataramattanā kvacīti attanā atisayena piyaṃ aññaṃ
analyzed: tattha sabbāḥ disāḥ anuparigamma cetasā ati sabbāḥ anavasesāḥ dasa api disā pariyesana vasena  cittena anugantvā piyataram attanā kvaci iti attanā atisayena piyam aññam
translated: Having searched all quarters with his mind: having searched all the ten quarters without exception by way of seeking.🔽Nowhere did he find anyone dearer than self: no one, no matter how much he might search with all his might, would find anyone else dearer than self.

original: koci puriso sabbussāhena pariyesanto kvaci katthaci sabbadisāsu neva adhigaccheyya🔽na passeyya. Evaṃ piyo puthu attā paresanti evaṃ kassaci attanā piyatarassa anupalabbhanavasena
analyzed: koci purisaḥ sabba ussāhena pariyesantaḥ kvaci katthaci sabba disāsu na iva adhigaccheyya  na passeyya evam piyaḥ puthu attā paresanti evam kassaci attanā piyatarassa an upalabbhana vasena
translated: He would not find anyone, he would not see anyone, anywhere, in any of the quarters.🔽Thus self is dear to each one: thus, because of the non-apprehension of anyone else dearer than self, self is dear to each one, to each being, separately, individually.

original: puthu visuṃ visuṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ attāva piyo. Tasmā na hiṃse paramattakāmoti
analyzed: puthu visum visum tesam tesam sattānam attā ava piyo tasmā na hiṃse paramatta kāmo ti
translated: Therefore, one who desires his own welfare should not harm another:

original: yasmā evaṃ sabbopi satto attānaṃ piyāyati attano sukhakāmo dukkhappaṭikūlo, tasmā
analyzed: yasmai evam sabbaḥ api sattaḥ attānam piyāyati attano sukha kāmaḥ dukkha ppaṭikūlaḥ tasmai
translated: Since all beings love themselves, since all beings want to be happy and do not want to suffer,

original: attakāmo attano hitasukhaṃ icchanto paraṃ sattaṃ antamaso kunthakipillikaṃ upādāya🔽na hiṃse na haneyya na pāṇileḍḍudaṇḍādīhipi viheṭheyya. Parassa hi attanā kate dukkhe
analyzed: atta kāmaḥ attanaḥ hita sukham icchantaḥ param sattam antamasaḥ kuntha kipillikam upādāya  na hiṃse na haneyya na viheṭheyya parassa hi attanā kate dukkhe
translated: therefore, one who loves himself, who wants his own welfare and happiness, should not harm or kill another being, not even a tiny gnat,

original: taṃ tato saṅkamantaṃ viya kālantare attani sandissati. Ayañhi kammānaṃ dhammatāti.
analyzed: tam tatas saṅkamantam viya kāla antare attani sandissati ayam hi kammānam dhamma tā ti
translated: not even offend him with hand, clod, stick, or sword. For when another suffers pain inflicted by oneself, it will appear to oneself later on, as if it were transferred from the other. This is the nature of kamma.

original: Paṭhamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭhama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the first sutta is finished.

original: 2. Appāyukasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: appāyuka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on Short Life

original: 42. Dutiye acchariyaṃ, bhanteti idampi meghiyasutte viya garahaṇacchariyavasena veditabbaṃ.🔽Yāva appāyukāti yattakaṃ parittāyukā, atiittarajīvitāti attho. Sattāhajāteti sattāhena
analyzed: dutiye acchariyam bhante ti idam pi meghiya sutte viya garahaṇa chariya vasena veditabbam  appāyukā ati yattakam paritta āyukā ati ittara jīvitā ati satta aha jātā iti satta ahena
translated: In the second sutta, “It is wonderful, venerable sir,” should be understood as in the Meghiya Sutta.

original: jāto sattāhajāto. Tasmiṃ sattāhajāte, jātassa sattame ahanīti attho. Tusitaṃ kāyaṃ
analyzed: jātaḥ satta aha jātaḥ tasmin satta aha jāte jātassa sattame ahani iti attho tusitam kāyam
translated: “Short-lived”: as short-lived as possible; that is, with a very short life. “Seven days old”: born seven days ago. “Seven days old” means born seven days ago. “Seven days after his birth”: seven days after his birth.

original: upapajjīti tusitaṃ devanikāyaṃ paṭisandhiggahaṇavasena upapajji.🔽Ekadivasaṃ kira thero pacchābhattaṃ divāṭṭhāne nisinno lakkhaṇānubyañjanappaṭimaṇḍitaṃ🔽sobhaggappattaṃ dassanānuttariyabhūtaṃ bhagavato rūpakāyasiriṃ manasi karitvā, “aho
analyzed: upapajji iti tusitam devanikāyam paṭisandhi ggahaṇa vasena upapajji  eka divasam kira thero pacchābhattam divāṭṭhāne nisinnaḥ lakkhaṇa anubyañjana paṭimaṇḍitam  sobhagga ppattam dassana anuttariya bhūtam bhagavataḥ rūpa kāya sirim manasi karitvā aho
translated: He was reborn in the Tusita heaven by taking up a new existence there.🔽One day, it seems, the Elder was sitting in the pavilion after his midday meal. He brought to mind the glory of the Blessed One’s physical body, which was adorned with the major and minor characteristics of a Great Man,

original: buddhānaṃ rūpakāyasampatti dassanīyā samantapāsādikā manoharā”ti uḷāraṃ pītisomanassaṃ
analyzed: buddhānam rūpa kāya sampatti dassanīyā samanta pāsādikā manoharā ati uḷāram pīti somanassam
translated: which had reached the perfection of beauty, and which was the most worthy object in the world to be looked upon. He thought: “How beautiful is the Blessed One’s physical body,🔽which is so lovely and so fair to behold!” And he experienced exalted joy and happiness.

original: paṭisaṃvedento evaṃ cintesi – “vijātamātuyā nāma virūpopi putto surūpo viya manāpo
analyzed: paṭisaṃvedentaḥ evam cintesi vijāta mātuyā nāma virūpaḥ api putto surūpaḥ viya manāpaḥ
translated: He thought further: “Even a son of ugly parents is lovely and dear to them,

original: hoti, sace pana buddhānaṃ mātā mahāmāyā devī dhareyya, kīdisaṃ nu kho tassā bhagavato
analyzed: hoti sace pana buddhānam mātā mahāmāyā devī dhareyya kīdisam nu kho tassāḥ bhagavataḥ
translated: but if the Blessed One’s mother, Mahā Māyā, had lived, how much more would she have loved him,

original: rūpadassane pītisomanassaṃ uppajjeyya, mahājāni kho mayhaṃ mahāmātu deviyā, yā sattāhajāte
analyzed: rūpa dassane pīti somanassam uppajjeyya mahājāni kho mayham mahāmātu deviyā yā satta aha jāte
translated: for he was born of her womb! But she died seven days after his birth.”

original: bhagavati kālakatā”ti. Evaṃ pana cintetvā bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā attano parivitakkitaṃ
analyzed: bhagavati kālakatā ati evam pana cintetvā bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā attanaḥ parivitakkitam
translated: Having thus reflected, he went to the Blessed One and told him what he had been thinking about.

original: ārocento tassā kālakiriyaṃ garahanto “acchariyaṃ, bhante”tiādimāha.
analyzed: ārocentaḥ tassā kālakiriyam garahantaḥ acchariyam bhante itiādim āha
translated: and he said “It is wonderful, Lord” and so on, in order to censure her for dying at such a time.

original: Keci panāhu – “mahāpajāpati gotamī bhagavantaṃ mahatā āyāsena pabbajjaṃ yācitvāpi
analyzed: keci pana āhu mahāpajāpati gotamī bhagavantam mahatā āyāsena pabbajjam yācitvā api
translated: But some say that the Gotami, Pajāpatī the Great, asked the Lord for the going forth with great difficulty,

original: paṭikkhittā, mayā pana upāyena yācito bhagavā aṭṭhagarudhammappaṭiggahaṇavasena tassā
analyzed: paṭikkhittā mayā pana upāyena yācitaḥ bhagavā aṭṭhagaru dhamma paṭiggahaṇa vasena tassā
translated: and that although he refused, she went forth by means of the going forth consisting in the acceptance of the eight important principles,

original: pabbajjaṃ upasampadañca anujāni, sā te dhamme paṭiggahetvā laddhapabbajjūpasampadā
analyzed: pabbajjam upasampadam ca anujāni sā te dhamme paṭiggahetvā laddha pabbajja upasampadā
translated: and that after she had accepted those principles and had gone forth and been ordained,

original: bhagavato dutiyaṃ parisaṃ uppādetvā catutthāya parisāya paccayo ahosi. Sace pana🔽bhagavato janetti mahāmāyā devī dhareyya, evametā cubhopi khattiyabhaginiyo ekato
analyzed: bhagavataḥ dutiyam parisam uppādetvā catutthāya parisāya paccayaḥ ahosi sace pana  bhagavataḥ mahāmāyā devī dhareyya evam etā cubho api khattiya bhaginiyo ekatas
translated: she became a condition for the fourth of the assemblies by producing the second of the assemblies.🔽But if the Lord’s mother, Mahāmāyā, had lived, then these two sisters,

original: hutvā imaṃ sāsanaṃ sobheyyuṃ, bhagavā ca mātari bahumānena mātugāmassa sāsane pabbajjaṃ🔽upasampadañca sukheneva anujāneyya, appāyukatāya panassā kasirena nipphannamidanti
analyzed: hutvā imam sāsanam sobheyyum bhagavā ca mātari bahu mānena mātugāmassa sāsane pabbajjam 🔽upasampadam ca sukhena iva anujāneyya appāyuka tāya panassā kasirena nipphannam idanti
translated: both of them of the warrior caste, would have been able to make a single blaze burn, and the Lord would have allowed the going forth and the admission of women into the Order without difficulty out of respect for his mother.🔽But because she died soon after his birth, he did so only after much insistence.

original: iminā adhippāyena thero bhagavato santike ‘acchariyaṃ, bhante’tiādimāhā”ti. Taṃ akāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: iminā adhippāyena theraḥ bhagavato santike acchariyam bhanta iti ādim āha ati tam akāraṇam
translated: It was with this intention that the Elder said to the Exalted One, ‘It is wonderful, venerable sir, it is marvellous, venerable sir.’ ”

original: Bhagavā hi mātuyā vā aññassa vā mātugāmassa attano sāsane pabbajjaṃ anujānanto garukaṃyeva
analyzed: bhagavā hi mātuyā vā aññassa vā mātu gāmassa attanaḥ sāsane pabbajjam anujānantaḥ garukam yā iva
translated: For the Exalted One, when he allows the going forth of a mother or any other woman in his dispensation, does so only after making it weighty,

original: katvā anujānāti, na lahukaṃ ciraṭṭhitikāmatāyāti.
analyzed: katvā anujānāti na lahukam cira ṭṭhiti kāma tāya ati
translated: not after making it light, because he desires that it endure.

original: Apare panāhu – “dasabalacatuvesārajjādike anaññasādhāraṇe anantāparimāṇe buddhaguṇe🔽thero manasi karitvā yā evaṃ mahānubhāvaṃ nāma loke aggapuggalaṃ satthāraṃ kucchinā
analyzed: apare pana āhu dasa bala catu vesārajja ādike anañña sādhāraṇe ananta aparimāṇe buddha guṇe  theraḥ manasi karitvā evam mahā anubhāvam nāma loke agga puggalam satthāram kucchinā
translated: But others say: “The Elder, having brought to mind the Exalted One’s incomparable and immeasurable special qualities of the ten powers, the four confidences, etc.,🔽which are not shared by others, thought: ‘It is not proper that the mother of the Exalted One, who carried in her womb for ten months the Teacher, the most powerful being in the world,

original: dasa māse parihari, sā buddhamātā kassaci paricārikā bhavissatīti ayuttamidaṃ. Kasmā?
analyzed: dasa māse sā buddha mātā kassaci paricārikā bhavissati iti ayuttam idam kasmā
translated: should be the attendant of anyone else.’ Why?

original: Satthu guṇānucchavikamevetaṃ, yadidaṃ sattāhajāte bhagavati janetti kālaṃ karoti,
analyzed: satthu guṇa anucchavikam yat idam satta aha jāte bhagavati kālam karoti
translated: It is proper that she should be in accordance with the qualities of the Teacher, who, seven days after his birth,

original: kālakatā ca tusitesu uppajjatīti acchariyabbhutacittajāto hutvā taṃ attano vitakkuppādanaṃ
analyzed: kālakatā ca tusitesu uppajjati iti acchariya bbhuta citta jātaḥ hutvā tam attanaḥ vitakka uppādanam
translated: was born again to the life of a Buddha, and whose mother died and reappeared in the Tusita heaven. The Elder, having generated this thought,

original: bhagavato ārocento ‘acchariyaṃ, bhante’tiādivacanaṃ avocā”ti.
analyzed: bhagavataḥ ārocentaḥ acchariyam bhante iti ādi vacanam avoca ati
translated: and he said, “It is wonderful, Lord,” and so on.

original: Satthā pana yasmā sattāhajātesu bodhisattesu bodhisattamātu kālakiriyā dhammatā siddhā,
analyzed: satthā pana yasmā satta aha jātesu bodhisattesu bodhisatta mātu kālakiriyā dhamma tā siddhā
translated: But since it is a natural law that the mothers of Bodhisattvas die seven days after giving birth,🔽the Teacher, in order to make this natural law clear, said, “So it is, Ānanda.”

original: tasmā taṃ dhammataṃ paridīpento “evametaṃ, ānandā”tiādimāha. Sā panāyaṃ dhammatā
analyzed: tasmai tam dhamma tam paridīpentaḥ evam etam ānanda ati ādim āha sā pana ayam dhamma tā
translated: This natural law is as follows:

original: yasmā yathā sabbe bodhisattā pāramiyo pūretvā tusitapure nibbattitvā tattha yāvatāyukaṃ
analyzed: yasmai yathā sabbe bodhisattā pāramiyaḥ pūretvā tusitapure nibbattitvā tattha yāvatāyukam
translated: All Bodhisattvas, after fulfilling the Perfections, are reborn in the Tusita heaven, where they live out their lives.

original: ṭhatvā āyupariyosāne dasasahassacakkavāḷadevatāhi sannipatitvā abhisambodhiṃ pattuṃ
analyzed: ṭhatvā āyu pariyosāne dasa sahassa cakkavāḷa devatāhi sannipatitvā abhisambodhim pattum
translated: At the end of their lives, the deities of the ten thousand world systems assemble and invite them to attain Buddhahood.

original: manussaloke paṭisandhiggahaṇāya ajjhesitā kāladīpadesakulāni viya janettiyā āyuparimāṇampi
analyzed: manussa loke paṭisandhi ggahaṇāya ajjhesitā kāla dīpa desa kulāni viya janettiyā āyu parimāṇam pi
translated: They look to see what the length of life will be in the world of men, and what country, city, family, and mother will be suitable for them, and then they take rebirth.

original: oloketvā paṭisandhiṃ gaṇhanti, ayampi bhagavā bodhisattabhūto tatheva tusitapure
analyzed: oloketvā paṭisandhim gaṇhanti ayam pi bhagavā bodhisatta bhūtaḥ tathā iva tusitapure
translated: This Blessed One, when he was a Bodhisatta, lived in the Tusita heaven,

original: ṭhito pañca mahāvilokanāni vilokento sattadivasādhikadasamāsaparimāṇaṃ mātuyā āyuparimāṇaṃ
analyzed: pañca mahā vilokanāni vilokento āyu parimāṇam
translated: and when he looked down upon the five great visions, he saw that the length of life in the world of men was a hundred years, and that the mother who would bear him would live only ten days more.

original: paricchinditvā “ayaṃ mama paṭisandhiggahaṇassa kālo, idāni uppajjituṃ vaṭṭatī”ti
analyzed: paricchinditvā ayam mama paṭisandhi ggahaṇassa kālaḥ idāni uppajjitum vaṭṭati iti
translated: and he decides, “This is the time for me to take rebirth-linking. Now it is proper for me to be reborn.”🔽

original: ñatvāva paṭisandhiṃ aggahesi, tasmā sabbabodhisattānaṃ āciṇṇasamāciṇṇavaseneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ñatvā ava paṭisandhim aggahesi tasmā sabba bodhisattānam āciṇṇa samāciṇṇa vasena iva veditabbam
translated: and having done so, he knew that the time had come for him to take rebirth-linking, and so he took rebirth-linking. Therefore it should be understood that this was done in accordance with the practice of all Bodhisattas.

original: Tenāha bhagavā – “appāyukā hi, ānanda, bodhisattamātaro hontī”tiādi.
analyzed: tena āha bhagavā appāyukāḥ hi ānanda bodhisatta mātaraḥ honti itiādi
translated: Hence the Exalted One said: “Ānanda, the mothers of Bodhisattas have a short life span” .

original: Tattha kālaṃ karontīti yathāvuttaāyuparikkhayeneva kālaṃ karonti, na vijātapaccayā.
analyzed: tattha kālam karonti iti yathā vutta āyu parikkhayena iva kālam karonti na vijāta paccayā
translated: Herein, they die after a short time: they die only after the exhaustion of the life span, not because of giving birth.

original: Carimattabhāvehi bodhisattehi vasitaṭṭhānaṃ cetiyagharasadisaṃ hoti, na aññesaṃ paribhogārahaṃ,
analyzed: carimatta bhāvehi bodhisattehi vasita ṭṭhānam cetiya ghara sadisam hoti na aññesam paribhoga araham
translated: The place where the Bodhisatta dwells in his last existence is like a shrine, not fit to be used by others.

original: na ca sakkā bodhisattamātaraṃ apanetvā aññaṃ aggamahesiṭṭhāne ṭhapetunti tattakaṃ
analyzed: na ca sakkā bodhisatta mātaram apanetvā aññam aggamahesi ṭṭhāne ṭhapetun ti tattakam
translated: And it is not possible to remove the Bodhisatta’s mother and appoint another in her place as chief queen.

original: eva bodhisattamātu āyuppamāṇaṃ hoti, tasmā tadā kālaṃ karonti. Imameva hi atthaṃ
analyzed: eva bodhisatta mātu āyu ppamāṇam hoti tasmai tadā kālam karonti imam eva hi attham
translated: Thus the life span of the Bodhisatta’s mother is limited to that. Therefore they die then. For this very reason

original: sandhāya mahābodhisattā pañcamaṃ mahāvilokanaṃ karonti.
analyzed: sandhāya mahā bodhisattā pañcamam mahā vilokanam karonti
translated: the great Bodhisattas make their fifth great survey.

original: Katarasmiṃ pana vaye kālaṃ karontīti? Majjhimavaye. Paṭhamavayasmiñhi sattānaṃ attabhāve
analyzed: katarasmim pana vaye kālam karonti iti majjhima vaye paṭhama vayasmin hi sattānam atta bhāve
translated: But in what age do they die? In the middle age. For in the first age beings are not subject to death through a formed kamma-resultant.🔽

original: chandarāgo balavā hoti, tena tadā sañjātagabbhā itthiyo yebhuyyena gabbhaṃ anurakkhituṃ🔽na sakkonti. Gaṇheyyuṃ ce, gabbho bahvābādho hoti. Majjhimavayassa pana dve koṭṭhāse
analyzed: chanda rāgaḥ balavā hoti tena tadā sañjāta gabbhā itthiyaḥ yebhuyyena gabbham anurakkhitum  na sakkonti gaṇheyyum ce gabbhaḥ bahu ābādhaḥ hoti majjhimavayassa pana dve koṭṭhāse
translated: In what age did they die? In middle age. For in the first age of life the passion of beings for their own bodies is strong. Therefore women who conceive then are mostly unable to preserve the embryo.

original: atikkamitvā tatiyakoṭṭhāse vatthu visadaṃ hoti, visade vatthumhi nibbattadārakā arogā
analyzed: atikkamitvā tatiya koṭṭhāse vatthu visadam hoti visade vatthumhi nibbatta dārakāḥ arogāḥ
translated: If they do conceive, the embryo is sickly. But in the third quarter of middle age the womb is clear, and children born in a clear womb are healthy.

original: honti, tasmā bodhisattamātaro paṭhamavaye sampattiṃ anubhavitvā majjhimavayassa tatiyakoṭṭhāse🔽vijāyitvā kālaṃ karontīti.🔽Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ bodhisattamātu aññesañca sabbasattānaṃ attabhāve āyussa
analyzed: honti tasmai bodhisatta mātaraḥ paṭhama vaye sampattim anubhavitvā majjhima vayassa tatiya koṭṭhāse  vijāyitvā kālam karonti iti  etam attham viditvā iti etam bodhisatta mātu aññesam ca sabba sattānam attabhāve āyussa
translated: Therefore the mothers of Bodhisattas, having experienced prosperity in the first age, die in the third quarter of middle age, after giving birth.

original: maraṇapariyosānataṃ viditvā tadatthavibhāvanamukhena anavajjappaṭipattiyaṃ ussāhadīpakaṃ
analyzed: maraṇa pariyosānataḥ viditvā tad attha vibhāvana mukhena ussāha dīpakam
translated: Knowing this matter: knowing this matter, namely, that the life of the Bodhisattas’ mothers and of all other beings ends in death.

original: imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: imam udānam udānesi
translated: He breathed forth this solemn utterance: he uttered this solemn utterance, which is a source of inspiration for the practice of the blameless way, in the sense of expounding that meaning.

original: Tattha ye kecīti aniyamaniddeso. Bhūtāti nibbattā. Bhavissantīti anāgate nibbattissanti.
analyzed: tattha ye keci iti aniyama niddesaḥ bhūtā ati nibbattā bhavissanti iti anāgate nibbattissanti
translated: Herein, any means without distinction. Have been means have been generated. Will be means will be generated in the future.

original: Vāsaddo vikappattho, apisaddo sampiṇḍanattho. Tena nibbattamānepi saṅgaṇhāti. Ettāvatā
analyzed: vā saddaḥ vikappa atthaḥ api saddaḥ sampiṇḍana ttho tena nibbattamāne pi saṅgaṇhāti ettāvatā
translated: The word ‘dwelling’ has the meaning of a state of existence, and the word ‘also’ has the meaning of inclusion. So it includes those being generated. So far🔽he has included without exception all beings included in the three divisions of time, that is to say,

original: atītādivasena tiyaddhapariyāpanne satte anavasesato pariyādiyati. Apica gabbhaseyyakasattā
analyzed: atīta ādi vasena satte anavasesataḥ apica gabbhaseyyaka sattā
translated: the past, the future, and the present. Moreover, beings who are born from a womb

original: gabbhato nikkhantakālato paṭṭhāya bhūtā nāma, tato pubbe bhavissanti nāma. Saṃsedajūpapātikā🔽paṭisandhicittato parato bhūtā nāma, tato pubbe uppajjitabbabhavavasena bhavissanti🔽nāma. Sabbepi vā paccuppannabhavavasena bhūtā nāma, āyatiṃ punabbhavavasena bhavissanti
analyzed: gabbhataḥ nikkhanta kālato paṭṭhāya bhūtāḥ nāma tatas pubbe bhavissanti nāma saṃsedaja upapātikā  paṭisandhi cittato paratas bhūtāḥ nāma tatas pubbe uppajjitabba bhava vasena bhavissanti  nāma sabbe pi vā paccuppanna bhava vasena bhūtāḥ nāma āyatim punabbhava vasena bhavissanti
translated: are called ‘have been’ from the time they are born from the womb onwards, and they are called ‘will be’ before that time. Those born by miraculous generation and by heat and moisture🔽are called ‘have been’ after the rebirth-linking consciousness, and they are called ‘will be’ before that time in the sense of the existence that will arise. Or all are called ‘have been’ in the sense of the present existence, and they are called ‘will be’ in the sense of the future existence. Those whose cankers are destroyed are called ‘have been’;

original: nāma. Khīṇāsavā bhūtā nāma. Te hi bhūtā eva, na puna bhavissantīti, tadaññe bhavissanti nāma.
analyzed: nāma khīṇa āsavāḥ bhūtāḥ nāma te hi bhūtāḥ eva na puna bhavissanti iti tad aññe bhavissanti nāma
translated: for they are only ‘have been’ and are not ‘will be’ again. The rest are called ‘will be.’

original: Sabbe gamissanti pahāya dehanti sabbe yathāvuttabhedā sabbabhavayonigativiññāṇaṭṭhitisattāvāsādivasena
analyzed: sabbe gamissanti pahāya dehan ti sabbe yathā vutta bhedā sabba bhava yoni gati viññāṇa ṭṭhiti sattā vāsa ādi vasena
translated: All will go away, leaving their bodies behind.

original: anekabhedabhinnā sattā dehaṃ attano sarīraṃ pahāya nikkhipitvā paralokaṃ gamissanti,
analyzed: aneka bheda bhinnā sattā deham attanaḥ sarīram pahāya nikkhipitvā para lokam gamissanti
translated: All beings, classified in the various ways stated above, will go to the other world, leaving behind their bodies, their physical frames.🔽But the Arahant’s Nibbāna is not subject to death. The Master shows that there is no one here who is not subject to death.🔽Having understood this, the wise one,🔽Having understood this, the wise one, the man of discernment,

analyzed: nissāya jīvati tam pi pubbe kata kamma paccayā na yāvadattham labhati tena vuttam  manussa daliddaḥ ti manussa kapaṇaḥ ti manussesu parama kapaṇa tam pattaḥ manussa varākaḥ iti

original: manussānaṃ hīḷitaparibhūtatāya ativiya dīno. Mahatiyā parisāyāti mahatiyā bhikkhuparisāya

original: ceva upāsakaparisāya ca.
analyzed: upāsaka parisāya ca

original: Ekadivasaṃ kira bhagavā mahābhikkhusaṅghaparivāro rājagahaṃ piṇḍāya pavisitvā bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: eka divasam kira bhagavā mahā bhikkhu saṅgha parivāraḥ rājagaham piṇḍāya pavisitvā bhikkhūnam
translated: One day, it seems, the Lord, surrounded by a great company of monks, entered Rājagaha for alms.

original: sulabhapiṇḍapātaṃ katvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātappaṭikkanto katipayabhikkhuparivāro🔽nikkhanto yehi dānaṃ dinnaṃ, tesaṃ upāsakānaṃ avasesabhikkhūnañca āgamanaṃ āgamayamāno🔽antonagareyeva aññatarasmiṃ ramaṇīye padese aṭṭhāsi. Tāvadeva bhikkhū tato tato āgantvā
analyzed: sulabha piṇḍapātam katvā pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ katipaya bhikkhu parivāro  nikkhantaḥ yehi dānam dinnam tesam upāsakānam avasesa bhikkhūnam ca āgamanam āgamayamānaḥ  antonagareya iva aññatarasmin ramaṇīye padese aṭṭhāsi tāvat eva bhikkhū tatas tatas āgantvā
translated: After the alms round, when he had returned from his alms round, he went out with a number of monks,🔽waiting for the lay devotees who had given him alms to come out, and he stood in a certain delightful place in the town.

original: bhagavantaṃ parivāresuṃ, upāsakāpi “anumodanaṃ sutvā vanditvā nivattissāmā”ti bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: bhagavantam parivāresum upāsakāḥ api anumodanam sutvā vanditvā nivattissāma ati bhagavantam
translated: Then the monks came from here and there and surrounded the Lord. The lay devotees, too, came to the Lord, thinking, “We will listen to the expression of appreciation and then pay homage and return.”🔽There was a great gathering. The Lord gave a sign to sit down.

original: upasaṅkamiṃsu, mahāsannipāto ahosi. Bhagavā nisīdanākāraṃ dassesi. Tāvadeva buddhārahaṃ
analyzed: upasaṅkamiṃsu mahā sannipātaḥ ahosi bhagavā nisīdana ākāram dassesi tāvat eva buddha araham

original: āsanaṃ paññāpesuṃ. Atha bhagavā asītianubyañjanappaṭimaṇḍitehi dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi
analyzed: āsanam paññāpesuṃ atha bhagavā asīti anubyañjana paṭimaṇḍitehi dvattiṃsa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇehi

original: virocamānāya byāmappabhāparikkhepasamujjalāya nīlapītalohitodātamañjeṭṭhapabhassarānaṃ
analyzed: virocamānāya byāma ppabhā parikkhepa samujjalāya
translated: to the one who shines, who is surrounded by the radiance of the sky, who is radiant, who has the bright colours of blue, yellow, red, white, and orange,

original: vasena chabbaṇṇabuddharaṃsiyo vissajjentiyā anupamāya rūpakāyasiriyā sakalameva taṃ
analyzed: vasena chabbaṇṇa buddha raṃsiyaḥ vissajjentiyāḥ anupamāya rūpa kāya siriyā sakalam eva tam
translated: and who, with her incomparable beauty, her radiance of six colours, which she emits by means of her blue, yellow, red, white, crimson, and clear lights, which shine forth from her body, and which is surrounded by a halo extending a fathom,

original: padesaṃ obhāsento tārāgaṇaparivuto viya puṇṇacando bhikkhugaṇaparivuto paññattavarabuddhāsane
analyzed: padesam obhāsento tārā gaṇa parivutaḥ viya puṇṇa candaḥ bhikkhu gaṇa parivutaḥ paññatta vara buddha āsane
translated: illuminates the whole place, like the full moon surrounded by the multitude of stars, sits down on the excellent seat prepared for her, surrounded by the multitude of Bhikkhunis,

original: nisīditvā manosilātale kesarasīho viya sīhanādaṃ nadanto karavīkarutamañjunā brahmassarena dhammaṃ deseti.
analyzed: nisīditvā manosilā tale kesarasīhaḥ sīha nādam nadanto karavīka ruta mañjunā brahmassarena dhammam deseti
translated: and preaches the Dhamma, like a lion on the mountain-top roaring his roar, in a voice sweet as the Karavīka bird’s, in the matchless voice of Brahmā.

original: Bhikkhūpi kho appicchā santuṭṭhā pavivittā asaṃsaṭṭhā āraddhavīriyā pahitattā codakā
analyzed: bhikkhū api kho appicchāḥ santuṭṭhāḥ pavivittāḥ asaṃsaṭṭhāḥ āraddha vīriyāḥ pahita ttā codakā
translated: The Bhikkhunis, too, are few in their desires, contented, secluded, and aloof, strenuous, earnest, and resolute, reproving,
