analyzed: pāpa garahinaḥ vattāraḥ vacana kkhamā sīla sampannā samādhi sampannā paññā sampannā vimutti sampannā
translated: and reproved, and obedient to the rules of training. They are perfect in morality, in concentration, in wisdom, in emancipation,

analyzed: vimutti ñāṇa dassana sampannā megha vaṇṇam paṃsukūla cīvaram pārupitvā su vammitāḥ viya
translated: and in the knowledge and insight of emancipation. They wear the patchwork garment of cast-off rags, well-mended,🔽and

analyzed: gandhahatthinaḥ bhagavantam parivāretvā ohita sotāḥ dhammam suṇanti upāsakāḥ api suddhavattha nivatthā
translated: and the elephants, having their trunks full of scents, stood listening to the Dhamma with their ears erect.🔽The lay devotees, too, dressed in clean clothes,

original: suddhuttarāsaṅgā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ mahādānāni pavattetvā gandhamālādīhi bhagavantaṃ🔽pūjetvā vanditvā bhikkhusaṅghassa nipaccakāraṃ dassetvā bhagavantaṃ bhikkhusaṅghañca
analyzed: suddha uttarāsaṅgā pubbaṇhasamayam mahādānāni pavattetvā gandha mālā ādīhi bhagavantam  pūjetvā vanditvā bhikkhu saṅghassa nipacca kāram dassetvā bhagavantam bhikkhu saṅghañca
translated: having offered great gifts in the morning, worshipped the Blessed One with scents, garlands, etc.,🔽honoured the Community of Bhikkhus, and then,

analyzed: parivāretvā saṃyata hattha pādāḥ ohita sotā sakkaccam dhammam suṇanti tena vuttam
translated: standing around the Blessed One and the Community of Bhikkhus, with their hands and feet well-controlled, and their ears well-controlled, they listened to the Dhamma with attention. Hence it was said above:

original: “tena kho pana samayena bhagavā mahatiyā parisāya parivuto dhammaṃ desento nisinno hotī”ti.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena bhagavā mahatiyā parisāya parivutaḥ dhammaṃ desento nisinno hoti iti
translated: “At that time the Blessed One was seated, teaching the Dhamma, surrounded by a great assembly.”

original: Suppabuddho pana jighacchādubbalyapareto ghāsapariyesanaṃ caramāno antaravīthiṃ otiṇṇo
analyzed: suppabuddhaḥ pana jighacchā dubbalya paretaḥ ghāsa pariyesanam caramānaḥ antara vīthim otiṇṇaḥ
translated: But Suppabuddha, exhausted by hunger and weakness, was wandering about in search of food when he came to the main street

original: dūratova taṃ mahājanasannipātaṃ disvā, “kiṃ nu kho ayaṃ mahājanakāyo sannipatito,
analyzed: dūratas vai tam mahā jana sannipātam disvā kim nu kho ayam mahā jana kāyaḥ sannipatitaḥ
translated: and saw the great crowd from a distance. Thinking, “What can this great crowd of people be doing assembled here?

original: addhā ettha bhojanaṃ dīyati maññe, appeva nāmettha gatena kiñci khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ
analyzed: addhā ettha bhojanam dīyati maññe appa iva nāma ittha gatena kiñci khādanīyam vā bhojanīyam
translated: Surely they must be giving food there, I suppose, so perhaps I can get something to eat or something to drink by going there,”

original: vā laddhuṃ sakkā”ti sañjātābhilāso tattha gantvā addasa bhagavantaṃ pāsādikaṃ dassanīyaṃ
analyzed: vā laddhum sakkā ati sañjāta abhilāso tattha gantvā addasa bhagavantam pāsādikam dassanīyam
translated: and he became eager to go there. When he got there he saw the Blessed One, who was inspiring, lovely,

original: pasādanīyaṃ uttamadamathasamathamanuppattaṃ dantaṃ guttaṃ santindriyaṃ susamāhitaṃ
analyzed: pasādanīyam uttama damatha samatham anuppattam dantam guttam santindriyam su samāhitam
translated: and confident, who had attained the highest self-control and peace, who was tamed, guarded, restrained, and controlled, and who was well concentrated.

original: tāya parisāya parivutaṃ dhammaṃ desentaṃ, disvāna purimajātisambhatāya paripakkāya
analyzed: tāya parisāya parivutam dhammam desentam disvāna purima jāti sambhatāya paripakkāya
translated: He was teaching the Dhamma surrounded by an assembly. When he saw this, he was urged by the ripeness of his basic wholesome actions accumulated in his previous births,

original: upanissayasampattiyā codiyamāno “yaṃnūnāhampi dhammaṃ suṇeyya”nti parisapariyante🔽nisīdi. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “addasā kho suppabuddho kuṭṭhī…pe… tattheva ekamantaṃ
analyzed: upanissaya sampattiyā codiyamānaḥ yat nūna aham pi dhammam suṇeyyanti parisapariyante  nisīdi tam sandhāya vuttam addasā kho suppabuddhaḥ kuṭṭhīpe tattha iva ekamantam
translated: and by the fulfilment of his spiritual potential. He thought, “Why shouldn’t I listen to the Dhamma?” He sat down at the edge of the assembly.

original: nisīdi ‘ahampi dhammaṃ sossāmī”’ti.
analyzed: nisīdi aham pi dhammaṃ sossāmi iti
translated: This is the meaning of the words, “Suppabuddha the leper saw the Buddha … and sat down at a respectful distance, thinking, ‘I too will listen to the Dhamma.’”

original: Sabbāvantanti sabbāvatiṃ hīnādisabbapuggalavataṃ, tattha kiñcipi anavasesetvāti attho.
analyzed: sabbāvantam ti sabbāvatim hīna ādi sabba puggalavatam tattha attho
translated: All: all the conduct of all the people, high and low, without exception.

original: “Sabbavanta”ntipi paṭhanti. Cetasāti buddhacakkhusampayuttacittena. Cittasīsena hi
analyzed: sabbavantam ti pi paṭhanti cetasā ti buddha cakkhu sampayutta cittena citta sīsena hi
translated: “Sabbavanta” is also read. With his mind: with the mind associated with the Buddha eye.

original: ñāṇaṃ niddiṭṭhaṃ, tasmā āsayānusayañāṇena indriyaparopariyattañāṇena cāti attho.
analyzed: ñāṇam niddiṭṭham tasmai āsaya anusaya ñāṇena indriya para upari yatta ñāṇena ca ati attho
translated: “Knowledge of the underlying tendency” is stated; thus, the meaning is “knowledge of the underlying tendency and knowledge of the higher and lower faculties.”

original: Ceto paricca manasākāsīti tassā parisāya cittaṃ paccekaṃ paricchinditvā manasi akāsi
analyzed: cetaḥ paricca manasā akāsi iti tassā parisāya cittam paccekam paricchinditvā manasi akāsi
translated: “He directed his mind to the assembly and surveyed it”: he discerned the minds of the individuals in the assembly and surveyed them.

original: te volokesi. Bhabbo dhammaṃ viññātunti maggaphaladhammaṃ adhigantuṃ samattho, upanissayasampannoti
analyzed: te volokesi bhabbaḥ dhammam viññātun ti magga phala dhammam adhigantum samatthaḥ upanissaya sampanno ti
translated: “He is capable of understanding the Dhamma”: he is capable of attaining the Dhamma of the path and the fruit; he is endowed with the requisite conditions, is the meaning.

original: attho. Etadahosīti ayaṃ suppabuddho kiñcāpi tagarasikhimhi paccekabuddhe aparajjhitvā
analyzed: attho etat ahosi iti ayam suppabuddhaḥ kiñca api tagarasikhimhi paccekabuddhe aparajjhitvā
translated: “This thought occurred to him”: although this Suppabuddha was born after having offended a paccekabuddha,

original: īdiso jāto, maggaphalūpanissayo panassa paṃsupaṭicchannasuvaṇṇanikkhaṃ viya antohadayeyeva
analyzed: īdisaḥ jātaḥ magga phala upanissayaḥ panassa paṃsu paṭicchanna suvaṇṇa nikkham viya
translated: nevertheless the requisite condition for the path and the fruit is shining within him like a gold nugget covered with dirt.

original: vijjotati, tasmā suviññāpiyoti idaṃ ahosi. Tenāha – “ayaṃ kho idha bhabbo dhammaṃ viññātu”nti.
analyzed: vijjotati tasmai su viññāpiyaḥ ti idam ahosi tena āha ayam kho idha bhabbaḥ dhammam viññātunti
translated: Therefore this thought occurred to him: “He is capable of understanding the Dhamma very well.”

original: Anupubbiṃ kathanti dānānantaraṃ sīlaṃ, sīlānantaraṃ saggaṃ, saggānantaraṃ magganti
analyzed: anupubbim kathanti dāna anantaram sīlam sīla anantaram saggam sagga anantaram magganti
translated: “A gradual talk”: after generosity, virtue; after virtue, heaven; after heaven, the path.

original: evaṃ anupaṭipāṭikathaṃ. Bhagavā hi paṭhamaṃ hetunā saddhiṃ assādaṃ dassetvā tato
analyzed: evam anupaṭipāṭi katham bhagavā hi paṭhamam hetunā saddhim assādam dassetvā tatas
translated: This is the way of exposition not in regular sequence.

original: satte vivecetuṃ nānānayehi ādīnavaṃ pakāsetvā ādīnavasavanena saṃviggahadayānaṃ nekkhammaguṇavibhāvanamukhena🔽ca vivaṭṭaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: satte vivecetum nānā nayehi ādīnavam pakāsetvā ādīnava savanena saṃvij gaha dayānam nekkhamma guṇa vibhāvana mukhena  ca vivaṭṭam dasseti
translated: For the Blessed One first shows the gratification in the way beginning, “When a noble disciple acts thus with body, speech, and mind after taking the wealth and storing it up, he experiences three kinds of bodily pleasant feelings here and now” ,🔽and then he shows the danger in the way beginning, “Again, bhikkhus, a noble disciple considers thus: ‘Suppose an enemy cherishes evil thoughts towards me …’ ” , and he shows the escape in the way beginning, “Avoiding both the one and the other, the middle course … is discerned by the Tathāgata … for the fading away of lust” .

original: Dānakathanti idaṃ nāma sukhānaṃ nidānaṃ, sampattīnaṃ mūlaṃ, bhogānaṃ patiṭṭhā, visamagatassa🔽tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ gati parāyaṇaṃ, idhalokaparalokesu dānasadiso avassayo patiṭṭhā ālambanaṃ
analyzed: dāna kathanti idam nāma sukhānam nidānam sampattīnam mūlam bhogānam patiṭṭhā visama gatassa  tāṇam leṇam gati parāyaṇam idha loka para lokesu dāna sadisaḥ avassayaḥ patiṭṭhā ālambanam
translated: “Talk on giving”: this is the source of happiness, the root of success, the foundation of wealth, the protection of the unprotected, the refuge, the support, the final goal of those who seek a refuge, the final goal of those who seek a support.

original: tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ gati parāyaṇaṃ natthi. Idañhi avassayaṭṭhena ratanamayasīhāsanasadisaṃ,🔽patiṭṭhānaṭṭhena mahāpathavisadisaṃ, ālambanaṭṭhena ālambanarajjusadisaṃ, dukkhanittharaṇaṭṭhena
analyzed: tāṇam leṇam gati parāyaṇam natthi idam hi avassaya ṭṭhena ratana maya sīhāsana sadisam  patiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena mahā pathavi sadisam ālambana ṭṭhena ālambana rajju sadisam dukkha nittharaṇa ṭṭhena
translated: There is no other such support, no other such refuge, no other such protection, no other such final goal in this world and the world beyond like giving.🔽For this is like a jeweled throne for those who seek a support;🔽like a great highway for those who seek a foundation; like a rope for those who seek a handhold;

original: nāvāsadisaṃ, samassāsanaṭṭhena saṅgāmasūro, bhayaparittāṇaṭṭhena suparikhāparikkhittanagaraṃ,
analyzed: nāvā sadisam samassa āsana ṭhena saṅgāma sūraḥ bhaya parittāṇa ṭhena su parikhā parikkhitta nagaram
translated: like a boat for those who seek to cross over; like a hero in battle for those who seek protection; like a well-fortified city for those who seek a refuge;

original: maccheramalādīhi anupalittaṭṭhena padumaṃ, tesaṃ nidahanaṭṭhena jātavedo, durāsadaṭṭhena
analyzed: macchera mala ādīhi an upalitta ṭṭhena padumam tesam nidahana ṭṭhena jātavedaḥ durāsada ṭṭhena
translated: It is a lotus in the sense of being unsoiled by the stains of avarice, etc.; it is a sacrificial fire in the sense of burning those ;

original: āsīviso, asantāsaṭṭhena sīho, balavantaṭṭhena hatthī, abhimaṅgalasammataṭṭhena setausabho,
analyzed: āsīvisaḥ asantāsa ṭhena sīhaḥ balavanta ṭṭhena hatthī abhimaṅgala sammata ṭṭhena setausabhaḥ
translated: it is a poisonous snake in the sense of being hard to approach; it is a lion in the sense of being fearless; it is an elephant in the sense of being powerful; it is a bull in the sense of being the most auspicious of animals;

original: khemantabhūmisampāpanaṭṭhena valāhako assarājā. Dānañhi loke rajjasiriṃ deti, cakkavattisampattiṃ
analyzed: khemanta bhūmi sampāpana ṭṭhena valāhakaḥ assa rājā dānam hi loke rajja sirim deti cakkavatti sampattim
translated: it is a rain-cloud in the sense of bringing about the state of security. For generosity gives in the world the glory of kingship, the excellence of a universal monarch,

original: sakkasampattiṃ mārasampattiṃ brahmasampattiṃ sāvakapāramīñāṇaṃ paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ
analyzed: sakka sampattim māra sampattim brahma sampattim sāvaka pāramī ñāṇam pacceka bodhi ñāṇam
translated: the excellence of Sakka, the excellence of Mara, the excellence of Brahma, the knowledge of the perfection of discipleship, the knowledge of the enlightenment of a paccekabuddha,

original: sammāsambodhiñāṇaṃ detīti evamādidānaguṇappaṭisaṃyuttakathaṃ.
analyzed: sammāsambodhi ñāṇam deti iti evamādi dāna guṇa paṭisaṃyutta katham
translated: and the knowledge of the supreme enlightenment. Such is the talk about generosity.

original: Yasmā pana dānaṃ dento sīlaṃ samādātuṃ sakkoti, tasmā dānakathānantaraṃ sīlakathaṃ🔽kathesi. Sīlakathanti sīlaṃ nāmetaṃ sattānaṃ avassayo patiṭṭhā ālambanaṃ tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ
analyzed: yasmai pana dānam dento sīlam samādātum sakkoti tasmai dāna kathā anantaram sīla katham  kathesi sīlakathanti sīlam nāma etam sattānam avassayaḥ patiṭṭhā ālambanam tāṇam leṇam
translated: But since one who gives can also undertake virtue, therefore, after the talk about generosity,🔽the Exalted One gave a talk about virtue. The talk about virtue is virtue, which is a support, a refuge, a protection, a resort,🔽a final relief, a final resort for beings. For virtue is a support, a refuge, a protection, a resort,

original: gati parāyaṇaṃ. Idhalokaparalokasampattīnañhi sīlasadiso avassayo patiṭṭhā ālambanaṃ
analyzed: gati parāyaṇam idhaloka paraloka sampattīnam hi sīla sadisaḥ avassayaḥ patiṭṭhā ālambanam
translated: a final relief, a final resort for beings in this world and the next.

original: tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ gati parāyaṇaṃ natthi, sīlālaṅkārasadiso alaṅkāro, sīlapupphasadisaṃ🔽pupphaṃ, sīlagandhasadiso gandho natthi, sīlālaṅkārena hi alaṅkataṃ sīlakusumapiḷandhitaṃ
analyzed: tāṇam leṇam gati parāyaṇam natthi sīla alaṅkāra sadisaḥ alaṅkāraḥ sīla puppha sadisam  puppham sīla gandha sadisaḥ gandhaḥ na atthi sīla alaṅkārena hi alaṅkatam sīla kusuma piḷandhitam
translated: There is no protection, no shelter, no refuge, no resort,🔽There is no ornament like the ornament of virtue, there is no flower🔽like the flower of virtue, there is no scent like the scent of virtue, for one🔽adorned with the ornament of virtue, sprinkled with the flower of virtue,

original: sīlagandhānulittaṃ sadevako loko olokento tittiṃ na gacchatīti evamādīhi sīlaguṇappaṭisaṃyuttakathaṃ.
analyzed: sīla gandha anulittam sa devakaḥ lokaḥ olokento tittim na gacchati iti evamādīhi sīla guṇa paṭisaṃyutta katham
translated: There is no ornament like the ornament of virtue, no garland like the garland of virtue, no perfume like the perfume of virtue, no adornment like the adornment of virtue. For the world with its gods looks on with delight at one who is adorned with the ornament of virtue, who is perfumed with the perfume of virtue, who is garlanded with the garland of virtue.🔽Thus he spoke in praise of virtue.

original: Idaṃ pana sīlaṃ nissāya ayaṃ saggo labbhatīti dassetuṃ sīlānantaraṃ saggakathaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: idam pana sīlam nissāya ayam saggo labbhati iti dassetum sīla anantaram sagga katham kathesi
translated: Next, in order to show that heaven is obtained by means of virtue, he spoke in praise of heaven.

original: Saggakathanti saggo nāma iṭṭho kanto manāpo, niccamettha kīḷā niccasampattiyo labbhanti,
analyzed: sagga kathanti saggaḥ nāma iṭṭhaḥ kantaḥ manāpaḥ niccam ettha kīḷāḥ nicca sampattiyaḥ labbhanti
translated: Heaven is desirable, lovely, pleasing, delightful. Here one always plays and enjoys oneself, and one obtains the highest success.

original: cātumahārājikā devā navutivassasatasahassāni dibbasukhaṃ dibbasampattiṃ paṭilabhanti,
analyzed: cātumahārājikāḥ devāḥ navuti vassa sata sahassāni dibba sukham dibba sampattim paṭilabhanti
translated: The gods of the Realm of the Four Great Kings obtain divine happiness and divine success for ninety thousand years.

original: tāvatiṃsā tisso vassakoṭiyo saṭṭhi ca vassasatasahassānīti evamādisaggaguṇappaṭisaṃyuttakathaṃ.
analyzed: tāvatiṃsā tissaḥ vassa koṭiyaḥ saṭṭhi ca vassa sata sahassāni iti evamādi sagga guṇa paṭisaṃyutta katham
translated: The gods of the Thirty-three obtain it for three hundred and sixty thousand years. Thus he spoke in praise of the qualities of heaven.

original: Saggasampattiṃ kathentānañhi buddhānaṃ mukhaṃ nappahoti. Vuttampi cetaṃ “anekapariyāyena
analyzed: sagga sampattim kathentānam hi buddhānam mukham na ppahoti vuttam pi ca itam aneka pariyāyena
translated: For the Buddhas’ faces do not suffice to tell the glory of the heavenly world. And this is said:🔽

original: kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, saggakathaṃ katheyya”ntiādi.🔽Evaṃ hetunā saddhiṃ saggakathāya palobhetvā puna hatthiṃ alaṅkaritvā tassa soṇḍaṃ
analyzed: kho aham bhikkhave sagga katham katheyya tiādi  evam hetunā saddhim sagga kathāya palobhetvā puna hatthim alaṅkaritvā tassa soṇḍam
translated: For the Buddhas’ faces do not break into a smile when they are telling about the excellence of the heavenly worlds. And this is said: “Monks, I could tell you about the heavenly worlds in such a way that anyone who heard would urinate hot blood” .

original: chindanto viya “ayampi saggo anicco adhuvo, na ettha chandarāgo kātabbo”ti dassanatthaṃ🔽“appassādā kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo”tiādinā nayena kāmānaṃ
analyzed: chindantaḥ viya ayam pi saggaḥ aniccaḥ adhuvaḥ na ettha chanda rāgo kātabbaḥ iti dassana ttham  appassādāḥ kāmāḥ bahu dukkhāḥ bahu pāyāsāḥ ādīnavaḥ ettha bhiyyaḥ ti ādinā nayena kāmānam
translated: Having thus tempted him with a talk on the heavenly worlds together with a reason, the Exalted One, as if to cut off the trunk of the elephant of his mind, said, “This heaven also is impermanent, unstable,” in order to show that desire and passion should not be indulged in there.

original: ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṃkilesaṃ kathesi. Tattha ādīnavanti dosaṃ. Okāranti lāmakasabhāvaṃ,🔽aseṭṭhehi sevitabbaṃ seṭṭhehi na sevitabbaṃ nihīnasabhāvanti attho. Saṃkilesanti
analyzed: ādīnavam okāram saṃkilesam kathesi tattha ādīnavanti dosam okāranti lāmaka sabhāvam  aseṭṭhehi sevitabbam seṭṭhehi na sevitabbam nihīna sabhāvanti attho saṃkilesanti
translated: Then, in order to show the danger, disadvantage, and corruption of sensual pleasures, he said, “Sensual pleasures are of little satisfaction and much suffering, much affliction and much corruption,” and so on. Herein, danger means disadvantage.

original: tehi sattānaṃ saṃsāre saṃkilissanaṃ. Tenāha – “kilissanti vata bho sattā”ti.
analyzed: tehi sattānam saṃsāre saṃkilissanam tena āha kilissanti vata bho sattā iti
translated: Corruption means the defilement of beings in the round of rebirths by means of those . Thus he said: “Defiled, indeed, are beings” .

original: Evaṃ kāmādīnavena tajjetvā nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi pabbajjāya jhānādīsu ca guṇaṃ
analyzed: evam kāma ādīnavena tajjetvā nekkhamme ānisaṃsam pakāsesi pabbajjāya jhāna ādīsu ca guṇam
translated: Having thus rebuked him with the nine terms beginning with “sensual-desire,” he then showed him the benefits of renunciation and the virtues of the jhānas, etc.,🔽and he praised and extolled them.

original: dīpesi vaṇṇesi. Kallacittantiādīsu kallacittanti kammaniyacittaṃ, heṭṭhā pavattitadesanāya
analyzed: dīpesi vaṇṇesi kalla cittanti ādīsu kalla cittanti kammaniya cittam heṭṭhā pavattita desanāya
translated: In the passage beginning with “When the Blessed One knew that his mind was ready,” “ready” means that his mind was fit for work,

original: assaddhiyādīnaṃ cittadosānaṃ vigatattā uparidesanāya bhājanabhāvūpagamanena kammaniyacittaṃ,🔽kammakkhamacittanti attho. Diṭṭhimānādisaṃkilesavigamena muducittaṃ. Kāmacchandādivigamena
analyzed: assaddhi ādīnam citta dosānam vigata ttā upari desanāya bhājana bhāva upagamanena kammaniya cittam  kamma khama cittanti atthaḥ diṭṭhi māna ādi saṃkilesa vigamena mudu cittam kāmacchanda ādi vigamena
translated: because he had got rid of the mental defilements of lack of faith, etc., which had previously arisen, and because he had become a fit vessel for the higher Dhamma by listening to the teaching on giving, etc.🔽The meaning is: his mind was fit for work. “Gentle” means that his mind was soft, because he had got rid of the defilements of wrong views, conceit, etc.🔽“Free from hindrances” means that his mind was free from sensual desire, etc.🔽“Elevated” means that his mind was uplifted by the joy and gladness of right practice.

original: vinīvaraṇacittaṃ. Sammāpaṭipattiyaṃ uḷārapītipāmojjayogena udaggacittaṃ. Tattha saddhāsampattiyā
analyzed: vinīvaraṇa cittam sammā paṭipattiyam uḷāra pīti pāmojja yogena udagga cittam tattha saddhā sampattiyā
translated: Herein, his mind was “confident” through the perfection of faith.

original: pasannacittaṃ, yadā bhagavā aññāsīti sambandho.
analyzed: pasanna cittam yadā bhagavā aññāsi iti sambandho
translated: The connection is this: when the Blessed One knew that his mind was ready, confident, gentle, free from hindrances, and elevated, then he knew that it was the right time to teach him the Dhamma.🔽Or alternatively, “ready” means that his mind was healthy, because it was free from sensual desire.

original: Atha vā kallacittanti kāmacchandavigamena arogacittaṃ. Muducittanti byāpādavigamena
analyzed: atha vā kalla cittanti kāmacchanda vigamena aroga cittam mudu cittanti byāpāda vigamena
translated: “Gentle” means that his mind was not hardened by ill will,

original: mettāvasena akathinacittaṃ. Vinīvaraṇacittanti uddhaccakukkuccavigamena avikkhipanato
analyzed: mettā vasena akathina cittam vinīvaraṇa cittam ti uddhacca kukkucca vigamena a vikkhipanato
translated: but was full of loving kindness. “Free from hindrances” means that his mind was not distracted by agitation and worry,

original: na pihitacittaṃ. Udaggacittanti thinamiddhavigamena sampaggahavasena alīnacittaṃ.
analyzed: na pihita cittam udagga cittam ti thinam iddha vigamena sampaggaha vasena alīna cittam
translated: Not with a closed mind. With a mind uplifted: with a mind that is not sluggish, because of the removal of stiffness and torpor.

original: Pasannacittanti vicikicchāvigamena sammāpaṭipattiyā adhimuttacittaṃ.
analyzed: pasanna cittam ti vicikicchā vigamena sammā paṭipattiyā adhimutta cittam
translated: With a mind confident: with a mind that is resolved upon right practice, because of the removal of doubt.

original: Athāti pacchā. Sāmukkaṃsikāti sāmaṃ ukkaṃsikā attanāva uddharitvā gahitā, sayambhūñāṇena
analyzed: atha ati pacchā sāmukkaṃsikā iti sāmam ukkaṃsikā uddharitvā gahitā sayambhū ñāṇena
translated: After: later. He had himself lifted out: he had himself taken out, by himself, by his own knowledge.

original: sāmaṃ diṭṭhā, aññesaṃ asādhāraṇāti attho. Kā ca pana sāti? Ariyasaccadesanā. Tenevāha
analyzed: sāmam diṭṭhā aññesam asādhāraṇā ti attho kā ca pana sā ati ariya sacca desanā tena iva āha
translated: The meaning is: he had himself seen, not shared by others. And what is that? The teaching of the noble truths. Therefore it is said:

original: – “dukkhaṃ samudayaṃ nirodhaṃ magga”nti. Idañhi saccānaṃ sarūpadassanaṃ, tasmā imasmiṃ
analyzed: dukkham samudayam nirodham magganti idam hi saccānam sarūpa dassanam tasmai imasmin
translated: “Suffering, origination, cessation, path.” For this is the seeing of the truths as they really are. Therefore

original: ṭhāne ariyasaccāni kathetabbāni, tāni sabbākārato vitthārena visuddhimagge vuttānīti
analyzed: ṭhāne ariya saccāni kathetabbāni tāni sabba ākārataḥ vitthārena visuddhi magge vuttāni iti
translated: in this place the noble truths should be spoken of. They are given in detail in the Visuddhimagga in all their aspects.

original: tattha vuttanayena veditabbāni.
analyzed: tattha vutta nayena veditabbāni
translated: So they should be understood in the way stated there.

original: Seyyathāpītiādinā upamāvasena suppabuddhassa kilesappahānaṃ ariyamagguppādañca dasseti.
analyzed: seyyathā api iti ādinā upamā vasena suppabuddhassa kilesa ppahānam ariya magga uppādam ca dasseti
translated: By the simile beginning “Just as if a man were to draw out a reed” he shows the complete abandoning of defilements and the arising of the noble path.

original: Apagatakāḷakanti vigatakāḷakaṃ. Sammadevāti suṭṭhuyeva. Rajananti nīlapītalohitamañjeṭṭhādiraṅgajātaṃ.
analyzed: apagata kāḷakam ti vigata kāḷakam sammad eva ati suṭṭhuyeva rajananti nīla pīta lohita mañjeṭṭha ādiḥ aṅga jātam
translated: “Free from the black” means free from the dark. “The light” means the light of the sun and moon. “The colors” means the colors blue, yellow, red, and so on.

original: Paṭiggaṇheyyāti gaṇheyya, pabhassaraṃ bhaveyya. Tasmiṃyeva āsaneti tassaṃyeva nisajjāyaṃ.
analyzed: paṭiggaṇheyya ati gaṇheyya pabhassaram bhaveyya tasmin yā iva āsane iti tassam yā iva nisajja ayam
translated: “Would accept” means would take up. “Would become radiant” means would become bright. “In that very seat” means in that very sitting.

original: Etenassa lahuvipassanakatā tikkhapaññatā sukhāpaṭipadā khippābhiññatā ca dassitā
analyzed: etena assa lahu vipassanaka tā tikkha pañña tā sukhā paṭipadā khippa abhiñña tā ca dassitā
translated: By this he shows his swiftness in insight, his keenness of wisdom, his ease in practice, and his quickness in direct knowledge.

original: honti. Virajaṃ vītamalanti apāyagamanīyarāgarajādīnaṃ abhāvena virajaṃ, anavasesadiṭṭhivicikicchāmalāpagamena
analyzed: honti virajam apāya gamanīya rāga raja ādīnam abhāvena virajam anavasesa diṭṭhi vicikicchā mala apagamena
translated: “Free from dust and stainless” means free from dust because of the absence of the dust of lust, etc., which lead to the states of loss, and stainless because of the absence of the stains of views and doubts without remainder.

original: vītamalaṃ. Paṭhamamaggavajjhakilesarajābhāvena vā virajaṃ, pañcavidhadussīlamalāpagamena
analyzed: vīta malam paṭhama magga vajjha kilesa raja abhāvena vā virajam pañcavidha dussīla mala apagamena
translated: Or alternatively, it is free from dust because of the absence of the dust of the defilements abandoned by the first path, and stainless because of the absence of the stains of the five kinds of moral shamelessness and moral recklessness.

original: vītamalaṃ. Dhammacakkhunti sotāpattimaggo adhippeto. Tassa uppattiākāradassanatthaṃ
analyzed: vīta malam dhamma cakkhunti sotāpatti maggo adhippeto tassa uppatti ākāra dassana ttham
translated: “The Dhamma eye” is the stream-entry path. In order to show the mode of its arising,

original: “yaṃkiñci samudayadhammaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ nirodhadhamma”nti vuttaṃ. Tañhi nirodhaṃ ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: yaṃ kiñci samudaya dhammam sabbam tat nirodha dhamman ti vuttam tat hi nirodham ārammaṇam
translated: “Whatever is of a nature to arise, all that is of a nature to stop” is said. For that cessation is the object of the path.

original: katvā kiccavasena eva saṅkhatadhamme paṭivijjhantaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: katvā kicca vasena eva saṅkhata dhamme paṭivijjhantam uppajjati
translated: It arises in one who penetrates formed things by way of their function.

original: Tatridaṃ upamāsaṃsandanaṃ – vatthaṃ viya cittaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, vatthassa āgantukamalehi
analyzed: tatra idam upamā saṃsandanam vattham viya cittam daṭṭhabbam vatthassa āgantu kamalehi
translated: Here is the correlation of the simile: the mind is like the cloth;

original: kiliṭṭhabhāvo viya cittassa rāgādimalehi saṃkiliṭṭhabhāvo, dhovanaphalakaṃ viya anupubbikathā,🔽udakaṃ viya saddhā, udakena temetvā temetvā gomayakhārehi kāḷake sammadditvā vatthassa
analyzed: kiliṭṭha bhāvaḥ viya cittassa rāga ādi malehi saṃkiliṭṭha bhāvaḥ dhovana phalakam viya anupubbi kathā  udakam viya saddhā udakena temetvā temetvā gomaya khārehi kāḷake sammadditvā vatthassa
translated: the mind’s being soiled by the stains of lust, etc., is like the cloth’s being soiled by the stains of clay, etc.;🔽the successive talk is like the washing board;

original: dhovanappayogo viya saddhāsalilena temetvā satisamādhipaññāhi dose sithile katvā
analyzed: dhovana ppayogaḥ viya saddhā salilena temetvā sati samādhi paññāhi dose sithile katvā
translated: the faith is like the water; the kneading and rubbing of the clay lump, etc., is like the mind’s being kneaded and rubbed with the water of faith, etc.;

original: saddhādividhinā cittassa sodhane vīriyārambho, tena payogena vatthe kāḷakāpagamo🔽viya vīriyārambhena kilesavikkhambhanaṃ, raṅgajātaṃ viya ariyamaggo, tena suddhassa
analyzed: saddhā ādi vidhinā cittassa sodhane vīriya ārambho tena payogena vatthe kāḷaka apagamo  viya vīriya ārambhena kilesa vikkhambhanam raṅga jātam viya ariya maggo tena suddhassa
translated: the effort to cleanse the mind by means of faith, etc., is like the effort to wash the cloth by means of the clay lump, etc.;🔽the suppression of the defilements by means of the effort is like the removal of the clay stains by means of that effort;

original: vatthassa pabhassarabhāvo viya vikkhambhitakilesassa cittassa maggena pariyodāpananti.
analyzed: vatthassa pabhassara bhāvaḥ viya vikkhambhita kilesassa cittassa maggena pariyodāpananti
translated: the path is like the dye; the purification of the mind by the path whose defilements have been suppressed is like the cloth’s being made bright by that dye.

original: Evaṃ pana suppabuddho parisapariyante nisinno dhammadesanaṃ sutvā sotāpattiphalaṃ
analyzed: evam pana suppabuddhaḥ parisa pariyante nisinnaḥ dhamma desanam sutvā sotāpatti phalam
translated: But Suppabuddha, sitting in the outer circle of the assembly, heard the discourse on the Law, and attained the fruit of entering the stream.

original: patvā attanā paṭiladdhaguṇaṃ satthu ārocetukāmo parisamajjhaṃ ogāhituṃ avisahanto
analyzed: patvā attanā paṭiladdha guṇam satthu ārocetu kāmo parisamajjham ogāhitum a visahantaḥ
translated: Then he desired to make known to the Teacher the quality he had attained, but being unable to force his way through the crowd,

original: mahājanassa satthāraṃ vanditvā anugantvā nivattakāle bhagavati vihāraṃ gate sayampi🔽vihāraṃ agamāsi. Tasmiṃ khaṇe sakko devarājā “ayaṃ suppabuddho kuṭṭhī attanā satthu
analyzed: mahā janassa satthāram vanditvā anugantvā nivatta kāle bhagavati vihāram gate sayam pi  vihāram agamāsi tasmin khaṇe sakkaḥ devarājā ayam su pabuddhaḥ kuṭṭhī attanā satthu
translated: he followed the Teacher until he had gone a little way, and then returned to his own house.

original: sāsane paṭiladdhaguṇaṃ pākaṭaṃ kātukāmo”ti ñatvā “vīmaṃsissāmi na”nti gantvā ākāse🔽ṭhito etadavoca – “suppabuddha tvaṃ manussadaliddo manussakapaṇo manussavarāko, ahaṃ
analyzed: sāsane paṭiladdha guṇam pākaṭam kātu kāmaḥ iti ñatvā vīmaṃsissāmi nanti gantvā ākāse  ṭhitaḥ etat avoca suppabuddha tvam manussa daliddaḥ manussa kapaṇaḥ manussa varākaḥ aham
translated: At that moment Sakka, King of the gods, thought to himself, “This leper Suppabuddha desires to make known the quality he has attained in the Dispensation of the Teacher.” So he went there, and standing in the air,

original: te aparimitaṃ dhanaṃ dassāmi, ‘buddho na buddho, dhammo na dhammo, saṅgho na saṅgho,
analyzed: te aparimitam dhanam dassāmi buddhaḥ na buddhaḥ dhammaḥ na dhammaḥ saṅghaḥ na saṅghaḥ
translated: said to him, “Suppabuddha, you are poor, you are a pauper, you are a beggar. I will give you unlimited wealth. Say, ‘The Buddha is not the Buddha, the Law is not the Law, the Order is not the Order.

original: alaṃ me buddhena, alaṃ me dhammena, alaṃ me saṅghenā’ti vadehī”ti. Atha naṃ so āha
analyzed: alam me buddhena alam me dhammena alam me saṅghena ati vadehi iti atha nam saḥ āha
translated: I have no more to do with the Buddha, I have no more to do with the Law, I have no more to do with the Order.’ ”🔽But he replied,

original: “kosi tva”nti? “Ahaṃ sakko devarājā”ti. “Andhabāla ahirika, tvaṃ mayā saddhiṃ kathetuṃ
analyzed: kaḥ asi tvanti aham sakkaḥ devarājā ati andha bāla ahirika tvam mayā saddhim kathetum
translated: “Who are you?” “I am Sakka, king of the gods.” “Blind fool, shameless one, you are not fit to talk with me.

original: na yuttarūpo, yo tvaṃ evaṃ avattabbaṃ vadesi, apica maṃ tvaṃ ‘duggato daliddo kapaṇo’ti
analyzed: na yutta rūpaḥ yaḥ tvam evam a vattabbam vadesi apica mamam tvam duggataḥ daliddaḥ kapaṇaḥ ti
translated: You say what should not be said. Moreover, why do you call me ‘poor, wretched, destitute’?

original: kasmā vadesi, nanu ahaṃ lokanāthassa orasaputto, nevāhaṃ duggato na daliddo na kapaṇo,
analyzed: kasmai vadesi nanu aham lokanāthassa orasa putto na iva aham duggataḥ na daliddaḥ na kapaṇaḥ
translated: Am I not the son of the Lord of the World? I am not poor, wretched, or destitute.

original: atha kho sukhappatto paramena sukhena apāhamasmi mahaddhano”ti vatvā āha –
analyzed: atha kho sukhappattaḥ paramena sukhena apa aham asmi mahat dhanaḥ iti vatvā āha
translated: I have attained happiness, the highest happiness. I am very rich.”🔽“Faith is wealth, virtue is wealth,

original: “Saddhādhanaṃ sīladhanaṃ, hiriottappiyaṃ dhanaṃ;
analyzed: saddhā dhanam sīla dhanam hiri ottappiyam dhanam
translated: a sense of shame is wealth, and a sense of integrity is wealth;🔽Learning is wealth, generosity is wealth,

original: Sutadhanañca cāgo ca, paññā ve sattamaṃ dhanaṃ.
analyzed: suta dhanam ca cāgaḥ ca paññā ve sattamam dhanam
translated: and wisdom is the seventh kind of wealth.🔽“Whoever has these kinds of wealth,

original: “Yassa ete dhanā atthi, itthiyā purisassa vā;
analyzed: yassa ete dhanā atthi itthiyā purisassa vā
translated: whether a woman or a man,

original: ‘Adaliddo’ti taṃ āhu, amoghaṃ tassa jīvita”nti. –
analyzed: adaliddaḥ ti tam āhu amogham tassa jīvitanti
translated: is called ‘not poor.’ Their life is not in vain.”

original: Tassimāni me satta ariyadhanāni santi. Yesañhi imāni dhanāni santi, na tveva te buddhehi vā paccekabuddhehi vā ‘daliddā’ti vuccantī”ti.
analyzed: tassa imāni me satta ariya dhanāni santi yesan hi imāni dhanāni santi na tu eva te buddhehi vā paccekabuddhehi vā daliddā ati vuccanti iti
translated: “I have these seven kinds of noble wealth. Those who have these kinds of wealth are not called ‘poor’ by Buddhas or Independent Buddhas.”

original: Sakko tassa kathaṃ sutvā taṃ antarāmagge ohāya satthu santikaṃ gantvā sabbaṃ taṃ🔽vacanaṃ paṭivacanañca ārocesi. Atha naṃ bhagavā āha – “na kho sakka sakkā tādisānaṃ
analyzed: sakko tassa katham sutvā tam antarāmagge ohāya satthu santikam gantvā sabbam tam  vacanam paṭivacanam ca ārocesi atha nam bhagavān āha na kho sakka sakkā tādisānam
translated: Sakka, having heard his words, left him on the way, went to the Teacher, and told him all his words and the Teacher’s reply. Then the Blessed One said to him: “It is not possible, Sakka, for such as you to understand the matter.

original: satenapi sahassenapi suppabuddhaṃ kuṭṭhiṃ ‘buddho na buddho, dhammo na dhammo, saṅgho🔽na saṅgho’ti kathāpetu”nti. Suppabuddhopi kho kuṭṭhī satthu santikaṃ gantvā satthārā🔽katapaṭisanthāro attanā paṭiladdhaguṇaṃ ārocesi. Tena vuttaṃ – “atha kho suppabuddho🔽kuṭṭhī diṭṭhadhammo”tiādi.🔽Tattha diṭṭhadhammoti diṭṭho ariyasaccadhammo etenāti diṭṭhadhammo. Sesapadesupi🔽eseva nayo. Tattha “diṭṭhadhammo”ti cettha sāmaññavacano dhammasaddo. Dassanaṃ nāma
analyzed: satena api sahassena api su ppabuddham kuṭṭhim buddhaḥ na buddhaḥ dhammaḥ na dhammaḥ saṅghaḥ  na saṅghaḥ iti kathāpetunti suppabuddhaḥ api kho kuṭṭhī satthu santikam gantvā satthārā  kata paṭisanthāraḥ attanā paṭiladdha guṇam ārocesi tena vuttam atha kho suppabuddhaḥ  kuṭṭhī diṭṭhadhammaḥ tiādi  tattha diṭṭhadhammo ti diṭṭhaḥ ariya sacca dhammo etena ati diṭṭhadhammo sesa padesu pi  esa iva nayaḥ tattha diṭṭhadhammo ti ca ittha sāmañña vacanaḥ dhamma saddo dassanam nāma
translated: Sakka, having heard his words, left him on the way and went to the Teacher and told him all his words and the reply. Then the Blessed One said to him: “It is not possible, Sakka, to make the leper Suppabuddha say: ‘The Buddha is not enlightened, the Dhamma is not well-taught, the Sangha is not practising well.’ ” Suppabuddha, the leper, having gone to the Teacher, and having been welcomed by the Teacher, told him of the qualities he had attained. Therefore it is said: “Then Suppabuddha, the leper, having seen the Dhamma … ”

original: ñāṇadassanato aññampi atthīti taṃ nivattanatthaṃ “pattadhammo”ti vuttaṃ. Patti ca
analyzed: ñāṇa dassanataḥ aññam pi atthi iti tam nivattana ttham pattadhammo ti vuttam ca
translated: Herein, he is one who has seen the Dhamma called the Noble Truth, thus he is a Dhamma-farer. The same method of explanation applies to the other terms. Herein, the word Dhamma is a general term in the sense of “he has seen the Dhamma.” Seeing is also something other than the seeing of knowledge. In order to exclude that, it is said: “he has attained the Dhamma.” Attainment is also something other than the attainment of the path. In order to exclude that, it is said: “he has understood the Dhamma.” Understanding is also something other than the understanding of the path. In order to exclude that, it is said: “he has fully understood the Dhamma.” Full understanding is also something other than the full understanding of the path. In order to exclude that, it is said: “he has directly experienced the Dhamma.” Direct experience is also something other than the direct experience of the path. In order to exclude that, it is said: “he has realized the Dhamma.” Realization is also something other than the realization of the path. In order to exclude that, it is said: “he has attained the Dhamma.” Attainment is also something other than the attainment of the path. In order to exclude that, it is said: “he has understood the Dhamma.” Understanding is also something other than the understanding of the path. In order to exclude that, it is said: “he has fully understood the Dhamma.” Full understanding is also something other than the full understanding of the path. In order to exclude that, it is said: “he has directly experienced the Dhamma.” Direct experience is also something other than the direct experience of the path. In order to exclude that, it is said: “he has realized the Dhamma.” Realization is also

original: ñāṇasampattito aññāpi vijjatīti tato visesanatthaṃ “viditadhammo”ti vuttaṃ. Sā panāyaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇa sampattitaḥ aññā api vijjati iti tatas visesana attham vidita dhammo ti vuttam sā pana ayam
translated: And since there is also another kind of knowledge besides the perfection of knowledge, the word “fully understood” is said for the purpose of distinguishing it.

original: viditadhammatā dhammesu ekadesenāpi hotīti nippadesato viditabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “pariyogāḷhadhammo”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Tenassa yathāvuttaṃ saccābhisambodhaṃyeva dīpeti. Maggañāṇañhi ekābhisamayavasena
analyzed: vidita dhamma tā dhammesu eka desena api hoti iti nippadesataḥ vidita bhāvam dassetum pariyogāḷha dhammaḥ ti  vuttam tena assa yathā vuttam sacca abhisambodham yā iva dīpeti magga ñāṇam hi eka abhisamaya vasena
translated: But this state of being fully understood is present even in a partial way in regard to ideas. Thus, in order to show that it is present in a fully understood way, the word “penetrated” is said.

original: pariññādikiccaṃ sādhentaṃ nippadesenapi pariññeyyadhammaṃ samantato ogāḷhaṃ nāma
analyzed: pariññā ādi kiccam sādhentam nippadesena api pariññeyya dhammam samantataḥ ogāḷham nāma
translated: And so it is that he shows his own discovery of the four noble truths in the way stated. For the knowledge of the path, accomplishing the functions of full understanding, etc., in a single act of direct- knowledge, is called “fully penetrated” in regard to the ideas that are to be fully understood, because it has penetrated them all round without remainder.🔽And that is not so in any other kind of knowledge.

original: hoti, na tadaññañāṇaṃ. Tena vuttaṃ – “diṭṭho ariyasaccadhammo etenāti diṭṭhadhammo”ti.
analyzed: hoti na tad añña ñāṇam tena vuttam diṭṭhaḥ ariya sacca dhammo etena ati diṭṭha dhammo ti
translated: That is why it is said: “He has seen the ideas of the noble truths, thus he is one who has seen the state” .

original: Tenevāha “tiṇṇavicikiccho”tiādi.
analyzed: tena iva āha tiṇṇa vicikicchā itiādi
translated: That is why it is said: “He has crossed over doubt, he is not subject to the stain of doubt” .

original: Tattha paṭibhayakantārasadisā soḷasavatthukā ca aṭṭhavatthukā ca tiṇṇā vicikicchā
analyzed: tattha paṭibhaya kantāra sadisā soḷasa vatthukā ca aṭṭha vatthukā ca tiṇṇā vicikicchā
translated: Herein, he has crossed over the doubts about the sixteen and eight grounds that are like a fearful forest track,🔽thus he is one who has crossed over doubt.

original: etenāti tiṇṇavicikiccho. Tato eva pavattiādīsu “evaṃ nu kho, na nu kho”ti evaṃ pavattitā
analyzed: etena ati tiṇṇa vicikiccho tatas eva pavatti ādīsu evam nu kho na nu kho iti evam pavatti tā
translated: And since he has done so, he is not subject to the stain of doubt that occurs in the form of the doubt “Is it so or is it not so?”

original: vigatā samucchinnā kathaṃkathā etassāti vigatakathaṃkatho. Sārajjakarānaṃ pāpadhammānaṃ
analyzed: vigatā samucchinnā kathaṃkathā etassa ati vigata kathaṃkathaḥ sārajja karānam pāpa dhammānam
translated: He is one who has no more perplexity, since he has got rid of and cut off perplexity about the path, etc., that is, about the three things beginning with the path.

original: pahīnattā tappaṭipakkhesu ca sīlādiguṇesu suppatiṭṭhitattā vesārajjaṃ visāradabhāvaṃ
analyzed: pahīna ttā tad paṭipakkhesu ca sīla ādi guṇesu suppatiṭṭhita ttā vesārajjam visārada bhāvam
translated: He has attained the state of fearlessness, since he has abandoned the states of fear, that is, the states of fear consisting in bodily and mental stiffness, trembling, and the hair standing on end, which are due to the fear of committing an offence in regard to the training rules, etc., and since he is well established in the opposite qualities of those states of fear, that is, in the virtues of morality, etc.

original: veyyattiyaṃ pattoti vesārajjappatto. Nāssa paro paccayo, na parassa saddhāya ettha🔽vattatīti aparappaccayo. Katthāti āha “satthusāsane”ti.
analyzed: veyyattiyam patto ti vesārajja ppatto na assa paraḥ paccayaḥ na parassa saddhāya ettha  vattati iti apara ppaccayaḥ kattha iti āha satthu sāsane iti
translated: He has no dependence on others, since he does not depend on others for the understanding of the path, etc., and since he does not follow others in the practice of the path, etc.🔽He has confidence in the Teacher’s Dispensation, since he has confidence in the Dispensation of the Teacher, that is, in the path, etc.

original: Abhikkantantiādīsu kiñcāpi ayaṃ abhikkantasaddo khayasundarābhirūpabbhanumodanādīsu🔽anekesu atthesu dissati, idha pana abbhanumodane daṭṭhabbo. Teneva so pasādavasena
analyzed: abhikkanta nti ādīsu kiñca api ayam abhikkanta saddo  anekesu atthesu dissati idha pana abbhanumodane daṭṭhabbo tena iva so pasāda vasena
translated: In the passage beginning with “Excellent, Master Gotama!” the word abhikkanta is used in the sense of “to be rejoiced in.”

original: pasaṃsāvasena ca dvikkhattuṃ vutto, sādhu sādhu, bhanteti vuttaṃ hoti. Abhikkantanti
analyzed: pasaṃsā vasena ca dvi kkhattum vuttaḥ sādhu sādhu bhante iti vuttam hoti abhikkantam ti
translated: Therefore it is said twice, in terms of his own confidence and in terms of his praise of the Blessed One: “Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent, Master Gotama!”

original: vā atikantaṃ atiiṭṭhaṃ atimanāpaṃ, atisundaranti attho. Tattha ekena abhikkantasaddena
analyzed: vā atikantam ati iṭṭham ati manāpam ati sundaram ti attho tattha ekena abhikkanta saddena
translated: Abhikkanta is to be understood in the sense of “gone beyond,” “gone to the further shore,” “gone to perfection,” “gone to excellence,” “gone to the sublime,” “gone to the beautiful,” “gone to the good,” “gone to the very best.”

original: bhagavato desanaṃ thometi, ekena attano pasādaṃ.
analyzed: bhagavataḥ desanam ekena pasādam
translated: Herein, by the first abhikkanta he extols the Blessed One’s teaching, and by the second his own confidence.

original: Ayañhettha adhippāyo – abhikkantaṃ, bhante, yadidaṃ bhagavato dhammadesanā, abhikkantaṃ,🔽bhante, yadidaṃ bhagavato dhammadesanaṃ āgamma mama pasādoti. Bhagavato eva vā vacanaṃ
analyzed: ayam ha ittha adhippāyaḥ abhikkantam bhante yat idam bhagavataḥ dhamma desanā abhikkantam  bhante yat idam bhagavataḥ dhamma desanam āgamma mama pasādaḥ ti bhagavataḥ eva vā vacanam
translated: The intention here is this: “Excellent, venerable sir, is the Blessed One’s teaching of the Dhamma, excellent is the teaching of the Dhamma!

original: abhikkantaṃ dosanāsanato, abhikkantaṃ guṇādhigamanato, tathā saddhāvaḍḍhanato, paññājananato,
analyzed: abhikkantam dosana āsanataḥ abhikkantam guṇa adhigamanataḥ tathā saddhā vaḍḍhanataḥ paññā jananataḥ
translated: And it is excellent, venerable sir, that I have obtained confidence in the Blessed One thus: ‘The Blessed One is accomplished, fully enlightened, perfect in true knowledge and conduct, sublime, knower of worlds, incomparable leader of persons to be tamed, teacher of gods and humans, enlightened, blessed.’ ” Or alternatively, the Blessed One’s word is excellent because it banishes defilements, because it brings about the attainment of special qualities, because it increases faith, because it generates understanding,

original: sātthato, sabyañjanato, uttānapadato, gambhīratthato, kaṇṇasukhato, hadayaṅgamato,
analyzed: sa atthataḥ sa byañjanataḥ uttāna padataḥ gambhīra atthataḥ kaṇṇa sukhataḥ hadayaṅgamataḥ
translated: because it has meaning, because it has phrasing, because it has clear words, because it has a deep import, because it is pleasant to the ear, because it goes to the heart,

original: anattukkaṃsanato, aparavambhanato, karuṇāsītalato, paññāvadātato, āpātharamaṇīyato,
analyzed: anattukkaṃsanataḥ apara vambhanataḥ karuṇā sītalataḥ paññā avadātataḥ āpātha ramaṇīyataḥ
translated: because it does not overpraise, because it does not disparage, because it is cool with loving-kindness, because it is clear with understanding, because it is delightful to listen to,

original: vimaddakkhamato, suyyamānasukhato, vīmaṃsiyamānahitatoti evamādinayehi thomento padadvayaṃ āha.
analyzed: vimadda khamataḥ suyyamāna sukhataḥ vīmaṃsiyamāna hitataḥ ti evamādi nayehi thomentaḥ pada dvayam āha
translated: because it is conducive to what is desirable, because it is pleasant to hear, and because it is conducive to welfare. So he uttered the two phrases “Excellent, venerable sir” in praise by way of these and other such terms.

original: Tato parampi catūhi upamāhi desanaṃyeva thometi. Tattha nikkujjitanti adhomukhaṭṭhapitaṃ,
analyzed: tato param pi catūhi upamāhi desanaṃyā iva thometi tattha nikkujjitam ti adhomukha ṭṭhapitam
translated: After that, he praises the teaching by means of four similes. Herein, overturned is what is placed face down.

original: heṭṭhāmukhajātaṃ vā. Ukkujjeyyāti upari mukhaṃ kareyya. Paṭicchannanti tiṇapaṇṇādinā🔽chāditaṃ. Vivareyyāti ugghāṭeyya. Mūḷhassāti disāmūḷhassa. Maggaṃ ācikkheyyāti hatthe
analyzed: heṭṭhā mukha jātam vā ukkujjeyya ati upari mukham kareyya paṭicchannam ti tiṇa paṇṇa ādinā  chāditam vivareyya ati ugghāṭeyya mūḷhassa ati disā mūḷhassa maggam ācikkheyya ati hatthe
translated: Or he has a face-downwards birth. He should make it face upwards: he should make it face upwards. Covered: concealed with grass, leaves, etc. He should uncover it: he should uncover it. Confused as to direction: confused as to the directions. He should point out the path: he should point out the path with his hand.

original: gahetvā “esa maggo”ti maggaṃ upadiseyya. Andhakāreti caturaṅgasamannāgate. Ayaṃ tāva padattho.🔽Ayaṃ pana adhippāyayojanā – yathā koci nikkujjitaṃ ukkujjeyya, evaṃ saddhammavimukhaṃ🔽asaddhamme patiṭṭhitaṃ maṃ asaddhammā vuṭṭhāpentena, yathā paṭicchannaṃ vivareyya,🔽evaṃ kassapassa bhagavato sāsanantaradhānato paṭṭhāya micchādiṭṭhigahanapaṭicchannaṃ
analyzed: gahetvā esa maggo ti maggam upadiseyya andhakāra iti catur aṅga samannāgate ayam tāva padattho  ayam pana adhippāya yojanā yathā koci nikkujjitam ukkujjeyya evam saddhamma vimukham  asat dhamme patiṭṭhitam mam asat dhammā vuṭṭhāpentena yathā paṭicchannam vivareyya  evam kassapassa bhagavato sāsana antaradhānataḥ paṭṭhāya micchādiṭṭhi gahana paṭicchannam
translated: or with the mouth turned downwards. He should turn it over: he should turn it face upwards. Covered: hidden by grass, leaves, etc. He should uncover it: he should remove the covering. Confused as to the directions: bewildered as to the directions. He should point out the path: he should take him by the hand and show him the path, saying, “This is the path.” In the dark: in the fourfold darkness. This is the word meaning.

original: sāsanaṃ vivarantena, yathā mūḷhassa maggaṃ ācikkheyya, evaṃ kummaggamicchāmaggappaṭipannassa
analyzed: sāsanam vivarantena yathā mūḷhassa maggam ācikkheyya evam kummaggam icchā magga ppaṭipannassa
translated: But the interpretation of the intention is as follows. Just as one would turn over what is turned face down, so too he should remove me from the wrong way and establish me in the right way, since I am averse to the true Dhamma and am established in the wrong Dhamma. Just as one would uncover what is covered, so too he should uncover the Dispensation, which is covered by the thicket of wrong views since the disappearance of the dispensation of the Blessed One Kassapa. Just as one would point out the path to one who is confused as to the directions, so too he should point out the path to one who is following a wrong path or a difficult path,

original: me saggamokkhamaggaṃ āvikarontena, yathā andhakāre telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya, evaṃ mohandhakāre
analyzed: me saggamokkha maggam āvikarontena yathā andhakāre tela pajjotam dhāreyya evam moha ndhakāre
translated: He has revealed to me the path leading to the Deathless, just as one might hold up an oil lamp in the darkness of the night.

original: nimuggassa me buddhādiratanarūpāni apassato tappaṭicchādakamohandhakāraviddhaṃsanadesanāpajjotadhāraṇena
analyzed: nimuggassa me buddha ādi ratana rūpāni a passataḥ tad paṭicchādaka moha ndhakāra viddhaṃsana desanā pajjota dhāraṇena
translated: He has dispelled the darkness of delusion that had concealed the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha from me.

original: bhagavatā nānānayehi pakāsitattā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
analyzed: bhagavatā nānā nayehi pakāsita ttā aneka pariyāyena dhammo pakāsito
translated: The Dhamma has been revealed to me in many ways by the Blessed One’s teaching, which dispels the darkness of delusion.

original: Evaṃ desanaṃ thometvā tāya desanāya ratanattaye pasannacitto pasannākāraṃ karonto🔽“esāha”ntiādimāha. Tattha esāhanti eso ahaṃ. Bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmīti bhagavā
analyzed: evam desanam thometvā tāya desanāya rata nattaye pasanna cittaḥ pasanna ākāram karontaḥ  esāham iti ādim āha tattha esāham aham bhagavantam saraṇam gacchāmi iti bhagavā
translated: Having thus praised the teaching, the brahmin, with a mind full of confidence in the Triple Gem revealed by that teaching, shows his confidence by saying,🔽“I go for refuge to the Blessed One.”🔽I go to the Blessed One for refuge, for protection, for the destruction of what is evil and for the growth of what is good.

original: me saraṇaṃ parāyaṇaṃ aghassa ghātā, hitassa vidhātāti iminā adhippāyena bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: me saraṇam parāyaṇam aghassa ghātā hitassa vidhātā ati iminā adhippāyena bhagavantam
translated: With this intention I go to the Blessed One, I follow him, I understand him in this way.

original: gacchāmi bhajāmi, evaṃ vā jānāmi bujjhāmīti. Yesañhi dhātūnaṃ gatiattho, buddhipi
analyzed: gacchāmi bhajāmi evam vā jānāmi bujjhāmi iti yesam hi dhātūnam gati atthaḥ
translated: For those roots that have the meaning of “going” also have the meaning of “knowing.”

original: tesaṃ atthoti. Dhammanti adhigatamagge sacchikatanirodhe yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjamāne
analyzed: tesam atthaḥ ti dhammanti adhigata magge sacchikata nirodhe yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjamāne
translated: The Dhamma is the path that has been discovered and the Nibbāna that has been realized, and it is the practice in accordance with the teaching.

original: catūsu apāyesu apatamāne dhāretīti dhammo. So atthato ariyamaggo ceva nibbānañca. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: catūsu apāyesu a patamāne dhāreti iti dhammo so atthataḥ ariya maggo ca iva nibbānam ca vuttam ha etam
translated: It is the Dhamma in the sense of what is to be borne in mind, since it is not to be fallen away from in the four states of deprivation. It is the noble path and Nibbāna in the sense of meaning. For this is said:

original: “Yāvatā, bhikkhave, dhammā saṅkhatā, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo tesaṃ aggamakkhāyatī”ti.
analyzed: yāvatā bhikkhave dhammāḥ saṅkhatāḥ ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo tesam aggam akkhāyati iti
translated: “Bhikkhus, the noble eightfold path is the supreme of all conditioned states” .

original: “Yāvatā, bhikkhave, dhammā saṅkhatā vā asaṅkhatā vā, virāgo tesaṃ aggamakkhāyatī”ti ca –
analyzed: yāvatā bhikkhave dhammā saṅkhatāḥ vā asaṅkhatāḥ vā virāgo tesam aggam akkhāyati iti ca
translated: “Bhikkhus, the fading away of lust is the supreme of all states, whether they be conditioned or unconditioned” .

original: Na kevalaṃ ariyamaggo ceva nibbānañca, apica kho ariyaphalehi saddhiṃ pariyattidhammopi. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: na kevalam ariya maggo ca iva nibbānam ca api ca kho ariya phalehi saddhim pariyatti dhammaḥ api vuttam ha etam
translated: Not only the noble path and Nibbāna, but also the scriptures are the Dhamma in the sense of what is to be borne in mind. For this is said:

original: “Rāgavirāgamanejamasokaṃ, dhammamasaṅkhatamappaṭikūlaṃ;
analyzed: rāga virāgam anejam asokam dhammam asaṅkhatam appaṭikūlam
translated: “The fading away of lust, the allaying of conceit, the ending of craving, is the supreme state, the unconditioned state, which is without peril, without danger, without disaster, and is not subject to change.

original: Madhuramimaṃ paguṇaṃ suvibhattaṃ, dhammamimaṃ saraṇatthamupehī”ti. ;
analyzed: madhuram imam paguṇam su vibhattam dhammam imam saraṇa attham upehi iti
translated: This Dhamma is sweet, has a sweet meaning, and ends in a sweet beyond. Come, take refuge in this Dhamma” .

original: Ettha hi rāgavirāganti maggo vutto. Anejamasokanti phalaṃ. Asaṅkhatanti nibbānaṃ. Appaṭikūlaṃ madhuramimaṃ paguṇaṃ suvibhattanti pariyattidhammo vuttoti.
analyzed: ettha hi rāga virāgam ti maggaḥ vuttaḥ anejam asokam ti phalam asaṅkhatanti nibbānam appaṭikūlam madhuram imam paguṇam su vibhattanti pariyatti dhammo vutto ti
translated: Herein, the noble eightfold path is called “the fading away of lust” . The fruition attainment is called “the allaying of conceit” . Nibbāna is called “the ending of craving” . The scriptures are called “the Dhamma which is sweet, has a sweet meaning, and ends in a sweet beyond.”

original: Bhikkhusaṅghanti diṭṭhisīlasāmaññena saṃhataṃ aṭṭhaariyapuggalasamūhaṃ. Ettāvatā
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅgham ti diṭṭhi sīla sāmaññena saṃhatam aṭṭha ariya puggala samūham ettāvatā
translated: The Community of Bhikkhus is the aggregate of the eight kinds of Noble Persons united by virtue of their having in common the same view and the same virtue.🔽So far Suppabuddha has declared his going for refuge in the Three Gems.

original: suppabuddho tīṇi saraṇagamanāni paṭivedesi. Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge
analyzed: suppabuddhaḥ tīṇi saraṇa gamanāni paṭivedesi upāsakam mam bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge
translated: Let the Blessed One remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge from today onward for life🔽who has gone for refuge with life as limit.

original: pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatanti ajjataggeti ajjataṃ ādiṃ katvā. “Ajjadagge”tipi pāṭho,
analyzed: saraṇam ajjataggā iti ādim katvā
translated: The reading “ajjhaggavā” is also found.

original: tattha dakāro padasandhikaro, ajja agge ajja ādiṃ katvāti attho. Pāṇupetanti pāṇehi
analyzed: tattha dakāraḥ pada sandhi karaḥ ajja agge ajja ādim katvā iti attho pāṇupetam ti pāṇehi
translated: Here the syllable “jja” is a word-connector. The meaning is: “from today onward, from the beginning.”

original: upetaṃ, yāva me jīvitaṃ pavattati, tāva upetaṃ anaññasatthukaṃ tīhi saraṇagamanehi
analyzed: upetam yāva me jīvitam pavattati tāva upetam anañña satthukam tīhi saraṇa gamanehi
translated: “With life as limit”: with life as the limit, as long as my life lasts, I am limited by life; I have gone for refuge with no other teacher, with the going for refuge in the Three Gems

original: saraṇaṃ gataṃ ratanattayassa upāsanato upāsakaṃ kappiyakārakaṃ maṃ bhagavā upadhāretu🔽jānātūti attho. Imassa ca saraṇagamanaṃ ariyamaggādhigameneva nipphannaṃ, ajjhāsayaṃ
analyzed: saraṇam gatam rata nattayassa upāsanataḥ upāsakam kappiya kārakam mam bhagavā upadhāretu  jānātu uti atthaḥ imassa ca saraṇa gamanam ariya magga adhigamena iva nipphannam ajjhāsayam
translated: as a lay follower, as one who is worthy of offerings, as one who is to be remembered as a lay follower. Let the Blessed One remember me🔽as one who knows.

original: pana āvikaronto evamāha.
analyzed: pana evam āha
translated: And this going for refuge is perfected only with the attainment of the Noble Path. But in revealing his intention, Suppabuddha says this.

original: Bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvāti bhagavato vacanaṃ cittena abhinanditvā
analyzed: bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinanditvā anumoditvā ati bhagavataḥ vacanam cittena abhinanditvā
translated: He rejoiced in and approved of what the Blessed One said.

original: tameva abhinanditabhāvaṃ pakāsento vuttanayena vācāya anumoditvā. Abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ
analyzed: tam eva abhinandita bhāvam pakāsentaḥ vutta nayena vācāya anumoditvā abhivādetvā padakkhiṇam
translated: and he shows that he rejoiced in that state by verbally rejoicing in the way already stated.

original: katvā pakkāmīti taṃ bhagavantaṃ pañcapatiṭṭhitena vanditvā tikkhattuṃ padakkhiṇaṃ
analyzed: katvā pakkāmi iti tam bhagavantam pañca patiṭṭhitena vanditvā tikkhattum padakkhiṇam
translated: Having paid homage and circumambulated him, I departed: having paid homage to the Blessed One by the fivefold prostration, and having circumambulated him three times by the right,

original: katvā satthu guṇaninnacitto yāva dassanavisayasamatikkamā bhagavantaṃyeva pekkhamāno
analyzed: katvā satthu guṇa ninna cittaḥ yāva dassana visaya samatikkamā bhagavantam yeva pekkhamānaḥ
translated: with my mind bent low with the Blessed One’s special qualities, looking back again and again,

original: pañjaliko namassamāno pakkāmi.🔽Pakkanto ca kuṭṭharogābhibhavena chinnahatthapādaṅguli ukkāragatto samantato vissandamānāsavo🔽kaṇḍūtipatipīḷito asuci duggandho jegucchatamo paramakāruññataṃ patto “nāyaṃ kāyo
analyzed: pañjalikaḥ namassamānaḥ pakkāmi  pakkantaḥ ca kuṭṭha roga abhibhavena chinna hattha pāda aṅguli ukkāra gatto samantataḥ vissandamāna āsavaḥ  kaṇḍūti patipīḍitaḥ asuci duggandhaḥ jegucchatamaḥ parama kāruñña tam pattaḥ na ayam kāyo
translated: with my hands raised in reverence, I departed.🔽And after I had departed, because of the disease of leprosy, my hands, feet, and fingers became like stumps, my skin peeled off, and the pus and blood flowed out all over.

original: imassa accantasantassa paṇītatamassa ariyadhammassa ādhāro bhavituṃ yutto”ti uppannābhisandhinā
analyzed: imassa accanta santassa paṇītatamassa ariya dhammassa ādhāraḥ bhavitum yuttaḥ iti uppanna abhisandhinā
translated: Afflicted by the itching of the disease, covered with filth, stinking, disgusting, and pitiable, I thought: “This body is not fit to be a support for the most excellent and sublime Dhamma. ”

original: viya saggasaṃvattaniyena puññakammena okāse kate appāyukasaṃvattaniyena upacchedakena
analyzed: viya sagga saṃvattaniyena puñña kammena okāse kate appāyuka saṃvattaniyena upacchedakena
translated: And as if I had been given an opportunity by a meritorious deed that would lead to heaven, but had been obstructed by a deed that would lead to a short life span,

original: pāpakammena katūpacitena codiyamāno taruṇavacchāya dhenuyā āpatitvā mārito. Tena
analyzed: pāpa kammena katu upacitena codiyamānaḥ taruṇa vacchāya dhenuyāḥ āpatitvā māritaḥ tena
translated: and he was killed by a cow with a young calf, which charged him as he was going along.

original: vuttaṃ – “atha kho acirapakkantaṃ suppabuddhaṃ kuṭṭhiṃ gāvī taruṇavacchā adhipatitvā jīvitā voropesī”ti.
analyzed: vuttam atha kho acira pakkantam suppabuddham kuṭṭhim gāvī taruṇa vacchā adhipatitvā jīvitā voropesi iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “Soon after he had left, a cow with a young calf charged him and killed him.”

original: So kira atīte eko seṭṭhiputto hutvā attano sahāyehi tīhi seṭṭhiputtehi saddhiṃ kīḷanto
analyzed: so kira atīte ekaḥ seṭṭhi puttaḥ hutvā attanaḥ sahāyehi tīhi seṭṭhi puttehi saddhim kīḷantaḥ
translated: It seems that in the past he was the son of a merchant. While he was playing with three other merchant youths,

original: ekaṃ nagarasobhiniṃ gaṇikaṃ uyyānaṃ netvā divasaṃ sampattiṃ anubhavitvā atthaṅgate🔽sūriye sahāye etadavoca – “imissā hatthe kahāpaṇasahassaṃ bahukañca suvaṇṇaṃ mahagghāni
analyzed: ekam nagara sobhinim gaṇikam uyyānam netvā divasam sampattim anubhavitvā atthaṅgate  sūriye sahāye etat avoca imissā hatthe kahāpaṇa sahassam bahukam ca suvaṇṇam mahagghāni
translated: he took a courtesan, the beauty of the city, to a park, and they enjoyed themselves for the day.

original: ca pasādhanāni saṃvijjanti, imasmiṃ vane añño koci natthi, ratti ca jātā, handa imaṃ
analyzed: ca pasādhanāni saṃvijjanti imasmin vane aññaḥ koci natthi ratti ca jātā handa imaṃ
translated: When the sun had set, he said to his companions: “She has a thousand coins and much gold and valuable ornaments. There is no one else in this forest. It is night. Come,

original: mayaṃ māretvā sabbaṃ dhanaṃ gahetvā gacchāmā”ti. Te cattāropi janā ekajjhāsayā hutvā
analyzed: mayam māretvā sabbam dhanam gahetvā gacchāma ati te cattāro api janāḥ ekajjhāsayā hutvā
translated: let us kill her, take all her money, and go.” All four of them, being of the same mind,

original: taṃ māretuṃ upakkamiṃsu. Sā tehi māriyamānā “ime nillajjā nikkaruṇā mayā saddhiṃ
analyzed: tam māretum upakkamiṃsu sā tehi māriyamānāḥ ime nillajjāḥ nikkaruṇāḥ mayā saddhim
translated: set about killing her. As they were killing her, she said to them: “You shameless, merciless men,

original: kilesasanthavaṃ katvā niraparādhaṃ maṃ kevalaṃ dhanalobhena mārenti, ekavāraṃ tāva
analyzed: kilesa santhavam katvā niraparādham mam kevalam dhana lobhena eka vāram tāva
translated: “They have made an alliance with the defilements and are killing me, who am innocent, merely out of greed for money. Just once

original: maṃ ime mārentu, ahaṃ pana yakkhinī hutvā anekavāraṃ ime māretuṃ samatthā bhaveyya”nti
analyzed: mam ime mārentu aham pana yakkhinī hutvā aneka vāram ime māretum samatthāḥ bhaveyyanti
translated: Having made a compact with the defilements, they were killing me, who was innocent, merely out of greed for my wealth. Let them kill me just this once. But I shall become a female ogre and be able to kill them many times over.”

original: patthanaṃ katvā kālamakāsi. Tesu kira eko pakkusāti kulaputto ahosi, eko bāhiyo dārucīriyo,
analyzed: patthanam katvā kālam akāsi tesu kira ekaḥ pakkusāti kula putto ahosi ekaḥ bāhiyaḥ dārucīriyo
translated: Having made this aspiration, she died. It is said that one of them was a young man of good family named Pakkula, another was Bāhiya of the Bark-cloth,

original: eko tambadāṭhiko coraghātako, eko suppabuddho kuṭṭhī, iti imesaṃ catunnaṃ janānaṃ🔽anekasate attabhāve sā yakkhayoniyaṃ nibbattā gāvī hutvā jīvitā voropesi. Te tassa
analyzed: ekaḥ tamba dāṭhikaḥ cora ghātako ekaḥ suppabuddhaḥ kuṭṭhī iti imesam catunnam janānam  aneka sate attabhāve sā yakkha yoniyam nibbattā gāvī hutvā jīvitā voropesi te tassa
translated: another was Tambadāṭhika the robber-slayer, and the fourth was the leper Suppabuddha. In the course of many hundreds of existences,

original: kammassa nissandena tattha tattha antarāmaraṇaṃ pāpuṇiṃsu. Evaṃ suppabuddhassa kuṭṭhissa
analyzed: kammassa nissandena tattha tattha antarāmaraṇam pāpuṇiṃsu evam suppabuddhassa kuṭṭhissa
translated: she killed them as cows and so on, in the ogre world. As a result of that kamma, they met with an untimely death here and there. Thus the leper Suppabuddha

original: sahasā maraṇaṃ jātaṃ, tena vuttaṃ – “atha kho acirapakkantaṃ…pe… voropesī”ti.
analyzed: sahasā maraṇam jātam tena vuttam atha kho acira pakkantaṃpe voropesi iti
translated: met with a sudden death. Hence it was said above: “Soon after he had left, the female ogre seized him and killed him” .

original: Atha sambahulā bhikkhū tassa kālakiriyaṃ bhagavato ārocetvā abhisamparāyaṃ pucchiṃsu. Bhagavā byākāsi. Tena vuttaṃ – “atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū”tiādi.🔽Tattha tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayāti sakkāyadiṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbataparāmāsoti🔽imesaṃ tiṇṇaṃ bhavabandhanānaṃ samucchedavasena pahānā. Sotāpannoti sotasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: atha sambahulāḥ bhikkhū tassa kālakiriyam bhagavataḥ ārocetvā abhisamparāyam pucchiṃsu bhagavā byākāsi tena vuttam atha kho sambahulāḥ bhikkhu iti ādi  tattha tiṇṇam saṃyojanānam parikkhayā ti sakkāya diṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbata parāmāso ti  imesam tiṇṇam bhava bandhanānam samuccheda vasena pahānā sotāpanno ti sota saṅkhātam
translated: Then a number of bhikkhus told the Exalted One of his death and asked about his future state. The Exalted One explained it to them. Hence it is said: “Then a number of bhikkhus” , and so forth.🔽Herein, with the destruction of three fetters means with the abandoning of the three fetters of personality view, doubt, and grasping at virtue and practices,

original: ariyamaggaṃ ādito panno. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: ariya maggam āditas pannaḥ vuttam ha etam
translated: which are the bonds of existence. He has entered the stream means he has entered the stream called the noble path. For this is said:

original: “Soto sototi idaṃ, āvuso sāriputta, vuccati. Katamo nu kho, āvuso, sototi? Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo”tiādi.
analyzed: soto sototi idam āvuso sāriputta vuccati katamaḥ nu kho āvuso sototi ayam eva ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo tiādi
translated: “Friend Sariputta, this ‘stream’ is said. What now is the stream? It is this noble eightfold path” .

original: Avinipātadhammoti vinipatanaṃ vinipāto, nāssa vinipāto dhammoti avinipātadhammo,
analyzed: a vinipāta dhammo ti vinipatanam vinipātaḥ na assa vinipātaḥ dhammo ti a vinipāta dhammo
translated: He is one bound for heaven means he is not bound for falling, for falling is downfall. He is not bound for downfall, thus he is not bound for falling.

original: catūsu apāyesu upapajjanavasena apatanasabhāvoti attho. Niyatoti dhammaniyāmena sammattaniyāmena
analyzed: catūsu apāyesu upapajjana vasena apatana sabhāvaḥ ti atthaḥ niyataḥ ti dhamma niyāmena sammatta niyāmena
translated: The meaning is that he is not subject to falling into the four lower worlds. He is bound for enlightenment means he is bound for the right path by the path of natural law.

original: niyato. Sambodhiparāyaṇoti uparimaggattayasaṅkhātā sambodhi paraṃ ayanaṃ assa gati🔽paṭisaraṇaṃ avassaṃ pattabbanti sambodhiparāyaṇo. Etena “tassa kā gati, ko abhisamparāyo”ti
analyzed: niyataḥ sambodhi parāyaṇaḥ ti upari magga ttaya saṅkhātā sambodhi param ayanam assa gati  paṭisaraṇam a vassam pattabbanti sambodhi parāyaṇaḥ etena tassa kā gati kaḥ abhisamparāyaḥ ti
translated: He is certain. He is bound for Sambodhi: his going, his course, his destination is the Sambodhi, that is, the three higher paths.🔽He is bound for Sambodhi. By this he shows the meaning: “His going is good, not bad.”

original: pucchāya bhaddikā eva suppabuddhassa gati, na pāpikāti ayamattho dassito. Na pana
analyzed: pucchāya bhaddikā eva suppabuddhassa gati na pāpikā ati ayam atthaḥ dassitaḥ na pana
translated: But he does not show his attained destination.

original: tena sampattā gati, taṃ pana pucchānusandhivasena pakāsetukāmo dhammarājā ettakameva🔽abhāsi. Passati hi bhagavā “mayā ettake kathite imissaṃyeva parisati anusandhikusalo
analyzed: tena sampattā tam pana puccha anusandhi vasena pakāsetu kāmaḥ dhammarājā ettakam eva  abhāsi passati hi bhagavā mayā ettake kathite imissam yeva parisati anusandhi kusalaḥ
translated: The King of the Dhamma, wishing to make that known by way of a question-and-answer sequence, spoke only this much.

original: eko bhikkhu suppabuddhassa kuṭṭhibhāvadāliddiyakapaṇabhāvānaṃ kāraṇaṃ pucchissati,
analyzed: ekaḥ bhikkhu suppabuddhassa kuṭṭhi bhāva dāliddiya kapaṇa bhāvānam kāraṇam pucchissati
translated: For the Exalted One saw: “If I speak this much, then in this very assembly a bhikkhu skilled in question-and-answer sequences will ask the reason for the cripple Suppabuddha’s poverty and his having to beg for alms.

original: athāhaṃ tassa taṃ kāraṇaṃ tena pucchānusandhinā pakāsetvā desanaṃ niṭṭhāpessāmī”ti.
analyzed: atha aham tassa tam kāraṇam tena puccha anusandhinā pakāsetvā desanam niṭṭhāpessāmi iti
translated: Then I will make that known to him by way of a question-and-answer sequence and conclude the teaching.”

original: Tenevāha – “evaṃ vutte aññataro bhikkhū”tiādi. Tattha hetūti asādhāraṇakāraṇaṃ, sādhāraṇakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: tena iva āha evam vutte aññataraḥ bhikkhu iti ādi tattha hetū iti asādhāraṇa kāraṇam sādhāraṇa kāraṇam
translated: Therefore he said: “When this was said, a certain bhikkhu” and so on. Herein, cause means an uncommon cause, a common cause,

original: pana paccayoti, ayametesaṃ viseso. Yenāti yena hetunā yena paccayena ca.
analyzed: pana paccayaḥ ti ayam etesam visesaḥ yena ati yena hetunā yena paccayena ca
translated: But the difference between them is that the former is a cause and the latter a condition.

original: Bhūtapubbanti jātapubbaṃ. Atīte kāle nibbattaṃ taṃ dassetuṃ “suppabuddho”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: bhūta pubbanti jāta pubbam atīte kāle nibbattam tam dassetum suppabuddhaḥ itiādi vuttam
translated: “Was” : was born. In order to show what was born in the past, it is said, “Suppabuddha.”

original: Kadā pana bhūtanti? Atīte kira anuppanne tathāgate bārāṇasiyā sāmantā ekasmiṃ gāme🔽ekā kuladhītā khettaṃ rakkhati. Sā ekaṃ paccekabuddhaṃ disvā pasannacittā tassa pañcahi
analyzed: kadā pana bhūtanti atīte kira anuppanne tathāgate bārāṇasiyā sāmantāḥ ekasmin gāme  ekā kula dhītā khettam rakkhati sā ekam paccekabuddham disvā pasanna cittā tassa pañcahi
translated: But when was it born? It seems that in the past, before the present Buddha appeared, in a village near Bārāṇasī,🔽a girl of a certain family was looking after a field. She saw a Paccekabuddha and with a pure mind gave him a lotus flower together with five hundred grains of parched rice.

original: lājāsatehi saddhiṃ ekaṃ padumapupphaṃ datvā pañca puttasatāni patthesi. Tasmiṃyeva
analyzed: lājā satehi saddhim ekam paduma puppham da tvā pañca putta satāni patthesi tasmiṃ yeva
translated: She then made a wish for five hundred sons.

original: khaṇe pañcasatā migaluddakā paccekabuddhassa madhuramaṃsaṃ datvā “etissā puttā bhaveyyāma,
analyzed: khaṇe pañca satā miga luddakā paccekabuddhassa madhura maṃsam da tvā etissā puttāḥ bhaveyyāma
translated: At that very moment five hundred hunters gave some sweet meat to the Paccekabuddha and made a wish, saying, “May we be her sons,

original: tumhehi pattavisesaṃ labheyyāmā”ti ca patthayiṃsu. Sā yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhatvā devaloke
analyzed: tumhehi patta visesam labheyyāma ati ca patthayiṃsu sā yāvatāyukam ṭhatvā deva loke
translated: and may we receive a special blessing from you.” She lived as long as she was supposed to and was reborn in the world of the gods.

original: nibbattā. Tato cutā ekasmiṃ jātassare padumagabbhe nibbatti. Tameko tāpaso disvā
analyzed: nibbattā tatas cutā ekasmin jātassare paduma gabbhe nibbatti tam ekaḥ tāpasaḥ disvā
translated: After passing away from there, she was reborn in a lotus bud in a certain lake. A certain ascetic saw her

original: paṭijaggi. Tassā vicarantiyā pāduddhāre pāduddhāre bhūmito padumāni uṭṭhahanti. Eko
analyzed: tassā vicarantiyā pāduddhāre pāduddhāre bhūmitaḥ padumāni uṭṭhahanti ekaḥ
translated: she looked after it. As she walked about, lotuses sprang up from the ground at every step she took.

original: vanacarako disvā bārāṇasirañño ārocesi. Rājā taṃ ānetvā aggamahesiṃ akāsi. Tassā🔽kucchiyaṃ gabbho saṇṭhāsi. Mahāpadumakumāro tassā kucchiyaṃ vasi, sesā gabbhamalaṃ
analyzed: vana carakaḥ disvā bārāṇasi raññaḥ ārocesi rājā tam ānetvā aggamahesim akāsi tassā  kucchiyam gabbho saṇṭhāsi mahāpaduma kumāro tassā kucchiyam vasi sesā gabbha malaṃ
translated: and she looked after her. As she walked about, lotuses sprang up from the ground at every step she took. A certain forester saw this and reported it to the king of Bārāṇasī. The king had her brought to him and made her his chief consort.

original: nissāya nibbattā, te vayappattā uyyāne padumasare kīḷantā ekekasmiṃ padume nisīditvā

original: pavattapāpakammassa. Niraye paccitthāti niraye nirayagginā dayhittha. “Paccitvā nirayagginā”tipi
analyzed: pavatta pāpa kammassa niraye paccittha ati niraye nirayagginā dayhittha paccitvā nirayagginā atipi
translated: He was burnt in hell. They also read: “He was burnt by the fire of hell.”

analyzed: paṭhanti tassa iva kammassa vipāka avasesena ati yena kammena so niraye paṭisandhim gaṇhi
translated: By the remainder of the result of that action: by the remainder of the result of the action by means of which he was reborn in hell.

analyzed: na tam kammam manussa loke vipākam deti yā pana assa nānakkhaṇikā cetanā tadā paccekabuddhe
translated: That action does not give its result in the human world. But the intention that was not simultaneous with that action, which arose in the form of opposition to the Paccekabuddha,

original: vippaṭipajjanavasena pavattā aparāpariyavedanīyabhūtā, sā aparāpariyavedanīyeneva
analyzed: vippaṭipajjana vasena pavattā apara apariya vedanīya bhūtā sā apara apariya vedanīyena iva
translated: which was to be experienced in some future period, by means of the other-made meritorious action

original: puññakammena manussesu tihetukapaṭisandhiyā dinnāya pavattiyaṃ kuṭṭhibhāvaṃ dāliddiyaṃ
analyzed: puñña kammena manussesu ti hetuka paṭisandhiyā dinnāya pavattiyam kuṭṭhi bhāvam dāliddiyam
translated: which was to be experienced in some future period, he was reborn in the human world with a rebirth-linking of the triple-root type. In the course of his existence he became a cripple, a beggar,
