analyzed: parama kāruñña tam āpādesi tam sandhāya kamma sabhāga tā vasena tassa iva kammassa vipāka avasesena ati
translated: and the utmost object of compassion. With reference to that, it is said: “By the remainder of the result of that action.”

original: vuttaṃ. Sadisepi hi loke tabbohāro diṭṭho yathā taṃ “sā eva tittirī, tāniyeva osadhānī”ti.
analyzed: vuttam sadise api hi loke tad bohāraḥ diṭṭhaḥ yathā tam sā eva tittirī osadhāni iti
translated: For in the world it is seen that the same food is eaten in different ways, just as the partridge eats the same plants as the peacock.

original: Ettāvatā “ko nu kho, bhante, hetū”ti tena bhikkhunā puṭṭhapañhaṃ vissajjetvā idāni
analyzed: ettāvatā kaḥ nu kho bhante hetu uti tena bhikkhunā puṭṭha pañham vissajjetvā idāni
translated: Having answered the question asked by the bhikkhu, “What, venerable sir, is the reason? “🔽

original: yo “tassa kā gati, ko abhisamparāyo”ti pubbe bhikkhūhi puṭṭhapañho, taṃ vissajjetuṃ🔽“so tathāgatappavedita”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha tathāgatappaveditanti tathāgatena bhagavatā
analyzed: yaḥ tassa kā gati kaḥ abhisamparāyaḥ ti pubbe bhikkhūhi puṭṭha pañhaḥ tam vissajjetum  so tathāgata ppavedita ntiādi vuttam tattha tathāgata ppaveditanti tathāgatena bhagavatā
translated: Having answered the question asked by the bhikkhu, “What, venerable sir, is the cause? ” the Exalted One now answers the question asked by the bhikkhus earlier, “What is his future destination, what is his future course? ”🔽“The Dhamma and Discipline that is well proclaimed”: the text reads “tathāgatappavedite dhammavinaye,” which means “in the Dhamma and Discipline proclaimed by the Tathāgata.”

original: desitaṃ akkhātaṃ pakāsitanti tathāgatappaveditaṃ. Āgammāti adhigantvā, nissāya ñatvā
analyzed: desitam akkhātam pakāsitanti tathāgata ppaveditam āgamma ati adhigantvā nissāya ñatvā
translated: “Having come to”: having attained, having relied upon, having known.

original: vā. “Tathāgatappavedite dhammavinaye”tipi pāṭho. Saddhaṃ samādiyīti sammāsambuddho🔽bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅghoti ratanattayasannissayaṃ
analyzed: vā tathāgata ppavedite dhamma vinaya iti pi pāṭhaḥ saddham samādiyi iti sammāsambuddhaḥ  bhagavā su ākkhātaḥ bhagavatā dhammo suppaṭipanno bhagavataḥ sāvaka saṅghaḥ ti ratana ttaya sannissayam
translated: “In the Dhamma and Discipline proclaimed by the Tathāgata” is another reading.

original: pubbabhāgasaddhañceva lokuttarasaddhañcāti duvidhampi saddhaṃ sammā ādiyi. Yathā
analyzed: pubbabhāga saddham ca iva lokuttara saddham ca ati duvidham pi saddham yathā
translated: “Having taken up faith”: having taken up the twofold faith, namely, the faith of the preliminary stage and the supramundane faith, by relying on the Triple Gem—namely, “The Exalted One is fully enlightened, the Dhamma is well proclaimed, and the Saṅgha is practicing the good way.”

original: na puna ādātabbā hoti, evaṃ yāva bhavakkhayā gaṇhi, attano cittasantāne uppādesīti
analyzed: na puna ādātabbā hoti evam yāva bhava khayā gaṇhi attano citta santāne uppādesi iti
translated: Having taken it up in such a way that it cannot be taken up again, he held it until the destruction of his becoming, he caused it to arise in his own mental continuum.

original: attho. Sīlaṃ samādiyītiādīsupi eseva nayo. Sīlanti pubbabhāgasīlena saddhiṃ maggasīlaṃ🔽phalasīlañca. Sutanti pariyattibāhusaccaṃ paṭivedhabāhusaccañcāti duvidhampi sutaṃ.
analyzed: attho sīlam samādiyi iti ādīsu pi esa eva nayaḥ sīlanti pubbabhāga sīlena saddhim magga sīlam  phala sīlam ca sutanti pariyatti bāhu saccam paṭivedha bāhu saccam ca ati duvidham pi sutam
translated: “Meaning” : the meaning of the three aggregates associated with virtue, the meaning of the three aggregates associated with concentration, and the meaning of the three aggregates associated with wisdom. “ Virtue” : the virtue of the path and the virtue of the fruition together with the virtue of the prior stage.🔽“Learning” : learning is of two kinds: learning in the scriptures and learning in the penetration of the truths.

original: Pariyattidhammāpi hi tena dhammassavanakāle saccappaṭivedhāya sāvakehi yathāladdhappakāraṃ🔽sutā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā cāti. Cāganti paṭhamamaggavajjhakilesābhisaṅkhārānaṃ
analyzed: pariyatti dhammā api hi tena dhamma ssavana kāle sacca ppaṭivedhāya sāvakehi yathā laddha ppakāram  sutā paricitā manasā anupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā ca ati ca āganti paṭhama magga vajjha kilesa abhisaṅkhārānaṃ
translated: For the truths are “learned” by the disciples at the time of hearing the teaching, and they are “thoroughly penetrated” by them through the development of insight.🔽“ Renunciation” : the renunciation of the defilements, the hindrances, and the formations that are to be abandoned by the first path, which is called “the relinquishing of the fetters.”

original: vossaggasaṅkhātaṃ cāgaṃ, yena ariyasāvakā deyyadhammesu muttacāgā ca honti payatapāṇī
analyzed: vossagga saṅkhātam cāgam yena ariya sāvakāḥ deyya dhammesu mutta cāgā ca honti payata pāṇī
translated: Through this renunciation the noble disciples become “generous” in regard to the things that can be given, “open-handed,” and “devoted to the relinquishing of gifts.”

original: vossaggaratā. Paññanti saddhiṃ vipassanāpaññāya maggapaññañceva phalapaññañca.
analyzed: vossagga ratāḥ paññanti saddhim vipassanā paññāya magga paññañca iva phala paññañca
translated: “ Wisdom” : the wisdom of the path and the wisdom of the fruition together with the wisdom of insight.

original: Kāyassa bhedāti upādinnakkhandhapariccāgā. Paraṃ maraṇāti tadanantaraṃ abhinibbattakkhandhagahaṇā.
analyzed: kāyassa bhedā ati upādinna kkhandha pariccāgā param maraṇā ati tad anantaram abhinibbatta kkhandha gahaṇā
translated: “ Dissolution of the body” : the relinquishing of the clung-to aggregates. “ At death” : the taking up of the aggregates that are reborn immediately after death.

original: Atha vā kāyassa bhedāti jīvitindriyassa upacchedā. Paraṃ maraṇāti cutito uddhaṃ.🔽Sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokanti padattayenāpi devalokameva vadati. So hi sampattīnaṃ sobhanattā🔽sundarā gatīti sugati, rūpādīhi visesehi suṭṭhu aggoti saggo, sabbakālaṃ sukhamevettha
analyzed: atha vā kāyassa jīvitindriyassa upacchedā param maraṇā ati cutitaḥ  sugatim saggam deva lokam eva vadati saḥ hi sampattīnam sobhanattā  sundarā gati iti su gati rūpa ādīhi visesehi suṭṭhu aggaḥ ti saggaḥ sabbakālam sukham eva ittha
translated: Or alternatively, “with the breakup of the body” means with the termination of the life faculty. “Beyond death” means after death.🔽“A good destination, a heavenly world” : he speaks of the heavenly world even with the word “destination” . For that is a good destination because of the excellence of the attainments there.🔽It is a heaven because of the excellence of the forms, etc., there. It is a world because of the presence there of the perishing and arising of beings.

original: lokiyati, lujjatīti vā lokoti vuccati. Upapannoti paṭisandhiggahaṇavasena upagato.🔽Sahabyatanti sahabhāvaṃ. Vacanattho pana saha byati pavattati, vasatīti vā sahabyo,
analyzed: lokiyati lujjati iti vā vuccati upapannaḥ ti paṭisandhi ggahaṇa vasena upagataḥ  sahabyatanti sahabhāvam vacana atthaḥ pana saha pavattati vasati iti vā sahabyaḥ
translated: “He is reborn” : he has gone by way of rebirth-linking.🔽“Companionship” : the state of being together. The word meaning is this: he is together with, he occurs together with, he dwells together with, he is a companion, a co-dweller.

original: sahaṭhāyī sahavāyī vā. Tassa bhāvo sahabyatā. Atirocatīti atikkamma abhibhavitvā🔽rocati virocati. Vaṇṇenāti rūpasampattiyā. Yasasāti parivārena. So hi asucimakkhitaṃ
analyzed: saha ṭhāyī sahavāyī vā tassa bhāvaḥ sahabya tā atirocati iti atikkamma abhibhavitvā  rocati virocati vaṇṇena ati rūpa sampattiyā yasasā ati parivārena saḥ hi asuci makkhitam
translated: The state of that is companionship.🔽“He shines forth” : he shines, he shines forth, surpassing and outshining.

original: jajjaraṃ mattikābhājanaṃ chaḍḍetvā anekaratanavicittaṃ pabhassararaṃsijālavinaddhasuddhajambunadabhājanaṃ
analyzed: jajjaram mattikā bhājanam chaḍḍetvā aneka ratana vicittam pabhassara raṃsi jāla vinaddha suddha jambu nada bhājanam
translated: “With beauty” : with the excellence of form. “With glory” : with the excellence of retinue. For just as a man might throw away a broken clay pot smeared with excrement and take up a pure golden pot filled with valuable gems,🔽so too, having abandoned this body smeared with excrement, which is broken and discarded in a cemetery, he takes up a pure golden body,

original: gaṇhanto viya vuttappakāraṃ kaḷevaraṃ idha nikkhipitvā ekacittakkhaṇena yathāvuttaṃ
analyzed: gaṇhantaḥ viya vutta ppakāram kaḷevaram idha nikkhipitvā ekacittakkhaṇena yathā vuttam
translated: as if he were taking it up, and placing it here in this way,🔽

original: dibbattabhāvaṃ mahatā parivārena saddhiṃ paṭilabhīti.
analyzed: dibbatta bhāvam mahatā parivārena saddhim paṭilabhi iti
translated: as if he were taking it, and then in a single moment of consciousness he attained the state of a god together with a great retinue.🔽Knowing the meaning of this,

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ pāpānaṃ aparivajjane ādīnavaṃ, parivajjane ca ānisaṃsaṃ sabbākārato viditvā tadatthavibhāvanaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam pāpānam aparivajjane ādīnavam parivajjane ca ānisaṃsam sabba ākārataḥ viditvā tad attha vibhāvanam imam udānam udānesi
translated: knowing the danger in not avoiding evil and the benefit in avoiding it in all ways, he uttered this utterance in order to make that known.

original: Tassāyaṃ saṅkhepattho – yathā cakkhumā puriso parakkame kāyikavīriye vijjamāne sarīre
analyzed: tassa ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ yathā cakkhumā puriso parakkame kāyika vīriye vijjamāne sarīre

He is an ascetic by mere profession because he counts himself as an ascetic in the counting of the number of monks, etc., and because he falsely claims to be an ascetic. He is an ascetic by mere claim because he claims to be an ascetic by saying, “I am an ascetic,” though he is not. He is an unvirtuous man because he is not a virtuous man. He is a false celibate because he claims to be a celibate by saying, “I am a celibate,” though he is not, when he sees other celibates who live by a proper livelihood, who go about in the villages and towns, etc., for alms after dressing in the morning, taking their bowls and robes, and who are thus endowed with the proper appearance. He is a celibate by mere claim because he claims to be a celibate by saying, “I am a celibate,” when he is not, when he appears at the observance day ceremony, etc.

original: tintattā avassutaṃ. Sañjātarāgādikacavarattā sīlavantehi chaḍḍetabbattā ca kasambujātaṃ.
analyzed: tintattā avassutam sañjāta rāga ādika cavara ttā sīlavantehi chaḍḍetabba ttā ca kasambu jātam
translated: He is rotten within because he is penetrated by the corruption of virtue. He is a lecher because he is rained on by the defilements of lust, etc., through the six sense doors. He is a lecher by nature because he is naturally given to lust, etc. He is a lecher by choice because he chooses to live in a certain place in order to indulge in lust, etc. He is a lecher by profession because he makes his living by being a lecher. He is a lecher by addiction because he is addicted to lust, etc. He is a lecher by habit because he is in the habit of lusting after others’ wives, etc. He is a lecher by birth because he is born into a family of lechers.

original: Majjhe bhikkhusaṅghassa nisinnanti saṅghapariyāpanno viya bhikkhusaṅghassa anto nisinnaṃ.
analyzed: majjhe bhikkhu saṅghassa nisinnanti saṅgha pariyāpannaḥ viya bhikkhu saṅghassa antar nisinnam
translated: “In the midst of the Community of Bhikkhus” means sitting in the midst of the Community of Bhikkhus as if included in the Community.

original: Diṭṭhosīti ayaṃ pana na pakatattoti bhagavatā diṭṭho asi. Yasmā ca evaṃ diṭṭho, tasmā
analyzed: diṭṭho asi iti ayam pana na bhagavatā diṭṭhaḥ asi yasmai ca evam diṭṭhaḥ tasmai
translated: “Have you been seen?” means: “You have been seen by me as not being a genuine bhikkhu.” And because you have been seen in this way,

original: natthi te tava bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ ekakammādisaṃvāso. Yasmā pana so saṃvāso tava natthi,
analyzed: natthi te tava bhikkhūhi saddhim eka kamma ādi saṃvāso yasmā pana so saṃvāso tava natthi
translated: there is no longer any association with the bhikkhus in the performance of the duties of the Order, etc. And because there is no longer any association with them,

original: tasmā uṭṭhehi, āvusoti evamettha padayojanā veditabbā.
analyzed: tasmai uṭṭhehi āvuso ti evam ettha pada yojanā veditabbā
translated: therefore you should get up, friend.” This is how the words of the verse should be construed.

original: Tatiyampi kho so puggalo tuṇhī ahosīti anekavāraṃ vatvāpi thero “sayameva nibbinno
analyzed: tatiyam pi kho so puggalo tuṇhī ahosi iti aneka vāram vatvā api thero sayam eva nibbinnaḥ
translated: For the third time that person remained silent. Although the Elder had spoken in this way several times, he remained silent with the intention either that the other would become disgusted with himself

original: oramissatī”ti vā, “idāni imesaṃ paṭipattiṃ jānissāmī”ti vā adhippāyena tuṇhī ahosi.
analyzed: oramissati iti vā idāni imesam paṭipattim jānissāmi iti vā adhippāyena tuṇhī ahosi
translated: and leave or that he would now find out about the other’s practice.

original: Bāhāyaṃ gahetvāti bhagavatā mayā ca yāthāvato diṭṭho, yāvatatiyaṃ uṭṭhehīti vutto
analyzed: bāhāyam gahetvā iti bhagavatā mayā ca yāthāvataḥ diṭṭhaḥ yāvatatiyam uṭṭhehi iti vutto
translated: “Seizing him by the arm” means: “You have been seen by me and by the Blessed One as not being a genuine bhikkhu, and you have been told three times to get up.

original: na uṭṭhāti, “idānissa nikkaḍḍhanakālo mā saṅghassa uposathantarāyo ahosī”ti taṃ bāhāyaṃ
analyzed: na uṭṭhāti idānissa nikkaḍḍhana kālaḥ mā saṅghassa uposatha antarāyaḥ ahosi iti tam bāhāyam
translated: Since you do not get up, now is the time to drag you out. Let there be no obstruction to the observance day of the Community.” He seized him by the arm,

original: aggahesi, tathā gahetvā. Bahidvārakoṭṭhakā nikkhāmetvāti dvārakoṭṭhakasālato bahi🔽nikkhāmetvā. Bahīti pana nikkhāmitaṭṭhānadassanaṃ, atha vā bahidvārakoṭṭhakāti bahidvārakoṭṭhakatopi
analyzed: aggahesi tathā gahetvā bahi dvāra koṭṭhakāḥ nikkhāmetvā ati dvāra koṭṭhaka sālataḥ bahi  nikkhāmetvā bahi iti pana nikkhāmita ṭṭhāna dassanam atha vā bahi dvāra koṭṭhakā ati bahi dvāra koṭṭhakataḥ pi
translated: He took hold of him and, having taken hold of him, he led him out by the outer gate-tower.

original: nikkhāmetvā, na antodvārakoṭṭhakato, evaṃ ubhayathāpi vihārato bahi katvāti attho.
analyzed: nikkhāmetvā na antar dvāra koṭṭhakataḥ evam ubhayathā api vihārataḥ bahi katvā iti attho
translated: “Out” shows the place of leading out. Or else “by the outer gate-tower” means that he led him out by the gate-tower outside the monastery, not by the gate-tower inside the monastery. In both cases the meaning is that he led him out of the monastery.

original: Sūcighaṭikaṃ datvāti aggaḷasūciñca uparighaṭikañca ādahitvā, suṭṭhutaraṃ kavāṭaṃ🔽thaketvāti attho. Yāva bāhāgahaṇāpi nāmāti iminā “aparisuddhā, ānanda, parisā”ti🔽vacanaṃ sutvā eva hi tena pakkamitabbaṃ siyā, evaṃ apakkamitvā yāva bāhāgahaṇāpi
analyzed: sūci ghaṭikam datvā ati aggaḷa sūciñca upari ghaṭikañca ādahitvā suṭṭhutaram kavāṭam  thaketvā ti atthaḥ yāva bāhā gahaṇā api nāma ati iminā aparisuddhā ānanda parisā ti  vacanam sutvā eva hi tena pakkamitabbam siyā evam a pakkamitvā yāva bāhā gahaṇā api
translated: “Having fastened the bolt and the crossbar” means having inserted the bolt and the crossbar and having fastened the door very securely.

original: nāma so moghapuriso āgamessatīti acchariyamidanti dasseti. Idampi garahaṇacchariyamevāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: nāma saḥ mogha purisaḥ āgamessati iti acchariyam idam ti dasse ti idam pi garahaṇa chariyam evā ti veditabbam
translated: “Even to the point of seizing him by the arms” shows the marvel of his patience. For he might have gone away as soon as he heard the words “The assembly is impure, Ananda.” But he did not go away even to the point of seizing him by the arms. He shows that it is a marvel that that foolish man would come back. This too should be understood as the marvel of patience.

original: Atha bhagavā cintesi – “idāni bhikkhusaṅgho abbudajāto, aparisuddhā puggalā uposathaṃ
analyzed: atha bhagavā cintesi idāni bhikkhu saṅghaḥ abbuda jātaḥ aparisuddhā puggalā uposatham
translated: Then the Blessed One thought: “Now the Sangha of bhikkhus is like a mass of fermenting grain. Impure persons

original: āgacchanti, na ca tathāgatā aparisuddhāya parisāya uposathaṃ karonti, pātimokkhaṃ🔽uddisanti, anuddisante ca bhikkhusaṅghassa uposatho pacchijjati, yaṃnūnāhaṃ ito paṭṭhāya🔽bhikkhūnaṃyeva pātimokkhuddesaṃ anujāneyya”nti. Evaṃ pana cintetvā bhikkhūnaṃyeva
analyzed: āgacchanti na ca tathāgatāḥ a parisuddhāya parisāya uposatham karonti pātimokkham  uddisanti an uddisante ca bhikkhu saṅghassa uposathaḥ pacchijjati yaṃ nūna aham itas paṭṭhāya  bhikkhūnam yeva pātimokkha uddesam anujāneyyanti evam pana cintetvā bhikkhūnam yeva
translated: and the Buddha thought, “The Buddhas don’t do the observance-day ceremony or recite the Monastic Code in an impure gathering. If they don’t recite the Monastic Code, the observance-day ceremony of the Sangha of monks is interrupted. Let me allow the monks to recite the Monastic Code from now on.”🔽After thinking this, he allowed the monks to recite the Monastic Code.

original: pātimokkhuddesaṃ anujāni. Tena vuttaṃ – “atha kho bhagavā…pe… pātimokkhaṃ uddiseyyāthā”ti.
analyzed: pātimokkha uddesam anujāni tena vuttam atha kho bhagavā āpe pātimokkham uddiseyyātha ati
translated: And the Buddhas do not perform the Uposatha or recite the Pāṭimokkha in an impure gathering. If they do not recite it, the Uposatha of the Sangha of bhikkhus is interrupted. Let me allow the bhikkhus to recite the Pāṭimokkha from now on.” Having thought thus, he allowed the bhikkhus to recite the Pāṭimokkha. Hence it is said: “Then the Lord said to the monks: ‘Monks, I allow you to recite the Pāṭimokkha.’“

original: Tattha na dānāhanti idāni ahaṃ uposathaṃ na karissāmi, pātimokkhaṃ na uddisissāmīti
analyzed: tattha na idāni aham uposatham na karissāmi pātimokkham na uddisissāmi iti
translated: Herein, “I will not recite it” means “I will not perform the Uposatha or recite the Pāṭimokkha now.”

original: paccekaṃ na-kārena sambandho. Duvidhañhi pātimokkhaṃ āṇāpātimokkhaṃ ovādapātimokkhanti.
analyzed: paccekam nakārena sambandhaḥ duvidham hi pātimokkham āṇāpātimokkham ovāda pātimokkham ti
translated: The negative particle na is construed with each clause. For the Pāṭimokkha is of two kinds: the Pāṭimokkha as an injunction and the Pāṭimokkha as advice.

original: Tesu “suṇātu me, bhante”tiādikaṃ āṇāpātimokkhaṃ, taṃ sāvakāva uddisanti, na buddhā,
analyzed: tesu suṇātu me bhantā iti ādikam āṇāpātimokkham tam sāvakāḥ va uddisanti na buddhāḥ
translated: Herein, the Pāṭimokkha as an injunction is the passage beginning, “Let the venerable ones listen to me” , which is recited by the disciples and not by the Buddhas.

original: ayaṃ anvaddhamāsaṃ uddisiyati. “Khantī paramaṃ…pe… sabbapāpassa akaraṇaṃ…pe… anūpavādo
analyzed: ayam anvaddhamāsam uddisiyati khantī paramam sabba pāpassa a karaṇam pe an upavādaḥ
translated: This is recited every half-month. The Pāṭimokkha as advice is the passage beginning, “Patience is the highest austerity,” etc., and “Abstinence from all evil,” etc.,

original: anūpaghāto…pe… etaṃ buddhāna sāsana”nti imā pana tisso gāthā ovādapātimokkhaṃ nāma,
analyzed: etam buddhāna sāsanam ti imāḥ pana tissaḥ gāthāḥ ovādapātimokkham nāma
translated: These three verses are called the “advice recitation.”

original: taṃ buddhāva uddisanti, na sāvakā, channampi vassānaṃ accayena uddisanti. Dīghāyukabuddhānañhi
analyzed: tam buddhāḥ uddisanti na sāvakāḥ channam pi vassānam accayena uddisanti dīgha āyuka buddhānam hi
translated: The Buddhas themselves recite it, not their disciples. They recite it at the end of six years, not of five. For when the Buddhas have a long life span,

original: dharamānakāle ayameva pātimokkhuddeso, appāyukabuddhānaṃ pana paṭhamabodhiyaṃyeva.
analyzed: dharamāna kāle ayam eva pātimokkha uddesaḥ appāyuka buddhānam pana paṭhama bodhiyaṃya eva
translated: this is the only recitation of the Monastic Code. But when they have a short life span, they recite it at the first observance day after their awakening.

original: Tato paraṃ itaro, tañca kho bhikkhū eva uddisanti, na buddhā, tasmā amhākampi bhagavā
analyzed: tatas param tato tat ca kho bhikkhū eva uddisanti na buddhā tasmai amhākam pi bhagavā
translated: After that, the monks recite it, not the Buddhas. That’s why the Buddha,

original: vīsativassamattaṃ ovādapātimokkhaṃ uddisitvā imaṃ antarāyaṃ disvā tato paraṃ na uddisi.🔽Aṭṭhānanti akāraṇaṃ. Anavakāsoti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Kāraṇañhi yathā tiṭṭhati ettha
analyzed: vīsati vassa mattam ovāda pātimokkham uddisitvā imam antarāyam disvā tato param naḥ uddisi  aṭṭhānam ti akāraṇam anavakāsaḥ ti tassa iva vevacanam kāraṇam hi yathā tiṭṭhati ettha
translated: after reciting the advice recitation for twenty years, saw the danger in that and stopped reciting it.🔽“No grounds”: there is no reason. “No opportunity”: this is a synonym for “no grounds”. For grounds is said of that on which

original: phalaṃ tadāyattavuttitāyāti ṭhānanti vuccati, evaṃ anavakāsotipi vuccatīti. Yanti
analyzed: phalam tad āyatta vutti tāya ati ṭhānanti vuccati evam anavakāsaḥ iti pi vuccati iti yanti
translated: a fruit depends for its existence. In the same way, “no opportunity” is said.

original: kiriyāparāmasanaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayena yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: kiriyā parāmasanam tat heṭṭhā vutta nayena yojetabbam
translated: “For”: this is a reference to an action. It should be connected as above.

original: Aṭṭhime, bhikkhave, mahāsamuddeti ko anusandhi? Yvāyaṃ aparisuddhāya parisāya pātimokkhassa🔽anuddeso vutto, so imasmiṃ dhammavinaye acchariyo abbhuto dhammoti taṃ aparehi sattahi
analyzed: aṭṭhime bhikkhave mahā samudde iti kaḥ anusandhi yvā ayam a parisuddhāya parisāya pātimokkhassa  anuddesaḥ vuttaḥ saḥ imasmin dhamma vinaye acchariyaḥ abbhutaḥ dhammaḥ ti tam aparehi sattahi
translated: What is the connection between the eight wonders of the ocean and the eight wonders of the Dhamma? The fact that the recitation of the Pāṭimokkha is undertaken in an impure assembly is a wonder in this Dhamma and Discipline.

original: acchariyabbhutadhammehi saddhiṃ vibhajitvā dassetukāmo paṭhamaṃ tāva tesaṃ upamābhāvena
analyzed: acchariya abbhuta dhammehi saddhim vibhajitvā dassetu kāmo paṭhamam tāva tesam upamā bhāvena
translated: The Master, wishing to show that this wonder is not the only one in this Dhamma and Discipline, but that there are seven other wonders besides,

original: mahāsamudde aṭṭha acchariyabbhutadhamme dassento satthā “aṭṭhime, bhikkhave, mahāsamudde”tiādimāha.🔽Pakatidevā viya na suranti na isanti na virocantīti asurā, surā nāma devā, tesaṃ🔽paṭipakkhāti vā asurā, vepacittipahārādādayo. Tesaṃ bhavanaṃ sinerussa heṭṭhābhāge,
analyzed: mahā samudde aṭṭha acchariya bbhuta dhamme dassento satthā aṭṭhime bhikkhave mahā samudda iti ādim āha  pakati devāḥ viya na suranti na isanti na virocanti iti asurā surā nāma devā tesam  vā asurāḥ tesam bhavanam sinerussa heṭṭhābhāge
translated: first of all, by way of similes, shows the eight wonders of the ocean.🔽The asuras are not gods by nature, nor do they shine like the gods. They are the enemies of the gods. Their abode is beneath Mount Sineru.

original: te tattha pavisantā nikkhamantā sinerupāde maṇḍapādiṃ nimminitvā kīḷantāva abhiramanti.
analyzed: te tattha pavisantā nikkhamantā sineru pāde maṇḍapa ādim nimminitvā kīḷantā ava abhiramanti
translated: When they enter it or leave it, they create a pavilion in the hollow of Mount Sineru and sport and enjoy themselves there.

original: Tattha tesaṃ abhirati ime guṇe disvāti āha – “ye disvā disvā asurā mahāsamudde abhiramantī”ti.
analyzed: tattha tesam abhirati ime guṇe disvā iti āha ye disvā disvā asurāḥ mahā samudde abhiramanti iti
translated: Herein, he said “having seen these qualities” because of their delight in them.

original: Tattha abhiramantīti ratiṃ vindanti, anukkaṇṭhamānā vasantīti attho.
analyzed: tattha abhiramanti iti ratim vindanti an ukkaṇṭhamānāḥ vasanti iti attho
translated: Herein, they delight means they find delight, the meaning is that they live without annoyance.

original: Anupubbaninnotiādīni sabbāni anupaṭipāṭiyā ninnabhāvasseva vevacanāni. Na āyatakeneva
analyzed: anupubba ninnaḥ ti ādīni sabbāni anupaṭipāṭiyā ninna bhāvassa iva vevacanāni na āyatakena iva
translated: The words “in the depths” , etc., are all synonyms for the state of being deep.🔽Not a sheer precipice means not a sheer precipice like a great abyss with a precipitous bank.

original: papātoti na chinnataṭo mahāsobbho viya ādito eva papāto. So hi tīradesato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: papāta iti na chinna taṭaḥ mahā sobbhaḥ viya āditas eva papāto so hi tīra desataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: For that is deep

original: ekaṅguladvaṅgulavidatthiratanayaṭṭhiusabhaaḍḍhagāvutagāvutaḍḍhayojanādivasena gambhīro
analyzed: ekaṅgula dvaṅgula vidatthiratanayaṭṭhi usabha aḍḍhaga avutaga utaḍḍha yojana ādi vasena gambhīraḥ
translated: by one finger, two fingers, a span, a cubit, a hand, a forearm, an elbow, a fathom, a height of a man, a height of an ox, a height of a cow, a height of a buffalo, two, four, six, eight, ten, twenty, forty, and even eighty leagues from the bank.

original: hutvā gacchanto gacchanto sinerupādamūle caturāsītiyojanasahassagambhīro hutvā ṭhitoti dasseti.🔽Ṭhitadhammoti ṭhitasabhāvo avaṭṭhitasabhāvo. Na matena kuṇapena saṃvasatīti yena
analyzed: hutvā gacchantaḥ gacchantaḥ sineru pāda mūle caturāsīti yojana sahassa gambhīraḥ hutvā ṭhitaḥ iti dasseti  ṭhita dhammo ti ṭhita sabhāvaḥ avaṭṭhita sabhāvaḥ na matena kuṇapena saṃvasati iti yena
translated: It shows that it is deep eighty-four thousand leagues at the foot of Mount Sineru.🔽It has a fixed nature means it has a fixed condition, an unmoving condition. It does not lie with a corpse means it does not lie with the corpse of any elephant, horse, etc.

original: kenaci hatthiassādīnaṃ kaḷevarena saddhiṃ na saṃvasati. Tīraṃ vāhetīti tīraṃ apaneti.
analyzed: kenacid hatthi assa ādīnam kaḷevarena saddhim na saṃvasati tīram tīram apaneti
translated: It carries away the bank means it removes the bank.

original: Thalaṃ ussāretīti hatthena gahetvā viya vīcippahāreneva thale khipati. Gaṅgā yamunāti
analyzed: thalam ussāreti iti hatthena gahetvā viya vīci pahārena iva thale khipati gaṅgā yamunā ati
translated: He flings them up on to the bank: he flings them up on to the bank with the force of his kick as though he were seizing them with his hand. The Ganges and the Yamunā:

original: anotattadahassa dakkhiṇamukhato nikkhantanadī pañca dhārā hutvā pavattaṭṭhāne gaṅgātiādinā
analyzed: dakkhiṇa mukhataḥ nikkhanta nadī pañca dhārāḥ hutvā pavatta ṭṭhāne gaṅgā iti ādinā
translated: at the place where the river that flows out from the southern face of the Anotatta Lake becomes five streams, it is called the Ganges, and so on.

original: pañcadhā saṅkhaṃ gatā.
analyzed: pañcadhā saṅkham gatā
translated: It is thus that it becomes fivefold.

original: Tatrāyaṃ imāsaṃ nadīnaṃ ādito paṭṭhāya uppattikathā – ayañhi jambudīpo dasasahassayojanaparimāṇo,
analyzed: tatra ayam imāsam nadīnam āditaḥ paṭṭhāya uppatti kathā ayam hi jambudīpaḥ dasa sahassa yojana parimāṇaḥ
translated: Here is the story of how these rivers came into existence. This Rose-Apple Island is ten thousand leagues in extent.

original: tattha catusahassayojanappamāṇo padeso udakena ajjhotthaṭo samuddoti saṅkhaṃ gato,
analyzed: tattha catu sahassa yojana ppamāṇaḥ padesaḥ udakena ajjhotthaṭaḥ samuddaḥ iti saṅkham gataḥ
translated: The part of it that is four thousand leagues in extent is submerged by water and is known as the “ocean.”

original: tisahassayojanappamāṇe manussā vasanti, tisahassayojanappamāṇe himavā patiṭṭhito🔽ubbedhena pañcayojanasatiko caturāsītikūṭasahassapaṭimaṇḍito samantato sandamānapañcasatanadīvicitto,
analyzed: ti sahassa yojana ppamāṇe manussāḥ vasanti ti sahassa yojana ppamāṇe himavā patiṭṭhitaḥ  ubbedhena pañca yojana satikaḥ catur āsīti kūṭa sahassa paṭimaṇḍito samantataḥ sandamāna pañca sata nadī vicittaḥ
translated: Human beings live in the three thousand leagues that remain. The Himalayas are situated🔽five leagues in height and are adorned with eighty-four thousand peaks. They are five hundred leagues in circumference, and they are marked by five hundred rivers that flow in all directions.

original: yattha āyāmena vitthārena gambhīratāya ca paṇṇāsayojanappamāṇo diyaḍḍhayojanasataparimaṇḍalo
analyzed: āyāmena vitthārena gambhīra tāya ca paṇṇāsa yojana ppamāṇaḥ diyaḍḍha yojana sata parimaṇḍalaḥ
translated: There is a lake there, fifty leagues in length and breadth and twenty leagues in depth, with a circumference of one hundred and fifty leagues.

original: anotattadaho kaṇṇamuṇḍadaho rathakāradaho chaddantadaho kuṇāladaho mandākinidaho
analyzed: anotatta daho kaṇṇamuṇḍa dahaḥ rathakāra daho chaddanta daho kuṇāla daho mandākini daho
translated: the Anotatta lake, the Kaṇṇamuṇḍa lake, the Rathakāra lake, the Chaddanta lake, the Kuṇāla lake, the Mandākinī lake,

original: sīhapapātadahoti satta mahāsarā patiṭṭhitā.🔽Tesu anotattadaho sudassanakūṭaṃ cittakūṭaṃ kāḷakūṭaṃ gandhamādanakūṭaṃ kelāsakūṭanti
analyzed: sīha papāta dahā ti satta mahā sarā patiṭṭhitā  tesu sudassana kūṭam cittakūṭam kāḷa kūṭam gandhamādana kūṭam kelāsakūṭanti
translated: and the Sihapapātā lake.🔽Of these, the Anotatta lake is surrounded by five mountain ranges: the Sudassana range, the Citta range, the Kāḷaka range, the Gandhamādana range, and the Kelāsa range.

original: imehi pañcahi pabbatakūṭehi parikkhitto. Tattha sudassanakūṭaṃ sovaṇṇamayaṃ tiyojanasatubbedhaṃ
analyzed: imehi pañcahi pabbata kūṭehi parikkhittaḥ tattha sudassana kūṭam sovaṇṇa mayam ti yojana satu bedham
translated: The Sudassana range is a hundred leagues high and is made of gold.

original: antovaṅkaṃ kākamukhasaṇṭhānaṃ tameva saraṃ paṭicchādetvā ṭhitaṃ, cittakūṭaṃ sattaratanamayaṃ.
analyzed: antar vaṅkam kākamukha saṇṭhānam tam eva saram paṭicchādetvā ṭhitam citta kūṭam satta ratana mayam
translated: It is shaped like a crow’s head and covers the lake. The Citta range is made of the seven kinds of gems.

original: Kāḷakūṭaṃ añjanamayaṃ. Gandhamādanakūṭaṃ masāragallamayaṃ abbhantare muggavaṇṇaṃ;🔽mūlagandho, sāragandho, pheggugandho, tacagandho, papaṭikāgandho, khandhagandho,
analyzed: kāḷakūṭam añjana mayam gandhamādana kūṭam masāragalla mayam abbhantare mugga vaṇṇam  mūla gandho sāra gandho pheggu gandho taca gandho papaṭikā gandho khandha gandho
translated: The Kāḷaka range is made of collyrium. The Gandhamādana range is made of coral and is the colour of kidney beans inside.

original: rasagandho, pupphagandho, phalagandho, pattagandhoti imehi dasahi gandhehi ussannaṃ,
analyzed: rasa gandho puppha gandho phala gandho patta gandho ti imehi dasahi gandhehi ussannam
translated: There are ten kinds of scents: root scents, heartwood scents, flower scents, fruit scents, leaf scents,🔽and the scents of grass, of creepers, of the earth, of the sky, and of the water.

original: nānappakāraosadhasañchannaṃ, kāḷapakkhuposathadivase ādittaṃ viya aṅgāraṃ pajjalantaṃ
analyzed: nānappakāra osadha sañchannam kāḷa pakkha uposatha divase ādittam viya aṅgāram pajjalantam
translated: covered with various kinds of herbs, like a burning charcoal pit on the Uposatha day of the dark fortnight.

original: tiṭṭhati. Kelāsakūṭaṃ rajatamayaṃ. Sabbāni cetāni sudassanena samānubbedhasaṇṭhānāni
analyzed: tiṭṭhati kelāsa kūṭam rajata mayam sabbāni cetāni sudassanena samānubbedha saṇṭhānāni
translated: and it stands there blazing like a charcoal pit in the dark fortnight on the Uposatha day of the waning moon. The peak of Kelasa is made of silver. All these are the same in size and shape as Sudassana.

original: tameva saraṃ paṭicchādetvā ṭhitāni. Tattha devānubhāvena nāgānubhāvena ca devo vassati,
analyzed: tam eva saram paṭicchādetvā ṭhitāni tattha deva anubhāvena nāga anubhāvena ca devaḥ vassati
translated: They stand there covering that lake. There the rain falls by the power of the gods and the power of the nāgas,

original: nadiyo ca sandanti, taṃ sabbampi udakaṃ anotattameva pavisati, candimasūriyā dakkhiṇena
analyzed: nadiyaḥ ca sandanti tam sabbam pi udakam anotattam eva pavisati candima sūriyāḥ dakkhiṇena
translated: and the rivers flow. All that water enters only the Anotatta Lake. The moon and the sun, going south or north,

original: vā uttarena vā gacchantā pabbatantarena tattha obhāsaṃ karonti, ujukaṃ gacchantā
analyzed: vā uttarena vā gacchantā pabbata antarena tattha obhāsam karonti ujukam gacchantā
translated: illuminate it there by the mountain range. They do not illuminate it when going straight.

original: na karonti, tenevassa “anotatta”nti saṅkhā udapādi.
analyzed: na karonti tena iva assa saṅkhā udapādi
translated: Therefore the name “Anotatta” arose.

original: Tattha ratanamayamanuññasopānasilātalāni nimmacchakacchapāni phalikasadisāni nimmalūdakāni
analyzed: tattha ratana maya manuñña sopāna silā talāni nimmaccha kacchapāni phalika sadisāni nimmalūdakāni
translated: There are bathing places made of jewels, with steps and slabs of stone, without mud or turtles, like slabs of rock, with clear water,

original: tadupabhogasattānaṃ kammanibbattāneva nahānatitthāni ca honti, yattha buddhapaccekabuddhā
analyzed: tad upabhoga sattānam kamma nibbattāna iva nahāna titthāni ca honti yattha buddha paccekabuddhā
translated: created by the kamma of the beings who enjoy them, where Buddhas and Paccekabuddhas

original: iddhimanto sāvakā isayo ca nahānādīni karonti, devayakkhādayo udakakīḷaṃ kīḷanti.
analyzed: iddhimanto sāvakāḥ isayo ca nahāna ādīni karonti deva yakkha ādayaḥ udaka kīḷam kīḷanti
translated: and the seers, who have psychic power, bathe there, and gods, spirits, etc., play in the water.

original: Tassa catūsu passesu sīhamukhaṃ, hatthimukhaṃ, assamukhaṃ, usabhamukhanti cattāri
analyzed: tassa catūsu passesu sīha mukham hatthi mukham assa mukham usabha mukhanti cattāri
translated: At its four corners it has outlets in the form of lion-headed, elephant-headed, horse-headed, and bull-headed spouts,

original: udakanikkhamanamukhāni honti, yehi catasso nadiyo sandanti. Sīhamukhena nikkhantanadītīre
analyzed: udaka nikkhamana mukhāni honti yehi catasso nadiyo sandanti sīha mukhena nikkhanta nadī tīre
translated: through which the four rivers flow out. On the bank of the river flowing out through the lion-headed spout

original: kesarasīhā bahutarā honti, tathā hatthimukhādīhi hatthiassausabhā. Puratthimadisato
analyzed: kesara sīhāḥ bahutarāḥ honti tathā hatthi mukha ādīhi hatthi assa usabhā puratthima disataḥ
translated: there are more lions than elsewhere, and so on. From the eastern side

original: nikkhantanadī anotattaṃ tikkhattuṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā itarā tisso nadiyo anupagamma🔽pācīnahimavanteneva amanussapathaṃ gantvā mahāsamuddaṃ pavisati. Pacchimadisato uttaradisato🔽ca nikkhantanadiyopi tatheva padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pacchimahimavanteneva uttarahimavanteneva
analyzed: nikkhanta nadī anotattam tikkhattum padakkhiṇam katvā itarāḥ tissaḥ nadiyaḥ an upagamma  pācīna himavantena iva amanussa patham gantvā mahā samuddam pavisati pacchima disataḥ uttara disataḥ  ca nikkhanta nadiyaḥ api tathā iva padakkhiṇam katvā pacchima himavantena iva uttara himavantena iva
translated: the river Anotattā flows out, and after going three times round the lake clockwise it flows into the other three rivers🔽and goes by the way of the non-human beings to the great ocean by the Eastern Sea. The rivers flowing out of the northern and western sides

original: ca amanussapathaṃ gantvā mahāsamuddaṃ pavisanti.
analyzed: ca amanussa patham gantvā mahā samuddam pavisanti
translated: go in the same way clockwise, and they go by the way of the non-human beings to the great ocean by the Northern Sea and the Western Sea respectively.

original: Dakkhiṇadisato nikkhantanadī pana taṃ tikkhattuṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā dakkhiṇena ujukaṃ🔽pāsāṇapiṭṭheneva saṭṭhiyojanāni gantvā pabbataṃ paharitvā uṭṭhāya parikkhepena tigāvutappamāṇaudakadhārā
analyzed: dakkhiṇa disatas nikkhanta nadī pana tam tikkhattum padakkhiṇam katvā dakkhiṇena ujukam  pāsāṇa piṭṭhena iva saṭṭhi yojanāni gantvā pabbatam paharitvā uṭṭhāya parikkhepena tiga avuta ppamāṇa odaka dhārā
translated: The river that flows from the south, however, goes round the Anotatta thrice to the right and then flows straight south🔽for sixty leagues on the surface of the rock. Then, after striking the mountain, it rises up and falls in a cascade sixty leagues high,

original: hutvā ākāsena saṭṭhiyojanāni gantvā tiyaggaḷe nāma pāsāṇe patitā, pāsāṇo udakadhārāvegena
analyzed: hutvā ākāsena saṭṭhi yojanāni gantvā tiyaggaḷe nāma pāsāṇe patitā pāsāṇaḥ udaka dhārā vegena
translated: breaking into a hundred streams. After flowing through the air for sixty leagues, it falls on a rock called the Three-Forked Rock . The rock is split by the force of the water’s impact.

original: bhinno. Tattha paññāsayojanappamāṇā tiyaggaḷā nāma pokkharaṇī jātā, pokkharaṇiyā
analyzed: bhinno tattha paññāsa yojana ppamāṇā tiyaggaḷā nāma pokkharaṇī jātā pokkharaṇiyā
translated: There is a lotus tank called the Three-Forked Rock, fifty leagues in extent. The water breaks through the bank of the tank, enters the rock,

original: kūlaṃ bhinditvā pāsāṇaṃ pavisitvā saṭṭhiyojanāni gantvā tato ghanapathaviṃ bhinditvā🔽umaṅgena saṭṭhiyojanāni gantvā viñjhaṃ nāma tiracchānapabbataṃ paharitvā hatthatale
analyzed: kūlam bhinditvā pāsāṇam pavisitvā saṭṭhi yojanāni gantvā tatas ghana pathavim bhinditvā  umaṅgena saṭṭhi yojanāni gantvā viñjham nāma tiracchāna pabbatam paharitvā hattha tale
translated: and flows for sixty leagues. Then, after breaking through the solid rock,🔽it flows for sixty leagues in a subterranean course and falls on a rock called the Crevice, which is like the palm of a hand. There it divides into five streams

original: pañcaṅgulisadisā pañcadhārā hutvā pavattanti.
analyzed: pañca aṅguli sadisā pañca dhārāḥ hutvā pavattanti
translated: and flows on.

original: Sā tikkhattuṃ anotattaṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā gataṭṭhāne “āvaṭṭagaṅgā”ti vuccati, ujukaṃ
analyzed: sā tikkhattum anotattam padakkhiṇam katvā gata ṭṭhāne āvaṭṭagaṅgā ti vuccati ujukam
translated: The place where it goes round the Anotatta thrice to the right is called the Circular River . Then it flows straight south

original: pāsāṇapiṭṭhena saṭṭhiyojanāni gataṭṭhāne “kaṇhagaṅgā”ti, ākāsena saṭṭhiyojanāni gataṭṭhāne
analyzed: pāsāṇa piṭṭhena saṭṭhi yojanāni gata ṭṭhāne kaṇhagaṅgā ati ākāsena saṭṭhi yojanāni gata ṭṭhāne
translated: The place where it flows out through the rock-face for sixty leagues is called the “Sandy Ganges” (kaṇhagaṅgā);🔽the place where it flows through the air for sixty leagues is called the “Ganges of the Air” (ākāsagaṅgā);

original: “ākāsagaṅgā”ti, tiyaggaḷapāsāṇe paññāsayojanokāse ṭhitā “tiyaggaḷapokkharaṇī”ti,
analyzed: ākāsagaṅgā ati tiyaggaḷa pāsāṇe paññāsa yojana ukāse ṭhitā tiyaggaḷa pokkharaṇī ti
translated: the place where it stands on the rock-face of the Three Gates for fifty leagues is called the “Pool of the Three Gates” (tiyaggaḷapokkharaṇī);

original: kūlaṃ bhinditvā pāsāṇaṃ pavisitvā saṭṭhiyojanāni gataṭṭhāne “bahalagaṅgā”ti, umaṅgena
analyzed: kūlam bhinditvā pāsāṇam pavisitvā saṭṭhi yojanāni gata ṭṭhāne bahalagaṅgā ati umaṅgena
translated: the place where it flows out through the rock-face for sixty leagues after breaking through the bank and entering the rock is called the “Deep Ganges” (bahalagaṅgā);

original: saṭṭhiyojanāni gataṭṭhāne “umaṅgagaṅgā”ti vuccati, viñjhaṃ nāma tiracchānapabbataṃ
analyzed: saṭṭhi yojanāni gata ṭṭhāne umaṅgagaṅgā ti vuccati viñjham nāma tiracchāna pabbatam
translated: the place where it flows for sixty leagues through the Umoṅga rock is called the “Umoṅga Ganges” (umaṅgagaṅgā);

original: paharitvā pañcadhārā hutvā pavattaṭṭhāne gaṅgā, yamunā, aciravatī, sarabhū, mahīti
analyzed: paharitvā pañca dhārāḥ hutvā pavatta ṭṭhāne gaṅgā yamunā aciravatī sarabhū mahī iti
translated: the place where it flows out after splitting the rock called the Viñjha mountain and becoming five streams is called the “Ganges” (gaṅgā), the “Yamunā” (yamunā), the “Aciravatī” (aciravatī), the “Sarabhū” (sarabhū), and the “Mahī” (mahī);

original: pañcadhā saṅkhaṃ gatā. Evametā pañca mahānadiyo himavantato pavattantīti veditabbā.🔽Tattha nadī ninnagātiādikaṃ gottaṃ, gaṅgā yamunātiādikaṃ nāmaṃ. Savantiyoti yā kāci
analyzed: pañcadhā saṅkham gatāḥ evam etāḥ pañca mahā nadiyaḥ himavantataḥ pavattanti iti veditabbā  tattha nadī ninnagā ati ādikam gottam gaṅgā yamunā ati ādikam nāmam yā kāci
translated: it is known as the “five streams” (pañcadhā saṅkhaṃ gatā). Thus these five great rivers should be understood to flow from the Himalayas.

original: savamānā sandamānā gacchantiyo mahānadiyo vā kunnadiyo vā. Appentīti allīyanti osaranti.
analyzed: savamānā sandamānāḥ gacchantiyaḥ mahā nadiyaḥ vā kunnadiyaḥ vā appenti iti allīyanti osaranti
translated: Herein, the “river” is the river-bed. “Low-lying” is the characteristic of the river-bed. “Gently sloping” is the characteristic of the river-bed. “Flowing” is the characteristic of the river-bed. “Flowing on” is the characteristic of the river-bed. “The river” is the river-bed. “The river-bed” is the river-bed. “The river-bed” is the river-bed. “The river-bed” is the river-bed. “The river-bed” is the river-bed. “The river-bed” is the river-bed. “The river-bed” is the river-bed. “The river-bed” is the river-bed. “The river-bed” is the river-bed. “The river-bed” is the river-bed. “The river-bed” is the river-bed. “The river-bed” is the river-bed. “The river-bed” is the river-bed. “

original: Dhārāti vuṭṭhidhārā. Pūrattanti puṇṇabhāvo. Mahāsamuddassa hi ayaṃ dhammatā – “imasmiṃ🔽kāle devo mando jāto, jālakkhipādīni ādāya macchakacchape gaṇhissāmā”ti vā “imasmiṃ🔽kāle atimahantī vuṭṭhi, na labhissāma nu kho piṭṭhipasāraṇaṭṭhāna”nti vā taṃ na sakkā🔽vattuṃ. Paṭhamakappikakālato paṭṭhāya hi yaṃ vassitvā sinerumekhalaṃ āhacca udakaṃ
analyzed: dhārā ati vuṭṭhi dhārā pūrattanti puṇṇa bhāvaḥ mahā samuddassa hi ayam dhamma tā imasmin  kāle devaḥ mandaḥ jātaḥ jālakkhipa ādīni ādāya maccha kacchape gaṇhissāma ati vai imasmin  kāle ati mahantī vuṭṭhi na labhissāma nu kho piṭṭhi pasāraṇa ṭhānan ti vā tam na sakkā  vattum paṭhama kappika kālataḥ paṭṭhāya hi yam vassitvā sinerumekhalam udakam
translated: “Stream” is the stream of rain that falls. “Fullness” is the state of being full. For this is the nature of the great ocean that it cannot be said that “at this time the rain is light, we will catch fish and turtles with nets and baskets,” or that “at this time the rain is heavy, we will not be able to find a place to stretch our backs.” For from the time of the first aeon onwards the water that falls as rain and reaches the girdle of Mount Sineru

original: ṭhitaṃ, taṃ tato ekaṅgulamattampi udakaṃ neva heṭṭhā otarati, na uddhaṃ uttarati.
analyzed: ṭhitam tam tatas ekaṅgula mattam pi udakam na iva heṭṭhā otarati na uddham uttarati
translated: “Stream” is the stream of the rain that falls. “Full” is the state of being full. For this is the nature of the great ocean that it cannot be said that “at this time the rain is light; we shall catch fish and turtles with nets and traps,” or that “at this time the rain is heavy; we shall not be able to find a place to stretch our legs” . For from the time of the first aeon onwards, the water that has fallen as rain and stands to the depth of one finger’s breadth without overflowing downwards or overflowing upwards cannot be found.

original: Ekarasoti asambhinnaraso. Muttāti khuddakamahantavaṭṭadīghādibhedā anekavidhā muttā.🔽Maṇīti rattanīlādibhedo anekavidho maṇi. Veḷuriyoti vaṃsavaṇṇasirīsapupphavaṇṇādisaṇṭhānato
analyzed: ekarasā iti asambhinna rasaḥ muttā ati khuddaka mahanta vaṭṭa dīgha ādi bhedā anekavidhā muttā  maṇi iti ratta nīla ādi bhedaḥ anekavidhaḥ maṇi veḷuriyaḥ ti vaṃsa vaṇṇa sirīsa puppha vaṇṇa ādi saṇṭhānataḥ
translated: “Of one taste”: of undifferentiated taste. “Pearls”: pearls of various kinds, small and large, round and oblong, etc.

original: anekavidho. Saṅkhoti dakkhiṇāvattatambakucchikadhamanasaṅkhādibhedo anekavidho. Silāti
analyzed: anekavidho saṅkho ti dakkhiṇā vatta tamba kucchika dhamana saṅkhā ādi bhedaḥ anekavidhaḥ
translated: “Gems”: gems of various kinds, sapphires, etc. “Cat’s eyes”: cat’s eyes of various kinds, blue, yellow, etc. “Pearls and gems”: pearls and gems of various kinds. “Coral”: coral of various kinds, red, white, etc. “Silver”: silver of various kinds, refined and unrefined, etc. “Gold”: gold of various kinds, refined and unrefined, etc. “Sand”: sand of various kinds, coarse and fine, etc.

original: setakāḷamuggavaṇṇādibhedā anekavidhā. Pavāḷanti khuddakamahantamandarattaghanarattādibhedaṃ
analyzed: seta kāḷa mugga vaṇṇa ādi bhedāḥ anekavidhā pavāḷanti khuddaka mahanta manda ratta ghana ratta ādi bhedam
translated: They are of many kinds, being white, black, yellow, etc. “Coral” is of many kinds, being small, large, pale red, deep red, etc.

original: anekavidhaṃ. Lohitaṅgoti padumarāgādibhedo anekavidho masāragallanti kabaramaṇi.
analyzed: anekavidham paduma rāga ādi bhedaḥ anekavidhaḥ kabara maṇi
translated: “Ruby” is of many kinds, being padmarāga, etc. “Cat’s eye” is a precious stone.

original: “Cittaphalika”ntipi vadanti.
analyzed: vadanti
translated: They call it “citra-phala” .

original: Mahataṃ bhūtānanti mahantānaṃ sattānaṃ. Timitimiṅgalādikā tisso macchajātiyo. Timiṃ
analyzed: mahatam bhūtānam ti mahantānam sattānam timi timiṅgala ādikā tissaḥ maccha jātiyaḥ timiṃ
translated: “Of great beings”: of great creatures. “Timi and timiṅgala” are three kinds of fish:

original: gilanasamatthā timiṅgalā, timiñca timiṅgalañca gilanasamatthā “timitimiṅgalā”ti vadanti.
analyzed: gilana samatthā timiṅgalā timiñca timiṅgalañca gilana samatthā timi timiṅgalā ati vadanti
translated: the timiṅgala is able to swallow the timi, and the timiṅgala is able to swallow the timi and the timiṅgala, and so they are called “timi and timiṅgala.”

original: Nāgāti ūmipiṭṭhivāsinopi vimānaṭṭhakanāgāpi.🔽Evameva khoti kiñcāpi satthā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye soḷasapi bāttiṃsapi tato bhiyyopi
analyzed: nāgāḥ ti ūmi piṭṭhivāsinaḥ pi vimānaṭṭhaka nāgāḥ api  evam eva kho ti kiñcā api satthā imasmin dhamma vinaye tatas bhiyyas pi
translated: “Nāgas”: those that live on the ocean floor and those that live in palaces.

original: acchariyabbhutadhamme vibhajitvā dassetuṃ sakkoti, tadā upamābhāvena pana gahitānaṃ
analyzed: acchariya abbhuta dhamme vibhajitvā dassetum sakkoti tadā upamā bhāvena pana
translated: “So too, bhikkhus”: although the Master is able to analyze and point out in this Dhamma and Discipline even more than sixteen or thirty-two wonders and marvels,🔽yet he teaches the eight marvels that are appropriate to the eight similes that he has taken.

original: aṭṭhannaṃ anurūpavasena aṭṭheva te upametabbadhamme vibhajitvā dassento “evameva
analyzed: aṭṭhannam anurūpa vasena aṭṭha iva te upametabba dhamme vibhajitvā dassento evam eva
translated: “So too, bhikkhus,

original: kho, bhikkhave, imasmiṃ dhammavinaye aṭṭha acchariyā abbhutā dhammā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: kho bhikkhave imasmin dhamma vinaye aṭṭha acchariyāḥ abbhutāḥ dhammā ti ādim āha
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these eight wonderful and marvellous things in this Dhamma and Discipline.”

original: Tattha anupubbasikkhāya tisso bhikkhā gahitā, anupubbakiriyāya terasa dhutaṅgadhammā,🔽anupubbapaṭipadāya satta anupassanā aṭṭhārasa mahāvipassanā aṭṭhatiṃsa ārammaṇavibhattiyo🔽sattatiṃsa bodhipakkhiyadhammā ca gahitā. Na āyatakeneva aññāpaṭivedhoti maṇḍūkassa
analyzed: tattha anupubba sikkhāya tissaḥ bhikkhāḥ gahitāḥ anupubba kiriyāya terasa dhutaṅga dhammā  anupubba paṭipadāya satta anupassanāḥ aṭṭhārasa mahāvipassanāḥ aṭṭhatiṃsa ārammaṇa vibhattiyo  sattatiṃsa bodhi pakkhiya dhammā ca gahitā na āyatakena iva aññāpaṭivedho ti maṇḍūkassa
translated: Herein, the three kinds of persons are included by the successive higher training, the thirteen austerities by the successive activity,🔽the seven contemplations, the eighteen principal insights, the thirty-three kinds of consciousness with their associated and circumstantial states, and the thirty-seven states partaking of enlightenment are included by the successive way.

original: uppatitvā gamanaṃ viya āditova sīlapūraṇādīni akatvā arahattapaṭivedho nāma natthi,
analyzed: uppatitvā gamanam viya āditas va sīla pūraṇa ādīni a katvā arahatta paṭivedhaḥ nāma natthi

original: paṭipāṭiyā pana sīlasamādhipaññāyo pūretvāva arahattappattīti attho.
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā pana sīla samādhi paññāyo pūretvā ava arahatta ppattī ti attho

original: Mama sāvakāti sotāpannādike ariyapuggale sandhāya vadati. Na saṃvasatīti uposathakammādivasena
analyzed: mama sāvakā ati sotāpanna ādike ariya puggale sandhāya vadati na saṃvasati iti uposatha kamma ādi vasena

analyzed: saṃvāsam na karoti ukkhipati iti apaneti ārakā vāti dūreya iva na tena nibbāna dhātuyā
translated: Excludes: rejects. Far away: far off. Not with that element of extinction:

analyzed: ūnattam vā pūrattam vā ati asaṅkhyeyye pi mahā kappe buddhesu an uppajjantesu eka sattaḥ api

analyzed: parinibbātum na sakkoti tadā api tucchā nibbāna dhātū ti na sakkā vattum buddha kāle

analyzed: pana eka ekasmin samāgame asaṅkhyeyya api sattāḥ amatam ārādhenti tadā api na sakkā vattum
translated: in each of the assemblies countless beings attain the deathless. Even then, it cannot be said that the element of Nibbāna is full.

original: “pūrā nibbānadhātū”ti. Vimuttirasoti kilesehi vimuccanaraso. Sabbā hi sāsanassa sampatti
analyzed: pūrāḥ nibbāna dhātū ti vimutti rasaḥ ti kilesehi vimuccana rasaḥ sabbā hi sāsanassa sampatti

analyzed: yāvat eva an upādāya āsavehi cittassa vimuttiyā hoti
translated: is only the liberation of the mind from the effluents through non-clinging.

original: Ratanānīti ratijananaṭṭhena ratanāni. Satipaṭṭhānādayo hi bhāviyamānā pubbabhāgepi anappakaṃ pītipāmojjaṃ nibbattenti, pageva aparabhāge. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: ratanāni iti rati janana ṭṭhena ratanāni sati paṭṭhāna ādayaḥ hi bhāviyamānā pubba bhāge pi anappakam pīti pāmojjam nibbattenti pagā iva apara bhāge vuttam hetam
translated: “Jewels” are so called because they delight . For the foundations of mindfulness, etc., when developed, produce a measureless joy and gladness even in the earlier stages, much more so in the later stages. It is said:

translated: “From whatever point one comprehends The arising and passing away of the aggregates,

analyzed: labhatī pīti pāmojjam amatam tam
translated: One gains joy and gladness; That is the deathless, I say.”

analyzed: lokiya ratana nimittam pana pīti pāmojjam na tassa kalabhāgam pi agghati iti ayam atthaḥ heṭṭhā dassitaḥ eva apica
translated: And besides:

analyzed: cittīkatam mahaggham ca atulam dullabha dassanam
translated: “It is esteemed, of great worth, Incomparable, hard to find,

analyzed: a noma satta paribhogam pavuccati iti
translated: Fit for the use of noble men: That is why it is called ‘jewel.’ ”

analyzed: yadi ca cittīkatā ādi bhāvena ratanam nāma hoti bhūtataḥ ratana bhāvaḥ  bodhi pakkhiya dhammānam hi saḥ ānubhāvaḥ yam sāvakā sāvaka pāramī ñāṇam paccekabuddhā
translated: And if it is a jewel because it is esteemed, etc., then the foundations of mindfulness, etc., are the real jewels.🔽For it is their power that enables disciples to attain the knowledge of the disciple’s perfections,🔽and the paccekabuddhas to attain the knowledge of the paccekabuddhas,

analyzed: parampara kāraṇam hi dāna ādi upanissayaḥ ti evam rati janana ṭṭhena cittīkata ādi atthena ca

analyzed: ratana bhāvaḥ bodhi pakkhiya dhammānam sa atisayaḥ tena vuttam tatra imāni ratanāni sā iyyathā idam

original: cattāro satipaṭṭhānā”tiādi.
analyzed: cattāro sati paṭṭhāna atiādi
translated: the four foundations of mindfulness” , and so on.

original: Tattha ārammaṇe pakkhanditvā upaṭṭhānaṭṭhena paṭṭhānaṃ, satiyeva paṭṭhānaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: tattha ārammaṇe pakkhanditvā upaṭṭhāna aṭṭhena paṭṭhānam satiyā iva paṭṭhānam sati paṭṭhānam
translated: Herein, it is the establishment of mindfulness that is the establishment ; the establishment of the mindfulness is the establishment of mindfulness .

original: Ārammaṇassa pana kāyādivasena catubbidhattā vuttaṃ “cattāro satipaṭṭhānā”ti. Tathā🔽hi kāyavedanācittadhammesu subhasukhaniccaattasaññānaṃ pahānato asubhadukkhāniccānattatāgahaṇato
analyzed: ārammaṇassa pana kāya ādi vasena catubbidha ttā vuttam cattāro sati paṭṭhānā ti tathā  hi kāya vedanā citta dhammesu subha sukha nicca atta saññānam pahānataḥ asubha dukkha anicca anatta tā gahaṇato
translated: But since the object is of four kinds as the body, and so on, it is said that “there are four establishments of mindfulness” .

original: ca nesaṃ kāyānupassanādibhāvo vibhatto.
analyzed: ca nesam kāya anupassanā ādi bhāvaḥ vibhattaḥ
translated: For the contemplation of the body, etc., is distinguished as the contemplation of the unattractive, the contemplation of feelings, the contemplation of the mind, and the contemplation of mind-objects, respectively, because of the abandoning of the perception of beauty, the perception of pleasure, the perception of permanence, and the perception of self, and because of the arousing of the perception of the unattractive, the perception of pain, the perception of impermanence, and the perception of non-self, in the body, and so on.

analyzed: adhivacanam tam pi anuppannuppannānam akusalānam an uppādana pahāna vasena anuppannuppannānam 🔽kusalānam dhammānam uppādana bhāvanā vasena ca catu kiccam katvā vuttam cattāro sammappadhānā ti
translated: It is right endeavour because it is the means of right endeavour, or because it is itself rightly endeavoured, or because it

original: Ijjhatīti iddhi, samijjhati nipphajjatīti attho. Ijjhanti vā etāya sattā iddhā vuddhā🔽ukkaṃsagatā hontīti iddhi. Iti paṭhamena atthena iddhi eva pādo iddhipādo, iddhikoṭṭhāsoti🔽attho. Dutiyena atthena iddhiyā pādo patiṭṭhā adhigamūpāyoti iddhipādo. Tena hi uparūparivisesasaṅkhātaṃ🔽iddhiṃ pajjanti pāpuṇanti, svāyaṃ iddhipādo yasmā chandādike cattāro adhipatidhamme
analyzed: ijjhati iti id hi samijjhati nipphajjati iti attho ijjhanti vai etāya sattāḥ iddhāḥ vuddhā  ukkaṃsa gatāḥ honti iti iddhi iti paṭhamena atthena iddhi eva pādaḥ iddhi pādaḥ iddhi koṭṭhāso ti  atthaḥ dutiyena atthena iddhiyā pādo patiṭṭhā adhigama upāyo ti iddhipādo tena hi uparu upari visesa saṅkhātam  iddhim pajjanti pāpuṇanti svāyam iddhipādaḥ yasmā chanda ādike cattāro adhipati dhamme
translated: ‘It succeeds’ means ‘it succeeds, it comes about, it is produced’ is the meaning. Or alternatively, ‘beings succeed by means of it, they are successful, they are developed, they reach the summit’ is success. So in the first case success itself is a foot, thus it is success-as-a-foot ; the meaning is, a basis for success. In the second case, success’s foot is a basis, a means of obtaining, thus it is success-as-a-foot ; for by means of it beings reach, obtain, higher and higher kinds of success called ‘further-development’ . This success-as-a-foot is fourfold as being due to zeal, energy, confidence, and inquiry, that is to say, ‘due to zeal’ and so on.🔽

original: dhure jeṭṭhake katvā nibbattiyati, tasmā vuttaṃ “cattāro iddhipādā”ti.
analyzed: dhure jeṭṭhake katvā nibbattiyati tasmā vuttam cattāraḥ iddhipādā ti
translated: ‘It succeeds’ means ‘it succeeds, it comes about, it is produced’ is the meaning. Or alternatively, ‘beings succeed by means of it, they are successful, they are developed, they reach the summit’ is how ‘success’ should be understood. So in the first case success itself is a ‘foot’ , thus it is success-as-a-foot ; the meaning is, a basis for success. In the second case it is a ‘foot’ for success, a basis, a means of obtaining, thus it is success-as-a-foot. For by means of it beings reach, obtain, the success called the higher and higher kinds. And this success-as-a-foot is produced by making the four things beginning with will the chief factor. That is why it is said ‘The four bases for success’ .

original: Pañcindriyānīti saddhādīni pañca indriyāni. Tattha assaddhiyaṃ abhibhavitvā adhimokkhalakkhaṇe🔽indaṭṭhaṃ kāretīti saddhindriyaṃ, kosajjaṃ abhibhavitvā paggahalakkhaṇe, pamādaṃ
analyzed: pañcindriyāni iti saddhā ādīni pañca indriyāni tattha assaddhiyam abhibhavitvā adhimokkha lakkhaṇe  indaṭṭham kāreti iti saddhi indriyam kosajjam abhibhavitvā paggaha lakkhaṇe pamādam
translated: The five faculties: the five faculties beginning with faith. Herein, it makes the state of an ‘overlord’ by the characteristic of resolution since it has overcome faithlessness;🔽it makes the state of an ‘overlord’ by the characteristic of exertion since it has overcome idleness; it makes the state of an ‘overlord’ by the characteristic of establishment since it has overcome negligence;

original: abhibhavitvā upaṭṭhānalakkhaṇe, vikkhepaṃ abhibhavitvā avikkhepalakkhaṇe, aññāṇaṃ
analyzed: abhibhavitvā upaṭṭhāna lakkhaṇe vikkhepam abhibhavitvā avikkhepa lakkhaṇe aññāṇam
translated: it makes the state of an ‘overlord’ by the characteristic of non-distraction since it has overcome distraction; it makes the state of an ‘overlord’ by the characteristic of knowledge since it has overcome ignorance;

original: abhibhavitvā dassanalakkhaṇe indaṭṭhaṃ kāretīti paññindriyaṃ.
analyzed: abhibhavitvā dassana lakkhaṇe indaṭṭham kāreti iti paññindriyam
translated: It makes the faculty of faith stand out by outrivalling faithlessness, and so on.

original: Tāniyeva assaddhiyādīhi anabhibhavanīyato akampiyaṭṭhena sampayuttadhammesu thirabhāvena “balānī”ti veditabbāni.
analyzed: tāni yeva assaddhi ādīhi anabhibhavanīyataḥ akampiya ṭṭhena sampayutta dhammesu thira bhāvena balāni iti veditabbāni
translated: They should be understood as powers in the sense of unshakability, since they cannot be assailed by their opposites, faithlessness, and so on, and in the sense of firmness, since they are unshakable in the things associated with them.🔽The seven enlightenment factors: enlightenment (bodhi) is either the state of the noble path or the state of the fruit.

original: Satta bojjhaṅgāti bodhiyā, bodhissa vā aṅgāti bojjhaṅgā. Yā hi esā dhammasāmaggī🔽yāya lokuttaramaggakkhaṇe uppajjamānāya līnuddhaccapatiṭṭhānāyūhanakāmasukhattakilamathānuyoga-🔽ucchedasassatābhinivesādīnaṃ anekesaṃ upaddavānaṃ paṭipakkhabhūtāya satidhammavicayavīriyapītipassaddhisamādhiupekkhāsaṅkhātāya
analyzed: satta bojjhaṅgā ati bodhiyā bodhissa vā aṅgā ati bojjhaṅgā yā hi esā dhamma sāmaggī  yāya lokuttara magga kkhaṇe uppajjamānāya  uccheda sassata abhinivesa ādīnam anekesam upaddavānam paṭipakkha bhūtāya sati dhamma vicaya vīriya pīti passaddhi samādhi upekkhā saṅkhātāya
translated: The factors (aṅga) of that are the enlightenment factors (bojjhaṅga).

original: dhammasāmaggiyā ariyasāvako bujjhati, kilesaniddāya vuṭṭhahati, cattāri vā ariyasaccāni
analyzed: dhamma sāmaggiyā ariya sāvakaḥ bujjhati kilesa niddāya vuṭṭhahati cattāri vā ariya saccāni
translated: For the noble disciple is said to be “enlightened” because he is enlightened by the concordant state of the dhammas called mindfulness, investigation of (the nature of) things, energy, rapture, tranquillity, concentration, and equanimity, which arises at the moment of the supramundane path and is the opposite of the many dangers such as the depression and excitement that prevent the arising of the path, the pursuit of sensual pleasures, the pursuit of self-mortification, the adherence to systems of doctrines and practices, and the adherence to rules and vows.🔽Or he is said to be “enlightened” because he penetrates the four noble truths or realizes Nibbāna.

original: paṭivijjhati, nibbānameva vā sacchikarotīti “bodhī”ti vuccati, tassā dhammasāmaggisaṅkhātāya
analyzed: paṭivijjhati nibbānam eva vā sacchikaroti iti bodhī iti vuccati tassāḥ dhamma sāmaggi saṅkhātāya
translated: The factors of that concordant state of the dhammas are called enlightenment factors.

original: bodhiyā aṅgātipi bojjhaṅgā jhānaṅgamaggaṅgādayo viya. Yopesa vuttappakārāya dhammasāmaggiyā
analyzed: bodhiyā bojjhaṅgāḥ jhānaṅga maggaṅga ādayaḥ viya vutta ppakārāya dhamma sāmaggiyā
translated: They are enlightenment factors in the way that the factors of the jhāna, factors of the path, etc., are factors.

original: bujjhatīti katvā ariyasāvako “bodhī”ti vuccati, tassa bodhissa aṅgātipi bojjhaṅgā🔽senaṅgarathaṅgādayo viya. Tenāhu porāṇā – “bujjhanakassa puggalassa aṅgāti bojjhaṅgā”ti.
analyzed: bujjhati iti katvā ariya sāvakaḥ bodhī iti vuccati tassa bodhissa aṅgā atipi bojjhaṅgā  senaṅga rathaṅga ādayaḥ viya tena āhu porāṇā bujjhanakassa puggalassa aṅgā ati bojjhaṅgā ati
translated: The noble disciple is called “enlightenment” because he is enlightened by the aforesaid combination of states.🔽They are enlightenment factors in the way that the factors of the army, factors of the chariot, etc., are factors of the army, factors of the chariot.🔽Hence the ancients said: “Enlightenment factors in the way that they are factors of the person who is enlightened.”

original: “Bodhiyā saṃvattantīti bojjhaṅgā”tiādinā nayenapi bojjhaṅgānaṃ bojjhaṅgattho veditabbo.
analyzed: bodhiyā saṃvattanti iti bojjhaṅga ati ādinā nayena api bojjhaṅgānam bojjhaṅga tthaḥ veditabbo
translated: And the meaning of enlightenment factor should be understood in the way of acting as a cause for the enlightenment of the noble disciple by the aforesaid combination of states.

original: Ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggoti taṃtaṃmaggavajjhakilesehi ārakattā ariyabhāvakarattā ariyaphalapaṭilābhakarattā
analyzed: ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo ti taṃ taṃ magga vajjha kilesehi ārakattā ariya bhāva karattā ariya phala paṭilābha karattā
translated: It is noble because it is far from the defilements that have to be abandoned by means of each of the supramundane paths, because it causes the state of being noble, and because it causes the attainment of the fruit of the noble path.

original: ca ariyo. Sammādiṭṭhiādīni aṭṭhaṅgāni assa atthi, aṭṭha aṅgāniyeva vā aṭṭhaṅgiko.
analyzed: ca ariyaḥ sammādiṭṭhi ādīni aṭṭhaṅgāni assa atthi aṭṭha vā aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ
translated: It has eight factors, or it is the eight factors, of right view, etc.,

original: Kilese mārento gacchati, nibbānatthikehi maggiyati, sayaṃ vā nibbānaṃ maggatīti maggoti.
analyzed: kilese mārentaḥ gacchati nibbānatthikehi sayam vā nibbānam maggati iti
translated: It is a path in the sense of passing , in the sense of being travelled by those seeking Nibbāna, or in the sense of going to Nibbāna itself.

original: Evametesaṃ satipaṭṭhānādīnaṃ atthavibhāgo veditabbo.
analyzed: evam etesam sati paṭṭhāna ādīnam attha vibhāgaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: This is how the exposition should be known here as to meaning.

original: Sotāpannoti maggasaṅkhātaṃ sotaṃ āpajjitvā pāpuṇitvā ṭhito, sotāpattiphalaṭṭhoti
analyzed: sotāpannaḥ ti magga saṅkhātam sotam āpajjitvā pāpuṇitvā ṭhitaḥ sotāpatti phala ṭṭho ti
translated: “One who has entered the stream”: one who has reached the stream called the path, who has arrived at it, who has attained it. The meaning is: “one who has attained the fruit of stream-entry.”

original: attho. Sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipannoti sotāpattiphalassa attapaccakkhakaraṇāya
analyzed: atthaḥ sotāpatti phala sacchikiriyāya paṭipannaḥ ti sotāpatti phalassa atta paccakkha karaṇāya
translated: “One who is practicing for the realization of the fruit of stream-entry”: one who is practicing for the realization of the fruit of stream-entry by himself.

original: paṭipajjamāno paṭhamamaggaṭṭho, yo aṭṭhamakotipi vuccati. Sakadāgāmīti sakideva imaṃ
analyzed: paṭipajjamānaḥ paṭhama magga ṭṭho yaḥ aṭṭhamakaḥ tipi vuccati sakadāgāmī iti sakidevaḥ imam
translated: The meaning is: “one who has attained the first path,” who is also called an “eighth-stage noble disciple.”🔽“One who is a once-returner”: one who has attained the second fruit, who has a tendency to return to this world only once.
