translated: Therefore it is said: “Then the venerable Ānanda … the community of bhikkhus … the Exalted One.”

original: sammānaṃ labhitvā mama uppādato paṭṭhāya hatalābhasakkārā ahesunti bāverujātakaṃ kathesi.🔽Etamatthaṃ viditvāti diṭṭhigatikānaṃ tāva sakkārasammāno yāva na sammāsambuddhā loke
analyzed: sammānam labhitvā mama uppādataḥ paṭṭhāya hata lābha sakkārāḥ ahesun ti bāveru jātakam kathesi  etam attham viditvā iti diṭṭhi gatikānam tāva sakkāra sammānaḥ yāva na sammāsambuddhāḥ loke
translated: Then the Exalted One thought: “Even before my appearance in the world, some low-class people received honor. But since my appearance, they have received little gain and honor. They have become lusterless and joyless.” Thus he related the Bāvarī Jātaka.

original: uppajjanti, tesaṃ pana uppādato paṭṭhāya te hatalābhasakkārā nippabhā nittejāva honti,
analyzed: uppajjanti tesam pana uppādato paṭṭhāya te hata lābha sakkārāḥ nippabhāḥ nittejāḥ ava honti
translated: Having known this matter, the Exalted One thought: “As long as the Perfectly Enlightened Ones do not appear in the world, those who have wrong views receive gain and honor. But since their appearance, they have received little gain and honor.🔽They have become lusterless and joyless.

original: duppaṭipattiyā dukkhato ca na muccantīti etamatthaṃ sabbākārato viditvā tadatthadīpanaṃ🔽imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: duppaṭipattiyāḥ dukkhataḥ ca na muccanti iti etam attham sabba ākārataḥ viditvā tad attha dīpanam  imam udānam udānesi
translated: and they do not escape from suffering through wrong practice. Having known the meaning of this in all aspects, he uttered this utterance in order to reveal that meaning.

original: Tattha obhāsati tāva so kimīti so khajjūpanakakimi tāvadeva obhāsati jotati dibbati.🔽Yāva na unnamate pabhaṅkaroti tīsupi mahādīpesu ekakkhaṇe ālokakaraṇena “pabhaṅkaro”ti
analyzed: tattha obhāsati so kimi iti saḥ tāva eva obhāsati jotati dibbati  yāva na unnamate pabhaṅkaroti tīsu pi mahā dīpesu eka kkhaṇe āloka karaṇena pabhaṅkaroti
translated: Herein, he shines so long as the sun does not rise: the firefly shines, glows and radiates so long as the sun, which has received the name “the risener”

original: laddhanāmo sūriyo yāva na uggamati na udeti. Anuggate hi sūriye laddhokāsā khajjūpanakā
analyzed: laddha nāmaḥ sūriyaḥ yāva na uggamati na udeti an uggate hi sūriye laddha ukāsā khajjūpanakā
translated: because it causes light to arise in the three great world-spheres simultaneously, does not rise, does not appear. For when the sun has risen and the fireflies have had their chance,🔽they are like the fruit of the kaṇṭakaphalā tree in the dark and they do not shine.

original: viparivattamānāpi kaṇṭakaphalasadisā tamasi vijjotanti. Sa verocanamhi uggate, hatappabho
analyzed: viparivattamānā api kaṇṭaka phala sadisā tamasi vijjotanti sa verocanamhi uggate hata ppabho
translated: But when the sun has risen, he is powerless,

original: hoti na cāpi bhāsatīti samantato andhakāraṃ vidhamitvā kiraṇasahassena virocanasabhāvatāya
analyzed: hoti na ca api bhāsati iti samantataḥ andhakāram vidhamitvā kiraṇa sahassena virocana sabhāvatāya
translated: and he does not shine. Having dispelled the darkness all round by its thousand rays and being of the nature to shine,

original: verocananāmake ādicce uṭṭhite so khajjūpanako hatappabho nittejo kāḷako hoti, rattandhakāre
analyzed: verocana nāmake ādicce uṭṭhite so khajjūpanakaḥ hata ppabhaḥ nittejaḥ kāḷakaḥ hoti ratta ndhakāre
translated: the sun called “the risener” has risen, then that firefly is powerless, lacking in radiance, and black,

original: viya na bhāsati na dibbati.
analyzed: viya na bhāsati na dibbati
translated: and he does not shine, does not glow, as if in the darkness of night.

original: Evaṃ obhāsitameva takkikānanti yathā tena khajjūpanakena sūriyuggamanato pureyeva
analyzed: evam yathā tena khajjūpanakena sūri yuj gamanataḥ
translated: Thus the theorists’ light is only a dazzle. Just as the khajjupana tree is dazzled by the sun before it rises,

original: obhāsitaṃ hoti, evaṃ takketvā vitakketvā parikappanamattena diṭṭhīnaṃ gahaṇato “takkikā”ti
analyzed: obhāsitam hoti evam takketvā vitakketvā parikappana mattena diṭṭhīnam gahaṇato takkikā ati
translated: so too the theorists, who are called “theorists” because they hold views by theorizing and conjecturing,

original: laddhanāmehi titthiyehi obhāsitaṃ attano samayatejena dīpetvā adhiṭṭhitaṃ tāva, yāva
analyzed: laddha nāmehi titthiyehi obhāsitam attano samaya tejena dīpetvā adhiṭṭhitam tāva yāva
translated: dazzle and illuminate and establish their own doctrines by the brilliance of their own theories, as long as

original: sammāsambuddhā loke nuppajjanti. Na takkikā sujjhanti na cāpi sāvakāti yadā pana
analyzed: sammāsambuddhāḥ loke nuppajjanti na takkikāḥ sujjhanti na ca api sāvakāḥ ati yadā pana
translated: fully enlightened Buddhas do not arise in the world. The theorists are not purified, nor are their disciples.

original: sammāsambuddhā loke uppajjanti, tadā diṭṭhigatikā na sujjhanti na sobhanti, na cāpi
analyzed: sammāsambuddhāḥ loke uppajjanti tadā diṭṭhi gatikāḥ na sujjhanti na sobhanti na ca api
translated: But when fully enlightened Buddhas arise in the world, then the theorists do not shine, do not gleam,

original: tesaṃ sāvakā sobhanti, aññadatthu vihatasobhā rattikhittā viya sarā na paññāyanteva.🔽Atha vā yāva sammāsambuddhā loke nuppajjanti, tāvadeva takkikānaṃ obhāsitaṃ attano
analyzed: tesam sāvakā sobhanti aññadatthu vihata sobhāḥ ratti khittāḥ viya sarāḥ na paññāyanta iva  atha vā yāva sammāsambuddhāḥ loke na uppajjanti tāvat eva takkikānam obhāsitam attanaḥ
translated: nor do their disciples gleam, but rather they are as if their beauty were destroyed, as if they were struck down by night, and they are not even known.

original: samayena jotanaṃ bālalāpanaṃ, na tato paraṃ. Kasmā? Yasmā na takkikā sujjhanti, na
analyzed: samayena jotanam bāla lāpanam na param kasmai yasmai na na
translated: Or alternatively, as long as fully enlightened Buddhas do not arise in the world, the theorists’ light, their illumination by their own doctrines, their prattle to fools, lasts only so long. Not beyond that. Why? Because the theorists are not purified,🔽nor are their disciples.

original: cāpi sāvakā. Te hi durakkhātadhammavinayā sammāpaṭipattirahitā na saṃsārato sujjhanti
analyzed: ca api sāvakā te hi durakkhāta dhamma vinayā sammā paṭipatti rahitā na saṃsārataḥ sujjhanti
translated: and his disciples. For they are not purified from saṃsāra because they have not penetrated the Dhamma and Discipline well and they do not practice rightly,

original: aniyyānikasāsanattā. Tenāha “duddiṭṭhī na dukkhā pamuccare”ti. Takkikā hi ayāthāvaladdhikatāya
analyzed: aniyyānika sāsana ttā tena āha duddiṭṭhī na dukkhā pamuccara iti takkikā hi a yāthāva laddhika tāya
translated: because the Dispensation is not their vehicle. Therefore it is said: “Those of wrong views are not freed from suffering.” For the logicians,

original: duddiṭṭhino micchābhiniviṭṭhadiṭṭhikā viparītadassanā taṃ diṭṭhiṃ anissajjitvā saṃsāradukkhato
analyzed: duddiṭṭhinaḥ micchā abhiniviṭṭha diṭṭhikāḥ viparīta dassanā tam diṭṭhim a nissajjitvā saṃsāra dukkhato
translated: because of their lack of understanding of the way things really are, are of wrong views, are attached to wrong views, and have perverted vision. Without abandoning that view,

original: na kadācipi muccantīti.
analyzed: na kadācid pi muccanti iti
translated: they are never freed from the suffering of saṃsāra.

original: Dasamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dasama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the tenth sutta is finished.

original: Niṭṭhitā ca jaccandhavaggavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: niṭṭhitā ca jaccandha vagga vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the “Chapter on the Blind Man” is finished.

original: 7. Cūḷavaggo
analyzed: cūḷa vaggo
translated: The Minor Chapter

original: 1. Paṭhamalakuṇḍakabhaddiyasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The First Discourse to Bhaddiya the Dwarf

original: 61. Cūḷavaggassa paṭhame lakuṇḍakabhaddiyanti ettha bhaddiyoti tassa āyasmato nāmaṃ,
analyzed: cūḷa vaggassa paṭhame ettha bhaddiyo ti tassa āyasmataḥ nāmaṃ
translated: In the first sutta of the Minor Chapter , “Bhaddiya the Dwarf” : here “Bhaddiya” is the name of that venerable one,

original: kāyassa pana rassattā “lakuṇḍakabhaddiyo”ti naṃ sañjānanti. So kira sāvatthivāsī
analyzed: kāyassa pana rassattā lakuṇḍakabhaddiyā iti nam sañjānanti saḥ kira sāvatthi vāsī
translated: but because his body was small he was known as “Bhaddiya the Dwarf.” He was a clansman living in Sāvatthī,

original: kulaputto mahaddhano mahābhogo rūpena apāsādiko dubbaṇṇo duddasiko okoṭimako. So
analyzed: kula puttaḥ mahat dhanaḥ mahā bhogaḥ rūpena apāsādikaḥ dubbaṇṇaḥ duddasikaḥ okoṭimakaḥ saḥ
translated: a man of great wealth and property, but ugly, unsightly, and repulsive, a hunchback.

original: ekadivasaṃ satthari jetavane viharante upāsakehi saddhiṃ vihāraṃ gantvā dhammadesanaṃ🔽sutvā paṭiladdhasaddho pabbajitvā laddhūpasampado satthu santike kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: eka divasam satthari jetavane viharante upāsakehi saddhim vihāram gantvā dhamma desanam  sutvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ pabbajitvā laddha upasampadaḥ satthu santike kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā
translated: One day, while the Teacher was residing at Jetavana, the lay disciple went to the monastery, heard the Teacher preach the Law,🔽obtained faith, retired from the world, received the higher ordination, and obtained the assurance of his future enlightenment.🔽Then the Teacher gave him a subject of meditation, and he applied himself to the practice of insight.

original: vipassanāya kammaṃ karonto sotāpattiphalaṃ pāpuṇi. Tadā sekkhā bhikkhū yebhuyyena🔽āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ upasaṅkamitvā uparimaggatthāya kammaṭṭhānaṃ yācanti, dhammadesanaṃ
analyzed: vipassanāya kammaṃ karonto sotāpatti phalam pāpuṇi tadā sekkhāḥ bhikkhū yebhuyyena  āyasmantam sāriputtam upasaṅkamitvā upari magga tthāya kammaṭṭhānam yācanti dhamma desanam
translated: The Teacher, the Elder Sāriputta, and the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, and the other Elders,🔽all went to the Elder Sāriputta, and asked him for a subject of meditation, and asked him to preach the Law to them, and asked him questions.

original: yācanti, pañhaṃ pucchanti. So tesaṃ adhippāyaṃ pūrento kammaṭṭhānaṃ ācikkhati, dhammaṃ🔽deseti, pañhaṃ vissajjeti. Te ghaṭentā vāyamantā appekacce sakadāgāmiphalaṃ, appekacce
analyzed: yācanti pañham pucchanti saḥ tesam adhippāyam pūrentaḥ kammaṭṭhānam ācikkhati dhammaṃ  deseti pañham vissajjeti te ghaṭentā vā āyamantā appekacce sakadāgāmi phalam appekacce
translated: The Elder Sāriputta, in order to satisfy their wishes, explained the subject of meditation to them, preached the Law to them,

original: anāgāmiphalaṃ, appekacce arahattaṃ, appekacce tisso vijjā, appekacce chaḷabhiññā,
analyzed: anāgāmi phalam appekacce arahattam appekacce tissaḥ vijjāḥ appekacce chaḍḍabhiññā
translated: and answered their questions. They applied themselves diligently to the practice of meditation, and some of them attained the Fruit of Conversion, some of them attained the Fruit of the Second Path, some of them attained the Fruit of the Third Path, some of them attained Arahatship, some of them attained the Three Sciences, some of them attained the Six Super-knowledges,

original: appekacce catasso paṭisambhidā adhigacchanti. Te disvā lakuṇḍakabhaddiyopi sekho
analyzed: appekacce catasso paṭisambhidāḥ adhigacchanti te disvā sekho
translated: and some of them attained the Four Analytical Knowledges. The novice Bhaddiya, seeing this,

original: samāno kālaṃ ñatvā attano cittakallatañca sallekhañca paccavekkhitvā dhammasenāpatiṃ🔽upasaṅkamitvā katapaṭisanthāro sammodamāno dhammadesanaṃ yāci. Sopissa ajjhāsayassa🔽anurūpaṃ kathaṃ kathesi. Tena vuttaṃ – “tena kho pana samayena āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ
analyzed: samāno kālam ñatvā attano citta kalla tañca sallekhañca paccavekkhitvā dhamma senāpatim  upasaṅkamitvā kata paṭisanthāraḥ sammodamānaḥ dhamma desanam yāci so upissa ajjhāsayassa  anurūpam katham kathesi tena vuttam tena kho pana samayena āyasmā sāriputtaḥ āyasmantam
translated: Knowing the time, he considered his own mental ease and the need for seclusion. He approached the General of the Dhamma,

original: lakuṇḍakabhaddiyaṃ anekapariyāyena dhammiyā kathāya sandassetī”tiādi.
analyzed: lakuṇḍakabhaddiyam aneka pariyāyena dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti itiādi
translated: and after exchanging greetings and polite conversation, he asked for a talk on the Dhamma. The latter gave a talk in accordance with his disposition. Hence it was said: “On that occasion the venerable Sariputta was instructing, rousing, enthusing, and cheering the bhikkhus with talk on the Dhamma” .

original: Tattha anekapariyāyenāti “itipi pañcakkhandhā aniccā, itipi dukkhā, itipi anattā”ti
analyzed: tattha aneka pariyāyena ati iti pi pañca khandhāḥ aniccāḥ iti pi dukkhāḥ iti pi anattā ati
translated: Here “in many ways” means “in many ways such as ‘The five aggregates are impermanent,’ ‘They are painful,’ ‘They are not self.’“

original: evaṃ anekehi kāraṇehi. Dhammiyā kathāyāti pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ udayabbayādipakāsaniyā🔽dhammiyā kathāya. Sandassetīti tāniyeva aniccādilakkhaṇāni udayabbayādike ca sammā
analyzed: evam anekehi kāraṇehi dhammiyā kathāyā ati pañcannam upādānakkhandhānam udaya bbaya ādi pakāsaniyā  dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti iti tāniyā eva anicca ādi lakkhaṇāni udaya bbaya ādike ca sammā
translated: “Talk on the Dhamma” is talk that reveals the rise and fall, etc., of the five aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: dasseti, hatthena gahetvā viya paccakkhato dasseti. Samādapetīti tattha lakkhaṇārammaṇikaṃ
analyzed: dasseti hatthena gahetvā viya paccakkhataḥ dasseti samādapeti iti tattha lakkhaṇa ārammaṇikam
translated: “Instructing” means revealing correctly the characteristics of impermanence, etc., and the rise and fall, etc., of those same aggregates as objects of clinging, revealing them as if taking them in the hand and showing them. “Rousing” means rousing them by showing the danger in the aggregates as objects of clinging, which are subject to birth, etc., by means of the peril in birth, etc. “Enthusing” means enthusing them by showing the benefit in the noble fruits and in the state of peace, Nibbāna, by means of the noble fruits and the state of peace, Nibbāna. “Cheering” means cheering them by showing the special qualities of the jhānas, etc., and the special qualities of the noble fruits and of Nibbāna.

original: vipassanaṃ sammā ādapeti, yathā vīthipaṭipannā hutvā pavattati, evaṃ gaṇhāpeti. Samuttejetīti🔽vipassanāya āraddhāya saṅkhārānaṃ udayabbayādīsu upaṭṭhahantesu yathākālaṃ paggahaniggahasamupekkhaṇehi
analyzed: vipassanam sammā ādapeti yathā vīthi paṭipannā hutvā pavattati evam gaṇhāpeti samuttejeti iti  vipassanāya āraddhāya saṅkhārānam udaya bbaya ādīsu upaṭṭhahantesu yathākālam paggaha niggaha samupekkhaṇehi
translated: He sets it right in the sense of making it go forward by the path, he makes it go forward in the right way. He rouses it:🔽when insight has been begun and the rise and fall, etc., of formations are occurring, he rouses the mind with the arousing, he restrains it with the restraining, he looks on at it with equanimity with the equanimity,

original: bojjhaṅgānaṃ anupavattanena bhāvanaṃ majjhimaṃ vīthiṃ otāretvā yathā vipassanāñāṇaṃ🔽sūraṃ pasannaṃ hutvā vahati, evaṃ indriyānaṃ visadabhāvakaraṇena vipassanācittaṃ
analyzed: bojjhaṅgānaṃ an upavattanena bhāvanam majjhimam vīthim otāretvā yathā vipassanā ñāṇam  sūram pasannam hutvā vahati evam indriyānam visada bhāva karaṇena vipassanā cittam
translated: and he brings the development to the middle of the path by the non-occurrence of the enlightenment factors.🔽He makes it brace up: he makes the insight consciousness

original: sammā uttejeti, visadāpanavasena vodapeti. Sampahaṃsetīti tathā pavattiyamānāya vipassanāya
analyzed: sammā uttejeti visadāpana vasena vā udapeti sampahaṃseti iti tathā pavattiyamānāya vipassanāya
translated: brace up by means of the purification of the faculties, so that insight knowledge goes forward clear and bright.

original: samappavattabhāvanāvasena ceva upariladdhabbabhāvanābalena ca cittaṃ sammā pahaṃseti,
analyzed: sama ppavatta bhāvanā vasena ca iva upari laddhabba bhāvanā balena ca cittam sammā pahaṃseti
translated: He makes it confident: he makes the mind confident by means of the development that has gone forward thus, and by means of the strength of the development that has been reached,

original: laddhassādavasena vā suṭṭhu toseti. Anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccīti yathā yathā
analyzed: vā suṭṭhu toseti an upādāya āsavehi cittam vimucci iti yathā yathā
translated: or he delights it well by means of the satisfaction that has been reached. His mind is liberated from the taints by non-clinging: as the insight reaches its culmination,

original: dhammasenāpati dhammaṃ deseti, tathā tathā tathalakkhaṇaṃ vipassantassa therassa
analyzed: dhamma senāpati dhammaṃ deseti tathā tathā tatha lakkhaṇam vipassantassa therassa
translated: The Dhamma Lord taught the Dhamma, and as the Elder was thus contemplating the characteristics of the various states,

original: ca desanānubhāvena, attano ca upanissayasampattiyā ñāṇassa paripākaṃ gatattā desanānusārena🔽ñāṇe anupavattante kāmāsavādīsu kañci āsavaṃ aggahetvā maggapaṭipāṭiyāva anavasesato
analyzed: ca desanā anubhāvena attano ca upanissaya sampattiyāḥ ñāṇassa paripākam gata ttā desanā anusārena  ñāṇe kāma āsava ādīsu kañci āsavam aggahetvā magga paṭipāṭiyā iva anavasesato
translated: and by the power of the teaching and by his own possession of the necessary supporting conditions, his knowledge reached maturity. As a result of the teaching,

original: cittaṃ vimucci, arahattaphalaṃ sacchākāsīti attho.
analyzed: cittam arahatta phalam sacchākāsi iti
translated: his mind was liberated from the taints without his taking anything as a basis, and he attained the state of arahantship in its entirety, without reserve.

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ āyasmato lakuṇḍakabhaddiyassa aññārādhanasaṅkhātaṃ atthaṃ sabbākārato viditvā tadatthadīpanaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.🔽Tattha uddhanti rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā ca. Adhoti kāmadhātuyā. Sabbadhīti sabbasmimpi🔽saṅkhāragate. Vippamuttoti pubbabhāge vikkhambhanavimuttiyā aparabhāge samucchedapaṭipassaddhivimuttīhi
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam āyasmataḥ lakuṇḍakabhaddiyassa añña ārādhana saṅkhātam attham sabba ākārataḥ viditvā tad attha dīpanam imam udānam udānesi 🔽tattha uddhanti rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā ca adhoti kāmadhātuyā sabbadhi iti sabbasmim pi 🔽saṅkhāra gate vippamuttaḥ ti pubba bhāge vikkhambhana vimuttiyā apara bhāge samuccheda paṭipassaddhi vimuttīhi
translated: Having known the meaning of this, having known in all its aspects the meaning of the Elder Lakunñaka Bhaddiya’s pleasing of another, he uttered this exalted utterance.

original: sabbappakārena vimutto. Ettha ca uddhaṃ vippamuttoti etena pañcuddhambhāgiyasaṃyojanapahānaṃ
analyzed: sabba ppakārena vimuttaḥ ettha ca uddham vippamuttaḥ ti etena pañcuddhambhāgiya saṃyojana pahānam
translated: and is released in every way.🔽And here, “released upwards” shows the abandoning of the five lower fetters,

original: dasseti. Adho vippamuttoti etena pañcorambhāgiyasaṃyojanapahānaṃ. Sabbadhi vippamuttoti
analyzed: dasseti adhas vippamutto ti etena pañcorambhāgiya saṃyojana pahānam sabbadhi vippamutto ti
translated: “released downwards” shows the abandoning of the five higher fetters, and “released in every way”

original: etena avasiṭṭhasabbākusalapahānaṃ dasseti. Atha vā uddhanti anāgatakālaggahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: etena avasiṭṭha sabba akusala pahānam dasseti atha vā uddhanti anāgata kāla ggahaṇam
translated: shows the abandoning of all the remaining unwholesome states. Or alternatively, “upwards” is the taking of the future,

original: Adhoti atītakālaggahaṇaṃ. Ubhayaggahaṇeneva tadubhayapaṭisaṃyuttattā paccuppanno
analyzed: adhas ti atīta kāla ggahaṇam ubhaya ggahaṇena iva tad ubhaya paṭisaṃyutta ttā paccuppannaḥ
translated: “downwards” is the taking of the past, and by the taking of both, the present is taken too, because it is connected with both.

original: addhā gahito hoti, tattha anāgatakālaggahaṇena anāgatakkhandhāyatanadhātuyo gahitā.
analyzed: addhā gahitaḥ hoti tattha anāgata kāla ggahaṇena anāgata kkhandha āyatana dhātuyaḥ gahitā
translated: Therein, by the taking of the future, the future aggregates, sense bases, and elements are taken.

original: Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Sabbadhīti kāmabhedādike sabbasmiṃ bhave. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ tesaṃ manussānaṃ āpānabhūmiramaṇīyesu mahāpariḷāhesu anekānatthānubandhesu
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam tesam manussānam āpānabhūmi ramaṇīyesu mahā pariḷāhesu aneka anattha anubandhesu
translated: Having known the meaning of this: having known the meaning of those people’s drinking parties, which were full of great suffering,

original: ghorāsayhakaṭukaphalesu kāmesu anādīnavadassitaṃ sabbākārato viditvā kāmānañceva
analyzed: ghorāsayha kaṭuka phalesu kāmesu anādīnava dassitam sabba ākārataḥ viditvā kāmānam ca eva
translated: He saw the danger in sensual desires, which have a terrible outcome, a bitter fruit, and he understood them in all aspects.

original: kilesānañca ādīnavavibhāvanaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: ādīnava vibhāvanam imam udānam udānesi
translated: And he uttered this exalted utterance on the analysis of the danger in sensual desires and in defilements:

original: Tattha kāmesu sattāti vatthukāmesu kilesakāmena rattā mattā sattā visattā laggā laggitā
analyzed: tattha kāmesu sattā ati vatthu kāmesu kilesa kāmena rattā mattā sattā visattā laggā laggitā
translated: Herein, in sensual desires seven times means that beings are attached, stuck, glued, bound, fastened, and tied to the sensual desires as objects by the defilement of sensual desire.

original: saṃyuttā. Kāmasaṅgasattāti tāyeva kāmasattiyā vatthukāmesu rāgasaṅgena ceva diṭṭhimānadosaavijjāsaṅgehi🔽ca sattā āsattā. Saṃyojane vajjamapassamānāti kammavaṭṭaṃ vipākavaṭṭena, bhavādike🔽vā bhavantarādīhi, satte vā dukkhehi saṃyojanato bandhanato saṃyojananāmake kāmarāgādikilesajāte
analyzed: saṃyuttā kāma saṅga sattā ati tāya iva kāma sattiyā vatthu kāmesu rāga saṅgena ca iva diṭṭhi māna dosa avijjā saṅgehi  ca sattā āsattā saṃyojane kamma vaṭṭam vipāka vaṭṭena bhava ādike  vā bhavantara ādīhi satte vā dukkhehi saṃyojanataḥ bandhanataḥ saṃyojana nāmake kāma rāga ādi kilesa jāte
translated: In the bond of sensual desires means that they are attached, stuck, glued, bound, fastened, and tied to the sensual desires as objects by the bond of lust for sensual desires and by the bonds of the defilements of false view, conceit, and ignorance.

original: saṃyojanīyesu dhammesu assādānupassitāya vaṭṭadukkhamūlabhāvādikaṃ vajjaṃ dosaṃ ādīnavaṃ
analyzed: saṃyojanīyesu dhammesu assāda anupassitāya vaṭṭa dukkha mūla bhāva ādikam vajjam dosam ādīnavam
translated: Not seeing the danger in the fetter means that they do not see the danger, the fault, the disadvantage, the disadvantageous result, in the fetter called the fetters of lust for sensual desires, etc., in the various kinds of defilements that are called fetters, because they regard things that should be avoided as profitable.🔽They do not see the danger in the fetter in the sense that they do not see the danger in the fetter as the root cause of the suffering of the round, etc.

original: apassantā. Na hi jātu saṃyojanasaṅgasattā, oghaṃ tareyyuṃ vipulaṃ mahantanti evaṃ
analyzed: a passantāḥ na hi jātu saṃyojana saṅga sattāḥ ogham tareyyum vipulam mahantanti evam
translated: They will never cross the flood so vast and great means that they will never cross the flood of sensual desires, the flood of existence, the flood of wrong view, and the flood of ignorance.

original: ādīnavadassanābhāvena saṃyojanasabhāvesu saṅgesu, saṃyojanasaṅkhātehi vā saṅgehi🔽tesaṃ visayesu tebhūmakadhammesu sattā vipulavisayatāya anādikālatāya ca vipulaṃ
analyzed: ādīnava dassana abhāvena saṃyojana sabhāvesu saṅgesu saṃyojana saṅkhātehi vā saṅgehi  tesam visayesu tebhūmaka dhammesu sattāḥ vipula visaya tāya anādi kāla tāya ca vipulam
translated: Because of the absence of the seeing of danger in the aggregates that are of the nature of the fetters, or in the aggregates called the fetters,🔽beings are attached to the things of the three planes that are the objects of the fetters. Because of their vastness and because of their beginninglessness, they are called “the great flood of sensuality.”🔽

original: vitthiṇṇaṃ mahantañca kāmādioghaṃ, saṃsāroghameva vā na kadāci tareyyuṃ, ekaṃseneva
analyzed: vitthiṇṇam mahantam ca kāma ādi ogham saṃsāra ogham eva vā na kadācid tareyyuṃ eka aṃsena iva
translated: Because of the absence of the seeing of danger, beings will never cross over the flood of sensual desire, etc., which is extensive and great because of the extensiveness of its domain and its beginninglessness.

original: tassa oghassa pāraṃ na gaccheyyunti attho.
analyzed: tassa oghassa pāram na gaccheyyunti attho
translated: The meaning is that they will never go to the far shore of that flood.

original: Tatiyasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tatiya sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the third sutta is finished.

original: 4. Dutiyasattasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya satta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The second sutta on the seven

analyzed: tasmā kāmena anandhā api andhā katā ati andhīkatā sesam anantara sutte vutta nayam eva
translated: Therefore, even though they are not blind, beings are made blind by sensual desire, and so they are “blinded by sensual desire.” The rest is in the way already stated.

analyzed: tattha hi manussānam pavatti bhikkhūhi disvā bhagavataḥ ārocitā idha bhagavatā sāmaṃyā eva
translated: For here the occurrence among human beings was reported to the Blessed One by the bhikkhus after they had seen it, while here the Blessed One saw it with his own divine eye.

analyzed: diṭṭhā ti ayam eva visesaḥ satthā sāvatthitaḥ nikkhamitvā jetavanam gacchantaḥ antarāmagge  aciravatiyam nadiyam macchabandhehi oḍḍitam kuminam pavisitvā nikkhantum a sakkonte

translated: and stretching its neck to put its mouth in the cow’s stomach. Then

analyzed: bhagavā vihāram pavisitvā pāde pakkhāletvā paññatta vara buddha āsane nisinno pacchimam
translated: the Blessed One entered the monastery, washed his feet, sat down on the prepared seat,

analyzed: tattha kāma andhā ati vatthu kāmesu kilesa kāmena andhā vicakkhukā katā jāla sañchannā

analyzed: aneka bheda bhinnesu heṭṭhu pariya vasena apara aparam uppattiyāḥ antogadhānam anattha āvahato

analyzed: ca jāla bhūtāya taṇhāya sukhuma chiddena jālena parivutaḥ viya udaka rahadaḥ sañchannā  paliguṇṭhitā ajjhotthaṭā taṇhā chadana chāditā ati taṇhā saṅkhātena chadanena sevā lapaṇakena
translated: It is as if a pond were covered, enveloped, and shrouded by a net,🔽because of craving, which is like a net.🔽  Covered by the covering of craving: as if the water were covered by a covering of moss and mud, by craving called a covering. The meaning is, concealed, hidden, shut in.

analyzed: antalikkha caro pāsaḥ yvā ayam carati mānaso
translated: “The snare that spreads in air, That lurks and watches here,

translated: Namuci, Kaṇha, pamattabandhu: these are the three names of Mara. For the Mara of defilement, like the Mara of the Devaputtas,

analyzed: tattha bandhanā iti kāma guṇa bandhanā iti atthaḥ baddhā ati niyamitā yathā kim

analyzed: yathā nāma maccha bandhakena oḍḍitassa kuminassa mukhe paviṭṭhā macchā

analyzed: tena baddhāḥ hutvā maraṇam anventi pāpuṇanti evam eva mārena oḍḍitena kāma guṇa bandhanena

analyzed: baddhāḥ ime sattāḥ jarā maraṇam anventi vaccho mātaram yathā khīra pāyī taruṇa vaccho  attanaḥ mātaram anveti anugacchati na aññam evam māra bandhana baddhā sattā saṃsāre
translated: Like a calf for milk its mother. Just as a young calf follows its mother in order to drink milk,

original: paribbhamantā maraṇameva anventi anugacchanti, na ajaraṃ amaraṇaṃ nibbānanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: paribbhamantā maraṇam eva anventi anugacchanti na ajaram amaraṇam nibbānanti adhippāyaḥ
translated: so beings, bound by the bonds of Mara, wandering in the round of rebirths, follow death, not the deathless, Nibbana, is the meaning.

analyzed: catuttha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā

translated: . The commentary on the fifth sutta

analyzed: sati sampajaññam su upaṭṭhitam katvā samāhitena cittena pade padam nikkhipantaḥ gacchati

analyzed: ohīḷenti thero tam jānitvā piṭṭhitaḥ piṭṭhitaḥ gacchati mā ime mama nissāya apuññam  pasaviṃsu iti evam te bhikkhū ca thero ca sāvatthim patvā vihāram pavisitvā yena
translated: The elder knew this and followed behind him, thinking, “Let them not make demerit by reason of me.”

analyzed: bhagavā tena upasaṅkamanti tena vuttam tena kho pana samayena āyasmā lakuṇḍakabhaddiyoti ādi  tattha dubbaṇṇam ti virūpam tenassa vaṇṇa sampattiyā saṇṭhāna sampattiyā ca abhāvam  dasseti duddasikam ti apāsādika dassanam tena assa anubyañjana sampattiyā ākāra sampattiyā

He shows by that the absence of any excellence of minor characteristics and of bearing.

translated: not knowing the elder’s virtues, treat him with contempt, taking hold of his hands, ears, and so on, and playing with him.

analyzed: na ariyā kalyāṇa puthujjanā vā
