analyzed: passatha no ti passatha nu na ca sā samāpatti sulabha rūpā yā tena bhikkhunā a samāpanna pubbā ati
translated: “Do you see?” means “Do you see?” The attainment he has reached is not an easy one to reach, for he has never before failed to attain it.

original: rūpasamāpatti arūpasamāpatti brahmavihārasamāpatti nirodhasamāpatti phalasamāpattīti
analyzed: rūpa samāpatti arūpa samāpatti brahmavihāra samāpatti nirodha samāpatti phala samāpatti iti
translated: The attainment of the material form sphere, the attainment of the immaterial form sphere, the attainment of the divine abodes, the attainment of cessation, and the attainment of fruition.

original: evaṃ pabhedā sāvakasādhāraṇā yā kāci samāpattiyo nāma, tāsu ekāpi samāpatti na sulabharūpā,
analyzed: evam sāvaka sādhāraṇā yā kāci samāpattiyaḥ nāma tāsu ekā api samāpatti na sulabha rūpā
translated: Thus, whatever kinds of attainment there are, whether shared with disciples or not, not one of them is easy to attain.

original: dullabhā, natthiyeva sā tena lakuṇḍakabhaddiyena bhikkhunā asamāpannapubbā. Etenassa🔽yaṃ vuttaṃ. “Mahiddhiko mahānubhāvo”ti, tattha mahiddhikataṃ pakāsetvā idāni mahānubhāvataṃ
analyzed: dullabhā sā tena lakuṇḍakabhaddiyena bhikkhunā a samāpanna pubbā etena assa  yam vuttam mahiddhikaḥ mahā anubhāvaḥ ti tattha mahiddhika tam pakāsetvā idāni mahā anubhāva tam
translated: They are difficult to attain. There is none that the Elder Lakuṇṭaka Bhaddiya had not already attained.🔽This is what is shown by the words, “He was powerful and mighty.”

original: dassetuṃ “yassa catthāyā”tiādimāha. Taṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayameva. Ettha ca bhagavā “eso,🔽bhikkhave, bhikkhū”tiādinā, “bhikkhave, ayaṃ bhikkhu na yo vā so vā dubbaṇṇo duddasiko
analyzed: dassetum yassa ca atthāya iti ādim āha tam heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva ettha ca bhagavā eso  bhikkhave bhikkhu iti ādinā bhikkhave ayam bhikkhu na yaḥ vā saḥ vā dubbaṇṇaḥ duddasikaḥ
translated: Having shown his great power, the Master now said, “For whose sake” in order to show his great might. The meaning of this has already been explained.🔽Here the Blessed One said, “This bhikkhu,” and so on, and “Bhikkhus, this bhikkhu is not one to be despised. He is not a bhikkhu to be despised.

original: okoṭimakoti bhikkhūnaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito āgacchatīti ca ettakena na oññātabbo, atha
analyzed: okoṭimako ti bhikkhūnam piṭṭhitaḥ piṭṭhitaḥ āgacchati iti ca ettakena na oññātabbo atha
translated: He is a bhikkhu who comes behind you, ugly, unsightly, hunchbacked.” One should not despise him because of this.

original: kho mahiddhiko mahānubhāvo, yaṃkiñci sāvakena pattabbaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ tena anuppattaṃ,
analyzed: kho mahiddhikaḥ mahā anubhāvaḥ yaṃ kiñci sāvakena pattabbam sabbam tam tena an uppattam
translated: But rather he is powerful and mighty. Whatever can be attained by a disciple, all that has been attained by him.

original: tasmā taṃ pāsāṇacchattaṃ viya garuṃ katvā oloketha, taṃ vo dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya
analyzed: tasmai tam pāsāṇa chattam viya garum katvā tam vaḥ dīgharattam hitāya sukhāya
translated: Therefore look upon him as heavy with significance, like a stone umbrella, for your welfare and happiness for a long time.

original: bhavissatī”ti dasseti.
analyzed: bhavissati iti dasseti
translated: he shows that it will be.

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ āyasmato lakuṇḍakabhaddiyassa mahiddhikatāmahānubhāvatādibhedaṃ guṇarāsiṃ sabbākārato jānitvā tadatthadīpanaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam ā yasmataḥ lakuṇḍakabhaddiyassa mahiddhika tā mahā anubhāva tā ādi bhedam guṇa rāsim sabba ākārataḥ jānitvā tad attha dīpanam imam udānam udānesi
translated: Having understood the matter: having understood in all aspects the mass of special qualities consisting in the Elder’s great spiritual power, his great influence, and so on. He uttered this utterance explaining that matter.

original: Tattha nelaṅgoti elaṃ vuccati doso, nāssa elanti nelaṃ. Kiṃ pana taṃ? Suparisuddhasīlaṃ.
analyzed: tattha na ilaṅgo ti elam vuccati doso na assa elanti na ilam kim pana tam su parisuddha sīlam
translated: Herein, nelan means ela, which is a term for hate. It is nelan because it has no ela, that is, no hate. But what is it? It is virtue that is quite purified.

original: Tañhi niddosaṭṭhena idha “nela”nti adhippetaṃ. Taṃ nelaṃ padhānabhūtaṃ aṅgaṃ etassāti
analyzed: tat hi niddosa ṭṭhena idha na ilanti adhippetam tam na ilam padhāna bhūtam aṅgam etassa ati
translated: For that is intended here by nelan in the sense of being without hate. It has the nelan as its principal part, thus it is nelan-ga.

original: nelaṅgo. So yaṃ “ratho”ti vakkhati, tena sambandho, tasmā suparisuddhasīlaṅgoti attho.
analyzed: nelaṅgo saḥ yam ratho ti vakkhati tena sambandho tasmā su parisuddha sīlaṅgo ti attho
translated: It is connected with what he calls a chariot, thus it is a chariot-part. Therefore the meaning is: a part consisting of quite purified virtue.

original: Arahattaphalasīlañhi idhādhippetaṃ. Seto pacchādo etassāti setapacchādo. Pacchādoti
analyzed: arahatta phala sīlam hi idha adhippetam seto pacchādo etassa ati seta pacchādo pacchādo ti
translated: For the virtue of the fruition of arahatship is intended here. It has a white covering, thus it is white-covered. A covering is

original: rathassa upari attharitabbakambalādi. So pana suparisuddhadhavalabhāvena seto vā
analyzed: rathassa upari attharitabba kambala ādi so pana su parisuddha dhavala bhāvena setaḥ vā
translated: a blanket, etc., to be spread over a chariot. But that is white because of its quite purified whiteness.

original: hoti rattanīlādīsu vā aññataro. Idha pana arahattaphalavimuttiyā adhippetattā suparisuddhabhāvaṃ🔽upādāya “setapacchādo”ti vuttaṃ yathā aññatrāpi “ratho sīlaparikkhāro”ti. Eko satisaṅkhāto
analyzed: hoti ratta nīla ādīsu vā aññataraḥ idha pana arahatta phala vimuttiyā adhippeta ttā su parisuddha bhāvam  upādāya seta pacchādo ti vuttam yathā aññatra api ratho sīla parikkhāro ti ekaḥ sati saṅkhāto
translated: or one of the other gems, such as sapphire, etc. But here, because of the purity of the state of liberation consisting in the fruit of arahantship, the simile of the white-clothed man is used,🔽just as elsewhere the simile of the chariot with its equipment of armor is used.🔽The chariot has one wheel, and the man who drives it is called a “one-wheeled man.”

original: aro etassāti ekāro. Vattatīti pavattati. Rathoti therassa attabhāvaṃ sandhāya vadati.
analyzed: araḥ etassa ati eka araḥ vattati iti pavattati ratho ti therassa atta bhāvam sandhāya vadati
translated: “He goes” means he proceeds. The chariot is the Elder’s own person.

original: Anīghanti niddukkhaṃ, khobhavirahitaṃ yānaṃ viya kilesaparikhobhavirahitanti attho.
analyzed: anīgham ti niddukkham khobha virahitam yānam viya kilesa parikhobha virahitam ti attho
translated: “Without fear” means without suffering, without the agitation of defilements, like a vehicle without jolting.

original: Āyantanti sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito āgacchantaṃ. Chinnasotanti pacchinnasotaṃ.
analyzed: āyantam ti sambahulānam bhikkhūnam piṭṭhitas piṭṭhitas āgacchantam chinna sotam ti pacchinna sotam
translated: “Coming” means coming behind a number of bhikkhus. “With a severed stream” means with a severed stream of defilements.

original: Pakatirathassa hi sukhapavattanatthaṃ akkhasīsesu nābhiyañca upalittānaṃ sappitelādīnaṃ
analyzed: pakati rathassa hi sukha pavattana attham akkha sīsesu nābhiyam ca upalittānam sappi tela ādīnam
translated: For in a well-oiled chariot the axle, etc., are smeared with oil, and the wheels roll on smoothly, without jolting. But in a chariot that is not well-oiled, the axle, etc., are not smeared with oil, and the wheels roll on with a jolting sound.

original: soto savanaṃ sandanaṃ hoti, tena so acchinnasoto nāma hoti. Ayaṃ pana chattiṃsatiyā
analyzed: sotoḥ savanam sandanam hoti tena saḥ acchinnasotaḥ nāma hoti ayam pana chattiṃsatiyā
translated: This Elder, however, is called “one with a severed stream” because he has severed the stream of defilements.

original: sotānaṃ anavasesato pahīnattā chinnasoto nāma hoti, taṃ chinnasotaṃ. Natthi etassa🔽bandhananti abandhano. Rathūpattharassa hi akkhena saddhiṃ niccalabhāvakaraṇatthaṃ
analyzed: sotānam anavasesataḥ pahīna ttā chinnasotaḥ nāma hoti tat chinnasotam natthi etassa  bandhanam ti abandhanaḥ rathūpattharassa hi akkhena saddhim niccala bhāva karaṇa attham
translated: He is called “one whose stream is cut off” because he has abandoned the streams of defilements without remainder. He is “one whose stream is cut off.”🔽There is no bond for him, thus he is “unbound.” For a chariot is “bound” because it has many bonds for the purpose of making it stand still together with the axle.

original: bahūni bandhanāni honti, tena so sabandhano. Ayaṃ pana sabbasaṃyojanabandhanānaṃ
analyzed: bahūni bandhanāni honti tena so sa bandhanaḥ ayam pana sabba saṃyojana bandhanānam
translated: But he is “unbound” because he has completely exhausted all the bonds of the fetters.

original: anavasesato parikkhīṇattā abandhano, taṃ abandhanaṃ. Passāti bhagavā therassa guṇehi🔽somanassappatto hutvā attānaṃ vadati.
analyzed: anavasesataḥ parikkhīṇa ttā abandhano tam abandhanam passāti bhagavā therassa guṇehi  somanassa pattaḥ hutvā attānam vadati
translated: The Blessed One sees the Elder’s virtues and becomes glad.

original: Iti satthā āyasmantaṃ lakuṇḍakabhaddiyaṃ arahattaphalasīsena sucakkaṃ, arahattaphalavimuttiyā
analyzed: iti satthā āyasmantam lakuṇḍakabhaddiyam arahatta phala sīsena su cakkam arahatta phala vimuttiyā
translated: Thus the Teacher shows the Elder Lakkhaṇa to be a well-controlled charioteer by means of the fruit of arahantship, a well-covered chariot by means of the deliverance of the fruit of arahantship,

original: suuttaracchadaṃ, sūpaṭṭhitāya satiyā svāraṃ, kilesaparikhobhābhāvena aparikhobhaṃ,
analyzed: su uttaracchadam su upaṭṭhitāya satiyā svāram kilesa parikhobha abhāvena a parikhobham
translated: a well-sounding chariot by means of the well-established mindfulness, a chariot without jolting by reason of the absence of any jolting of the defilements,

original: taṇhūpalepābhāvena anupalepaṃ, saṃyojanādīnaṃ abhāvena abandhanaṃ suparikkhittaṃ🔽suyuttaṃ ājaññarathaṃ katvā dasseti.
analyzed: taṇhu upalepa abhāvena an upalepam saṃyojana ādīnam abhāvena abandhanam su parikkhittam  su yuttam ājañña ratham katvā dasseti
translated: a chariot without splashing by reason of the absence of any splashing of craving, a well-guarded chariot by reason of the absence of the fetters, etc., and a well-yoked chariot.

original: Pañcamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pañcama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the fifth sutta is finished.

original: 6. Taṇhāsaṅkhayasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: taṇhāsaṅkhaya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 6. The explanation of the “Discourse on the Destruction of Craving”

original: 66. Chaṭṭhe aññāsikoṇḍaññoti ettha koṇḍaññoti tassāyasmato gottato āgatanāmaṃ. Sāvakesu
analyzed: chaṭṭhe ettha koṇḍañño ti tassa ayasmataḥ gottataḥ āgata nāmam sāvakesu
translated: In the sixth , “Koṇḍañña who has known” : Koṇḍañña is the name of this elder’s clan.🔽But among the disciples, he was the first to penetrate the noble truths.

original: pana sabbapaṭhamaṃ ariyasaccāni paṭivijjhīti bhagavatā “aññāsi vata, bho, koṇḍañño”ti
analyzed: pana sabba paṭhamam ariya saccāni paṭivijjhi iti bhagavatā aññāsi vata bho koṇḍañño ti
translated: The Exalted One said, “Koṇḍañña has known, indeed!”

original: vuttaudānavasena thero sāsane “aññāsikoṇḍañño”tveva paññāyittha. Taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttinti
analyzed: vutta odāna vasena thero sāsane paññāyittha taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttin ti
translated: and by the exclamation, the elder became known in the Dispensation as “Koṇḍañña who has known.”🔽The destruction of craving is Nibbāna, in which craving is destroyed and abandoned.

original: taṇhā saṅkhīyati pahīyati etthāti taṇhāsaṅkhayo, nibbānaṃ. Tasmiṃ taṇhāsaṅkhaye vimutti.🔽Taṇhā vā saṅkhīyati pahīyati etenāti taṇhāsaṅkhayo, ariyamaggo. Tassa phalabhūtā,
analyzed: taṇhā saṅkhīyati pahīyati ettha ati taṇhā saṅkhayaḥ nibbānam tasmin taṇhā saṅkhaye vimutti  taṇhā vā saṅkhīyati pahīyati etena ati taṇhā saṅkhayaḥ ariya maggo tassa phala bhūtā
translated: The liberation in that destruction of craving is the liberation in the destruction of craving.🔽Or the noble path is the destruction of craving, in which craving is destroyed and abandoned.🔽The liberation that is the fruit of that, or the culmination of that, is the liberation in the destruction of craving.

original: pariyosānabhūtā vā vimuttīti taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutti, nippariyāyena arahattaphalasamāpatti.
analyzed: pariyosāna bhūtā vā vimutti iti taṇhā saṅkhaya vimutti nippariyāyena arahatta phala samāpatti
translated: In the ultimate sense, it is the attainment of the fruit of arahantship.

original: Taṃ paccavekkhamāno nisinno hoti. Ayañhi āyasmā bahulaṃ phalasamāpattiṃ samāpajjati,
analyzed: tam paccavekkhamānaḥ nisinnaḥ hoti ayan hi āyasmā bahulam phala samāpattim samāpajjati
translated: He was sitting reflecting on that. For this venerable elder often attained the fruit attainment.

original: tasmā idhāpi evamakāsi.
analyzed: tasmai idha api evam akāsi
translated: Therefore, here too he did so.

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ aññāsikoṇḍaññattherassa aggaphalapaccavekkhaṇaṃ viditvā tadatthadīpanaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: etam attham viditvā ti etam aññāsikoṇḍañña therassa agga phala paccavekkhaṇam viditvā tad attha dīpanam imam udānam udānesi
translated: knowing the Elder Aññāsikoṇḍañña’s reviewing of the chief fruit, he uttered this exalted utterance explaining that meaning.

original: Tattha yassa mūlaṃ chamā natthīti yassa ariyapuggalassa attabhāvarukkhamūlabhūtā
analyzed: tattha yassa mūlam chamā natthi iti yassa ariya puggalassa atta bhāva rukkha mūla bhūtā
translated: Herein, he whose root and bark are gone: in the case of the tree of the person who is an ariyan disciple,🔽ignorance is the root of the tree of his selfhood,

original: avijjā, tassāva patiṭṭhā hetubhūtā āsavanīvaraṇaayonisomanasikārasaṅkhātā chamā pathavī
analyzed: avijjā tassa ava patiṭṭhā hetu bhūtā āsava nīvaraṇa ayoni soma nasikāra saṅkhātā chamā pathavī
translated: and the bark is the soil, the cause, called taints, hindrances, and wrong reflection, which is the soil, the cause, of that ignorance.

original: ca natthi aggamaggena samugghātitattā. Paṇṇā natthi kuto latāti natthi latā kuto
analyzed: ca natthi agga maggena samugghātita ttā paṇṇā natthi kutas latā ati natthi latā kutas
translated: But in his case that bark is gone too, because it has been uprooted by the path of Arahantship. He has no leaves, so how can he have creepers?🔽The construction is: he has no leaves, so how can he have creepers? He has no creepers, so how can he have leaves?

original: paṇṇāti padasambandho. Mānātimānādipabhedā sākhāpasākhādisaṅkhātā latāpi natthi,
analyzed: paṇṇā ati pada sambandhaḥ māna atimāna ādi pabhedā sākhā pasākhā ādi saṅkhātā latā api natthi
translated: He has no creepers, which are of the kind classed as branches and twigs and are of the kind classed as conceit, over-conceit, etc.,

original: kuto eva madappamādamāyāsāṭheyyādipaṇṇānīti attho. Atha vā paṇṇā natthi kuto latāti
analyzed: kutas eva mada ppamāda māyā sāṭheyya ādi paṇṇāni iti atthaḥ atha vā paṇṇā na atthi kutas latā ati
translated: so how can he have leaves, which are of the kind classed as intoxication, negligence, deceit, fraud, etc.? Or alternatively, he has no leaves, so how can he have creepers?

original: rukkhaṅkurassa vaḍḍhamānassa paṭhamaṃ paṇṇāni nibbattanti. Pacchā sākhāpasākhāsaṅkhātā
analyzed: rukkha aṅkurassa vaḍḍhamānassa paṭhamam paṇṇāni nibbattanti pacchā sākhā pasākhā saṅkhātā
translated: When the shoot of the tree grows, its leaves appear first, and afterwards the branches and twigs, which are called creepers,

original: latāti katvā vuttaṃ. Tattha yassa ariyamaggabhāvanāya asati uppajjanārahassa attabhāvarukkhassa🔽ariyamaggassa bhāvitattā yaṃ avijjāsaṅkhātaṃ mūlaṃ, tassa patiṭṭhānabhūtaṃ āsavādi🔽ca natthi. Mūlaggahaṇeneva cettha mūlakāraṇattā bījaṭṭhāniyaṃ kammaṃ tadabhāvopi
analyzed: katvā vuttam tattha yassa ariya magga bhāvanāya asati uppajjana arahassa atta bhāva rukkhassa  ariya maggassa bhāvita ttā yam avijjā saṅkhātam mūlam tassa patiṭṭhāna bhūtam āsava ādi  ca natthi mūla ggahaṇena iva ca ittha mūla kāraṇa ttā bīja ṭṭhāniyam kammam tad abhāvaḥ api
translated: and so it is said of it. Herein, the tree of existence that would arise if there were no development of the noble path🔽has no cankers, etc., which are the root, in the sense of ignorance, and the soil, in the sense of the physical base,🔽because the noble path has been developed. And since kamma is the seed in the sense of being the primary cause, it should be understood that its absence is included

original: gahitoyevāti veditabbo. Asati ca kammabīje taṃnimitto viññāṇaṅkuro, viññāṇaṅkuranimittā
analyzed: gahitaḥ yā iva ati veditabbaḥ asati ca kamma bīje tad nimittaḥ viññāṇa aṅkuraḥ viññāṇa aṅkura nimittā
translated: by the mention of the root. And when there is no seed of kamma, the sprout of consciousness, which has that as its condition, and the trunk, branches, and leaves, which have the sprout of consciousness as their condition,

original: ca nāmarūpasaḷāyatanapattasākhādayo na nibbattissantiyeva. Tena vuttaṃ – “yassa mūlaṃ
analyzed: ca nāma rūpa saṅgāyatana patta sākhā ādayaḥ na tena vuttam yassa mūlam
translated: will not come into existence. That is why it is said: “If there is no root,

original: chamā natthi, paṇṇā natthi kuto latā”ti.🔽Taṃ dhīraṃ bandhanā muttanti taṃ catubbidhasammappadhānavīriyayogena vijitamārattā
analyzed: chamā natthi paṇṇā natthi kutas latā ati  tam dhīram bandhanā tam catubbidha sammappadhāna vīriya yogena
translated: no trunk, no leaves, how can there be a creeper?”

original: dhīraṃ, tato eva sabbakilesābhisaṅkhārabandhanato muttaṃ. Ko taṃ ninditumarahatīti
analyzed: dhīram tatas eva sabba kilesa abhisaṅkhāra bandhanataḥ muttam kaḥ tam ninditum arahati iti
translated: The wise are freed from bondage: he is wise because he has conquered the enemy in the form of the fourfold right endeavour and energy. And because of that he is freed from the bondage of all the defilements and determinations.

original: ettha nti nipātamattaṃ. Evaṃ sabbakilesavippamuttaṃ sīlādianuttaraguṇasamannāgataṃ
analyzed: ettha nti nipāta mattam evam sabba kilesa vippamuttam sīla ādi anuttara guṇa samannāgatam
translated: Here the word “here” is merely a particle.

original: ko nāma viññujātiko nindituṃ garahituṃ arahati nindānimittasseva abhāvato. Devāpi
analyzed: kaḥ nāma viññu jātikaḥ ninditum garahitum arahati nindā nimittassa iva abhāvataḥ deva api
translated: Thus, who is there, who is wise, who is worthy, who is blameless, who is fit to blame and censure him who is thus completely liberated from all defilements and who is endowed with the unsurpassed qualities of virtue, etc.?🔽Even the gods praise him.

original: naṃ pasaṃsantīti aññadatthu devā sakkādayo guṇavisesavidū, apisaddena manussāpi khattiyapaṇḍitādayo
analyzed: nam pasaṃsanti iti aññadatthu devā sakka ādayaḥ guṇa visesa vidū api saddena manussā api khattiya paṇḍita ādayo
translated: The word “even” implies that men, too, the wise men such as the nobles, praise him.

original: pasaṃsanti. Kiñca bhiyyo brahmunāpi pasaṃsito mahābrahmunāpi aññehipi brahmanāgayakkhagandhabbādīhipi
analyzed: pasaṃsanti kiñca bhiyyas brahmunā api pasaṃsitaḥ mahābrahmunā api aññehi pi brahma nāga yakkha gandhabba ādīhi pi
translated: Moreover, he is praised by Brahma, by Maha Brahma, and by the other Brahmas, Nagas, Gandhabbas, etc.

original: pasaṃsito thomitoyevāti.
analyzed: pasaṃsitaḥ
translated: He is praised and extolled.

original: Chaṭṭhasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: chaṭṭha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the sixth sutta is finished.

original: 7. Papañcakhayasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The sutta on the destruction of proliferation

original: 67. Sattame papañcasaññāsaṅkhāpahānanti papañcenti yattha sayaṃ uppannā, taṃ santānaṃ
analyzed: sattame papañca saññā saṅkhā apahānam ti papañcenti yattha sayam uppannā tam santānam
translated: In the seventh sutta, the phrase “the abandoning of the proliferation of perception and the proliferation of the underlying tendency to proliferation” means that the defilements proliferate, spread out, and last long in the continuity of consciousness in which they arise.

original: vitthārenti ciraṃ ṭhapentīti papañcā, kilesā. Visesato rāgadosamohataṇhādiṭṭhimānā. Tathā hi vuttaṃ –
analyzed: vitthārenti ciram ṭhapenti iti papañcā kilesāḥ visesato rāga dosa moha taṇhā diṭṭhi mānā tathā hi vuttam
translated: They are therefore called “proliferations.” In particular, they are craving, delusion, conceit, views, and pride. For it is said:

original: “Rāgo papañco, doso papañco, moho papañco, taṇhā papañco, diṭṭhi papañco, māno papañco”ti. –🔽Apica saṃkilesaṭṭho papañcaṭṭho, kacavaraṭṭho papañcaṭṭho. Tattha rāgapapañcassa
analyzed: rāgaḥ papañcaḥ dosaḥ papañcaḥ mohaḥ papañcaḥ taṇhā papañcaḥ diṭṭhi papañcaḥ māno papañco ti  apica saṃkilesa ṭṭho papañca ṭṭho kacavara ṭṭho papañca ṭṭho tattha rāga papañcassa
translated: “Lust is a proliferation, hate is a proliferation, delusion is a proliferation, craving is a proliferation, views are a proliferation, conceit is a proliferation” .🔽Besides, the meaning of corruption is the meaning of proliferation, the meaning of refuse is the meaning of proliferation. Herein, the sign is the cause of lust- proliferation,

original: subhasaññā nimittaṃ, dosapapañcassa āghātavatthu, mohapapañcassa āsavā, taṇhāpapañcassa🔽vedanā, diṭṭhipapañcassa saññā, mānapapañcassa vitakko nimittaṃ. Tehi papañcehi sahagatā
analyzed: subha saññā nimittam dosa papañcassa āghāta vatthu moha papañcassa āsavā taṇhā papañcassa  vedanā diṭṭhi papañcassa saññā māna papañcassa vitakkaḥ nimittam tehi papañcehi sahagatā
translated: the object of irritation is the cause of hate-proliferation, the taints are the cause of delusion-proliferation,🔽feeling is the cause of craving-proliferation,🔽perception is the cause of view-proliferation,

original: saññā papañcasaññā. Papañcasaññānaṃ saṅkhā bhāgā koṭṭhāsā papañcasaññāsaṅkhā. Atthato
analyzed: saññā papañca saññā papañca saññānam saṅkhā bhāgā koṭṭhāsā papañca saññā saṅkhā atthataḥ
translated: and applied thought is the cause of conceit-proliferation. The perception associated with those proliferations is perception of proliferation. The formations together with the signs are the formations of perception of proliferation. In the sense of being a portion, a section, of them,

original: saddhiṃ nimittehi taṃtaṃpapañcassa pakkhiyo kilesagaṇo. Saññāgahaṇañcettha tassa
analyzed: saddhim nimittehi taṃ taṃ papañcassa pakkhiyaḥ kilesa gaṇaḥ saññā gahaṇam ca ittha tassa
translated: the mass of defilements together with the signs is the proliferation of such and such a proliferation.

original: nesaṃ sādhāraṇahetubhāvena. Vuttañhetaṃ – “saññānidānā hi papañcasaṅkhā”ti. Tesaṃ
analyzed: na isam sādhāraṇa hetu bhāvena vuttam ha etam saññā nidānāḥ hi papañca saṅkhāti tesam
translated: The word “perception” here includes that as a common cause. For this is said: “Proliferation of formations has perception as its source” .

original: pahānaṃ, tena tena maggena rāgādikilesānaṃ samucchedananti attho.
analyzed: pahānam tena tena maggena rāga ādi kilesānam samucchedanan ti attho
translated: The abandoning of that is the meaning of the complete destruction of lust, etc., by the various paths.

original: Tadā hi bhagavā atītāsu anekakoṭisatasahassasaṅkhāsu attano jātīsu anatthassa nimittabhūte
analyzed: tadā hi bhagavā atītāsu aneka koṭi sata sahassa saṅkhāsu attanaḥ jātīsu anatthassa nimitta bhūte
translated: For at that time the Exalted One was reviewing the defilements which had been the cause of his own countless hundreds of thousands of births in the past,

original: kilese imasmiṃ carimabhave ariyamaggena bodhimaṇḍe savāsane pahīne paccavekkhitvā
analyzed: kilese imasmin carima bhave ariya maggena bodhimaṇḍe sa vāsane pahīne paccavekkhitvā
translated: and which had been abandoned by the Noble Path at the foot of the Bodhi Tree together with their underlying tendencies.

original: sattasantānañca kilesacaritaṃ rāgādikilesasaṃkiliṭṭhaṃ kañjiyapuṇṇalābuṃ viya takkabharitacāṭiṃ
analyzed: satta santānam ca kilesa caritam rāga ādi kilesa saṃkiliṭṭham kañjiya puṇṇa lābum viya takka bharita cāṭim
translated: And he was also reviewing the defilements of other beings, which were defiling their mental streams like a gourd filled with poison, like a cloth smeared with excrement,🔽and which were difficult to remove.

original: viya vasāpītapilotikaṃ viya ca dubbinimociyaṃ disvā “evaṃ gahanaṃ nāmidaṃ kilesavaṭṭaṃ
analyzed: viya vasā pīta pilotikam viya ca dubbinimociyam disvā evam gahanam nāma idam kilesa vaṭṭam
translated: Seeing this, he thought: “This cycle of defilements is so deep and so difficult to fathom.

original: anādikālabhāvitaṃ mayhaṃ anavasesaṃ pahīnaṃ, aho suppahīna”nti uppannapītipāmojjo
analyzed: anādi kāla bhāvitam mayham anavasesam pahīnam aho su pahīnam ti uppanna pīti pāmojjaḥ
translated: But I have abandoned it completely. Oh, how well it has been abandoned!”🔽And as a result of the joy and gladness that arose in him, he uttered this exclamation.

original: udānaṃ udānesi. Tena vuttaṃ – “atha kho bhagavā attano papañcasaññāsaṅkhāpahānaṃ
analyzed: udānam udānesi tena vuttam atha kho bhagavā attanaḥ papañca saññā saṅkhā apahānam
translated: This is why it is said: “Then the Exalted One, having known the abandoning of his own conceptual thoughts and perceptions,

original: viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesī”ti.
analyzed: viditvā imam udānam udānesi iti
translated: on that occasion uttered this inspired utterance.”

original: Tattha yassa papañcā ṭhiti ca natthīti yasmā bhagavā attānameva paraṃ viya katvā
analyzed: tattha yassa ca natthi iti yasmai bhagavā attānam eva param viya katvā
translated: Herein, the words “who has no conceptual thoughts and perceptions” are said by the Exalted One with reference to himself.

original: niddisati tasmā yassa aggapuggalassa vuttalakkhaṇā papañcā, tehi katā saṃsāre ṭhiti
analyzed: niddisati tasmai yassa agga puggalassa vutta lakkhaṇā papañcā tehi katā saṃsāre ṭhiti
translated: He shows that there is no abiding in the round of rebirths for the person of highest distinction who has the characteristics already stated.

original: ca natthi. Nettiyaṃ pana “ṭhiti nāma anusayo”ti vuttaṃ. Anusayo hi bhavapavattiyā
analyzed: ca natthi nettiyam pana ṭhiti nāma anusayaḥ ti vuttam anusayaḥ hi bhava pavattiyā
translated: But in the Netti it is said: “Abiding is a latent tendency” .🔽For the latent tendency is the root of the round of rebirths.🔽They cause beings to abide in the round of rebirths, thus they are abiders .

original: mūlanti. Satte saṃsāre papañcentīti papañcā. “Papañcaṭṭhitī”ti ca pāṭho. Tassattho
analyzed: satte saṃsāre papañcenti iti papañcā papañca ṭhitī iti ca pāṭhaḥ tassa attho
translated: The reading “papañcaṭṭhiti” is also found. Its meaning is this.

original: – papañcānaṃ ṭhiti vijjamānatā maggena asamucchedo papañcaṭṭhiti, papañcā eva vā
analyzed: papañcānam ṭhiti vijjamāna tā maggena a samucchedaḥ papañca ṭhiti papañcaḥ eva vā
translated: The abiding of the abiders, i.e., the non-cutting off by the path of the existence of the abiders, is the abiding of the abiders.

original: avasiṭṭhakusalākusalavipākānaṃ pavattiyā hetubhāvato vaṭṭassa ṭhiti papañcaṭṭhiti,🔽sā yassa aggapuggalassa natthi. Sandānaṃ palighañca vītivattoti yo bandhanaṭṭhena🔽santānasadisattā “sandāna”nti laddhanāmā taṇhādiṭṭhiyo, nibbānanagarapavesanisedhanato
analyzed: avasiṭṭha kusala akusala vipākānam pavattiyāḥ hetu bhāvataḥ vaṭṭassa ṭhiti papañca ṭṭhiti  sā yassa agga puggalassa na atthi sandānam paligham ca vītivatto ti yaḥ bandhana ṭṭhena  santāna sadisa ttā sandānan ti laddha nāmā taṇhā diṭṭhiyaḥ nibbāna nagara pavesa nisedhanato
translated: Or the abiding of the round is the abiding of the abiders, since it is the cause of the occurrence of the remaining profitable, unprofitable, and functional states.🔽He has gone beyond the yoke and the fetter : craving and views, which are called the yoke because they are like a yoke since they are similar to a yoke, and which are called the fetter because they are like a fetter since they are an impediment in the sense of binding,🔽and also ignorance, which is called the fetter because it is like a fetter since it is an impediment in the sense of obstructing the entry to the city of Nibbāna,

original: palighasadisattā palighasaṅkhātaṃ avijjañca vītivatto savāsanapahānena visesato atikkanto.
analyzed: paligha sadisa ttā paligha saṅkhātam avijjam ca vītivatto sa vāsanā pahānena visesataḥ atikkanto
translated: he has gone beyond, i.e., has especially surpassed, by abandoning them together with their inherent tendencies.

original: Apare pana kodhaṃ “sandāna”nti vadanti, taṃ na gahetabbaṃ. So hi “parābhisajjanī”ti vuttoti.🔽Taṃ nittaṇhaṃ muniṃ carantanti taṃ sabbathāpi taṇhābhāvena nittaṇhaṃ, ubhayalokamunanato
analyzed: apare pana kodham sandānam ti vadanti tam na gahetabbam so hi para abhisajjanī iti vuttaḥ ti  tam nittaṇham munim tam sabbathā api taṇhā bhāvena nittaṇham
translated: But others say that anger is the “sandana” . That should not be accepted, since it is said to be “parābhisajjanī” .

original: attahitaparahitamunanato ca muniṃ, ekanteneva sabbasattahitatthaṃ catūhi iriyāpathehi
analyzed: ca munim ekantena iva sabba satta hita attham catūhi iriyāpathehi
translated: Wandering: he wanders by means of the four postures of the body,

original: nānāsamāpatticārehi anaññasādhāraṇena ñāṇacārena ca carantaṃ. Nāvajānāti sadevakopi
analyzed: nānā samāpatti cārehi anañña sādhāraṇena ñāṇa cārena ca carantam na avajānāti sa devakaḥ api
translated: by means of the various kinds of attainment, and by means of the knowledge that is not shared by others.🔽The world with its gods: the entire world of living beings together with the gods.

original: lokoti sabbo sapaññajātiko sattaloko sadevakopi sabrahmakopi na kadācipi avajānāti🔽na paribhoti, atha kho ayameva loke aggo seṭṭho uttamo pavaroti garuṃ karonto sakkaccaṃ
analyzed: loko ti sabbo sa paññajātiko satta loko sa devako api sa brahmako api na kadāci pi avajānāti  na paribhoti atha kho ayam eva loke aggaḥ seṭṭhaḥ uttamaḥ pavaroti garum karontaḥ sakkaccam
translated: The world with its Brahmās: the entire world of living beings together with the Brahmās.🔽The world with its ascetics and brahmins: the entire world of living beings together with the ascetics and brahmins.🔽The world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās: the entire world of living beings together with the gods, Māras, and Brahmās.🔽The world with its men and Maras: the entire world of living beings together with men and Māras.🔽The world with its gods, men, and Brahmas: the entire world of living beings together with the gods, men, and Brahmas.🔽The world with its ascetics, brahmins, gods, men, and Brahmas: the entire world of living beings together with the ascetics, brahmins, gods, men, and Brahmas.🔽The world with its gods, men, and Brahmas, with its ascetics and brahmins, having understood it as it really is,

original: pūjāsakkāranirato hotīti.
analyzed: pūjā sakkāra nirataḥ hoti iti
translated: the world with its gods, men, and Brahmas, with its ascetics and brahmins, he does not despise, does not treat with contempt, does not look down upon, does not disparage.

original: Sattamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sattama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The seventh sutta is finished.

original: 8. Kaccānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kaccāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the eighth sutta

original: 68. Aṭṭhame ajjhattanti ettha ayaṃ ajjhattasaddo “cha ajjhattikāni āyatanānī”tiādīsu
analyzed: aṭṭhame ajjhattam ti ettha ayam ajjhatta saddo cha ajjhattikāni āyatanāni iti ādīsu
translated: In the passage beginning “internally” the word “internally” is used in such passages as “The six internal sense bases” .

original: ajjhattajjhatte āgato. “Ajjhattā dhammā, ajjhattaṃ vā kāye kāyānupassī”tiādīsu niyakajjhatte.
analyzed: ajjhatta jjhatte āgataḥ ajjhattāḥ dhammāḥ ajjhattam vā kāye kāya anupassī iti ādīsu niyaka jjhatte
translated: “Internally and externally” : in the sense of one’s own and another’s. “Internally” in the sense of one’s own, as in the passage: “Contemplating the body as a body, internally” .

original: “Sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā ajjhattaṃ suññataṃ upasampajja viharatī”tiādīsu visayajjhatte,🔽issariyaṭṭhāneti attho. Phalasamāpatti hi buddhānaṃ issariyaṭṭhānaṃ nāma. “Tenānanda,🔽bhikkhunā tasmiṃyeva purimasmiṃ samādhinimitte ajjhattameva cittaṃ saṇṭhapetabba”ntiādīsu
analyzed: sabba nimittānam amanasikārāḥ ajjhattam suññatam upasampajja viharati itiādīsu visaya jjhatte  issariya ṭhāne ti attho phala samāpatti hi buddhānam issariya ṭṭhānam nāma tena ānanda  bhikkhunā tasmin yeva purimasmin samādhi nimitte ajjhattam eva cittam saṇṭhapetabban ti ādīsu
translated: “Internally” in the sense of the object, as in the passage: “Avoiding all signs externally” .🔽“Internally” in the sense of the domain, as in the passage: “The domain of the Tathāgata is internal” .

original: gocarajjhatte. Idhāpi gocarajjhatteyeva daṭṭhabbo. Tasmā ajjhattanti gocarajjhattabhūte
analyzed: gocara jjhatte idha api gocara jjhattā iya iva daṭṭhabbo tasmai gocara jjhatta bhūte
translated: “Internally” in the sense of the basis, as in the passage: “The mind, monks, is internally impure, and because the mind is internally impure, the wisdom therein is impure” .🔽“Internally” in the sense of the proximate, as in the passage: “One should not attend externally” .🔽“Internally” in the sense of the near, as in the passage: “One should not attend externally” .🔽“Internally” in the sense of the near, as in the passage: “One should not attend externally” .🔽“Internally” in the sense of the near, as in the passage: “One should not attend externally” .

original: kammaṭṭhānārammaṇeti vuttaṃ hoti. Parimukhanti abhimukhaṃ. Sūpaṭṭhitāyāti suṭṭhu
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna ārammaṇā iti vuttam hoti parimukham ti abhimukham su upaṭṭhitāya ati suṭṭhu
translated: “Internally” in the sense of the near, as in the passage: “One should not attend externally” .🔽“Internally” in the sense of the near, as in the passage: “One should not attend externally” .🔽“Internally” in the sense of the near, as in the passage: “One should not attend externally” .

original: upaṭṭhitāya kāyagatāya satiyā. Satisīsena cettha jhānaṃ vuttaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti
analyzed: upaṭṭhitāya kāya gatāya satiyā sati sīsena ca ittha jhānam vuttam idam vuttam hoti
translated: “Internally” in the sense of the near, as in the passage: “One should not attend externally” .

original: “ajjhattaṃ kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānavasena paṭiladdhaṃ uḷāraṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā”ti.
analyzed: ajjhattam kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhāna vasena paṭiladdham uḷāram jhānam samāpajjitvā ati
translated: “Internally” in the sense of the near, as in the passage: “One should not attend externally” .

original: Ayañhi thero bhagavati sāvatthiyaṃ viharante ekadivasaṃ sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā
analyzed: ayan hi theraḥ bhagavati sāvatthiyam viharante eka divasam sāvatthiyam piṇḍāya caritvā
translated: For this Elder, while the Blessed One was staying at Sāvatthi, had gone for alms in Sāvatthi one day,🔽and after his meal, when he had returned from his alms round, he entered the monastery,

original: pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātappaṭikkanto vihāraṃ pavisitvā bhagavato vattaṃ dassetvā divāṭṭhāne
analyzed: pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ vihāram pavisitvā bhagavataḥ vattam dassetvā divāṭṭhāne
translated: and after doing the duties to the Blessed One, he sat down in the day-time quarters

original: divāvihāraṃ nisinno nānāsamāpattīhi divasabhāgaṃ vītināmetvā sāyanhasamayaṃ vihāramajjhaṃ
analyzed: divāvihāram nisinnaḥ nānā samāpattīhi divasa bhāgam vihāra majjham
translated: and spent the day in various attainments. In the evening he came down from the monastery,

original: otaritvā bhagavati gandhakuṭiyaṃ nisinne “akālo tāva bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitu”nti
analyzed: otaritvā bhagavati gandhakuṭiyam nisinne akālaḥ tāva bhagavantam upasaṅkamitum ti
translated: and when the Blessed One was sitting in the Fragrant Cottage, he thought, “This is not the time to approach the Blessed One,”

original: gandhakuṭiyā avidūre, aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle kālaparicchedaṃ katvā yathāvuttaṃ samāpattiṃ🔽samāpajjitvā nisīdi. Satthā taṃ tathānisinnaṃ gandhakuṭiyaṃ nisinnoyeva passi. Tena
analyzed: gandhakuṭiyāḥ avidūre aññatarasmim rukkha mūle kāla paricchedam katvā yathāvuttam samāpattim  samāpajjitvā nisīdi satthā tam tathā nisinnam gandhakuṭiyam nisinnaḥ yā iva passi tena
translated: and not far from the Fragrant Cottage, at the root of a certain tree, he made a time limit and sat down in the attainment described above.

original: vuttaṃ – “tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahākaccāno…pe… sūpaṭṭhitāyā”ti.
analyzed: vuttam tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahākaccānope su upaṭṭhitāya ati
translated: The Teacher, sitting in the Fragrant Cottage, saw him sitting there in that way. Therefore it was said above: “At that time the venerable Maha Kaccana was sitting not far from the Blessed One … with perfect confidence” .

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ āyasmato mahākaccānattherassa satipaṭṭhānabhāvanāvasena
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam āyasmataḥ mahākaccāna therassa sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā vasena
translated: Having understood the meaning of this,

original: adhigataṃ jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā samāpajjanaṃ sabbākārato viditvā tadatthadīpanaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: adhigatam jhānam pādakam katvā samāpajjanam sabba ākārataḥ viditvā tad attha dīpanam imam udānam udānesi
translated: He had attained jhāna by means of the development of mindfulness occupied with the body, and he had entered upon it after discerning its meaning in all ways. He uttered this inspired utterance revealing its meaning.

original: Tattha yassa siyā sabbadā sati, satataṃ kāyagatā upaṭṭhitāti yassa āraddhavipassakassa
analyzed: tattha yassa siyā sabbadā sati satatam kāya gatā upaṭṭhitā ati yassa āraddha vipassakassa
translated: Herein, there is always mindfulness in him who has it always established in the body: in him who has begun insight,

original: ekadivasaṃ cha koṭṭhāse katvā sabbasmimpi kāle nāmarūpabhedena duvidhepi kāye gatā
analyzed: eka divasam cha koṭṭhāse katvā sabbasmin pi kāle nāma rūpa bhedena duvidhe api kāye gatā
translated: in the twofold body classed as material and immaterial, there is always mindfulness established without break,

original: kāyārammaṇā pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ aniccādisammasanavasena satataṃ nirantaraṃ
analyzed: kāya ārammaṇā pañcannam upādāna kkhandhānam anicca ādi sammasana vasena satatam nirantaram
translated: by means of the contemplation of impermanence, etc., of the five aggregates as objects of clinging,

original: sātaccābhiyogavasena sati upaṭṭhitā siyā.
analyzed: sātacca abhiyoga vasena sati upaṭṭhitā siyā
translated: and by means of the maintenance of that and the exertion for it.

original: Ayaṃ kirāyasmā paṭhamaṃ kāyagatāsatikammaṭṭhānavasena jhānaṃ nibbattetvā taṃ pādakaṃ
analyzed: ayam kira ayasmā paṭhamam kāya gata asati kammaṭṭhāna vasena jhānam nibbattetvā tam pādakam
translated: This venerable one, it seems, first produced jhāna by means of the development of mindfulness occupied with the body as meditation subject. Then, making that the basis,

original: katvā kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānamukhena vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā arahattaṃ patto. So
analyzed: katvā kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhāna mukhena vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā arahattam pattaḥ so
translated: he instigated insight by way of the contemplation of the body, and he reached Arahantship.

original: aparabhāgepi yebhuyyena tameva jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya tatheva ca vipassitvā
analyzed: apara bhāge pi yebhuyyena tam eva jhānam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya tathā iva ca vipassitvā
translated: Later, for the most part, he entered upon that same jhāna, emerged, and then contemplated the body in various ways by using insight.

original: phalasamāpattiṃ samāpajjati. Svāyaṃ yena vidhinā arahattaṃ patto, taṃ vidhiṃ dassento
analyzed: phala samāpattim samāpajjati svāyam yena vidhinā arahattam pattaḥ tam vidhim dassento
translated: The Master, showing the way in which he had attained Arahantship,

original: satthā “yassa siyā sabbadā sati, satataṃ kāyagatā upaṭṭhitā”ti vatvā tassā upaṭṭhānākāraṃ
analyzed: satthā yassa siyā sabbadā sati satatam kāya gatā upaṭṭhitā iti vatvā tassāḥ upaṭṭhāna ākāram
translated: said: “For him who has mindfulness always established, always present in body.”

original: vibhāvetuṃ “no cassa no ca me siyā, na bhavissati na ca me bhavissatī”ti āha.
analyzed: vibhāvetum no cassa no ca me siyā na bhavissati na ca me bhavissati iti āha
translated: Then he said: “May not be, may not be mine, will not be, will not be mine” in order to show the mode of its presence.

original: Tassattho dvidhā veditabbo sammasanato pubbabhāgavasena sammasanakālavasena cāti.🔽Tesu pubbabhāgavasena tāva no cassa no ca me siyāti atītakāle mama kilesakammaṃ no🔽cassa na bhaveyya ce, imasmiṃ paccuppannakāle ayaṃ attabhāvo no ca me siyā na me
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ dvidhā veditabbaḥ sammasanataḥ pubba bhāga vasena sammasana kāla vasena ca ati  tesu pubba bhāga vasena tāva no ca assa no ca me siyā ti atīta kāle mama kilesa kammam no  cassa na bhaveyya ce imasmin paccuppanna kāle ayam attabhāvo no ca me siyā na me
translated: The meaning of this should be understood in two ways, namely, as prior to absorption and as to the time of absorption.🔽As prior to absorption: “May not be, may not be mine” means that if my defilements and my kamma had not been,

original: uppajjeyya. Yasmā pana me atīte kammakilesā ahesuṃ, tasmā taṃnimitto etarahi ayaṃ
analyzed: uppajjeyya yasmā pana me atīte kamma kilesāḥ ahesum tasmā tad nimittaḥ etarahi ayaṃ
translated: “may this individual essence not be, may not be mine.” But because my defilements and kamma were in the past, therefore this individual essence of mine has come about.

original: me attabhāvo pavattati. Na bhavissati na ca me bhavissatīti imasmiṃ attabhāve paṭipakkhādhigamena
analyzed: me atta bhāvo pavattati na bhavissati na ca me bhavissati iti imasmin atta bhāve paṭipakkha adhigamena
translated: “Will not be, will not be mine” means that by the attainment of the opposite of this individual essence,

original: kilesakammaṃ na bhavissati na uppajjissati me, āyatiṃ vipākavaṭṭaṃ na ca me bhavissati🔽na me pavattissatīti. Evaṃ kālattaye kammakilesahetukaṃ idaṃ mayhaṃ attabhāvasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: kilesa kammam na bhavissati na uppajjissati me āyatim vipāka vaṭṭam na ca me bhavissati  na me pavattissati iti evam kālattaye kamma kilesa hetukam idam mayham atta bhāva saṅkhātam
translated: “No kamma-generated defilements will be, no kamma-generated kamma will be, no kamma-generated result will be for me in the future.🔽It will not occur to me.” Thus he shows the seeing of the occurrence of name-and-form with conditions in the past, present, and future in this way: “This my present five aggregates of existence called ‘I’ and ‘mine’ are not caused by an Overlord, etc., but are caused by kamma and defilements.

original: khandhapañcakaṃ, na issarādihetukaṃ, yathā ca mayhaṃ, evaṃ sabbasattānanti sappaccayanāmarūpadassanaṃ pakāsitaṃ hoti.🔽Sammasanakālavasena pana no cassa no ca me siyāti yasmā idaṃ khandhapañcakaṃ hutvā
analyzed: khandha pañcakam na issara ādi hetukam yathā ca mayham evam sabba sattānam ti sappaccaya nāmarūpa dassanam pakāsitam hoti  sammasana kāla vasena pana no ca ssa no ca me siyāti yasmai idam khandha pañcakam hutvā
translated: And just as they are for me, so they are for all beings.”

original: abhāvaṭṭhena aniccaṃ, abhiṇhapaṭipīḷanaṭṭhena dukkhaṃ, avasavattanaṭṭhena anattā,
analyzed: abhāva ṭṭhena aniccam abhiṇha paṭipīḷana ṭṭhena dukkham avasavattana ṭṭhena anattā
translated: “It will not be mine” : since this five aggregates of existence will be non-existent in the future, they are impermanent in the sense of non-existence. They are suffering in the sense of repeated oppression. They are non-self in the sense of being unable to control these three characteristics.

original: evaṃ yadi ayaṃ attā nāma nāpi khandhapañcakavinimutto koci no cassa no ca siyā na
analyzed: evam yadi ayam attā nāma na api khandha pañcaka vinimuttaḥ koci no ca assa no ca siyā na
translated: “If this so-called self were not separate from the five aggregates of existence, it would not be mine and would not be I.

original: bhaveyya, evaṃ, bhante, no ca me siyā mama santakaṃ nāma kiñci na bhaveyya. Na bhavissatīti
analyzed: bhaveyya evam bhante no ca me siyā mama santakam nāma kiñci na bhaveyya na bhavissati iti
translated: It would not be mine” : nothing called “mine” would be. “It will not be” :

original: attani attaniye bhavitabbaṃ yathā cidaṃ nāmarūpaṃ etarahi ca atīte ca attattaniyaṃ🔽suññaṃ, evaṃ na bhavissati na me bhavissati, anāgatepi khandhavinimutto attā nāma
analyzed: attani attaniye bhavitabbam yathā ca idam nāma rūpam etarahi ca atīte ca attattaniyam  suññam evam na bhavissati na me bhavissati anāgate pi khandha vinimuttaḥ attā nāma
translated: and what is not self is not his. And just as this present and past mentality-materiality are void of self and of what belongs to self,🔽so it will not exist in the future. There will be no self and no what belongs to self.

original: na koci na me bhavissati na pavattissati, tato eva kiñci palibodhaṭṭhāniyaṃ na me🔽bhavissati āyatimpi attaniyaṃ nāma na me kiñci bhavissatīti. Iminā tīsu kālesu “aha”nti
analyzed: na koci na me bhavissati na pavattissati tatas eva kiñci palibodha ṭṭhāniyam na me  bhavissati āyatimpi attaniyam nāma na me kiñci bhavissati iti iminā tīsu kālesu ahanti
translated: For there is no self that is separate from the aggregates and that will arise in the future. There will be no occurrence of it. And there will be nothing that is a basis for the assumption that “It is mine.”

original: gahetabbassa abhāvato “mama”nti gahetabbassa ca abhāvaṃ dasseti. Tena catukkoṭikā🔽suññatā pakāsitā hoti.🔽Anupubbavihāri tattha soti evaṃ tīsupi kālesu attattaniyaṃ suññataṃ tattha saṅkhāragate
analyzed: gahetabbassa abhāvataḥ gahetabbassa ca abhāvam dasseti tena catukkoṭikā  suññatā pakāsitā hoti  anupubba vihāri tattha so ti evam tīsu pi kālesu attattaniyam suññatam tattha saṅkhāra gate
translated: In the future there will be nothing that is his. By this he shows that there is no self to be found in the three periods of time and that there is no what belongs to self to be found. Thus he shows the voidness of the four-cornered argument.

original: anupassanto anukkamena udayabbayañāṇādivipassanāñāṇesu uppajjamānesu anupubbavipassanāvihāravasena
analyzed: anupassantaḥ anukkamena udaya bbaya ñāṇa ādi vipassanā ñāṇesu uppajjamānesu anupubba vipassanā vihāra vasena
translated: He contemplates as void there, the self and what belongs to self in the three periods of time. As he contemplates thus, the insight-knowledge of rise and fall, etc., arises in him in due course. He is then called “one who abides in insight.”

original: anupubbavihārī samāno. Kāleneva tare visattikanti so evaṃ vipassanaṃ matthakaṃ pāpetvā
analyzed: anupubba vihārī samānaḥ kālena iva tare visattikam ti saḥ evam vipassanam matthakam pāpetvā
translated: he crosses over the flood in time.🔽The meditator who has reached the end of insight in this way,

original: ṭhito yogāvacaro indriyānaṃ paripākagatakālena vuṭṭhānagāminiyā vipassanāya maggena
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ yogāvacaraḥ indriyānam paripāka gata kālena vuṭṭhāna gāminiyā vipassanāya maggena
translated: at the time of the maturity of the faculties, by the path of insight leading to emergence,

original: ghaṭitakālena ariyamaggassa uppattikālena sakalassa bhavattayassa saṃtananato visattikāsaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: ghaṭita kālena ariya maggassa uppatti kālena sakalassa bhava ttayassa saṃtananataḥ visattikā saṅkhātam
translated: at the time of the arising of the noble path, by the continuity of the three kinds of existence, the flood called craving,

original: taṇhaṃ tareyya, vitaritvā tassā paratīre tiṭṭheyyāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: taṇham tareyya vitaritvā tassā para tīre tiṭṭheyya ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: which is called the “flood” , he would cross over, and having crossed over, he would stand on the other shore. This is the purport.

original: Iti bhagavā aññāpadesena āyasmato mahākaccānassa arahattuppattidīpanaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: iti bhagavā añña apadesena āyasmataḥ mahākaccānassa arahatta uppatti dīpanam udānam udānesi
translated: Thus the Blessed One uttered this exalted utterance, indicating the arising of the arahantship of the venerable Mahā Kaccāna by the expression “knowing and seeing.”

original: Aṭṭhamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: aṭṭhama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the eighth sutta is finished.

original: 9. Udapānasuttavaṇṇanā🔽69. Navame mallesūti mallā nāma jānapadino rājakumārā, tesaṃ nivāso ekopi janapado
analyzed: udapāna sutta vaṇṇanā  navame mallesu iti mallāḥ nāma jānapadinaḥ rāja kumārā tesam nivāsaḥ ekaḥ api janapadaḥ
translated: The explanation of the ninth sutta🔽In the ninth sutta, the word “Malla” is the name of a clan of princes in the country. Their country is called “Malla” because it is inhabited by them.

original: ruḷhīvasena “mallā”ti vuccati, tesu mallesu, yaṃ loke “mallo”ti vuccati. Keci pana
analyzed: ruḷhī vasena mallā ti vuccati tesu mallesu yam loke mallo ti vuccati keci pana
translated: In them, the one who is called “Malla” in the world. But some say

original: “mālesū”ti paṭhanti. Cāriyaṃ caramānoti aturitacārikāvasena mahāmaṇḍalajanapadacārikaṃ
analyzed: paṭhanti cāriyam aturita cārikā vasena mahā maṇḍala janapada cārikam
translated: “Wandering on a walking tour”: wandering on a walking tour for the purpose of not being ill, wandering on a walking tour through the great circle of the country.

original: caramāno. Mahatā bhikkhusaṅghenāti aparicchedaguṇena mahantena samaṇagaṇena. Tadā🔽hi bhagavato mahābhikkhuparivāro ahosi. Thūṇaṃ nāma mallānaṃ brāhmaṇagāmoti puratthimadakkhiṇāya
analyzed: caramānaḥ mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena ati a pariccheda guṇena mahantena samaṇa gaṇena tadā  hi bhagavataḥ mahā bhikkhu parivāraḥ ahosi thūṇam nāma mallānam brāhmaṇa gāmaḥ iti puratthima dakkhiṇāya
translated: “With a great company of monks”: with a great company of monks, with a company of monks that is not limited.🔽For at that time the Blessed One had a great company of monks.

original: disāya majjhimadesassa avadhiṭṭhāne malladese thūṇanāmako brāhmaṇabahulatāya brāhmaṇagāmo.
analyzed: disāya majjhima desassa avadhi ṭhāne malla dese thūṇa nāmakaḥ brāhmaṇa bahula tāya brāhmaṇa gāmaḥ
translated: “Thūṇa” is a brahmin village of the Mallas: in the eastern southern direction, in the country of the Mallas, which is the boundary of the Middle Country, there was a brahmin village called Thūṇa because of the abundance of brahmins there.🔽“He came to”: he came to, he reached the road to the village of Thūṇa, is the meaning.🔽“The brahmins and householders”: the brahmins and householders.

original: Tadavasarīti taṃ avasari, thūṇagāmamaggaṃ pāpuṇīti attho. Assosunti suṇiṃsu, sotadvārasampattavacananigghosānusārena
analyzed: tad avasari iti tam avasari thūṇa gāma maggam pāpuṇi iti attho sota dvāra sampatta vacana nigghosa anusārena
translated: “Heard”: they heard, they knew by the sound of the voice that reached the ear door, is the meaning.🔽“Kho” is a particle that fills out the line or has the meaning of restriction.

original: jāniṃsūti attho. Khoti padapūraṇe, avadhāraṇatthe vā nipāto. Tattha avadhāraṇatthena
analyzed: jāniṃsu iti atthaḥ kho ti pada pūraṇe avadhāraṇa atthe vā nipātaḥ tattha avadhāraṇa atthena
translated: Therein, by the meaning of restriction,

original: assosuṃyeva, na tesaṃ savanantarāyo ahosīti vuttaṃ hoti. Padapūraṇena padabyañjanasiliṭṭhattamattameva.
analyzed: na tesam savana antarāyaḥ ahosi iti vuttam hoti pada pūraṇena
translated: they heard only, there was no obstruction to their hearing, is what is said. By filling out the line, it is merely the arrangement of the syllables of the words.

original: Thūṇeyyakāti thūṇagāmavāsino. Brāhmaṇagahapatikāti ettha brahmaṃ aṇantīti brāhmaṇā,
analyzed: thūṇeyyakā ati thūṇa gāma vāsinaḥ brāhmaṇagahapatikā ati ettha brahmaṃ aṇanti iti brāhmaṇāḥ
translated: The Thūneyyakas: the inhabitants of the village of Thūṇa. The brahmin householders: the brahmins are those who are purified by the Brahma world;

original: mante sajjhāyantīti attho. Idameva hi jātibrāhmaṇānaṃ nibbacanaṃ, ariyā pana bāhitapāpattā
analyzed: mante sajjhāyanti iti atthaḥ idam eva hi jāti brāhmaṇānam nibbacanam ariyā pana
translated: the meaning is, they recite the mantras. For this is the definition of brahmins by birth; but noble ones are called

original: “brāhmaṇā”ti vuccanti. Gahapatikāti khattiyabrāhmaṇe vajjetvā ye keci agāraṃ ajjhāvasantā
analyzed: brāhmaṇā ati vuccanti gahapatikā ati khattiya brāhmaṇe vajjetvā ye keci agāram ajjhāvasantā
translated: “brahmins” because they have expelled evil. The householders are those who, apart from the nobles and brahmins, live in a house;

original: vuccanti, visesato vessā. Brāhmaṇā ca gahapatikā ca brāhmaṇagahapatikā.
analyzed: vuccanti visesataḥ vessāḥ brāhmaṇā ca gahapatikā ca brāhmaṇa gahapatikā
translated: in particular, they are the tradesmen. The brahmins and the householders are the brahmin householders.

original: Idāni yamatthaṃ te assosuṃ, taṃ dassetuṃ “samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idāni yam attham te assosum tam dassetum samaṇaḥ khalu bho gotamaḥ iti ādi vuttaṃ
translated: Now, in order to show the matter which they heard, it is said: “It is reported, sirs, that the recluse Gotama. ”

original: Tattha samitapāpattā “samaṇo”ti veditabbo. Vuttañhetaṃ – “samitāssa honti pāpakā
analyzed: tattha samita pāpattā samaṇaḥ ti veditabbaḥ vuttam ha etam samitā assa honti pāpakā
translated: Herein, the recluse should be understood as one who has quieted evil,

original: akusalā dhammā”tiādi. Bhagavā ca anuttarena ariyamaggena sabbaso samitapāpo. Tenassa
analyzed: akusalāḥ dhammā ati ādi bhagavā ca anuttarena ariya maggena sabbaso samita pāpo tena assa
translated: for this is said: “Evil unprofitable ideas are quieted in him” , and so on. And the Blessed One has quieted all evil by the unsurpassed noble path. Therefore

original: yathābhuccaguṇādhigatametaṃ nāmaṃ, yadidaṃ samaṇoti. Khalūti anussavatthe nipāto.
analyzed: yathābhucca guṇa adhigatam etam nāmam yat idam samaṇa iti khalu iti anussava atthe nipātaḥ
translated: this name, namely, recluse, is rightly got by him. It is reported: the particle khalu is for emphasis.

original: Bhoti brāhmaṇajātikānaṃ jātisamudāgataṃ ālapanamattaṃ. Vuttampi cetaṃ “bhovādi nāma
analyzed: bhoti brāhmaṇa jātikānam jāti samudāgatam ālapana mattam vuttam pi ca itam bhovādi nāma
translated: “Bho” is a form of address used by people of the brahmin caste when they address one another. It is said: “Bho is used

original: so hoti, sace hoti sakiñcano”ti. Gotamoti gottavasena bhagavato parikittanaṃ. Tasmā
analyzed: saḥ hoti sace hoti sakiñcana uti gotamaḥ iti gotta vasena bhagavataḥ parikittanam tasmā
translated: when one is possessed of something.” “Gotama” is the Blessed One’s clan name. Therefore

original: “samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo”ti samaṇo kira, bho, gotamagottoti ayamettha attho. Sakyaputtoti
analyzed: samaṇaḥ khalu bho gotamaḥ iti samaṇaḥ kira bho gotama gotto ti ayam ettha attho sakya putto ti
translated: the meaning here is: “The recluse Gotama is a recluse of the Gotama clan.” “Son of Sakka”🔽is a designation of the Blessed One’s high family. “Gone forth from the Sakyan clan”

original: idaṃ pana bhagavato uccākulaparidīpanaṃ. Sakyakulā pabbajitoti saddhāpabbajitabhāvaparidīpanaṃ.
analyzed: idam pana bhagavataḥ uccā kula paridīpanam sakya kulā pabbajito ti saddhā pabbajita bhāva paridīpanam
translated: is a designation of his going forth out of faith.

original: Kenaci pārijuññena anabhibhūto aparikkhīṇaṃyeva taṃ kulaṃ pahāya nekkhammādhigamasaddhāya🔽pabbajitoti vuttaṃ hoti. Udapānaṃ tiṇassa ca bhusassa ca yāva mukhato pūresunti pānīyakūpaṃ
analyzed: kenacid pārijuññena an abhibhūtaḥ a parikkhīṇam yeva tam kulam pahāya nekkhamma adhigama saddhāya  pabbajitoti vuttam hoti udapānam tiṇassa ca bhusassa ca yāva mukhataḥ pūresunti pānīya kūpam
translated: He went forth out of faith, abandoning a clan that was not impoverished, not overcome by any misfortune.🔽“They filled the well up to the brim with grass and chaff” means that they filled the water-well

original: tiṇena ca bhusena ca mukhappamāṇena vaḍḍhesuṃ, tiṇādīni pakkhipitvā kūpaṃ pidahiṃsūti attho.
analyzed: tiṇena ca bhusena ca mukha ppamāṇena vaḍḍhesum tiṇa ādīni pakkhipitvā kūpam pidahiṃsu iti attho
translated: with grass and chaff up to the mouth of the well. The meaning is that they covered the well by throwing in grass and so forth.

original: Tassa kira gāmassa bahi bhagavato āgamanamagge brāhmaṇānaṃ paribhogabhūto eko udapāno
analyzed: tassa kira gāmassa bahi bhagavataḥ āgamana magge brāhmaṇānam paribhoga bhūtaḥ ekaḥ udapānaḥ
translated: It seems that on the road by which the Exalted One was to enter the village there was a well belonging to the brahmins, which they used for their own purposes.

original: ahosi. Taṃ ṭhapetvā tattha sabbāni kūpataḷākādīni udakaṭṭhānāni tadā visukkhāni nirudakāni
analyzed: ahosi tam ṭhapetvā tattha sabbāni kūpa taḷāka ādīni udaka ṭṭhānāni tadā visukkhāni nirudakāni
translated: Apart from that, all the other water-sources in the village, such as the ponds and tanks, were dry and empty.

original: ahesuṃ. Atha thūṇeyyakā ratanattaye appasannā maccherapakatā bhagavato āgamanaṃ sutvā🔽“sace samaṇo gotamo sasāvako imaṃ gāmaṃ pavisitvā dvīhatīhaṃ vaseyya, sabbaṃ imaṃ
analyzed: ahesum atha thūṇeyyakāḥ rata nattaye appasannāḥ maccherapakatāḥ bhagavataḥ āgamanam sutvā  sace samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ sa sāvakaḥ imam gāmam pavisitvā dvīhatīham vaseyya sabbam imam
translated: Then the people of Thūṇa, who were not devoted to the Three Jewels and were full of greed, heard that the Exalted One was coming.

original: janaṃ attano vacane ṭhapeyya, tato brāhmaṇadhammo patiṭṭhaṃ na labheyyā”ti tattha
analyzed: janam attanaḥ vacane ṭhapeyya tatas brāhmaṇa dhammo patiṭṭham na labheyya ati tattha
translated: “If the ascetic Gotama enters this village with his disciples and stays here for two or three days, he will win over all the people to his own views. Then the brahminical doctrine will not be established here.”

original: bhagavato avāsāya parisakkantā “imasmiṃ gāme aññattha udakaṃ natthi, amuṃ udapānaṃ
analyzed: bhagavataḥ a vāsāya parisakkantāḥ imasmin gāme aññattha udakam natthi amum udapānaṃ
translated: So they gathered together to prevent the Exalted One from staying there. “There is no water in this village except for that well.

original: aparibhogaṃ karissāma, evaṃ samaṇo gotamo sasāvako imaṃ gāmaṃ na pavisissatī”ti sammantayitvā
analyzed: a paribhogam karissāmaḥ evam samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ sa sāvakaḥ imam gāmam na pavisissati iti sammantayitvā
translated: We will make it unusable. In this way the ascetic Gotama with his disciples will not enter the village.”

original: sabbe gāmavāsino sattāhassa udakaṃ gahetvā cāṭiādīni pūretvā udapānaṃ tiṇena ca bhusena
analyzed: sabbe gāma vāsino satta ahasse udakam gahetvā cāṭi ādīni pūretvā udapānam tiṇena ca bhusena
translated: Having thus agreed, all the villagers took water for seven days, filled their water-pots and so on, and covered the well with grass and rubbish.

original: ca pidahiṃsu. Tena vuttaṃ – “udapānaṃ tiṇassa ca bhusassa ca yāva mukhato pūresuṃ,
analyzed: ca pidahiṃsu tena vuttam udapānam tiṇassa ca bhusassa ca yāva mukhataḥ pūresuṃ
translated: and they filled the mouth of the well with grass and chaff.

original: ‘mā te muṇḍakā samaṇakā pānīyaṃ apaṃsū”’ti.
analyzed: mā te muṇḍakā samaṇakā pānīyam
translated: ‘Don’t let those shaveling petty ascetics drink our water.’

original: Tattha muṇḍakā samaṇakāti muṇḍe “muṇḍā”ti samaṇe “samaṇā”ti vattuṃ vaṭṭeyya, te pana
analyzed: tattha muṇḍakā samaṇakā ati muṇḍe muṇḍā ati samaṇe samaṇā ati vattum vaṭṭeyya te pana
translated: Herein, ‘shaveling petty ascetics’ : it is proper to say ‘shaveling’ for ‘shaveling’ and ‘ascetic’ for ‘ascetic’,

analyzed: yasmai pana te imasmin atta bhāve ariya phalāni ratanattayam payirupāsiṃsu
