original: hutvā attano ambavane satthuvasanānucchavikaṃ gandhakuṭiṃ, bhikkhusaṅghassa ca rattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhānaupaṭṭhānasālākuṭimaṇḍapacaṅkamanādike🔽ca sampādetvā pākāraparikkhittaṃ dvārakoṭṭhakayuttaṃ vihāraṃ katvā buddhappamukhassa
analyzed: hutvā attanaḥ ambavane satthu vasana anucchavikam gandha kuṭim bhikkhu saṅghassa ca ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭṭhāna upaṭṭhāna sālā kuṭi maṇḍapa caṅkamana ādike  ca sampādetvā pākāra parikkhittam dvāra koṭṭhaka yuttam vihāram katvā buddha ppamukhassa
translated: After making a fragrant chamber suitable for the Master’s residence in his own mango grove, and also night quarters for the bhikkhu community, day quarters, attendance halls, huts, pavilions, and walking-meditation paths, etc.,

original: saṅghassa niyyādesi. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “tatra sudaṃ bhagavā pāvāyaṃ viharati🔽cundassa kammāraputtassa ambavane”ti.
analyzed: saṅghassa niyyādesi tam sandhāya vuttam tatra sudam bhagavā pāvāyam viharati  cundassa kammāra puttassa ambavane ti
translated: he had a monastery built, surrounded by a wall, with a gatehouse, and dedicated it to the community headed by the Buddha. It is in reference to this that it is said: “The Blessed One was staying at Pāvā in Cunda the smith’s mango grove” .

original: Paṭiyādāpetvāti sampādetvā. “Sūkaramaddavanti sūkarassa mudusiniddhaṃ pavattamaṃsa”nti
analyzed: paṭiyādāpetvā ati sampādetvā sūkara maddavanti sūkarassa mudu siniddham pavattam aṃsanti
translated: “Having had prepared” : having made ready. “Tender pork” is the tender, soft, fresh meat of a pig.

original: mahāaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Keci pana “sūkaramaddavanti na sūkaramaṃsaṃ, sūkarehi madditavaṃsakaḷīro”ti
analyzed: mahā aṭṭhakathā ayam vuttam keci pana sūkara maddavanti na sūkara maṃsam sūkarehi maddita vaṃsa kaḷīraḥ ti
translated: This is said in the Mahā-aṭṭhakathā. But some say that “tender pork” is not pork but a kind of bamboo shoot that is pounded by pigs .

original: vadanti. Aññe “sūkarehi madditappadese jātaṃ ahichattaka”nti. Apare pana “sūkaramaddavaṃ🔽nāma ekaṃ rasāyana”nti bhaṇiṃsu. Tañhi cundo kammāraputto “ajja bhagavā parinibbāyissatī”ti
analyzed: vadanti aññe sūkarehi maddita ppadese jātam ahichattakanti apare pana sūkara maddavam  nāma ekam rasāyananti bhaṇiṃsu tat hi cundaḥ kammāra putto ajja bhagavā parinibbāyissati iti
translated: Some say that it was produced in the place where the pigs were trampled. Others say that it was a kind of elixir.

original: sutvā “appeva nāma naṃ paribhuñjitvā cirataraṃ tiṭṭheyyā”ti satthu cirajīvitukamyatāya adāsīti vadanti.
analyzed: sutvā appā iva nāma nam paribhuñjitvā cirataram tiṭṭheyya ati satthu cira jīvitu kamyatāya adāsi iti vadanti
translated: For Cunda the Smith, having heard that the Blessed One would attain final Nibbāna that day, gave it to the Blessed One, thinking: “If he eats it, he will live longer.”

original: Tena maṃ parivisāti tena mamaṃ bhojehi. Kasmā bhagavā evamāha? Parānuddayatāya. Tañca
analyzed: tena mam tena bhojehi kasmai bhagavā evam āha tat ca
translated: “Serve it to me” means “Serve it to me.” Why did the Blessed One say this? Out of compassion for others.

original: kāraṇaṃ pāḷiyaṃ vuttameva. Tena abhihaṭabhikkhāya paresaṃ aparibhogārahato ca tathā🔽vattuṃ vaṭṭatīti dassitaṃ hoti. Tasmiṃ kira sūkaramaddave dvisahassadīpaparivāresu
analyzed: kāraṇam pāḷiyam vuttam eva tena abhihaṭa bhikkhāya paresam a paribhoga arahataḥ ca tathā  vattum vaṭṭati iti dassitam hoti tasmin kira sūkara maddave dvi sahassa dīpa parivāresu
translated: And the reason is stated in the text itself. It shows that it is proper to say so in order to show that the food brought by others is not fit to be eaten.

original: catūsu mahādīpesu devatā ojaṃ pakkhipiṃsu. Tasmā taṃ añño koci sammā jīrāpetuṃ na
analyzed: catūsu mahā dīpesu devatāḥ ojam pakkhipiṃsu tasmā tam añño koci sammā jīrāpetum na
translated: It is said that in that pig’s delight the deities infused potency, in the four great continents surrounded by two thousand islands. Therefore no one else was able to digest it properly.

original: sakkoti, tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā parūpavādamocanatthaṃ “nāhaṃ taṃ, cunda, passāmī”tiādinā🔽sīhanādaṃ nadi. Ye hi pare upavadeyyuṃ “attanā paribhuttāvasesaṃ neva bhikkhūnaṃ,
analyzed: sakko ti tam attham pakāsento satthā parūpavāda mocana attham na aham tam cunda passāmi itiādinā  sīhanādam nadi ye hi pare upavadeyyum attanā paribhutta avasesam na iva bhikkhūnam
translated: In order to free himself from the censure of others, the Teacher, in the passage beginning with the words, “Cunda, I do not see,”

original: na aññesaṃ manussānaṃ adāsi, āvāṭe nikhaṇāpetvā vināsesī”ti, “tesaṃ vacanokāso mā
analyzed: na aññesam manussānam adāsi āvāṭe nikhaṇāpetvā vināsesi iti tesam vacana ukāsaḥ mā
translated: utters his lion’s roar. If others should censure him, saying, “He did not give the remainder of his meal to the bhikkhus or to other people, but had it thrown away and wasted,” then let there be no occasion for their words.

original: hotū”ti parūpavādamocanatthaṃ sīhanādaṃ nadi.🔽Tattha sadevaketiādīsu saha devehīti sadevako, saha mārenāti samārako, saha brahmunāti🔽sabrahmako, saha samaṇabrāhmaṇehīti sassamaṇabrāhmaṇī, pajātattā pajā, saha devamanussehīti
analyzed: hotu uti parūpavāda mocana attham sīhanādam nadi  tattha sa devaka iti ādīsu saha deva ihi iti sa devakaḥ saha mārena ati sa mārakaḥ saha brahmunā ati  sabrahmakaḥ saha samaṇa brāhmaṇehi iti sā samaṇa brāhmaṇī pajāta ttā pajā saha deva manussehi iti
translated: In order to free himself from the censure of others, he utters his lion’s roar.

original: sadevamanussā. Tasmiṃ sadevake loke…pe… sadevamanussāya. Tattha sadevakavacanena
analyzed: sa deva manussā tasmin sa devake lokepe sa deva manussāya tattha sa devaka vacanena
translated: In the passage beginning with the words, “In this world with its gods,” etc., the expression “with its gods” means “together with the gods.” “With Mara” means “together with Mara.” “With Brahma” means “together with Brahma.” “With ascetics and brahmins” means “together with ascetics and brahmins.” “With the world of beings” means “with the world of beings.” “With gods and men” means “together with gods and men.” In this world with its gods, etc., … in this generation with its gods and men. Here, by the expression “with its gods,”

original: pañcakāmāvacaradevaggahaṇaṃ, samārakavacanena chaṭṭhakāmāvacaradevaggahaṇaṃ, sabrahmakavacanena
analyzed: pañca kāmāvacara deva ggahaṇam sa māraka vacanena chaṭṭha kāmāvacara deva ggahaṇam sa brahmaka vacanena
translated: the five classes of gods of the sense-sphere are included. By the expression “with Mara,” the six classes of gods of the sense-sphere are included. By the expression “with Brahma,”

original: brahmakāyikādibrahmaggahaṇaṃ, sassamaṇabrāhmaṇīvacanena sāsanassa paccatthikapaccāmittasamaṇabrāhmaṇaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: brahmakāyika ādi brahma ggahaṇam sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇī vacanena sa asanassa paccatthika pacca amitta samaṇa brāhmaṇa ggahaṇam
translated: The words “with Brahmā” include the Brahmā-world, and the words “with ascetics and brahmans” include ascetics and brahmins who are opponents and enemies of the Dispensation.

original: samitapāpabāhitapāpasamaṇabrāhmaṇaggahaṇañca, pajāvacanena sattalokaggahaṇaṃ, sadevamanussavacanena
analyzed: samita pāpa bāhita pāpa samaṇa brāhmaṇa ggahaṇam ca pajā vacanena satta loka ggahaṇam sa deva manussa vacanena
translated: The words “with good and bad” include ascetics and brahmins who are good and bad. The words “with the people” include the world of beings. The words “with gods and men” include gods by general consent and the rest of men.

original: sammutidevaavasesamanussaggahaṇaṃ. Evamettha tīhi padehi okāsalokavasena, dvīhi pajāvasena
analyzed: evam ettha tīhi padehi okāsa loka vasena dvīhi pajā vasena
translated: Thus the world of beings should be understood as included by three terms according to the world of location, by two terms according to the world of beings,

original: sattaloko gahitoti veditabbo. Aparo nayo – sadevakavacanena arūpāvacaraloko gahito,🔽samārakavacanena chakāmāvacaradevaloko, sabrahmakavacanena rūpī brahmaloko, sassamaṇabrāhmaṇavacanena
analyzed: satta lokaḥ gahito ti veditabbaḥ aparaḥ nayaḥ sa devaka vacanena arūpāvacara lokaḥ gahito  sa māraka vacanena sa brahmaka vacanena rūpī brahma lokaḥ sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇa vacanena
translated: and by two terms according to the world of ideas. Another method: the words “with gods” include the immaterial world;

original: catuparisavasena sammutidevehi saha manussaloko, avasesasattaloko vā gahitoti veditabbo.
analyzed: catu parisa vasena sammuti devehi saha manussa lokaḥ avasesa satta lokaḥ vā gahitaḥ ti veditabbo
translated: the words “with Māra” include the six divine worlds of the sense sphere; the words “with Brahmā” include the fine-material world of Brahmās; the words “with ascetics and brahmins” include the world of gods by general consent together with the human world, or the rest of the world of beings.

original: Bhuttāvissāti bhuttavato. Kharoti pharuso. Ābādhoti visabhāgarogo. Pabāḷhāti balavatiyo.
analyzed: bhuttāvissāti bhuttavataḥ kharo ati pharusaḥ ābādho ati visa bhāga rogo balavatiyaḥ
translated: “When he has eaten” : when he has eaten as much as he needs. “Rough” : harsh. “Sickness” : an illness that is not normal. “Violent” : strong.

original: Māraṇantikāti maraṇantā maraṇasamīpapāpanasamatthā. Sato sampajāno adhivāsesīti satiṃ🔽upaṭṭhitaṃ katvā ñāṇena paricchinditvā adhivāsesi. Avihaññamānoti vedanānuvattanavasena🔽asallakkhitadhammo viya aparāparaṃ parivattanaṃ akaronto apīḷiyamāno adukkhiyamāno🔽viya adhivāsesi. Bhagavato hi veḷuvagāmakeyeva tā vedanā uppannā, samāpattibalena
analyzed: māraṇantikā ati maraṇa antā maraṇa samīpa pāpana samatthā sataḥ sampajānaḥ adhivāsesi iti satim  upaṭṭhitam katvā ñāṇena paricchinditvā adhivāsesi a vihaññamānaḥ ti vedanā anuvattana vasena  a sallakkhita dhammaḥ viya apara aparam parivattanam a karontaḥ a pīḷiyamānaḥ a dukkhiyamānaḥ  viya adhivāsesi bhagavataḥ hi tā vedanā uppannā samāpatti balena
translated: “Fatal” : capable of bringing death, capable of bringing the evil of death. “Endured” : he endured them with mindfulness established and with knowledge discerning them. “Without being hurt” : without being affected by the feelings, as one who has not discerned the Dhamma is by the succession of thoughts. “Without being afflicted” : without being oppressed, without being pained. For the Blessed One endured them as if he were not being hurt or afflicted.🔽🔽The Blessed One’s feelings arose only in the village of Veḷuvana. He endured them by the power of his attainment.

original: pana vikkhambhitā yāva parinibbānadivasā na uppajjiṃsu divase divase samāpattīhi🔽paṭipaṇāmanato. Taṃ divasaṃ pana parinibbāyitukāmo “koṭisahassahatthīnaṃ balaṃ dhārentānaṃ🔽vajirasaṅghātasamānakāyānaṃ aparimitakālaṃ upacitapuññasambhārānampi bhave sati evarūpā🔽vedanā pavattanti, kimaṅgaṃ pana aññesa”nti sattānaṃ saṃvegajananatthaṃ samāpattiṃ
analyzed: pana vikkhambhitāḥ yāva parinibbāna divasāḥ na uppajjiṃsu divase divase samāpattīhi 🔽paṭipaṇāmanataḥ tam divasam pana parinibbāyitu kāmo koṭi sahassa hatthīnam balam dhārentānam 🔽aparimita kālam bhave sati evarūpā 🔽vedanā pavattanti kimaṅgam pana aññesanti sattānam saṃvega janana attham samāpattim
translated: “Fatal” : capable of bringing death, capable of bringing nearness to death, capable of bringing about evil. “Endured” : he endured them with mindfulness established and with knowledge discerning. “Without being hurt” : without being affected by the pain, without being turned about by the pain, without being oppressed by the pain, without being afflicted by the pain. For the Blessed One endured the pain as if it were a matter of no concern, as if it were a matter of no importance. For the Blessed One had already attained the supreme state of sublime peace, the supreme state of sublime security, the supreme state of sublime purity, the supreme state of sublime excellence. But the Blessed One endured the pain in order to generate disgust in beings, in order to generate a sense of urgency in beings, in order to generate a sense of disenchantment in beings. For the Blessed One had already attained the supreme state of sublime peace, the supreme state of sublime security, the supreme state of sublime purity, the supreme state of sublime excellence. But the Blessed One endured the pain in order to generate disgust in beings, in order to generate a sense of urgency in beings, in order to generate a sense of disenchantment in beings. For the Blessed One had already attained the supreme state of sublime peace, the supreme state of sublime security, the supreme state of sublime purity, the supreme state of sublime excellence. But the Blessed One endured the pain in order to generate disgust in beings, in order to generate a sense of urgency in beings, in order to generate a sense of disenchantment in beings.

original: na samāpajji, tena vedanā kharā vattiṃsu. Āyāmāti ehi yāma.
analyzed: na samāpajji tena vedanā kharā vattiṃsu āyāma ati ehi yāma
translated: and he did not attain it, and so painful feelings arose in him. ‘Come’: let us go.

original: Cundassa bhattaṃ bhuñjitvātiādikā aparabhāge dhammasaṅgāhakehi ṭhapitā gāthā. Tattha
analyzed: cundassa bhattam bhuñjitvā ati ādikā apara bhāge dhamma saṅgāhakehi ṭhapitā gāthā tattha
translated: After the meal of Cunda the Smith: the verses set out later by the Dhamma-preservers. Herein,

original: bhuttassa ca sūkaramaddavenāti bhuttassa udapādi, na pana bhuttapaccayā. Yadi hi🔽abhuttassa uppajjissā, atikharo abhavissā, siniddhabhojanaṃ pana bhuttattā tanukā
analyzed: bhuttassa ca sūkara maddavena ati bhuttassa udapādi na pana bhutta paccayā yadi hi  a bhuttassa uppajjissā ati kharaḥ abhavissā siniddha bhojanam pana bhutta ttā tanukā
translated: after eating: arose after eating, but not as a result of eating. For if it had arisen

original: vedanā ahosi, teneva padasā gantuṃ asakkhi. Etena yvāyaṃ “yassa taṃ paribhuttaṃ sammā🔽pariṇāmaṃ gaccheyya aññatra tathāgatassā”ti sīhanādo nadito, tassa sātthakatā dassitā.🔽Buddhānañhi aṭṭhāne gajjitaṃ nāma natthi. Yasmā taṃ paribhuttaṃ bhagavato na kiñci
analyzed: vedanā ahosi tena iva padasā gantum asakkhi etena yvā ayam yassa tam paribhuttam sammā  pariṇāmam gaccheyya aññatra tathāgatassa ati sīha nādaḥ naditaḥ tassa sātthaka tā dassitā  buddhānam hi aṭṭhāne gajjitam nāma natthi yasmā tam paribhuttam bhagavataḥ na kiñci
translated: in one who had not eaten, it would have been very painful indeed. But because he had eaten soft food, the feeling was🔽mild, and so he was unable to go on foot. And by this it is shown that the lion’s roar uttered by the Blessed One in the passage beginning ‘Were it to be digested in him, it would be well, but if not, then as to that man … ’ is not without fruit.

original: vikāraṃ uppādesi, kammena pana laddhokāsena uppādiyamānaṃ vikāraṃ appamattatāya upasamento
analyzed: vikāram uppādesi kammena pana laddha ukāsena uppādiyamānam vikāram appamatta tāya upasamento
translated: For the Buddhas do not roar without reason. Since that food caused no change in the Blessed One at all, he was showing that he was able to endure any change that might have arisen through the opportunity afforded by the kamma.

original: sarīre balaṃ uppādesi, yena yathā vakkhamānaṃ tividhaṃ payojanaṃ sampādesi, tasmā
analyzed: sarīre balam uppādesi yena yathā vakkhamānam tividham payojanam sampādesi tasmai
translated: He generated strength in his body, by means of which he accomplished the three purposes as they will be described.

original: sammadeva taṃ pariṇāmaṃ gataṃ, māraṇantikattā pana vedanānaṃ aviññātaṃ apākaṭaṃ ahosīti.🔽Viriccamānoti abhiṇhaṃ pavattalohitavirecanova samāno. Avocāti attanā icchitaṭṭhāne
analyzed: sammat eva tam pariṇāmam gatam māraṇa antika ttā pana vedanānam aviññātam apākaṭam ahosi iti  viriccamānaḥ iti abhiṇham pavatta lohita virecanā uva samānaḥ avoca iti attanā icchita ṭṭhāne
translated: Therefore, it was only right that he should have done so. But because the feelings were on the point of death, they were not recognized or made plain.🔽“He was having a hemorrhage”: he was having a hemorrhage of blood that occurred frequently.

original: parinibbānatthāya evamāha.
analyzed: parinibbāna atthāya evam āha
translated: “He said”: he said this for the purpose of attaining final Nibbāna in the place he had chosen.

original: Kasmā pana bhagavā evaṃ roge uppanne kusināraṃ agamāsi, kiṃ aññattha na sakkā parinibbāyitunti?
analyzed: kasmā pana bhagavā evam roge uppanne kusināram agamāsi kim aññattha na sakkā parinibbāyitunti
translated: Why did the Exalted One go to Kusinārā when he became ill? Why was it not possible for him to attain final Nibbāna elsewhere?

original: Parinibbāyituṃ nāma na katthaci na sakkā, evaṃ pana cintesi – mayi kusināraṃ gate🔽mahāsudassanasuttadesanāya aṭṭhuppatti bhavissati, tāya yā devaloke anubhavitabbasadisā
analyzed: parinibbāyitum nāma na katthaci na sakkā evam pana cintesi mayi kusināram gate  mahāsudassana sutta desanāya aṭṭhuppatti bhavissati tāya yā deva loke anubhavitabba sadisā
translated: It is not possible to attain final Nibbāna anywhere. But he thought: “When I go to Kusinārā,🔽the occasion will arise for teaching the Mahāsudassana Sutta. I will teach it, embellishing it with two recitations,

original: sampatti manussaloke mayā anubhūtā, taṃ dvīhi bhāṇavārehi paṭimaṇḍetvā desessāmi,
analyzed: sampatti manussa loke mayā anubhūtā tam dvīhi bhāṇavārehi paṭimaṇḍetvā desessāmi
translated: and I will say: ‘The kind of prosperity that is to be experienced in the heavenly world has been experienced by me in the human world. ’

original: taṃ sutvā bahū janā kusalaṃ kattabbaṃ maññissanti. Subhaddopi kattha maṃ upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: tam sutvā bahū janā kusalam kattabbam maññissanti subhaddaḥ api kattha mama upasaṅkamitvā
translated: and hearing it, many people will think that merit should be made. And Subhadda, after approaching me,

original: pañhaṃ pucchitvā vissajjanapariyosāne saraṇesu patiṭṭhāya pabbajitvā laddhūpasampado
analyzed: pañham pucchitvā vissajjana pariyosāne saraṇesu patiṭṭhāya pabbajitvā laddha upasampadaḥ
translated: will ask a question, and at the end of the answer he will be established in the refuges, and after going forth he will attain perfection.

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ bhāvetvā mayi dharanteyeva arahattaṃ patvā pacchimasāvako nāma bhavissati.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam bhāvetvā mayi arahattam patvā pacchimasāvakaḥ nāma bhavissati
translated: And he will be known as the last disciple.

original: Aññattha mayi parinibbute dhātunimittaṃ mahākalaho bhavissati, lohitaṃ nadī viya🔽sandissati. Kusinārāyaṃ pana parinibbute doṇabrāhmaṇo taṃ vivādaṃ vūpasametvā dhātuyo
analyzed: aññattha mayi parinibbute dhātu nimittam mahā kalahaḥ bhavissati lohitam nadī viya  sandissati kusinārāyam pana parinibbute doṇa brāhmaṇaḥ tam vivādam vūpasametvā
translated: But if I were to attain final Nibbāna elsewhere, there would be a great dispute over the relics, and blood would flow as in a river,

original: vibhajitvā dassatīti imāni tīṇi kāraṇāni passanto bhagavā mahatā ussāhena kusināraṃ agamāsi.🔽Iṅghāti codanatthe nipāto. Kilantosmīti parissanto asmi. Tena yathāvuttavedanānaṃ
analyzed: vibhajitvā dassati iti imāni tīṇi kāraṇāni passantaḥ bhagavā mahatā ussāhena kusināram agamāsi  iṅghā iti codana tthe nipātaḥ kilantaḥ asmi iti parissantaḥ asmi tena yathāvutta vedanānam
translated: but if I attain final Nibbāna at Kusinārā, the brahmin Dona will settle the dispute and distribute the relics. Seeing these three reasons, the Fortunate One went to Kusinārā with great effort.

original: balavabhāvaṃ eva dasseti. Bhagavā hi attano ānubhāvena tadā padasā agamāsi, aññesaṃ
analyzed: balava bhāvam eva dasseti bhagavā hi attanaḥ ānubhāvena tadā padasā agamāsi aññesam
translated: The indeclinable ‘iṅgha’ is in the sense of urging. ‘I am tired’ means I am exhausted. By this he shows the strength of the feelings he had at that time. For the Fortunate One went on foot by his own power, but the others🔽went by the power of the Fortunate One.

original: pana yathā paduddhārampi kātuṃ na sakkā, tathā vedanā tikhiṇā kharā kaṭukā vattiṃsu.
analyzed: pana yathā paduddhāram pi kātum na sakkā tathā vedanā tikhiṇā kharā kaṭukā vattiṃsu
translated: but they were so sharp, harsh, and bitter that he could not even recite the alphabet.

original: Tenevāha “nisīdissāmī”ti.
analyzed: tena iva āha nisīdissāmi iti
translated: That is why he said: “I will sit down.”

original: Idānīti adhunā. Luḷitanti madditaṃ viya ākulaṃ. Āvilanti ālulaṃ. Acchodakāti tanupasannasalilā.
analyzed: idāni iti adhunā madditam viyaḥ ākulam āvilanti ālulam acchodakāti tanu upasanna salilā
translated: “Now”: at that time. “Sluggish”: as if beaten down, agitated. “Turbid”: agitated. “With clear water”: with water that is fine and pure.

original: Sātodakāti madhuratoyā. Sītodakāti sītalajalā. Setodakāti nikkaddamā. Udakañhi sabhāvato
analyzed: sāta udakā ati madhura toyā sīta udakā ati sītala jalā sāta udakā ati nikkaddamā udakañhi
translated: “Sweet water”: with water that is sweet-tasting. “Cool water”: with cool water. “Clear water”: with water that is free from muddiness.

original: setavaṇṇaṃ, bhūmivasena kaddamāvilatāya ca aññādisaṃ hoti, kakudhāpi nadī vimalavālikā
analyzed: seta vaṇṇam bhūmi vasena kaddama āvila tāya ca aññādisam hoti nadī vimala vālikā
translated: For water is white in its natural colour, but it becomes of a different appearance through being mixed with the muddiness of the earth.🔽The Kakudha River, too, flows white, being mixed with pure sand.

original: samokiṇṇā setavaṇṇā sandati. Tena vuttaṃ “setodakā”ti. Supatitthāti sundaratitthā.
analyzed: samokiṇṇā seta vaṇṇā sandati tena vuttam seta udakā ati supatitthā ati sundaratitthā
translated: That is why it is said: “Clear water.” “With good fords”: with beautiful fords.

original: Ramaṇīyāti manoharabhūmibhāgatāya ramitabbā yathāvuttaudakasampattiyā ca manoramā.
analyzed: ramaṇīyā ati manohara bhūmi bhāga tāya ramitabbā yathāvutta odaka sampattiyā ca manoramā
translated: “Delightful”: delightful because of the beauty of the land and because of the possession of the water already mentioned.

original: Kilantosmi cundaka, nipajjissāmīti tathāgatassa hi –🔽“Kāḷāvakañca gaṅgeyyaṃ, paṇḍaraṃ tambapiṅgalaṃ;
analyzed: kilantaḥ asmi cundaka nipajjissāmi iti tathāgatassa hi 🔽kāḷāvakam ca gaṅgeyyam paṇḍaram tamba piṅgalam
translated: “I am tired, Cundaka, I will lie down.” For the Tathāgata thought:

original: Gandhamaṅgalahemañca, uposathachaddantime dasā”ti. –🔽Evaṃ vuttesu dasasu hatthikulesu kāḷāvakasaṅkhātānaṃ yaṃ dasannaṃ pakatihatthīnaṃ
analyzed: gandha maṅgala hemañcaḥ uposatha chaddantime dasāti  evam vuttesu dasasu hatthi kulesu kāḷāvaka saṅkhātānam yam dasannam pakati hatthīnam
translated: and the Gandhamangala and the Hemañña and the Uposatha and the Chaddanta and the Timedasa.”🔽Of these ten royal breeds of elephants, the strength of ten ordinary elephants of the kind called “black-backed”

original: balaṃ, taṃ ekassa gaṅgeyyassāti evaṃ dasaguṇitāya gaṇanāya pakatihatthīnaṃ koṭisahassabalappamāṇaṃ🔽sarīrabalaṃ. Taṃ sabbampi tasmiṃ divase pacchābhattato paṭṭhāya caṅgavāre pakkhittaudakaṃ🔽viya parikkhayaṃ gataṃ. Pāvāya tigāvute kusinārā. Etasmiṃ antare pañcavīsatiyā ṭhānesu
analyzed: balam tam ekassa gaṅgeyyassa ati evam dasa guṇitāya gaṇanāya pakati hatthīnam koṭi sahassa bala ppamāṇam  sarīra balam tam sabbam pi tasmin divase pacchābhattataḥ paṭṭhāya caṅgavāre pakkhitta udakam  viya parikkhayam gatam pāvāya tigāvute kusinārāḥ etasmin antare pañcavīsatiyāḥ ṭhānesu
translated: is equal to that of one elephant of the breed called “Gajapati.” By this method of calculation the physical strength of ordinary elephants, which is a thousand koṭis in amount,🔽was all exhausted in him on that day, like water poured into a leaky vessel. Pāvā was three gavutes from Kusinārā. The Blessed One,

original: nisīditvā mahantaṃ ussāhaṃ katvā āgacchanto sūriyatthaṅgamanavelāya bhagavā kusināraṃ
analyzed: nisīditvā mahantam ussāham katvā āgacchantaḥ sūriyatthaṅgamana velāya bhagavā kusināram
translated: having sat down on the way at twenty-five places and having gone on with great effort, reached Kusinārā at sunset.

original: pāpuṇīti evaṃ “rogo nāma sabbaṃ ārogyaṃ maddanto āgacchatī”ti imamatthaṃ dassento
analyzed: pāpuṇi iti evam rogaḥ nāma sabbam ārogyam maddantaḥ āgacchati iti imam attham dassento
translated: Thus showing the meaning “Sickness comes destroying all health,”

original: sadevakassa lokassa saṃvegakaraṃ vācaṃ bhāsanto “kilantosmi, cundaka, nipajjissāmī”ti āha.
analyzed: sa devakassa lokassa saṃvega karam vācam bhāsantaḥ kilantaḥ asmi cundaka nipajjissāmi iti āha
translated: and speaking words that caused a thrill in the world with its gods, he said, “I am tired, Cundaka, I will lie down.”

original: Sīhaseyyanti ettha kāmabhogīseyyā petaseyyā tathāgataseyyā sīhaseyyāti catasso seyyā.
analyzed: sīha seyyanti ettha kāmabhogī seyyā peta seyyā tathāgata seyyā sīha seyyā ati catasso seyyā
translated: “Lion-like posture” : there are four postures: the posture of the sensualist, the posture of the ghost, the posture of the Tathāgata, and the lion-like posture.

original: Tattha “yebhuyyena, bhikkhave, kāmabhogī vāmena passena seyyaṃ kappentī”ti ayaṃ kāmabhogīseyyā.
analyzed: tattha yebhuyyena bhikkhave kāma bhogī vāmena passena seyyam kappenti iti ayam kāma bhogīseyyā
translated: Herein, the posture of the sensualist is this: “Monks, sensualists usually lie down on their left side.”

original: “Yebhuyyena, bhikkhave, petā uttānā sentī”ti ayaṃ petaseyyā. Catutthajjhānaṃ tathāgataseyyā.
analyzed: yebhuyyena bhikkhave petāḥ uttānāḥ senti iti ayaṃ peta seyyā catuttha jhānam tathāgata seyyā
translated: The posture of the ghost is this: “Monks, ghosts usually lie down face downwards.” The fourth jhāna is the posture of the Tathāgata.

original: “Sīho, bhikkhave, migarājā dakkhiṇena passena seyyaṃ kappetī”ti ayaṃ sīhaseyyā. Ayañhi
analyzed: sīhaḥ bhikkhave miga rājā dakkhiṇena passena seyyam kappeti iti ayam sīha seyyā ayam hi
translated: The lion-like posture is this: “Monks, the lion, king of beasts, lies down covering both feet.” This is

original: tejussadairiyāpathattā uttamaseyyā nāma. Tena vuttaṃ – “dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṃ🔽kappesī”ti. Pāde pādanti dakkhiṇapāde vāmapādaṃ. Accādhāyāti atiādhāya, gopphakaṃ🔽atikkamma ṭhapetvā. Gopphakena hi gopphake, jāṇunā jāṇumhi saṅghaṭṭiyamāne abhiṇhaṃ
analyzed: tejussa dairiyā pathattā uttamaseyyā nāma tena vuttam dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyam  kappesi iti pāde pādanti dakkhiṇa pāde vāma pādam accādhāya ati atiādhāya gopphakam  atikkamma ṭhapetvā gopphakena hi gopphake jāṇunā jāṇumhi saṅghaṭṭiyamāne abhiṇham
translated: called the supreme posture because it is the posture of the supreme jhāna. Therefore it is said: “He lay down on his right side in the lion-like posture,🔽placing one foot on the other.” “Placing one foot on the other” means placing the right foot on the left thigh, not allowing it to hang down.

original: vedanā uppajjanti, seyyā phāsukā na hoti. Yathā pana na saṅghaṭṭeti, evaṃ atikkamma
analyzed: vedanāḥ uppajjanti seyyā phāsukā na hoti yathā pana na saṅghaṭṭeti evam atikkamma
translated: For if the ankle of the right foot is allowed to hang down, it is likely to become painful. But if it is placed on the left thigh, it does not become painful.

original: ṭhapite vedanā nuppajjanti, seyyā phāsukā hoti. Tasmā evaṃ nipajji.
analyzed: ṭhapite vedanā nuppajjanti seyyā phāsukā hoti tasmai evam nipajji
translated: and when it was so placed, the pain did not arise, and he felt better. That is why he lay down.

original: Gantvāna buddhoti imā gāthā aparabhāge dhammasaṅgāhakehi ṭhapitā. Tattha nadikanti
analyzed: gantvāna buddhaḥ ti imāḥ gāthāḥ aparabhāge dhamma saṅgāhakehi ṭhapitā tattha nadikam ti
translated: The Buddha went and sat down on the seat prepared for him. The verses beginning with the words “The Buddha, the unsurpassed Trainer of men to be tamed” were spoken by the disciples who were the custodians of the Dhamma at a later period.🔽Herein, the river is the river.

original: nadiṃ. Appaṭimodha loketi appaṭimo idha imasmiṃ sadevake loke. Nhatvā ca pivitvā
analyzed: nadim appaṭimaḥ udha loka iti appaṭimaḥ idha imasmin sa devake loke nhatvā ca pivitvā
translated: The unsurpassed One in the world: the unsurpassed One in this world with its gods.🔽Having bathed and drunk,

original: cudatārīti gattānaṃ sītikaraṇavasena nhatvā ca pānīyaṃ pivitvā ca nadito uttari.
analyzed: gattānam sītikaraṇa vasena ca pānīyam pivitvā ca naditaḥ uttari
translated: he crossed over the river.

original: Tadā kira bhagavati nhāyante antonadiyaṃ macchakacchapā, udakaṃ, ubhosu tīresu vanasaṇḍo,🔽sabbo ca so bhūmibhāgoti sabbaṃ suvaṇṇavaṇṇameva ahosi. Purakkhatoti guṇavisiṭṭhasattuttamagarubhāvato
analyzed: tadā kira bhagavati nhāyante antonadiyam maccha kacchapāḥ udakam ubhosu tīresu  sabbaḥ ca so bhūmi bhāgaḥ ti sabbam suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam eva ahosi purakkhato ti guṇa visiṭṭha sattu ttama garu bhāvato
translated: It seems that while the Blessed One was bathing in the river, there were fish and turtles in the water, and on both banks there were groves,🔽and all that land was of golden colour.🔽Honoured: because of his being the most excellent of beings, distinguished by special qualities, he was honoured by the world with its gods, by means of worship and respect.

original: sadevakena lokena pūjāsammānavasena purakkhato. Bhikkhugaṇassa majjheti bhikkhusaṅghassa
analyzed: sa devakena lokena pūjā sammāna vasena purakkhataḥ bhikkhu gaṇassa majjheti bhikkhu saṅghassa
translated: In the midst of the community of bhikkhus: in the midst of the community of bhikkhus.

original: majjhe. Tadā bhikkhū bhagavato vedanānaṃ adhimattabhāvaṃ viditvā āsannā hutvā samantato
analyzed: majjhe tadā bhikkhū bhagavataḥ vedanānaṃ adhimatta bhāvam viditvā āsannāḥ hutvā samantataḥ
translated: At that time, the bhikkhus, having understood that the Blessed One’s pain was severe, stood close by him on all sides,

original: parivāretvāva gacchanti. Satthāti diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikaparamatthehi sattānaṃ🔽anusāsanato satthā. Pavattā bhagavā idha dhammeti bhāgyavantatādīhi bhagavā idha
analyzed: parivāretvā ava gacchanti satthā ati diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika paramatthehi sattānam  anusāsanataḥ satthā pavattā bhagavā idha dhamme iti bhāgyavanta tā ādīhi bhagavā idha
translated: and they went along surrounding him. Teacher: because he teaches beings the highest good of this life and the life to come.

original: sīlādisāsanadhamme pavattā, dhamme vā caturāsītidhammakkhandhasahassāni pavattā pavattetā.🔽Ambavananti tassā eva nadiyā tīre ambavanaṃ. Āmantayi cundakanti tasmiṃ kira khaṇe
analyzed: sīla ādi sāsana dhamme pavattā dhamme vā caturāsīti dhammakkhandha sahassāni pavattā pavattetā  ambavananti tassāḥ eva nadiyāḥ tīre ambavanam cundakanti tasmin kira khaṇe
translated: The Blessed One is the one who has gone forth in this Dhamma: because the Blessed One has gone forth in the Dhamma of virtue, etc., which is taught here, or because he has gone forth in the eighty-four thousand aggregates of dhamma that constitute the Dhamma.

original: āyasmā ānando udakasāṭikaṃ pīḷento ohīyi, cundakatthero samīpe ahosi. Tasmā taṃ bhagavā
analyzed: āyasmai ānandaḥ udaka sāṭikam pīḍentaḥ cundaka thero samīpe ahosi tasmā tam bhagavā
translated: The mango grove: a mango grove on the bank of that river. He addressed Cundaka: it seems that at that moment the venerable Ananda was lagging behind, pressing his water- strainer, and the elder Cundaka was near him. Therefore the Blessed One addressed him.

original: āmantayi. Pamukhe nisīdīti vattasīsena satthu purato nisīdi “kiṃ nu kho satthā āṇāpetī”ti.
analyzed: āmantayi pamukhe nisīdi iti vatta sīsena satthu puratas nisīdi kim nu kho satthā āṇāpeti iti
translated: Sit down in front: he sat down in front of the Teacher with his head bowed down, thinking, “What does the Teacher want? ”

original: Ettāvatā dhammabhaṇḍāgāriko anuppatto. Evaṃ anuppattaṃ atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi.
analyzed: ettāvatā dhammabhaṇḍāgārikaḥ an uppattaḥ evam an uppattam atha kho bhagavā āyasmantam ānandam āmantesi
translated: Up to this point the treasurer of the Dhamma has arrived. When he had arrived, then the Blessed One addressed the venerable Ananda.

original: Upadaheyyāti uppādeyya, vippaṭisārassa uppādako koci puriso siyā api bhaveyya. Alābhāti
analyzed: upadaheyya ati uppādeyya vippaṭisārassa uppādako koci puriso siyā api bhaveyya alābhā ati
translated: ‘Would be a cause for remorse’: would be a cause for regret. ‘There might be a man’: there might be some man who would cause remorse. ‘No gain’:

original: ye aññesaṃ dānaṃ dadantānaṃ dānānisaṃsasaṅkhātā lābhā honti, te alābhā. Dulladdhanti
analyzed: ye aññesam dānam dadantānam dāna anisaṃsa saṅkhātāḥ lābhāḥ honti te alābhāḥ
translated: the gains that are the benefits of giving to others are no gain for you. ‘Hard to get’:

original: puññavisesena laddhampi manussattaṃ dulladdhaṃ. Yassa teti yassa tava. Uttaṇḍulaṃ🔽vā atikilinnaṃ vā ko taṃ jānāti, kīdisampi pacchimaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjitvā tathāgato🔽parinibbuto, addhā tena yaṃ vā taṃ vā dinnaṃ bhavissatīti. Lābhāti diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikā
analyzed: puñña visesena laddham api manussa ttam dulladdham yassa te ti yassa tava uttaṇḍulam  vā ati kilinnam vā kaḥ tam jānāti kīdisam pi pacchimam piṇḍapātam bhuñjitvā tathāgataḥ  parinibbutaḥ addhā tena yam vā tam vā dinnam bhavissati iti diṭṭhadhammika samparāyikā
translated: human birth, which is obtained through special merit, is hard to get for you. ‘What you ate’:

original: dānānisaṃsasaṅkhātā lābhā. Suladdhanti tuyhaṃ manussattaṃ suladdhaṃ. Sammukhāti sammukhato,🔽na anussavena na paramparāyāti attho. Metanti me etaṃ mayā etaṃ. Dvemeti dve ime.
analyzed: dāna anisaṃsa saṅkhātāḥ lābhāḥ su laddhanti tuyham manussattam su laddham sammukhā ati sammukhatas  na anussavena na paramparāya ati attho mā itanti me etam mayā etam dvema iti dve ime
translated: what you ate, whether it was rice with curry or just plain rice, who knows? The Tathāgata attained Nibbāna after eating such and such a last meal. Surely what you gave must have been that.’ ‘Gain’: the gains that are the benefits of giving, whether in this very life or in some future life. ‘Well-gotten’: your human birth is well-gotten. ‘Face to face’: face to face,

original: Samasamaphalāti sabbākārena samānaphalā.
analyzed: sama sama phalā ati sabba ākārena samāna phalā
translated: not by hearsay or tradition. ‘Mine’: this is mine. ‘These two’: these two. ‘Equal in fruit’: equal in fruit in every way.

original: Nanu ca yaṃ sujātāya dinnaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjitvā tathāgato abhisambuddho, taṃ kilesānaṃ
analyzed: nanu ca yam sujātāya dinnam piṇḍapātam bhuñjitvā tathāgataḥ abhisambuddhaḥ tam kilesānam
translated: Did not the Blessed One become enlightened after eating the alms food given by Sujātā?

original: appahīnakāle dānaṃ, idaṃ pana cundassa dānaṃ khīṇāsavakāle, kasmā etāni samaphalānīti?🔽Parinibbānasamatāya samāpattisamatāya anussaraṇasamatāya ca. Bhagavā hi sujātāya
analyzed: appahīna kāle dānam idam pana cundassa dānam khīṇāsava kāle kasmai etāni sama phalāni iti  parinibbāna samatāya samāpatti samatāya anussaraṇa samatāya ca bhagavā hi sujātāya
translated: That gift was given at a time when the defilements had not been abandoned, but this gift was given at a time when the defilements had been abandoned. Why are they equal in fruit?

original: dinnaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjitvā saupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbuto, cundena dinnaṃ
analyzed: dinnam piṇḍapātam bhuñjitvā sa aupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbutaḥ cundena dinnam
translated: Because of the equality of final Nibbāna, the equality of attainment, and the equality of recollection. For the Blessed One became finally emancipated in the Nibbāna element without residue of clinging after eating the alms food given by Sujātā,

original: bhuñjitvā anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbutoti evaṃ parinibbānasamatāyapi samaphalāni.
analyzed: bhuñjitvā anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbutaḥ ti evam sama phalāni
translated: and he became finally emancipated in the Nibbāna element without residue of clinging after eating the alms food given by Cunda. Thus they are equal in fruit because of the equality of final Nibbāna.

original: Abhisambujjhanadivase ca aggamaggassa hetubhūtā catuvīsatikoṭisatasahassasaṅkhā samāpattiyo
analyzed: abhisambujjhana divase ca aggamaggassa hetu bhūtā catuvīsati koṭi sata sahassa saṅkhā samāpattiyaḥ
translated: And on the day of his enlightenment he attained the thirty-four jhānas consisting of the four jhānas of the four paths, the four jhānas of the four fruits, and the twenty-four jhānas of the four immaterial states in each of the six sense-sphere jhānas.

original: samāpajji, parinibbānadivasepi sabbā tā samāpajji. Evaṃ samāpattisamatāyapi samaphalāni.
analyzed: samāpajji parinibbāna divase pi sabbā tā samāpajji evam samāpatti sama tāya api sama phalāni
translated: And on the day of his final Nibbāna he again attained all those jhānas. Thus they are equal in fruit because of the equality of attainment.

original: Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: And this was said by the Blessed One:

original: “Yassa cetaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjitvā anuttaraṃ appamāṇaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharati, appamāṇo tassa puññābhisando kusalābhisando”tiādi. –
analyzed: yassa cetam piṇḍapātam paribhuñjitvā anuttaram appamāṇam cetosamādhim upasampajja viharati appamāṇaḥ tassa puñña abhisando kusala abhisando tiādi
translated: “And if anyone, having eaten of this almsfood, should attain the supreme, immeasurable concentration of mind, the merit of that person would be immeasurable.”

original: Sujātā ca aparabhāge assosi “na kira sā rukkhadevatā, bodhisatto kiresa, taṃ kira
analyzed: sujātā ca aparabhāge assosi na kira sā rukkha devatā bodhisatto kiresa tam kira
translated: Later on Sujātā heard that it was not a tree-spirit but a Bodhisatta who had eaten her almsfood, and that

original: piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjitvā anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho, sattasattāhaṃ kirassa
analyzed: piṇḍapātam paribhuñjitvā anuttaram sammāsambodhim abhisambuddhaḥ satta sattāham kirassa
translated: having eaten it he had attained supreme enlightenment. For seven days, it was said,

original: tena yāpanā ahosī”ti. Tassā idaṃ sutvā “lābhā vata me”ti anussarantiyā balavapītisomanassaṃ🔽udapādi. Cundassapi aparabhāge “avasānapiṇḍapāto kira mayā dinno, dhammasīsaṃ kira🔽mayā gahitaṃ, mayhaṃ kira piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjitvā satthā attanā cirakālābhipatthitāya
analyzed: tena yāpanā ahosi iti tassāḥ idam sutvā lābhāḥ vata mā iti anussarantiyāḥ balava pīti somanassam  udapādi cundassa api aparabhāge avasāna piṇḍapātaḥ kira mayā dinnaḥ dhamma sīsam kira  mayā gahitam kira piṇḍapātam paribhuñjitvā satthā attanā cira kāla abhipatthitāya
translated: he had lived on it. She thought, “How fortunate I am!” and as she recalled the incident a powerful sense of spiritual joy and happiness

original: anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbuto”ti sutvā “lābhā vata me”ti anussarato balavapītisomanassaṃ
analyzed: an upādisesāya nibbāna dhātuyā parinibbuto ti sutvā lābhāḥ vata me iti anussarataḥ balava pīti somanassam
translated: arose in her. Later on Cunda heard that the last almsfood he had given had been eaten by the Teacher, that the “head of the Dhamma” had been taken by him, and that having eaten his almsfood the Teacher had attained final Nibbāna in the Nibbāna-element without residue of conditioning. He thought, “How fortunate I am!” and as he recalled the incident a powerful sense of spiritual joy and happiness arose in him.

original: udapādi. Evaṃ anussaraṇasamatāyapi samaphalāni dvepi piṇḍapātadānānīti veditabbāni.
analyzed: udapādi evam sama phalāni dve api piṇḍapāta dānāni iti veditabbāni
translated: and it occurred to him. So it should be understood that the two gifts of alms food have the same result because of the equality of their arousing of recollection.

original: Āyusaṃvattanikanti dīghāyukasaṃvattanikaṃ. Upacitanti pasutaṃ uppāditaṃ. Yasasaṃvattanikanti parivārasaṃvattanikaṃ. Ādhipateyyasaṃvattanikanti seṭṭhabhāvasaṃvattanikaṃ.
analyzed: āyu saṃvattanikanti dīgha āyuka saṃvattanikam upacitanti pasutam uppāditam yasa saṃvattanikanti parivāra saṃvattanikam ādhipateyya saṃvattanikanti seṭṭha bhāva saṃvattanikam
translated: “Conducive to long life”: conducive to long life span. “Built up”: accumulated, produced. “Conducive to fame”: conducive to a retinue. “Conducive to sovereignty”: conducive to the state of a master.

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ dānassa mahapphalatañceva sīlādiguṇehi attano ca anuttaradakkhiṇeyyabhāvaṃ
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam dānassa mahapphala tam ca iva sīla ādi guṇehi attano ca anuttara dakkhiṇeyya bhāvam
translated: Having understood the meaning: having understood the meaning of the great fruit of the gift and his own worthiness of offerings through the special qualities of virtue, etc.,

original: anupādāparinibbānañcāti tividhampi atthaṃ sabbākārato viditvā tadatthadīpanaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.🔽Tattha dadato puññaṃ pavaḍḍhatīti dānaṃ dentassa cittasampattiyā ca dakkhiṇeyyasampattiyā
analyzed: anupādā parinibbānam ca ati tividham pi attham sabba ākārataḥ viditvā tad attha dīpanam imam udānam udānesi  tattha dadataḥ puññam pavaḍḍhati iti dānam dentassa citta sampattiyā ca dakkhiṇeyya sampattiyā
translated: and the final Nibbāna without clinging, in all its aspects. Having understood the meaning in this threefold sense, he uttered this exalted utterance expressing that meaning.

original: ca dānamayaṃ puññaṃ upacīyati, mahapphalatarañca mahānisaṃsatarañca hotīti attho.
analyzed: ca dāna mayam puññam upacīyati mahapphalataram ca mahā nisaṃsataram ca hoti iti attho
translated: Herein, as to the words “merit grows for one who gives”: the meaning is that the merit consisting in giving increases and becomes more fruitful and more beneficial for one who gives when his mental qualities are good and when he is worthy of offerings.

original: Atha vā dadato puññaṃ pavaḍḍhatīti deyyadhammaṃ pariccajanto pariccāgacetanāya bahulīkatāya
analyzed: atha vā dadataḥ puññam pavaḍḍhati iti deyya dhammam pariccajantaḥ pariccāga cetanāya bahulīkatāya
translated: Or else, “merit grows for one who gives” means that as one who gives, by the repetition of the thought of giving up,

original: anukkamena sabbattha anāpattibahulo suvisuddhasīlaṃ rakkhitvā samathavipassanañca
analyzed: anukkamena sabbattha anāpatti bahulaḥ su visuddha sīlam rakkhitvā samatha vipassanam ca
translated: gradually becomes one who is not at fault in all things, and having guarded his virtue well, he is able to develop serenity and insight.

original: bhāvetuṃ sakkotīti tassa dānādivasena tividhampi puññaṃ abhivaḍḍhatīti evamettha
analyzed: bhāvetum sakkoti iti tassa dāna ādi vasena tividham pi puññam abhivaḍḍhati iti evam ettha
translated: Thus his merit grows in the three ways beginning with giving. This is how the meaning should be understood here.

original: attho veditabbo. Saṃyamatoti sīlasaṃyamena saṃyamantassa, saṃvare ṭhitassāti attho.
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbo saṃyamato ti sīla saṃyamena saṃyamantassa saṃvare ṭhitassa ati attho
translated: “For one restrained, hatred does not increase”: for one restrained by the restraint of virtue, for one who abides in restraint, is the meaning.

original: Veraṃ na cīyatīti pañcavidhaveraṃ na pavaḍḍhati, adosapadhānattā vā adhisīlassa kāyavācācittehi
analyzed: veram na cīyati iti pañcavidha veram na pavaḍḍhati a dosa padhāna ttā vā adhi sīlassa kāya vācā cittehi
translated: “Hatred does not increase”: the five kinds of hatred do not increase. Or, because of the predominance of non-hate, hatred does not increase in one who is restrained in virtue.

original: sayaṃmanto suvisuddhasīlo khantibahulatāya kenaci veraṃ na karoti, kuto tassa upacayo.
analyzed: sayaṃmantaḥ su visuddha sīlo khanti bahula tāya kenaci veram na karoti kutas tassa upacayo
translated: Since he is well restrained in body, speech, and mind, and since he is well purified in virtue, and since he is abundant in patience, he does not make hatred towards anyone. How then can it increase?

original: Tasmā tassa saṃyamato saṃyamantassa, saṃyamahetu vā veraṃ na cīyati. Kusalo ca jahāti
analyzed: tasmā tassa saṃyamataḥ saṃyamantassa saṃyama hetu vā veram na cīyati kusalaḥ ca jahāti
translated: Therefore, “for one restrained, hatred does not increase.”

original: pāpakanti kusalo pana ñāṇasampanno suvisuddhasīle patiṭṭhito aṭṭhatiṃsāya ārammaṇesu
analyzed: kusalaḥ pana ñāṇa sampanno su visuddha sīle patiṭṭhitaḥ aṭṭhatiṃsāya ārammaṇesu
translated: “The skillful one abandons evil”: but the skillful one, who is endowed with knowledge, who is well established in well purified virtue, who is abundant in patience, and who is endowed with the virtue of abandoning evil, abandons evil.

original: attano anurūpaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā upacārappanābhedaṃ jhānaṃ sampādento pāpakaṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ anurūpam kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā upacāra ppanā bhedam jhānam sampādento pāpakam
translated: He abandons, he surrenders, the evil unwholesome states beginning with lust by suppressing them with the supramundane path.

original: lāmakaṃ kāmacchandādiakusalaṃ vikkhambhanavasena jahāti pariccajati. So tameva jhānaṃ🔽pādakaṃ katvā saṅkhāresu khayavayaṃ paṭṭhapetvā vipassanāya kammaṃ karonto vipassanaṃ🔽ussukkāpetvā ariyamaggena anavasesaṃ pāpakaṃ lāmakaṃ akusalaṃ samucchedavasena jahāti.
analyzed: lāmakam kāmacchanda ādi akusalam vikkhambhana vasena jahāti pariccajati saḥ tam eva jhānam  pādakam katvā saṅkhāresu khaya vayam paṭṭhapetvā vipassanāya kammam karontaḥ vipassanam  ussukkāpetvā ariya maggena anavasesam pāpakam lāmakam akusalam samuccheda vasena jahāti
translated: He abandons, he surrenders, the evil unwholesome states beginning with lust by cutting them off without remainder by means of the noble path, making his jhāna the basis for insight and arousing insight by discerning the rise and fall of formations.🔽He is quenched by the destruction of lust, hatred, and delusion.🔽Having thus abandoned the evil, he is quenched by the destruction of lust, etc., that is, by the extinction of defilements without remainder,

original: Rāgadosamohakkhayā sa nibbutoti so evaṃ pāpakaṃ pajahitvā rāgādīnaṃ khayā anavasesakilesanibbānena,🔽tato paraṃ khandhanibbānena ca nibbuto hotīti evaṃ bhagavā cundassa ca dakkhiṇasampattiṃ,
analyzed: rāga dosa moha khayā sa nibbutaḥ ti saḥ evam pāpakam pajahitvā rāga ādīnam khayā anavasesa kilesa nibbānena  tatas param khandha nibbānena ca nibbutaḥ hoti iti evam bhagavā cundassa ca dakkhiṇa sampattim
translated: and by the subsequent extinction of the aggregates. This is the burden he has laid down.

original: attano ca dakkhiṇeyyasampattiṃ nissāya pītivegavissaṭṭhaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: attanaḥ ca dakkhiṇeyya sampattim nissāya pīti vega vissaṭṭham udānam udānesi
translated: Thus the Exalted One uttered this Solemn Utterance, a spontaneous utterance inspired by the excellence of the offering made by Cunda and by his own excellence as a recipient of offerings.

original: Pañcamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pañcama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the fifth sutta is finished.

original: 6. Pāṭaligāmiyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pāṭaligāmiya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Pāṭaligāmiyā Sutta

analyzed: chaṭṭhe magadhesu iti magadha raṭṭhe mahatā ati idha api guṇa mahat tena api aparicchinna saṅkhya tā

analyzed: gaṇana mahattena api mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena pāṭaligāmaḥ ti evaṃnāmakaḥ magadha raṭṭhe ekaḥ  gāmaḥ tassa kira gāmassa māpana divase gāma ggahaṇa ṭṭhāne dve tayo
translated: In the sixth, in Magadha: in the Magadha country. With a great community of bhikkhus: here too the community is great in the sense of the greatness of its special qualities, since it is immeasurable,

analyzed: ubbhijjitvā nikkhamiṃsu tena tam pāṭaligāmaḥ ūtvā iva vohariṃsu tad avasarī iti tam pāṭaligāmam  avasari anupāpuṇi kadā pana bhagavā pāṭaligāmam anupāpuṇi heṭṭhā vutta nayena sāvatthiyam  dhammasenāpatino cetiyam kārāpetvā tatas nikkhamitvā rājagahe vasanto tattha āyasmataḥ
translated: and in the sense of the greatness of its number, since it is large. At Paṭaligāma: a village in the Magadha country named Paṭaligāma. original: mahāmoggallānassa ca cetiyaṃ kārāpetvā tato nikkhamitvā ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ vasitvā aturitacārikāvasena

translated: having made a canopy of many colours over it, having spread it with hand-spreads, etc., with coverings of many colours,

original: santharitabbayuttakaṃ sabbokāsaṃ santharāpesuṃ. Tena vuttaṃ – “sabbasanthariṃ āvasathāgāraṃ santharitvā”ti.
analyzed: santharitabba yuttakam sabba okāsam tena vuttam sabba santharim āvasatha āgāram santharitvā iti
translated: and they had the whole of it plastered over with a thick layer of lime. Hence it was said above: “Having plastered the rest-house all over with a thick layer of lime” .

original: Āsanānañhi majjhaṭṭhāne tāva maṅgalathambhaṃ nissāya mahārahaṃ buddhāsanaṃ paññāpetvā🔽tattha yaṃ yaṃ mudukañca manoramañca paccattharaṇaṃ, taṃ taṃ paccattharitvā ubhatolohitakaṃ
analyzed: āsanānam hi majjha ṭṭhāne tāva maṅgala thambham nissāya mahā raham buddha āsanam paññāpetvā  tattha yam yam mudukam ca manoramam ca paccattharaṇam tam tam paccattharitvā ubhatolohitakam
translated: In the middle of the seats they set up a magnificent Buddha-seat, leaning against the auspicious pillar.🔽They spread out the softest and most beautiful bedspreads,🔽and on top of them they put a pillow with both ends red.

original: manuññadassanaṃ upadhānaṃ upadahitvā upari suvaṇṇarajatatārakāvicittaṃ vitānaṃ bandhitvā
analyzed: manuñña dassanam upadhānam upadahitvā upari suvaṇṇa rajata tārakā vicittam vitānam bandhitvā
translated: They hung a canopy above it, decorated with golden and silver stars,

original: gandhadāmapupphadāmādīhi alaṅkaritvā samantā dvādasahatthe ṭhāne pupphajālaṃ kāretvā🔽tiṃsahatthamattaṭṭhānaṃ paṭasāṇiyā parikkhipāpetvā pacchimabhittiṃ nissāya bhikkhusaṅghassa
analyzed: gandha dāma puppha dāma ādīhi alaṅkaritvā samantā dvādasa hatthe ṭhāne puppha jālam kāretvā  tiṃsa hattha matta ṭṭhānam paṭa sāṇiyā parikkhipāpetvā pacchima bhittim nissāya bhikkhu saṅghassa
translated: and they adorned it with garlands of scent, garlands of flowers, and so on. All around, in an area twelve hat, they had a flower-net made.🔽They had the area thirty hat in extent surrounded with a curtain,🔽and they set up couches, chairs, and so on for the Community of Bhikkhus against the back wall.

original: pallaṅkaapassayamañcapīṭhādīni paññāpetvā upari setapaccattharaṇehi paccattharāpetvā
analyzed: pallaṅka apassaya mañca pīṭha ādīni paññāpetvā upari seta paccattharaṇehi paccattharāpetvā
translated: They had the couches covered with white bedspreads,

original: sālāya pācīnapassaṃ attano nisajjāyoggaṃ kāresuṃ. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “āsanāni paññāpetvā”ti.
analyzed: sālāya pācīnapassam attanaḥ nisajjāyoggam kāresuṃ tam sandhāya vuttam āsanāni paññāpetvā iti
translated: and they prepared a sitting place for themselves on the eastern side of the hall. In reference to this it was said: “Having prepared the seats” .

original: Udakamaṇikanti mahākucchikaṃ udakacāṭiṃ. Evaṃ bhagavā bhikkhusaṅgho ca yathāruciyā
analyzed: udakamaṇikam ti mahākucchikam udaka cāṭim evam bhagavā bhikkhu saṅghaḥ ca yathāruciyā
translated: A water-jar means a large water-pot. Thus the Blessed One and the Community of Bhikkhus, according to their pleasure,

original: hatthapāde dhovissanti, mukhaṃ vikkhālessantīti tesu tesu ṭhānesu maṇivaṇṇassa udakassa🔽pūretvā vāsatthāya nānāpupphāni ceva udakavāsacuṇṇāni ca pakkhipitvā kadalipaṇṇehi
analyzed: hattha pāde dhovissanti mukham vikkhālessanti iti tesu tesu ṭhānesu maṇi vaṇṇassa udakassa  pūretvā vāsa atthāya nānā pupphāni ca iva udaka vāsa cuṇṇāni ca pakkhipitvā kadali paṇṇehi
translated: will wash their hands and feet and rinse their mouths. In various places they filled with water of the colour of gems

original: pidahitvā patiṭṭhapesuṃ. Tena vuttaṃ “udakamaṇikaṃ patiṭṭhāpetvā”ti.🔽Telappadīpaṃ āropetvāti rajatasuvaṇṇādimayadaṇḍadīpikāsu yodhakarūpavilāsakhacitarūpakādīnaṃ
analyzed: pidahitvā patiṭṭhapesum tena vuttam udakamaṇikam patiṭṭhāpetvā iti  āropetvā ati rajata suvaṇṇa ādi maya daṇḍa dīpikāsu yodhaka rūpa vilāsa khacita rūpaka ādīnam
translated: water-pots for the purpose of bathing and placed them, having put in them various flowers and bath-powder, and having covered them with plantain leaves. Therefore it was said: “Having placed a water-jar” .🔽Having lit a lamp means having lit an oil-lamp in silver and gold and other kinds of lamp-stands, in the hands of the figures of Yakkhas, Kinnaras, and Kinnaris, and in golden and silver and other kinds of bowls placed

original: hatthe ṭhapitasuvaṇṇarajatādimayakapallikāsu telappadīpaṃ jālayitvā. Yena bhagavā
analyzed: hatthe ṭhapita suvaṇṇa rajata ādi maya kapallikāsu telappadīpam jālayitvā yena bhagavān
translated: in the direction of the Blessed One.🔽They approached the Blessed One means that the lay devotees of Pāṭaliputta not only the dwelling-place,

original: tenupasaṅkamiṃsūti ettha pana te pāṭaligāmiyā upāsakā na kevalaṃ āvasathāgārameva,
analyzed: tena upasaṅkamiṃsu iti ettha pana te pāṭaligāmiyāḥ upāsakāḥ na kevalam āvasatha āgāram eva
translated: but also

original: atha kho sakalasmimpi gāme vīthiyo sajjāpetvā dhaje ussāpetvā gehadvāresu puṇṇaghaṭe🔽kadaliyo ca ṭhapāpetvā sakalagāmaṃ dīpamālāhi vippakiṇṇatārakaṃ viya katvā “khīrapake🔽dārake khīraṃ pāyetha, daharakumāre lahuṃ lahuṃ bhojetvā sayāpetha, uccāsaddaṃ mā
analyzed: atha kho sakalasmim pi gāme vīthiyaḥ sajjāpetvā dhaje ussāpetvā geha dvāresu puṇṇa ghaṭe  kadaliyaḥ ca sakala gāmam dīpa mālāhi vippakiṇṇa tārakam viya katvā khīrapake  dārake khīram pāyetha dahara kumāre lahum lahum bhojetvā sayāpetha uccāsaddam mā
translated: Then, having had the streets of the whole village decorated, having hoisted flags, having had full water-pots

original: karittha, ajja ekarattiṃ satthā antogāme vasissati, buddhā nāma appasaddakāmā hontī”ti
analyzed: karittha ajja eka rattim satthā antogāme vasissati buddhāḥ nāma appasadda kāmāḥ honti iti
translated: and plantain trees placed at the doors of the houses, having had the whole village lit up with garlands of lamps like a sky full of stars, having had the children who were drinking milk given milk to drink, having had the young boys and girls fed quickly and put to bed, having had loud noises avoided, having had a proclamation made with a drum: “Today, for one night, the Teacher will stay in the village,” (saying): “Buddhas are desirous of quiet,”

original: bheriṃ carāpetvā sayaṃ daṇḍadīpikā ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu.
analyzed: bherim cara apetvā sayam daṇḍa dīpikāḥ ādāya yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamiṃsu
translated: and having taken a torch himself, he approached the Fortunate One.

original: Atha kho bhagavā nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena yena āvasathāgāraṃ
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā nivāsetvā patta cīvaram ādāya saddhim bhikkhu saṅghena yena āvasatha āgāram
translated: Then the Fortunate One, having dressed in the morning time, after picking up his bowl and robe, approached the rest-house

original: tenupasaṅkamīti “yassa dāni, bhante, bhagavā kālaṃ maññatī”ti evaṃ kira tehi kāle
analyzed: tena upasaṅkami iti yassa dāni bhante bhagavā kālam maññati iti evam kira tehi kāle
translated: together with the Community of monks, (saying): “Now is the time, reverend Sir, for whatever you are thinking, reverend Sir.” Thus it seems they announced the time

original: ārocite bhagavā lākhārasena tintarattakoviḷārapupphavaṇṇaṃ rattadupaṭṭaṃ kattariyā
analyzed: ārocite bhagavā lākhā rasena tinta ratta koviḷāra puppha vaṇṇam ratta dupaṭṭam kattariyā
translated: to the Fortunate One. The Fortunate One, like a coral tree in blossom, having put on his red outer robe, and having taken his bowl and robe,

original: padumaṃ kantento viya, saṃvidhāya timaṇḍalaṃ paṭicchādento nivāsetvā suvaṇṇapāmaṅgena🔽padumakalāpaṃ parikkhipanto viya, vijjulatāsassirikaṃ kāyabandhanaṃ bandhitvā rattakambalena
analyzed: padumam kantentaḥ viya saṃvidhāya ti maṇḍalam paṭicchādentaḥ nivāsetvā suvaṇṇa pāmaṅgena  paduma kalāpam parikkhipantaḥ viya vijju latā sassirikam kāyabandhanam bandhitvā ratta kambalena
translated: as if he were a bee humming around a lotus, he put on his lower robe, covering his navel,🔽as if he were surrounding a cluster of lotuses with a golden garland, he fastened his belt, which was as brilliant as a flash of lightning,

original: gajakumbhaṃ pariyonandhanto viya, ratanasatubbedhe suvaṇṇagghike pavāḷajālaṃ khipamāno
analyzed: gaja kumbham pariyonandhantaḥ viya suvaṇṇagghike pavāḷa jālam khipamānaḥ
translated: as if he were throwing a net of coral over a golden casket with a hundred jewels, he put on his upper robe,

original: viya, mahati suvaṇṇacetiye rattakambalakañcukaṃ paṭimuñcanto viya, gacchantaṃ puṇṇacandaṃ🔽rattavalāhakena paṭicchādento viya, kañcanagirimatthake supakkalākhārasaṃ parisiñcanto
analyzed: viya mahati suvaṇṇa cetiye ratta kambala kañcukam paṭimuñcantaḥ viya gacchantam puṇṇa candam  ratta valāhakena paṭicchādentaḥ viya kañcana giri matthake su pakkala ākhā rasam parisiñcantaḥ
translated: as if he were putting a red blanket over a great golden shrine, he went,🔽as if he were covering the full moon with a red cloud, as if he were sprinkling the top of the golden mountain with pure red dye,

original: viya, cittakūṭapabbatamatthakaṃ vijjulatājālena parikkhipanto viya, sakalacakkavāḷasineruyugandharamahāpathaviṃ
analyzed: viya cittakūṭa pabbata matthakam vijju latā jālena parikkhipantaḥ viya sakala cakkavāḷa sineru yugandhara mahā pathavim
translated: as if he were surrounding the peak of the Cittakūṭa mountain with a net of lightning, as if he were shaking the whole world with its oceans and mountains,

original: cāletvā gahitanigrodhapallavasamānavaṇṇaṃ surattavarapaṃsukūlaṃ pārupitvā vanagahanato
analyzed: cāletvā gahita nigrodha pallava samāna vaṇṇam su ratta vara paṃsukūlam vana gahanataḥ
translated: he put on his well-dyed, reddish-brown patchwork cloak, which was the same color as the leaves of the Nigrodha tree, and left the forest.

original: nikkhantakesarasīho viya, samantato udayapabbatakūṭato puṇṇacando viya, bālasūriyo
analyzed: nikkhanta kesara sīhaḥ viya samantataḥ udayapabbata kūṭataḥ puṇṇa candaḥ viya bāla sūriyaḥ
translated: like a lion emerging from a lotus-pool, like the full moon emerging from the peak of the Udaya mountain, like a young sun,

original: viya ca attanā nisinnacārumaṇḍapato nikkhami.
analyzed: viya ca attanā nisinna cāru maṇḍapataḥ nikkhami
translated: he emerged from the beautiful pavilion in which he was sitting.

original: Athassa kāyato meghamukhato vijjukalāpā viya rasmiyo nikkhamitvā suvaṇṇarasadhārāparisekapiñjarapattapupphaphalasākhāviṭape
analyzed: athassa kāyataḥ megha mukhataḥ vijju kalāpāḥ viya rasmiyaḥ nikkhamitvā suvaṇṇa rasa dhārā pariseka piñjara patta puppha phala sākhā viṭape
translated: Then from his body, like a flash of lightning from a cloud, rays emerged and made the trees all around, like a grove of leaves, flowers, fruits and branches moistened with a shower of gold,

original: viya samantato rukkhe kariṃsu. Tāvadeva attano attano pattacīvaramādāya mahābhikkhusaṅgho
analyzed: viya samantataḥ rukkhe kariṃsu tāvat eva attano attano patta cīvaram ādāya mahā bhikkhu saṅghaḥ
translated: shine. Immediately the great community of monks, taking their own bowls and robes,

original: bhagavantaṃ parivāresi. Te ca naṃ parivāretvā ṭhitā bhikkhū evarūpā ahesuṃ appicchā
analyzed: bhagavantam parivāresi te ca nam parivāretvā ṭhitā bhikkhū evarūpāḥ ahesuṃ appicchāḥ
translated: surrounded the Lord. And those monks who stood surrounding him were such that they were few in wishes,

original: santuṭṭhā pavivittā asaṃsaṭṭhā āraddhavīriyā vattāro vacanakkhamā codakā pāpagarahino
analyzed: santuṭṭhāḥ pavivittāḥ asaṃsaṭṭhāḥ āraddha vīriyāḥ vattāraḥ vacana khamā codakā pāpa garahino
translated: content, secluded, aloof from society, strenuous, respectful, reproving,

original: sīlasampannā samādhisampannā paññāsampannā vimuttisampannā vimuttiñāṇadassanasampannā.
analyzed: sīla sampannā samādhi sampannā paññā sampannā vimutti sampannā vimutti ñāṇa dassana sampannā
translated: blaming indulgence, perfect in morality, perfect in concentration, perfect in wisdom, perfect in deliverance, perfect in the knowledge and insight of deliverance.

original: Tehi parivuto bhagavā rattakambalaparikkhitto viya suvaṇṇakkhandho, nakkhattaparivārito
analyzed: tehi parivutaḥ bhagavā ratta kambala parikkhittaḥ viya suvaṇṇa kkhandhaḥ nakkhatta parivārito
translated: Surrounded by them the Lord was like a mass of gold surrounded by a wreath of red cloth, like the moon surrounded by the stars,

original: viya puṇṇacando, rattapadumavanasaṇḍamajjhagatā viya suvaṇṇanāvā, pavāḷavedikaparikkhitto🔽viya suvaṇṇapāsādo virocittha. Mahākassapappamukhā pana mahātherā meghavaṇṇaṃ paṃsukūlacīvaraṃ
analyzed: viya puṇṇa candaḥ viya suvaṇṇa nāvā pavāḷa vedika parikkhitto  viya suvaṇṇa pāsādaḥ virocittha mahākassapa pamukhāḥ pana mahā therāḥ megha vaṇṇam paṃsukūla cīvaram
translated: and like a golden ship in the midst of a grove of red lotuses, and like a golden palace surrounded by a rampart of coral,🔽shone forth. But the great Elders, with the Elder Mahākassapa at their head, having put on their rag-robes the colour of rain-clouds,

original: pārupitvā maṇivammavammitā viya mahānāgā parivārayiṃsu vantarāgā bhinnakilesā vijaṭitajaṭā
analyzed: maṇi vamma vammitāḥ viya mahā nāgā parivārayiṃsu vanta rāgāḥ bhinna kilesāḥ vijaṭita jaṭāḥ
translated: surrounded him like great Nāgas anointed with gems and jewels, with their inner passions destroyed, their corruptions destroyed, their matted hair unraveled,

original: chinnabandhanā kule vā gaṇe vā alaggā.
analyzed: chinna bandhanā kule vā gaṇe vā a laggā
translated: their bonds cut, not clinging to a family or a group.

original: Iti bhagavā sayaṃ vītarāgo vītarāgehi, vītadoso vītadosehi, vītamoho vītamohehi,
analyzed: iti bhagavā sayam vīta rāgaḥ vīta rāgehi vīta dosaḥ vīta dosehi vīta mohaḥ vīta mohehi
translated: Thus the Exalted One, himself free from passion, was surrounded by those free from passion; himself free from hatred, by those free from hatred; himself free from delusion, by those free from delusion;

original: nittaṇho nittaṇhehi, nikkileso nikkilesehi, sayaṃ buddho anubuddhehi parivārito pattaparivāritaṃ
analyzed: nittaṇhaḥ nittaṇhehi nikkilesaḥ nikkilesehi sayam buddhaḥ anubuddhehi parivāritaḥ patta parivāritam
translated: himself free from desire, by those free from desire; himself free from corruption, by those free from corruption; himself enlightened, by those enlightened in conformity with his enlightenment; surrounded like a lotus by bees,

original: viya kesaraṃ, kesaraparivāritā viya kaṇṇikā, aṭṭhanāgasahassaparivārito viya chaddanto
analyzed: viya kesaram kesara parivāritāḥ viya kaṇṇikāḥ aṭṭhanāga sahassa parivāritaḥ viya chaddanto
translated: like a kaṇṇikā flower by keṭaka flowers, like the elephant-king Chaddanta by a thousand elephants,

original: nāgarājā, navutihaṃsasahassaparivārito viya dhataraṭṭho haṃsarājā, senaṅgaparivārito
analyzed: nāga rājā navuti haṃsa sahassa parivāritaḥ viya dhataraṭṭhaḥ haṃsa rājā senaṅga parivārito
translated: like the swan-king Dhataraṭṭha by ninety thousand swans, like the king of the gods by the army of the gods,

original: viya cakkavattirājā, marugaṇaparivārito viya sakko devarājā, brahmagaṇaparivārito
analyzed: viya cakkavatti rājā maru gaṇa parivāritaḥ viya sakkaḥ devarājā brahma gaṇa parivāritaḥ
translated: surrounded by a retinue of gods, as Sakka, the king of the gods, is surrounded by a retinue of the Thirty-three gods,

original: viya hāritamahābrahmā, tārāgaṇaparivārito viya puṇṇacando, anupamena buddhavesena
analyzed: viya hārita mahā brahmā tārā gaṇa parivāritaḥ viya puṇṇa candaḥ anupamena buddha vesena
translated: as the Great Brahmā Hārita is surrounded by a retinue of the Brahmā gods, as the full moon is surrounded by a retinue of stars,

original: aparimāṇena buddhavilāsena pāṭaligāminaṃ maggaṃ paṭipajji.
analyzed: aparimāṇena buddha vilāsena pāṭali gāminam maggam paṭipajji
translated: with incomparable Buddha-beauty, with incomparable Buddha-grace, he went along the road to Pāṭali Village.

original: Athassa puratthimakāyato suvaṇṇavaṇṇā ghanabuddharasmiyo uṭṭhahitvā asītihatthaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: athassa puratthima kāyataḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇāḥ ghana buddha rasmiyaḥ uṭṭhahitvā asīti hattha ṭṭhānam
translated: Then from his front part golden-coloured, solid Buddha-rays arose and filled a space of eighty cubits,

original: aggahesuṃ, tathā pacchimakāyato dakkhiṇapassato vāmapassato suvaṇṇavaṇṇā ghanabuddharasmiyo🔽uṭṭhahitvā asītihatthaṭṭhānaṃ aggahesuṃ, uparikesantato paṭṭhāya sabbakesāvaṭṭehi🔽moragīvarājavaṇṇā asitā ghanabuddharasmiyo uṭṭhahitvā gaganatale asītihatthaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: aggahesum tathā pacchima kāyataḥ dakkhiṇa passataḥ vāma passataḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇāḥ ghana buddha rasmiyaḥ  uṭṭhahitvā asīti hattha ṭṭhānam aggahesuṃ upari kesantataḥ paṭṭhāya sabba kesa avaṭṭehi  asitāḥ ghana buddha rasmiyaḥ uṭṭhahitvā gagana tale asīti hattha ṭṭhānam
translated: and in the same way from his back part, from his right side, from his left side, golden-coloured, solid Buddha-rays arose and filled a space of eighty cubits,🔽and from the top of his head down to the tips of his hair,🔽black, solid Buddha-rays arose and filled a space of eighty cubits in the sky,

original: aggahesuṃ, heṭṭhāpādatalehi pavāḷavaṇṇā rasmiyo uṭṭhahitvā ghanapathaviyaṃ asītihatthaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: aggahesum heṭṭhā pāda talehi pavāḷa vaṇṇāḥ rasmiyaḥ uṭṭhahitvā ghana pathaviyam asīti hattha ṭṭhānam
translated: and from the soles of his feet red-coloured rays arose and filled a space of eighty cubits on the solid earth,

original: aggahesuṃ, dantato akkhīnaṃ setaṭṭhānato, nakhānaṃ maṃsavimuttaṭṭhānato odātā ghanabuddharasmiyo
analyzed: aggahesum dantataḥ akkhīnam seta ṭṭhānataḥ nakhānam maṃsa vimutta ṭṭhānataḥ odātāḥ ghana buddha rasmiyaḥ
translated: and from the white parts of the eyes, and from the parts of the nails free from flesh, white, thick, and compact rays of light

original: uṭṭhahitvā asītihatthaṭṭhānaṃ aggahesuṃ, rattapītavaṇṇānaṃ sambhinnaṭṭhānato mañjeṭṭhavaṇṇā
analyzed: uṭṭhahitvā asīti hattha ṭṭhānam aggahesum ratta pīta vaṇṇānam sambhinna ṭṭhānataḥ mañjeṭṭha vaṇṇā
translated: rose up and covered a distance of eighty cubits. From the parts where the red and yellow colours were mixed, rays of light of the colour of the mango blossom

original: rasmiyo uṭṭhahitvā asītihatthaṭṭhānaṃ aggahesuṃ, sabbatthakameva pabhassarā rasmiyo
analyzed: rasmiyaḥ uṭṭhahitvā asīti hattha ṭṭhānam aggahesum sabbatthakam eva pabhassarāḥ rasmiyaḥ
translated: rose up and covered a distance of eighty cubits. Rays of light, which were bright everywhere,

original: uṭṭhahiṃsu. Evaṃ samantā asītihatthaṭṭhānaṃ chabbaṇṇā buddharasmiyo vijjotamānā vipphandamānā🔽vidhāvamānā kañcanadaṇḍadīpikādīhi niccharitvā ākāsaṃ pakkhandamānā mahāpadīpajālā
