original: dassetuṃ, “pañcime gahapatayo”tiādinā dhammadesanatthaṃ āmantesi.
analyzed: dassetum pañcime gahapatayo ti ādinā dhamma desana attham āmantesi
translated: he addressed them with the Dhamma talk beginning with “Householders.”

original: Tattha dussīloti nissīlo. Sīlavipannoti vipannasīlo bhinnasaṃvaro. Ettha ca “dussīlo”ti
analyzed: tattha dussīlaḥ nti nissīlaḥ sīla vipannaḥ ti vipanna sīlaḥ bhinna saṃvaraḥ ettha ca dussīlaḥ ti
translated: Herein, unvirtuous means without virtue. Virtue-corrupter means one whose virtue is corrupted, whose restraint is broken. And here the word unvirtuous

original: padena puggalassa sīlābhāvo vutto. So panassa sīlābhāvo duvidho asamādānena vā samādinnassa🔽bhedena vāti. Tesu purimo na tathā sāvajjo, yathā dutiyo sāvajjataro. Yathādhippetādīnavanimittaṃ🔽sīlābhāvaṃ puggalādhiṭṭhānāya desanāya dassetuṃ, “sīlavipanno”ti vuttaṃ. Tena “dussīlo”ti
analyzed: padena puggalassa sīla abhāvaḥ vutto so panassa sīla abhāvaḥ duvidhaḥ asamādānena vā samādinnassa  bhedena vāti tesu purimaḥ na tathā sāvajjaḥ yathā dutiyaḥ sāvajjataraḥ yathā adhippeta ādīnava nimittam  sīla abhāvam puggala adhiṭṭhānāya desanāya dassetum sīla vipannaḥ ti vuttam tena dussīlaḥ ti
translated: states the person’s absence of virtue. But that absence of virtue is twofold, namely, as non-undertaking and as undertaking and then breaking.🔽Of these, the first is not so blameworthy as the second, which is more blameworthy. The word virtue-corrupter is said in order to show the absence of virtue as the disadvantage stated in the Thread,🔽by a teaching based on the person, in the way stated. So it shows the meaning of the word unvirtuous.

original: padassa atthaṃ dasseti. Pamādādhikaraṇanti pamādakāraṇā. Idañca suttaṃ gahaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: padassa attham dasseti pamāda adhikaraṇam ti pamāda kāraṇā idam ca suttam gahaṭṭhānam
translated: Cause of negligence: reason for negligence. And this Thread comes down as addressed to householders,

original: vasena āgataṃ, pabbajitānampi pana labbhateva. Gahaṭṭho hi yena sippaṭṭhānena jīvikaṃ
analyzed: vasena āgatam pabbajitānam pi pana labbhate iva gahaṭṭhaḥ hi yena sippa ṭṭhānena jīvikam
translated: but it is also allowable for those gone forth into homelessness. For a householder who makes a living by some craft or occupation,

original: kappeti yadi kasiyā yadi vāṇijjāya yadi gorakkhena, pāṇātipātādivasena pamatto taṃ
analyzed: kappeti yadi kasiyā yadi vāṇijjāya yadi gorakkhena pāṇa atipāta ādi vasena pamattaḥ tam
translated: whether by farming or by trading or by tending cattle, is negligent in the way beginning “By killing breathing things … “

original: taṃ yathākālaṃ sampādetuṃ na sakkoti, athassa kammaṃ vinassati. Māghātakāle pana
analyzed: tam yathākālam sampādetum na sakkoti atha assa kammam vinassati māghāta kāle pana
translated: If he is unable to make amends for it in time, his kamma will be lost. But if he commits killing breathing things, etc.,

original: pāṇātipātādīni karonto daṇḍavasena mahatiṃ bhogajāniṃ nigacchati. Pabbajito dussīlo
analyzed: pāṇa atipāta ādīni karontaḥ daṇḍa vasena mahatim bhoga jānim nigacchati pabbajitaḥ dussīlo
translated: during the month of Magha, he will incur a great loss of wealth in the form of punishment. An unvirtuous monk

original: pamādakāraṇā sīlato buddhavacanato jhānato sattaariyadhanato ca jāniṃ nigacchati.🔽Pāpako kittisaddoti gahaṭṭhassa “asuko amukakule jāto dussīlo pāpadhammo pariccattaidhalokaparaloko
analyzed: pamāda kāraṇā sīlataḥ buddha vacanataḥ jhānataḥ satta ariya dhanataḥ ca jānim nigacchati  pāpako kitti saddo ti gaha ṭṭhassa asukaḥ amuka kule jātaḥ dussīlaḥ pāpa dhammo pariccatta edhaloka paraloko
translated: will incur a loss of virtue, of the Buddha’s word, of jhāna, and of the seven treasures of the ariyans through his negligence.

original: salākabhattamattampi na detī”ti parisamajjhe pāpako kittisaddo abbhuggacchati. Pabbajitassa
analyzed: salāka bhatta mattam pi na deti iti parisamajjhe pāpakaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggacchati pabbajitassa
translated: Evil reputation: in the case of a layman, an evil reputation will spread about in the village or town: “That man, born in such and such a family, is unvirtuous, of evil character, who has abandoned himself to sensual pleasures, who does not give even to the extent of a ladleful of boiled rice.” In the case of a monk,

original: “asuko nāma thero satthu sāsane pabbajitvā nāsakkhi sīlāni rakkhituṃ, na buddhavacanaṃ
analyzed: asukaḥ nāma theraḥ satthu sāsane pabbajitvā na asakkhi sīlāni rakkhitum na buddha vacanam
translated: an evil reputation will spread about: “That monk, who went forth in the dispensation of the Master, was unable to guard himself in virtue, to master the Buddha’s word,

original: gahetuṃ, vejjakammādīhi jīvati, chahi agāravehi samannāgato”ti evaṃ pāpako kittisaddo abbhuggacchati.
analyzed: gahetum vejja kamma ādīhi jīvati chahi agāravehi samannāgataḥ ti evam pāpakaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggacchati
translated: to live by medicine given him, and to be endowed with the six kinds of confidence. ”

original: Avisāradoti gahaṭṭho tāva avassaṃ bahūnaṃ sannipātaṭṭhāne “koci mama kammaṃ jānissati,
analyzed: avisāradaḥ ti gaha ṭṭho tāva avassam bahūnam sannipāta ṭṭhāne koci mama kammam jānissati
translated: Unsteady: a layman, thinking, “Someone will know my deeds here in this gathering of many people,

original: atha maṃ nindissati, rājakulassa vā dassessatī”ti sabhayo upasaṅkamati, maṅkubhūto
analyzed: atha mam nindissati rāja kulassa vā dassessati iti sabhayaḥ upasaṅkamati maṅku bhūtaḥ
translated: and then he will criticize me or inform the king’s court,” approaches with fear, becomes embarrassed,

original: pattakkhandho adhomukho nisīdati, visārado hutvā kathetuṃ na sakkoti. Pabbajitopi🔽bahubhikkhusaṅghe sannipatite “avassaṃ koci mama kammaṃ jānissati, atha me uposathampi
analyzed: pattakkhandhaḥ adhomukhaḥ nisīdati visāradaḥ hutvā kathetum na sakkoti pabbajitaḥ api  bahu bhikkhu saṅghe sannipatite avassam koci mama kammam jānissati atha me uposatham pi
translated: sits down with shoulders drooping and head down, and is unable to speak with confidence. A monk,

original: pavāraṇampi ṭhapetvā sāmaññato cāvetvā nikkaḍḍhissatī”ti sabhayo upasaṅkamati, visārado
analyzed: pavāraṇam pi ṭhapetvā sāmaññataḥ cāvetvā nikkaḍḍhissati iti sabhayaḥ upasaṅkamati visāradaḥ
translated: thinking, “Someone will know my deeds in this gathering of many bhikkhus,” approaches with fear, thinking, “Then they will suspend my observance day and invitation ceremony, expel me from the ascetic practices, and banish me.” He is unable to speak with confidence.

original: hutvā kathetuṃ na sakkoti. Ekacco pana dussīlopi samāno susīlo viya carati, sopi
analyzed: hutvā kathetum na sakkoti ekaccaḥ pana dussīlaḥ api samānaḥ su sīlaḥ viya carati saḥ api
translated: But some, though unvirtuous, behave as if virtuous. He too is embarrassed

original: ajjhāsayena maṅku hotiyeva.
analyzed: ajjhāsayena maṅku hotiyā iva
translated: by his own thoughts.

original: Sammūḷho kālaṃ karotīti dussīlassa hi maraṇamañce nipannassa dussīlakammāni samādāya
analyzed: sammūḷhaḥ kālam karoti iti dussīlassa hi maraṇa mañce nipannassa dussīla kammāni samādāya
translated: Dies confused: for when an unvirtuous person lies down on his deathbed, his unvirtuous deeds come to claim him.

original: pavattitaṭṭhānāni āpāthaṃ āgacchanti. So ummīletvā idhalokaṃ, nimīletvā paralokaṃ
analyzed: pavattita ṭṭhānāni āpātham āgacchanti saḥ ummīletvā idha lokam nimīletvā para lokam
translated: and the places of rebirth come into focus. He sees the world of men by opening his eyes and the world of the dead by closing them.

original: passati. Tassa cattāro apāyā kammānurūpaṃ upaṭṭhahanti, sattisatena pahariyamāno
analyzed: passati tassa cattāro apāyā kamma anurūpam upaṭṭhahanti satti satena pahariyamāno
translated: The four states of misery appear to him in accordance with his kamma. He is as if struck by a hundred spears🔽and as if burned by a mass of fire. He dies

original: viya aggijālābhighātena jhāyamāno viya ca hoti. So “vāretha, vārethā”ti viravantova
analyzed: aggi jāla abhighātena jhāyamānaḥ ca hoti saḥ vāretha vāretha ati viravantaḥ uva
translated: shouting, “Stop, stop!”

original: marati. Tena vuttaṃ – “sammūḷho kālaṃ karotī”ti.🔽Kāyassa bhedāti upādinnakkhandhapariccāgā. Paraṃ maraṇāti tadanantaraṃ abhinibbattakkhandhaggahaṇā.
analyzed: marati tena vuttam sammūḷhaḥ kālam karoti iti  kāyassa bhedā ati upādinna kkhandha pariccāgā param maraṇā ati tad anantaram abhinibbatta kkhandha ggahaṇā
translated: That is why it is said, “He dies confused.”🔽With the breakup of the body, after death: with the giving up of the appropriated aggregates, with the laying down of the body.

original: Atha vā kāyassa bhedāti jīvitindriyassa upacchedā. Paraṃ maraṇāti cutito uddhaṃ.🔽Apāyantiādi sabbaṃ nirayavevacanaṃ. Nirayo hi saggamokkhahetubhūtā puññasaṅkhātā🔽ayā apetattā, sukhānaṃ vā ayassa, āgamanassa vā abhāvā apāyo. Dukkhassa gati paṭisaraṇanti
analyzed: atha vā kāyassa jīvitindriyassa upacchedā param maraṇā ati cutitaḥ 🔽sabbam niraya vevacanam nirayaḥ hi saggamokkha hetu bhūtā puñña saṅkhātā 🔽sukhānam vā ayassa āgamanassa vā abhāvā apāyaḥ dukkhassa gati paṭisaraṇanti
translated: He is bound to reappear in a lower destiny: after death he is bound to arise in a lower plane.

original: duggati, dosabahulatāya vā duṭṭhena kammunā nibbattā gatīti duggati. Vivasā nipatanti
analyzed: duggati dosa bahula tāya vā duṭṭhena kammunā nibbattā gatīti duggati vivasāḥ nipatanti
translated: and it is a state of loss because of being a state of loss of the bliss of the heavenly world, or because of being a state of loss of the bliss of the noble path, or because of being a state of loss of the bliss of Nibbāna.

original: ettha dukkatakārinoti vinipāto, vinassantā vā ettha nipatanti sambhijjamānaṅgapaccaṅgāti
analyzed: ettha dukkata kārinaḥ ti vinipātaḥ vinassantāḥ vai ettha nipatanti sambhijjamāna aṅga paccaṅgā ati
translated: It is a downfall because of the falling of those who do evil, or because of the falling of the limbs and minor parts of the body as they are cut off.

original: vinipāto. Natthi ettha assādasaññito ayoti nirayo.
analyzed: vinipātaḥ na atthi ettha assāda saññitaḥ ayaḥ ti nirayo
translated: It is hell because of the absence there of any perception of pleasure.

original: Atha vā apāyaggahaṇena tiracchānayoniṃ dīpeti. Tiracchānayoni hi apāyo sugatito apetattā,
analyzed: atha vā apāya ggahaṇena tiracchānayonim dīpeti tiracchānayoni hi apāyaḥ sugatitaḥ apeta tā
translated: Or alternatively, by the word “states of loss” he shows the animal generation, for that is a state of loss since it has departed from the happy destiny,

original: na duggati mahesakkhānaṃ nāgarājādīnaṃ sambhavato. Duggatiggahaṇena pettivisayaṃ
analyzed: na duggati mahesakkhānam nāga rāja ādīnam sambhavataḥ duggati ggahaṇena petti visayam
translated: but it is not a state of loss of the great nāga kings, etc., because of their greatness. By the word “states of loss of happiness” he shows the ghost realm,

original: dīpeti. So hi apāyo ceva duggati ca sugatito apetattā, dukkhassa ca gatibhūtattā,
analyzed: dīpeti saḥ hi apāyaḥ ca iva duggati ca sugatitaḥ apeta ttā dukkhassa ca gati bhūta ttā
translated: for that is a state of loss and a state of loss of happiness since it has departed from the happy destiny, and it is a state of loss of happiness because it is a state of suffering.

original: na tu vinipāto asurasadisaṃ avinipatitattā petamahiddhikānampi vijjamānattā. Vinipātaggahaṇena
analyzed: na tu vinipātaḥ asura sadisam a vinipatita ttā peta mahiddhikānam pi vijjamāna ttā vinipāta ggahaṇena
translated: But it is not a downfall because of the absence of falling in the way stated, since the great ghosts are not fallen. By the word “downfalls” he shows the asura group,

original: asurakāyaṃ dīpeti. So hi yathāvuttenaṭṭhena “apāyo” ceva “duggati” ca sabbasampattisamussayehi
analyzed: asura kāyam dīpeti saḥ hi yathā vuttena ṭṭhena apāyaḥ ca iva duggati ca sabba sampatti samussayehi
translated: for that is a state of loss and a state of loss of happiness in the way stated, and it is a state of loss of happiness because of the absence of all kinds of success and prosperity.

original: vinipatitattā “vinipāto”ti ca vuccati. Nirayaggahaṇena avīciādikaṃ anekappakāraṃ
analyzed: vinipatita ttā vinipāto ti ca vuccati niraya ggahaṇena avīci ādikam aneka ppakāram
translated: It is called “the downfall” because it has fallen down. By the word “hell” is meant the various kinds of hell, such as the Avīci Hell, etc.

original: nirayameva dīpeti. Upapajjatīti nibbattati.
analyzed: nirayam eva dīpeti upapajjati iti nibbattati
translated: “Is reborn there” means is born there.

original: Ānisaṃsakathā vuttavipariyāyena veditabbā. Ayaṃ pana viseso – sīlavāti samādānavasena
analyzed: ānisaṃsa kathā vutta vipariyāyena veditabbā ayam pana visesaḥ sīlavā ati samādāna vasena
translated: The explanation of the benefits should be understood in the opposite sense to the above. But there is this difference. “Virtuous” means virtuous by way of undertaking .

original: sīlavā. Sīlasampannoti parisuddhaṃ paripuṇṇañca katvā sīlassa samādānena sīlasampanno.
analyzed: sīlavā sīla sampannaḥ ti parisuddham paripuṇṇam ca katvā sīlassa samādānena sīla sampannaḥ
translated: “Endowed with virtue” means endowed with virtue by undertaking virtue that is pure and complete.

original: Bhogakkhandhanti bhogarāsiṃ. Sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokanti ettha sugatiggahaṇena manussagatipi🔽saṅgayhati, saggaggahaṇena devagati eva. Tattha sundarā gati sugati, rūpādīhi visayehi
analyzed: bhogakkhandham ti bhogarāsim sugatim saggam lokanti ettha sugati ggahaṇena manussa gati pi  sagga ggahaṇena deva gati eva tattha sundarā gati su gati rūpa ādīhi visayehi
translated: “A great mass of good fortune” means a great heap of good fortune. “A good destination, a heavenly world” : here, by the word “good destination” human existence is included,

original: suṭṭhu aggoti saggo, so sabbopi lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena lokoti.
analyzed: suṭṭhu aggaḥ ti saggaḥ saḥ sabbaḥ api lujjana palujjana ṭṭhena loko ti
translated: and by the word “heavenly world” only divine existence. There, a good destination is a good destination because it is beautiful , and a heavenly world is a heavenly world because one goes well by way of the sense objects such as visible forms. All of these are called “worlds” because they are subject to destruction and ultimate destruction.

original: Pāṭaligāmiye upāsake bahudeva rattiṃ dhammiyā kathāyāti aññāyapi pāḷimuttāya dhammakathāya
analyzed: pāṭaligāmiye upāsake bahu deva rattim dhammiyā kathāya ati pāḷimuttāya dhamma kathāya
translated: “The lay followers of Pāṭaligāma, having listened to the Dhamma for much of the night” : by way of the Dhamma talk that is outside the texts.

original: ceva āvasathānumodanakathāya ca. Tadā hi bhagavā yasmā ajātasattunā tattha pāṭaliputtanagaraṃ
analyzed: āvasatha anumodana kathāya ca tadā hi bhagavā yasmai ajātasattunā pāṭaliputta nagaram
translated: Then, as Ajātasattu was having the city of Pāṭaliputta built there,

original: māpentena aññesu gāmanigamajanapadarājadhānīsu ye sīlācārasampannā kuṭumbikā, te
analyzed: māpentena aññesu gāma nigama janapada rājadhānīsu ye sīla ācāra sampannā kuṭumbikā te
translated: he brought from other villages, towns, districts, and royal cities all the wealthy householders who were virtuous and well-conducted,

original: ānetvā dhanadhaññagharavatthukhettavatthādīni ceva parihārañca dāpetvā nivesiyanti.🔽Tasmā pāṭaligāmiyā upāsakā ānisaṃsadassāvitāya visesato sīlagarukā sabbaguṇānañca
analyzed: ānetvā dhana dhañña ghara vatthu khetta vattha ādīni ca iva parihāram ca dāpetvā  tasmā pāṭaligāmiyāḥ upāsakāḥ visesato sīla garukā
translated: and he gave them wealth, grain, houses, fields, land, and so on, and had them settled there.🔽So the lay devotees of Pāṭaliputta, who were eager to see the benefits, were especially respectful of virtue. And because virtue is the foundation of all good qualities,

original: sīlassa adhiṭṭhānabhāvato tesaṃ paṭhamaṃ sīlānisaṃse pakāsetvā tato paraṃ ākāsagaṅgaṃ
analyzed: sīlassa adhiṭṭhāna bhāvato tesam paṭhamam sīla anisaṃse pakāsetvā tato param ākāsagaṅgaṃ
translated: the Blessed One first expounded the benefits of virtue to them, and then, like one who has brought down the celestial Ganges,

original: otārento viya, pathavojaṃ ākaḍḍhanto viya, mahājambuṃ matthake gahetvā cālento viya,🔽yojanikamadhukaṇḍaṃ cakkayantena pīḷetvā madhurasaṃ pāyamāno viya pāṭaligāmikānaṃ
analyzed: otārentaḥ viya pathavojam ākaḍḍhantaḥ viya mahā jambum matthake gahetvā cālentaḥ viya  yojanika madhu kaṇḍam cakkayantena pīḍetvā madhu rasam pāyamānaḥ
translated: like one who has drawn out the earth, like one who has shaken a great rose-apple tree,

original: upāsakānaṃ hitasukhāvahaṃ pakiṇṇakakathaṃ kathento “āvāsadānaṃ nāmetaṃ gahapatayo
analyzed: upāsakānam hita sukha āvaham pakiṇṇaka katham kathentaḥ āvāsadānam nāma etam gahapatayaḥ
translated: like one who has pressed a honey-comb with a wheel, he gave the lay devotees of Pāṭaliputta a miscellaneous discourse that brought them welfare and happiness, saying: “Householders, this is not a gift of a dwelling-place.

original: mahantaṃ puññaṃ, tumhākaṃ āvāso mayā paribhutto, bhikkhusaṅghena ca paribhutto, mayā
analyzed: mahantam puññam tumhākam āvāsaḥ mayā paribhuttaḥ bhikkhu saṅghena ca paribhuttaḥ mayā
translated: you have made much merit, my dwelling has been used by me and by the Community of monks,

original: ca bhikkhusaṅghena ca paribhutte pana dhammaratanenapi paribhuttoyeva hoti. Evaṃ🔽tīhi ratanehi paribhutte aparimeyyo ca vipāko, apica āvāsadānasmiṃ dinne sabbadānaṃ
analyzed: ca bhikkhu saṅghena ca paribhutte pana dhamma ratanena pi hoti evam  tīhi ratanehi paribhutte aparimeyyaḥ ca vipākaḥ apica āvāsa dānasmim dinne sabba dānam
translated: “You have gained great merit. My dwelling has been used by me and by the Community of Bhikkhus. But when it has been used by me and by the Community of Bhikkhus, then it has also been used by the True Idea. Thus

original: dinnameva hoti, bhūmaṭṭhakapaṇṇasālāya vā sākhāmaṇḍapassa vā saṅghaṃ uddissa katassa🔽ānisaṃso paricchindituṃ na sakkā. Āvāsadānānubhāvena hi bhave nibbattamānassapi sampīḷitagabbhavāso🔽nāma na hoti, dvādasahattho ovarako viyassa mātukucchi asambādhova hotī”ti evaṃ nānānayehi
analyzed: dinnam eva hoti bhūmaṭṭhaka paṇṇasālāya vā sākhāmaṇḍapassa vā saṅgham uddissa katassa  ānisaṃsaḥ paricchinditum na sakkā āvāsa dāna anubhāvena hi bhave nibbattamānassa api sampīḍita gabbha vāso  nāma na hoti dvādasa hatthaḥ ovarakaḥ viyassa mātukucchi asambādhaḥ uva hoti iti evam nānānayehi
translated: when it has been used by the three Jewels, the outcome is immeasurable. Moreover, when a gift of a dwelling has been given, then all gifts have been given. When a leaf hut or a pavilion of branches has been made for the Community, the blessing

original: vicittaṃ bahuṃ dhammakathaṃ kathetvā –
analyzed: vicittam bahum dhamma katham kathetvā
translated: of that cannot be measured. For when one is reborn in a becoming through the influence of a gift of a dwelling, then the state of being crowded in the womb does not exist. The mother’s womb is as uncrowded as a twelve-league town. ” After telling them this and various other kinds of edifying stories, he said:

original: “Sītaṃ uṇhaṃ paṭihanti, tato vāḷamigāni ca;
analyzed: sītam uṇham paṭihanti tatas vāḍamigāni ca
translated: “Cold and heat are warded off, and then wild beasts as well,

original: Sarīsape ca makase, sisire cāpi vuṭṭhiyo.
analyzed: sarīsape ca makase sisire ca api
translated: And snakes and crocodiles, and then the cold-weather rains.

original: “Tato vātātapo ghoro, sañjāto paṭihaññati;
analyzed: tatas vāta ātapaḥ ghoro sañjātaḥ paṭihaññati
translated: “Then a terrible wind and heat arise to ward it off,

original: Leṇatthañca sukhatthañca, jhāyituñca vipassituṃ.
analyzed: leṇattham ca sukhattham ca jhāyitum ca vipassitum
translated: For shelter, for comfort, for meditation, for insight.

original: “Vihāradānaṃ saṅghassa, aggaṃ buddhena vaṇṇitaṃ;
analyzed: vihāra dānam saṅghassa aggam buddhena vaṇṇitam
translated: “The gift of a dwelling to the Order, the Buddha has declared to be the foremost;

original: Tasmā hi paṇḍito poso, sampassaṃ atthamattano.
analyzed: tasmā hi paṇḍitaḥ posaḥ sampassam attham attano
translated: Therefore the wise man, seeing his own good,

original: “Vihāre kāraye ramme, vāsayettha bahussute;
analyzed: vihāre ramme vāsayettha bahu sute
translated: “Should build delightful dwellings and lodge therein the learned;

original: Tesaṃ annañca pānañca, vatthasenāsanāni ca.
analyzed: tesam annam ca pānam ca vattha senāsanāni ca
translated: To them he should give food and drink, clothes and lodging,

original: “Dadeyya ujubhūtesu, vippasannena cetasā;
analyzed: dadeyya uju bhūtesu vippasannena cetasā
translated: “And give it with a pure heart to the upright;

original: Te tassa dhammaṃ desenti, sabbadukkhāpanūdanaṃ;
analyzed: te tassa dhammam desenti sabba dukkha apanūdanam
translated: They will teach him the Dhamma that removes all suffering;

original: Yaṃ so dhammaṃ idhaññāya, parinibbāti anāsavo”ti. –
analyzed: yam saḥ dhammam idhaññāya parinibbāti anāsavaḥ ti
translated: Having understood the Dhamma here, he attains extinction, undefiled.”

original: Evaṃ ayampi āvāsadāne ānisaṃsoti bahudeva rattiṃ atirekataraṃ diyaḍḍhayāmaṃ āvāsadānānisaṃsakathaṃ
analyzed: evam ayam pi āvāsa dāne bahu deva rattim atirekataram āvāsa dāna ānisaṃsa katham
translated: Thus this is also a benefit in the giving of dwellings. And so, for much of the night, for more than half the night, he spoke this Thread on the benefits of giving dwellings.

original: kathesi. Tattha imā gāthā tāva saṅgahaṃ āruḷhā, pakiṇṇakadhammadesanā pana saṅgahaṃ
analyzed: kathesi tattha imā gāthā tāva saṅgaham āruḷhā pakiṇṇaka dhamma desanā pana saṅgaham
translated: Herein, these verses are included in the Compendium, but the miscellaneous Dhamma teaching does not come into the Compendium.

original: nārohati. Sandassetvātiādīni vuttatthāneva.
analyzed: na ārohati sandassetvā ati ādīni vutta tthāni eva
translated: The words “having exchanged friendly greetings” and so on have already been explained.

original: Abhikkantāti atikkantā dve yāmā gatā. Yassa dāni kālaṃ maññathāti yassa gamanassa
analyzed: abhikkantā ati atikkantāḥ dve yāmāḥ gatāḥ yassa dāni kālam maññatha ati yassa gamanassa
translated: “The first watch of the night has passed” : the two watches of the night have gone by. “Now is the time to do as you think fit” : now is the time for you to go

original: tumhe kālaṃ maññatha, gamanakālo tumhākaṃ, gacchathāti vuttaṃ hoti. Kasmā pana bhagavā
analyzed: tumhe kālam maññatha gamana kālo tumhākam gacchatha ati vuttam hoti kasmā pana bhagavā
translated: “You may know the time, the time has come for you to do as you think fit.” What is meant is: “You may go.” But why did the Blessed One send them away?

original: te uyyojesīti? Anukampāya. Tiyāmarattiñhi tattha nisīditvā vītināmentānaṃ tesaṃ sarīre
analyzed: te uyyojesi iti anukampāya tiyāma rattim hi tattha nisīditvā tesam sarīre
translated: Out of compassion. For if they had spent the three watches of the night sitting there, their bodies would have become tired and

original: ābādho uppajjeyyāti, bhikkhusaṅghepi ca vippabhātasayananisajjāya okāso laddhuṃ vaṭṭati,
analyzed: ābādhaḥ uppajjeyya ti bhikkhu saṅghe pi ca vippabhāta sayana nisajjāya okāsaḥ laddhum vaṭṭati
translated: they would have had no opportunity to sit and lie down in the company of the community of bhikkhus.🔽So he sent them away out of compassion for both.

original: iti ubhayānukampāya uyyojesīti. Suññāgāranti pāṭiyekkaṃ suññāgāraṃ nāma tattha natthi.
analyzed: iti ubhaya anukampāya uyyojesi iti suññāgāram ti pāṭiyekkam suññāgāram nāma tattha natthi
translated: A deserted abode: there is no deserted abode by itself.

original: Tena kira gahapatayo tasseva āvasathāgārassa ekapasse paṭasāṇiyā parikkhipāpetvā
analyzed: tena kira gahapatayaḥ tassa eva āvasathāgārassa eka passe paṭa sāṇiyā parikkhipāpetvā
translated: It seems that the laymen had a dwelling built for him on one side of the monastery,

original: kappiyamañcaṃ paññāpetvā tattha kappiyapaccattharaṇaṃ attharitvā upari suvaṇṇarajatatārakāgandhamālādipaṭimaṇḍitaṃ
analyzed: kappiya mañcam paññāpetvā tattha kappiya paccattharaṇam attharitvā upari suvaṇṇa rajata tārakā gandha mālā ādi paṭimaṇḍitam
translated: enclosing it with a curtain, and they had a bedstead placed there and a sitting mat spread out, and above they had a canopy hung with gold and silver stars and perfumed with scents,

original: vitānaṃ bandhitvā telappadīpaṃ āropesuṃ “appeva nāma satthā dhammāsanato vuṭṭhāya
analyzed: vitānam bandhitvā telappadīpam āropesuṃ appā iva nāma satthā dhammāsanataḥ vuṭṭhāya
translated: and they had an oil lamp lit, thinking: “Perhaps the Teacher, rising from his seat,

original: thokaṃ vissamitukāmo idha nipajjeyya, evaṃ no idaṃ āvasathāgāraṃ bhagavatā catūhi
analyzed: thokam vissamitu kāmaḥ idha nipajjeyya evam naḥ idam āvasatha āgāram bhagavatā catūhi
translated: “If he wants to rest a little, he can lie down here.” In this way the dwelling place was given to the Buddha by the four great kings.

original: iriyāpathehi paribhuttaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissatī”ti. Satthāpi tadeva🔽sandhāya tattha saṅghāṭiṃ paññāpetvā sīhaseyyaṃ kappesi. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “suññāgāraṃ🔽pāvisī”ti. Tattha pādadhovanaṭṭhānato paṭṭhāya yāva dhammāsanā agamāsi, ettake ṭhāne🔽gamanaṃ nipphannaṃ. Dhammāsanaṃ patvā thokaṃ aṭṭhāsi, idaṃ tattha ṭhānaṃ. Bhagavā🔽dve yāme dhammāsane nisīdi, ettake ṭhāne nisajjā nipphannā. Upāsake uyyojetvā dhammāsanato
analyzed: iriyāpathehi paribhuttam dīgharattam hitāya sukhāya bhavissati iti satthā api tat eva  sandhāya tattha saṅghāṭim paññāpetvā sīha seyyam kappesi tam sandhāya vuttam suññāgāram  pāvisi iti tattha pāda dhovana ṭṭhānato paṭṭhāya yāva dhamma āsanā agamāsi ettake ṭhāne  gamanam nipphannam dhammāsanam patvā thokam aṭṭhāsi idam tattha ṭhānam bhagavā  dve yāme dhammāsane nisīdi ettake ṭhāne nisajjā nipphannā upāsake uyyojetvā dhammāsanato
translated: “If he were to lie down here for a little while, then this dwelling-place of ours would be used by the Lord for a long time in the four postures of the body, to our welfare and happiness.” The Teacher, thinking of this,

original: oruyha yathāvutte ṭhāne sīhaseyyaṃ kappesi. Evaṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ bhagavatā catūhi iriyāpathehi🔽paribhuttaṃ ahosīti.
analyzed: oruyha yathāvutte ṭhāne sīha seyyam kappesi evam tam ṭhānam bhagavatā catūhi iriyāpathehi 🔽paribhuttam ahosi iti
translated: spread out his outer robe and lay down in the lion’s posture. It was in reference to this that it was said: “entered an empty dwelling.” From the time he went from the place for washing the feet up to the seat of the Dhamma, the going was the performance. When he reached the seat of the Dhamma he stood for a little while. This was the standing there. The Lord sat down on the seat of the Dhamma for two watches of the night. This was the sitting there. After dismissing the lay devotees he came down from the seat of the Dhamma, and in the place mentioned above he lay down in the lion’s posture. Thus that place was used by the Lord for a long time in the four postures of the body.

original: Sunidhavassakārāti sunidho ca vassakāro ca dve brāhmaṇā. Magadhamahāmattāti magadharañño
analyzed: sunidha vassakārā ati sunidhaḥ ca vassakāro ca dve brāhmaṇāḥ magadha mahāmattā ati magadha raññaḥ
translated: Sunidha and Vassakara: two Brahmins. Ministers of Magadha: ministers of the king of Magadha.

original: mahāamaccā, magadharaṭṭhe vā mahāmattā mahatiyā issariyamattāya samannāgatāti mahāmattā.
analyzed: mahāamaccā magadharaṭṭhe vā mahā mattā mahatiyā issariya mattāya samannāgatā ati mahā mattā
translated: Sunidha and Vassakara: two Brahmins. Great ministers of Magadha: great ministers of the king of Magadha, or great ministers in the kingdom of Magadha, endowed with great authority, they are great ministers.

original: Pāṭaligāme nagaraṃ māpentīti pāṭaligāmasaṅkhāte bhūmipadese nagaraṃ māpenti. Vajjīnaṃ
analyzed: pāṭaligāme nagaram mā āpenti iti pāṭaligāma saṅkhāte bhūmi padese nagaram mā āpenti vajjīnam
translated: They are building a city at Pataliputta: they are building a city in the place called Pataliputta.

original: paṭibāhāyāti licchavirājūnaṃ āyamukhappacchindanatthaṃ. Sahassasahassevāti ekekavaggavasena🔽sahassaṃ sahassaṃ hutvā. Vatthūnīti gharavatthūni. Cittāni namanti nivesanāni māpetunti
analyzed: paṭibāhāya ati āya mukha ppacchindana attham sahassa sahassā iva āti eka eka vagga vasena  sahassam sahassam hutvā vatthūni iti ghara vatthūni cittāni namanti nivesanāni mā āpetunti
translated: To ward off the Vajjians: to cut off the source of their wealth, the Licchavi kings.🔽As if they were a thousand times a thousand: as if they were a thousand times a thousand.

original: rañño rājamahāmattānañca nivesanāni māpetuṃ vatthuvijjāpāṭhakānaṃ cittāni namanti.
analyzed: raññaḥ rāja mahāmattānam ca nivesanāni māpetum vatthu vijjā pāṭhakānam cittāni namanti
translated: Sites: building sites. Their minds are inclined to build dwellings: their minds are inclined to build dwellings for the king and the king’s ministers.

original: Te kira attano sippānubhāvena heṭṭhāpathaviyaṃ tiṃsahatthamatte ṭhāne “idha nāgaggāho,
analyzed: te kira attano sippa anubhāvena heṭṭhā pathaviyam tiṃsa hattha matte ṭhāne idha nāga ggāho
translated: It seems that by the power of their craft they know at a depth of thirty cubits in the earth below: “Here is a nāga-entrance,

original: idha yakkhaggāho, idha bhūtaggāho, idha pāsāṇo vā khāṇuko vā atthī”ti jānanti. Te
analyzed: idha yakkha gāhaḥ idha bhūta gāhaḥ idha pāsāṇaḥ vā khāṇukaḥ vā atthi iti jānanti te
translated: here a yakkha-entrance, here a bhūta-entrance, here is a stone or a stump.” They

original: tadā sippaṃ jappetvā devatāhi saddhiṃ sammantayamānā viya māpenti.
analyzed: tadā sippam jappetvā devatāhi saddhim sammantayamānāḥ viya māpenti
translated: and they build them as if consulting with the deities.

original: Atha vā nesaṃ sarīre devatā adhimuccitvā tattha tattha nivesanāni māpetuṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: atha vā na īsam sarīre devatāḥ adhimuccitvā tattha tattha nivesanāni mā āpetum cittam
translated: Or else the deities become intent on the families’ welfare and inspire them to build dwellings here and there.

original: nāmenti. Tā catūsu koṇesu khāṇuke koṭṭetvā vatthumhi gahitamatte paṭivigacchanti.
analyzed: tā catūsu koṇesu khāṇuke koṭṭetvā vatthumhi gahita matte paṭivigacchanti
translated: They tap the posts in the four corners, and when the site has been marked out, they disappear.

original: Saddhakulānaṃ saddhā devatā tathā karonti, assaddhakulānaṃ assaddhā devatā. Kiṃkāraṇā?
analyzed: saddha kulānam saddhāḥ devatā tathā karonti assaddha kulānam assaddhāḥ devatā kiṃkāraṇā
translated: Deities with faith do this for families with faith, and deities without faith for families without faith. Why is this?

original: Saddhānañhi evaṃ hoti “idha manussā nivesanaṃ māpentā paṭhamaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ nisīdāpetvā
analyzed: saddhānam hi evam hoti idha manussāḥ nivesanam māpentā paṭhamam bhikkhu saṅgham nisīdāpetvā
translated: For the thought occurs to the faithful: ‘When people build a dwelling, they will first seat the Community of Bhikkhus and have them utter a blessing.

original: maṅgalaṃ vadāpessanti, atha mayaṃ sīlavantānaṃ dassanaṃ dhammakathaṃ pañhavissajjanaṃ
analyzed: maṅgalam vadāpessanti atha mayam sīlavantānam dassanam dhamma katham pañha vissajjanam
translated: Then we shall be able to see the virtuous and hear a talk on the Dhamma and the answering of questions

original: anumodanaṃ sotuṃ labhissāma, manussā ca dānaṃ datvā amhākaṃ pattiṃ dassantī”ti. Assaddhā
analyzed: anumodanam sotum labhissāma manussā ca dānam da tvā amhākam pattim dassanti iti assaddhā
translated: and the expression of appreciation. And people will give us the merit of the offering.’

original: devatāpi “attano icchānurūpaṃ tesaṃ paṭipattiṃ passituṃ, kathañca sotuṃ labhissāmā”ti tathā karonti.
analyzed: devatā api attanaḥ icchā anurūpam tesam paṭipattim passitum kathañca sotum labhissāma ati tathā karonti
translated: The faithless deities think: ‘How shall we be able to see and hear the performance of the rite in the way we want?’ So they do this.

original: Tāvatiṃsehīti yathā hi ekasmiṃ kule ekaṃ paṇḍitamanussaṃ, ekasmiñca vihāre ekaṃ bahussutaṃ
analyzed: tāvatiṃsehi iti yathā hi ekasmim kule ekam paṇḍita manussam ekasmin ca vihāre ekam bahu ssutam
translated: As in a family the wise man is the one, and in a monastery the learned one is the one,🔽

original: bhikkhuṃ upādāya “asukakule manussā paṇḍitā, asukavihāre bhikkhū bahussutā”ti saddo
analyzed: bhikkhum upādāya asuka kule manussā paṇḍitāḥ asuka vihāre bhikkhū bahu ssutā ati saddaḥ
translated: For just as in a single family the wise man is the one who is spoken of as “the wise man in this family,” and in a single monastery the learned bhikkhu is the one who is spoken of as “the learned man in this monastery,”

original: abbhuggacchati, evameva sakkaṃ devarājānaṃ, vissakammañca devaputtaṃ upādāya “tāvatiṃsā🔽paṇḍitā”ti saddo abbhuggato. Tenāha “tāvatiṃsehī”ti. Seyyathāpītiādinā devehi tāvatiṃsehi
analyzed: abbhuk gacchati evam eva sakkam devarājānam vissakammam ca devaputtam upādāya tāvatiṃsā  paṇḍita ati saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ tena āha tāvatiṃsehi iti seyyathā api iti ādinā devehi tāvatiṃsehi
translated: so too, the expression “the Thirty-three” is used in reference to Sakka, king of the gods, and to the divine youth Suja.

original: saddhiṃ mantetvā viya sunidhavassakārā nagaraṃ māpentīti dasseti.
analyzed: saddhim mantetvā viya sunidha vassakārāḥ nagaram māpenti iti dasseti
translated: Therefore it is said: “among the Thirty-three gods.” The words “just as if” and so on show that they planned the city as if in consultation with the Thirty-three gods.

original: Yāvatā, ānanda, ariyaṃ āyatananti yattakaṃ ariyamanussānaṃ osaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ nāma atthi.🔽Yāvatā vaṇippathoti yattakaṃ vāṇijānaṃ āhaṭabhaṇḍassa rāsivasena kayavikkayaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: yāvatā ānanda ariyam āyatanan ti yattakam ariya manussānam osaraṇa ṭhānam nāma atthi  yāvatā vaṇi patho ti yattakam vāṇijānam āhaṭa bhaṇḍassa rāsi vasena kaya vikkaya ṭṭhānam
translated: “As far as the noble fields extend”: as far as there are places for the noble ones to descend.🔽“As far as the trade-routes extend”: as far as there are places for the buying and selling of goods brought by traders, or as far as there are places where traders live.

original: nāma, vāṇijānaṃ vasanaṭṭhānaṃ vā atthi. Idaṃ agganagaranti tesaṃ ariyāyatanavaṇippathānaṃ
analyzed: nāma vāṇijānam vasana ṭṭhānam vā atthi idam agga nagaran ti tesam ariya āyatana vaṇippathānam
translated: “This is the best city”: among the noble fields and trade-routes.

original: idaṃ nagaraṃ aggaṃ bhavissati jeṭṭhakaṃ pāmokkhaṃ. Puṭabhedananti bhaṇḍapuṭabhedanaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: idam nagaram aggam bhavissati jeṭṭhakam pāmokkham puṭabhedanam ti bhaṇḍa puṭabhedana ṭhānaṃ
translated: This city will be the best, the foremost, the most excellent. The place for opening bales means the place for opening up goods that are in bales;

original: bhaṇḍabhaṇḍikānaṃ mocanaṭṭhānanti vuttaṃ hoti. Sakalajambudīpe aladdhabhaṇḍampi hi
analyzed: bhaṇḍa bhaṇḍikānam mocana ṭṭhānan ti vuttam hoti sakala jambudīpe a laddha bhaṇḍam pi hi
translated: the place for unloading goods that are in bales is what is meant. For even goods that have not been obtained in the whole of India

original: idheva labhissanti, aññattha vikkayaṃ agacchantāpi idheva vikkayaṃ gacchissanti,
analyzed: idhā iva labhissanti aññattha vikkayam agacchanta api idhā iva vikkayam gacchissanti
translated: will be obtained here. And those who go to sell their goods will go to sell them here.

original: tasmā idheva puṭaṃ bhindissantīti attho. Āyānampi hi catūsu dvāresu cattāri, sabhāyaṃ
analyzed: tasmai idha iva puṭam bhindissanti iti attho āyānam pi hi catūsu dvāresu cattāri sabhāyam
translated: Therefore the meaning is that they will open up their bales here. For there will be four entrances at the four gates,

original: ekanti evaṃ divase divase pañcasatasahassāni tattha uṭṭhahissanti. Tāni sabhāvāni āyānīti dasseti.
analyzed: ekam ti evam divase divase pañca sata sahassāni tattha uṭṭhahissanti tāni sabhāvāni āyāni iti dasseti
translated: and one in the assembly hall. Thus five hundred thousand will arise there each day. He shows that those are the incomes.

original: Aggito vātiādīsu samuccayattho vāsaddo, agginā ca udakena ca mithubhedena ca nassissatīti
analyzed: aggitaḥ vā ati ādīsu samuccaya tthaḥ vā saddaḥ agginā ca udakena ca mithu bhedena ca
translated: As regards the words “from fire, etc.,” the word “and” has the conjunctive sense. The meaning is: it will be destroyed by fire, water, and dissension among the friends.

original: attho. Tassa hi eko koṭṭhāso agginā nassissati, nibbāpetuṃ na sakkhissanti, ekaṃ🔽koṭṭhāsaṃ gaṅgā gahetvā gamissati, eko iminā akathitaṃ amussa, amunā akathitaṃ imassa
analyzed: attho tassa hi ekaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ agginā nassissati nibbāpetum na sakkhissanti ekam 🔽koṭṭhāsam gaṅgā gahetvā gamissati ekaḥ iminā a kathitam amussa amunā a kathitam imassa
translated: For one part of it will be destroyed by fire; they will not be able to extinguish it. One part🔽the Ganges will carry away. One will be destroyed by the people of this country not speaking to the people of that country, and vice versa.

original: vadantānaṃ pisuṇavācānaṃ vasena bhinnānaṃ manussānaṃ aññamaññabhedena vinassissati.
analyzed: vadantānam pisuṇa vācānam vasena bhinnānam manussānam aññamañña bhedena vinassissati
translated: and through the evil speech of those who will speak maliciously, people will be divided and will perish through mutual disunion.

original: Evaṃ vatvā bhagavā paccūsakāle gaṅgātīraṃ gantvā katamukhadhovano bhikkhācāravelaṃ āgamayamāno nisīdi.
analyzed: evam vatvā bhagavā paccūsa kāle gaṅgā tīram gantvā kata mukha dhovanaḥ bhikkhā cāra velam āgamayamānaḥ nisīdi
translated: Having said this, the Lord went to the bank of the Ganges at dawn, and after washing his face, he sat down to wait for the time to go for alms.

original: Sunidhavassakārāpi “amhākaṃ rājā samaṇassa gotamassa upaṭṭhāko, so amhe upagate pucchissati
analyzed: amhākam rājā samaṇassa gotamassa upaṭṭhāko so amhe upagate pucchissati
translated: Sunīdha and Vassakāra thought: “Our king is a supporter of the ascetic Gotama, and when we go to him he will ask:

original: ‘satthā kira pāṭaligāmaṃ agamāsi, kiṃ tassa santikaṃ upasaṅkamittha, na upasaṅkamitthā’ti.🔽‘Upasaṅkamimhā’ti ca vutte ‘nimantayittha, na nimantayitthā’ti pucchissati. ‘Na nimantayimhā’ti
analyzed: satthā kira pāṭaligāmam agamāsi kim tassa santikam upasaṅkamittha na upasaṅkamittha ati  upasaṅkamimha ati ca vutte nimantayittha na nimantayittha ati pucchissati na nimantayimha ati
translated: ‘They say the Teacher has come to Pāṭali Village. Did you go to see him, or not?🔽’ And if we say that we did, he will ask: ‘Did you invite him to come for a meal tomorrow? Or didn’t you invite him?

original: ca vutte amhākaṃ dosaṃ āropetvā niggaṇhissati, idañcāpi mayaṃ akataṭṭhāne nagaraṃ
analyzed: ca vutte amhākam dosam āropetvā niggaṇhissati idam ca api mayam a kata ṭṭhāne nagaram
translated: ’ And if we say that we didn’t invite him, he will accuse us of a fault and punish us. And we have not yet built the city,

original: māpema, samaṇassa kho pana gotamassa gatagataṭṭhāne kāḷakaṇṇisattā paṭikkamanti,
analyzed: māpema samaṇassa kho pana gotamassa gata gata ṭṭhāne kāḷakaṇṇi sattā paṭikkamanti
translated: and wherever the ascetic Gotama goes, black cobras flee before him.

original: taṃ mayaṃ nagaramaṅgalaṃ vācāpessāmā”ti cintetvā satthāraṃ upasaṅkamitvā nimantayiṃsu.
analyzed: tam mayam nagara maṅgalam vācā āpessāma iti cintetvā satthāram upasaṅkamitvā nimantayiṃsu
translated: So they approached the Teacher and invited him.

original: Tena vuttaṃ – “atha kho sunidhavassakārā”tiādi.
analyzed: tena vuttam atha kho sunidha vassaka arāti ādi
translated: Therefore it is said: “Then Sunīdha and Vassakāra” and so on.

original: Pubbaṇhasamayanti pubbaṇhe kāle. Nivāsetvāti gāmapavesananīhārena nivāsanaṃ nivāsetvā kāyabandhanaṃ bandhitvā. Pattacīvaramādāyāti cīvaraṃ pārupitvā pattaṃ hatthena gahetvā.

analyzed: pattim dadeyya pūjitā pūjayanti iti ime manussāḥ amhākam ñātakāḥ api na honti evam pi

analyzed: no pattim denti iti ārakkham su saṃvihitam karonti suṭṭhu ārakkham karonti mānitā
translated: ” Therefore they make their protection well-ordered, they make their protection well-arranged.🔽Respected:

analyzed: mānayanti iti kāla anukālam bali kamma karaṇena mānitāḥ ete manussāḥ amhākam ñātakāḥ api na

analyzed: haranti tatas tam paṇḍita jātikam purisam ure ṭhapetvā vaḍḍhitam
translated: Then: “Then that wise man” . He was brought up, placed on his mother’s breast,

analyzed: yathā mātā orasam puttam anukampati uppanna parissaya haraṇa attham eva assa yathā vā āyamati
translated: just as a mother feels compassion for her child and makes an effort to remove the suffering that has arisen,

translated: so they felt compassion for him. He saw what was good: he saw what was beautiful.

analyzed: anumoditvā ti tehi tadā pasuta puññassa anumodana vasena tesam dhamma katham katvā
translated: After rejoicing: after rejoicing in the merit made by them by way of rejoicing in the Dhamma talk given to them, Sunīdha and Vassakāra

analyzed: yāḥ tattha devatāḥ āsum tāsam dakkhiṇam ādisa iti bhagavataḥ vacanam sutvā devatānam
translated: “Whatever deities there were, they gave the gift to them” . Having heard the Blessed One’s words, they gave the gift to the deities.

analyzed: nikkhami tam gotamadvāram nāma ahosi gaṅgāya pana uttaraṇa attham gotamatittham  nāma nā ahosi pūrā ati puṇṇā samatittikā ati taṭa samam udakassa tittā bharitā kākapeyyā ti  tīre ṭhita kākehi pātum padehi ubhatas kūla samam paripuṇṇa bhāvam eva

translated: Both words show that the water was full to the banks. Uḷumpi means a raft made by lashing together logs and planks. Kullā means

translated: a raft made by lashing together bamboo poles, etc., and creepers, etc.

analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam mahā janassa gaṅgā udaka mattassa api kevalam taritum
translated: Having known this matter: having known that the great mass of water in the Ganges was not enough for the people to cross over,

translated: This is what is said: those who cross the ocean of the round of rebirths that is deep and wide and the river of craving, having made a bridge called the noble path,🔽without even touching the water-filled low-lying places, are like this man who, wanting to cross this little water,

analyzed: idam appamattakam udakam taritu kāmo kullam hi janaḥ pabandhati kullam bandhitum āyāsam  āpajjati tiṇṇā medhāvinaḥ janāti ariya magga ñāṇa saṅkhātāya medhāya samannāgata ttā
translated: binds a raft and makes an effort to bind the raft. The wise people who have crossed🔽are the Buddhas and the Buddhas’ disciples, who, because they are endowed with the wisdom called the knowledge of the noble path,

original: Chaṭṭhasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.

original: 7. Dvidhāpathasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dvidhāpatha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on the Crossroads

original: 77. Sattame addhānamaggapaṭipannoti addhānasaṅkhātaṃ dīghamaggaṃ paṭipanno gacchanto
analyzed: sattame addhāna magga paṭipannaḥ ti addhāna saṅkhātam dīgha maggam paṭipannaḥ gacchantaḥ

analyzed: vīsati vassāni a nibaddhāḥ upaṭṭhākāḥ ahesum tatas param yāva parinibbānā pañcavīsati vassāni  āyasmā ānando chāyā va upaṭṭhāsi ayam pana a nibaddha upaṭṭhāka kālo tena vuttam āyasmatā
translated: the Blessed One had no regular attendant, but for the next twenty-five years until his final extinction🔽the venerable Ānanda was his attendant like a shadow that keeps nothing back. But this was the time when he had no regular attendant. That is why it is said, “with the venerable Nāgasamāla as his attendant.”

original: nāgasamālena pacchāsamaṇenā”ti. Dvidhāpathanti dvidhābhūtaṃ maggaṃ. “Dvedhāpatha”ntipi
analyzed: nāga samālena pacchā samaṇena ati dvidhā pathanti dvidhā bhūtam maggam
translated: “A cross-road” is a road at a junction. Some read “Dvedhāpatha” .

analyzed: paṭhanti āyasmā nāgasamālaḥ attanā pubbe tattha kata paricaya ttā uju bhāvañcassa sandhāya
translated: The venerable Nāgasamāla said this because he had himself previously made a study of the place and because of the Blessed One’s uprightness.

original: vadati “ayaṃ, bhante bhagavā, pantho”ti.
analyzed: vadati ayam bhante bhagavā panthā iti
translated: “This is the road, venerable sir, for the Blessed One.”

original: Bhagavā pana tadā tassa saparissayabhāvaṃ ñatvā tato aññaṃ maggaṃ gantukāmo “ayaṃ,🔽nāgasamāla, pantho”ti āha. “Saparissayo”ti ca vutte asaddahitvā “bhagavā na tattha
analyzed: bhagavā pana tadā tassa sa parissaya bhāvam ñatvā tatas aññam maggam gantu kāmo ayam  pantho ti āha sa parissayaḥ ti ca vutte a saddahitvā bhagavā na tattha
translated: The Exalted One, however, knew that the road was dangerous, and wishing to take another route, said: “This is the road, Nāgasamāla.”

original: parissayo”ti vadeyya, tadassa dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyāti “saparissayo”ti na kathesi.🔽Tikkhattuṃ “ayaṃ pantho, iminā gacchāmā”ti vatvā catutthavāre “na bhagavā iminā maggena
analyzed: parissayaḥ iti vadeyya tat assa dīgharattam ahitāya dukkhāya ati sa parissayaḥ iti na kathesi  tikkhattum ayam pantho iminā gacchāma iti vatvā catuttha vāre na bhagavā iminā maggena
translated: If Nāgasamāla had said: “It is dangerous,” and had not believed it, and had said: “The Exalted One will not be in danger there,” it would have been to his long-lasting harm and suffering. Therefore, the Exalted One did not say: “It is dangerous.”

translated: Three times he said: “This is the road. Let us go by this road.” But the fourth time he thought: “The Exalted One does not wish to go by this road. This is the straight road. Let me give the Exalted One his bowl and robe, and go by this road.”

original: maggena gamissāmī”ti cintetvā satthu pattacīvaraṃ dātuṃ asakkonto bhūmiyaṃ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: maggena gamissāmi iti cintetvā satthu patta cīvaram dātum a sakkontaḥ bhūmiyam ṭhapetvā
translated: Unable to give the bowl and robe to the Exalted One, he placed them on the ground and,

analyzed: paccupaṭṭhitena dukkha saṃvattanikena kammunā codiyamānaḥ bhagavataḥ vacanam an ādiyitvā ava
translated: urged on by the deed that was to bring him suffering, he went away without heeding the Exalted One’s words.

original: pakkāmi. Tena vuttaṃ – “atha kho āyasmā nāgasamālo bhagavato pattacīvaraṃ tattheva
analyzed: tena vuttam atha kho āyasmā nāgasamālaḥ bhagavato patta cīvaram tattha iva
translated: Therefore it was said: “Then the venerable Nāgasamāla left the bowl and robe of the Exalted One right there and went away.”

original: chamāyaṃ nikkhipitvā pakkāmī”ti. Tattha bhagavato pattacīvaranti attano hatthagataṃ
analyzed: chamāyam nikkhipitvā pakkāmi iti tattha bhagavato patta cīvaranti attanaḥ hattha gatam
translated: and left the Blessed One’s bowl and robe on the road and went away.”🔽The Blessed One’s bowl and robe: the bowl and robe that were in his hand.

original: bhagavato pattacīvaraṃ. Tatthevāti tasmiṃyeva magge chamāyaṃ pathaviyaṃ nikkhipitvā🔽pakkāmi. Idaṃ vo bhagavā pattacīvaraṃ, sace icchatha, gaṇhatha, yadi attanā icchitamaggaṃyeva
analyzed: bhagavato patta cīvaram tattha iva ati tasmin yeva magge chamāyam pathaviyam nikkhipitvā  idam vaḥ bhagavā patta cīvaram sace icchatha gaṇhatha yadi
translated: There on the road: on the road itself, on the ground.

original: gantukāmatthāti adhippāyo. Bhagavāpi attano pattacīvaraṃ sayameva gahetvā yathādhippetaṃ maggaṃ paṭipajji.
analyzed: gantu kāmatthā ati adhippāyaḥ bhagavā api attanaḥ patta cīvaram sayam eva gahetvā yathā adhippetam maggam paṭipajji
translated: He left them there and went away. This is the Blessed One’s bowl and robe. If you wish, take them. The intention is that he wanted to go on his own way. The Blessed One took his own bowl and robe and went on his way as he had planned.

original: Antarāmagge corā nikkhamitvāti tadā kira pañcasatā purisā luddā lohitapāṇino rājāparādhino🔽hutvā araññaṃ pavisitvā corikāya jīvikaṃ kappentā “pāripanthikabhāvena rañño āyapathaṃ
analyzed: antara āmagge corāḥ nikkhamitvā ati tadā kira pañca satā purisāḥ luddāḥ lohita pāṇinaḥ rāja aparādhinaḥ  hutvā araññam pavisitvā corikāya jīvikam kappentā pāripanthika bhāvena raññaḥ āya patham
translated: Robbers came out on the road: it seems that at that time five hundred hunters, their hands bloody, having offended the king,🔽having fled and entered the forest, were making a living by banditry. They were standing in the forest near the road, thinking: “We will cut off the king’s line of supply by way of an ambush.”

original: pacchindissāmā”ti maggasamīpe araññe tiṭṭhanti. Te theraṃ tena maggena gacchantaṃ
analyzed: pacchindissāma ati magga samīpe araññe tiṭṭhanti te theram tena maggena gacchantam
translated: They saw the elder going on that road.

original: disvā “ayaṃ samaṇo iminā maggena āgacchati, avaḷañjitabbaṃ maggaṃ vaḷañjeti, amhākaṃ
analyzed: disvā ayam samaṇaḥ iminā maggena āgacchati a vaḷañjitabbam maggam vaḷañjeti amhākam
translated: and they said, “This monk is coming along this path. He is clearing the path that we have not cleared.

analyzed: sahasā theram bhūmiyam pātetvā hattha pādehi koṭṭetvā mattikā pattam cassa bhinditvā
translated: and they suddenly threw the Elder to the ground. They beat him with their hands and feet, broke his clay bowl,

analyzed: cīvaram khaṇḍākhaṇḍikam chinditvā pabbajita ttā tam na hanāma itas paṭṭhāya imassa
translated: and tore his robe to shreds. Then they said, “Since he is a monk, we will not kill him. But from now on

analyzed: maggassa parissaya bhāvam jānāhi iti vissajjesum tena vuttam atha kho āyasmat ope vipphālesun ti
translated: know that this path is dangerous.” And they let him go. That is why it was said, “Then the venerable elder … was released.”

original: Bhagavāpi “ayaṃ tena maggena gato corehi bādhito maṃ pariyesitvā idāneva āgamissatī”ti
analyzed: bhagavā api ayam tena maggena gataḥ corehi bādhitaḥ mam pariyesitvā idānā iva āgamissati iti
translated: The Blessed One thought, “He has gone along that path. He has been attacked by bandits. He will be looking for me. He will come now.”

original: ñatvā thokaṃ gantvā maggā okkamma aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle nisīdi. Āyasmāpi kho nāgasamālo
analyzed: ñatvā thokam gantvā maggā okkamma aññatarasmim rukkha mūle nisīdi āyasmā api kho nāgasamālo

analyzed: paccāgantvā satthārā gata maggam eva gahetvā gacchantaḥ tasmiṃ rukkha mūle bhagavantam

analyzed: passitvā upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā tam pavattim sabbam ārocesi tena vuttam atha  kho āyasman nāga samālope saṅghāṭiñca vipphālesunti
translated: and he returned by the way he had come. As he was going he saw the Blessed One at the foot of the tree. He approached him, paid homage to him, and told him all that had happened. Hence it is said: “Then the venerable Nāgasamāla … and shook out his outer robe.”

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvāti etaṃ āyasmato nāgasamālassa attano vacanaṃ anādiyitvā akhemantamaggagamanaṃ, attano ca khemantamaggagamanaṃ viditvā tadatthadīpanaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: etam attham viditvā iti etam āyasmataḥ nāgasamālassa attanaḥ vacanam an ādiyitvā a khemanta magga gamanam attanaḥ ca khemanta magga gamanam viditvā tad attha dīpanam imam udānam udānesi
translated: “Knowing the meaning of this”: knowing the venerable Nāgasamāla’s refusal to follow his advice and his going by an unsafe path, and his own going by a safe path, he uttered this exclamation revealing that meaning.

original: Tattha saddhiṃ caranti saha caranto. Ekato vasanti idaṃ tasseva vevacanaṃ, saha vasantoti🔽attho. Misso aññajanena vedagūti veditabbaṭṭhena vedasaṅkhātena catusaccaariyamaggañāṇena
analyzed: tattha saddhim caranti saha carantaḥ ekatas vasanti idam tassa iva vevacanam saha vasanto ti  atthaḥ missaḥ añña janena vedagū ti veditabba ṭṭhena veda saṅkhātena catu sacca ariya magga ñāṇena
translated: Herein, they go together, they go along together, they live together, this is a synonym for that. The meaning is: living together.🔽The one who has gone to the end of the wise man’s knowledge: the one who has gone to the end of the wise man’s knowledge in the sense of being known as the one who has gone to the end of the knowledge called the wise man’s knowledge, which is the knowledge of the four noble truths that are the ariyan path.

original: gatattā adhigatattā, vedassa vā sakalassa ñeyyassa pāraṃ gatattā vedagū. Attano hitāhitaṃ
analyzed: gatattā adhigatattā vedassa vā sakalassa ñeyyassa pāram gatattā vedagū attanaḥ hita ahitam
translated: Or he is a wise man because he has gone to the end of the entire knowable.

original: na jānātīti añño, avidvā bāloti attho. Tena aññena janena misso sahacaraṇamattena🔽misso. Vidvā pajahāti pāpakanti tena vedagūbhāvena vidvā jānanto pāpakaṃ abhaddakaṃ
analyzed: na jānāti iti aññaḥ a vidvā bālo ti attho tena aññena janena misso sahacaraṇa mattena  missaḥ vidvā pajahāti pāpakanti tena vedagū bhāvena vidvā jānantaḥ pāpakam abhaddakam
translated: “Does not know” means that he is different, the meaning being that he is ignorant, a fool. He is “mixed” with that other person, mixed by mere association.

original: attano dukkhāvahaṃ pajahāti, pāpakaṃ vā akalyāṇapuggalaṃ pajahāti. Yathā kiṃ? Koñco🔽khīrapakova ninnaganti yathā koñcasakuṇo udakamissite khīre upanīte vinā toyaṃ khīramattasseva
analyzed: attanaḥ dukkha āvaham pajahāti pāpakam vā akalyāṇa puggalam pajahāti yathā kim koñco  khīra pakā uva ninnaganti yathā koñca sakuṇaḥ udaka missite khīre upanīte vinā toyam khīra mattassa iva
translated: “The wise man abandons evil”: by means of that knowledge which is called “the wise man’s” , the wise man, the knower, abandons evil, unwholesome states that bring him suffering, or he abandons evil, unwholesome people. How?🔽“Like a bird, a drop of oil, or a grain of salt.”

original: pivanato khīrapako ninnaṭṭhānagamanena ninnagasaṅkhātaṃ udakaṃ pajahāti vajjeti,
analyzed: pivanataḥ khīrapakaḥ ninna ṭṭhāna gamanena ninnaga saṅkhātam udakam pajahāti vajja iti
translated: Just as a bird, when it has drunk water mixed with oil, abandons the water, which is called “the low,” by going to a high place,

original: evaṃ paṇḍito kira duppaññapuggalehi ṭhānanisajjādīsu sahabhūtopi ācārena te pajahāti,
analyzed: evam paṇḍitaḥ kira duppañña puggalehi ṭhāna nisajja ādīsu saha bhūtaḥ api ācārena te pajahāti
translated: so the wise man, though he may be in the same place or on the same seat as ignorant people, abandons them by his conduct,

original: na kadācipi sammisso hoti.
analyzed: na kadācid pi sammissaḥ hoti
translated: and is never mixed up with them.

original: Sattamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽8. Visākhāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sattama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  visākhā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the seventh sutta is finished.🔽The Visākhā Sutta

original: 78. Aṭṭhame visākhāya migāramātuyā nattā kālaṅkatā hotīti visākhāya mahāupāsikāya
analyzed: aṭṭhame visākhāya migāra mātuyā nattā kālaṅkatā hoti iti visākhāya mahā upāsikāya
translated: In the eighth sutta, “Visākhā’s grandson” is the grandson of the laywoman Visākhā,

original: puttassa dhītā kumārikā kālaṅkatā hoti. Sā kira vattasampannā sāsane abhippasannā
analyzed: puttassa dhītā kumārikā kālaṅkatā hoti sā kira vatta sampannā sāsane abhippasannā
translated: The daughter of the son, a girl, died. She was virtuous, and had faith in the Dispensation.

original: mahāupāsikāya gehaṃ paviṭṭhānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunīnañca attanā kātabbaveyyāvaccaṃ
analyzed: mahā upāsikāya geham paviṭṭhānam bhikkhūnam bhikkhunīnam ca attanā kātabba veyyāvaccam
translated: She was diligent in doing what was to be done for the monks and nuns who entered the house of the great lay devotee.

original: purebhattaṃ pacchābhattañca appamattā akāsi, attano pitāmahiyā cittānukūlaṃ paṭipajji.
analyzed: purebhattam pacchābhattam ca appamattā akāsi attanaḥ pitāmahiyā citta anukūlam paṭipajji
translated: She did it before the meal and after the meal. She behaved in a way that was pleasing to her grandmother.

original: Tena visākhā gehato bahi gacchantī sabbaṃ tassāyeva bhāraṃ katvā gacchati, rūpena
analyzed: tena visākhā gehataḥ bahi gacchantī sabbam tassāya iva bhāram katvā gacchati rūpena
translated: Therefore Visākhā, when going out of the house, made everything her responsibility. She was beautiful,

original: ca dassanīyā pāsādikā, iti sā tassā visesato piyā manāpā ahosi. Sā rogābhibhūtā kālamakāsi.
analyzed: ca dassanīyā pāsādikā iti sā tassāḥ visesataḥ piyā manāpā ahosi sā roga abhibhūtā kālam akāsi
translated: and pleasing to the eye. Thus she was especially dear and beloved to her. She was overcome by illness and died.

original: Tena vuttaṃ – “tena kho pana samayena visākhāya migāramātuyā nattā kālaṅkatā hoti
analyzed: tena vuttam tena kha pana samayena visākhāya migāra mātuyāḥ nattā kālaṅkatā hoti
translated: Therefore it was said: “Then at that time the daughter of Visākhā, Migāra’s mother, died,

original: piyā manāpā”ti. Atha mahāupāsikā tassā maraṇena sokaṃ sandhāretuṃ asakkontī dukkhī
analyzed: piyā manāpā ati atha mahā upāsikā tassāḥ maraṇena sokam sandhāretum a sakkontī dukkhī
translated: and was dear and beloved.” Then the great lay devotee, being unable to bear the grief of her death, was miserable

original: dummanā sarīranikkhepaṃ kāretvā “api nāma satthu santikaṃ gatakāle cittassādaṃ labheyya”nti
analyzed: dummanā sarīra nikkhepam kāretvā api nāma satthu santikam gata kāle citta ssādam labheyyanti
translated: and sad. She had the body laid out, thinking: “Perhaps she will find satisfaction in her mind when she goes into the presence of the Teacher.”

original: bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkami. Tena vuttaṃ – “atha kho visākhā migāramātā”tiādi. Tattha
analyzed: bhagavantam upasaṅkami tena vuttam atha kho visākhā migāra mātā atiādi tattha
translated: He approached the Blessed One. Therefore it is said: “Then Visākhā, Migāra’s mother” and so on.

original: divā divassāti divasassāpi divā, majjhanhike kāleti attho.
analyzed: divā divassā ati divasassa api divā majjhanhike kāle ti attho
translated: Day after day: even by day of the day, at midday, is the meaning.

original: Bhagavā visākhāya vaṭṭābhiratiṃ jānanto upāyena sokatanukaraṇatthaṃ “iccheyyāsi tvaṃ
analyzed: bhagavā visākhāya vaṭṭa abhiratim jānantaḥ upāyena soka tanu karaṇa attham iccheyyāsi tvam
translated: The Blessed One, knowing Visākhā’s delight in round things, spoke thus with a device in order to remove her sorrow: “Would you like, Visākhā,

original: visākhe”tiādimāha. Tattha yāvatikāti yattakā. Tadā kira satta janakoṭiyo sāvatthiyaṃ🔽paṭivasanti. Taṃ sandhāya bhagavā “kīvabahukā pana visākhe sāvatthiyā manussā devasikaṃ
analyzed: visākhā iti ādim āha tattha yāvatikā ati yattakā tadā kira satta jana koṭiyaḥ sāvatthiyam  paṭivasanti tam sandhāya bhagavā kīvabahukāḥ pana visākhe sāvatthiyāḥ manussāḥ devasikam
translated: to have as many as” and so on. Therein, as many as: as many as there are. At that time, it seems, seven koṭis of people were living in Sāvatthi.

original: kālaṃ karontī”ti pucchi. Visākhā “dasapi, bhante”tiādimāha. Tattha tīṇīti tayo. Ayameva
analyzed: kālam karonti iti visākhā bhante itiādim āha tattha tīṇi iti ayam eva
translated: With reference to them the Blessed One asked: “But how many, Visākhā, are the people in Sāvatthi who die daily?” Visākhā said: “Ten, venerable sir,” and so on. Therein, three: three. This is the reading.

original: vā pāṭho. Avivittāti asuññā.
analyzed: vā pāṭhaḥ a vivittā ati asuññā
translated: Not deserted: not empty.

original: Atha bhagavā attano adhippāyaṃ pakāsento “api nu tvaṃ kadāci karahaci anallavatthā
analyzed: atha bhagavā attanaḥ adhippāyam pakāsentaḥ api nu tvam kadāci karahaci
translated: Then the Blessed One, revealing his own intention, said: “But would you ever be without a lower garment

original: vā bhaveyyāsi anallakesā vā”ti āha. Nanu evaṃ sante tayā sabbakālaṃ sokābhibhūtāya
analyzed: vā bhaveyyāsi analla kesā vā iti āha nanu evam sante tayā sabbakālam soka abhibhūtāya
translated: or without an upper garment?” Would you not be overcome by sorrow all the time if that were so?

original: matānaṃ puttādīnaṃ amaṅgalūpacāravasena udakorohaṇena allavatthāya allakesāya eva
analyzed: matānam putta ādīnam amaṅgala upacāra vasena uda korohaṇena allavatthāya allakesāya eva
translated: He shows that it is necessary to be wet-garmented and wet-clothed by the wetting of the water-offering in the manner of the performance of the inauspicious rite for the sake of his own children and so on.

original: bhavitabbanti dasseti. Taṃ sutvā upāsikā saṃvegajātā “no hetaṃ, bhante”ti paṭikkhipitvā
analyzed: bhavitabbanti dasseti tam sutvā upāsikā saṃvega jātā no ha etam bhante ti paṭikkhipitvā
translated: Having heard that, the lay devotee, being agitated, said, “No, indeed, Venerable Sir,” and having rejected it,

original: piyavatthuṃ vippaṭisārato attano cittassa nivattabhāvaṃ satthu ārocentī “alaṃ me,
analyzed: piya vatthum vippaṭisārataḥ attano cittassa nivatta bhāvam satthu ārocentī alam me
translated: she informed the Teacher of the state of her mind, which had turned back from regret, saying, “Enough, Venerable Sir,

original: bhante, tāvabahukehi puttehi ca nattārehi cā”ti āha.
analyzed: bhante tāva bahukehi puttehi ca nattārehi ca ati āha
translated: with so many children and grandchildren.”

original: Athassā bhagavā “dukkhaṃ nāmetaṃ piyavatthunimittaṃ, yattakāni piyavatthūni, tattakāni
analyzed: athassā bhagavā dukkham nāma etam piya vatthu nimittam yattakāni piya vatthūni tattakāni
translated: Then the Blessed One, saying, “This is not a pleasant thing, namely, that which is the cause of the object of affection, as many as there are objects of affection, so many are the sorrows.

original: dukkhāni. Tasmā sukhakāmena dukkhappaṭikūlena sabbaso piyavatthuto cittaṃ vivecetabba”nti
analyzed: dukkhāni tasmā sukha kāmena dukkha ppaṭikūlena sabbasas piya vatthutaḥ cittam vivecetabbanti
translated: Therefore, one who desires happiness, who is averse to suffering, should completely separate the mind from the objects of affection,”

original: dhammaṃ desento “yesaṃ kho visākhe sataṃ piyāni, sataṃ tesaṃ dukkhānī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: dhammaṃ desento yesam kho visākhe satam piyāni satam tesam dukkhāni iti ādim āha
translated: he spoke the Dhamma, saying, “Visākhā, for those who have a hundred objects of affection, there are a hundred sorrows,” and so on.

original: Tattha sataṃ piyānīti sataṃ piyāyitabbavatthūni. “Sataṃ piya”ntipi keci paṭhanti.
analyzed: tattha satam piyāni iti satam piyāyitabba vatthūni satam piyanti pi keci paṭhanti
translated: Herein, a hundred objects of affection means a hundred things that should be loved. “A hundred objects of affection” is also read.

original: Ettha ca yasmā ekato paṭṭhāya yāva dasa, tāva saṅkhyā saṅkhyeyyappadhānā, tasmā “yesaṃ🔽dasa piyāni, dasa tesaṃ dukkhānī”tiādinā pāḷi āgatā. Keci pana “yesaṃ dasa piyānaṃ,
analyzed: ettha ca yasmai ekatas paṭṭhāya yāva dasa tāva saṅkhyā saṅkhyeyya padhānā tasmai  dasa piyāni dasa tesam dukkhāni iti ādinā āgatā keci pana yesam dasa piyānam
translated: And here, since the reckoning is the pre-eminent thing from the one onwards up to the ten, the text of the sutta is stated thus: “Yesam dasa piyāni, dasa tesam dukkhāni. ”

original: dasa nesaṃ dukkhāna”ntiādinā paṭhanti, taṃ na sundaraṃ. Yasmā pana vīsatito paṭṭhāya🔽yāva sataṃ, tāva saṅkhyā saṅkhyeyyappadhānāva, tasmā tatthāpi saṅkhyeyyappadhānataṃyeva
analyzed: dasa nesam dukkhānaṃ ti ādinā paṭhanti tam na sundaram yasmā pana vīsatitaḥ paṭṭhāya  yāva tau saṅkhyā saṅkhyeyya padhānau tasmā
translated: But some read it thus: “Yesam dasa piyānaṃ, dasa nesaṃ dukkhāni,” which is not good.

original: gahetvā “yesaṃ kho visākhe sataṃ piyāni, sataṃ tesaṃ dukkhānī”tiādinā pāḷi āgatā.
analyzed: gahetvā yesam kho visākhe satam piyāni satam tesam dukkhāni iti ādinā āgatā
translated: But since the reckoning is the pre-eminent thing from the twenty onwards up to the hundred, the text of the sutta is stated thus: “Yesam kho visākhe sataṃ piyāni, sataṃ tesam dukkhāni. ”

original: Sabbesampi ca “yesaṃ ekaṃ piyaṃ, ekaṃ tesaṃ dukkha”nti pāṭho, na pana dukkhassāti.
analyzed: sabbesam pi ca yesam ekam piyam ekam tesam dukkham ti pāṭhaḥ na pana dukkhassa ati
translated: And in all cases the reading is “Yesam ekaṃ piyaṃ, ekaṃ tesam dukkhaṃ,” and not “dukkhassa.”

original: Etasmiñhi pakkhe ekarasā ekajjhāsayā ca bhagavato desanā hoti. Tasmā yathāvuttanayāva pāḷi veditabbā.
analyzed: etasmin hi pakkhe ekarasā ekajjhāsayā ca bhagavataḥ desanā hoti tasmā yathā vutta nayā ava pāḷi veditabbā
translated: For in this case the Blessed One’s teaching is of one taste, of one flavour. Therefore the text of the sutta should be understood in the way stated.

original: Etamatthaṃ viditvā sokaparidevādikaṃ cetasikaṃ kāyikañca dukkhaṃ piyavatthunimittaṃ
analyzed: etam attham viditvā soka parideva ādikam cetasikam kāyikam ca dukkham piya vatthu nimittam
translated: Having known this meaning, the mental and physical suffering of sorrow, lamentation, etc., which has as its object a loved object,

original: piyavatthumhi sati hoti, asati na hotīti etamatthaṃ sabbākārato jānitvā tadatthaparidīpanaṃ
analyzed: piya vatthumhi sati hoti asati na hoti iti etam attham sabba ākārataḥ jānitvā tad attha paridīpanam
translated: When there is a lovable object, there is love, and when there is not, there is not. Having known the meaning of this in all its aspects, he demonstrates that meaning.

original: imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: imam udānam udānesi
translated: When there is a loved object, grief is; when there is not, it is not. Having known the meaning in all ways, he uttered this utterance in order to teach that meaning.

original: Tassattho – ñātibhogarogasīladiṭṭhibyasanehi phuṭṭhassa anto nijjhāyantassa bālassa
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ ñāti bhoga roga sīla diṭṭhi byasanehi phuṭṭhassa antaḥ nijjhāyantassa bālassa
translated: Its meaning is this. For a fool who is affected by the loss of relatives, property, health, virtue, or view, who broods on it,

original: cittasantāpalakkhaṇā ye keci mudumajjhādibhedena yādisā tādisā sokā vā tehiyeva phuṭṭhassa
analyzed: citta santāpa lakkhaṇāḥ ye keci mudu majjha ādi bhedena yādisā tādisā sokā vā tehiyā iva phuṭṭhassa
translated: whatever grief there is, of whatever kind, classed as mild, medium, etc.,

original: sokuddehakasamuṭṭhāpitavacīvippalāpalakkhaṇā paridevitā vā aniṭṭhaphoṭṭhabbapaṭihatakāyassa🔽kāyapīḷanalakkhaṇā dukkhā vā tathā avuttatthassa vikappanatthena vāsaddena gahitā
analyzed: soka uddehaka samuṭṭhāpita vacī vippalāpa lakkhaṇā paridevitā vā aniṭṭha phoṭṭhabba paṭihata kāyassa  kāya pīḷana lakkhaṇā dukkhā vā tathā a vutta tthassa vikappana tthena vā saddena gahitā
translated: or whatever lamenting there is, which is characterized by the aimless prattle of speech produced by the impact of grief,

original: domanassūpāyāsādayo vā nissayabhedena ca anekarūpā nānāvidhā imasmiṃ sattaloke dissanti
analyzed: domanassūpāyāsa ādayaḥ vā nissaya bhedena ca aneka rūpāḥ nānāvidhāḥ imasmin satta loke dissanti
translated: or whatever pain there is, which is characterized by bodily affliction produced by the impact of what is not wanted, or whatever grief, sorrow, pain, despair, and other mental fever there is, which is classed as of many kinds according to the different bases, and is described as “ manifold,”🔽all this is seen, is found, in this world of living beings,

original: upalabbhanti, sabbepi ete piyaṃ piyajātikaṃ sattaṃ saṅkhārañca paṭicca nissāya āgamma
analyzed: upalabbhanti sabbe pi ete piyam piya jātikam sattam saṅkhārañca paṭicca nissāya āgamma
translated: because of a loved object, because of a being and a formation that is loved.

original: paccayaṃ katvā pabhavanti nibbattanti. Tasmiṃ pana yathāvutte piyavatthumhi piye🔽asante piyabhāvakare chandarāge pahīne na kadācipi ete bhavanti. Vuttañhetaṃ – “piyato🔽jāyatī soko…pe… pemato jāyatī soko”ti ca ādi. Tathā “piyappabhūtā kalahā vivādā,🔽paridevasokā sahamaccharehī”ti ca ādi. Ettha ca “paridevitā vā dukkhā vā”ti liṅgavipallāsena
analyzed: paccayam katvā pabhavanti nibbattanti tasmin pana yathā vutte piya vatthumhi piye  asante piya bhāva kare chanda rāge pahīne na kadāci pi ete bhavanti vuttam ha etam piyato  jāyatī soka upe ca ādi tathā kalahā vivādā  ca ādi ettha ca paridevitā vā dukkhā vā ati liṅga vipallāsena
translated: and they do not arise when the object of affection is not there and the desire and lust that cause affection are abandoned. For this is said: “Sorrow arises from the dear and beloved” , and so on, and: “From the dear and beloved, quarrels, disputes, and contentions, lamentations, sorrow and suffering are born” . And here the words “lamentation and suffering” are in the locative case.🔽

original: vuttaṃ, “paridevitāni vā dukkhāni vā”ti vattabbe vibhattilopo vā katoti veditabbo.🔽Tasmā hi te sukhino vītasokāti yasmā piyappabhūtā sokādayo yesaṃ natthi, tasmā te🔽eva sukhino vītasokā nāma. Ke pana te? Yesaṃ piyaṃ natthi kuhiñci loke yesaṃ ariyānaṃ
analyzed: vuttam paridevitāni vā dukkhāni vā iti vattabbe vibhatti lopaḥ vā kataḥ ti veditabbaḥ  tasmā hi te sukhinaḥ vīta sokā ati yasmā piya ppabhūtā soka ādayaḥ yesam natthi tasmā te  eva sukhinaḥ vīta sokāḥ nāma ke pana te yesam piyam natthi kuhiñci loke yesam ariyānam
translated: They do not occur when the object that is dear is absent, or when the desire and lust for the object that is dear have been abandoned. For this is said: “Sorrow arises from the dear” , etc., and “Sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair arise with the coming of the dear” . And it is said: “From the dear originates strife, From the dear originates fear” . Here the words “sorrow, lamentation” are a metathesis for “sorrow and lamentation” . Or the locative case ending should be regarded as elided in the words “sorrow and lamentation” .🔽“Therefore they are happy and free from sorrow” : because they have no sorrow originating from the dear, etc., they are called “happy” and “free from sorrow” . But who are they?

original: sabbaso vītarāgattā katthacipi sattaloke saṅkhāraloke ca piyaṃ piyabhāvo “putto”ti
analyzed: sabbasas vīta rāga ttā katthacipi satta loke saṅkhāra loke ca piyam piya bhāvo putto ti
translated: “Those who have no dear in the world” : those noble ones who have no dear in any world of beings or in the world of formations, because of their complete absence of lust.🔽“No dear one is found anywhere” .

original: vā “bhātā”ti vā “bhaginī”ti vā “bhariyā”ti vā piyaṃ piyāyanaṃ piyabhāvo natthi, saṅkhāralokepi
analyzed: vā bhātā ati vā bhaginī iti vā bhariyā ati vā piyam piyāyanam piya bhāvaḥ na atthi saṅkhāra loke pi
translated: In the world of formations too,

original: “etaṃ mama santakaṃ, imināhaṃ imaṃ nāma sukhaṃ labhāmi labhissāmī”ti piyaṃ piyāyanaṃ
analyzed: etam mama santakam iminā aham imam nāma sukham labhāmi labhissāmi iti piyam piyāyanam
translated: “This is mine, by this I get this pleasure, I get this pleasure.” There is no affection, no loving-kindness,

original: piyabhāvo natthi. Tasmā asokaṃ virajaṃ patthayāno, piyaṃ na kayirātha kuhiñci loketi
analyzed: piya bhāvaḥ natthi tasmai asokam virajam patthayāno piyam na kayirātha kuhiñci loke iti
translated: no loving-kindness-state. Therefore, desiring the sorrowless, the dust-free, one should not make anything dear anywhere in the world.

original: yasmā ca sukhino nāma vītasokā, vītasokattāva katthacipi visaye piyabhāvo natthi,
analyzed: ca sukhinaḥ nāma vīta sokāḥ katthacipi visaye piya bhāvaḥ natthi
translated: And because those who are happy are indeed sorrowless, and because of being sorrowless, there is no loving-kindness-state anywhere in the world.

original: tasmā attano yathāvuttasokābhāvena ca asokaṃ asokabhāvaṃ rāgarajādivigamanena virajaṃ
analyzed: tasmai yathā vutta soka abhāvena ca asokam asoka bhāvam rāga raja ādi vigamanena virajam
translated: Therefore, by his own sorrowlessness, and by the sorrowless state, by the departure of the dust of passion, etc., and by the dust-free state,

original: virajabhāvaṃ arahattaṃ, sokassa rāgarajādīnañca abhāvahetubhāvato vā “asokaṃ viraja”nti🔽laddhanāmaṃ nibbānaṃ patthayāno kattukamyatākusalacchandassa vasena chandajāto katthaci
analyzed: viraja bhāvam arahattam sokassa rāga raja ādīnam ca abhāva hetu bhāvataḥ vā asokam virajanti  laddha nāmam nibbānam patthayāno kattu kamya tā kusala chandassa vasena chanda jātaḥ katthaci
translated: Nibbāna, which is called “sorrowless” and “dust-free,”🔽desiring to attain, one who is desirous by way of the unwholesome desire to do, should not make anything dear, should not make anything a loving-kindness-state, anywhere in the world,

original: loke rūpādidhamme antamaso samathavipassanādhammepi piyaṃ piyabhāvaṃ viyāyanaṃ na
analyzed: loke rūpa ādi dhamme antamaso samatha vipassanā dhamme pi piyam piya bhāvam viyāyanam na
translated: in the form, etc., states, or even in the states of serenity and insight.

original: kayirātha na uppādeyya. Vuttañhetaṃ – “dhammāpi vo, bhikkhave, pahātabbā, pageva adhammā”ti.
analyzed: na uppādeyya vuttam ha etam dhammā api vaḥ bhikkhave pahātabbā pagā iva adhammā ti
translated: and should not give rise to what has not yet arisen. For this is said: “Ideas, bhikkhus, should be abandoned, to say nothing of un-Dhamma” .

original: Aṭṭhamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽9. Paṭhamadabbasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: aṭṭhama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The eighth sutta is finished.🔽The first Dabba sutta

original: 79. Navame āyasmāti piyavacanaṃ. Dabboti tassa therassa nāmaṃ. Mallaputtoti mallarājassa🔽putto. So hi āyasmā padumuttarassa bhagavato pādamūle katābhinīhāro kappasatasahassaṃ
analyzed: navame piya vacanam dabbo ti tassa therassa nāmam mallaputto ti malla rājassa  putto so hi āyasmā padumuttarassa bhagavato pāda mūle kata abhinīhāraḥ kappa sata sahassam
translated: In the ninth , “the venerable one” is a term of affection. Dabba is the name of that elder. Mallaputta is the son of the king of the Mallas.

original: upacitapuññasañcayo amhākaṃ bhagavato kāle mallarājassa devikā kucchiyaṃ nibbatto
analyzed: upacita puñña sañcayaḥ amhākam bhagavataḥ kāle malla rājassa devikā kucchiyam nibbattaḥ
translated: For this venerable one made his aspiration at the feet of the Blessed One Padumuttara. He was a storehouse of merit accumulated for a hundred thousand aeons. In the time of our Blessed One he was reborn in the womb of the queen of the king of the Mallas.

original: katādhikārattā jātiyā sattavassikakāleyeva mātāpitaro upasaṅkamitvā pabbajjaṃ yāci.
analyzed: kata adhikāra ttā jātiyā satta vassika kāleya iva mātā pitaraḥ upasaṅkamitvā pabbajjam yāci
translated: Because of his previous practice, when he was seven years old he went to his parents and asked for the going forth.

analyzed: te ca pabbajitvā api ācāram tāva sikkhatu sace tam na abhiramissati idha iva āgamissati iti
translated: They said: “Go forth and train in the practice for a while. If you do not like it, you can come back here.”🔽So they gave their consent. He went to the Teacher and asked for the going forth. The Teacher,

analyzed: anujāniṃsu saḥ satthāram upasaṅkamitvā pabbajjam yāci satthā apissa upanissaya sampattim
translated: seeing that he had the requisite of faith,

analyzed: oloketvā pabbajjam anujāni tassa pabbajjā samaye dinnaovādena bhavattayam ādittam  viya upaṭṭhāsi saḥ vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā khuraggeya iva arahattam pāpuṇi yaṃkiñci
translated: and gave him permission to go forth. At the time of his going forth he was given a talk on the Dhamma, and he became established in the fruition of stream-entry. He then set about developing insight, and on the very same day he reached Arahantship.

original: sāvakena pattabbaṃ, “tisso vijjā catasso paṭisambhidā chaḷabhiññā nava lokuttaradhammā”ti
analyzed: sāvakena pattabbam tissaḥ vijjāḥ catasso paṭisambhidāḥ chaḍ abhiññāḥ nava lokuttara dhammā ati
translated: and he gave him the going-forth. At the time of his going-forth he was given advice, and he became established in the three knowledges like a fire that has been lit. He set about insight, and on the very same seat he reached Arahantship. Whatever is to be reached by a disciple, the three knowledges, the four discriminations, the six direct knowledges, the nine supramundane states, and so on,

original: evamādikaṃ sabbaṃ adhigantvā asītiyā mahāsāvakesu abbhantaro ahosi. Vuttañhetaṃ tena āyasmatā –
analyzed: evamādikam sabbam adhigantvā asītiyā mahāsāvakesu abbhantaraḥ ahosi vuttam ha etam tena āyasmatā

analyzed: mayā kho jātiyā satta vassena arahattam sacchikatam yaṃ kiñci sāvakena pattabbam sabbam tat an uppattam mayā atiādi
translated: “When I was seven years old I realized Arahantship. Whatever is to be reached by a disciple, all that has been reached by me.”

analyzed: piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ bhagavataḥ vattam dassetvā divāṭṭhānam gantvā udaka kumbhato udakam
translated: after returning from his almsround, after his meal

analyzed: gahetvā pāde pakkhāletvā gattāni sītim katvā camma kkhaṇḍam paññāpetvā nisinnaḥ kāla paricchedam  katvā samāpattim samāpajji atha ayasmai yathākāla paricchedam samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhahitvā
translated: and after washing his feet, he cooled his limbs. Then he sat down,🔽and after determining the time, he attained concentration. Then, when the time he had determined was up,

analyzed: attanaḥ āyu saṅkhāre olokesi tassa te parikkhīṇā katipaya muhuttikā upaṭṭhahiṃsu so
translated: he emerged from concentration and surveyed his life-continuum. He saw that it had only a few hours left.

analyzed: cintesi na kho mā etam pati rūpam yam aham satthu an ārocetvā sabrahmacārīhi ca a viditaḥ
translated: He thought, “It is not proper for me to attain final Nibbāna without informing the Teacher and without taking leave of my fellow monks.

analyzed: idha yathā nisinnaḥ uva parinibbāyissāmi yat nūna aham satthāram upasaṅkamitvā parinibbānam  anujānāpetvā satthu vattam dassetvā sāsanassa niyyānika bhāva dassana attham mayham iddha anubhāvam
translated: Let me go to the Teacher and get his permission to attain final Nibbāna. Let me then show respect to the Teacher, and,

analyzed: vibhāventaḥ ākāse nisīditvā tejodhātum samāpajjitvā parinibbāyeyyam evam sante ye

analyzed: mayi assaddhā appasannā tesam pi pasādaḥ uppajjissati tat assa tesam dīgharattam hitāya

original: sukhāyā”ti. Evañca so āyasmā cintetvā bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā sabbaṃ taṃ tatheva
analyzed: sukhāya ati evañca saḥ āyasmā cintetvā bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā sabbam tam tathā iva

analyzed: tena vuttam atha kho āyasmā dabbaḥ malla putto yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami itiādi

translated: But some say that

analyzed: na tāva theraḥ jiṇṇaḥ na ca gilānaḥ parinibbānāya ca satthāram āpucchati kim tattha

analyzed: kāraṇam mettiya bhūmajakāḥ bhikkhū pubbe mama amūlakena pārājikena an uddhaṃsesuṃ

analyzed: tasmā aham idānā iva parinibbāyissāmi iti sanniṭṭhānam katvā satthāram āpucchi iti tam

analyzed: akāraṇam na hi khīṇa āsavāḥ a parikkhīṇe āyu saṅkhāre paresam upavāda ādi bhayena parinibbānāya  cetenti ghaṭayanti vā āyamanti na ca paresam pasaṃsā ādi hetu ciram tiṭṭhanti atha kho
translated: This is not the reason. For those whose cankers are destroyed do not attain final Nibbāna through fear of others’ censure, etc.,

analyzed: na abhikaṅkhāmi maraṇam na abhikaṅkhāmi jīvitam

analyzed: ca tesu ekaccānam mahantam kāruññam ahosi ekacce ārodana pattāḥ ahesum athassa  bhagavā citta ācāram ñatvā tena hi dabba mayham bhikkhu saṅghassa ca iddhi pāṭihāriyam
